translated: The word yaṃ is substituted for the smiṃ of the other words, or āyādeso is substituted. Kaññāyaṃ, kaññāya, kaññāsu.

original: Evamaññepi –
analyzed: evam aññe pi
translated: In the same way in the other words:

original: Saddhā medhā paññā vijjā, cintā mantā vīṇā taṇhā;
analyzed: saddhā medhā paññā vijjā cintā mantā vīṇā taṇhā
translated: Saddhā, medhā, paññā, vijjā, cintā, mantā, vīṇā, taṇhā,

original: Icchā mucchā ejā māyā, mettā mattā sikkhā bhikkhā.
analyzed: icchā mucchā ejā māyā mettā mattā sikkhā bhikkhā
translated: icchā, mucchā, ejā, māyā, mettā, mattā, sikkhā, bhikkhā,

original: Jaṅghā gīvā jivhā vācā,
analyzed: jaṅghā gīvā jivhā vācā
translated: jaṅghā, gīvā, jivhā, vācā,

original: Chāyā āsā gaṅgā nāvā;🔽Gāthā senā lekhā sālā,
analyzed: chāyā āsā gaṅgā nāvā  gāthā senā lekhā sālā
translated: Shade, hope, Ganges, boat,🔽Verse, army, line, hall,

original: Mālā velā pūjā khiḍḍā.
analyzed: mālā velā pūjā khiḍḍā
translated: Garland, time, worship, play.

original: Pipāsā vedanā saññā, cetanā tasiṇā pajā;
analyzed: pipāsā vedanā saññā cetanā tasiṇā pajā
translated: Thirst, feeling, perception, volition, meditation, people,

original: Devatā vaṭṭakā godhā, balākā parisā sabhā.🔽Ūkāsephālikā laṅkā, salākā vālikā sikhā;
analyzed: devatā vaṭṭakā godhā balākā parisā sabhā  ūkā sephālikā laṅkā salākā vālikā sikhā
translated: Deities, circle, crocodile, heron, assembly, council.🔽Owl, arrow, Lanka, voting ticket, sand, flame,

original: Visākhā visikhā sākhā, vacā vañjhā jaṭā ghaṭā.🔽Jeṭṭhā soṇḍā vitaṇḍā ca, karuṇā vanitā latā;
analyzed: visākhā visikhā sākhā vacā vañjhā jaṭā ghaṭā  jeṭṭhā soṇḍā vitaṇḍā ca karuṇā vanitā latā
translated: Visākhā, flame, branch, speech, barren, matted hair, pot.🔽Eldest, beak, and dispute, and compassion, woman, creeper,

original: Kathā niddā sudhā rādhā, vāsanā siṃsapā papā.
analyzed: kathā niddā sudhā rādhā vāsanā siṃsapā papā
translated: Story, sleep, nectar, Rādhikā, perfume, bamboo, stump.

original: Pabhā sīmā khamā jāyā,🔽Khattiyā sakkharā surā;
analyzed: pabhā sīmā khamā jāyā  khattiyā sakkharā surā
translated: Light, boundary, forgiveness, wife,

original: Dolā tulā silā līlā,
analyzed: dolā tulā silā līlā
translated: Noble, gravel, liquor,🔽Swing, balance, stone, sport,

original: Lāle’lā mekhalā kalā.🔽Vaḷavā’lambusā mūsā, mañjūsā sulasā disā;
analyzed: vaḷavā alambusā mūsā mañjūsā sulasā disā
translated: Love, necklace, art.🔽Donkey, cucumber, mouse,🔽Sweet-voiced, easy to live with, direction,🔽Nose, rainy season, cave, desire,

original: Nāsā juṇhā guhā īhā, lasikā vasudhādayo.
analyzed: nāsā juṇhā guhā īhā lasikā vasudhā ādayaḥ
translated: Fat, earth, etc.

original: Ammādīnaṃ ālapaneva rūpabhedo. Ammā, ammā ammāyo.
analyzed: rūpa bhedaḥ
translated: The division of nouns is like the addressing of mother, etc. Mother, mother, mothers.

original: Gassa “ghate cā”ti ekāre sampatte –
analyzed: gassa gha te ca a ti ekāre sampatte
translated: When the singular “ghate ca” is reached,

original: 181. Na ammādito.
analyzed: na am m ā t itaḥ
translated: Not from mother, etc.

original: Ammā annāiccevamādito parassa gassa ālapanekavacanassa na ekārattaṃ hoti. “Ākāro vā”ti rassattaṃ.🔽Bhoti amma bhoti ammā, bhotiyo ammā ammāyo. Evaṃ annā, annā annāyo, bhoti anna bhoti
analyzed: am mā anna a it ca ivamāditaḥ parassa gassa ālapana ekavacanassa na ekārattam hoti ākāraḥ vāti  bhoti amma bhoti ammāḥ bhotiyaḥ ammāḥ ammāyaḥ evam annāḥ annāḥ annāyaḥ bhoti anna bhoti
translated: “Ammā, annā” is the singular form of the vocative case ending in -a.🔽“Bhoti amma, bhoti ammā, bhotiyo ammā, ammāyo” is the dual form of the vocative case ending in -a.🔽“Evaṃ annā, annā annāyo, bhoti anna, bhoti annā, bhotiyo annā, annāyo” is the dual form of the vocative case ending in -a.

original: annā, bhotiyo annā annāyo. Ambā, ambā ambāyo, bhoti amba bhoti ambā, bhotiyo ambā ambāyo iccādi.
analyzed: annāḥ bhotiyaḥ annāḥ annāyaḥ ambāḥ ambāḥ ambāyaḥ bhoti amba bhoti ambāḥ bhotiyaḥ ambāḥ ambāyaḥ iccādi
translated: “Ambā, ambā, ambāyo, bhoti amba, bhoti ambā, bhotiyo ambā, ambāyo” is the dual form of the vocative case ending in -a.

original: Ākārantaṃ.🔽Ikāranto itthiliṅgo rattisaddo;
analyzed: ākāra antam  ikāra antaḥ itthi liṅgaḥ ratti saddaḥ
translated: The vocative case ending in -a is complete.🔽The feminine noun “ratti” has the stem “ratti” and the base “ratti”.

original: Tatheva syādyuppatti, silopo, ratti.
analyzed: tathā iva si lopaḥ
translated: The feminine noun “ratti” has the same formation as the feminine noun “silā”.

original: Bahuvacane “saññā, ivaṇṇuvaṇṇā”ti ca vattate.🔽182. Te itthikhyā po.🔽Itthiyā ākhyā saññā itthikhyā, liṅgassantā te ivaṇṇuvaṇṇā yadā itthikhyā, tadā pasaññā
analyzed: bahuvacane saññā ca vattate  te itthi khyā paḥ  itthiyā ākhyā saññā itthi khyā liṅga ssantā te yadā itthi khyā tadā pasaññā
translated: In the plural, the feminine noun “ratti” is declined as “saññā, ivaṇṇuvaṇṇā”.🔽The feminine noun “ratti” has the same formation as the feminine noun “silā”.🔽When the feminine noun “ratti” is in the vocative case, the vocative case ending in -a is elided by the grammatical convention “ghapato ca”.

original: hontīti pasaññāyaṃ “ghapato cā”tiādinā yolopo, “yosu kata”iccādinā dīgho. Rattī rattiyo
analyzed: honti iti ca ati ādinā yo lopaḥ yosu dīghaḥ
translated: The feminine noun “ratti” is declined as “ratti, rattī, rattiyo”.🔽The vocative case ending in -a is elided by the grammatical convention “ghapato ca”.🔽The feminine noun “ratti” is declined as “ratti, rattī, rattiyo”.🔽The vocative case ending in -a is elided by the grammatical convention “ghapato ca”.

original: ratyo vā, he ratti, he rattī he rattiyo.
analyzed: ratyaḥ vā he ratti he rattī he
translated: The feminine noun “ratti” is declined as “ratti, rattī, rattiyo”.🔽The vocative case ending in -a is elided by the grammatical convention “ghapato ca”.

original: “Aṃmo”tiādinā niggahītaṃ, rattiṃ, rattī rattiyo;
analyzed: aṃmo ti ādinā niggahītam
translated: The feminine noun “ratti” is declined as “ratti, rattī, rattiyo”.

original: Tatiyādīsu “ekavacanānaṃ, nādīna”nti ca vattate.
analyzed: tatiyā ādīsu ekavacanānam ca vattate
translated: The feminine of the feminine.🔽The feminine of the feminine of the singulars of the case-series other than the vocative is elided, like the feminine of the feminine of the vocative. Of the night, by the nights, with the nights, for the night, of the nights, of the nights.

original: 183. Pato yā.
analyzed: pa taḥ yā
translated: In the fifth case:

original: Pasaññato ivaṇṇuvaṇṇehi paresaṃ nādīnamekavacanānaṃ vibhattigaṇānaṃ yāādeso hoti. Rattiyā, rattīhi rattībhi rattihi rattibhi, rattiyā, rattīnaṃ rattinaṃ.
analyzed: pa saññataḥ i va ṇ u vaṇṇehi paresam na ādīnam ekavacanānam vibhatti gaṇānam yā ādesaḥ hoti rattiyā rattīhi rattībhi rattihi rattibhi rattiyā rattīnam rattinam
translated: The feminine of the feminine of the singulars of the case-series other than the vocative is elided, like the feminine of the feminine of the vocative. Of the night, by the nights, with the nights, for the night, of the nights, of the nights.

original: Pañcamiyaṃ –🔽184. Amā pato smiṃsmānaṃ vā.
analyzed: pañcamiyam  amā patoḥ smiṃsmānam vā
translated: In the fifth case:🔽The feminine of the feminine of the singulars of the case-series other than the vocative is elided, like the feminine of the feminine of the vocative. Of the night, by the nights, with the nights, for the night, of the nights, of the nights.🔽In the fifth case:

original: Paiccetasmā paresaṃ smiṃ smāiccetesaṃ yathākkamaṃ aṃ āādesā honti vā. Vavatthitavibhāsatthoyaṃ vāsaddo, tena uvaṇṇantato na honti, ivaṇṇantatopi yathāpayogaṃ.
analyzed: paresam smim sma ai c ca itesam yathākkamam aṃ ā ādesāḥ honti vā vavatthita vibhāsa atthaḥ yam vā saddaḥ tena na honti yathā apayogam
translated: The feminine of the feminine of the singulars of the case-series other than the vocative is elided, like the feminine of the feminine of the vocative. Of the night, by the nights, with the nights, for the night, of the nights, of the nights.🔽In the fifth case:

original: “Sare, yakāro”ti ca vattate, sīhamaṇḍūkagatīhi yovacanekavacanaggahaṇañca.
analyzed: sare yakāra uti ca vattate sīha maṇḍūka gatīhi yo vacana ekavacana ggahaṇam ca
translated: The feminine of the feminine of the singulars of the case-series other than the vocative is elided, like the feminine of the feminine of the vocative. Of the night, by the nights, with the nights, for the night, of the nights, of the nights.

original: 185. Pasaññassa ca.
analyzed: pasaññassa ca
translated: In the fifth case:

original: Pasaññassa ivaṇṇassa yovacanekavacanavibhattīnamādese sare pare yakāro hoti. Ettha
analyzed: pa saññassa i va ṇṇassa yo vacana ekavacana vibhattīnam ādese sare pare yakāraḥ hoti ettha
translated: The feminine of the feminine of the singulars of the case-series other than the vocative is elided, like the feminine of the feminine of the vocative. Of the night, by the nights, with the nights, for the night, of the nights, of the nights.🔽In the fifth case:

original: ca yakārassevādhikārato pasaññaggahaṇena ivaṇṇova gayhati, caggahaṇaṃ “ratto”tiādīsu
analyzed: ca yakārassa iva adhikārataḥ pasañña ggahaṇena ca ggahaṇam ratta uti ādīsu
translated: The feminine of the feminine of the singulars of the case-series other than the vocative is elided, like the feminine of the feminine of the vocative. Of the night, by the nights, with the nights, for the night, of the nights, of the nights.🔽In the fifth case:🔽The feminine of the feminine of the singulars of the case-series other than the vocative is elided, like the feminine of the feminine of the vocative

original: nivattanatthaṃ. Ratyā rattiyā, rattīhi rattībhi rattihi rattibhi, rattiyā, rattīnaṃ
analyzed: nivattana attham ratyā rattiyā rattīhi rattībhi rattihi rattibhi rattiyā rattīnam
translated: For the purpose of the negative. In the locative case: ratyā rattiyā, rattīhi rattībhi rattihi rattibhi, rattiyā, rattīnaṃ

original: rattinaṃ. Smiṃvacane amādesayakārādesā, ratyaṃ. “Ghapato smiṃ yaṃ vā”ti yaṃādeso, rattiyaṃ.
analyzed: rattinam smin vacane am ādesa yakāra ādesāḥ ratyam gha patoḥ smin yam vāti yaṃ ādesaḥ rattiyam
translated: rattinaṃ. In the locative singular: ratyaṃ. “Ghapato smiṃ yaṃ vā” (Pā. 1.3.65) thus yaṃādesa. Rattiyaṃ.

original: Aññattha “aṃ, smiṃ, vā”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: aññattha aṃ smin vāti ca vattate
translated: “Aṃ, smiṃ, vā” (Pā. 1.3.64) is used in other places.

original: 186. Ādito o ca.
analyzed: ā t itaḥ o ca
translated: . O at the beginning.

original: Ādiiccetasmā smiṃvacanassa aṃ oādesā honti vā. Casaddena aññasmāpi ā aṃ oādesā. Ratyā rattiṃ ratto rattiyā, rattīsu rattisu.
analyzed: ādi i c ca itasmā smiṃvacanassa aṃ o ādesā honti vā ca saddena aññasma api ā aṃ o ādesā ratyā rattim ratto rattiyā rattīsu rattisu
translated: “Ādito o ca” (Pā. 1.3.63) thus aṃ and o are the ādesas of the locative singular. By the word ca, ā, aṃ, o are the ādesas of other cases too. Ratyā rattiṃ ratto rattiyā, rattīsu rattisu.

original: Evamaññānipi –
analyzed: evam aññāni pi
translated: So also the following:

original: Patti yutti vutti kitti, mutti titti khanti kanti;
analyzed: patti yutti vutti kitti mutti titti khanti kanti
translated: Patti, yutti, vutti, kitti, mutti, titti, khanti, kanti;

original: Santi tanti siddhi suddhi, iddhi vuddhi buddhi bodhi.
analyzed: santi tanti siddhi suddhi iddhi vuddhi buddhi bodhi
translated: Santi, tanti, siddhi, suddhi, iddhi, vuddhi, buddhi, bodhi.

original: Bhūmi jāti pīti sūti, nandi sandhi sāṇi koṭi;
analyzed: bhūmi jāti pīti sūti nandi sandhi sāṇi koṭi
translated: Bhūmi, jāti, pīti, sūti, nandi, sandhi, sāṇi, koṭi;

original: Diṭṭhi vuḍḍhi tuṭṭhi yaṭṭhi, pāḷi āḷi nāḷi keḷi;
analyzed: diṭṭhi vuḍḍhi tuṭṭhi yaṭṭhi pāḷi āḷi nāḷi keḷi
translated: Diṭṭhi, vuḍḍhi, tuṭṭhi, yaṭṭhi, pāḷi, āḷi, nāḷi, keḷi;

original: Sati mati gati cuti, dhiti yuvati vikati.
analyzed: sati mati gati cuti dhiti yuvati vikati
translated: Sati, mati, gati, cuti, dhiti, yuvati, vikati.

original: Rati ruci rasmi asani vasani osadhi aṅguli dhūli dundubhi doṇi aṭavi chavi ādīni ikārantanāmāni.
analyzed: rati ruci rasmi asani vasani osadhi aṅguli dhūli dundubhi doṇi aṭavi chavi ādīni ikāra anta nāmāni
translated: Rati, ruci, rasmi, asani, vasani, osadhi, aṅguli, dhūli, dundubhi, doṇi, aṭavi, chavi, etc., are feminine nouns ending in i.

original: Ikārantaṃ.🔽Īkāranto itthiliṅgo itthīsaddo;
analyzed: ikāra antam  īkāra antaḥ itthi liṅgaḥ itthī saddaḥ
translated: Feminine nouns ending in i.🔽The feminine word itthi, a woman, is feminine.

original: “Ittha”itīdha “itthiyaṃ, paccayo”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: itthā eti idha itthiyam ca vattate
translated: “Itthi” is used in the sense of “a woman” and “a condition.”

original: 187. Nadādito vā ī.
analyzed: nad ād itaḥ vā ī
translated: Or it is ī from nadā.

original: Nadādito vā anadādito vā itthiyaṃ vattamānā liṅgamhā īppaccayo hoti. Vāggahaṇamanadādisampiṇḍanatthaṃ, tena puthugavādito ca ī.
analyzed: nad āditaḥ vā a nad āditaḥ vā itthiyam vattamānā liṅgamhā īp paccayaḥ hoti vāc gahaṇam a nad ādi sampiṇḍana attham tena puthugava āditaḥ ca ī
translated: Or it is ī from nadā or from non-nadā, when it is used in the sense of a woman. The word “or” is for the purpose of including non-nadā, etc. Therefore, it is also ī from puthu, etc.

original: Saralope “kvacāsavaṇṇaṃ lutte”ti asavaṇṇe sampatte pakatibhāvo nāmabyapadeso, syādyuppatti.
analyzed: sara lope asavaṇṇam lutta iti asavaṇṇe sampatte pakati bhāvaḥ nāma byapadesaḥ
translated: In the elision of the first syllable, “kvacāsavaṇṇaṃ lutte” means that when asavaṇṇaṃ is obtained, the name pakatibhāvo is a substitute for the gender, and syādyuppatti occurs.

original: Itthī, itthī “agho rassa”ntiādinā rassattaṃ, itthiyo. Sambodhane “jhalapā rassa”nti
analyzed: itthī itthī aghaḥ rassanti ādinā rassattam itthiyaḥ sambodhane rassanti
translated: Itthi, itthi, “agho rassa” and so on, it becomes short, itthī. In addressing, “jhalapā rassa”

original: rassattaṃ. Bhoti itthi, bhotiyo itthī itthiyo.
analyzed: rassattam bhoti itthi bhotiyo itthī itthiyo
translated: it becomes short. Bhoti is a woman, bhotiyo are women, itthi is a woman, itthiyo are women.

original: Dutiyekavacane “ghapato smiṃ yaṃ vā”ti ito “vā”ti vattate.
analyzed: dutiya ikavacane gha patoḥ smin yam vāti itas vāti vattate
translated: In the second singular, “ghapato smiṃ yaṃ vā” means “or” from here.

original: 188. Aṃ yamīto pasaññato.
analyzed: aṃ pasaññataḥ
translated: Aṃ yamīto pasaññato.

original: Pasaññato īkārato parassa aṃvacanassa yaṃ hoti vā. Itthiyaṃ itthiṃ, itthī itthiyo,🔽itthiyā, itthīhi itthībhi, itthiyā, itthīnaṃ, itthiyā, itthīhi itthībhi, itthiyā,
analyzed: pa saññataḥ īkārataḥ parassa aṃvacanassa yam hoti vā itthiyam itthī itthī itthiyo  itthiyā itthīhi itthībhiḥ itthiyā itthīnam itthiyā itthīhi itthībhiḥ itthiyā

original: cā”ti īkārassa yakāro, “yavataṃ talana”iccādinā dyassa jakāro, dvittaṃ. Najjo sandanti, nadiyo.🔽Ettha cevaṃ sijjhantānaṃ najjoādīnaṃ vuttiyaṃ ānattaggahaṇādinā nipphādanaṃ atraja sugatādīnaṃ viya nipphādanūpāyantaradassanatthanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: īkārassa yakāraḥ yavatam tala naicca ādinā dyassa jakāraḥ dvittam najjaḥ sandanti nadiyaḥ  ettha ca ivam sijjhantānam najjo ādīnam vuttiyam ānatta ggahaṇa ādinā nipphādanam sugata ādīnam viya nipphādana upāya antara dassana atthanti daṭṭhabbaṃ

original: He nadi, he nadī he najjo he nadiyo, nadiyaṃ nadiṃ, nadī najjo nadiyo.
analyzed: he nadi he nadī he najjaḥ he nadiyaḥ nadiyam nadim nadī najjaḥ nadiyaḥ
translated: The feminine of the word “woman” is “woman” (itthi).🔽The

original: Amādisutte ā patoti yogavibhāgena kvaci nāsānañcāttaṃ, tena na jaccā vasalo hoti, pathabyā ekarajjenāti ādi ca sijjhati, pure viya yakārajakārādesadvittāni.
analyzed: am ādi sutte ā patoti yogavibhāgena kvaci tena na hoti pathabyā eka rajjena ati ādi ca sijjhati pure
translated: In the Mādisutta, the word ā is found in the form āpato in the sense of “from the nose” by the method of yoking, and therefore the expression “not a low-caste man from birth” and the expression “by a single king of the earth” are established. And the words pure, viya, yakāra, and jakāra are declined in the same way as the word nadi.

original: Najjā kataṃ nadiyā, nadīhi nadībhi, najjā nadiyā, nadīnaṃ, najjā nadiyā, nadīhi nadībhi, najjā nadiyā, nadīnaṃ, najjaṃ nadiyaṃ nadiyā, nadīsu.
analyzed: najjā katam nadiyā nadīhi nadībhiḥ najjā nadiyā nadīnam najjā nadiyā nadīhi nadībhiḥ najjā nadiyā nadīnam najjam nadiyam nadīsu
translated: The river is made by the river, by the rivers, by the river, by the rivers, by the river, by the rivers, by the river, by the rivers, in the river, in the rivers, in the river, in the rivers.

original: Aññepi –
analyzed: aññe pi
translated: And also:

original: Mahī vetaraṇī vāpī, pāṭalī kadalī ghaṭī;
analyzed: mahī vetaraṇī vāpī pāṭalī kadalī ghaṭī
translated: Mahī, vetaraṇī, vāpī, pāṭalī, kadalī, ghaṭī,

original: Nārī kumārī taruṇī, vāruṇī brāhmaṇī sakhī.
analyzed: nārī kumārī taruṇī vāruṇī brāhmaṇī sakhī
translated: Nārī, kumārī, taruṇī, vāruṇī, brāhmaṇī, sakhī,

original: Gandhabbī kinnarī nāgī, devī yakkhī ajī migī;
analyzed: gandhabbī kinnarī nāgī devī yakkhī ajī migī
translated: Gandhabbī, kinnarī, nāgī, devī, yakkhī, ajī, migī,

original: Vānarī sūkarī sīhī, haṃsī kākī ca kukkuṭī –🔽Iccādayo itthīsaddasamā.🔽Tatheva mātulasaddato īppaccaye kate –
analyzed: vānarī sūkarī sīhī haṃsī kākī ca kukkuṭī  i c ca ādayaḥ itthī sad dasamā  tathā iva mātula saddataḥ īp paccaye kate
translated: Vānarī, sūkarī, sīhī, haṃsī, kākī, ca kukkuṭī,🔽And so on are feminine nouns.🔽And likewise, when the word mātulā is declined,

original: 189. Mātulādīnamānattamīkāre.
analyzed: mātula ādīn amānattamīkāre
translated: The words mātulā, etc., are declined like māna.

original: Mātula ayyakavaruṇaiccevamādīnamanto ānattamāpajjate īkāre paccaye pare, antāpekkhāyaṃ chaṭṭhī, saralopādi. Mātulānī, evaṃ ayyakānī, varuṇānī, sesaṃ itthīsaddasamaṃ.
analyzed: mātula ayyaka varuṇa e t ca evamādīnam antaḥ ānattam āpajjate īkāre paccaye pare anta apekkhā ayam chaṭṭhī sara lopa ādi mātulānī evam ayyakānī varuṇānī sesam itthī sadda samam
translated: The ending -ani is added to the words mātula, ayya, varuṇa, etc., when the vowel i is the penultimate syllable, and the final vowel is elided, etc., when the final syllable is looked for. Mātu-lāni, ayya-kāni, varuṇa-kāni. The rest is the same as the feminine word.

original: Anadādīsu puthusaddato īppaccayo. “O sare cā”ti ettha casaddena ukārassa avādeso.🔽Puthavī, puthaviyo. Sasmā smiṃsu puthabyā puthaviyā, puthabyā puthaviyā, puthabyaṃ
analyzed: an ad ādīsu puthu saddataḥ īp paccayaḥ o sare ca ati ettha ca saddena ukārassa a vādesaḥ  puthavī sasmā smiṃsu puthabyā puthaviyā puthabyā puthaviyā puthabyam
translated: In anada, etc., the ending -ī is added to the word puthu. “O and sa are elided” means that the vowel o is elided.

original: puthaviyaṃ puthaviyā iccādi.
analyzed: puthaviyam puthaviyāḥ iccādi
translated: Puthavī, puthaviyo. In the locative case, puthabyā, puthaviyā. In the ablative case, puthabyā, puthaviyā. In the genitive case, puthabyaṃ, puthaviyaṃ, puthaviyā, etc.

original: Gosaddato “nadādito vā ī”ti īppaccayo. Mahāvuttinā vā “gāva se”ti ettha gāvaiti yogavibhāgena vā okārassa āvādeso. Gāvī, gāvī gāviyo iccādi itthīsaddasamaṃ.
analyzed: go saddāt nad āditaḥ vā ī ti īp paccayaḥ mahāvuttinā vā gāva sa iti ettha gāva eti yogavibhāgena vā okārassa āvādesaḥ gāvī gāvī gāviyo iccādi itthī sadda samam
translated: In the word go, the ending -ī is added by the rule “Or by the word nada, etc.” Or by the Mahā-vutti, the vowel o is elided by the rule “Gāva se” or by the division of the compound. Gāvī, gāvī, gāviyo, etc., are the same as the feminine word.

original: “Mānava”itīdha “itthiyaṃ, vā, ī”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: itthiyam vai īti ca vattate
translated: In the word mānava, the ending -ī is added by the rule “In the feminine, or by the word ī.”

original: 190. Ṇava ṇika ṇeyya ṇantuhi.
analyzed: ṇava ṇika ṇeyya ṇantuhi
translated: Ṇava, ṇika, ṇeyya, ṇantuhi.

original: Ṇava ṇika ṇeyya ṇantuppaccayantehi itthiyaṃ vattamānehi liṅgehi īppaccayo hoti. Vādhikāro katthaci nivattanattho, saralopādi. Mānavī, evaṃ nāvikī, venateyyī, gotamī.
analyzed: ṇava ṇika ṇeyya ṇantuppaccayantehi itthiyam vattamānehi liṅgehi īp paccayaḥ hoti vā adhikāraḥ katthaci nivattana atthaḥ sara lopa ādi mānavī evam nāvikī venateyyī gotamī
translated: The feminine forms in -ī are formed by adding ī to the nominative singular in -ant of the nine feminine declensions. The addition is sometimes omitted, and the -r- is elided, etc. Mānavī, nāvikī, venateyyī, gotamī.

original: “Guṇavantu ī”itīdha “vā”ti vattate.
analyzed: guṇavantu vāti vattate
translated: “Guṇavantu ī” means “guṇavatī, etc.”

original: 191. Ntussa tamīkāre.
analyzed: ntus sa tamīkāre
translated: . Ntussa tamīkāre.

original: Sabbasseva ntuppaccayassa takāro hoti vā īkārappaccaye pare, aññattha saralopādi. Guṇavatī, guṇavatī guṇavatiyo, guṇavantī, guṇavantī guṇavantiyo iccādi itthīsaddasamaṃ.
analyzed: sabbassa iva ntup paccayassa takāraḥ hoti vā īkāra ppaccaye pare aññattha sara lopa ādi guṇavatī guṇavatī guṇavatiyaḥ guṇavantī guṇavantī guṇavantiyaḥ iccādi itthī sadda samam
translated: The -nt- of all the nine feminine declensions is changed to -t- or -t- is added, before the ending in -ī, etc. Guṇavatī, guṇavatī, guṇavatiyo, guṇavantī, guṇavantī, guṇavantiyo, etc. are the same as the feminine forms in -ī.

original: Evaṃ kulavatī, sīlavatī, yasavatī, rūpavatī, satimatī, gottamatī.
analyzed: evam kulavatī sīlavatī yasavatī rūpavatī satimatī gottamatī
translated: Similarly, kulavatī, sīlavatī, yasavatī, rūpavatī, satimatī, gottamatī.

original: Mahantasaddato “nadādito vā ī”ti īppaccayo, ntubyapadeso vikappena takārādeso. Mahatī mahantī.
analyzed: mahanta saddataḥ nad āditaḥ vā ī ti īp paccayaḥ n tu byapadesaḥ vikappena takāra ādesaḥ mahatī mahantī
translated: From the word mahantā, the feminine form is mahantī, by adding ī to the nominative singular in -ant, according to the rule “nadādito vā ī”. The -nt- is changed to -t- optionally. Mahatī, mahantī.

original: “Bhavanta ī”itīdha “īkāre”ti vattate.
analyzed: bhavantaḥ ī iti idhaḥ īkāra iti vattate
translated: “Bhavanta ī” means “bhavantī, etc.”

original: 192. Bhavato bhoto.
analyzed: bhavataḥ bhoto
translated: . Bhavato bhoto.

original: Sabbasseva bhavantasaddassa bhotādeso hoti īkāre itthigate pare. Sā bhotī, bhotī bhotiyo, he bhoti, he bhotī bhotiyo iccādi.
analyzed: sabbassa iva bhavanta saddassa bhota ādesaḥ hoti īkāre itthi gate pare sā bhotī bhotī bhotiyaḥ he bhoti he bhotī bhotiyaḥ iccādi
translated: The form bhotā is the base for all the words beginning with bhavaṃ, when the following word begins with i. She is bhotī, bhotī, bhotiyo; he bhoti, he bhotī, bhotiyo, etc.

original: “Bhikkhu” itīdha “itthiya”nti vattate “vā”ti ca.🔽193. Patibhikkhurājīkārantehi inī.
analyzed: bhikkhu iti idha itthiyanti vattate vāti ca  pati bhikkhu rājī kāra antehi inī
translated: Herein, bhikkhu is feminine as it were, and also as it were masculine.🔽Inī after patibhikkhu, rājī, and kāraṇte.

original: Pati bhikkhu rāja iccetehi īkārantehi ca itthiyaṃ vattamānehi liṅgehi inīppaccayo hoti.
analyzed: pati bhikkhu rājaḥ iti ca etehi īkāra antehi ca itthiyam vattamānehi liṅgehi in ip paccayaḥ hoti
translated: The inī affix is formed after patibhikkhu, rājā, and kāraṇte, when these masculine words are used in the feminine.

original: “Saralopo’mādesa”iccādisutte tuggahaṇena kvaci pubbalopassa nisedhanato “vā paro asarūpā”ti saralopo. Bhikkhunī, bhikkhunī bhikkhuniyo iccādi.
analyzed: sara lopa umā desa e c ca ādi sutte tu ggahaṇena kvaci pubba lopassa nisedhanataḥ vā paraḥ asarūpā ati sara lopaḥ bhikkhunī bhikkhunī bhikkhuniyaḥ iccādi
translated: The inī affix is formed after bhikkhu, etc., with elision of the final syllable, according to the rule: “Saralopo mādeso” , etc. The final syllable is elided by the rule: “Vā paro asarūpā” . Bhikkhunī, bhikkhunī, bhikkhuniyo, etc.

original: Gahapatisaddato inī, “atta”miti vattate.
analyzed: gahapati saddataḥ inī attam iti vattate
translated: The inī affix is formed after gahapati, according to the rule: “Atta” .

original: 194. Patissinīmhi.
analyzed: patissinīmhi
translated: Inissinīmhi.

original: Patisaddassa anto attamāpajjate inīppaccaye pare. Tatheva parasare lutte “pubbo cā”ti dīgho, gahapatānī.
analyzed: pati saddassa antaḥ attam āpajjate in ip paccaye pare tathā iva para sare lutte pubbaḥ ca ati dīghaḥ gaha patānī
translated: The inī affix is formed after patis, when the following word begins with a vowel. The vowel is lengthened by the rule: “Pubbo ca” . Gahapatānī.

original: Tatheva rājasaddato inī, saralopapakatibhāvā, rājinī. Īkārantesu daṇḍīsaddato inī, saralopādi, daṇḍinī, daṇḍinī daṇḍiniyo, evaṃ hatthinī, medhāvinī, tapassinī, piyabhāṇinī iccādi.
analyzed: tathā iva inī sara lopa pakati bhāvā rājinī īkāra antesu daṇḍī sara lopa ādi daṇḍinī daṇḍinī daṇḍiniyaḥ evam hatthinī medhāvinī tapassinī piya bhāṇinī iccādi
translated: From daṇḍi, “a staff-bearer,” comes daṇḍinī, “a female staff-bearer,” by the addition of inī, the elision of ra, and so on. Likewise, hatthinī, “a female elephant,” medhāvinī, “a female genius,” tapassinī, “a female ascetic,” piyabhāṇinī, “a female sweet-talker,” and so on.

original: “Pokkharinī” itīdha “tesu vuddhī”tiādinā ikāranakārānaṃ akāraṇakārādesā, pokkharaṇī,
analyzed: pokkharinī iti idha tesu vuddhi iti ādinā ikāra nakārānam akāra a nakāra ādesā pokkharaṇī
translated: In pokkharinī, “a lotus-pond,” the i of tesu vuddhī is changed to a by the rule, and the i of pokkharinī is changed to e by the rule.

original: pokkharaṇī. “Tato yonamo tū”ti sutte tuggahaṇena yonamokāro ca, īkārassa yakāro,
analyzed: pokkharaṇī tatas yonamaḥ tu iti sutte tu ggahaṇena yonama okāraḥ ca īkārassa yakāro
translated: The o of pokkharinī is changed to u by the rule, and the u of pokkharinī is changed to o by the rule.🔽The ṇ of pokkharinī is changed to ñ by the rule, and the ñ of pokkharinī is changed to ṇ by the rule.

original: “yavata”miccādisutte kāraggahaṇena ṇyassa ñakāro, dvittaṃ. Pokkharañño pokkharaṇiyo vā iccādi.🔽Vādhikāro anuttasamuccayattho, tena vidū yakkhāditopi inī, paracittavidunī, saraloparassattāni, paracittavidunī paracittaviduniyo, yakkhinī yakkhiniyo, sīhinī sīhiniyo iccādi.

translated: The ṇ of pokkharinī is changed to ṇa by the rule, and the ṇa of pokkharinī is changed to ṇ by the rule.🔽The ṇ of pokkharinī is changed to ṇa by the rule, and the ṇa of pokkharinī is changed to ṇ by the rule.🔽The ṇ of pokkharinī is changed to ṇa by the rule, and the ṇa of pokkharinī is changed to ṇ by the rule.🔽The ṇ of pokkharinī is changed to ṇa by the rule, and the ṇa of pokkharinī is changed to ṇ by the rule.🔽The ṇ of pokkharinī is changed to ṇa by the rule, and the ṇa of pokkharinī is changed to ṇ by the rule.🔽The ṇ of pokkharinī is changed to ṇa by the rule, and the ṇa of pokkharinī is changed to ṇ by the rule.

original: Īkārantaṃ.🔽Ukāranto itthiliṅgo yāgusaddo.
analyzed: īkāra antam 🔽ukāra antaḥ itthi liṅgaḥ yāgu saddaḥ
translated: The ṇ of pokkharinī is changed to ṇa by the rule, and the ṇa of pokkharinī is changed to

original: Tassa rattisaddasseva rūpanayo. Amādesādiabhāvova viseso.
analyzed: tassa ratti saddassa iva rūpa nayaḥ viseso
translated: The method of derivation is that of the word ratti, and the only difference is that there is no ādesā, etc.

original: Yāgu, yāgū yāguyo, he yāgu, he yāgū yāguyo, yāguṃ, yāgū yāguyo, yāguyā, yāgūhi yāgūbhi
analyzed: yāgu yāgū yāguyaḥ he yāgu he yāgū yāguyaḥ yāgum yāgū yāguyaḥ yāguyā yāgūhi yāgūbhi

original: yāguhi yāgubhi, yāguyā, yāgūnaṃ yāgunaṃ, yāguyā, yāgūhi yāgūbhi yāguhi yāgubhi, yāguyā,
analyzed: yāguhi yāgubhi yāguyā yāgūnam yāgunam yāguyā yāgūhi yāgūbhi yāguhi yāgubhi yāguyā
translated: yāguhi yāgubhi, yāguyā, yāgūnaṃ yāgunaṃ, yāguyā, yāgūhi yāgūbhi yāguhi yāgubhi, yāguyā,

original: yāgūnaṃ yāgunaṃ, yāguyaṃ yāguyā, yāgūsu yāgusu.
analyzed: yāgūnam yāgunam yāguyam yāguyā yāgūsu yāgusu
translated: yāgūnaṃ yāgunaṃ, yāguyaṃ yāguyā, yāgusu yāgusu.

original: Evaṃ dhātu dhenu kāsu daddu kacchu kaṇḍu rajju kareṇu piyaṅgu sassuādīni.
analyzed: evam dhātu dhenu kāsu daddu kacchu kaṇḍu rajju kareṇu piyaṅgu sassu ādīni
translated: So too with dhātu, dhenu, kāsu, daddu, kacchu, kaṇḍu, rajju, kareṇu, piyaṅgu, sassu, and so on.

original: Mātusaddassa bhedo. Tassa pitusaddasseva rūpanayo. “Āratta”miti bhāvaniddesena ārādesābhāve “pato yā”ti yādesova viseso.
analyzed: mātu saddassa bhedo tassa pitu saddassa iva rūpa nayaḥ ārattam iti bhāva niddesena ārā desa abhāve viseso
translated: The difference is that there is no ādesā, etc., and the only difference is that there is yādesā, as in “āratta,” in the method of derivation of the word pitā, which is the same as that of the word mātu.

original: Mātā, mātaro, bhoti māta, bhoti mātā bhotiyo mātaro, mātaraṃ, mātare mātaro, mātarā
analyzed: mātā mātaraḥ bhoti māta bhoti mātā mātaraḥ mātare mātaraḥ
translated: Mātā, mātaro, bhoti māta, bhoti mātā, bhotiyo mātaro, mātaraṃ, mātare mātaro, mātarā

original: mātuyā matyā, “tesu vuddhī”tiādinā ukāralopo, rassattañca. Mātarehi mātarebhi mātūhi
analyzed: mātuyā matyā tesu vuddhi iti ādinā ukāra lopaḥ mātarehi mātarebhi mātūhi
translated: mātuyā matyā, “tesu vuddhī”ti ādinā ukāralopo, rassattañca. Mātarehi mātarebhi mātūhi

original: mātūbhi mātuhi mātubhi, mātu mātussa mātuyā, mātarānaṃ mātānaṃ mātūnaṃ mātunaṃ, mātarā🔽mātuyā, mātarehi mātarebhi mātūhi mātūbhi, mātu mātussa mātuyā, mātarānaṃ mātānaṃ
analyzed: mātūbhi mātuhi mātubhi mātu mātussa mātuyā mātarānam mātānam mātūnam mātunam mātarā  mātuyāḥ mātarehi mātarebhi mātūhi mātūbhi mātu mātuḥ mātuyāḥ mātarānam mātānam
translated: Mothers, mothers, mothers, mother, of a mother, of a mother’s mother, of mothers, of mothers’ mothers, of mothers’ mothers’ mothers, with a mother,🔽of a mother’s mother, of mothers’ mothers, of mothers’ mothers’ mothers, of mothers,🔽with a mother’s mother, with mothers’ mothers, with mothers’ mothers’ mothers, with mothers, mother, of a mother’s mother, of mothers’ mothers,

original: mātūnaṃ mātunaṃ, mātari, mātaresu mātūsu mātusu.
analyzed: mātūnam mātunam mātari mātaresu mātūsu mātusu
translated: of mothers’ mothers’ mothers, of mothers, with a mother’s mother, with mothers’ mothers, with mothers’ mothers’ mothers, with mothers.

original: Evaṃ dhītā, dhītaro, duhitā, duhitaro iccādi.
analyzed: evam dhītāḥ dhītaraḥ duhitāḥ duhitaraḥ iccādi
translated: So too daughter, daughters, daughter, daughters, and so on.

original: Ukārantaṃ.🔽Ūkāranto itthiliṅgo jambūsaddo.
analyzed: ukāra antam  ūkāra antaḥ itthi liṅgaḥ jambu saddaḥ
translated: The feminine noun ending in u.🔽The feminine noun ending in ū is the word for a rose-apple tree.

original: Jambū, jambū jambuyo, he jambu, he jambū jambuyo, jambuṃ, jambū jambuyo iccādi itthīsaddasamaṃ.
analyzed: jambū jambū jambuyaḥ he jambu he jambū jambuyaḥ jambum jambū jambuyaḥ iccādi itthī sadda samam
translated: Rose-apple tree, rose-apple trees, O rose-apple tree, O rose-apple trees, a rose-apple tree, rose-apple trees, and so on, is the same as the feminine word.

original: Evaṃ vadhū ca sarabhū, sarabū sutanū camū;
analyzed: evam vadhū ca sarabhū sarabū su tanū camū
translated: So too a bride, a doe, a female deer, a good-natured woman, an army;

original: Vāmūrū nāganāsūrū, samāni khalu jambuyā.
analyzed: vāmūrū nāga nāsūrū samāni khalu
translated: A woman with beautiful thighs, a woman with a nose like a snake, are the same as a rose-apple tree.

original: Ūkārantaṃ.
analyzed: ūkāra antam
translated: The feminine noun ending in ū.

original: Okāranto itthiliṅgo gosaddo.
analyzed: okāra antaḥ itthi liṅgaḥ go saddaḥ
translated: The feminine noun ending in o is the word for a cow.

original: Tassa pulliṅgagosaddasseva rūpanayo.
analyzed: tassa put liṅga go saddassa iva rūpa nayaḥ
translated: The method of formation of its noun and adjective genders is the same as that of the masculine noun and adjective word for a cow.

original: Kaññā ratti nadī itthī, mātulānī ca bhikkhunī;
analyzed: kaññā ratti nadī itthī mātulānī ca bhikkhunī
translated: A virgin, a night, a river, a woman, a mother’s sister, a bhikkhunī,

original: Daṇḍinī yāgu mātā ca, jambū gotitthisaṅgaho.
analyzed: daṇḍinī yāgu mātā ca jambū go titthi saṅgahaḥ
translated: A woman with a stick, gruel, a mother, is the collection of feminine nouns ending in o.

original: Itthiliṅgaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: itthi liṅgam niṭṭhitam
translated: The feminine noun is finished.

original: Napuṃsakaliṅga
analyzed: napuṃsaka liṅga
translated: The neuter noun

original: Atha napuṃsakaliṅgāni vuccante.
analyzed: atha napuṃsaka liṅgāni vuccante
translated: Now the neuter genders are stated.

original: Akāranto napuṃsakaliṅgo cittasaddo.
analyzed: akāra antaḥ napuṃsaka liṅgaḥ citta saddo
translated: The word citta has a neuter gender without a reason.

original: Pure viya syādyuppatti, “citta si” itīdha –
analyzed: iti idha
translated: As in the past, the origin is “citta si” here,

original: “Napuṃsakehi, ato nicca”nti ca vattate.
analyzed: napuṃsakehi a taḥ niccanti ca vattate
translated: “In the neuter, therefore, always” is stated.

analyzed: siṃ

original: Si, aṃiti dvipadamidaṃ. Akārantehi napuṃsakaliṅgehi parassa sivacanassa aṃ hoti niccaṃ. Saralopapakatibhāvādi, cittaṃ.
analyzed: si aṃ iti dvipadam idam akāra antehi napuṃsaka liṅgehi parassa si vacanassa aṃ hoti niccam sara lopa pakati bhāva ādi cittam
translated: This is a dvanda compound. After the word si of the nominative case, aṃ is always added to neuter words without a reason. The natural state of the vowel sarva is elided, cittaṃ.

original: Bahuvacane “yonaṃ ni napuṃsakehī”ti vattate.
analyzed: bahuvacane ya ūnam ni napuṃsakehi iti vattate
translated: In the plural, “yonaṃ ni napuṃsakehī” is stated.

original: 196. Ato niccaṃ.
analyzed: a taḥ niccam
translated: . Ato niccaṃ.

original: Akārantehi napuṃsakaliṅgehi yonaṃ niccaṃ ni hoti. “Sabbayonīnamāe”ti nissa vā ākāro. Aññattha “yosu kata”iccādinā dīgho. Cittā cittāni.
analyzed: akāra antehi napuṃsaka liṅgehi yonam niccam ni hoti sabba yonīnam āeti nissa vai ākāraḥ aññattha yosu kata e c ca ādinā dīghaḥ cittā cittāni
translated: After neuter words without a reason, ni is always added to yonaṃ. “Sabbayonīnamāe” is the form with ni. Elsewhere, the long vowel is by “yosu kata” and so on. Cittaṃ, cittāni.

original: Yonaṃ nibhāve cāette, siddhepi avisesato;
analyzed: ni bhāve ca ā e tte siddhe pi avisesataḥ
translated: Although the nominative case is established without distinction,

original: “Ato nicca”nti ārambhā, āettaṃ kvacidevidha.
analyzed: atas ārambhāḥ āettam
translated: “In the neuter, therefore, always” is begun,

original: Ālapane galopo. He citta, he cittā cittāni, dutiyāyaṃ nissa vikappenekāro. Cittaṃ, citte cittāni. Sesaṃ purisasaddena samaṃ.
analyzed: ālapane ga lopaḥ he citta he cittā cittāni dutiya ayam vikappena ikāraḥ cittam citte cittāni sesam purisa saddena samam
translated: and ā is sometimes added in some places. He citta, he cittā cittāni. In the second case, the form with ni is changed to one form. Cittaṃ, citte cittāni. The rest is the same as the word for man.

original: Evamaññānipi –
analyzed: evam aññāni pi
translated: So too the other words:

original: Puñña pāpa phala rūpa sādhanaṃ,
analyzed: puñña pāpa phala rūpa sādhanaṃ
translated: The fruit of merit and demerit, the means of making visible,

original: Sota ghāna sukha dukkha kāraṇaṃ;
analyzed: sota ghāna sukha dukkha kāraṇaṃ
translated: The cause of ear, nose, pleasure and pain,

original: Dāna sīla dhana jhāna locanaṃ,
analyzed: dāna sīla dhana jhāna locanaṃ
translated: The eye of the wealth of giving and virtue, the meditation,

original: Mūla kūla bala jālamaṅgalaṃ.🔽Naḷina liṅga mukha’ṅga jala’mbujaṃ,
analyzed: mūla kūla bala jālamaṅgalaṃ  naḷina liṅga mukhaṅga jalambujaṃ
translated: The auspicious net of the root, the bank, the strength.🔽The lotus, the sign, the face, the limb, the water, the lotus,

original: Pulina dhañña hirañña padā’mataṃ;
analyzed: pulina dhañña hirañña padāmatam
translated: The bank, the grain, the gold, the foot, the immortal,

original: Paduma vaṇṇa susāna vanā’yudhaṃ,
analyzed: paduma vaṇṇa susāna vanāyudham
translated: The colour of the lotus, the charnel ground, the forest, the weapon,

original: Hadaya cīvara vattha kuli’ndriyaṃ.
analyzed: kulindriyam
translated: The heart, the robe, the cloth, the crest-jewel, the sense-faculty.

original: Nayana vadana yāno’dāna sopāna pānaṃ,
analyzed: nayana vadana yāna udāna sopāna pānam
translated: The eye, the face, the vehicle, the gift, the staircase, the drink,

original: Bhavana bhuvana lohā’lāta tuṇḍa’ṇḍa pīṭhaṃ;
analyzed: bhavana bhuvana loha alāta tuṇḍaṇḍa pīṭham
translated: The abode, the world, the whirling fire-brand, the beak, the egg, the seat;

original: Karaṇa maraṇa ñāṇā’rammaṇā’rañña tāṇaṃ,
analyzed: karaṇa maraṇa ñāṇa ārammaṇa arañña tāṇaṃ
translated: The instrument, the death, the knowledge, the object, the forest, the refuge,

original: Caraṇa nagara tīracchatta chiddo’dakāni –
analyzed: caraṇa nagara tīracchatta chidda udakāni
translated: The practice, the city, the shore, the umbrella, the hole, the water –

original: Iccādīni.
analyzed: i t ca ādīni
translated: And so on.

original: Kammasaddassa tatiyekavacanādīsu rūpabhedo.
analyzed: kamma saddassa tatiya ekavacana ādīsu rūpa bhedaḥ
translated: The analysis of the form of the singular, etc., in the word kamma is as follows.

original: Kammaṃ, kammā kammāni, he kamma, he kammā kammāni, kammaṃ, kamme kammāni.
analyzed: kammam kammā kammāni he kamma he kammā kammāni kammam kamme kammāni
translated: Kamma, kammā, kammāni, he kamma, he kammā, he kammāni, kammaṃ, kamme, kammāni.

original: “Vā, u, nāmhi, cā”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: vai u nāmhi ca ati ca vattate
translated: And “vā, u, nāmhi, cā” occurs.

original: 197. A kammantassa ca.
analyzed: a kammantassa ca
translated: And in the nominative case of the neuter.

original: Kammasaddantassa ukāra akārādesā honti vā nāmhi vibhattimhi. Antaggahaṇena thāmaddhādīnamantassapi
analyzed: kamma sadda antassa ukāra akāra ādesāḥ honti vā nāmhi vibhattimhi anta ggahaṇena thā maddha ādīnam antassa pi
translated: The word “final” includes the final of a prefix.🔽The word “also” includes the final of yuva and maghavā.

original: uttaṃ. Casaddaggahaṇena yuva maghavānamantassa ā hoti kvaci nā suiccetesu. Kammunā
analyzed: uttam maghavānam antassa ā hoti kvaci nā su icca itesu kammunā
translated: The word “sometimes” excludes such words as na.🔽The word “by” is a case-ending.

original: kammanā kammena vā, kammehi kammebhi.
analyzed: kammanā kammena vā kammehi kammebhi
translated: The word “in” is a case-ending.🔽The word “or” in the above rule includes the final of a masculine noun ending in a consonant.🔽The word “also” in the above rule includes the final of a masculine noun ending in a consonant.

original: Sasmāsu “u nāmhi cā”ti ettha casaddena puma kammathāmantassa cukāro vā sasmāsūti
analyzed: sa smāsu u nāmhi ca a ti ettha ca saddena puma cukāraḥ vā sa smāsu iti
translated: The word “sometimes” excludes such words as na.🔽The word “in” is a case-ending.🔽The word “or” in the above rule includes the final of a masculine noun ending in a consonant.🔽The word “also” in the above rule includes the final of a masculine noun ending in a consonant.🔽The word “sometimes” excludes such words as na.

original: uttaṃ. Kammuno kammassa, kammānaṃ, kammunā kammā kammamhā kammasmā, kammehi kammebhi,
analyzed: uttam kammunaḥ kammassa kammānam kammunā kammā kammamhā kammasmā kammehi kammebhi
translated: The word “in” is a case-ending.🔽The word “or” in the above rule includes the final of a masculine noun ending in a consonant.🔽The word “also” in the above rule includes the final of a masculine noun ending in a consonant.🔽The word “sometimes” excludes such words as na.

original: kammuno kammassa, kammānaṃ.
analyzed: kammunaḥ kammassa kammānam
translated: The word “in” is a case-ending.🔽The word “or” in the above rule includes the final of a masculine noun ending in a consonant.🔽The word “also” in the above rule includes the final of a masculine noun ending in a consonant.🔽The word “sometimes” excludes such words as na.🔽The word “in” is a case-ending.🔽The word “or” in the above rule includes the final of a masculine noun ending in a consonant.🔽The word “also” in the above rule includes the final of a masculine noun ending in a consonant.🔽The word “sometimes” excludes such words as na.

original: Smiṃvacane “brahmato tu smiṃnī”ti ettha tusaddena kvaci ni hoti. Kammani kamme kammamhi kammasmiṃ, kammesu.
analyzed: smiṃvacane brahmataḥ tu smiṃni iti ettha tu saddena kvaci ni hoti kammani kamme kammamhi kammasmim kammesu
translated: The word “in” is a case-ending.🔽The word “or” in the above rule includes the final of a masculine noun ending in a consonant.

original: Evaṃ thāmunā thāmena thāmasā vā, thāmuno thāmassa, thāmunā thāmā. Addhunā, addhuno iccādi purimasamaṃ.
analyzed: evam thāmunā thāmena thāmasā vā thāmunā thāmassa thāmunā thāmā addhunā addhunā iccādi purima samam
translated: The word “also” in the above rule includes the final of a masculine noun ending in a consonant.🔽The word “sometimes” excludes such words as na.

original: Guṇavantu si, “savibhattissa, ntussa, simhī”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: guṇavantu si sa vibhattissa n tussa simhi iti ca vattate
translated: The word “in” is a case-ending.

original: 198. Aṃ napuṃsake.
analyzed: am napuṃsake
translated: 198. Aṃ is the neuter.

original: Napuṃsake vattamānassa liṅgassa sambandhino ntuppaccayassa savibhattissa aṃ hoti simhi vibhattimhi. Guṇavaṃ cittaṃ.
analyzed: napuṃsake vattamānassa liṅgassa sambandhinaḥ n t up paccayassa sa vibhattissa aṃ hoti simhi vibhattimhi guṇavam cittam
translated: When the neuter is in process, aṃ is the ending of the nt-declension, with case-affix, in the locative simhi. The mind is endowed with virtue.

original: Yomhi “ntussanto yosu cā”ti attaṃ, ikāro ca. Guṇavanti, guṇavantāni, sesaṃ ñeyyaṃ.
analyzed: yomhi n tus antaḥ yosu ca ati attam ikāraḥ ca guṇavanti guṇavantāni sesam ñeyyam
translated: In the nominative yomhi, the a is elided by “ntussanto yosu cā” and the i is elided. The mind is endowed with virtue, endowed with virtue, the rest is to be known.

original: Gacchanta si, “simhi gacchantādīnaṃ ntasaddo a”miti aṃ. Gacchaṃ gacchantaṃ, gacchantā gacchantāni.
analyzed: gacchanta si simhi gacchanta ādīnam nta saddaḥ am iti am gaccham gacchantam gacchantā gacchantāni
translated: In the locative simhi, the a is elided by “simhi gacchantādīnaṃ ntasaddo a” and the i is elided. The mind is going, the mind is going, the minds are going.

original: Akārantaṃ.
analyzed: akāra antam
translated: The word akāranta.

original: Ākāranto napuṃsakaliṅgo assaddhāsaddo.
analyzed: ākāra antaḥ napuṃsaka liṅgaḥ assaddha asaddaḥ
translated: The word assaddhā is neuter, without a final vowel.

original: “Assaddhā”iti ṭhite –
analyzed: assaddhā iti ṭhite
translated: When it is established thus:

original: “Samāsassā”ti adhikicca “saro rasso napuṃsake”ti samāsantassa rassattaṃ, samāsattā nāmabyapadeso, syādyuppatti. Sesaṃ cittasamaṃ.
analyzed: samāsassa ati saraḥ rassaḥ napuṃsaka iti samāsa antassa rassattam samāsattā nāma byapadesaḥ syādi uppatti sesam cittasamam
translated: “Assaddhā” by the addition of the rule “saro rasso napuṃsake” the final vowel of the compound is elided, the compound is called a name-base, the sibilant is elided. The rest is the same as the mind.

original: Assaddhaṃ kulaṃ, assaddhā assaddhāni kulāni iccādi.
analyzed: assaddham kulam assaddhāḥ assaddhāni kulāni iccādi
translated: A family is without faith, the families are without faith.

original: Tathā mukhanāsikāsaddo. Tassa dvandekattā sabbatthekavacanameva. Mukhanāsikaṃ, he mukhanāsika, mukhanāsikaṃ, mukhanāsikena iccādi.
analyzed: tathā mukha nāsikā saddo tassa dvanda ekattā sabbattha ekavacanam eva mukha nāsikam he mukha nāsika mukha nāsikam mukha nāsikena iccādi
translated: So also the word for “mouth and nose.” Because it is a dvanda compound, it is declined in all ways as one word. “Mouth and nose,” “O mouth and nose,” “mouth and nose,” “by mouth and nose,” etc.

original: Ākārantaṃ.🔽Ikāranto napuṃsakaliṅgo aṭṭhisaddo.🔽Syādyuppatti, silopo, aṭṭhi.
analyzed: ākāra antam  ikāra antaḥ napuṃsaka liṅgaḥ aṭṭhi saddaḥ  si ādi uppatti si lopaḥ aṭṭhi
translated: The word for “bone” is feminine.🔽The word for “bone” is feminine, ending in -ī.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.

original: “Vā”ti vattate.🔽199. Yonaṃ ni napuṃsakehi.
analyzed: vāti vattate  yonam ni napuṃsakehi
translated: The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.

original: Napuṃsakaliṅgehi paresaṃ sabbesaṃ yonaṃ ni hoti vā.
analyzed: napuṃsaka liṅgehi paresam sabbesam yonam ni hoti vā
translated: The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.

original: Aṭṭhīni, aññattha niccaṃ yolopo, dīgho ca, aṭṭhī, tathā he aṭṭhi, he aṭṭhī aṭṭhīni, aṭṭhiṃ, aṭṭhī aṭṭhīni, aṭṭhinā iccādi aggisaddasamaṃ.🔽Evaṃ satthi dadhi vāri akkhi acchi acci iccādīni.
analyzed: aṭṭhīni aññattha niccam yo lopaḥ dīghaḥ ca aṭṭhī tathā he aṭṭhi he aṭṭhī aṭṭhīni aṭṭhim aṭṭhī aṭṭhīni aṭṭhinā iccādi aggi sadda samam  evam satthi dadhi vāri akkhi acchi acci icca ādīni
translated: The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.

original: Ikārantaṃ.🔽Īkāranto napuṃsakaliṅgo sukhakārīsaddo.
analyzed: ikāra antam  īkāra antaḥ napuṃsaka liṅgaḥ sukhakārī saddo
translated: The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.

original: “Sukhabhārī si” itīdha anapuṃsakattābhāvā sismimpi “agho rassa”miccādinā rassattaṃ,
analyzed: sukha bhārī si a napuṃsaka ttā abhāvā a ghaḥ
translated: The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.🔽The feminine form is formed by adding -ī to the masculine form.

original: silopo. Sukhakāri dānaṃ, sukhakārī sukhakārīni, he sukhakāri, he sukhakārī he sukhakārīni,
analyzed: sukha kāri dānam sukha kārī sukha kārīni he sukha kāri he sukha kārī he sukha kārīni
translated: Silopo. Giving brings happiness, happiness, happiness, O happy one, O happy ones, O happy ones,

original: Napuṃsakaliṅgaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.

original: Sabbanāma
analyzed: sabbanāma
translated: All nouns

original: Atha sabbanāmāni vuccante.🔽Sabba, katara, katama, ubhaya, itara, añña, aññatara, aññatama, pubba, para, apara,
analyzed: atha sabbanāmāni vuccante  sabba katara katama ubhaya itara añña aññatara aññatama pubba para apara

analyzed: dakkhiṇa uttara adhara ya te ete ima amu kim eka ubha dvi ti catu tumha

original: amha iti sattavīsati sabbanāmāni, tāni sabbanāmattā tiliṅgāni.
analyzed: iti sattavīsati sabbanāmāni tāni sabba nāma ttā ti liṅgāni
translated: Amha is the twenty-seventh of the personal pronouns. They are all in the neuter gender.

original: Tattha sabbasaddo niravasesattho, so yadā pulliṅgavisiṭṭhatthābhidhāyī, tadā rūpanayo. Pure viya syādyuppatti, “so”ti sissa okāro, saralopaparanayanāni. Sabbo jano.
analyzed: tattha sabba saddaḥ niravasesa atthaḥ saḥ yadā pulliṅga visiṭṭha ttha abhidhāyī tadā rūpa nayaḥ pure saḥ ti sissaḥ okāraḥ sara lopa para nayanāni sabbaḥ janaḥ
translated: Herein, the word sabba has the meaning of “without remainder.” When it expresses a meaning distinguished by the feminine gender, then it is the Feminine Gender System. The origin of the syllable sya is as in the previous case. “So” is the nominative case of the pronoun “so.” The elision of the final -r, the addition of -a-, and the change of -o- to -o- are the grammatical operations. Sabbo jano .

original: Bahuvacane “sabba yo” itīdha “parasamaññā payoge”ti sabbādīnaṃ sabbanāmasaññā.
analyzed: bahuvacane sabba yaḥ iti idha para samaññā payoge iti sabba ādīnam sabbanāma saññā
translated: In the plural, “sabba yo” . Herein, “in the use of a name for another” , the words sabba, etc., are called personal pronouns.

original: “Yo”ti vattate.
analyzed: yoti vattate
translated: “Yo” is used.

original: 200. Sabbanāmakārate paṭhamo.
analyzed: paṭhamaḥ
translated: The first is the personal pronoun.

original: Sabbesaṃ itthipumanapuṃsakānaṃ nāmāni sabbanāmāni, tesaṃ sabbesaṃ sabbanāmasaññānaṃ liṅgānaṃ akārato paro paṭhamo yo ettamāpajjate. Sabbe purisā.
analyzed: sabbesam itthi puma napuṃsakānam nāmāni sabbanāmāni tesam sabbesam sabbanāma saññānam liṅgānam akārataḥ paraḥ paṭhamaḥ yaḥ sabbe purisāḥ
translated: The names of all women, men, and neuters are personal pronouns. The first of the personal pronouns, which is in the nominative case, is used after the word sabba, which is in the neuter gender. Sabbe purisā .

original: Akāratoti kiṃ? Sabbā amū.
analyzed: akārataḥ iti kim sabbāḥ amū

original: He sabba sabbā, he sabbe, sabbaṃ, sabbe, sabbena, sabbehi sabbebhi.

original: Catutthekavacane āyādese sampatte –
analyzed: catuttha ikavacane āya ādese sampatte
translated: When the fourth case ending -e is added,

translated: “Ato, ā e, smāsmiṃnaṃ, āya catutthekavacanassā” is used.

original: 201. Tayo neva ca sabbanāmehi.🔽Akārantehi sabbanāmehi paresaṃ smā smiṃ iccetesaṃ, catutthekavacanassa ca ā e āyaiccete
analyzed: tayaḥ na iva ca sabba nāmehi  akāra antehi sabbanāmehi paresam smā smim i t ca itesam catuttha ekavacanassa ca ā e āya e c ca ite

original: ādesā neva hontīti āyādesābhāvo. Caggahaṇaṃ katthaci paṭisedhanivattanatthaṃ, tena
analyzed: ādesāḥ na iva honti iti ca ggahaṇam katthaci paṭisedha nivattana attham tena

analyzed: napuṃsake pubbam ṭhānam pubbāni he pubba he pubbāni pubbam pubbāni sesam pulliṅga samam evam para apara dakkhiṇa uttara adhara saddāḥ
translated: In the neuter, the first is the place: pubbāni, he pubba, he pubbāni, pubbaṃ, pubbāni, the rest is the same as in the feminine. So too with the words parāpara, dakkhiṇa, uttara, adhara.

original: “Sabbanāmato, dvandaṭṭhā”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: sabbanāmataḥ dvandaṭṭhā iti ca vattate
translated: “In a dvanda compound, a word ending in -n is not a sabbanāmika.”

original: 209. Nāññaṃ sabbanāmikaṃ.🔽Dvandaṭṭhā sabbanāmato parassa yovacanassa ṭhapetvā ettaṃ aññaṃ sabbanāmikaṃ kāriyaṃ
analyzed: na aññam sabbanāmikam  dvandaṭṭhā sabbanāmataḥ parassa yo vacanassa ṭhapetvā ettam aññam sabbanāmikam kāriyam
translated: . No other word ending in -n.🔽In a dvanda compound, a word ending in -n is not a sabbanāmika, except for the word ettaka.

original: na hotīti saṃsānamādesābhāvo. Pubbāparānaṃ, pubbuttarānaṃ adharuttarānaṃ, “nāññaṃ
analyzed: na hoti iti pubba aparānam pubbuttarānam adharuttarānam na aññam
translated: . There is no change of vowel. In a tatpurisa compound, too, with the addition of vin, as in pubbāpara, pubbuttara, adharuttara, “no other word ending in -n

original: sabbanāmika”nti vinādhikārena yogena tatiyāsamāsepi. Māsapubbāya, māsapubbānaṃ.
analyzed: sabbanāmikam ti vinā adhikārena yogena tatiyā samāse pi māsa pubbāya māsa pubbānam
translated: is a sabbanāmika.” Māsapubbāya, māsapubbānaṃ.

original: “Nāññaṃ sabbanāmika”nti ca vattate.
analyzed: na aññam sabbanāmikam ti ca vattate
translated: “No other word ending in -n is a sabbanāmika.”

original: 210. Bahubbīhimhi ca.
analyzed: bahup bīhimhi ca
translated: . And in a bahubbīhi compound.

original: Bahubbīhimhi ca samāse sabbanāmikavidhānaṃ nāññaṃ hoti. Piyapubbāya, piyapubbānaṃ, piyapubbe.
analyzed: bahu bbīhimhi ca samāse sabbanāmika vidhānam na aññam hoti piya pubbāya piya pubbānam piya pubbe
translated: And in a bahubbīhi compound, the rule for a word ending in -n is not the same as that for a sabbanāmika. Piyapubbāya, piyapubbānaṃ, piyapubbe.

original: Casaddaggahaṇena disatthasabbanāmānaṃ bahubbīhimhi sabbanāmikavidhānaṃva hoti.
analyzed: ca sadda gahaṇena dis attha sabbanāmānam bahu bbīhimhi sabbanāmika vidhānam va hoti
translated: By the word ca, the rule for a sabbanāmika is the same as that for a word ending in -n in a bahubbīhi compound, when the word is a directional or a time-expression.

original: Dakkhiṇassā ca pubbassā ca yadantarāḷanti atthe bahubbīhi, dakkhiṇapubbassaṃ, dakkhiṇapubbassā, evaṃ uttarapubbassaṃ, uttarapubbassā iccādi.
analyzed: dakkhiṇassā ca pubbassā ca atthe bahu bbīhi dakkhiṇa pubbassam dakkhiṇa pubbassā evam uttara pubbassam uttara pubbassā iccādi
translated: The meaning of the locative case is the middle between the south and the east, etc., and the locative case is formed by adding the suffix -ssā to the cardinal points, thus: dakkhiṇassā ca pubbassā ca yadantarāḷaṃ = dakkhiṇapubbassaṃ, dakkhiṇapubbassā, and similarly uttarapubbassaṃ, uttarapubbassā, etc.

original: Yatetasaddādīnamālapane rūpaṃ na sambhavati. Yasaddo aniyamattho.
analyzed: rūpam na sambhavati ya saddaḥ aniyama tthaḥ
translated: The locative case is not possible in the formation of the words yattha, etc. The word ya is of indefinite meaning.

original: Yo puriso, ye purisā, yaṃ, ye. Yā kaññā, yā yāyo, yaṃ, yā yāyo. Yaṃ cittaṃ, yāni, yaṃ, yāni. Sesaṃ sabbattha sabbasaddasamaṃ.
analyzed: yaḥ purisaḥ ye purisāḥ yam ye yā kaññā yāḥ yāyaḥ yam yā yāyaḥ yam cittam yāni yam yāni sesam sabbattha sabba sadda samam
translated: Yo puriso, ye purisā, yaṃ, ye. Yā kaññā, yā yāyo, yaṃ, yā yāyo. Yaṃ cittaṃ, yāni, yaṃ, yāni. The rest is the same as sabba.

original: Ta eta ima amu kiṃiccete parammukha samīpa accantasamīpadūra pucchanatthavacanā.
analyzed: te ete ime amu kiṃicca ete parammukha samīpa accanta samīpa dūra
translated: Ta, eta, ima, amu, kiṃ, icc-ete are used in the sense of the person in front, near, very near, far, asking, and stating.

original: Tasaddassa bhedo. “Ta si” itīdha –
analyzed: ta saddassa bhedaḥ ta si iti idha
translated: The word ta has a special formation.

original: “Anapuṃsakassāyaṃ simhīti, sa”miti ca vattate.
analyzed: a napuṃsakassa ayam simhi iti sam iti ca vattate
translated: “Anapuṃsakassa siṃhīti” (Pā. 1.4.1) thus the word si is formed.

original: 211. Etatesaṃ to.
analyzed: etatesam taḥ
translated: Et, esa, tesa, tesaṃ are the forms of the words ta, eta, ima, amu, kiṃ, icc-ete.

original: Eta taiccetesaṃ anapuṃsakānaṃ takāro sakāramāpajjate simhi vibhattimhi. So puriso.🔽Sabbanāmaggahaṇañca, ito taggahaṇañca vattate.
analyzed: e ta ta i c ca itesam a napuṃsakānam takāraḥ sakāram āpajjate simhi vibhattimhi saḥ purisaḥ  sabbanāma ggahaṇam ca i taḥ ta ggahaṇam ca vattate
translated: Et, eta, icc-ete take the form ta, sa in the feminine case siṃhī. So puriso.🔽The words sabba and ta are included here.

original: 212. Tassa vā nattaṃ sabbattha.
analyzed: tassa vā nattam sabbattha
translated: Tassa, tassā, tassāni, tassāni, tassā, tassāyo, tassāni, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tassā, tassāyo, tass

original: Taiccetassa sabbanāmassa takārassa nattaṃ hoti vā sabbattha liṅgesu. Ne te, naṃ taṃ, ne te, nena tena, nehi nebhi tehi tebhi.
analyzed: tai c ca itassa sabbanāmassa takārassa nattam hoti vā sabbattha liṅgesu ne te naṃ tam ne te nena tena nehi nebhi tehi tebhi
translated: But if it is the whole of that word, then the t is dropped in all genders. Ne te, naṃ taṃ, ne te, nena tena, nehi nebhi tehi tebhi.

original: “Sabbassa, tassa vā sabbatthā”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: sabbassa tassa vā sabbattha ati ca vattate
translated: “Of all, of that, or in all places” is said.

original: 213. Sasmāsmiṃsaṃsāsvattaṃ.
analyzed: sasmā smiṃsaṃsāsvattam
translated: . In smā, smiṃ, saṃ, and sāsvatta, the t is dropped.

original: Taiccetassa sabbanāmassa sabbasseva attaṃ hoti vā sa smā smiṃ saṃ sāiccetesu vacanesu sabbattha liṅgesu. Assa nassa tassa, nesaṃ tesaṃ nesānaṃ tesānaṃ.
analyzed: taic ca itassa sabba nāmassa sabbassa iva attam hoti vā sa smā smim sam sāic ca itesu vacanesu sabbattha liṅgesu assa nassa tassa nesam tesānam tesānam
translated: But if it is the whole of that word, then the t of all is dropped in all genders in the words smā, smiṃ, saṃ, and sāsvatta. Assa nassa tassa, nesaṃ tesaṃ nesānaṃ tesānaṃ.

original: “Smāhismiṃnaṃ mhābhimhi vā”ti ito “smāsmiṃnaṃ, mhāmhī”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: mha abhimhi vāti itas sma asmin nam mha amhi iti ca vattate
translated: “In smā, smiṃ, naṃ, mhā, and bhi” is said from here.

original: 214. Na timehi katākārehi.
analyzed: na timehi kata ākārehi
translated: . In timehi, katākārehi.

original: Ta imaiccetehi katākārehi paresaṃ smāsmiṃnaṃ mhā mhiiccete ādesā na honti.
analyzed: te kata akārehi paresam mhā mhi it ca ete ādesāḥ na honti
translated: But in timehi, katākārehi, the ādeśas smā, smiṃ, naṃ, mhā, and bhi are not.

original: Pakatisandhividhāna
analyzed: pakati sandhi vidhāna
translated: The rule of normal sandhi

original: Atha sarānameva sandhikāriye sampatte pakatibhāvo vuccate.
analyzed: atha sandhi kāriye sampatte pakati bhāvaḥ vuccate
translated: Now, when the sandhi is to be done with a vowel, the normal state is stated.

original: “Sarā, pakatī”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: ca vattate
translated: “With a vowel, normal” is said.

original: 35. Sare kvaci.
analyzed: sare kvaci
translated: . In sare, kvaci.

original: Sarā kho sare pare kvaci chandabhedāsukhuccāraṇaṭṭhāne, sandhicchārahitaṭṭhāne ca pakatirūpāni honti, na lopādesavikāramāpajjanteti attho.
analyzed: sarā kho sare pare kvaci chanda bheda asukha uccāraṇa ṭhāne sandhi chā rahita ṭhāne ca pakati rūpāni honti na lopa ādesa vikāram āpajjantā iti attho
translated: The original forms are found in the places where there is no elision of the first syllable of a compound, and where there is no elision of the first syllable of a word, and where there is no elision of the first syllable of a phrase.

original: Tattha pakatiṭṭhānaṃ nāma ālapanantā anitismiṃ acchandānurakkhaṇe asamāse padantadīghā ca ikārukārā ca nāmapadantātītakriyādimhīti evamādi.
analyzed: tattha pakatiṭṭhānam nāma an itismim a chanda anurakkhaṇe a samāse pad anta dīghā ca ikāra ukārā ca nāma pad anta atīta kriyā ādimhi iti evamādi
translated: Herein, the “original place” is the place where there is no elision of the first syllable of a compound, no elision of the first syllable of a word, no elision of the first syllable of a phrase, no elision of the first syllable of a name, no elision of the first syllable of a root, and so on.

original: Ālapanantesu tāva – katamā cānanda aniccasaññā, katamā cānanda ādīnavasaññā, sāriputta🔽idhekacco, ehi sivika uṭṭhehi, upāsakā idhekacco, bhoti ayye, bhikkhu arogaṃ tava
analyzed: ālapana ntesu tāva katamā ca ānanda anicca saññā katamā ca ānanda ādīnava saññā sāriputta  idha ekaccaḥ ehi sivika uṭṭhehi upāsakā idha ekaccaḥ bhoti ayye bhikkhu arogam tava
translated: Herein, firstly, as regards the elision of the first syllable of a compound: What is the perception of impermanence, Ānanda? What is the perception of danger, Ānanda? Sāriputta,

original: sīlaṃ, siñca bhikkhu imaṃ nāvaṃ, bhikkhave evaṃ vadāmi, pañcime gahapatayo ānisaṃsā
analyzed: sīlam siñca bhikkhu imam nāvam bhikkhave evam vadāmi pañcime gahapatayaḥ ānisaṃsā
translated: Here someone says: “Come, friend Sivika, get up, lay follower. Here someone says: ‘Lady, your virtue is sound, Sivika, a bhikkhu should water this boat, bhikkhus, I say thus, householders, these are the five advantages,

original: iccevamādīsu pakatibhāvo, pubbassaralopayavādesādayo na honti.
analyzed: iti ca ivamādīsu pakati bhāvaḥ pubba ssara lopa yava ādesa ādayaḥ na honti
translated: and so on. Herein, there is no elision of the first syllable of a compound, no elision of the first syllable of a word, no elision of the first syllable of a phrase, no elision of the first syllable of a name, no elision of the first syllable of a root, and so on.

original: Kvaciggahaṇena itismiṃ chandānurakkhaṇe sandhi hoti, yathā – sakkā devīti, namo te buddha vīratthu.
analyzed: kvacid gahaṇena itismim chanda anurakkhaṇe sandhi hoti yathā sakkā devī iti namaḥ te buddha
translated: By the word “somewhere” is meant that there is a sandhi when there is elision of the first syllable of a phrase, as in Sakka devī, Namo te buddha vīratthu.

original: Sareti kiṃ? Sādhu mahārājāti, evaṃ kira bhikkhūti.
analyzed: sara iti kim sādhu mahā rāja ati evam kira bhikkhu iti
translated: What did he say? ‘Excellent, Great King!’ – so it seems, monks.

original: Asamāse padantadīghesu – āyasmā ānando gāthā ajjhabhāsi, devā ābhassarā yathā, tevijjā
analyzed: a samāse pada anta dīghesu āyasmai ānandaḥ gāthāḥ ajjhabhāsi devāḥ ābhassarāḥ yathā tevijjā
translated: In the case of words ending in a compound, or in a long vowel: The venerable Ānanda spoke this verse, like the Ābhassara gods, those who have attained the three knowledges,

original: iddhippattā ca, bhagavā uṭṭhāyāsanā, bhagavā etadavoca, abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi,
analyzed: iddhi pattā ca bhagavā uṭṭhāya āsanā bhagavā etat avoca abhivādetvā ekamantam aṭṭhāsi
translated: and the supernormal powers, the Blessed One rose from his seat, the Blessed One said this, after paying homage, he stood at one side,

original: gantvā olokento, bhūtavādī atthavādī, yaṃ itthī arahā assa, sāmāvatī āha, pāpakārī
analyzed: gantvā olokentaḥ bhūta vādī attha vādī yam itthī arahā assa sāmāvatī āha pāpa kārī
translated: and looked, one who speaks of what is, one who speaks of what is beneficial, if a woman were to be a Worthy One, Sāmāvatī said, one who does evil,

original: ubhayattha tappati, nadī ottharati, ye te bhikkhū appicchā, bhikkhū āmantesi, bhikkhūujjhāyiṃsu,
analyzed: ubhayattha tappati nadī ottharati ye te bhikkhū appicchāḥ bhikkhū āmantesi bhikkhū ujjhāyiṃsu
translated: suffers in both places, the river overflows, those monks who are few in their wishes, the monks addressed him, the monks were exhausted,

original: bhikkhū evamāhaṃsu, imasmiṃ gāme ārakkhakā, sabbe ime, katame ekādasa, gambhīre odakantike,
analyzed: bhikkhū evam āhaṃsu imasmin gāme ārakkhakā sabbe ime katame ekādasa gambhīre odakantike
translated: the monks said this, in this village there are guards, all of these, which eleven, in a deep, watery place,

original: appamādo amatapadaṃ, saṅgho āgacchatu, ko imaṃ pathaviṃ viccessati, āloko udapādi,
analyzed: appamādaḥ amata padam saṅghaḥ āgacchatu kaḥ imam pathavim vicca issati ālokaḥ udapādi
translated: carefulness is the path to immortality, may the Community come, who will divide this earth, light arose,

original: eko ekāya, cattāro oghā.
analyzed: ekaḥ ekāya cattāro oghā
translated: one, and one, four floods.

original: Nipātesupi – are ahampi, sace imassa kāyassa, no abhikkamo, aho acchariyo, atho anto ca, atha kho āyasmā, atho oṭṭhavacittakā, tato āmantayī satthā.🔽Kvaciggahaṇena akāra itīvevetthādīsu sandhipi. Yathā – āgatattha, āgatamhā, katamāssu🔽cattāro, appassutāyaṃ puriso, itthīti, ca marīva, sabbeva, sveva, eseva nayo, parisuddhetthāyasmanto,🔽nettha, taṃ kutettha labbhā, sacesa brāhmaṇa, tathūpamaṃ, yathāha.🔽Asamāseti kiṃ? Jivhāyatanaṃ, avijjogho, itthindriyaṃ, abhibhāyatanaṃ, bhayatupaṭṭhānaṃ. Acchandānurakkhaṇeti kiṃ? Saddhīdha vittaṃ purisassa seṭṭhaṃ, yo missaro.
analyzed: nipātesu pi are aham pi sace imassa kāyassa no abhikkamaḥ aho acchariyaḥ atho antaḥ ca atha kho āyasmai atho oṭṭhavacittakā tatas āmantayī satthā  akāraḥ iti iva iva itthā ādīsu sandhi pi yathā āgatatthaḥ katamāssu  cattāro appassutā ayam puriso itthī iti ca marī iva sabbā iva svā iva esā iva nayo parisuddhā itthā ayasmantaḥ  na ittha tam kuta ittha labbhā sacā isa brāhmaṇa tathā upamam yathā āha  a samāse iti kim jivhā āyatanam itthi indriyam abhibhā āyatanam bhayatupaṭṭhānam a chanda anurakkhaṇa iti kim saddhi idha vittam purisassa seṭṭham yaḥ missaraḥ
translated: In the Nipāta, too: are, if, of this body, no more, how wonderful, and then, and then the venerable one, and then the people of Oṭṭha, then the Teacher addressed them.

original: Nāmapadantaikārukāresu – gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi, pupphāni āhariṃsu, satthu adāsi.🔽Kvacīti kiṃ? Manasākāsi.🔽36. Sarā pakati byañjane.
analyzed: gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi pupphāni āhariṃsu satthu adāsi 🔽kvaci iti kim 🔽sarā pakati byañjane
translated: In some cases the sandhi is also in the same way, as in nipāta, itthabba, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthāhaṃ, itthā

original: Sarā kho byañjane pare pakatirūpā hontīti yebhuyyena dīgharassalopehi vikārābhāvo.
analyzed: vyañjane pare vikāra abhāvaḥ
translated: But in the case of a consonant, the other letters are in their normal form. That is why there is no modification by the lengthening of the short and so on.

original: Yathā – accayo, paccayo, bhāsati vā karoti vā, vedanākkhandho, bhāgyavā, bhadro kasāmiva,
analyzed: yathā accayaḥ paccayaḥ bhāsati vā karoti vā vedanā khandhaḥ bhāgyavā bhadro kasām iva
translated: For example: accayo, paccayo, bhāsati, karoti, vedanākkhandho, bhāgyavā, bhadro, kasāmiva,

original: dīyati, tuṇhībhūto, so dhammaṃ deseti.
analyzed: dīyati tuṇhībhūto so dhammaṃ deseti
translated: dīyati, tuṇhībhūto, so dhammaṃ deseti.

original: Iti pakatisandhividhānaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: iti pakati sandhi vidhānam niṭṭhitam
translated: So the normal-form linking is finished.

original: Byañjanasandhividhāna
analyzed: byañjana sandhi vidhāna
translated: The linking of consonants

original: Atha byañjanasandhi vuccate.
analyzed: atha byañjana sandhi vuccate
translated: Now the linking of consonants is stated.

original: “Byañjane”ti adhikāro, “sarā, kvacī”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: byañjana iti kvaci iti ca vattate
translated: The scope is “in a consonant” and “in some places” is applicable.

original: 37. Dīghaṃ.
analyzed: dīgham
translated: Long

original: Sarā kho byañjane pare kvaci dīghaṃ pappontīti suttasukhuccāraṇachandānurakkhaṇaṭṭhānesu dīgho.🔽Tyassa pahīnā tyāssa pahīnā, svassa svāssa, madhuva maññati bālo madhuvā maññatī
analyzed: sarā khaḥ byañjane pare kvaci dīgham papponti iti sutta sukha uccāraṇa chanda anurakkhaṇa ṭṭhānesu dīghaḥ  pahīnā tyāssa pahīnā svassa svassa madhuvā maññati bālaḥ madhuvā maññatī
translated: In the case of a consonant, the other letters sometimes take the long form. That is why there is a long vowel in the case of the ease of a sutta, a pleasant sound, the preservation of the metre, and the preservation of the place.

original: bālo, tathā evaṃ gāme munī care, khantī paramaṃ tapo titikkhā, na maṅkū bhavissāmi,
analyzed: bālo tathā evam gāme munī care khantī paramam tapaḥ titikkhā na bhavissāmi
translated: Tyassa pahīnā, tyassa pahīnā, svassa svāssa, madhuva maññati bālo, madhuvā maññatī bālo, tathā evaṃ gāme munī care, khantī paramaṃ tapo titikkhā, na maṅkū bhavissāmi,

original: svākkhāto, yvāhaṃ, kāmato jāyatī soko, kāmato jāyatī bhayaṃ, sakko ujū ca suhujū
analyzed: su ākkhātaḥ yvā aham kāmataḥ jāyatī sokaḥ kāmataḥ jāyatī bhayam sakkaḥ ujū ca suhujū
translated: Well-taught, straight, very straight,

original: ca, anūpaghāto, dūrakkhaṃ, dūramaṃ, sūrakkhaṃ, dūharatā.
analyzed: ca anūpaghātaḥ dūrakkham dūramam sūrakkham dūhara tā
translated: not-harming, far-reaching, far-going, well-protected, well-guarded, well-taken-up.

original: Kvacīti kiṃ? Tyajja, svassa, patiliyyati.
analyzed: kvaci iti kim
translated: Where? In the words: Tyajja, svassa, patiliyyati.

original: Yiṭṭhaṃ vā hutaṃ vā loke, yadi vā sāvake, puggalā dhammadasā te, bhovādī nāma so hoti, yathābhāvī guṇena so itīdha –
analyzed: vā hutam vā loke yadi vā sāvake puggalāḥ dhamma dasā te bho vādī nāma saḥ hoti yathābhāvī guṇena saḥ iti idha
translated: What is given, what is offered in the world, or what is given to disciples, those people who are seers of Dhamma, he is called a “Sir” by them, he is as he is by virtue of his qualities.

original: Pubbasmiṃyevādhikāre –
analyzed: pubbasmin eva adhikāre
translated: In the preceding section:

original: 38. Rassaṃ.
analyzed: rassam
translated: Rassaṃ.

original: Sarā kho byañjane pare kvaci rassaṃ pappontīti chandānurakkhaṇe, āgame, saṃyoge ca rassattaṃ.
analyzed: sarā khaḥ byañjane pare kvaci rassam papponti iti chanda anurakkhaṇe āgame saṃyoge ca rassa ttam
translated: Sometimes the short vowel occurs in a word with a following consonant. In the preservation of the metre, in the continuation of the text, and in the connection of the words, the short vowel is a fact.

original: Chandānurakkhaṇe tāva yiṭṭhaṃva hutaṃva loke, yadiva sāvake, puggala dhammadasā te, bhovādi nāma so hoti, yathābhāvi guṇena so.
analyzed: chanda anurakkhaṇe tāva loke yat iva sāvake puggala dhamma dasā te bho vādi nāma saḥ hoti yathābhāvi guṇena so
translated: In the preservation of the metre, for instance: What is given, what is offered in the world, or what is given to disciples, those people who are seers of Dhamma, he is called a “Sir” by them, he is as he is by virtue of his qualities.

original: Āgame yathayidaṃ, sammadakkhāto.
analyzed: āgame yathayidam sammad akkhāto
translated: In the continuation of the text, for instance: Thus is the right teaching well-proclaimed.

original: Saṃyoge parākamo parakkamo, āsādo assādo, evaṃ taṇhakkhayo, jhānassa lābhimhi, vasimhi, thullaccayo.
analyzed: saṃyoge parākamaḥ parakkamaḥ āsādaḥ assādaḥ evam taṇha khayaḥ jhānassa lābhimhi vasimhi thullaccayo
translated: In the connection of the words, for instance: The highest, the supreme, the satisfaction, the satisfaction, thus the destruction of craving, I have attained jhāna, I have mastery, a grave offence.

original: Kvacīti kiṃ? Māyidaṃ, manasā daññā vimuttānaṃ, yathākkamaṃ, ākhyātikaṃ, dīyyati, sūyyati.
analyzed: kvaci iti kim manasā daññā yathākkamam ākhyātikam dīyyati sūyyati
translated: Where? What? Māyidaṃ, manasā, daññā, vimuttānaṃ, yathākkamaṃ, ākhyātikaṃ, dīyyati, sūyyati.

original: Eso kho byantiṃ kāhiti, so gacchaṃ na nivattati iccatra –
analyzed: saḥ gaccham na nivattati id catra
translated: Eso kho byantiṃ kāhiti, so gacchaṃ na nivattati iccatra –

original: Tasmiṃyevādhikāre –
analyzed: tasmin ya eva adhikāre
translated: Tasmiṃyevādhikāre –

original: 39. Lopañca tatrākāro.
analyzed: lopaḥ ca tatra akāraḥ
translated: . Lopañca tatrākāro.

original: Sarā kho byañjane pare kvaci lopaṃ papponti, tatra lutte ṭhāne akārāgamo ca hoti. Etatasaddantokārassevāyaṃ lopo.
analyzed: sarā khaḥ byañjane pare kvaci lopam tatra lutte ṭhāne akāra āgamaḥ ca hoti lopaḥ
translated: Sarā kho byañjane pare kvaci lopaṃ papponti, tatrutte ṭhāne akārāgamo ca hoti. Etatasaddantokārassevāyaṃ lopo.

original: Esa kho byantiṃ kāhiti, sa gacchaṃ na nivattati, evaṃ esa dhammo, esa pattosi, sa muni, sa sīlavā.
analyzed: esa kho byantim sa gaccham na nivattati evam esa dhammo esa pattosi sa muni sa sīlavā
translated: Esa kho byantiṃ kāhiti, sa gacchaṃ na nivattati, evaṃ esa dhammo, esa pattosi, sa muni, sa sīlavā.

original: Kvacīti kiṃ? Eso dhammo, so muni, so sīlavā.
analyzed: kvaci iti kim esaḥ dhammo so muni so sīlavā
translated: Where? What? Eso dhammo, so muni, so sīlavā.

original: Casaddena etasaddantassa sarepi kvaci lopo. Yathā – esa attho, esa ābhogo, esa idāni.
analyzed: ca saddena eta sadda antassa sare pi kvaci lopaḥ yathā esa atthaḥ esa ābhogaḥ esa idāni
translated: Casaddena etasaddantassa sarepi kvaci lopo. Yathā – esa attho, esa ābhogo, esa idāni.

original: Vipariṇāmena “saramhā, byañjanassā”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: vipariṇāmena saramhā byañjanassa ati ca vattate
translated: Vipariṇāmena “saramhā, byañjanassā”ti ca vattate.

original: 40. Paradvebhāvo ṭhāne.
analyzed: para dvebhāvaḥ ṭhāne
translated: . Paradvebhāvo ṭhāne.

original: Saramhā parassa byañjanassa dvebhāvo hoti ṭhāne. Dvinnaṃ bhāvo dvibhāvo, so eva dvebhāvo.
analyzed: saramhā parassa byañjanassa dvebhāvaḥ hoti ṭhāne dvinnam bhāvaḥ dvi bhāvaḥ saḥ eva dvebhāvaḥ
translated: Saramhā parassa byañjanassa dvebhāvo hoti ṭhāne. Dvinnaṃ bhāvo dvibhāvo, so eva dvebhāvo.

original: Ettha ca ṭhānaṃ nāma rassākārato paraṃ pa pati paṭikamukusa kudha kī gaha juta ñāsi🔽su sambhū sara sasādīnamādibyañjanānaṃ dvebhāvaṃ, tika taya tiṃsa vatādīnamādi ca,🔽vatu vaṭudisādīnamantañca, u du ni-upasagga ta catu cha santasaddādesādiparañca,🔽apadantā nākāradīghato yakārādi ca,
analyzed: ettha ca ṭhānam nāma rassa ākārato param pa pati  su sambhū sara sasa ādīnam ādi byañjana ānam dvebhāvam tika taya tiṃsa vata ādīnam ādi ca  vatu vaṭu disa ādīnam antañca u du ni upasagga catu cha santa sadda desa ādi parañca  a pada antāḥ na ākāra dīghataḥ yakāra ādi ca
translated: And here a place is the two-part state of the initial letters r, s, p, p, p, m, k, k, k, g, g, h, j, j, ñ, ñ, y, y, v, v, s, s, s, h, and so on, and the initial of t, t, t, t, t, v, v, v, and so on,🔽and the end of v, v, v, and so on, and the end of u, u, u, u, u, and so on, and the end of the prefix u, and the end of t, c, c, s, s, s, and so on, and the end of a, ā, i, i, u, u, e, e, o, o,🔽and the long ā, and the y, r, l, v, and so on,🔽

original: Yavataṃ talanādīna-mādeso ca sayādinaṃ;🔽Saha dhātvantassādeso, sīsakāro tapādito.🔽Chandānurakkhaṇe ca – ghara jhe dhaṃsu bhamādīnamādi ca, rassākārato vaggānaṃ catutthadutiyā ca iccevamādi.🔽Tattha pa pati paṭīsu tāva – idha pamādo idhappamādo, evaṃ appamādo, vippayutto,
analyzed: ya vatam tala na ādīnam ādesaḥ ca saya ādinam  saha dhātu antaḥ sa ādesaḥ sīsakāraḥ ta pa ā t itaḥ  chanda anurakkhaṇe ca ghara jhe dhaṃsu bhama ādīnam ādi ca rassa ākārataḥ vaggānam catuttha dutiyā ca i ca evamādi  tattha pa pati paṭīsu tāva idha pamādaḥ idhappamādaḥ evam appamādaḥ vippayutto
translated: And here a place is the first two of the letters beginning with r, p, p, p, k, k, k, k, g, g, h, j, ñ, ñ, ñ, ñ, y, y, y, y, r, r, r, r, l, l, l, l, v, v, v, v, s, s, s, s, h, h, h, h, m, m, m, m, n, n, n, n, y, y, y, y, w, w, w, w, o, o, o, o, a, a, a, a, ā, ā, ā, ā, i, i, i, i, u, u, u, u, e, e, e, e, o, o, o, o, am, am, am, am, aṃ, aṃ, aṃ, aṃ, āṃ, āṃ, āṃ, āṃ, iṃ, iṃ, iṃ, iṃ, uṃ, uṃ, uṃ, uṃ, eṃ, eṃ, eṃ, eṃ, oṃ, oṃ, oṃ, oṃ,

original: suppasanno, sammā padhānaṃ sammappadhānaṃ, rassattaṃ, appativattiyo, adhipatippaccayo,
analyzed: su pasannaḥ sammā padhānam sammappadhānam rassattam appativattiyaḥ adhipati paccayo
translated: and the first of the letters beginning with s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s, s,

original: suppatiṭṭhito, appaṭipuggalo, vippaṭisāro, suppaṭipanno, suppaṭipatti.🔽Kamādidhātūsu – pakkamo, paṭikkamo, hetukkamo, ākamati akkamati, evaṃ parakkamati, yathākkamaṃ.
analyzed: suppatiṭṭhitaḥ appaṭipuggalaḥ vippaṭisāraḥ suppaṭipanno suppaṭipatti  kama ādi dhātūsu pakkamaḥ paṭikkamaḥ hetukkamaḥ ākamati akkamati evam parakkamati yathākkamam
translated: well-established, without opponent, without remorse, well-practised, well-practised conduct.

original: Pakkosati, paṭikkosati, anukkosati, ākosati, akkosati.
analyzed: pakkosati paṭikkosati anukkosati ākosati akkosati
translated: In the realms of sensuality, etc.: departure, return, sequence of cause, he goes, he steps, thus he goes, he invites, he rejects, he follows, he speaks, he reviles.

original: Akkuddho, atikkodho.🔽Dhanakkīto, vikkayo, anukkayo.
analyzed: akkuddhaḥ atikkodhaḥ  dhanakkītaḥ vikkayaḥ anukkayaḥ
translated: Not angry, not very angry.🔽Bought with money, sold, followed.

original: Paggaho, viggaho, anuggaho, niggaho, candaggaho, diṭṭhiggāho.
analyzed: paggahaḥ viggahaḥ anuggahaḥ niggahaḥ candaggahaḥ diṭṭhiggāho
translated: Grasping, disclaiming, supporting, rejecting, grasping the moon, grasping a view.

original: Pajjoto, vijjotati, ujjoto.
analyzed: pajjotaḥ vijjotati ujjotaḥ
translated: Shining, shining forth, shining well.

original: Kataññū, viññū, paññāṇaṃ, viññāṇaṃ, anuññā, manuññā, samaññā.🔽Avassayo, nissayo, samussayo.🔽Appassuto, vissuto, bahussuto, āsavā assavā.
analyzed: kataññū viññū paññāṇam viññāṇam anuññā manuññā samaññā  avassayaḥ nissayaḥ samussayaḥ  appassutaḥ vissutaḥ bahu ssutaḥ āsavā assavā
translated: Thankful, discerning, wisdom, consciousness, allowed, agreeable, agreement.🔽Not to be relied on, to be relied on, to be relied on together.

original: Passambhanto, vissambhati.🔽Aṭṭassaro, vissarati, anussarati.
analyzed: passambhantaḥ vissambhati  aṭṭassaraḥ vissarati anussarati
translated: Not learned, well-learned, much learned, taints, not taints.

original: Passasanto, vissasanto, mahussasanto, āsāso assāso.
analyzed: passasantaḥ vissasantaḥ mahussasantaḥ āsāsaḥ assāsaḥ
translated: Calming, trusting, much trusting, hope, hope.

original: Avissajjento, vissajjento, pariccajanto, upaddavo, upakkiliṭṭho, mittaddu, āyabbayo, udabbahi iccādi.🔽Saramhāti kiṃ? Sampayutto, sampatijāto, sampaṭicchannaṃ, saṅkamanto, saṅgaho.
analyzed: a vissajjentaḥ vissajjentaḥ pariccajantaḥ upaddavaḥ upakkiliṭṭhaḥ mittaddu āyabbayaḥ udabbahi iccādi  saramha ati kim sampayuttaḥ sampatijātaḥ sampaṭicchannam saṅkamantaḥ saṅgahaḥ
translated: not giving back, giving back, handing over, a hindrance, soiled, a friend’s foe, a danger, a threat, etc.🔽What with sam? associated, born together, consenting, going together, inclusion.

original: Ṭhāneti kiṃ? Mā ca pamādo, patigayhati, vacīpakopaṃ rakkheyya, ye pamattā yathā matā, manopakopaṃ rakkheyya, idha modati, pecca modati.🔽Tikādīsu – kusalattikaṃ, pītittikaṃ, hetuttikaṃ, vedanāttikaṃ, lokattayaṃ, bodhittayaṃ,🔽vatthuttayaṃ. Ekattiṃsa, dvattiṃsa, catuttiṃsa. Sīlabbataṃ, subbato, sappītiko, samannāgato, punappunaṃ iccādi.🔽Vatu vaṭu disādīnamante yathā – vattati, vaṭṭati, dassanaṃ, phasso iccādi.🔽U du ni upasaggādiparesu – ukaṃso ukkaṃso. Dukaraṃ dukkaraṃ, nikaṅkho nikkaṅkhe.
