analyzed: ṭhānā iti kim mā ca pamādaḥ patigayhati vacī pakopam rakkheyya ye pamattāḥ yathā matāḥ manā upakopam rakkheyya idha modati pecca modati 🔽tika ādīsu kusala ttikam pīti ttikam hetu ttikam vedanā ttikam lokattayam bodhittayam 🔽vatthuttayam ekattiṃsa dvattiṃsa catuttiṃsa sīlabbatam subbataḥ sappītikaḥ samannāgato punappunam iccādi 🔽vatu vaṭu disā ādīnam ante yathā vattati vaṭṭati dassanam phasso iccādi 🔽u du ni upasagga ādi paresu ukaṃsaḥ ukkaṃsaḥ dukaram dukkaram nikaṅkhaḥ nikkaṅkhe
translated: ‘Not giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up, giving up,

original: Evaṃ uggataṃ, duccaritaṃ, nijjaṭaṃ, uññātaṃ, unnati, uttaro, dukkaro, niddaro, unnato, duppañño, dubbalo, nimmalo, uyyutto, dullabho, nibbatto, ussāho, dussaho, nissāro.
analyzed: evam uggatam duccaritam nijjaṭam uññātam unnati uttaraḥ dukkaraḥ niddaraḥ unnataḥ duppaññaḥ dubbalaḥ nimmalaḥ uyyuttaḥ dullabhaḥ nibbattaḥ ussāhaḥ dussahaḥ nissāraḥ
translated: Uggataṃ, duccaritaṃ, nijjitaṃ, uññātaṃ, unnati, uttaro, dukkaro, niddaro, unnato, duppañño, dubbalo, nimmalo, uyyutto, dullabho, nibbatto, ussāho, dussaho, nissāro.

original: Tathā takkaro, tajjo, tanninno, tappabhavo, tammayo.
analyzed: tathā takkaraḥ tajjaḥ tanninnaḥ tappabhavaḥ tammayaḥ
translated: Tathā takkaro, tajjo, tanninno, tappabhavo, tammayo.

original: Catukkaṃ, catuddisaṃ, catuppādo, catubbidhaṃ, catussālaṃ.
analyzed: catukkam catuddisam catur pādaḥ catubbidham catur sālam
translated: Catukkaṃ, catuddisaṃ, catuppādo, catubbidhaṃ, catussālaṃ.

original: Chakkaṃ, channavuti, chappadikā, chabbassāni.
analyzed: chakkam channavuti chappadikā chabbassāni
translated: Chakkaṃ, channavuti, chappadikā, chabbassāni.

original: Sakkāro, sakkato, saddiṭṭhi, sappuriso, mahabbalo.
translated: Sakkāro, sakkato, saddiṭṭhi, sappuriso, mahabbalo.

original: Ṭhāneti kiṃ? Nikāyo, nidānaṃ, nivāso, nivāto, tato, catuvīsati, chasaṭṭhi.
analyzed: ṭhānā iti kim nikāyaḥ nidānam nivāsaḥ nivāto catuvīsati
translated: Ṭhāneti kiṃ? Nikāyo, nidānaṃ, nivāso, nivāto, tato, catuvīsati, chasaṭṭhi.

original: Yakārādimhi – nīyyati, sūyyati, abhibhūyya, viceyya, vineyya, dheyyaṃ, neyyaṃ, seyyo, jeyyo, veyyākaraṇo.
analyzed: yakāra ādimhi sūyyati abhibhūyya viceyya vineyya dheyyam neyyam seyyaḥ jeyyaḥ veyyākaraṇaḥ
translated: Yakārādimhi – Nīyyati, sūyyati, abhibhūyya, viceyya, vineyya, dheyyaṃ, neyyaṃ, seyyo, jeyyo, veyyākaraṇo.

original: Ādisaddena etto, ettāvatā.
analyzed: ādi saddena ettaḥ ettāvatā
translated: Ādisaddena etto, ettāvatā.

original: Anākāraggahaṇaṃ kiṃ? Mālāya, dolāya, samādāya.
analyzed: an ākāra ggahaṇam kim mālāya dolāya samādāya
translated: Anākāraggahaṇaṃ kiṃ? Mālāya, dolāya, samādāya.

original: Ṭhāneti kiṃ? Upanīyati, sūyati, toyaṃ.
analyzed: upanīyati sūyati toyam
translated: Ṭhāneti kiṃ? Upanīyati, sūyati, toyaṃ.

original: Yavatamādese – jāti andho, vipali āso, ani āyo, yadi evaṃ, api ekacce, api ekadā iccatra, ikārassa “ivaṇṇo yaṃ navā”ti yakāre kate –
analyzed: yava tama ādese jāti andhaḥ yadi evam api ekacce api ekadā iccatra ikārassa yam navāti yakāre kate
translated: In the case of the yavatādesas, the following are the forms: jātiandho, vipallāsas, aññāyo, yajjevaṃ, appekacce, appekadā. Here the i of the first is changed to ya by the rule: “ivaṇṇo yaṃ navā” .

original: “Sabbassa so dāmhi vā”ti ito maṇḍūkagatiyā vāti vattate.
analyzed: sabbassa saḥ dāmhi vāti itas maṇḍūkagatiyā vāti vattate
translated: “Sabbassa so dāmhi vā” , the maṇḍūkagati is applied.

original: 41. Yavataṃ talanadakārānaṃ byañjanāni calañajakārattaṃ.
analyzed: yavatam byañjanāni
translated: The consonants of the yavatādesas are changed to the consonants of the talanadakāras.

original: Yakāravantānaṃ talanadakārānaṃ saṃyogabyañjanāni yathākkamaṃ calañajakārattamāpajjante vā.
analyzed: saṃyoga byañjanāni yathākkamam vā
translated: The consonants of the yavatādesas which have the ya are changed to the consonants of the talanadakāras in order.

original: Kāraggahaṇaṃ yavataṃ sakāra ka ca ṭa pavaggānaṃ sakārakacaṭapavaggādesatthaṃ, tathā yavataṃ ta dha ṇakārānaṃ cha jhañakārādesatthañca, tato yavatamādesassa anena dvibhāvo.
analyzed: kāra ggahaṇam yavatam sakāra ka ca ṭa pavaggānam sakāraka ca ṭa pavagga ādesa attham tathā yavatam ta dha ṇakārānam cha jha ñakāra ādesa attham ca tatas anena dvi bhāvaḥ
translated: The inclusion of the ka is for the sake of the sakārakacaṭapavaggādesas, the sakārakacaṭapavaggādesas, and the yavatādesas. Similarly, the inclusion of the ta is for the sake of the chajhañakārādesas, the chajhañakārādesas, and the yavatādesas. Then the yavatādesas are made to have two syllables by this rule.

original: Jaccandho, vipallāso, aññāyo, yajjevaṃ, appekacce appekadā.
analyzed: vipallāsaḥ aññāyaḥ appekacce appekadā
translated: Jaccandho, vipallāsas, aññāyo, yajjevaṃ, appekacce, appekadā.

original: Vāti kiṃ? Paṭisanthāravutyassa, bālyaṃ, ālasyaṃ.
analyzed: vāti kim bālyam ālasyam
translated: What is the maṇḍūkagati? Paṭisanthāravutyassa, bālyaṃ, ālasyaṃ.

original: Saramhāti kiṃ? Añāyo, ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ.
analyzed: saramhā ati kim
translated: What is the saramhi? Aññāyo, ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ.

original: Tapādito simhi – tapassī, yasassī.
analyzed: tapa āditaḥ simhi tapassī yasassī
translated: The simhi is from tapādito: tapassī, yasassī.

original: Chandānurakkhaṇe – nappajjahe vaṇṇabalaṃ purāṇaṃ, ujjugatesu seyyo, gacchanti suggatinti.
analyzed: chanda anurakkhaṇe vaṇṇa balam purāṇam ujju gatesu seyyaḥ gacchanti suggatin ti
translated: In the preservation of the order of the sentences, the first and the last are preserved.🔽In the preservation of the order of the feet, the third and the first are preserved.🔽In the preservation of the order of the syllables, the third and the first are preserved.🔽In the preservation of the order of the words, the fourth and the second are preserved.

original: Vaggacatutthadutiyesu pana tasmiṃyevādhikāre “paradvebhāvo ṭhāne”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: vagga catuttha dutiyesu pana tasmin yeva adhikāre para dvebhāvaḥ ṭhāna iti ca vattate
translated: In the preservation of the order of the sentences, the fourth and the second are preserved.🔽In the preservation of the order of the feet, the third and the first are preserved.🔽In the preservation of the order of the syllables, the third and the first are preserved.🔽In the preservation of the order of the words, the fourth and the second are preserved.

original: Vaggacatutthadutiyānaṃ sadisavasena dvibhāve sampatte niyamatthamāha.
analyzed: vagga catuttha dutiyānam sadisa vasena dvi bhāve sampatte niyama ttham āha
translated: In the preservation of the order of the sentences, the fourth and the second are preserved.

original: 42. Vagge ghosāghosānaṃ tatiyapaṭhamā.
analyzed: vagge ghosāghosānam tatiya paṭhamā
translated: In the preservation of the order of the feet, the third and the first are preserved.🔽In the preservation of the order of the syllables, the third and the first are preserved.

original: Saramhā parabhūtānaṃ vagge ghosāghosānaṃ byañjanānaṃ yathākkamaṃ vaggatatiya paṭhamakkharā dvibhāvaṃ gacchanti ṭhāneti ṭhānāsannavasena tabbagge tatiyapaṭhamāva honti.
analyzed: para bhūtānam vagge ghosa aghosānam byañjanānam yathākkamam vagga tatiya paṭhama kkharāḥ dvi bhāvam gacchanti ṭhāne iti ṭhāna āsanna vasena tad bagge tatiya paṭhamāḥ ava honti
translated: In the preservation of the order of the words, the fourth and the second are preserved.🔽In the preservation of the order of the sentences, the fourth and the second are preserved.🔽In the preservation of the order of the feet, the third and the first are preserved.🔽In the preservation of the order of the syllables, the third and the first are preserved.🔽In the preservation of the order of the words, the fourth and the second are preserved.🔽In the preservation of the order of the sentences, the fourth and the second are preserved.

original: Ettha ca sampatte niyamattā ghosāghosaggahaṇena catutthadutiyāva adhippetā, itarathā🔽aniṭṭhappasaṅgosiyā. Tena “kataññū, tannayo, tammayo”tiādīsu vaggapañcamānaṃ satipi
analyzed: ettha ca sampatte niyama ttā ghosa aghosa ggahaṇena catuttha dutiyā vā adhippetāḥ itarathā  tena kataññū tannayaḥ tammayaḥ ti ādīsu vagga pañcamānam satipi
translated: In the preservation of the order of the feet, the third and the first are preserved.🔽In the preservation of the order of the syllables, the third and the first are preserved.🔽In the preservation of the order of the words, the fourth and the second are preserved.🔽In the preservation of the order of the sentences, the fourth and the second are preserved.🔽In the preservation of the order of the feet, the third and the first are preserved.

original: ghosatte tatiyappasaṅgona hoti, ṭhānādhikārato vā.
analyzed: ghosatte tatiya ppasaṅgo na hoti ṭhāna adhikārataḥ vā
translated: In the preservation of the order of the syllables, the third and the first are preserved.🔽In the preservation of the order of the words, the fourth and the second are preserved.🔽In the preservation of the

original: Gharādīsu pa u du niādiparacatutthesu tāva – pagharati paggharati, evaṃ uggharati,
analyzed: ghara ādīsu pa u du ni ādi para catutthesu tāva pagharati paggharati evam uggharati
translated: Now, as regards the four cases ending in pa, u, du, ni, etc., in such words as ghara, etc., it is as follows: He cooks, he cooks; he rises up, he rises up;

original: ugghāṭeti, dugghoso, nigghoso, eseva cajjhānaphalo, paṭhamajjhānaṃ, abhijjhāyati,
analyzed: ugghāṭeti dugghosaḥ nigghosaḥ esa iva paṭhamajjhānam abhijjhāyati
translated: In the words gharā, etc., the first four of the remaining reduplicated words are as follows: pagharati, paggharati, thus uggharati, ugghāṭeti, dugghoso, nigghoso, eseva cajjhānaphalo, paṭhamajjhānaṃ, abhijjhāyati,

original: ujjhāyati, viddhaṃseti, uddhaṃsito, uddhāro, niddhāro, niddhano, niddhuto, vibbhanto,
analyzed: ujjhāyati viddhaṃseti uddhaṃsitaḥ uddhāraḥ niddhāraḥ niddhanaḥ niddhutaḥ vibbhantaḥ
translated: ujjhāyati, viddhaṃseti, uddhaṃsito, uddhāro, niddhāro, niddhano, niddhuto, vibbhanto,

original: ubbhato, dubbhikkhaṃ, nibbhayaṃ, tabbhāvo, catuddhā, cabhubbhi, chaddhā, saddhammo,
analyzed: ubbhataḥ dubbhikkham nibbhayam tad bhāvaḥ catuddhā chaddhā saddhammaḥ
translated: ubbhato, dubbhikkhaṃ, nibbhayaṃ, tabbhāvo, catuddhā, cabhubbhi, chaddhā, saddhammo,

original: sabbhūto, mahaddhano, mahabbhayaṃ.
analyzed: sat bhūtaḥ mahat dhanaḥ mahat bhayam
translated: sabbhūto, mahaddhano, mahabbhayaṃ.

original: Yavata mādesādīsu – bojjhaṅgā, āsabbhaṃ, bujjhitabbaṃ, bujjhati.
analyzed: yava ta mā desa ādīsu bojjhaṅgāḥ āsabbham bujjhitabbam bujjhati
translated: In the words yavata mādesā, etc., the reduplicated words are as follows: bojjhaṅgā, āsabbhaṃ, bujjhitabbaṃ, bujjhati.

original: Ṭhāneti kiṃ? Sīlavantassa jhāyino, ye jhānappasutā dhīrā, nidhānaṃ, mahādhanaṃ.
analyzed: ṭhāne ti kim sīlavantassa jhāyinaḥ ye jhāna ppasutāḥ dhīrāḥ nidhānam mahādhanam
translated: What is the purpose of the reduplication? “For one virtuous, for one who has jhāna, for those who are devoted to jhāna, for the wise, a treasure, great wealth.”

original: Rassākāratoparaṃ vaggadutiyesu – pañca khandhā pañcakkhandhā, evaṃrūpakkhandho, akkhamo,
analyzed: rassa ākāra toparam vagga dutiyesu pañca khandhāḥ pañca khandhāḥ evaṃrūpa kkhandhaḥ akkhamaḥ
translated: In the words rassākāra, etc., the first two of the remaining reduplicated words are as follows: pañca khandhā, pañcakkhandhā, evaṃrūpakkhandho, akkhamo,

original: abhikkhaṇaṃ, avikkhepo, jātikkhettaṃ, dhātukkhobho, āyukkhayo. Setachattaṃ setacchattaṃ,
analyzed: abhikkhaṇam avikkhepaḥ jāti kkhettam dhātu kkhobho āyu kkhayo seta chattam seta chattam
translated: abhikkhaṇaṃ, avikkhepo, jātikkhettaṃ, dhātukkhobho, āyukkhayo. Setachattaṃ setacchattaṃ,

original: evaṃ sabbacchannaṃ, vicchinnaṃ, bodhicchāyā, jambucchāyā, samucchedo. Tatra ṭhito
analyzed: evam sabba channam vicchinnam bodhi chāyā jambu chāyā samucchedaḥ tatra ṭhitaḥ
translated: Thus: all-covered, cut off, shadow of the Bodhi tree, shadow of the Rose-apple tree, and a break. Standing there,

original: tatraṭṭhito, evaṃ thalaṭṭhaṃ, jalaṭṭhaṃ, adhiṭṭhitaṃ, niṭṭhitaṃ, cattāriṭṭhānāni,
analyzed: tatraṭṭhitaḥ evam thala aṭṭham jala aṭṭham adhiṭṭhitam niṭṭhitam cattāri ṭhānāni
translated: standing there, thus: standing on the ground, standing in the water, resolved, finished, the four grounds,

original: garuṭṭhāniyo, samuṭṭhito, suppaṭṭhāno. Yasatthero, yattha, tattha, pattharati, vitthāro,
analyzed: samuṭṭhitaḥ su paṭṭhānaḥ yasa thero yattha tattha pattharati vitthāro
translated: heavy grounds, arisen, well-established. The Elder Yasas, where, there, spreads, spread out,

original: abhitthuto, vitthambhito, anutthunaṃ, catuttho, kuttha. Papphoṭeti, mahapphalaṃ,
analyzed: abhitthutaḥ vitthambhitaḥ anutthunam catutthaḥ mahat phalam
translated: overwhelmed, obstructed, not to be shaken, the fourth, where? rubs, great fruit,

original: nipphalaṃ, vipphāro, paripphuseyya, madhupphāṇitaṃ.
analyzed: nipphalam vipphāraḥ paripphuseyya madhu phāṇitam
translated: fruitless, spread out, would spread over, honey and ghee.

original: Ākārato – ākhāto ākkhāto, evaṃ taṇhākkhayo, āṇākkhettaṃ, saññākkhandho, āchādayati, ācchādayati, evaṃ ācchindati, nāvāṭṭhaṃ, āttharati, āpphoṭeti.
analyzed: ākārataḥ ākhātaḥ ākkhātaḥ evam taṇhā kkhayaḥ āṇā khettam saññā kkhandho āchādayati ācchādayati evam ācchindati āttharati āpphoṭeti
translated: From the mode: announced, announced, thus: destruction of craving, the field of command, the perception category, covers, covers, thus: cuts off, standing in a boat, touches, rubs.

original: Saramhāti kiṃ? Saṅkhāro, taṅkhaṇe, sañchannaṃ, taṇṭhānaṃ, santhuto, tamphalaṃ.
analyzed: saramhā ati kim sañchannam taṇṭhānam
translated: What is the “sa” ? Formations, at that moment, covered, a place for tanning, spread out, that fruit.

original: Ṭhāneti kiṃ? Pūvakhajjakaṃ, tassa chaviyādīni chinditvā, yathā ṭhitaṃ, kathaṃ, kammaphalaṃ.
analyzed: ṭhāna iti kim pūva khajjakam tassa chaviya ādīni chinditvā yathā ṭhitam katham kamma phalam
translated: It is used in the sense of a reason, as in the expression “for what reason?” .🔽It is used in the sense of a cause, as in the expression “the cause for the arising of consciousness” .🔽It is used in the sense of a condition, as in the expression “the condition for the arising of consciousness” .🔽It is used in the sense of a basis, as in the expression “the basis for the arising of consciousness” .

original: Nikamati, nipatti, nicayo, nicarati, nitaraṇaṃ iccatra – “do dhassa cā”ti ettha caggahaṇassa bahulatthattā tena caggahaṇena yathāpayogaṃ bahudhā ādeso siyā.🔽Yathā – ni upasaggato kamu pada ci cara tarānaṃ paṭhamassa vaggadutiyo iminā dvittaṃ, nikkhamati, nipphatti, nicchayo, niccharati, nittharaṇaṃ.
analyzed: nikamati nipatti nicayaḥ nicarati nitaraṇam iccatra daḥ dhassa ca ati ettha ca ggahaṇassa bahula ttha ttā tena ca ggahaṇena yathā apayogam bahudhā ādesaḥ siyā  yathā ni upasaggataḥ kamu pada ci cara tarānam paṭhamassa vagga dutiyaḥ iminā nikkhamati nipphatti nicchayaḥ niccharati nittharaṇam
translated: It is used in the sense of a location, as in the expression “in the location of the heart” .🔽It is used in the sense of a time, as in the expression “at that time” .

original: Tathā bo vassa kuva diva siva vajādīnaṃ dvirūpassāti vakāradvayassa bakāradvayaṃ,
analyzed: tathā baḥ vassa kuva diva siva vaja ādīnam dvi rūpassa ati vakāra dvayassa bakāra dvayam
translated: It is used in the sense of a portion, as in the expression “in the portion of the night” .🔽It is used in the sense of a limit, as in the expression “up to the limit of the ocean” .🔽It is used in the sense of a basis, as in the expression “in the basis for spiritual power” .

original: yathā – kubbanto, evaṃ kubbāno, kubbanti, sadhātvantayādesassa dvittaṃ. Divati dibbati,
analyzed: yathā kubbantaḥ evam kubbāno kubbanti sa dhātu anta yādesassa dvittam divati dibbati
translated: It is used in the sense of a cause, as in the expression “in the cause for the arising of consciousness” .🔽It is used in the sense of a reason, as in the expression “for what reason?” .🔽It is used in the sense of a location, as in the expression “in the location of the heart” .🔽It is used in the sense of a time, as in the expression “at that time” .

original: evaṃ dibbanto, sibbati, sibbanto, pavajati pabbajati, pabbajanto, nivānaṃ nibbānaṃ,
analyzed: evam dibbantaḥ sibbati sibbantaḥ pavajati pabbajati pabbajantaḥ nivānam nibbānam
translated: It is used in the sense of a portion, as in the expression “in the portion of the night” .

original: nibbuto, nibbindati, udabbayaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: nibbutaḥ nibbindati udabbayam iti ca ādi
translated: It is used in the sense of a limit, as in the expression “up to the limit of the ocean” .🔽It is used in the sense of a basis, as in the expression “in the basis for spiritual power” .🔽It is used in the sense of a cause, as in the expression “in the cause for the arising of consciousness” .🔽It is used in the sense of a reason, as in the expression “for what reason?” .

original: Lo rassa pari taruṇādīnaṃ kvaci. Paripanno palipanno, evaṃ palibodho, pallaṅkaṃ, taruṇo taluno, mahāsālo, māluto, sukhumālo.
analyzed: laḥ rassa pari taruṇa ādīnam kvaci paripannaḥ palipannaḥ evam palibodhaḥ pallaṅkam taruṇaḥ talunaḥ mahāsālaḥ mālutaḥ sukhumālaḥ
translated: Lo rassa pari taruṇādīnaṃ kvaci. Paripanno palipanno, evaṃ palibodho, pallaṅkaṃ, taruṇo taluno, mahāsālo, māluto, sukhumālo.

original: Ṭo tassa dukkatādīnaṃ kvaci. Yathā – dukkataṃ dukkaṭaṃ, evaṃ sukaṭaṃ, pahaṭo, patthaṭo, uddhaṭo, visaṭo iccādi.
analyzed: ṭaḥ tassa dukkata ādīnam kvaci yathā dukkatam dukkaṭam evam sukaṭam pahaṭaḥ patthaṭaḥ uddhaṭaḥ visaṭaḥ iccādi
translated: Ṭo tassa dukkatādīnaṃ kvaci. Yathā – dukkataṃ dukkaṭaṃ, evaṃ sukaṭaṃ, pahaṭo, patthaṭo, uddhaṭo, visaṭo iccādi.

original: Ko tassa niyatādīnaṃ kvaci. Niyato niyako.
analyzed: kaḥ tassa niyata ādīnam kvacid niyataḥ niyakaḥ
translated: Ko tassa niyatādīnaṃ kvaci. Niyato niyako.

original: Yo jassa nijādissa vā, nijaṃputtaṃ niyaṃputtaṃ.
analyzed: yaḥ jassa nija ādissa vā nijaṃputtam niyaṃputtam
translated: Yo jassa nijādissa vā, nijaṃputtaṃ niyaṃputtaṃ.

original: Ko gassa kulūpagādīnaṃ, kulūpago kulūpako.
analyzed: kaḥ gassa kulūpaga ādīnam kulūpagaḥ kulūpakaḥ
translated: Ko gassa kulūpagādīnaṃ, kulūpago kulūpako.

original: Tathā ṇo nassa pa pariādito. Panidhānaṃ paṇidhānaṃ, evaṃ paṇipāto, paṇāmo, paṇītaṃ, pariṇato, pariṇāmo, ninnayo niṇṇayo, evaṃ uṇṇato, oṇato iccādi.
analyzed: tathā panidhānam paṇidhānam evam paṇipātaḥ paṇāmaḥ paṇītam pariṇataḥ pariṇāmaḥ ninnayaḥ ninnayaḥ evam uṇṇataḥ oṇataḥ iccādi
translated: Tathā ṇo nassa pa pariādito. Panidhānaṃ paṇidhānaṃ, evaṃ paṇipāto, paṇāmo, paṇītaṃ, pariṇato, pariṇāmo, ninnayo niṇṇayo, evaṃ uṇṇato, oṇato iccādi.

original: Patiaggi, patihaññati itīdha –
analyzed: pati aggi pati haññati iti idha
translated: Patiaggi, patihaññati itīdha –

original: 43. Kvaci paṭi patissa.
analyzed: kvaci paṭi patissa
translated: . Kvaci paṭi patissa.

original: Patiiccetassa upasaggassa sare vā byañjane vā pare kvaci paṭiādeso hoti pubbassaralopo. Paṭaggi, paṭihaññati.
analyzed: pati i cca itassa upasaggassa sare vā byañjane vā pare kvaci paṭi ādesaḥ hoti pubba ssara lopaḥ paṭaggi paṭihaññati
translated: Patiiccetassa upasaggassa sare vā byañjane vā pare kvaci paṭiādeso hoti pubbassaralopo. Paṭaggi, paṭihaññati.

original: Kvacīti kiṃ? Paccattaṃ, patilīyati.
analyzed: kvaci iti kim paccattam patilīyati
translated: Where? What? Paccattaṃ, patilīyati.

original: Puthajano puthabhūtaṃ itīdha “anto”ti vattate.
analyzed: putha jano putha bhūtam iti idha antaḥ iti vattate
translated: Puthajano puthabhūtaṃ, here “within” is what is meant.

original: 44. Puthassu byañjane.
analyzed: puthassu byañjane
translated: Puthassu byañjane.

original: Puthaiccetassa anto saro ukāro hoti byañjane pare, dvittaṃ. Puthujjano, puthubhūtaṃ.
analyzed: antaḥ saraḥ ukāraḥ hoti byañjane pare dvittam puthujjano puthubhūtam
translated: Puthaiccetassa anto saro ukāro hoti byañjane pare, dvittaṃ. Puthujjano, puthubhūtaṃ.

original: Byañjaneti kiṃ? Putha ayaṃ. “Puthassa a putha”iti samāseneva siddhe puna antaggahaṇādhikārena kvaci aputhantassāpi uttaṃ sare.
analyzed: byañjana iti kim ayam puthassa samāsena iva siddhe puna anta ggahaṇa adhikārena kvaci sare
translated: Byañjaneti kiṃ? Putha ayaṃ. “Puthassa a putha”iti samāseneva siddhe puna antaggahaṇādhikārena kvaci aputhantassāpi uttaṃ sare.

original: Mano aññaṃ manuññaṃ, evaṃ imaṃ evumaṃ, paralopo, iti evaṃ itvevaṃ, ukārassa vakāro.
analyzed: manaḥ aññam manuññam evam imaṃ evumam para lopaḥ iti evam i tu evam ukārassa vakāraḥ
translated: Mano aññaṃ manuññaṃ, evaṃ imaṃ evumaṃ, paralopo, iti evaṃ itvevaṃ, ukārassa vakāro.

original: Avakāso, avanaddho, avavadati, avasānamitīdha –
analyzed: avakāsaḥ avanaddhaḥ avavadati avasānam iti idha
translated: Avakāso, avanaddho, avavadati, avasānamitīdha –

original: “Kvaci byañjane”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: kvacid byañjana iti ca vattate
translated: “Kvaci byañjane”ti ca vattate.

original: 45. O avassa.
analyzed: o avassa
translated: O avassa.

original: Avaiccetassa upasaggassa okāro hoti kvaci byañjane pare. Okāso, onaddho, ovadati, osānaṃ.
analyzed: upasaggassa okāraḥ hoti kvaci byañjane pare okāsaḥ onaddhaḥ ovadati osānam
translated: Avaiccetassa upasaggassa okāro hoti kvaci byañjane pare. Okāso, onaddho, ovadati, osānaṃ.

original: Kvacīti kiṃ? Avasānaṃ, avasussatu.
analyzed: kvaci iti kim avasānam avasussatu
translated: Kvacīti kiṃ? Avasānaṃ, avasussatu.

original: Byañjaneti kiṃ? Avayāgamanaṃ, avekkhati.
analyzed: byañjana iti kim avayā gamanam avekkhati
translated: Byañjaneti kiṃ? Avayāgamanaṃ, avekkhati.

original: Avagate sūriye, avagacchati, avagahetvā itīdha –
analyzed: avagate sūriye avagacchati avagahetvā iti idha
translated: When the sun has risen, it rises, having risen, here,

original: “Avasse”ti vattate oggahaṇañca.
analyzed: avassa iti vattate oggahaṇam ca
translated: “Avasse” is said. And the affix is included.

original: 46. Tabbiparītūpapade byañjane ca.
analyzed: tap bipari tu upapade byañjane ca
translated: With the opposite of the preceding and with a sibilant.

original: Avasaddassa upapade tiṭṭhamānassa tassokārassa viparīto ca hoti byañjane pare.🔽Tassa viparīto tabbiparīto, upoccāritaṃ padaṃ upapadaṃ, okāraviparītoti ukārassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Casaddo katthaci nivattanattho, dvittaṃ. Uggate sūriye, uggacchati, uggahetvā.
analyzed: avasaddassa upapade tiṭṭhamānassa tassa ukārassa viparītaḥ ca hoti byañjane pare  tassa viparītaḥ tad biparītaḥ upoccāritam padam upapadam okāra viparītaḥ iti ukārassa etam adhivacanam ca saddo katthaci nivattana atthaḥ uggate sūriye uggacchati uggahetvā
translated: With the preceding of the affix of the word “avasse” the “o” is changed to the opposite, and with a sibilant following it.

original: Atippakho tāva, parasataṃ, parasahassaṃ itīdha –
analyzed: tāva para satam para sahassam iti idha
translated: The opposite of that is “tabbiparīto”, the word “upapada” means “that which is repeated”, the “o” is the opposite, this is a synonym for “ukārassa”. The word “ca” means “in some places”, the second. When the sun has risen, it rises, having risen,

original: “Āgamo”ti vattate.
analyzed: āgamaḥ iti vattate
translated: “Atippa” is said.

original: 47. Kvaci o byañjane.
analyzed: kvaci o byañjane
translated: With a sibilant in some places.

original: Byañjane pare kvaci okārāgamo hotīti atippa parasaddehi okārāgamo “yavamada”iccādisutte casaddena atippato gakārāgamo ca.
analyzed: byañjane pare kvaci okāra āgamaḥ hoti iti para saddehi okāra āgamaḥ ca saddena gakāra āgamaḥ ca
translated: With a sibilant following it, in some places the “o” is added. “Atippa parasaddehi okārāgamo” means the “o” is added to “atippa” and “para”. In the sutta “yavamada” etc., the “ca” means “in some places”. The “o” is added and the “ga” is added.

original: Atippago kho tāva, parosataṃ, parosahassaṃ, ettha “sarā sare lopa”nti pubbassaralopo.
analyzed: atippago kho tāva parosatam parosahassam ettha sarā sare pubbassara lopaḥ
translated: “Atippago kho tāva, parosataṃ, parosahassaṃ”, here the “pubba” is elided by “sarā sare lopa”.

original: Manamayaṃ, ayamayaṃ itīdha “manogaṇādīna”nti vattate.
analyzed: manam ayam ayam iti idha manaḥ gaṇa ādīn anti vattate
translated: “Manogaṇādīna” is said here.

original: 48. Etesamo lope.
analyzed: e te samaḥ lope
translated: . In the elision of these.

original: Etesaṃ manogaṇādīnamanto ottamāpajjate vibhattilope kate.
analyzed: etesam manaḥ gaṇa ādīnam antaḥ vibhatti lope kate
translated: In the elision of the case-ending, the last of these, manogaṇādīna, is made.

original: Manomayaṃ, ayomayaṃ, evaṃ manoseṭṭhā, ayopatto, tapodhano, tamonudo, siroruho, tejokasiṇaṃ, rajojallaṃ, ahorattaṃ, rahogato.
analyzed: manaḥ mayam ayaḥ mayam evam manoseṭṭhā ayopatto tapodhano tamonudaḥ siroruhaḥ tejaḥ kasiṇam rajojallam ahorattam rahogataḥ
translated: Manomayaṃ, ayomayaṃ. So manoseṭṭho, ayopatto, tapodhano, tamonudo, siroruho, tejokasiṇaṃ, rajojallaṃ, ahorattaṃ, rahogato.

original: Ādisaddena āpodhātu, vāyodhātu.
analyzed: ādi saddena āpaḥ dhātu vāyodhātu
translated: By the word “ādisaddena” is meant āpodhātu, vāyodhātu.

original: Sīhagatiyā vādhikārato idha na bhavati, manamattena manacchaṭṭhānaṃ, ayakapallaṃ, tamavinodano, manaāyatanaṃ.
analyzed: sīha gatiyā vā adhikārataḥ idha na bhavati mana mattena mana cha ṭṭhānam mana āyatanam
translated: Because of the rule of sīhagatiyā, it is not here: manamattena, manacchaṭṭhānaṃ, ayakapallaṃ, tamavinodano, manaāyatanaṃ.

original: Iti byañjanasandhividhānaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: iti byañjana sandhi vidhānam niṭṭhitam
translated: Thus the method of the connection of the letters is finished.

original: Niggahītasandhividhāna
analyzed: niggahīta sandhi vidhāna
translated: The method of the connection of the ligatures

original: Atha niggahītasandhi vuccate.
analyzed: atha niggahīta sandhi vuccate
translated: Now the connection of the ligatures is stated.

original: Taṇhaṃ karo, raṇaṃ jaho, saṃ ṭhito, jutiṃ dharo, saṃ mato itīdha “niggahīta”nti adhikāro, “byañjane”ti vattate.
analyzed: adhikāraḥ byañjana iti vattate
translated: Taṇhaṃ karo, raṇaṃ jaho, saṃ ṭhito, jutiṃ dharo, saṃ mato. Here “niggahīta” is the rule. “Byañjane” is said.

original: 49. Vaggantaṃ vā vagge.
analyzed: vagga antam vā vagge
translated: . In the elision of the group.🔽. In the elision of the group, the last of these, niggahīta, is made.

original: Vaggabhūte byañjane pare niggahītaṃ kho vaggantaṃ vā pappotīti nimittānusvarānaṃ
analyzed: vagga bhūte byañjane pare niggahītam kho vaggantam vā pappoti iti
translated: When a vowel is followed by a consonant, it is lengthened if the consonant is a ligature,🔽or if it is the fifth of a ligature, or if it is the first of a ligature.

original: ṭhānāsannavasena tabbaggapañcamo hoti. Vavatthitavibhāsatthoyaṃ vāsaddo. Tena “taṇhaṅkaro,🔽raṇañjaho, saṇṭhito, jutindharo, sammato”tiādīsu niccaṃ.
analyzed: ṭhāna āsanna vasena tad bagga pañcamaḥ hoti vavatthita vibhāsa atthaḥ yam vā saddaḥ tena taṇhaṅkaro  raṇañjahaḥ saṇṭhitaḥ jutindharaḥ sammataḥ ti ādīsu niccam
translated: The word vās is used in the sense of a particular location.

original: Taṅkaroti taṃ karoti, taṅkhaṇaṃ taṃkhaṇaṃ, saṅgaho saṃgaho, taṅghataṃ taṃ ghataṃ.
analyzed: taṅkaroti tam karoti taṅkhaṇam taṃkhaṇam saṅgaho saṃgaho taṅghatam tam ghatam
translated: Taṅkaroti = taṃ karoti. Taṅkhaṇaṃ = taṃ khaṇaṃ. Saṅgaho = saṃgaho. Taṅghataṃ = taṃ ghataṃ.

original: Dhammañcare dhammaṃ care, tañchannaṃ taṃ channaṃ, tañjātaṃ taṃ jātaṃ, taññāṇaṃ taṃ
analyzed: dhammam care dhammam care tat channam tat channam tat jātam tat jātam tat ñāṇam taṃ
translated: Dhammañcare = dhammaṃ care. Tañchannaṃ = taṃ channaṃ. Tañjātaṃ = taṃ jātaṃ. Taññāṇaṃ = taṃ

original: ñāṇaṃ. Taṇṭhānaṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ, taṇḍahati bhaṃ ḍahati. Tantanoti taṃ tanoti, tanthiraṃ
analyzed: ñāṇam tat ṭhānam tam ṭhānam tat ḍahati bham ḍahati tantanoti tam tanoti tanthiram
translated: ñāṇaṃ. Taṇṭhānaṃ = taṃ ṭhānaṃ. Taṇḍahati = taṃ ḍahati. Tantanoti = taṃ tanoti. Tanthiraṃ = taṃ

original: taṃ thiraṃ, tandānaṃ taṃ dānaṃ, tandhanaṃ taṃ dhanaṃ, tanniccutaṃ taṃ niccutaṃ. Tampatto
analyzed: tam thiram tat dānam tam dānam tat dhanam tam dhanam tat niccutam tam niccutam tam patto
translated: thiraṃ. Tandānaṃ = taṃ dānaṃ. Tandhanaṃ = taṃ dhanaṃ. Tanniccutaṃ = taṃ niccutaṃ. Tampatto = taṃ

original: taṃ patto, tamphalaṃ taṃ phalaṃ, tesambodho tesaṃ bodho, sambhūto saṃbhūto, tammittaṃ
analyzed: tam patto tam phalam tam phalam tesambodho tesambodho sambhūtaḥ saṃbhūtaḥ tammittaṃ
translated: patto. Tamphalaṃ = taṃ phalaṃ. Tesambodho = tesaṃ bodho. Sambhūto = saṃbhūto. Tammittaṃ = taṃ🔽mittaṃ.

original: taṃ mittaṃ. Kiṅkato kiṃ kato, dātuṅgato dātuṃ gatoti evamādīsu vikappena.
analyzed: tam mittam kiṅkato kim kataḥ dātuṃgataḥ dātum gataḥ iti evamādīsu vikappena
translated: In such passages as “Kiṅkato kiṃ kato, dātuṅgato dātuṃ gato” (Dhp 101), it is by ellipsis.🔽Here it is not.

original: Idha na bhavati, na taṃ kammaṃ kataṃ sādhu, saraṇaṃ gacchāmi.
analyzed: idha na bhavati na tam kammam katam sādhu saraṇam gacchāmi
translated: In such passages as “Na bhavati na taṃ kammaṃ kataṃ sādhu, saraṇaṃ gacchāmi” (Dhp 101), it is by ellipsis.

original: Sati copari vāggahaṇe vijjhantare vā idha vāggahaṇakaraṇamatthantaraviññāpanatthaṃ,
analyzed: sati ca upari vāc gahaṇe vijjhantare vā idha vāc gahaṇa karaṇam atthantara viññāpana attham
translated: And in such passages as “Sati copari vāggahaṇe vijjhantare vā idha vāggahaṇakaraṇam” (P. 101), it is for the purpose of showing a different meaning.

original: tena niggahītassa saṃupasaggapumantassa le lakāro. Yathā – paṭisaṃlīno paṭisallīno,
analyzed: tena niggahītassa saṃupasagga pumantassa le lakāraḥ yathā paṭisaṃlīnaḥ paṭisallīnaḥ
translated: So the le and la vowels are substituted for the niggahīta vowel ñ in the word saṃupasagga,🔽just as the le and la vowels are substituted for the niggahīta vowel ñ in the words paṭisaṃlīno, paṭisallīno,

original: evaṃ paṭisallāṇo, sallakkhaṇā, sallekho, sallāpo, puṃliṅgaṃ pulliṅgaṃ.
analyzed: evam paṭisallāṇaḥ sat lakkhaṇā sat lekhaḥ sallāpaḥ pum liṅgam pum liṅgam
translated: so too paṭisallāṇo, sallakkhaṇā, sallekho, sallāpo.

original: Paccattaṃ eva, taṃ eva, tañhi tassa, evañhi vo itīdha “vā”ti adhikāro.
analyzed: paccattam eva tam eva tañhi tassa evañhi vaḥ iti idha vāti adhikāro
translated: Paccattaṃ eva, taṃ eva, tañhi tassa, evañhi vo. Here the word “eva” is to be construed with each of the words “paccattaṃ,” etc.

original: 50. Ehe ñaṃ.
analyzed: e he ñaṃ
translated: Ehe ñaṃ.

original: Ekārahakāre pare niggahītaṃ kho ñakāraṃ pappoti vā, ekāre ñādesassa dvibhāvo.
analyzed: ekāra hakāre pare niggahītam kho ñakāram pappoti vā ekāre ña ādesassa dvi bhāvaḥ
translated: When the niggahīta vowel ñ is followed by the vowel e or a, it becomes the vowel o.

original: Paccattaññevapaccattaṃ eva, taññeva taṃ eva, tañhi tassa tañhi tassa, evañhi vo evañhi vo.
analyzed: eva taṃ eva tam eva tañhi tassa tañhi tassa evañhi vo evañhi vo
translated: Paccattaññeva, taññeva, tañhi tassa, evañhi vo.

original: Vavatthitavibhāsattā vāsaddassa evahinipātato aññattha na hoti, yathā – evametaṃ, evaṃ hoti.
analyzed: vavatthita vibhāsa ttā vā saddassa eva hi nipātataḥ aññattha na hoti yathā evam etam evam hoti
translated: The affix -tva is used in the sense of ‘having been defined’ and ‘having been distinguished’, and it is not used in any other sense, e.g. evaṃ, evaṃ hoti.

original: Saṃyogo, saṃyojanaṃ, saṃyato, saṃyācikāya, yaṃ yadeva, ānantarikaṃ yamāhu itīdha “ña”miti vattate.
analyzed: saṃyogaḥ saṃyojanam saṃyataḥ saṃyācikāya yam yat eva ānantarikam yam āhuḥ iti idha ñam iti vattate
translated: The affix ña is not used elsewhere than in the sense of “having completed” and “having reached” and in the sense of “having added” and “having joined” and “having been bound” and “having been bound up” and “having been restrained” and “having been restrained” and “having been enjoined” and “whatever” and “immediately next” and “they say.”

original: 51. Sa ye ca.
analyzed: sa ye ca
translated: Sa ye ca.

original: Niggahītaṃ kho yakāre pare saha yakārena ñakāraṃ pappoti vā, ñādesassa dvittaṃ.
analyzed: niggahītam kho yakāre pare saha yakārena ñakāram pappoti vā ña ādesassa
translated: When the vowel sign is combined with the ya, the ya becomes ña. The vowel sign is doubled.

original: Saññogo saṃyogo, saññojanaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, saññato saṃyato, saññācikāya saṃyācikāya, yaññadeva yaṃ yadeva, ānantarikaññamāhu ānantarikaṃ yamāhu.🔽Vāsaddassa vavatthitavibhāsattāva saṃpadantato ca sabbanāmayakāraparato ca niggahītā aññattha na hoti. Yathā – etaṃ yojanaṃ, taṃ yānaṃ, saraṇaṃ yanti.
analyzed: saññogo saṃyogo saññojanam saṃyojanam saññato saṃyato saññācikāya saṃyācikāya yat yat eva ānantarikam yam āhu ānantarikam yam āhu  vā saddassa saṃpad antataḥ ca sabba nāma yakāra paratas ca niggahītā aññattha na hoti yathā etam yojanam tam yānam saraṇam yanti
translated: Saññogo saññogo, saññojanaṃ saññojanaṃ, saññato saññato, saññācikāya saññācikāya, yaññadeva yaññadeva, ānantarikaṃ ānantarikaṃ, yamāhu yamāhu.

original: Ettha ca “saha ye cā”ti vattabbe “sa ye cā”ti vacanato suttantesu sukhuccāraṇatthamakkharalopopīti
analyzed: ettha ca saha ye ca ati vattabbe sa ye ca ati vacanato suttantesu
translated: The affix ña is not used elsewhere than in the sense of “having completed” and “having reached” and in the sense of “having added” and “having joined” and “having been bound” and “having been bound up” and “having been restrained” and “having been restrained” and “having been enjoined” and “whatever” and “immediately next” and “they say” and in the sense of “having been completed” and “having been reached” and in the sense of “having been added” and “having been joined” and “having been bound” and “having been bound up” and “having been restrained” and “having been restrained” and “having been enjoined” and “whatever” and “immediately next” and “they say” and in the sense of “having been completed” and “having been reached” and in the sense of “having been added” and “having been joined” and “having been bound” and “having been bound up” and “having been restrained” and “having been restrained” and “having been enjoined” and “whatever” and “immediately next” and “they say” and in the sense of “having been completed” and “having been reached” and in the sense of “having been added” and “having been joined” and “having been bound” and “having been bound up” and “having been restrained” and “having been restrained” and “having been enjoined” and “whatever” and “immediately next” and “they say” and in the sense of “having been completed” and “having been reached” and in the sense

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ, tena paṭisaṅkhāya yoniso paṭisaṅkhā yoniso, sayaṃ abhiññāya sacchikatvā
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam tena paṭisaṅkhāya yonisas paṭisaṅkhā yonisas sayam abhiññāya sacchikatvā
translated: should be seen thus. Having reflected with right reflection, having directly known and realized it for himself,

original: sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā, pariyesanāya pariyesanātiādi sijjhati.
analyzed: sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā pariyesanāya pariyesanā ati ādi sijjhati
translated: having directly known and realized it for himself, it is right to search for it by searching.

original: Taṃ ahaṃ brūmi, yaṃ āhu, dhanaṃ eva, kiṃ etaṃ, nindituṃ arahati, yaṃ aniccaṃ, taṃ anattā, etaṃ avoca, etaṃ eva iccatra –
analyzed: tam aham brūmi yam āhu dhanam eva kim etam ninditum arahati yam aniccam tam anattā etam avocaḥ etam eva
translated: I say that which they call wealth is just that. What is impermanent is not self. This is what was said. This is what was said here:

original: 52. Madā sare.
analyzed: madā sare
translated: Madā sare.

original: Niggahītassa kho sare pare makāradakārādesā honti vā. Ettha ca vāsaddādhikārassa vavatthitavibhāsattā dakāro yatetasaddato parasseva.
analyzed: niggahītassa kho sare pare makāra dakāra ādesāḥ honti vā ettha ca vā sadda adhikārassa vavatthita vibhāsa ttā dakāraḥ parassa iva
translated: Niggahītassa kho sare, pare makāradakārādesā honti vā. Ettha ca vāsaddādhikārassa vavatthitavibhāsattā dakāro yatetasaddato parasseva.🔽I say that which they call wealth is just that. What is impermanent is not self. This is what was said. This is what was said here:

original: Tamahaṃ brūmi, yamāhu, dhanameva, kimetaṃ, ninditumarahati, yadaniccaṃ, tadanattā, etadavoca, etadeva.
analyzed: tam aham brūmi yam āhuḥ dhanam eva kim etam ninditum arahati yat aniccam tat anattā etat avocaḥ etat eva
translated: Vāti kiṃ? I say that which they call wealth is just that. What is impermanent is not self. This is what was said. This is what was said here:

original: Vāti kiṃ? Taṃ ahaṃ, etaṃ eva, akkocchi maṃ avadhi maṃ.
analyzed: vāti kim tam aham etam eva mam
translated: Akkoci maṃ avadhi maṃ.

original: Ettha ca madāti yogavibhāgena byañjanepi vā makāro. Tena “buddhama saraṇama gacchāmī”tiādi sijjhati.
analyzed: ca yoga vibhāgena byañjane pi vā tena buddham saraṇam gacchāmi itiādi sijjhati
translated: Ettha ca madāti yogavibhāgena byañjanepi vā makāro. Tena “buddhama saraṇama gacchāmī”tiādi sijjhati.

original: Tāsaṃ ahaṃ santike, vidūnaṃ aggaṃ, tassa adāsiṃ ahaṃ itīdha “sare”ti vattate.
analyzed: tāsam aham santike vidūnam aggam tassa adāsim aham iti idha sarā iti vattate
translated: I gave to them, to the foremost of the wise, here ‘sare’ is used.

original: 53. Kvaci lopaṃ.
analyzed: kvaci lopam
translated: Sometimes there is elision.

original: Niggahītaṃ kho sare pare lopaṃ pappoti kvaci chandānurakkhaṇe sukhuccāraṇaṭṭhāne. Pubbassaralopo, parassa asaṃyogantassa dīgho.
analyzed: niggahītam kho sare pare lopam pappoti kvaci chanda anurakkhaṇe sukha uccāraṇa ṭṭhāne pubbassara lopaḥ parassa a saṃyoga antassa dīghaḥ
translated: Elision of the preceding syllable is sometimes found in the place of the elision of the preceding syllable in the preservation of the metre, etc. The long is of the preceding syllable which is not in combination.

original: Tāsāhaṃ santike, vidūnaggaṃ, tassa adāsāhaṃ, tathāgatāhaṃ, evāhaṃ, kyāhaṃ.
analyzed: tāsāham santike vidūnaggam tassa adāsāham tathāgatāham eva aham kyā aham
translated: I gave to them, to the foremost of the wise, I gave to him, I am the Enlightened One, I am so, what am I?

original: Kvacīti kiṃ? Evamassa, kimahaṃ.
analyzed: kvaci iti kim evam assa kim aham
translated: What is meant by ‘sometimes’? Thus it is, what am I?

original: Ariyasaccānaṃ dassanaṃ, etaṃ buddhānaṃ sāsanaṃ, saṃratto, saṃrāgo, saṃrambho, avisaṃhāro, ciraṃ pavāsiṃ, gantuṃ kāmo, gantuṃ mano itīdha “kvaci lopa”nti vattate.
analyzed: ariya saccānam dassanam etam buddhānam sāsanam saṃrattaḥ saṃrāgaḥ saṃrambhaḥ a visaṃhāraḥ ciram pavāsim gantum kāmaḥ gantum mano iti idha kvaci vattate
translated: The seeing of the Noble Truths, this is the Dispensation of the Buddhas, being devoted, passion, being passionate, being excited, being unconfused, I lived for a long time, I am desirous of going, I am of the opinion that I should go, here ‘sometimes there is elision’ is used.

original: 54. Byañjane ca.
analyzed: byañjane ca
translated: And in the case of the consonant.

original: Niggahītaṃ kho byañjane ca pare lopaṃ pappoti kvaci chandānurakkhaṇādimhi. Rakārahakāresu upasaggantassa dīgho.
analyzed: niggahītam khaḥ byañjane ca pare lopam pappoti kvaci chanda anurakkhaṇa ādimhi rakāra hakāresu upasagga antassa dīghaḥ
translated: Elision of the preceding consonant is sometimes found in the preservation of the metre, etc. The long is of the preceding consonant which is a prefix.

original: Ariyasaccāna dassanaṃ, etaṃ buddhāna sāsanaṃ, sāratto, sārāgo, sārambho, avisāhāro, cirappavāsiṃ, dvittaṃ, gantukāmo, gantumano.
analyzed: ariya saccāna dassanam etam buddhāna sāsanam sā rattaḥ sā rāgaḥ sārambhaḥ a visāhāraḥ cira ppavāsim dvittam gantu kāmaḥ gantu manaḥ
translated: He is dear, he is greedy, he is angry, he is not able to bear, he has been away for a long time, he is second, he is desirous of going, he is minded to go.

original: Kvacīti kiṃ? Etaṃ maṅgalamuttamaṃ.
analyzed: kvaci iti kim etam maṅgalam uttamam
translated: Where? What? This is the supreme blessing.

original: Kataṃ iti, kiṃ iti, abhinanduṃ iti, uttattaṃ iva, cakkaṃ iva, kaliṃ idāni, kiṃ idāni,
analyzed: katam iti kim iti abhinandum iti uttattam iva cakkam iva kalim idāni kim idāni
translated: What is done? What? They rejoiced. As if it were lifted up, as if it were a wheel, what now is the quarrel? What now is

original: tvaṃ asi, idaṃ api, uttariṃ api, dātuṃ api, sadisaṃ eva itīdha “niggahītamhā, lopa”nti ca vattate.
analyzed: tvam asi idam api uttarim api dātum api sadisam eva iti idha ca vattate
translated: you are, this too, further too, to give too, just the same. Here “niggahītamhā, lopa” is said.

original: 55. Paro vā saro.
analyzed: paras vā saro
translated: Or the vowel of the preceding syllable.

original: Niggahītamhā paro saro lopaṃ pappoti vā. Niggahītassa vaggantattaṃ.🔽Katanti, kinti, abhinandunti, uttattaṃva, cakkaṃva, kalindāni, kindāni, tvaṃsi, idampi, uttarimpi, dātumpi, sadisaṃva.
analyzed: niggahītamhā paraḥ saraḥ lopam pappoti vā niggahītassa vagga anta ttam  katanti kinti abhinandunti cakkaṃva kalindāni kindāni tvaṃsi idampi uttarimpi dātumpi sadisaṃva
translated: The vowel of the preceding syllable becomes elided after niggahīta.🔽What is done? What? They rejoiced. As if it were lifted up, as if it were a wheel, what now is the quarrel? What now is🔽you are, this too, further too, to give too, just the same.

original: Vāti kiṃ? Kataṃ iti, kimiti, dātumapi, sāmaṃ eva.
analyzed: vāti kim iti kim iti dātum api eva
translated: What is said? What is done? To give too, just the same.

original: Ayampi vāsaddassa vavatthitavibhāsattā itīvīdānisīpevādito aññattha na hoti. Yathā – ahaṃ ettha, etaṃ ahosi.
analyzed: ayam pi vā saddassa vavatthita vibhāsa ttā iti ivi idānisī pevā āditaḥ aññattha na hoti yathā aham ettha etam ahosi
translated: This is a case of the “as” being a substitute for the “as-s” in the sense of “having been defined and analysed” . It is not used elsewhere. As in: “I was here”, “It was here”.

original: Evaṃ assa te āsavā, pupphaṃ assā uppajjati itīdha sare pare lutte vipariṇāmena “parasmiṃ, sare, lutte”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: evam assa te āsavā puppham assā uppajjati iti idha sare pare lutte vipariṇāmena parasmin sare luttā iti ca vattate
translated: “Thus would his cankers be”, “the flower would arise for him” . Here the “as” is used in the sense of “if” and “when” .

original: 56. Byañjano ca visaññogo.🔽Niggahītamhā parasmiṃ sare lutte byañjano saññogo ce, visaññogova hotīti saṃyogekadesassa purimabyañjanassa lopo.
analyzed: byañjanaḥ ca vi saññogaḥ  niggahītamhā parasmin sare lutte byañjanaḥ saññogaḥ ce visaññogaḥ uva hoti iti saṃyoga eka desassa purima byañjanassa lopaḥ
translated: “Conjunction” and “disjunction”.🔽“Conjunction” is the combination of the first letter with the rest of the word when the “as” is omitted in the sense of “having been combined with the rest”.

original: Dvinnaṃ byañjanānamekatra ṭhiti saññogo, idha pana saṃyujjatīti saññogo, purimo vaṇṇo, vigato saññogo assāti visaññogo, paro.
analyzed: dvinnam byañjanānam ekatra saññogaḥ idha pana saṃyujjati iti saññogaḥ purimaḥ vaṇṇaḥ vigataḥ saññogaḥ assa ati visaññogaḥ paraḥ
translated: “Disjunction” is the separation of the first letter from the rest of the word when the “as” is omitted in the sense of “having been combined with the rest”.

original: Evaṃ sa te āsavā, pupphaṃsā uppajjati.
analyzed: evam sa te āsavāḥ pupphaṃsāḥ uppajjati
translated: “Thus would his cankers be”, “the flower would arise for him”.

original: Lutteti kiṃ? Evamassa.
analyzed: luttā iti kim evam assa
translated: What is the use of “lutta”? As in: “Evamassa”.

original: Casaddena tiṇṇaṃ byañjanānaṃ sarūpasaṃyogopi visaññogo hoti. Yathā – agyāgāraṃ, vutyassa.
analyzed: ca saddena tiṇṇam byañjanānam sarūpa saṃyogaḥ api visaññogaḥ hoti yathā
translated: By the word “ca” , the “as” is also a case of disjunction in the sense of “having been combined with the rest” . As in: “agyāgāraṃ”, “vutyassa”.

original: Cakkhu udapādi, ava siro, yāvacidha bhikkhave, aṇuthūlāni, ta sampayuttā ibhīdha “sare, āgamo, kvaci, byañjane”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: cakkhu udapādi ava siraḥ yāvacidha bhikkhave aṇu thūlāni ta sampayuttā ibhīdha sare āgamaḥ kvaci byañjana iti ca vattate
translated: “Eye arose” is the first word. “Downward” is the second. “As far as” is the third. “The subtle and gross” is the fourth. “That is associated with” is the fifth. “Here” is the sixth. “In the case of” is the seventh. “In the case of a sound” is the eighth.

original: 57. Niggahitañca.
analyzed: niggahitam ca
translated: And the “suppressed”

original: Niggahītañca āgamo hoti sare vā byañjane vā kvaci sukhuccāraṇaṭṭhāne. Niggahītassa rassānugatattā rassatoyevāyaṃ.
analyzed: niggahītaṃ ca āgamaḥ hoti sare vā byañjane vā kvaci sukha uccāraṇa ṭṭhāne niggahītassa rassa anugata ttā
translated: The “suppressed” is the “suppressed” in the case of a sound, in the case of a place of easy pronunciation. Because of the shortness of the “suppressed” it is “short” only.

original: Cakkhuṃ udapādi, avaṃsiro, yāvañcidha bhikkhave, aṇuṃthūlāni, taṃsampayuttā, evaṃ taṅkhaṇe, taṃsabhāvo.
analyzed: udapādi avaṃsiraḥ yāvat cidha bhikkhave aṇuṃthūlāni tad sampayuttā evam taṅkhaṇe taṃsa bhāvaḥ
translated: “Eye arose” is the first word. “Downward” is the second. “As far as” is the third. “The subtle and gross” is the fourth. “That is associated with” is the fifth. “In that moment” is the sixth. “In that state” is the seventh.

original: Kvacīti kiṃ? Na hi etehi, idha ceva.🔽Evaṃ vutte, taṃ sādhu, ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā, aggiṃva sanamaṃ itīdha lopādesakāriye sampatte yebhuyyena tadapavādatthamāha.🔽58. Aṃ byañjane niggahītaṃ.🔽Niggahītaṃ kho byañjane pare aṃiti hoti.
analyzed: kvaci iti kim na hi etehi idha ca iva  evam vutte tam sādhu ekam samayam bhagavā iti idha lopādesakāriye sampatte yebhuyyena tad apavāda attham āha  am byañjane niggahītam  niggahītam khaḥ byañjane pare a ṃ iti hoti
translated: “In the case of” is what? For these are not here.

original: Akāro uccāraṇattho, “saralopo”tiādinā pubbassaralopo vā.
analyzed: akāraḥ uccāraṇa atthaḥ sara lopaḥ iti ādinā pubbassara lopaḥ vā
translated: When this was said, “That is good” is the first word. “At one time” is the second. “The Blessed One” is the third. “In the vicinity of Rājagaha” is the fourth. “In the Bamboo Grove” is the fifth. “In the Squirrel’s Feeding Place” is the sixth. “With a great Saṅgha of bhikkhus” is the seventh. “With a thousand bhikkhus” is the eighth. “All of them” is the ninth. “Worthy of offerings” is the tenth. “Wise” is the eleventh. “Discerning” is the twelfth. “Greatly mature” is the thirteenth. “Greatly freed” is the fourteenth. “Greatly released” is the fifteenth. “Greatly secluded” is the sixteenth. “Greatly calm” is the seventeenth. “Greatly composed” is the eighteenth. “Greatly attained to concentration” is the nineteenth. “Greatly attained to wisdom” is the twentieth. “Greatly attained to deliverance” is the twenty-first. “Greatly attained to the knowledge and vision of deliverance” is the twenty-second. “Accompanied by” is the twenty-third. “By a great Saṅgha of bhikkhunīs” is the twenty-fourth. “By a great Saṅgha of male lay followers” is the twenty-fifth. “By a great Saṅgha of female lay followers” is the

original: Evaṃ vutte, taṃ sādhu, ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā, aggiṃva sandhamaṃ.🔽Idha avuttavisesānampi vuttanayātidesatthamatidesamāha.
analyzed: evam vutte tam sādhu ekam samayam bhagavān aggim iva sandhamam  idha avutta visesānam pi vutta naya atidesa ttham atidesam āha
translated: When this was said, the Blessed One said to him: “Good, good, Anuruddha!

original: 59. Anupadiṭṭhānaṃ vuttayogato.
analyzed: an upadiṭṭhānam vutta yogataḥ
translated: Herein, although the particularities are not mentioned, the method of interpretation is stated by the word “thus” .🔽The method of interpretation of those not seen here is by the method stated in the Sarasangaha, etc.🔽.

original: Ye idha amhehi visesato na upadiṭṭhā upasagganipātādayo, tesaṃ vuttayogato vuttanayena sarasandhādīsu vuttanayānusārena rūpasiddhi veditabbā.
analyzed: ye idha amhehi visesataḥ na upadiṭṭhāḥ upasagga nipāta ādayaḥ tesam vutta yogataḥ vutta nayena sarasandha ādīsu vutta naya anusārena rūpa siddhi veditabbā
translated: Those upasaggas, nipātas, etc., which are not particularly mentioned here, should be known by the method of interpretation stated in the Sarasangaha, etc., by the method stated in the Sarasangaha, etc.

original: Tena “do dhassa cā”ti sutte casaddena pariyādīnaṃ rahanādivaṇṇassa vipariyayo yavādīhi,
analyzed: tena daḥ dhassa ca ati sutte ca saddena pariya ādīnam rahana ādi vaṇṇassa vipariyayaḥ yava ādīhi
translated: By the word “ca” in the sutta “do dhassa ca” the reversal of the colour of pariyudāha, etc., is by yavā, etc.,

original: yathā – pariyudāhāsi payirudāhāsi, ariyassa ayirassa, bahvābādho bavhābādho, na abhineyya anabhineyya.
analyzed: yathā ariyassa ayirassa bahu ābādhaḥ bavhābādhaḥ na abhineyya an abhineyya
translated: as follows: pariyudāhāsi, payirudāhāsi, ariyassa, ayirassa, bahvābādho, bavhābādho, na abhineyya, anabhineyya.

original: “Taṃ imināpi jānāthā”ti ettha “paro vā saro”ti sare lutte “tatrākāro”ti yogavibhāgena akāro niggahītassa dakāro, tadamināpi jānātha iccādi.
analyzed: tam iminā api jānātha ati ettha paraḥ vā saraḥ ti sare lutte tatra akāro ti yoga vibhāgena akāraḥ niggahītassa dakāro tat aminā api jānātha iccādi
translated: “You should know this by this too” : here “paro vā saro” is the saro in the sutta “tatrākāro” is the akāro of niggahīta, the dakāro by the analysis of the compound. You should know this by this too, etc.

original: Iti niggahītasandhividhānaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: iti niggahītasandhi vidhānam niṭṭhitam
translated: Thus the method of niggahīta sandhi is finished.

original: Saññāvidhānaṃ sarasandhi sandhi,
analyzed: saññā vidhānam sara sandhi sandhi
translated: The method of saññā is the sandhi of the Sarasangaha, etc.

original: Nisedhanaṃ byañjanasandhi sandhi;
analyzed: nisedhanam byañjana sandhi sandhi
translated: The affixing of the ending, the affixing of the vowel,

original: Yo niggahītassa ca sandhikappe,
analyzed: yaḥ niggahītassa ca sandhikappe
translated: The affixing of the affix to the reduplicated syllable,

original: Sunicchayo sopi mayettha vutto.
analyzed: su nicchayaḥ saḥ api mayā ittha vutto
translated: The deletion of the vowel, too, is stated here.

original: Iti rūpasiddhiyaṃ sandhikaṇḍo
analyzed: iti sandhi kaṇḍo
translated: Thus ends the chapter on affixes in the Rūpasiddhi.

original: Paṭhamo.
analyzed: paṭhamaḥ
translated: The first.

original: 2. Nāmakaṇḍa
analyzed: nāmakaṇḍa
translated: The chapter on nouns

original: Atha nāmikavibhatyāvatāro vuccate.
analyzed: atha vuccate
translated: Now the introduction to the nominal case endings is stated.

original: Atthābhimukhaṃ namanato, attani catthassa nāmanato nāmaṃ, dabbābhidhānaṃ.
analyzed: attha abhimukham namanataḥ attani catthassa nāmanataḥ nāmam dabba abhidhānam
translated: Because of bending towards the meaning, because of naming the meaning in oneself, the name is the designation of the word.

original: Taṃ pana duvidhaṃ anvattharuḷhīvasena, tividhaṃ pumitthinapuṃsakaliṅgavasena. Yathā – rukkho, mālā, dhanaṃ.
analyzed: tam pana duvidham anvattha ruḷhī vasena tividham pum itthi napuṃsaka liṅga vasena yathā rukkhaḥ mālā dhanam
translated: But that is twofold by way of the rooted and the non-rooted, threefold by way of the masculine, feminine, and neuter genders, as follows: tree, garland, wealth.

original: Catubbidhaṃ sāmaññaguṇakriyāyadicchāvasena, yathā – rukkho, nīlo, pācako, sirivaḍḍhotiādi.
analyzed: catubbidham sāmañña guṇa kriyā yat icchā vasena yathā rukkhaḥ nīlaḥ pācako sirivaḍḍhā ti ādi
translated: Fourfold by way of the common noun, quality, action, and desire, as follows: tree, blue, cooking, Sirivaḍḍha, and so on.

original: Aṭṭhavidhaṃ avaṇṇivaṇṇuvaṇṇokāraniggahītantapakatibhedena.
analyzed: aṭṭhavidham avaṇṇi vaṇṇu vaṇṇa ukāra niggahī tanta pakati bhedena
translated: Eightfold by way of the colorless, colored, color-cause, prohibition, reduplication, and natural divisions.

original: Pulliṅga
analyzed: pul liṅga
translated: The neuter gender

original: Tattha paṭhamaṃ akārantamhā pulliṅgā jātinimittā purisasaddā syādivibhattiyo parā yojīyante.
analyzed: tattha paṭhamam pulliṅgāḥ jāti nimittā purisa saddāḥ parāḥ
translated: Herein, first, from the non-cause-ending neuter gender nouns denoting a class are joined with the sy-ending case endings.

original: 60. Jinavacanayuttañhi.
analyzed: jina vacana yuttam hi
translated: For it is suitable in the Victor’s Word.

original: Adhikāroyaṃ. Tattha pañca māre jitavāti jino, buddho. Jinassa vacanaṃ jinavacanaṃ,
analyzed: adhikāraḥ ayam tattha pañca māre jitavāti jinaḥ buddhaḥ jinassa vacanam jina vacanam
translated: This is the context. Herein, the Victor is he who has won by conquering the five kinds of enemies called corruptions, namely, the corruptions of sense-desire, of being, of view, of ignorance, and of misapprehension of rules and vows. The Victor’s Word is the word of the Victor.

original: tassa jinavacanassa yuttaṃ jinavacanayuttaṃ, tepiṭakassa buddhavacanassa māgadhikāya
analyzed: tassa jina vacanassa yuttam jina vacana yuttam tepiṭakassa buddha vacanassa māgadhikāya
translated: That which is suitable to the Victor’s Word is suitable to the Victor’s Word. That which is suitable to the Buddha’s Word in its entirety is suitable to the Buddha’s Word in its entirety.

original: sabhāvaniruttiyā yuttaṃ anurūpamevāti idaṃ adhikāratthaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: sabhāva niruttiyā yuttam anurūpam eva ati idam adhikāra attham veditabbam
translated: This is the meaning of the context to be understood.

original: Sā māgadhī mūlabhāsā, narā yāyādikappikā;
analyzed: sā māgadhī mūlabhāsā narā yāyādikappikā
translated: The Magadhan language is the basic language,🔽The Brahmins’ language is the language of the learned,

original: Brahmāno ca’ssutālāpā, sambuddhā cāpi bhāsare.
analyzed: sambuddhā ca api bhāsare
translated: The language of the Enlightened Ones is the language of the speech-makers.

original: Adhikāro pana tividho sīhagatikamaṇḍūkagatikayathānupubbikavasena, ayaṃ pana sīhagatiko pubbāparavilokanato, yathānupubbikoyeva vā.
analyzed: adhikāraḥ pana tividhaḥ sīha gatika maṇḍūka gatika yathānupubbika vasena ayam pana sīha gatikaḥ pubba apara vilokanataḥ vā
translated: The context is of three kinds, namely, the lion-like, the frog-like, and the gradual. But this is the lion-like, because of looking back and forward, or it is the gradual kind.

original: Sakkatavisadisaṃ katvā jinavacanānurūpavasena pakatiṭṭhapanatthaṃ paribhāsamāha.
analyzed: sakkata visadisam katvā jina vacana anurūpa vasena pakati ṭṭhapana attham paribhāsam āha
translated: He uttered the metarule in order to establish the natural language in accordance with the Victor’s Word by making it like the language of Sakka.

original: 61. Liṅgañca nipaccate.
analyzed: liṅgam ca nipaccate
translated: And the gender is inflected.

original: Liṅgaṃpāṭipadikaṃ, yathā yathā jinavacanayuttañhi liṅgaṃ, tathā tathā idha liṅgaṃ
analyzed: yathā yathā liṅgam tathā tathā liṅgam
translated: The gender is the verbal base. The gender is inflected in whatever way is suitable to the Victor’s Word. In whatever way the gender is inflected,

original: nipaccate ṭhapīyati. Casaddena dhātavo cāti jinavacanānurūpato “purisa”iti liṅge
analyzed: nipaccate ca saddena dhātavaḥ ca ati jina vacana anurūpato liṅge
translated: and is placed. By the word “man” the gender is placed in accordance with the words of the Conqueror.

original: ṭhapite tato tassa dhātuppaccayavibhattivajjitassa atthavato saddassa “parasamaññā
analyzed: ṭhapite tatas tassa dhātuppaccaya vibhatti vajjitassa atthavataḥ saddassa para samaññā
translated: Then, in the case of the word “man” which is devoid of the case-endings that are the cause of the arising of the gender, the gender-sign is made by the rule “In the use of a name for another”

original: payoge”ti paribhāsato liṅgasaññāyaṃ –
analyzed: payoga iti paribhāsataḥ liṅga saññā ayam
translated: after the word “man” has been made into a noun.

original: Ito paraṃ vibhattippaccayādividhāne sabbattha liṅgaggahaṇamanuvattate.
analyzed: i tassa param vibhatti ppaccaya ādi vidhāne sabbattha liṅga ggahaṇam anuvattate
translated: From here on, in all the methods of case-endings, etc., the mention of gender is repeated.

original: 62. Tato ca vibhattiyo.
analyzed: tatas ca vibhattiyaḥ
translated: . And then the case-endings.

original: Tato jinavacanayuttehi liṅgehi parā vibhattiyo honti. Casaddaggahaṇena tavetunādipaccayantanipātatopi. Kammādivasena, ekattādivasena ca liṅgatthaṃ vibhajantīti vibhattiyo.
analyzed: tatas jina vacana yuttehi liṅgehi parāḥ vibhattiyaḥ honti ca sadda ggahaṇena kamma ādi vasena ekatta ādi vasena ca liṅga attham vibhajanti iti vibhattiyaḥ
translated: Then, after the gender-words that are in accordance with the words of the Conqueror, the case-endings come. By the word “and” the case-endings that are the cause of the elision of the final vowel, etc., are included. They are called case-endings because they divide the meaning of the gender according to the action, etc., and according to the singleness, etc.

original: Kā ca pana tā vibhattiyo? “Vibhattiyo”ti adhikāro.
analyzed: kā ca pana tā vibhattiyaḥ vibhattiyaḥ ti adhikāro
translated: But what are these case-endings? The topic is “case-endings.”

original: 63. Siyo, aṃyo, nāhi, sanaṃ, smāhi, sanaṃ, smiṃsu.
analyzed: siyaḥ aṃyaḥ na ahi sanam smāhi sanam smiṃsu
translated: . Si, yo, aṃ, yo, nāhi, sanaṃ, smāhi, sanaṃ, smiṃsu.

original: Syādayo dvisatta vibhattiyo nāma honti. Tattha si, yo iti paṭhamā, aṃ, yo iti dutiyā,
analyzed: sya ādayaḥ dvisatta vibhattiyaḥ nāma honti tattha si yo iti paṭhamā aṃ yo iti dutiyā
translated: The case-endings beginning with syā are called the twenty-two case-endings. Herein, si, yo is the first case-ending; aṃ, yo is the second case-ending;

original: nā, hi iti tatiyā, sa, naṃ iti catutthī, smā, hi iti pañcamī, sa, naṃ iti chaṭṭhī,
analyzed: nā hi iti tatiyā sa naṃ iti catutthī smā hi iti pañcamī sa naṃ iti chaṭṭhī
translated: The third is nā, hi iti; the fourth is sa, naṃ iti; the fifth is smā, hi iti; the sixth is sa, naṃ iti;

original: smiṃ, su iti sattamī.
analyzed: smim su iti sattamī
translated: The seventh is smī, su iti.

original: Idaṃ pana saññādhikāraparibhāsāvidhisuttesu saññāsuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ, vuttañhi vuttiyaṃ
analyzed: idam pana saññā adhikāra paribhāsā vidhi suttesu saññāsuttanti daṭṭhabbam vuttam hi vuttiyam
translated: But this should be regarded as the “declension of the demonstrative pronoun” in the “Treatise on Declensions” in the Suttas on Declensions and Syntactical-Sugestions, for this is said in the Grammar:

original: “vibhattiiccanena kvattho, amhassa mamaṃ savibhattissa se”ti, itarathā purimasuttena
analyzed: vibhatti iccanena kvatthaḥ amhassa mamam sa vibhattissa sa iti itarathā purima suttena
translated: “The kvatha ending is by desire of the case-ending, and the amh and mama are with the case-ending.” Otherwise, by the first sutta,

original: ekayogo kattabboti. Ettha ca paṭhamādivohāro, ekavacanādivohāro ca anvatthavasena,
analyzed: eka yogo kattabbo ti ettha ca paṭhama ādi vohāro ekavacana ādi vohāro ca anvattha vasena
translated: the compound would have to be made with the word ca. And here the mode of expression beginning with the first case-ending and the mode of expression beginning with the singular number,

original: parasamaññāvasena vā siddhoti veditabbo.
analyzed: para samaññā vasena vā siddhaḥ iti veditabbaḥ
translated: should be understood as established by way of the order of sequence or by way of the designation of another.🔽The speech of one is the singular number; the speech of many is the plural number; the second is the dual number. Otherwise, by the first sutta,

original: Ekassa vacanaṃ ekavacanaṃ, bahūnaṃ vacanaṃ bahuvacanaṃ, dvinnaṃ pūraṇī dutiyātiādi, itarathā purimasutte casaddena saññākaraṇe appakataniratthakavidhippasaṅgo siyā.
analyzed: ekassa vacanam ekavacanam bahūnam vacanam bahuvacanam dvinnam pūraṇī dutiyā atiādi itarathā purima sutte ca saddena saññā karaṇe appakata niratthaka vidhi ppasaṅgo siyā
translated: if the declension were made with the word ca, there would be the undesirable consequence of the rule being purposeless because of the omission of the word ca.

original: “Jinavacanayuttañhi, liṅgañca nipaccate”ti ca vattate. Idha pana padanipphādanampi jinavacanassāvirodhenāti ñāpetuṃ paribhāsantaramāha.
analyzed: jina vacana yuttam hi liṅgam ca ca vattate idha pana pada nipphādanam pi jina vacanassa avirodhena ati ñāpetum paribhāsa antaram āha
translated: “For the gender and the case-ending are inflected according to the word of the Victor.” But here the production of the words is shown to be not in conflict with the word of the Victor. To show this he gives a supplementary explanation.

original: 64. Tadanuparodhena.
analyzed: tad an uparodhena
translated: . In accordance with that.

original: Yathā yathā tesaṃ jinavacanānaṃ uparodho na hoti, tathā tathā idha liṅgaṃ, casaddenākhyātañca🔽nipaccate, nipphādīyatīti attho. Teneva idha ca ākhyāte ca dvivacanāggahaṇaṃ, sakkatavisadisato
analyzed: yathā yathā tesam jinavacanānam uparodhaḥ na hoti tathā tathā idha liṅgam ca saddena ākhyātam ca  nipaccate nipphādīyati iti tena iva idha ca ākhyāte ca dvivacana a ggahaṇam
translated: In accordance with the way in which there is no conflict with those words of the Victor, the gender and the case-ending

original: vibhattippaccayādividhānañca katanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: vibhatti paccaya ādi vidhānam ca katam ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: are inflected, the meaning is that they are produced. That is why the dual and plural are included here and in the case-ending, and why the rules for the case-endings, etc., are given, as in the Sakkattavisada .

original: Tattha avisesena sabbasyādivibhattippasaṅge “vatticchānupubbikā saddappavattī”ti vatticchāvasā –
analyzed: tattha avisesena sabbasya ādi vibhatti ppasaṅge vatti chā anupubbikā sadda ppavattī iti vatti chā avasā
translated: . Herein, without distinction, when all the case-endings are included, the order of the vowels is as follows: “The order of the vowels is the order of their appearance” .

original: 65. Liṅgatthe paṭhamā.
analyzed: liṅga tthe paṭhamā
translated: . The first is in the sense of gender.🔽The first case-ending is in the sense of the naming of gender. Herein, when the singular and plural are included without distinction,

original: Liṅgatthābhidhānamatte paṭhamāvibhatti hotīti paṭhamā. Tatthāpi aniyamenekavacanabahuvacanappasaṅge
analyzed: liṅga attha abhidhāna matte paṭhamā vibhatti hoti iti paṭhamā tattha api aniyamena ekavacana bahuvacana ppasaṅge
translated: . The second is in the sense of the instrument.🔽The second case-ending is in the sense of the instrument.

original: “ekamhī vattabbe ekavacana”nti paribhāsato liṅgatthassekattavacanicchāyaṃ paṭhamekavacanaṃ si.
analyzed: ekamhi vattabbe ekavacanan ti paribhāsataḥ liṅga atthassa ikatta vacanicchāyam paṭhama ekavacanam si
translated: “When one is to be spoken of, the singular number” is the first singular form in the desire to use the singular number for the meaning of the gender according to the usage.

original: “Ato nenā”ti ito “ato”ti vattate, liṅgaggahaṇañca.
analyzed: atas nena ati itas atas iti vattate liṅga ggahaṇam ca
translated: “From this, therefore” is used from this, and the gender is included.

analyzed: saḥ

original: Si, oiti dvipadamidaṃ. Liṅgassa akārato parassa sivacanassa okāro hoti.
analyzed: si o iti dvipadam idam liṅgassa akārataḥ parassa si vacanassa okāraḥ hoti
translated: Si, oiti dvipadamidaṃ. The vowel o is used for the word si after the vowel a of the gender.

original: Suttesu hi paṭhamāniddiṭṭhassa kāriyino chaṭṭhīvipariṇāmena vivaraṇaṃ ādesāpekkhanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: suttesu hi paṭhamā niddiṭṭhassa kāriyino chaṭṭhī vipariṇāmena vivaraṇam ādesa apekkhanti daṭṭhabbam
translated: For in the Suttas the explanation by the sixth case of the one first demonstrated is to be regarded as requiring a substitute.

original: Ettha ca sīti vibhatti gayhate vibhattikāriyavidhippakaraṇato, “tato ca vibhattiyo”ti
analyzed: ettha ca si iti vibhatti gayhate vibhatti kāriya vidhi ppakaraṇato tatas ca vibhattiyā ti
translated: And here the case-ending is taken as the case-ending function by the rule of the Vibhattyattha Kanda, “And from that the case-endings” .

original: ito vibhattiggahaṇānuvattanato vā, evaṃ sabbattha syādīnaṃ kāriyavidhāne vibhattiyevāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: i tassa vibhatti ggahaṇa anuvattanataḥ vā evam sabbattha sya ādīnam kāriya vidhāne vibhattiyā iva iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: Or else because it follows the inclusion of the case-ending from this, in the same way the case-ending should be regarded as the only function in the demonstration of the forms sy and so on in all instances.

original: “Vā paro asarūpā”ti paralope sampatte tadapavādena pubbalopamāha.
analyzed: vā paraḥ a sarūpā ati para lope sampatte tad apavādena pubba lopam āha
translated: “Or after, when not of the same form” is said by the rejection of the former elision when the elision of the following is applicable.

original: 67. Saralopo’mādesappaccayādimhi saralope tu pakati.
analyzed: sara lopa umā desa ppaccaya ādimhi sara lope tu pakati
translated: . Saralopo’mādesappaccayādimhi saralope tu pakati. But when there is elision of the vowel a in a substitute, etc., it is the original.

original: Pubbassarassa lopo hoti aṃvacane, ādesappaccayādibhūte ca sare pare, saralope kate
analyzed: pubbassarassa lopaḥ hoti aṃ vacane ādesa ppaccaya ādi bhūte ca sare pare sara lope kate
translated: The preceding vowel is dropped in the case of the vowel a, and also in the case of the following vowel which is the cause of the lengthening, etc., of the preceding vowel, after the dropping of the preceding vowel has taken place.

original: tu parasarassa pakatibhāvo hoti. Ettha ca “saralope”ti punaggahaṇaṃ imināva katasaralopanimitteyeva🔽parassa vikāre sampatte pakatibhāvatthaṃ. Parasarassa pakatibhāvavidhānasāmatthiyato
analyzed: tu para sarassa pakati bhāvaḥ hoti ettha ca sara lopa iti punaggahaṇam kata sara lopa nimittā iya iva  parassa vikāre sampatte pakati bhāva attham para sarassa pakati bhāva vidhāna sāmatthiyato
translated: The following vowel then becomes the original vowel. And the repetition of the word “dropping” here is for the purpose of showing that🔽the following vowel becomes the original vowel only when the preceding vowel has been dropped by the above-mentioned cause.

original: amādesappaccayādibhūte sare paretipi siddhaṃ.🔽Tyādivibhattiyo cettha, paccayattena gayhare;
analyzed: am ādesa ppaccaya ādi bhūte sare para itipi siddham  ca ittha paccaya ttena gay hare
translated: But it is established that the following vowel becomes the original vowel even when the preceding vowel is not the cause of the lengthening, etc., of the following vowel.🔽If the case-endings, etc., are,

original: Ādiggahaṇamākhyāta-kitakesvāgamatthidaṃ.
analyzed: ādi gahaṇam ākhyāta kita kesu āgama tthidam
translated: The inclusion of the initial vowel is for the purpose of showing that the same applies to the a-prefix and to the kitaka-prefix.

original: Paccayasāhacariyā, cādeso pakatīparo;
analyzed: paccaya sāhacariyā ca ādesaḥ pakati paraḥ
translated: The a-prefix and the following vowel become the original vowel,

original: Padantassaralopo na, tena’bbhāhādike pare.
analyzed: pad antaḥ sara lopaḥ na tena ap bhā ha ādike pare
translated: But not when the case-ending is added, therefore in the case of abbhāhati, etc.

original: Tuggahaṇaṃ bhikkhunīādīsu saralopanivattanatthaṃ, “naye paraṃ yutte”ti paraṃ netabbaṃ. Puriso tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: tuk gahaṇam bhikkhunī ādīsu sara lopa nivattana attham naye param yutta iti param netabbam purisaḥ tiṭṭhati
translated: The inclusion of the word “tu” is for the purpose of excluding the dropping of the preceding vowel in the case of bhikkhunī, etc. The word “paraṃ” should be taken to mean “netabbaṃ” (to be taken). A man stands.

original: Puriso ca puriso cāti purisa purisaiti vattabbe –
analyzed: puriso ca purisaḥ ca ati vattabbe
translated: If it is said “puriso ca puriso cā” (a man and a man),

original: 68. Sarūpānamekasesvasakiṃ.
analyzed: sa rūpa ānam eka se sva sa kim
translated: The same form is used for the first of a class.

original: Sarūpānaṃ samānarūpānaṃ padabyañjanānaṃ majjhe ekova sissate, aññe lopamāpajjante
analyzed: sarūpānam samāna rūpānam pada byañjanānam majjhe ekaḥ iva sissate aññe lopam āpajjante
translated: In the middle of similar words, similar in form and similar in letters, only one remains, the others fall into the class of elision.

original: asakinti ekaseso. Ettha ca “sarūpāna”nti vuttattāva siddhe asakimpayoge punāsakiṃgahaṇaṃ
analyzed: ettha ca siddhe a sakim payoge
translated: The elision is single. And here, since the words “similar” have already established the use of the elision, the mention of the elision again

original: ekavibhattivisayānamevāsakimpayoge evāyanti dassanatthaṃ, na ca vicchāpayoge’tippasaṅgo.
analyzed: eva āyanti dassana ttham na ca vicchā apayoga iti pasaṅgaḥ
translated: is for the purpose of showing that only those having a single case-ending come under the use of the elision, and not those having different case-endings.

original: “Vaggā pañcapañcaso mantā”ti ettha “pañcapañcaso”ti niddeseneva vicchāpayogasiddhiyā
analyzed: vaggā pañca pañcasaḥ mantā ati ettha pañca pañcasaḥ ti niddesena iva vicchā apayoga siddhiyā
translated: In the words “The groups are five and five, the mantras are five and five” the use of the different case-endings is established by the mere indication of the words “five and five.”

original: ñāpitattā, atha vā sahavacanicchāya’maya’mekaseso.
analyzed: ñāpita ttā atha vā
translated: Or, the elision is single by the desire for a compound.

original: Yogavibhāgato cettha, ekasesvasakiṃ iti;
analyzed: yoga vibhāgataḥ ca itthā iti
translated: And here, in the analysis of the compound, the elision is single,

original: Virūpekaseso hoti, vā “pitūna”ntiādisu.
analyzed: virūpa ekasesaḥ hoti vā pitūnanti ādisu
translated: The elision is different, as in the words “pitūna” and so on.

original: Tattheva liṅgatthassa bahuttavacanicchāyaṃ “bahumhi vattabbe bahuvacana”nti paṭhamābahuvacanaṃ yo, purisa yo itīdha “ato, vā”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: tattha iva liṅga atthassa bahutta vacanicchāyam bahumhi vattabbe bahuvacananti paṭhamā bahuvacanam yo iti idha atas vā ati ca vattate
translated: There itself, in the desire for the plural case-ending of the word “liṅga,” the first plural, which is “bahumhi vattabbe bahuvacana,” is used. The words “ato, vā” are used here.

original: 69. Sabbayonīnamāe.
analyzed: sabba yonī namāe
translated: Of all the wombs.🔽.

analyzed: akāra pit ādi antā an amā
translated: The word ge is used in the sense of addressing.🔽The vowel a of the noun and the final a of the words father, teacher, etc., become a in the word ge when it follows.🔽The word ge is used in the sense of addressing.

analyzed: ge rassam iti ca vattate  ākāraḥ vā
translated: The word ge is used in the sense of addressing.🔽The vowel a of the noun and the final a of the words father, teacher, etc., become a in the word ge when it follows.🔽The word ge is used in the sense of addressing.

translated: The vowel a of the noun and the final a of the words father, teacher, etc., become a in the word ge when it follows.

analyzed: se sa taḥ lopam ga sipi  sim saḥ syā ca sa khataḥ gasse vā gha te ca ati evamādīhi niddiṭṭhehi aññaḥ sesaḥ nāma

analyzed: tatas sesataḥ liṅgamhā gasi it ca ete lopam āpajjante apiggahaṇam dutiya ttha sampiṇḍana ttham

analyzed: keci ālapana abhibyattiyā bhavantasaddam vā hesaddam vā payujjante bho purisa tiṭṭha he purisāḥ vā
translated: The vowel a of the noun and the final a of the words father, teacher, etc., become a in the word ge when

original: Bahuvacane na viseso, bhavanto purisā tiṭṭhatha.
analyzed: bahuvacane na visesaḥ bhavanto purisā tiṭṭhatha
translated: There is no difference in the plural: “Gentlemen, the men stand.”

original: Tattheva kammatthavacanicchāyaṃ “va,”ti vattate.
analyzed: tattha iva kammattha vacanicchāyam vati vattate
translated: The particle “va” is used in the same way in the expression of the object.

original: 75. Yaṃ karoti taṃ kammaṃ.
analyzed: yam karoti tam kammam
translated: . What is done is the action.

original: Yaṃ vā karoti, yaṃ vā vikaroti, yaṃ vā pāpuṇāti, taṃ kārakaṃ kriyānimittaṃ kammasaññaṃ hoti.
analyzed: yam vā karoti yam vā vikaroti yam vā pāpuṇāti tam kārakam kriyā nimittam kamma saññam hoti
translated: Or what is done, what is changed, what is reached, is the doer, the sign of the action, the idea of the action.

original: 76. Kammatthe dutiyā.
analyzed: kammatthe dutiyā
translated: . The second case is used in the sense of the object.

original: Kammatthe dutiyāvibhatti hoti. Pure viya dutiyekavacanaṃ aṃ, “saralopo”tiādinā sare lutte “dīgha”nti dīghe sampatte pakatibhāvo ca, purisaṃ passa.
analyzed: kammatthe dutiyā vibhatti hoti pure viya dutiyā ekavacanam sara lopa uti ādinā sare lutte dīghanti dīghe sampatte pakati bhāvaḥ ca purisam passa
translated: The second case is used in the sense of the object. As before, the singular of the second case is “a,” but the “sa” is elided by the rule beginning “saralopa” . Then by the rule “dīgha” , the long vowel is lengthened. The natural state is restored. See a man.

original: Bahuvacane “sabbayonīnamāe”ti yovacanassekāro, purise passa.
analyzed: bahuvacane yo vacanassa ikāraḥ purise passa
translated: In the plural, the second case is “e” by the rule “sabbayonīnamāe” . See men.

original: Tattheva kattuvacanicchāyaṃ –
analyzed: tatthā iva kattu vacani chāyam
translated: In the same way, in the expression of the doer,

original: 77. Yo karoti sa kattā.
analyzed: yaḥ karoti sa kattā
translated: . He who does is the doer.

original: Yo attappadhāno kriyaṃ karoti, so kattusañño hoti.
analyzed: yaḥ atta ppadhānaḥ kriyam karoti saḥ kattu saññaḥ hoti
translated: He who is the principal agent and does the action is the idea of the doer.

original: “Tatiyā”ti vattate.
analyzed: tatiyā ati vattate
translated: “The third case” is used.

original: 78. Kattari ca.
analyzed: kattari ca
translated: . And in the doer.

original: Kattari ca kārake tatiyāvibhatti hotīti tatiyekavacanaṃ nā.
analyzed: kattari ca kārake tatiyā vibhatti hoti iti tatiyā ekavacanam nā
translated: And in the doer, the agent, the third case is used. The singular of the third case is “na.”

original: 79. Ato nena.
analyzed: a taḥ nena
translated: . From that, by that.

original: Enāti avibhattikaniddeso. Akārantato liṅgamhā parassa nāvacanassa enādeso hoti, saralopādi, purisena kataṃ.🔽Bahuvacanamhi –🔽80. Suhisvakāro e.
analyzed: ena ati avibhattika niddesaḥ akāra antataḥ liṅgamhā parassa nā vacanassa ena ādeso hoti sara lopa ādi purisena katam  bahuvacanam hi  su hi sva kāraḥ e
translated: En is a substitute for the indeclinable. The substitute en is for the nominative case ending of a word ending in a vowel, and for the nominative case ending of a word ending in a consonant, after the vowel a, with omission of the vowel a, e.g. kataṃ purisena, kataṃ purisena.🔽In the plural number:🔽Suhi and svaka are e.

original: Su, hiiccetesu vibhattirūpesu paresu liṅgassa sambandhī akāro ettamāpajjate.🔽81. Smāhismiṃnaṃ mhābhimhi vā.🔽Sabbato liṅgamhā smā hi smiṃiccetesaṃ yathākkamaṃ mhā, bhi, mhiiccete ādesā honti vā, purisehi, purisebhi kataṃ.🔽Tattheva karaṇavacanicchāyaṃ –🔽82. Yena vā kayirate taṃ karaṇaṃ.🔽Yena vā kayirate, yena vā passati, yena vā suṇāti, taṃ kārakaṃ karaṇasaññaṃ hoti.🔽83. Karaṇe tatiyā.🔽Karaṇakārake tatiyāvibhatti hoti, sesaṃ kattusamaṃ, āviṭṭhena purisena so puññaṃ karoti, purisehi, purisebhi.🔽Tattheva sampadānavacanicchāyaṃ –
analyzed: su hi it ca itesu vibhatti rūpesu paresu liṅgassa sambandhī akāraḥ āpajjate 🔽sma ahi smiṃnam mha abhimhi vā 🔽sabbatas liṅga mhā smā hi smiṃ iti etesam yathākkamam mhā bhi mhi iti ete ādesāḥ honti vā purisehi purisebhi katam 🔽tatthā iva karaṇa vacani chāyam 🔽yena vā tam karaṇam 🔽yena vā yena vā passati yena vā suṇāti tam kārakam karaṇa saññam hoti 🔽karaṇe tatiyā 🔽karaṇa kārake tatiyā vibhatti hoti sesam kattu samam āviṭṭhena purisena saḥ puññam karoti purisehi purisebhi 🔽tatthā iva sampadāna vacanicchāyam

original: Bahuvacanamhi “dīgha”nti vattate.

translated: “From this, of all, to, to” is said.

original: 90. Smāsmiṃna vā.

original: Akārantato liṅgamhā sabbesaṃ smā smiṃiccetesaṃ yathākkamaṃ ākārekārādesā honti vā, aññattha mhādeso. Purisā apeti, purisamhā, purisasmā.

translated: From a word ending in a vowel, of all, the fifth case-ending, the locative, has the vowel-change ā, or the vowel-change m, in place of the final vowel. Of men, in men, from men.

original: Bahuvacane sabbattha tatiyāsamaṃ, hissa bhiādeso hoti. Purisehi, purisebhi apeti.
analyzed: bahuvacane sabbattha tatiyā samam hissa bhi ādesaḥ hoti purisehi purisebhi apa iti
translated: In the plural, everywhere, the third case-ending, the instrumental, has the vowel-change i in place of the final vowel. By men, by the men.

original: Yassa vā pariggaho, taṃ sāmisaññaṃ hoti.
analyzed: yassa vā pariggahaḥ tam sāmi saññam hoti
translated: That which is owned is called the owner.

original: Tattheva okāsavacanicchāyaṃ –🔽93. Yodhāro tamokāsaṃ.🔽Yo kattukammānaṃ kriyāya ādhāro, taṃ kārakaṃ okāsasaññaṃ hoti.

translated: In the locative, the sixth case-ending, is the same as the fourth case-ending, everywhere, except for the vowel-change ā. Of the man, this is the wealth, of the men.

original: “Vā”ti vattate.
