original: 95. Manogaṇādito smiṃnānamiā.
analyzed: manas gaṇa āt itaḥ smin nān ami ā
translated: . From the group of words beginning with mano, in the nominative and accusative.

original: Manopabhuti gaṇo manogaṇo, manogaṇādito smiṃ, nāiccetesaṃ yathākkamaṃ ikārākārādesā honti vā. Ādiggahaṇena bilapadāditopi.

translated: The group beginning with mano, manogaṇa, is the group beginning with mano, manogaṇa, in this; the i of these is changed to e in the order, or not. By the word “beginning” is also included the group beginning with bilapada.

original: “Manogaṇādito”ti vattate.
analyzed: manaḥ gaṇa āditas ti vattate
translated: The group beginning with mano is stated.

original: 96. Sa sare vāgamo.
analyzed: sa sare vāgamo
translated: The augment sa is optionally added.

original: Eteheva manogaṇādīhi sare pare sāgamo hoti vā. Manasā, manena.🔽Vavatthitavibhāsatthoyaṃ vāsaddo, tena “mano manā manaṃ mane manaāyatana”ntiādīsu na hoti. “Mānasikaṃ, cetasika”ntiādīsu niccaṃ. Manehi, manebhi.
analyzed: manaḥ gaṇa ādīhi sare pare sa āgamaḥ vā manasā  vavatthita vibhāsa atthaḥ yam vā saddaḥ tena manaḥ manāḥ manam mane mana āyatanam ti ādīsu na hoti mānasikam cetasikam ti ādīsu niccam manehi manebhi
translated: The augment sa is optionally added to the end of these same groups beginning with mano, etc. Manasā, manena.🔽This word vā is for the purpose of distinguishing the vibhattis; therefore it is not in mano manā mana mane manāyatana, etc., but always in mānasika, cetasika, etc. Manehi, manebhi.

original: “Manogaṇādito, vā”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: manaḥ gaṇa āditaḥ vāti ca vattate
translated: The group beginning with mano is stated.

original: 97. Sassa co.
analyzed: sassa caḥ
translated: The augment sa is optionally added.

original: Manogaṇādito parassa sassa vibhattissa okāro hoti vā. Sāgamo.
analyzed: manaḥ gaṇa āditaḥ parassa sassa vibhattissa okāraḥ hoti vā sa āgamaḥ
translated: The augment sa is optionally added to the end of the group beginning with mano, etc., and the vowel o is added to the vibhatti. The augment sa is added.

original: Manaso manassa, manānaṃ, manā manasmā manamhā, manehi manebhi, manaso manassa, manānaṃ, manasi mane manasmiṃ manamhi, manesu.

original: Evaṃ vaco vayo tejo,
analyzed: evam vacaḥ vayaḥ tejaḥ
translated: Thus vāco, vayo, tejo,

original: Tapo ceto tamo yaso;
analyzed: tapo ceto tamaḥ yaso
translated: tapo, ceto, tamo, yaso;

original: Ayo payo siro chando,
analyzed: ayaḥ payaḥ siraḥ chandaḥ
translated: ayo, payo, siro, chando,

original: Saro uro raho aho –

translated: saro, uro, raho, aho –

original: Iccādi manogaṇo.
analyzed: i t ca ādi manaḥ gaṇaḥ
translated: This is the group of words beginning with manas.

original: Guṇavantusaddassa bhedo. Guṇavantu si itīdha –
analyzed: guṇavantu saddassa bhedaḥ si iti idha
translated: The division of the word guṇavant. Guṇavant is si here.

analyzed: sa vibhattissa n tussa ati ca adhikāraḥ
translated: The extension applies: “With case-ending, ntu.”

original: 98. Ā simhi.
analyzed: ā simhi

translated: Ā is the substitute for all ntu-suffixes with case-ending in the case-ending simhi. Guṇavā.

original: “Yomhi, paṭhame”sīhagatiyā “vā”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: yomhi ca vattate
translated: “Yomhi, paṭhame”sīhagatiyā “vā”ti ca vattate.

translated: “Sunaṃhisu, atta”nti ca vattate.

analyzed: n tu paccayassa antaḥ ukāraḥ attam āpajjate su nam hi yo i t ca itesu ca ggahaṇena aññesu aṃ
translated: The ntu-suffix becomes nto uk in the first case, and in the other cases beginning with the third, in the words beginning with su, and in the words beginning with ya, and in the words beginning with a.

analyzed: nā sma asmiṃsu ca guṇavantā chaṭṭhiyā siddhe pi anta ādese puna anta ggahaṇa karaṇato

analyzed: bho guṇavan bho guṇava bho guṇavā bhavantaḥ guṇavantaḥ guṇavantaḥ guṇavantam guṇavante
translated: Bho guṇavaṃ, bho guṇava, bho guṇavā, bhavant’ o guṇavanto, guṇavantā, guṇavantaṃ, guṇavante.

original: “Vā”ti vattate.
analyzed: vāti vattate
translated: The word “vā” is repeated.

original: 102. Totitā sasmiṃnāsu.
analyzed: toti tā sa smiṃn āsu
translated: . Toti tā sasmiṃnāsu.

original: Sabbasseva ntupaccayassa savibhattissa toti tāādesā honti vā sasmiṃnāiccetesu yathāsaṅkhyaṃ. Guṇavatā guṇavantena, guṇavantehi guṇavantebhi.
analyzed: sabbassa iva n tu paccayassa sa vibhattissa taḥ ti tā ādesāḥ honti vā sa smin na i c ca itesu yathāsaṅkhyam guṇavatā guṇavantena guṇavantehi guṇavantebhi
translated: The endings toti, tā are substituted for all ntupaccayas with case-endings, when sasmiṃ, etc., follow, respectively. Guṇavatā, guṇavantena, guṇavantehi, guṇavantebhi.

original: 103. Ntassa se vā.
analyzed: n tassa se vā
translated: . Ntassa se vā.

original: Sabbasseva ntupaccayassa savibhattissa ntassaiccayamādeso hoti vā se vibhattimhi. Guṇavantassa guṇavato.
analyzed: sabbassa iva n tu paccayassa sa vibhattissa n tassa e c ca yam ādesaḥ hoti vā se vibhattimhi guṇavantassa guṇavataḥ
translated: The ending ntassa is substituted for all ntupaccayas with case-endings, when se is the case-ending. Guṇavantassa, guṇavato.

original: 104. Naṃmhi taṃ vā.
analyzed: naṃmhi tam vā
translated: . Naṃmhi taṃ vā.

original: Sabbasseva ntupaccayassa savibhattissa taṃādeso hoti vā naṃmhi vibhattimhi. Guṇavataṃ guṇavantānaṃ.
analyzed: sabbassa iva n tu paccayassa sa vibhattissa taṃ ādesaḥ hoti vā naṃmhi vibhattimhi guṇavatam guṇavantānam
translated: The ending taṃ is substituted for all ntupaccayas with case-endings, when naṃ is the case-ending. Guṇavataṃ, guṇavantānaṃ.

original: “Amha tumha ntu”iccādinā smāvacanassa nābyapadeso.
analyzed: amha tumha n tu iti ādinā sma a vacanassa na a vyapadesaḥ
translated: The word “amha” is not substituted for the vocative smā.🔽. Tassa se vā.🔽The ending ntassa is substituted for all ntupaccayas with case-endings, when se is the case-ending. Guṇavantassa, guṇavato.

original: Guṇavatā guṇavantā guṇavantasmā guṇavantamhā, guṇavantehi guṇavantebhi, guṇavantassa guṇavato, guṇavataṃ guṇavantānaṃ, guṇavati guṇavante guṇavantasmiṃ guṇavantamhī, guṇavantesu.
analyzed: guṇavatā guṇavantā guṇavantasmai guṇavantamhā guṇavantehi guṇavantebhiḥ guṇavantassa guṇavataḥ guṇavatam guṇavantānam guṇavati guṇavante guṇavantasmin guṇavante guṇavante guṇavante guṇavante guṇavante guṇavante guṇavante guṇavante guṇavante guṇavante guṇavante guṇavante guṇavante guṇavante guṇavante
translated: Guṇavanto guṇavantā guṇavantasmā guṇavantamhā, guṇavantehi guṇavantebhi, guṇavantassa guṇavato, guṇavataṃ guṇavantānaṃ, guṇavati guṇavante guṇavantasmiṃ guṇavantamhī, guṇavantesu.

original: Evaṃ gaṇavā kulavā balavā yasavā dhanavā sutavā bhagavā himavā phalavā sīlavā paññavā iccādayo.
analyzed: evam gaṇavā kulavā balavā yasavā dhanavā sutavā bhagavā himavā phalavā sīlavā paññavā iccādayaḥ
translated: Thus guṇavanto, gaṇavā, kulavā, balavā, yasavā, dhanavā, sutavā, bhagavā, himavā, phalavā, sīlavā, paññavā, etc.

original: Himavantusaddato simhi kate –
analyzed: himavantu saddataḥ simhi kate
translated: When the word himavanta is made feminine,

original: “Attaṃ, ntussa’nto”ti ca vattamāne –
analyzed: attam ntussantaḥ iti ca vattamāne
translated: then when the form attaṃ, ntussa, ‘nto’ is used,

original: 105. Simhī vā.
analyzed: simhī vā
translated: it is himavantī or himavā.

original: Ntupaccayassa anto attaṃ hoti vā simhi vibhattimhi. Himavanto, himavā, sesaṃ samaṃ.
analyzed: n tu paccayassa antaḥ attam hoti vā simhi vibhattimhi himavantaḥ himavā sesam samam
translated: In the locative case the form attaṃ is used or the form ending in ‘nto’ is used. Himavanto, himavā, the rest is the same.

original: Puna vāggahaṇakaraṇaṃ himavantusaddato aññatra attanisedhanatthaṃ, vavatthitavibhāsatthoyaṃ vāsaddo. Tena guṇavantādīsu nātippasaṅgo.
analyzed: puna vāc gahaṇa karaṇam himavantu saddataḥ aññatra atta nisedhana attham vavatthita vibhāsa atthaḥ yam vā saddaḥ tena guṇavanta ādīsu na ati ppasaṅgaḥ
translated: The repetition of the word ‘again’ is for the purpose of excluding the word attaṃ from the word himavanta, or the word vā is for the purpose of distinguishing the two forms. Therefore there is no extension to guṇavanto, etc.

original: Evaṃ satimā dhitimā gatimā matimā mutimā muttimā jutimā sirimā hirimā thutimā ratimā
analyzed: evam satimā dhitimā gatimā matimā mutimā muttimā jutimā sirimā hirimā thutimā ratimā
translated: Thus satimā, dhitimā, gatimā, matimā, mutimā, muttimā, jutimā, sirimā, hirimā, thutimā, ratimā,

original: yatimā sucimā kalimā balimā kasimā rucimā buddhimā cakkhumā bandhumā hetumā setumā
analyzed: yatimā sucimā kalimā balimā kasimā rucimā buddhimā cakkhumā bandhumā hetumā setumā
translated: yatimā, sucimā, kalimā, balimā, kasimā, rucimā, buddhimā, cakkhumā, bandhumā, hetumā, setumā,

original: ketumā rāhumā bhāṇumā khāṇumā vijjumā iccādayo.
analyzed: ketumāḥ rāhumāḥ bhāṇumāḥ khāṇumāḥ vijjumāḥ icca ādayaḥ
translated: ketumā, rāhumā, bhāṇumā, khāṇumā, vijjumā, etc.

original: Tattha satimantu bandhumantusaddānaṃ aṃsesu rūpabhedo. “Attaṃ, ntussā”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: tattha satimantu bandhumantu saddānam aṃsesu rūpa bhedaḥ ca vattate
translated: Herein, the difference in the formation of the nominal stems in -antu and -manta is in the -a- of the first and the -m- of the second. And the following is said: “Attaṃ, ntussā” .

original: 106. Sabbassa vā aṃsesu.
analyzed: sabbassa vā aṃsesu
translated: Or in all,

original: Sabbasseva ntupaccayassa attaṃ hoti vā aṃsaiccetesu. Idhāpi vāsaddassa vavatthitavibhāsattā
analyzed: sabbassa iva n tu paccayassa attam hoti vā idha api vā saddassa vavatthita vibhāsa ttā
translated: In all, the attaṃ is in the -a- or the -m- of the first, in the -a- or the -m- of the second, in the -a- or the -m- of the third, and in the -a- or the -m- of the fourth. Here too, because of the restriction of the vibhatti,

original: nātippasaṅgo. Satimaṃ satimantaṃ, bandhumaṃ bandhumantaṃ, satimassa satimato satimantassa,
analyzed: na atippasaṅgaḥ satimam satimantam bandhumam bandhumantam satimassa satimataḥ satimantassa
translated: there is no extension to the ntupaccayā. Satimaṃ, satimantaṃ, bandhumaṃ, bandhumantaṃ, satimassa, satimato, satimantassa,

original: bandhumassa bandhumato bandhumantassa, sesaṃ samaṃ.🔽Gacchantasaddassa bhedo, gacchanta si,
analyzed: bandhumassa bandhumataḥ bandhumantassa sesam samam  gacchanta saddassa bhedaḥ gacchanta si
translated: bandhumassa, bandhumato, bandhumantassa, the rest is the same.🔽The difference in the formation of the nominal stems in -anta is in the -a- of the first and the -m- of the second.

original: “Vā”ti vattate.
analyzed: vāti vattate
translated: “Vā” is said.

original: 107. Simhi gacchantādīnaṃ ntasaddo aṃ.
analyzed: simhi gacchanta ādīnam nta saddaḥ aṃ
translated: . In the -a- of the first, in the -m- of the second, in the -a- of the third, and in the -m- of the fourth, the ntasadda is in the -a- or the -m- of the first, in the -a- or the -m- of the second, in the -a- or the -m- of the third, and in the -a- or the -m- of the fourth.

original: Gacchanticcevamādīnaṃ antappaccayantānaṃ ntasaddo aṃrūpaṃ āpajjate vā simhi vibhattimhi. Saralopasilopā, so gacchaṃ, gacchanto vā gaṇhāti.
analyzed: gacchanti iti ca evamādīnam anta ppaccaya antānam nta saddaḥ aṃ rūpam āpajjate vā simhi vibhattimhi sara lopa si lopā saḥ gaccham gacchantaḥ vā gaṇhāti
translated: The nt-ending of such words as gacchantaṃ, etc., becomes aṃ in the locative case. The nt-ending is elided, and the s- is elided, so it is said gacchanto gacchaṃ, or gaṇhāti.

original: “Gacchantādīnaṃ, ntasaddo”ti ca vattamāne –🔽108. Sesesu ntuva.
analyzed: gacchanta ādīnam ca vattamāne  se sesu n tu va
translated: The nt-ending of such words as gacchantaṃ, etc., becomes an-ending in the locative case, and the nt-ending becomes o-ending in the absolutive. The nt-ending becomes a-ending in the instrumental and dative cases, and the nt-ending becomes e-ending in the genitive case. The nt-ending becomes o-ending in the ablative case, and the nt-ending becomes a-ending in the nominative case. The nt-ending becomes e-ending in the vocative case. The nt-ending becomes a-ending in the locative case, and the nt-ending becomes o-ending in the absolutive. The nt-ending becomes a-ending in the instrumental and dative cases, and the nt-ending becomes e-ending in the genitive case. The nt-ending becomes o-ending in the ablative case, and the nt-ending becomes a-ending in the nominative case. The nt-ending becomes e-ending in the vocative case. The nt-ending becomes a-ending in the locative case, and the nt-ending becomes o-ending in the absolutive.

original: Gacchantādīnaṃ ntasaddo ntupaccayova daṭṭhabbo sesesu vibhattippaccayesu, asmimhi kāriyātidesoyaṃ. Sesaṃ guṇavantusamaṃ.🔽Te gacchanto gacchantā, bho gacchaṃ bho gaccha bho gacchā, bhavanto gacchanto gacchantā,
analyzed: gacchanta ādīnam nta saddaḥ ntu paccayaḥ iva daṭṭhabbaḥ sesesu vibhatti ppaccayesu asmimhi kāriyā atidesaḥ yam sesam guṇavat tu samam  te gacchantaḥ gacchantā bho gaccham bho gaccha bho gaccha bho gaccha bhavantaḥ gacchantaḥ gacchantā
translated: The nt-ending of such words as gacchantaṃ, etc., should be regarded as the nt-ending of the absolutive case only. In the other case-endings, the nt-ending is the same as the o-ending.

original: [gacchaṃ] gacchantaṃ, gacchante, gacchatā gacchantena, gacchantehi gacchantebhi,🔽gacchato gacchantassa, gacchataṃ gacchantānaṃ, gacchatā gacchantasmā gacchantamhā,
analyzed: gaccham gacchantam gacchante gacchatā gacchantena gacchantehi gacchantebhiḥ  gacchataḥ gacchantassa gacchatam gacchantānam gacchata gacchantasmai gacchantamhā
translated: The nt-ending of such words as gacchanto, etc., becomes a-ending in the nominative case, and the nt-ending becomes o-ending in the vocative case. The nt-ending becomes a-ending in the instrumental and dative cases, and the nt-ending becomes e-ending in the genitive case. The nt-ending becomes o-ending in the ablative case, and the nt-ending becomes a-ending in the nominative case. The nt-ending becomes e-ending in the vocative case. The nt-ending becomes a-ending in the locative case, and the nt-ending becomes o-ending in the absolutive.

original: gacchantehi gacchantebhi, gacchato gacchantassa, gacchataṃ gacchantānaṃ, gacchati
analyzed: gacchantehi gacchantebhiḥ gacchataḥ gacchantassa gacchatam gacchantānam gacchati
translated: The nt-ending of such words as gacchanto, etc., becomes a-ending in the nominative case, and the nt-ending becomes o-ending in the vocative case. The nt-ending becomes a-ending in the instrumental and dative cases, and the nt-ending becomes e-ending in the genitive case.

original: gacchante gacchantasmiṃ gacchantamhī, gacchantesu.
analyzed: gacchante gacchantasmin gacchantamhi gacchantesu
translated: Going, going, going, going, they go.

original: Evaṃ mahaṃ caraṃ tiṭṭhaṃ, dadaṃ bhuñjaṃ suṇaṃ pacaṃ;
analyzed: evam maham caram tiṭṭham dadam bhuñjam suṇam pacam
translated: Thus, great, walking, standing, giving, eating, hearing, cooking,

original: Jayaṃ jīraṃ cavaṃ mīyaṃ, saraṃ kubbaṃ japaṃ vajaṃ –
analyzed: jayam jīram cavam mīyam saram kubbam japam vajam
translated: Conquering, decaying, being born, dying, flowing, being crooked, muttering, striking,

original: Iccādayo.
analyzed: i t ca ādayaḥ
translated: Thus, etc.

original: Bhavantasaddassa ga yo nā savacanesu viseso. So bhavaṃ.
analyzed: bhavanta saddassa ga yaḥ nā savacanesu visesaḥ saḥ bhavam
translated: The word bhavaṃ is the same as bhavataṃ in the sense of “you”. It is bhavaṃ.

original: “Bhavato”ti vattate.
analyzed: bhavataḥ iti vattate
translated: “Bhavato” is said.

original: 109. Obhāvo kvaci yosu vakārassa.
analyzed: o bhāvaḥ kvaci yosu vakārassa
translated: The vowel o is sometimes lengthened in the feminine.

original: Bhavantaiccetassa vakārassa obhāvo hoti kvaci yoiccetesu. Te bhonto bhavanto bhavantā.
analyzed: bhavanta e c ca itassa vakārassa o bhāvaḥ hoti kvaci te bhontaḥ bhavantaḥ bhavantā
translated: The vowel o is lengthened in the word bhavati in the feminine in some of these words. They are bhonto, bhavantā, bhavantā.

original: “Bhavato”ti vattate.
analyzed: bhavataḥ iti vattate
translated: “Bhavato” is said.

original: 110. Bho ge tu.
analyzed: bho ge tu
translated: Bho is used with ge.

original: Sabbasseva bhavantasaddassa bho hoti ge pare. Tusaddena bhante, bhontādi ca, galopo, bho bhante bhonta bhontā, bhonto bhavanto bhavantā, bhavantaṃ, bhonte bhavante.
analyzed: sabbassa iva bhavanta saddassa bho hoti ge pare tu saddena bhante bhonta ādi ca ga lopaḥ bho bhante bhonta bhontā bhontaḥ bhavantaḥ bhavantā bhavantam bhonte bhavante
translated: Bho is used with all words ending in bhavataṃ. With the word tu, it is bho bhante, bhonta, bhavantā, bhonto, bhavantā, bhavantā, bhavataṃ, bhonte, bhavante, etc.

original: Nāsesu “obhāvo kvacī”ti yogavibhāgena obhāvo.
analyzed: nāsesu o bhāvaḥ kvaci iti yogavibhāgena
translated: In the sense of “you”, the vowel o is lengthened by the rule “sometimes the vowel o is lengthened”.

original: Bhotā bhavatā bhavantena, bhoto bhavato bhavantassa iccādi.
analyzed: bhotā bhavatā bhavantena bhotaḥ bhavataḥ bhavantassa iccādi
translated: By bhotā, bhavatā, bhavantena, bhoto, bhavato, bhavantassa, etc.

original: 111. Bhadantassa bhaddanta bhante.
analyzed: bhadantassa bhaddanta bhante
translated: 111. Bhadantassa bhaddanta bhante.

original: Sabbasseva bhadantasaddassa bhaddanta bhanteiccete ādesā honti kvaci ge pare yosu ca. Bho bhaddanta bhante, bhadanta bhadantā vā iccādi purisasaddasamaṃ.
analyzed: sabbassa iva bhadanta saddassa bhaddanta bhante icca ete ādesāḥ honti kvaci ge pare yosu ca bho bhaddanta bhante bhadanta bhadantāḥ vā iccādi purisa sadda samam
translated: All the words beginning with bhadantassa have the augment bhaddanta bhante. In some cases the augment is sakāra, in some yosu, and in some ge. Bho bhaddanta bhante, bhadanta bhadantā vā.

original: 112. Santasaddassa so bhe bo cante.🔽Sabbasseva santasaddassa sasaddādeso hoti bhakāre pare, ante ca bakārāgamo hoti.
analyzed: santa saddassa saḥ bhe baḥ ca nte  sabbassa iva santa saddassa sa sadda ādesaḥ hoti bhakāre pare ante ca bakāra āgamaḥ hoti
translated: . Santasaddassa so bhe bo cante.🔽All the words beginning with santa have the augment sasaddādeso, i.e. the augment so, in the case of the following bhakāra, and the addition of the akk of bo.

original: Casaddaggahaṇena abhakārepi samāse kvaci sakārādeso. Sabbhi.
analyzed: a bhakāre pi samāse kvaci sakāra ādesaḥ
translated: By the word ca, the augment sakāra is sometimes added to the compound, even when there is no bhakāra. Sabbhi.

original: Bheti kiṃ? Santehi, sesaṃ gacchantasaddasamaṃ.
analyzed: bheti kim santehi sesam
translated: Bheti kiṃ? Santehi, the rest is the same as the word gacchanta.

original: Atthi rāja brahma atta sakhasaddādīnaṃ bhedo, tatheva syādyuppatti, “rāja si”iti ṭhite –
analyzed: atthi rāja brahma atta sakha sadda ādīnam bhedaḥ tathā iva
translated: Atthi rāja brahma atta sakhasaddādīnaṃ bhedo, tatheva syādyuppatti, “rāja si”iti ṭhite –

original: “Brahmattasakharājādito”ti adhikāro.
analyzed: adhikāraḥ
translated: “Brahmattasakharājādito”ti adhikāro.

original: 113. Syā ca.
analyzed: syā ca
translated: . Syā ca.

original: Brahma atta sakha rājaiccevamādito sivacanassa ākāro hoti. Ādisaddena ātumādisaddato ca. Saralopādi. Rājā tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: brahma atta sakha rāja e c ca ivamāditaḥ si vacanassa ākāraḥ hoti ādi saddena ca sara lopa ādi rājā tiṭṭhati
translated: Brahma atta sakha rājaiccevamādito sivacanassa ākāro hoti. By the word ādi, also from ātumādisaddato. Saralopādi. Rājā tiṭṭhati.

original: 114. Yonamāno.
analyzed: yonamānaḥ
translated: . Yonamāno.

original: Brahmattasakharājādito yonaṃ ānoādeso hoti. Rājāno tiṭṭhanti, bho rāja bho rājā, bhavanto rājāno.
analyzed: brahmatta sakha rāja āditaḥ hoti rājāno tiṭṭhanti bho rāja bho rājā bhavantaḥ rājāno
translated: The words Brahmattasakharājādito are the origin of the declension. The kings stand, O king, O kings, gentlemen, the kings.

original: “Vā”ti vattate.
analyzed: vāti vattate
translated: The word “vā” is used.

original: 115. Brahmattasakharājādito amānaṃ.
analyzed: brahma tta sakha rāja ādeḥ a mānam
translated: . Brahmattasakharājādito amānaṃ.

original: Brahmādīhi parassa aṃvacanassa ānaṃ hoti vā. Rājānaṃ passa rājaṃ vā, rājāno.
analyzed: brahma ādīhi parassa aṃvacanassa ānam hoti vā rājānam rājam vā rājānaḥ
translated: The words Brahmadīhi parassa aṃvacanassa ānaṃ are the origin of the declension. See the king, the king, the kings.

original: “Savibhattissa, rājassā”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: sa vibhattissa rājassa ati ca vattate
translated: The words “Savibhattissa, rājassā” are used.

original: 116. Nāmhi raññā vā.
analyzed: nāmhi raññā vā
translated: . Nāmhi raññā vā.

original: Sabbasseva rājasaddassa savibhattissa raññāādeso hoti vā nāmhi vibhattimhi. Raññā kataṃ rājena vā.
analyzed: sabbassa iva rāja saddassa sa vibhattissa raññā ādesaḥ hoti vā nāmhi vibhattimhi raññā katam rājena vā
translated: The words Sabbasseva rājasaddassa savibhattissa raññāādeso hoti vā nāmhi vibhattimhi are the origin of the declension. Done by the king, by the king.

original: 117. Rājassa rāju sunaṃhisu ca.
analyzed: rājassa rāju ca
translated: . Rājassa rāju sunaṃhisu ca.

original: Sabbassa rājasaddassa rājuādeso hoti su naṃ hiiccetesu vacanesu. Casaddo vikappanattho, “sunaṃhisu cā”ti dīgho, rājūhi rājūbhi, rājehi rājebhi vā.
analyzed: sabbassa rāja saddassa rāju ādesaḥ hoti su nam hi iti ca etesu vacanesu ca saddaḥ vikappana atthaḥ su nam hi su ca ati dīghaḥ rājūhi rājūbhi rājehi rājebhi vā
translated: The words Sabbassa rājasaddassa rājuādeso hoti su naṃ hiiccetesu vacanesu are the origin of the declension. The word “ca” means “alternatively”. “Sunaṃhisu cā” is long. By the kings, by the kings, by the kings, or by the kings.

original: “Savibhattissā”ti adhikāro.
analyzed: sa vibhattissa ati adhikāraḥ
translated: The words “Savibhattissa” are the origin of the declension.

original: 118. Rājassa raññorājino se.
analyzed: rājassa rañño rājinaḥ se
translated: . Rājassa raññorājino se.🔽. The words Sabbassa rājasaddassa raññāādeso hoti seiccetesu vacanesu are the origin of the declension. The king, the king, the kings.

original: Sabbasseva rājasaddassa savibhattissa rañño rājinoiccete ādesā honti se vibhattimhi. Rañño, rājino deti.
analyzed: sabbassa iva rāja saddassa sa vibhattissa raññaḥ rājino icca ete ādesāḥ honti se vibhattimhi raññaḥ rājinaḥ deti
translated: In the case of all the words for king with a case-ending, the forms rañño and rājino are the augmentations in the sixth case. He gives to the king, to the king.

original: “Rājassā”ti vattate.🔽119. Raññaṃ naṃ mhī vā.
analyzed: rājassa ati vattate  raññam naṃ mhī vā
translated: The word rajjassa is used.

original: Sabbasseva rājasaddassa savibhattissa raññaṃādeso hoti vā naṃmhi vibhattimhi. Raññaṃ rājūnaṃ rājānaṃ.
analyzed: sabbassa iva rāja saddassa sa vibhattissa raññaṃ ādesaḥ hoti vā naṃmhi vibhattimhi raññam rājūnam rājānam
translated: In the case of all the words for king with a case-ending, the form raññaṃ is the augmentation in the sixth case. The kings, the kings, the king.

original: Pañcamiyaṃ –
analyzed: pañcamiyam
translated: In the fifth case:

original: 120. Amhatumhanturājabrahmattasakhasatthupitādīhi smā nāva.
analyzed: amha tumha ntu rāja brahma tta sakha satthu pita ādīhi smā na ava
translated: Amhatumhanturājabrahmattasakhasatthupitādīhi smā nāva.

original: Amhatumhanturājabrahmattasakhasatthupituiccevamādīhi smāvacanaṃ nāva daṭṭhabbanti smāvacanassa nābhāvātideso. Atideso pana chabbidho.
analyzed: amha tumha ntu rāja brahmatta sakha satthu pitu icca ivamādīhi smā vacanam nā ava daṭṭhabbanti smā vacanassa nā bhāva atideso atideso pana chabbidhaḥ
translated: The words amha, tumha, naṃ, rājā, brahmā, atta, sakhā, satthā, pitā, etc., are to be regarded as having the form of the third person singular, but not as such. The augmentations are of six kinds:

original: Vuttañca –
analyzed: vuttam ca
translated: And it is said:

original: “Byapadeso nimittañca, taṃrūpaṃ taṃsabhāvatā;
analyzed: byapadesaḥ nimittam ca taṃrūpam taṃsa bhāva tā
translated: Byapadeso nimittañca, taṃrūpaṃ taṃsabhāvatā;

original: Suttañceva tathā kāri-yātidesoti chabbidho”ti.
analyzed: suttam ca iva tathā kāriyā atideso ti chabbidhaḥ ti
translated: Suttañceva tathā kāri-yātidesoti chabbidho.

original: Tatrāyaṃ brahmattasakhādīsu pāṭhasāmatthiyato rūpātideso. Sesaṃ tatiyāsamaṃ.
analyzed: tatra ayam brahmatta sakha ādīsu pāṭha sāmatthiyataḥ rūpa atidesaḥ sesam tatiyāsamam
translated: Herein, the augmentation of the form is in the case of brahmā, sakhā, etc., because of the possibility of the reading. The rest is the same as in the third declension.

original: Raññā apeti, rājūhi rājūbhi, rājehi rājebhi, rañño, rājino santakaṃ, raññaṃ rājūnaṃ rājānaṃ.
analyzed: raññā apeti rājūhi rājūbhi rājehi rājebhi raññaḥ rājinaḥ santakam raññam rājūnam rājānam
translated: With the king, by the kings, by the kings, by the king, of the king, of the kings, of the kings.

original: “Rājassā”ti vattate.
analyzed: rājassa ati vattate
translated: “Of the king” is used.

original: 121. Smiṃmhi raññe rājini.
analyzed: smimhi raññe rājini
translated: In the locative, in the king, in the king.

original: Sabbasseva rājasaddassa savibhattissa raññerājiniiccete ādesā honti smiṃmhi vibhattimhi. Raññe, rājini patiṭṭhitaṃ, rājūsu rājesu.
analyzed: sabbassa iva rāja saddassa sa vibhattissa raññe rājini iti ca ete ādesāḥ honti smim mhi vibhattimhi raññe rājini patiṭṭhitam rājūsu rājesu
translated: In the locative case, the endings raññe and rājini are used for all the case-endings of the word rājā. Established in the king, in the kings, in the kings.

original: Brahmasaddassa ca ga nā sa smiṃsu viseso. Brahmā, brahmāno.
analyzed: brahma saddassa ca ga nā sa sminsu visesaḥ brahmā brahmānaḥ
translated: And of the word brahma, ga, na, sa are the alternatives in the locative. Brahma, brahmans.

original: Ālapane ca “e”ti vattate.🔽122. Brahmato gassa ca.
analyzed: ālapane ca eti vattate  brahmataḥ gassa ca
translated: And “e” is used in addressing.🔽And of brahma, ga has the svarita accent.

original: Brahmasaddato gassa ca ekāro hoti, caggahaṇaṃ eggahaṇānukaḍḍhanatthaṃ, bho brahme, bhavanto brahmāno, brahmānaṃ brahmaṃ, brahmāno.
analyzed: brahma saddataḥ gassa ca e kāraḥ hoti ca ggahaṇam e ggahaṇa anukaḍḍhana ttham bho brahme bhavantaḥ brahmānaḥ brahmānam brahmam brahmānaḥ
translated: Of the word brahma, ga has the svarita accent, the mention of ga is for the purpose of including the mention of e, O brahma, O brahmans, of the brahman, of the brahman, of the brahmans.

original: Vipariṇāmena “brahmassa, anto”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: vipariṇāmena brahmassa antaḥ iti ca vattate
translated: By the change of the vowel, “of the brahma, within” is used.

original: 123. Uttaṃ sanāsu.
analyzed: uttam sanāsu
translated: The svarita accent is in the locative.

original: Brahmasaddassa anto uttamāpajjate sa nāiccetesu vacanesu. Uttamiti bhāvaniddeso katthaci abhāvadassanattho. Brahmunā, brahmehi brahmebhi.
analyzed: brahma saddassa antaḥ uttam āpajjate sa vacanesu uttam iti bhāva niddesaḥ katthaci abhāva dassana tthaḥ brahmunā brahmehi brahmebhi
translated: The form of the word Brahmuna is the highest in these words. The word uttama is a description of the state of being developed. In some places it is for the purpose of showing the absence of the state of being developed. With Brahmuna, with Brahmas, with Brahmas.

original: Sasmiṃ utte kate “ivaṇṇuvaṇṇā jhalā”ti lasaññāyaṃ –
analyzed: sasmin u tte kate jha l ā ti la saññā ayam
translated: When the ut is made, “ivaṇṇuvaṇṇā jhalā” , in the sign of las.

original: 124. Jhalato sassa no vā.🔽Jhalasaññehi ivaṇṇuvaṇṇehi parassa saiccetassa vacanassa noiccādeso hoti vā. Brahmuno brahmassa, brahmānaṃ brahmūnaṃ vā, uttamiti yogavibhāgena aññatthāpi uttaṃ.🔽Pañcamiyaṃ nābhāvātideso. Brahmunā, brahmehi brahmebhi, brahmuno brahmassa, brahmānaṃ brahmūnaṃ vā.🔽125. Brahmato tu smiṃ ni.
analyzed: jha l ataḥ sassa naḥ vā  jha l a saññehi i va ṇ u vaṇṇehi parassa sa e cca itassa vacanassa no icca ādesaḥ hoti vā brahmunaḥ brahmassa brahmānam brahmūnam vā uttam iti yogavibhāgena aññattha api uttam  na abhāva atidesaḥ brahmunā brahmehi brahmebhiḥ brahmunaḥ brahmassa brahmānam brahmūnam vā  brahmataḥ tu smin ni
translated: From jhal, the sa is not.

original: Brahmasaddato smiṃvacanassa ni hoti. Tusaddena kammacammamuddhādito ca kvaci. Brahmani, brahmesu.🔽Attasaddassa tatiyādīsveva viseso.
analyzed: brahma saddataḥ smiṃvacanassa ni hoti tu saddena kamma camma muddha āditaḥ ca kvaci brahmani brahmesu 🔽atta saddassa tatiya ādīsu eva visesaḥ
translated: The form of the word noiccādeso is made in the sign of jhal, with ivaṇṇuvaṇṇas, in the word of another’s saicceta. With Brahmuna, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brahmas, with Brah

original: Attā, attāno, bho atta bho attā, bhavanto attāno, attānaṃ attaṃ, attāno.
analyzed: attā attānaḥ bho atta bho attā bhavantaḥ attānaḥ attānam attam attānaḥ
translated: Attā, attāno, bho atta bho attā, bhavanto attāno, attānaṃ, attā.

original: Nāmhi “akammantassa cā”ti ettha casaddena attantassa attaṃ vā. Attanā attena vā.
analyzed: nāmhi a kammantassa ca ati ettha ca saddena attantassa attam vā attanā attena vā
translated: Nāmhi “akammantassa cā”ti ettha casaddena attantassa attaṃ vā. Attanā attena vā.

original: 126. Attanto hismimanattaṃ.
analyzed: attantaḥ hismimanattam
translated: . Attanto hismimanattaṃ.

original: Attasaddassa anto anattamāpajjate hismiṃ pare. Attanehi attanebhi.
analyzed: atta saddassa antaḥ anattam āpajjate hi smim pare attanehi attanebhi
translated: Attasaddassa anto anattamāpajjate hismiṃ pare. Attanehi attanebhi.

original: “Tato, attato”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: tatas ca vattate
translated: “Tato, attato”ti ca vattate.

original: 127. Sassa no.
analyzed: sassa no
translated: . Sassa no.

original: Tato attasaddato sassa vibhattissa no hoti. Attano, attānaṃ.
analyzed: tatas atta saddataḥ sassa vibhattissa no hoti attanaḥ attānam
translated: Tato attasaddato sassa vibhattissa no hoti. Attano, attānaṃ.

original: 128. Smā nā.
analyzed: smā nā
translated: . Smā nā.

original: Tato attasaddato smāvacanassa nā hoti. Attanā apeti.
analyzed: tatas atta saddataḥ smā vacanassa nā hoti attanā apeti
translated: Tato attasaddato smāvacanassa nā hoti. Attanā apeti.

original: Nābhāvātideseneva siddhepi uttarasuttena ekayogamakatvā bhinnayogakaraṇaṃ atthantaraviññāpanatthaṃ,
analyzed: na abhāva atidesena iva siddhe pi uttara suttena eka yogam a katvā bhinna yoga karaṇam atthantara viññāpana ttham
translated: Nābhāvātideseneva siddhepi uttarasuttena ekayogamakatvā bhinnayogakaraṇaṃ atthantaraviññāpanatthaṃ,

original: tena attantatakārassa rakāro jakāre kvaci. Atrajo attajo vā. Attanehi attanebhi, attano, attānaṃ.
analyzed: tena attanta takārassa rakāraḥ jakāre kvaci atrajaḥ attajaḥ vā attanehi attanebhi attano attānam
translated: tena attantatakārassa rakāro jakāre kvaci. Atrajo attajo vā. Attanehi attanebhi, attano, attānaṃ.

original: “Attato”ti vattate.
analyzed: attataḥ iti vattate
translated: “Attato”ti vattate.

original: 129. Tato smiṃ ni.
analyzed: tataḥ smin ni
translated: . Tato smiṃ ni.

original: Tato attasaddato smiṃvacanassa ni hoti. Attani, attesu.
analyzed: tatas atta saddataḥ smiṃvacanassa ni hoti atta ni attesu
translated: Then, from the word attā, ni is substituted for the locative case-ending. In attani, attesu.

original: Sakhasaddassa bhedo. Sakhā, sakhāno.
analyzed: sakha saddassa bhedaḥ sakhā sakhāno
translated: The word sakhā has two forms. Sakhā, sakhāno.

original: “Yona”miti vattate.🔽130. Sakhato cāyono.
analyzed: yonam iti vattate  sakhataḥ ca ayonaḥ
translated: The word yona is mentioned.🔽And from sakhā, āyo is substituted for yona.

original: Sakhasaddato yonaṃ āyo noādesā ca honti. Sakhāyo.
analyzed: ca honti sakhāyaḥ
translated: From the word sakhā, āyo is substituted for yona, and the vowel-change is not made. Sakhāyo.

original: 131. Sakhantassi nonānaṃsesu.
analyzed: sakhantassi na una an aṃsesu
translated: And from sakhā, ikā is substituted for the final a, in nonānaṃsaiccetesu.

original: Sakhasaddantassa ikārādeso hoti nonānaṃsaiccetesu paresu. Sakhino tiṭṭhanti.
analyzed: sakha sadda antassa ikāra ādesaḥ hoti no na anaṃsa e c ca itesu paresu sakhinaḥ tiṭṭhanti
translated: From the word sakhā, ikā is substituted for the final a, in nonānaṃsaiccetesu, the other words. Sakhino tiṭṭhanti.

original: Ālapane gasaññāyaṃ –
analyzed: ālapane ga saññāyam
translated: In addressing, in the case of the word gasa –

original: 132. Sakhato gasse vā.
analyzed: sakhataḥ gasse vā
translated: From sakhā, gasa has the vowel-change or not.

original: Sakhato gassa akāra ākāra ikāra īkāraekārādesā honti. Vāsaddena aññasmāpi kvaci ekāro. Yathā – bhaddante ise iti.
analyzed: sakhataḥ gassa akāra ākāra ikāra īkāra ekāra ādesāḥ honti vā saddena aññasma api kvaci ekāraḥ yathā bhaddante ise iti
translated: From sakhā, gasa has the vowel-change a, ā, i, ī, e, ai. By the word vā, the vowel-change is made in some other words also. As, bhaddante ise.

original: A ca ā ca i ca ī ca e cātipi e, pubbassarānaṃ kamena lopo.
analyzed: a ca ā ca i ca ī ca e ca atipi e pubbassarānam kamena lopaḥ
translated: And a, ā, i, ī, e, are also e. The first and second vowels are elided by the rule.

original: Bho sakha bho sakhā bho sakhi bho sakhī bho sakhe, bhavanto sakhāno sakhāyo sakhino.
analyzed: bho sakha bho sakhā bho sakhi bho sakhī bho sakhe bhavantaḥ sakhānaḥ sakhāyaḥ sakhinaḥ
translated: Bho sakha, bho sakhā, bho sakhi, bho sakhī, bho sakhe, bhavanto sakhāno sakhāyo sakhino.

original: “Sakhantassa, āro cā”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: sakhantassa āraḥ ca ati ca vattate
translated: And the words sakhassa, āro, are mentioned.

original: 133. Sunamaṃsu vā.
analyzed: su namaṃsu vā
translated: And sunamaṃsu, or.

original: Sakhantassa āro bhoti vā sunaṃ aṃiccetesu paresu. Sakhāraṃ sakhānaṃ sakhaṃ, sakhāno sakhāyo sakhino, sakhinā.
analyzed: sakhantassa āraḥ bhoti vā sunam aṃ it ca itesu paresu sakhāram sakhānam sakham sakhānaḥ sakhāyaḥ sakhinaḥ sakhinā
translated: The forms of the word sakhā are sakhāraṃ, sakhānaṃ, sakhaṃ, sakhāno, sakhāyo, sakhino, sakhinā.

original: “Sakhantassā”ti vattate.
analyzed: sakhantassa iti vattate
translated: The form sakhantassa is used.

original: 134. Āro himhi vā.
analyzed: āraḥ himhi vā
translated: The form āro is used in the locative case.

original: Sakhantassa āro hoti vā himhi vibhattimhi. Sakhārehi sakhārebhi, sakhehi sakhebhi.
analyzed: sakhantassa āraḥ hoti vā himhi vibhattimhi sakhārehi sakhārebhi sakhehi sakhebhi
translated: The form āro is used in the locative case. The forms are sakhārehi, sakhārebhi, sakhehi, sakhebhi.

original: Ikārādese “jhalato sassa no vā”ti no. Sakhino sakhissa, sakhārānaṃ sakhīnaṃ.
analyzed: ikāra ādese jha l ataḥ sassa no vāti no sakhinaḥ sakhissa sakhārānam sakhīnam
translated: In the declensions beginning with ika, the form no is used for sassa. The forms are sakhino, sakhissa, sakhārānaṃ, sakhīnaṃ.

original: Smāvacanassa nābhāvo. Sakhinā, sakhārehi sakhārebhi sakhehi sakhebhi, sakhino sakhissa, sakhārānaṃ sakhīnaṃ.
analyzed: smā vacanassa na abhāvaḥ sakhinā sakhārehi sakhārebhi sakhehi sakhebhi sakhino sakhissa sakhārānam sakhīnam
translated: The form nābhāvo is used. The forms are sakhinā, sakhārehi, sakhārebhi, sakhehi, sakhebhi, sakhino, sakhissa, sakhārānaṃ, sakhīnaṃ.

original: “Sakhato”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: sakhatoti ca vattate
translated: The form sakhato is used.

original: 135. Smime.
analyzed: smime
translated: The form smiṃ is used.

original: Sakhato smiṃvacanassa ekāro hoti. Niccatthoyamārambho. Sakhe, sakhāresu sakhesu.
analyzed: sakhataḥ smiṃvacanassa ekāraḥ hoti niccatthaḥ yam ārambhaḥ sakhe sakhāresu sakhesu
translated: The form ekāro is used in the locative case of the word sakhā. The purpose of this rule is to make the word permanent. The forms are sakhe, sakhāresu, sakhesu.

original: Ātumasaddassa paṭhamādutiyāsu attasaddasseva rūpanayo. Ātumā, ātumāno, bho ātuma bho ātumā, bhavanto ātumāno, ātumānaṃ ātumaṃ, ātumāno, ātumena iccādi purisasamaṃ.
analyzed: ātuma saddassa paṭhamā dutiyāsu atta saddassa iva rūpa nayaḥ ātumāḥ ātumānaḥ bho ātuma bho ātumāḥ bhavantaḥ ātumānaḥ ātumānam ātumam ātumānaḥ ātumena iccādi purisa samam
translated: The forms of the word ātuma are the same as those of the word purisa, except that the forms of the word ātuma are ātumā, ātumāno, bho ātuma, bho ātumā, bhavanto ātumāno, ātumānaṃ, ātumaṃ, ātumāno, ātumena, etc.

original: Pumasaddassa bhedo. Puma si,
analyzed: puma saddassa bhedaḥ puma si
translated: The difference of the word for “man”. Man, he.

original: “Savibhattissā”ti adhikāro.
analyzed: sa vibhattissa ati adhikāraḥ
translated: The extension “with case-ending” applies.

original: 136. Pumantassā simhi.
analyzed: pum antassa simhi
translated: In the feminine of the word for “man”.

original: Pumasaddassa savibhattissa ākārādeso hoti simhi vibhattimhi. Antaggahaṇena maghavayuvādīnamantassa ca. Pumā.
analyzed: puma saddassa sa vibhattissa ākāra ādesaḥ hoti simhi vibhattimhi anta ggahaṇena maghava yuva ādīnam antassa ca pumā
translated: There is a change of the form of the word for “man” with case-ending in the feminine case-ending. By the word “end” is also included the word for “man” in the vocative case and the word for “man” in the locative case. Man, he.

original: “Pumantassā”ti adhikāro.
analyzed: pumantassa ati adhikāraḥ
translated: The extension “of the word for ‘man’” applies.

original: 137. Yosvāno.
analyzed: yosvānaḥ
translated: In the feminine dual.

original: Pumantassa savibhattissa ānoādeso hoti yosu vibhattīsu. Pumāno.
analyzed: pum antassa sa vibhattissa ānaḥ ādesaḥ hoti yosu vibhattīsu pumānaḥ
translated: There is a change of the form of the word for “man” with case-ending in the feminine dual case-ending. Men, they.

original: 138. Amālapanekavacane.
analyzed: am ālapan ekavacane
translated: In the vocative singular.

original: Pumantassa savibhattissa aṃ hoti ālapanekavacane pare. He pumaṃ, he pumāno, pumaṃ, pumāno.
analyzed: pum antassa sa vibhattissa aṃ hoti ālapana ekavacane pare he pumam he pumāno pumam pumāno
translated: There is a change of the form of the word for “man” with case-ending in the vocative singular. He man, he men, man, men.

original: “Ā, vā”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: ā vāti ca vattate
translated: And the word “or” applies.

original: 139. U nāmhi ca.
analyzed: u nāmhi ca
translated: In the nominative and in the ablative.

original: Pumantassa āuādesā honti vā nāmhi vibhattimhi. Casaddena pumakammathāmantassa cu’kāro vā sasmāsu. Pumānā pumunā pumena vā.
analyzed: pum antassa āu ādesāḥ honti vā nāmhi vibhattimhi ca saddena puma kamma thām antassa cukāraḥ vā sa smāsu pumānā pumunā pumena vā
translated: There is a change of the form of the word for “man” to “u” or “a” in the nominative and ablative case-ending. By the word “and” is included the change of the form of the word for “man” in the locative case-ending to “u” or “a” and the change of the form of the word for “man” in the vocative case-ending to “u” or “a”. Man, men, by man, by men.

original: “Āne”ti vattate.
analyzed: āneti vattate
translated: The word “in” applies.

original: 140. Hivibhattimhi ca.
analyzed: hi vibhattimhi ca
translated: And in the instrumental.

original: Pumantassa hivibhattimhī ca āneādeso hoti. Vibhattiggahaṇaṃ savibhattiggahaṇanivattanatthaṃ. Pumānehi pumānebhi.
analyzed: pum antassa hi vibhattimhi ca āne ādesaḥ hoti vibhatti ggahaṇam sa vibhatti ggahaṇa nivattana attham pumānehi pumānebhi
translated: For a masculine noun, the vowel-sign ā is substituted for the vowel-signs i and ī of the case-endings. The mention of the case-endings is for the purpose of excluding those that have case-endings. Masculine with masculine, masculine with feminine.

original: Casaddena yuvamaghavādīnamantassa vā ānādeso hoti sabbavibhattīsu. “U nāmhi cā”ti
analyzed: ca saddena yuva maghava ādīnam antassa vā ān ādesaḥ hoti sabba vibhattīsu u na amhi ca ati
translated: By the word ca, the vowel-sign ā is substituted for the vowel-sign u of the case-ending in all the case-endings. “U nāmhi ca” (Gram. 1.1.5).

original: ettha casaddena pumantassukāro vā sasmāsu vibhattīsu. “Jhalato sassa no vā”ti no.
analyzed: ettha ca saddena vā vibhattīsu jha lataḥ sassa naḥ vā ati no
translated: Here, by the word ca, the vowel-sign u is substituted for the vowel-sign a of the masculine noun in the case-endings that have a. “Jhalato sassa no vā” (Gram. 1.1.6). Not.

original: Pumuno pumassa, pumānaṃ.
analyzed: pumunaḥ pumassa pumānam
translated: Masculine of masculine, masculine of feminine.

original: “Smā, nā”ti vattate.
analyzed: smā na ati vattate
translated: “Smā, nā” (Gram. 1.1.7) is applicable.

original: 141. Jhalato ca.
analyzed: jha l a taḥ ca
translated: . And from jhala.

original: Jhalaiccetehi smāvacanassa nā hoti. Caggahaṇaṃ kvaci nivattanatthaṃ. Pumānā pumunā pumā pumasmā pumamhā, pumānehi pumānebhi pumehi pumebhi, pumuno pumassa, pumānaṃ.
analyzed: jha l a i t ca i tehi sma a vacanassa nā hoti ca ggahaṇam kvaci nivattana attham pumānā pumunā pumā pumasmā pumamhā pumānehi pumānebhi pumehi pumebhi pumuno pumassa pumānam
translated: The word nā is not substituted for the word smā after these words beginning with jhala. The word ca is for the purpose of excluding in some cases. Masculine with masculine, masculine with masculine, masculine with masculine, from the masculine, by the masculine, by the masculines, by the masculine, by the masculines, by the masculine, by the masculines, of the masculine, of the masculines.

original: 142. Āne smiṃmhi vā.
analyzed: āne smim hi vā
translated: . Ā, ne, smiṃ, mhi, or vā.

original: Pumantassa savibhattissa āneādeso hoti vā smiṃmhi vibhattimhi. Pumāne pume pumasmiṃ pumamhi.
analyzed: pum antassa sa vibhattissa ā ne ādesaḥ hoti vā sminmhi vibhattimhi pumāne pume pumasmin pumamhi
translated: The vowel-sign ā is substituted for the vowel-sign i of the case-ending that has a case-ending, or in the case-ending smiṃ, mhi. By the masculine, by the masculine, in the masculine, in the masculine.

original: 143. Susmimā vā.
analyzed: su smimā vā
translated: . Su, smiṃ, or vā.

original: Pumantassa suiccetasmiṃ pare āādeso hoti vā. Pumāsu pumesu.
analyzed: pum antassa su iti itasmin pare āādesaḥ hoti vā pumāsu pumesu
translated: The vowel-sign ā is substituted for the vowel-sign u of the masculine noun, or in the following word that begins with s. By the masculines, by the masculines.

original: Yuvādīsu “yuva si” itīdha –
analyzed: yuva ādīsu yuva si iti idha
translated: in yuva si,

original: “Pumantassā simhī”ti ettha antaggahaṇena ākāro, “hivibhattimhi cā”ti sutte casaddena ānādeso ca.
analyzed: pum antassa simhi iti ettha anta ggahaṇena ākāraḥ hi vibhattimhi ca ati sutte ca saddena āna ādesaḥ ca
translated: in pumantassa siṃhī, the vowel sign is by the inclusion of the final, and the ā-sign is by the word ca in the sutta hīvibhattimhi ca.

original: Yuvā yuvāno, yuvānā yuvā, he yuva he yuvā he yuvāna he yuvānā, bhavanto yuvānā, yuvānaṃ yuvaṃ, yuvāne yuve.
analyzed: yuvā yuvānaḥ yuvānā yuvā he yuva he yuvā he yuvāna he yuvānā bhavantaḥ yuvānā yuvānam yuvam yuvāne yuve
translated: Yuva, yuvano, yuvanā, yuva, he yuva, he yuvano, he yuvanā, bhavanto yuvanā, yuvanassa, yuvaṃ, yuvane, yuve.

original: “Akammantassa cā”ti ettha casaddena yuvamaghavādīnamantassa ā hoti vā nāsuiccetesūti āttaṃ.
analyzed: a kammantassa ca ati ettha ca saddena yuva maghava ādīnam antassa ā hoti vā ā ttam
translated: In akammantassa ca, the ā-sign is by the word ca, and the ā-sign of yuva, maghavā, etc., is optionally by the word nāsuiccetesu.

original: Yuvānā yuvena yuvānena vā, yuvānehi yuvānebhi yuvehi yuvebhi, yuvānassa yuvassa,🔽yuvānānaṃ yuvānaṃ, yuvānā yuvānasmā yuvānamhā, yuvānehi yuvānebhi yuvehi yuvebhi,
analyzed: yuvānā yuvena yuvānena vā yuvānehi yuvānebhi yuvehi yuvebhi yuvānassa yuvassa  yuvānānam yuvānam yuvānā yuvānasmai yuvānamhā yuvānehi yuvānebhiḥ yuvehi yuvebhiḥ
translated: Yuvanā, yuvena, yuvanena, yuvanehi, yuvanebhi, yuvehi, yuvebhi, yuvanassa, yuvasse,🔽yuvanānaṃ, yuvanānaṃ, yuvanā, yuvasmā, yuvanamhā, yuvanehi, yuvanebhi, yuvehi, yuvebhi,

original: yuvānassa yuvassa, yuvānānaṃ yuvānaṃ, yuvāne yuvānasmiṃ yuvānamhi yuve yuvamhi yuvasmiṃ,
analyzed: yuvānassa yuvassa yuvānānam yuvānam yuvāne yuvānasmin yuvānamhi yuve yuvamhi yuvasmin
translated: yuvanassa, yuvasse, yuvanānaṃ, yuvanānaṃ, yuvane, yuvasmiṃ, yuvanamhī, yuve, yuvamhī, yuvasmiṃ,

original: yuvānesu yuvāsu yuvesu.
analyzed: yuvānesu yuvāsu yuvesu
translated: yuvanesu, yuvasu, yuvesu.

original: Evaṃ maghavā maghavāno, maghavānā iccādi yuvasaddasamaṃ.
analyzed: evam maghavā maghavānaḥ maghavānau iccādi yuvasaddasamam
translated: So too maghavā, maghavāno, maghavānā, etc., are like the word yuva.

original: Akārantaṃ.🔽Ākāranto pulliṅgo sāsaddo.
analyzed: akāra antam 🔽ākāra antaḥ pulliṅgaḥ sāsaddaḥ
translated: It is not a final.🔽The word ending in a is neuter.

original: Sā si, silopo, sā sunakho.
analyzed: sā si si lopaḥ sā su nakhaḥ
translated: That is the female jackal.

original: Bahuvacane –
analyzed: bahuvacane
translated: In the plural:

original: 144. Agho rassamekavacanayosvapi ca.
analyzed: a ghaḥ ras sam ekavacanayosu api ca
translated: And in the singular and dual, too, the word “fire”

original: Ghasaññakaākāravajjito liṅgassanto saro rassamāpajjate ekavacanesu yosu ca paresūti rassattaṃ. Apiggahaṇaṃ simhi nivattanatthaṃ. Sesaṃ neyyaṃ.
analyzed: gha saññaka ākāra vajjitaḥ liṅgaḥ santaḥ saraḥ rassam āpajjate ekavacanesu yosu ca paresu iti rassattam apiggahaṇam simhi nivattana attham sesam na iyyam
translated: Has the form of the feminine ending, omitting the sign of the feminine, and it takes the form of the singular and dual in the feminine. The word “too” is for the purpose of excluding the word “lion”. The rest is to be inferred.

original: Sā tiṭṭhanti, he sa he sā, he sā, saṃ, se, sena, sāhi sābhi, sassa sāya, sānaṃ, sā sasmā samhā, sāhi sābhi, sassa, sānaṃ, se sasmiṃ samhi, sāsu.
analyzed: sā tiṭṭhanti he sa he sā he sā sam se sena sāhi sā abhi sassa sāya sānam sā sasmā samhā sāhi sā abhi sassa sānam se sasmin samhi sāsu
translated: She stands, O he, he, she, she, they, they, they, by her, by them, of her, of them, of them, in her, in them, in them.

original: Evaṃ paccakkhadhammā gāṇḍīvadhanvāpabhutayo.
analyzed: evam paccakkha dhammāḥ gāṇḍīvadhanva apabhutayaḥ
translated: Thus the feminine forms are like the bow and the lute.

original: Ākārantaṃ.
analyzed: ākāra antam
translated: The feminine ending.

original: Ikāranto pulliṅgo aggisaddo. Syādyuppatti, aggi si,
analyzed: ikāra antaḥ pulliṅgaḥ aggi saddo syāt yuppatti aggi si
translated: The masculine word for “fire” has the vowel i. The vowel i is produced by a sibilant.

original: “Anto, simhi, vā”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: antaḥ s imhi vāti ca vattate
translated: “In the locative, or in the word for ‘lion’,” is said.

original: 145. Aggissini.
analyzed: aggissini
translated: . The feminine of “fire” is agnissī.

original: Aggissa anto ini hoti vā simhi vibhattimhi. “Sesato lopaṃ gasipī”ti silopo. Aggini aggi.
analyzed: aggissa antaḥ ini hoti vā simhi vibhattimhi sesataḥ lopam ga sipi iti si lopaḥ aggini aggi
translated: In the locative case, the word for “fire” has the feminine ending ini, or in the word for “lion”. “The feminine ending is elided after the rest,” is said. Aggini, aggi.

original: Bahuvacane “ivaṇṇuvaṇṇā jhalā”ti jhalasaññāyaṃ –
analyzed: bahuvacane jha l ā ti jha l a saññā ayam
translated: In the plural, “the vowels i and u are like the flames,” is said.

original: “Jhalato, vā”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: jha lataḥ vāti ca vattate
translated: “After the word for ‘flame,’ or,” is said.

original: 146. Ghapato ca yonaṃ lopo.
analyzed: gha pataḥ ca ya ūnam lopaḥ
translated: And in the case of a house, the omission of the vocative.

original: Ghapasaññehi itthivācakehi ākārivaṇṇuvaṇṇehi, jhalasaññehi ca paresaṃ yovacanānaṃ lopo hoti vā. Vavatthitavibhāsāyaṃ.
analyzed: gha pa saññehi itthi vācakehi ākāri vaṇṇu vaṇṇehi jha l a saññehi ca paresam yo vacanānam lopaḥ hoti vā
translated: In the case of the words for a woman, which are like a house, and in the case of the words for another’s young woman, which are like a hut, there is omission of the vocative, optionally. In the Vavatthana Vibhasa.

original: 147. Yosu katanikāralopesu dīghaṃ.
analyzed: yosu kata nikāra lopesu dīgham
translated: In the case of the feminine, the long in the omission of the affix ka.

original: Liṅgassantabhūtā sabbe rassasarā yosu katanikāralopesu dīghamāpajjante. Katā nikāralopā yesaṃ te katanikāralopā. Aggī.
analyzed: sabbe rassa sarāḥ yosu kata nikāra lopesu dīgham āpajjante katāḥ nikāra lopāḥ yesam te kata nikāra lopāḥ aggī
translated: All the short syllables become long in the case of the feminine, in the omission of the affix ka. Aggi.

original: “Pañcādīnamatta”nti ito “atta”miti vattate.🔽148. Yosvakatarasso jho.
analyzed: pañca ādīnam attanti itas attam iti vattate  ya us va katarassaḥ jhaḥ
translated: “Atta, etc.”: the word atta is derived from this.🔽In the case of the feminine, the jha becomes ya.

original: Yosu paresu akatarasso jho attamāpajjate. Aggayo.
analyzed: yosu paresu a katarassaḥ jhaḥ attam āpajjate aggayo
translated: In the case of the feminine, the jha becomes ya. Aggayo.

original: Jhoti kiṃ? Rattiyo.
analyzed: kim
translated: What is jha? Rattiyo.

original: Ālapanepevaṃ. He aggi, he aggī he aggayo.
analyzed: he aggi he aggī he aggayo
translated: In the case of the vocative, too, it is the same. He aggi, he aggī, he aggayo.

original: Dutiyekavacane pubbassaralope sampatte –
analyzed: dutiya ekavacane pubbassara lope sampatte
translated: When the omission of the first syllable has been effected in the singular,

original: 149. Aṃ mo niggahītaṃ jhalapehi.
analyzed: am maḥ niggahītam jha l apehi
translated: The aṃ is suppressed, and the jha is aspirated.

original: Jhalapaiccetehi parassa aṃvacanassa, makārassa ca niggahītaṃ ādeso hoti. Aggiṃ.
analyzed: jha l a pai cca itehi parassa aṃvacanassa makārassa ca niggahītam ādesaḥ hoti aggim
translated: The aṃ of the vocative and the m of the first syllable are suppressed, and the jha is aspirated. Aggiṃ.

original: Aggī aggayo, agginā, aggīhi aggībhi, “sunaṃhisu cā”ti ettha caggahaṇena katthaci dīghābhāvo. Aggihi aggibhi.
analyzed: aggī aggayaḥ agginā aggīhi aggībhi ca ati ettha ca ggahaṇena katthaci dīgha abhāvaḥ aggihi aggibhi
translated: Aggī, aggayo, agginā, aggīhi, aggībhi, “sunaṃhisu cā” ti ettha caggahaṇena katthaci dīghābhāvo. Aggīhi, aggībhi.

original: “Jhalato sassa no vā”ti no. Aggino aggissa, aggīnaṃ.
analyzed: jha l ataḥ sassa naḥ vāti naḥ agginaḥ aggissa aggīnam
translated: “Jhalato sassa no vā” ti no. Aggissa, aggīnaṃ.

original: “Smā nā”ti vattamāne “jhalato cā”ti vikappena nā. Agginā aggismā aggimhā, aggīhi aggībhi aggihi aggibhi, aggino aggissa, aggīnaṃ agginaṃ, aggimhi aggismiṃ, aggīsu aggisu.
analyzed: smā na ati vattamāne jha lataḥ ca ati vikappena nā agginā aggismā aggimhā aggīhi aggībhi aggihi aggibhi agginaḥ aggissa aggīnam agginam aggimhi aggismin aggīsu aggisu
translated: “Smā nā” ti vattamāne “jhalato cā” ti vikappena nā. Agginā, aggismā, aggimhā, aggīhi, aggībhi, aggīhi, aggibhi, aggino, aggissa, aggīnaṃ, agginaṃ, aggimhi, aggismiṃ, aggīsu, aggisu.

original: Evamaññepi –
analyzed: evam aññe pi
translated: So evaṃ aññepi –

original: Joti pāṇi gaṇṭhi muṭṭhi, kucchi vatthi sāli vīhi;
analyzed: joti pāṇi gaṇṭhi muṭṭhi kucchi vatthi sāli vīhi
translated: Joti pāṇi gaṇṭhi muṭṭhi, kucchi vatthi sāli vīhi;

original: Byādhi odhi bodhi sandhi, rāsi kesi sāti dīpi.
analyzed: byādhi odhi bodhi sandhi rāsi kesi sāti dīpi
translated: Byādhi odhi bodhi sandhi, rāsi kesi sāti dīpi.

original: Isi muni maṇi dhani yati giri ravi kavi,
analyzed: isi muni maṇi dhani yati giri ravi kavi
translated: Isi muni maṇi dhani yati giri ravi kavi,

original: Kapi asi masi nidhi vidhi ahi kimi pati;
analyzed: kapi asi masi nidhi vidhi ahi kimi pati
translated: Kapi asi masi nidhi vidhi ahi kimi pati;

original: Hari ari timi kali bali jaladhi gahapati,
analyzed: hari ari timi kali bali jaladhi gahapati
translated: Hari ari timi kali bali jaladhi gahapati,

original: Urudhiti varamati nirupadhi adhipati.
translated: Urudhiti varamati nirupadhi adhipati.

original: Añjali sārathi atithi samādhi udadhippabhutayo.
analyzed: añjali sārathi atithi samādhi udadhi ppabhutayaḥ
translated: Añjali sārathi atithi samādhi udadhippabhutayo.

original: Ikārantaṃ.
analyzed: ikāra antam
translated: The words ending in i.

original: Īkāranto pulliṅgo daṇḍīsaddo.
analyzed: īkāra antaḥ pulliṅgaḥ daṇḍī saddaḥ
translated: The masculine word daṇḍī ends in i.

original: “Daṇḍī si” itīdha –
analyzed: daṇḍī si
translated: “Daṇḍī si” itīdha –

original: “Agho rassamekavacanayosvapi cā”ti rassatte sampatte etthevāpiggahaṇena sismiṃ tadabhāve siddhe niyamatthamāha.
analyzed: aghaḥ sam ekavacanayosu api ca ati sampatte ettha iva a piggahaṇena tad abhāve siddhe niyama ttham āha
translated: “Agho rassamekavacanayosvapi cā”ti rassatte sampatte etthevāpiggahaṇena sismiṃ tadabhāve siddhe niyamatthamāha.

original: “Rassa”nti vattamāne –
analyzed: rassanti vattamāne
translated: “Rassa”nti vattamāne –

original: 150. Na sismimanapuṃsakāni.
analyzed: na si smima napuṃsakāni
translated: . Na sismimanapuṃsakāni.

original: Sismiṃ napuṃsakavajjitāni liṅgāni na rassamāpajjanteti rassattābhāvo, silopo. Daṇḍī tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: napuṃsaka vat jitāni liṅgāni na ras samāpajjante iti ras sattā abhāvaḥ si lopaḥ daṇḍī tiṭṭhati
translated: Sismiṃ napuṃsakavajjitāni liṅgāni na rassamāpajjanteti rassattābhāvo, silopo. Daṇḍī tiṭṭhati.

original: Anapuṃsakānīti kiṃ? Sukhakāri dānaṃ.
analyzed: anapuṃsakāni iti kim sukha kāri dānam
translated: Anapuṃsakānīti kiṃ? Sukhakāri dānaṃ.

original: Ettha ca –
analyzed: ettha ca
translated: Ettha ca –

original: Visadāvisadākāra-vohārobhayamuttakā;
analyzed: visada avisada ākāra vohāra ubhaya muttakā
translated: Visadāvisadākāra-vohārobhayamuttakā;

original: Pumādijānane hetu-bhāvato liṅgamīritā.
analyzed: pum ādi ja ānane hetu bhāvataḥ liṅgam īritā
translated: Pumādijānane hetu-bhāvato liṅgamīritā.

original: Yolope daṇḍī tiṭṭhanti.
analyzed: yolope daṇḍī tiṭṭhanti
translated: Yolope daṇḍī tiṭṭhanti.

original: Itaratra “agho rassa”miccādinā rassatte kate –
analyzed: itaratra aghaḥ rassam iccādinā rassa tte kate
translated: Itaratra “agho rassa”miccādinā rassatte kate –

original: “Jhato, katarassā”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: jhataḥ katarassa ati ca vattate
translated: “Jhato, katarassā”ti ca vattate.

original: 151. Yonaṃ no.
analyzed: yonam naḥ
translated: . Yonaṃ no.

original: Sabbesaṃ yonaṃ sālapanānaṃ jhato katarassā paresaṃ noiccādeso hoti. Daṇḍino tiṭṭhanti.
analyzed: sabbesam yonam sāla panānam jhato katarassa paresam no icca ādesaḥ hoti daṇḍinaḥ tiṭṭhanti
translated: Sabbesaṃ yonaṃ sālapanānaṃ jhato katarassā paresaṃ noiccādeso hoti. Daṇḍino tiṭṭhanti.

original: Katarassāti kiṃ? Aggayo.
analyzed: katarassa ati kim
translated: Katarassāti kiṃ? Aggayo.

original: Adhikāraṃ vinā “yonaṃ,
analyzed: adhikāram vinā
translated: Adhikāraṃ vinā “yonaṃ,

original: No”ti yogavibhāgato;
analyzed: na u ti yogavibhāgataḥ
translated: No”ti yogavibhāgato;

original: Kvaci akatarassāpi,
analyzed: kvaci a kataras sa api
translated: Kvaci akatarassāpi,

original: No sāramatino yathā.
analyzed: na u sāra matinaḥ yathā
translated: Not as they are in the opinion of the grammarians.

original: Ālapane “ge”ti vattate.
analyzed: ālapane geti vattate
translated: In addressing, “ge” is used.

original: 152. Jhalapā rassaṃ.
analyzed: jha l a pāḥ rassam
translated: The jhala becomes short.

original: Jhalapaiccete rassamāpajjante ge pare. Bho daṇḍi.
analyzed: jha l a pai c ca ite ras samāpajjante ge pare bho daṇḍi
translated: The jhala becomes short before the following ge. Bho daṇḍi.

original: “Agho rassa”ntiādināva siddhepi rassatte punārambho niyamattho, tena “bho go”tiādīsu na bhavati. Daṇḍī daṇḍino.
analyzed: siddhe pi siddhe pi tena bho go ti ādīsu na bhavati daṇḍī daṇḍino
translated: Although the shortening is established by “agho rassa” and so on, the repetition is for the purpose of restriction, so it is not in “bho go” and so on. Daṇḍī daṇḍino.

original: Dutiyāyaṃ rassatte kate “a”miti vattate, “ghapato smiṃ yaṃ vā”ti ito maṇḍūkagatiyā “vā”ti vattate.
analyzed: dutiyā ayam rassa tte kate am iti vattate gha patoḥ smin yam vāti itas maṇḍūka gatiyā vā iti vattate
translated: When the shortening is done in the second case, “a” is used. “Ghapato smiṃ yaṃ vā” is repeated from the frog-gaṇi by “vā”.

original: 153. Naṃ jhato katarassā.
analyzed: nam jha taḥ katarassā
translated: The naṃ is jhato katarassā.

original: Jhato katarassā parassa aṃvacanassa naṃ hoti vā. Daṇḍinaṃ daṇḍiṃ, daṇḍī daṇḍino, daṇḍinā, daṇḍīhi daṇḍībhi, daṇḍino daṇḍissa, daṇḍīnaṃ.
analyzed: jha taḥ katarassa parassa aṃvacanassa nam hoti vā daṇḍinam daṇḍim daṇḍī daṇḍinaḥ daṇḍinā daṇḍīhi daṇḍībhi daṇḍinaḥ daṇḍissa daṇḍīnam
translated: The naṃ is used for the aṃ of the other jhato katarassā. Daṇḍinaṃ daṇḍiṃ, daṇḍī daṇḍino, daṇḍinā, daṇḍīhi daṇḍībhi, daṇḍino daṇḍissa, daṇḍīnaṃ.

original: “Jhalato cā”ti nā. Daṇḍinā daṇḍismā daṇḍimhā, daṇḍīhi daṇḍībhi, daṇḍino daṇḍissa, daṇḍīnaṃ.
analyzed: jha l ataḥ ca ati nā daṇḍinā daṇḍismā daṇḍimhā daṇḍīhi daṇḍībhi daṇḍinaḥ daṇḍissa daṇḍīnam
translated: “Jhalato cā” is not. Daṇḍinā daṇḍismā daṇḍimhā, daṇḍīhi daṇḍībhi, daṇḍino daṇḍissa, daṇḍīnaṃ.

original: “Jhato, katarassā”ti ca vattate, pure viya “vā”ti ca.
analyzed: jhato katarassa ati ca vattate pure viya vāti ca
translated: “Jhato, katarassā” is repeated, and “vā” as before.

original: 154. Smiṃ ni.
analyzed: smin ni
translated: In smiṃ ni.

original: Jhato katarassā parassa smiṃvacanassa niiccādeso hoti vā. Daṇḍini daṇḍismiṃ daṇḍimhi, daṇḍīsu.
analyzed: jha taḥ katarassa parassa smiṃvacanassa ni i cca ādesaḥ hoti vā daṇḍini daṇḍismin daṇḍimhi daṇḍīsu
translated: The elision of the final vowel of the other word is optional in the following: Daṇḍini, daṇḍismiṃ, daṇḍimhi, daṇḍīsu.

original: Evamaññānipi –
analyzed: evam aññāni pi
translated: So too with the following:

original: Dhammī saṅghī ñāṇī hatthī, cakkī pakkhī dāṭhī raṭṭhī;
analyzed: dhammī saṅghī ñāṇī hatthī cakkī pakkhī dāṭhī raṭṭhī
translated: Dhammī, saṅghī, ñāṇī, hatthī, cakkī, pakkhī, dāṭhī, raṭṭhī,

original: Chattī mālī vammī yogī, bhāgī bhogī kāmī sāmī.
analyzed: chattī mālī vammī yogī bhāgī bhogī kāmī sāmī
translated: Chattī, mālī, vammī, yogī, bhāgī, bhogī, kāmī, sāmī,

original: Dhajī gaṇī sasī kuṭṭhī, jaṭī yānī sukhī sikhī;
analyzed: dhajī gaṇī sasī kuṭṭhī jaṭī yānī sukhī sikhī
translated: Dhajī, gaṇī, sasī, kuṭṭhī, jaṭī, yānī, sukhī, sikhī,

original: Dantī mantī karī cāgī, kusalī musalī balī.
analyzed: dantī mantī karī cāgī kusalī musalī balī
translated: Dantī, mantī, karī, cāgī, kusalī, musalī, balī,

original: Pāpakārī sattughātī, mālyakārī dīghajīvī;
analyzed: pāpa kārī sattu ghātī mālya kārī dīgha jīvī
translated: Pāpakārī, sattughātī, mālyakārī, dīghajīvī,

original: Dhammacārī sīghayāyī, sīhanādī bhūmisāyī –
analyzed: dhamma cārī sīgha yāyī sīha nādī bhūmi sāyī
translated: Dhammacārī, sīghayāyī, sīhanādī, bhūmisāyī,

original: Iccādīni īkārantanāmāni.
analyzed: i t ca ādīni īkāra anta nāmāni
translated: And so on.

original: Gāmaṇīsaddassa tu sattamiyaṃ bhedo.
analyzed: tu sattamiyam bhedaḥ
translated: But the word gāmaṇī has a different form in the seventh case:

original: Gāmaṇī, gāmaṇī gāmaṇino, bho gāmaṇi, bhonto gāmaṇī bhonto gāmaṇino, gāmaṇinaṃ gāmaṇiṃ, gāmaṇī gāmaṇino.🔽Sesaṃ daṇḍīsamaṃ. Niādesābhāvova viseso. Evaṃ senānī sudhīppabhutayo.
analyzed: gāmaṇī gāmaṇī gāmaṇinaḥ bho gāmaṇi bhontaḥ gāmaṇī bhontaḥ gāmaṇinaḥ gāmaṇinam gāmaṇim gāmaṇim gāmaṇī gāmaṇinaḥ  sesam daṇḍīsamam visesaḥ evam
translated: Gāmaṇī, gāmaṇī, gāmaṇino, bho gāmaṇi, bhonto gāmaṇī, bhonto gāmaṇino, gāmaṇinaṃ, gāmaṇiṃ, gāmaṇī, gāmaṇino.

original: Īkārantaṃ.
analyzed: īkāra antam
translated: The rest is like daṇḍī. The difference is that there is no elision of the final vowel. So too with senānī, sudhī, etc.

original: Ukāranto pulliṅgo bhikkhusaddo.
analyzed: ukāra antaḥ pulliṅgaḥ bhikkhu saddaḥ
translated: The word bhikkhu is masculine, ending in u.

original: Tatheva bhikkhusaddato si, silopo. So bhikkhu.
analyzed: tathā iva bhikkhu saddataḥ si si lopaḥ saḥ bhikkhu
translated: So bhikkhu.

original: Bahuvacane “ghapato ca yonaṃ lopo”ti yolopo, “yosu kata”iccādinā dīgho. Te bhikkhū.
analyzed: bahuvacane gha patoḥ ca yo nam lopaḥ iti yo lopaḥ yosu kata e c ādinā dīghaḥ te bhikkhū
translated: In the plural, “ghapato ca yonaṃ lopo” means yolopo, and “yosu kata” etc. means dīgho. Te bhikkhū.

original: Lopābhāve “vā, yona”nti ca vattate.
analyzed: lopa abhāve vā ca vattate
translated: In the absence of elision, “vā, yona” is said.

original: 155. Lato vokāro ca.
analyzed: la taḥ va o kāraḥ ca
translated: . And vokāro from la.

original: Lasaññato paresaṃ yovacanānaṃ vokārādeso hoti vā. Kāraggahaṇena yonaṃ no ca hoti.
analyzed: la saññataḥ paresam yo vacanānam vokāra ādesaḥ hoti vā kāra ggahaṇena no ca hoti
translated: The vowel o is substituted for the vowel of the other words beginning with y, optionally. By the mention of kāra, it is not so for yonaṃ.

original: Casaddaggahaṇaṃ katthaci nivattanatthaṃ. Atha vā caggahaṇaṃ noggahaṇānuvattanatthaṃ,
analyzed: ca sadda ggahaṇam katthaci nivattana attham atha vā ca ggahaṇam no ggahaṇa anuvattana attham
translated: The mention of ca is for the purpose of excluding in some places. Or the mention of ca is for the purpose of following the mention of no.

original: tena jantusabbaññūādito yonaṃ no ca hoti. Vāsaddo vavatthitavibhāsattho. Tena –
analyzed: tena jantu sabbaññū āditaḥ no ca hoti vā saddaḥ tena
translated: Therefore, jantu, sabbaññū, ādi, it is not so for yonaṃ. The word vā has the meaning of a particular vibhāṣā. Therefore –

original: Bhikkhuppabhutito niccaṃ, vo yonaṃ hetuādito;
analyzed: bhikkhu ppabhutitaḥ niccam vaḥ yonam hetu āditaḥ
translated: From bhikkhu etc. always, vo yonaṃ hetu ādito;

original: Vibhāsā na ca vo no ca, amuppabhutito bhave.
analyzed: vibhāsā na ca vaḥ na ca a m up pa bhutitaḥ bhave
translated: Vibhāsā na ca vo no ca, amuppabhutito bhave.

original: “Attaṃ, akatarasso”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: attam a katarassa iti ca vattate
translated: “Attaṃ, akatarasso” is said.

original: 156. Vevosu lo ca.
analyzed: ve vosu laḥ ca
translated: . Vevosu lo ca.

original: Ve voiccetesu ca paresu akatarasso lo attamāpajjate. Bhikkhavo, bho bhikkhu, bhavanto bhikkhū.
analyzed: ve vo iti itesu ca paresu a katarassaḥ laḥ attam āpajjate bhikkhavaḥ bho bhikkhu bhavantaḥ bhikkhū
translated: In ve, vo, icc, and the other words beginning with akatarasso, lo becomes atta. Bhikkhavo, bho bhikkhu, bhavanto bhikkhū.

original: Lopābhāve –
analyzed: lopa abhāve
translated: In the absence of elision –🔽.

original: 157. Akatarassā lato yvālapanassa vevo.
analyzed: a katarassa la taḥ yu ā lapanassa vevaḥ
translated: 157. The particle ve is used after a negative particle in addressing another,

original: Akatarassā lato parassa ālapane vihitassa yoiccetassa ve voādesā honti. Attaṃ. Bhavanto bhikkhave bhikkhavo. “Aṃ mo niggahītaṃ jhalapehī”ti niggahītaṃ.
analyzed: a katarassa la taḥ parassa ālapane vihitassa yo icca itassa ve vo ādesāḥ honti attam bhavantaḥ bhikkhave bhikkhavaḥ aṃ mo niggahītam jha lapehi iti niggahītam
translated: The particle ve is used after a negative particle in addressing another, when the latter is not intended: Attaṃ. Bhavanto bhikkhave bhikkhavo. “Aṃ mo niggahītaṃ jhalapehī”ti niggahītaṃ.

original: Bhikkhuṃ, bhikkhū bhikkhavo, bhikkhunā, bhikkhūhi bhikkhūbhi bhikkhuhi bhikkhubhi,🔽bhikkhuno bhikkhussa, bhikkhūnaṃ bhikkhunaṃ, bhikkhunā bhikkhusmā bhikkhumhā, bhikkhūhi
analyzed: bhikkhum bhikkhū bhikkhavaḥ bhikkhunā bhikkhūhi bhikkhūbhi bhikkhuhi bhikkhubhi  bhikkhunaḥ bhikkhussa bhikkhūnam bhikkhunā bhikkhusmā bhikkhumhā bhikkhūhi
translated: Bhikkhuṃ, bhikkhū bhikkhavo, bhikkhunā, bhikkhūhi bhikkhūbhi bhikkhuhi bhikkhubhi,🔽Bhikkhuno bhikkhussa, bhikkhūnaṃ bhikkhunaṃ, bhikkhunā bhikkhusmā bhikkhumhā, bhikkhūhi

original: bhikkhūbhi bhikkhuhi bhikkhubhi, bhikkhuno bhikkhussa, bhikkhūnaṃ bhikkhunaṃ, bhikkhumhi
analyzed: bhikkhūbhi bhikkhuhi bhikkhubhi bhikkhunaḥ bhikkhussa bhikkhūnam bhikkhunam bhikkhumhi
translated: Bhikkhūbhi bhikkhuhi bhikkhubhi, bhikkhuno bhikkhussa, bhikkhūnaṃ bhikkhunaṃ, bhikkhumhi

original: bhikkhusmiṃ, bhikkhūsu bhikkhusu.
analyzed: bhikkhusmim bhikkhūsu bhikkhusu
translated: Bhikkhusmiṃ, bhikkhūsu bhikkhusu.

original: Evaṃ setu ketu rāhu bhānu paṅgu ucchu veḷu maccu sindhu bandhu neru meru sattu kāru hetu jantu ruru paṭu iccādayo.
analyzed: evam setu ketu rāhu bhānu paṅgu ucchu veḷu maccu sindhu bandhu neru meru sattu kāru hetu jantu ruru paṭu icca ādayaḥ
translated: So too setu, ketu, rāhu, bhānu, paṅgu, ucchu, veḷu, maccu, sindhu, bandhu, neru, meru, sattu, kāru, hetu, jantu, ruru, paṭu, iccādi.

original: Hetujantusaddānaṃ paṭhamādutiyāsu viseso.
analyzed: hetu jantu saddānam paṭhamā dutiyāsu visesaḥ
translated: The words hetu and jantu are distinguished in the first and second cases.

original: Hetu, hetū hetavo hetuyo, bho hetu, bhonto hetū hetave hetavo, hetuṃ, hetū hetavo hetuyo. Sesaṃ bhikkhusamaṃ.
analyzed: hetu hetū hetavaḥ hetuyaḥ bho hetu bhontaḥ hetū hetave hetavaḥ hetum hetū hetavaḥ hetuyaḥ sesam bhikkhu samam
translated: The forms are: hetu, hetū, hetavo, hetuyo, bho hetu, bhonto hetū, hetave, hetavo, hetuṃ, hetū, hetavo, hetuyo. The rest is the same as for bhikkhu.

original: Jantu, jantū jantavo. Kāraggahaṇena yonaṃ no ca hoti. Jantuno jantuyo, bho jantu, jantū jantave jantavo, jantuṃ, jantū jantavo jantuno jantuyo iccādi.
analyzed: jantu jantū jantavaḥ kāraggahaṇena yonam no ca hoti jantunaḥ jantuyaḥ bho jantu jantū jantave jantavaḥ jantum jantū jantavaḥ jantunaḥ iccādi
translated: Jantu, jantū, jantavo. The forms with yona are not found. The forms are: jantuyo, bho jantu, jantū, jantave, jantavo, jantuṃ, jantū, jantavo, jantuno, jantuyo, etc.🔽The forms with satthu are different.

original: Satthusaddassa bhedo. “Satthu si”itīdha –
analyzed: satthu saddassa bhedaḥ satthu
translated: “Satthu si” is used here.

original: “Anto”ti vattate.
analyzed: antaḥ iti vattate
translated: “Anto” is used.

original: Tato ārādesato sabbesaṃ yonaṃ okārādeso hoti.
analyzed: tatas ārā desataḥ sabbesam yonam okāra ādesaḥ hoti
translated: Then, after the vowel, the vowel of all the words is o.

original: Tuggahaṇena aññehipi catuubhanadīgavādīhi yonamokāro hoti, saralopādi. Satthāro.
analyzed: tu k gahaṇena aññehi pi catu ubha nadī gava ādīhi yo namaḥ okāraḥ hoti sara lopa ādi
translated: By the rule of the four rivers, etc., the vowel of the words is o, with the elision of the first syllable, etc. Teachers.

original: Ālapane “akārapitādyantānamā”ti āttaṃ. “Ge rassa”nti adhikicca “ākāro vā”ti vikappena rassattaṃ, valopo. Bho sattha bho satthā, bhavanto satthāro, satthāraṃ, satthāre satthāro.
analyzed: ālapane akāra pita ādi antān ā ti ā ttam ge rassanti adhikicca ākāraḥ vāti vikappena va lopaḥ bho sattha bho satthāḥ bhavantaḥ satthāraḥ satthāram satthāre satthāraḥ
translated: In addressing, the vowel of the words ending in a is ā, by the rule “akārapitādyantānamā”. The vowel is short by the addition of “ge rassa” and by the exception of “ākāro vā”. Valopo. Bho sattha, bho satthā, bhavanto satthāro, satthāraṃ, satthāre satthāro.

original: “Tato”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: tatas iti ca vattate
translated: “Tato” is repeated.

analyzed: nā ā

original: Tato ārādesato nāvacanassa ākārādeso hoti. Satthārā, satthunāti ārattamitibhāvaniddesena siddhaṃ. Satthārehi satthārebhi.
analyzed: tatas ārā ādesataḥ nā vacanassa ākāra ādesaḥ hoti satthārā satthunā ati āratta miti bhāva niddesena siddham satthārehi satthārebhi
translated: Then, after the vowel, the vowel of the word nā is ā. Satthārā, satthunāti ārattamitibhāvaniddesena siddhaṃ. Satthārehi satthārebhi.

original: “Vā naṃmhī”ti ito “vā”ti vattate.
analyzed: vā iti itas vā ati vattate
translated: “Vā naṃmhī” is repeated from here.

original: 162. U sasmiṃ salopo ca.
analyzed: u sa smin sa lopaḥ ca
translated: . U sasmiṃ salopo ca.

original: Satthu pituiccevamādīnamantassa uttaṃ hoti vā sasmiṃ, salopo ca hoti. Ārādesāpavādoyaṃ. Satthu, aññattha bhāvaniddesenārābhāvo. Satthussa satthuno.
analyzed: satthu pitu icca evamādīnam antassa uttam hoti vā sasmin sa lopo ca hoti ārā desa apavādaḥ yam satthu aññattha bhāva niddesena ārā bhāvaḥ satthussa satthuno
translated: The vowel of the words satthu pitu, etc., is u, optionally, after the vowel, and there is elision. Ārādesāpavādoyaṃ. Satthu, elsewhere the vowel is by the rule of bhāvaniddesa. Satthussa satthuno.

original: “Āratta”nti vattate.
analyzed: ārattanti vattate
translated: “Āratta” is repeated.

original: 163. Vā naṃmhi.
analyzed: vā naṃmhi
translated: . Vā naṃmhi.

original: Satthu pituādīnamanto ārattamāpajjate vā naṃmhi vibhattimhi. Satthārānaṃ.
analyzed: satthu pitu ādīnam antaḥ ārattam āpajjate vā namhi vibhattimhi sattha ārānam
translated: The Locative is used when the meaning of the end of the Teacher, etc., is intended. Of the Teachers.

translated: . Sakamandhātādīnañca.

analyzed: sakaman dhātu iti ca evamādīnam antaḥ ca uttama āpajjate sasmin sa lopaḥ ca niccam punar bidhānā sakaman dhātu viya assa rājinaḥ vibhavaḥ sesam samam evam mahāman dhātu ppabhutayaḥ

original: Pitusaddassa bhedo. Simhi āttaṃ, silopo, pitā.
analyzed: pitu saddassa bhedaḥ simhi ā ttam si lopaḥ pitā
translated: The division of the word pitā. Simhi āttaṃ, silopo, pitā.

original: Yomhi “āro, rassa”nti ca vattate.
analyzed: yomhi āraḥ ca vattate
translated: Yomhi “āro, rassa”nti ca vattate.

original: pitānaṃ pitūnaṃ pitunaṃ, pitari, pitaresu pitūsu pitusu.
analyzed: pitānam pitūnam pitunam pitari pitaresu pitūsu pitusu
translated: Pitānaṃ, pitūnaṃ, pitunaṃ, pitari, pitaresu, pitūsu, pitusu.

original: Evaṃ bhātā, bhātaro iccādi.
analyzed: evam bhātā iti ca ādi
translated: Similarly, bhātā, bhātaro, etc.

original: Ukārantaṃ.
analyzed: ukāra antam
translated: The word ending in u.

original: Ūkāranto pulliṅgo abhibhūsaddo.
analyzed: ūkāra antaḥ pulliṅgaḥ abhibhū saddaḥ
translated: The masculine word abhibhū has the same origin.

original: Tatheva syādyuppatti, silopo. So abhibhū, yolope kate te abhibhū.
analyzed: tathā iva syāt yo lopaḥ kate te abhibhū
translated: The same applies to the formation of the feminine. The word ending in u becomes o. The word abhibhū becomes abhibhū.

original: “Agho rassa”ntiādinā rassattaṃ, vokāro. Katarassattā attābhāvo. Abhibhuvo, bho abhibhu, bhavanto abhibhū abhibhuvo.
analyzed: aghaḥ vokāraḥ kataraḥ sattā attā abhāvaḥ abhibhuvaḥ bho abhibhu bhavantaḥ abhibhū abhibhuvaḥ
translated: The word abhibhū becomes abhibhu by the rule beginning “Agho rassa” (Pā 1.1.64). The word abhibhu becomes abhibhuvo by the rule beginning “Katarassattā attābhāvo” (Pā 1.1.65). The words abhibhu, abhibhu, bhavanto abhibhū, abhibhuvo are formed.

original: Katarassattā veādeso na hoti. Sesaṃ bhikkhusaddasamaṃ, rassattameva viseso. Abhibhuṃ, abhibhū abhibhuvo, abhibhunā, abhibhūhi abhibhūbhi, abhibhuno abhibhussa, abhibhūnaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: katarassa ttā ve ādesaḥ na hoti sesam bhikkhu sadda samam visesaḥ abhibhum abhibhū abhibhuvaḥ abhibhunā abhibhūhi abhibhūbhi abhibhuno abhibhussa iccādi
translated: The change of ve to ā does not take place because of the rule beginning “Katarassattā” (Pā 1.1.65). The rest is the same as in the word bhikkhu. The only difference is that the word abhibhuvo becomes abhibhu by the rule beginning “Katarassattā attābhāvo” (Pā 1.1.65). The words abhibhuṃ, abhibhū, abhibhuvo, abhibhunā, abhibhūhi, abhibhūbhi, abhibhuno, abhibhussa, abhibhūnaṃ, etc., are formed.

original: Evaṃ sayambhū, vessabhū, parābhibhū, sahabhūādayo. Sahabhūsaddassa yonaṃ noādesova viseso. Sahabhū, sahabhū sahabhuvo sahabhuno iccādi.
analyzed: evam sayambhū vessabhū parābhibhū sahabhū ādayaḥ sahabhū saddassa visesaḥ sahabhū sahabhū sahabhuvo iccādi
translated: Similarly, sayambhū, vessabhū, parābhibhū, sahabhū, etc. The only difference is that the word sahabhū becomes sahabhū by the rule beginning “Yonāṃ noādeso” (Pā 1.1.66). The words sahabhū, sahabhū, sahabhuvo, sahabhuno, etc., are formed.

original: Tathā sabbaññūsaddassa yosveva viseso. So sabbaññū te sabbaññū, yolopābhāve rassattaṃ,
analyzed: tathā sabbaññū saddassa visesaḥ so sabbaññū te sabbaññū yo lopa abhāve
translated: In the case of the word all-knowing, the difference is only in the vowel.🔽The vowel is lengthened when the syllable is short,

original: “lato vokāro cā”ti ettha kāraggahaṇena yonaṃ noādeso. Vādhikārassa vavatthitavibhāsattā
analyzed: la taḥ vokāraḥ ca ati ettha kāra ggahaṇena no ādesaḥ vā adhikārassa
translated: and the vowel is not lengthened when the syllable is long.

original: na ca vokāro. Sabbaññuno, bho sabbaññu, bhonto sabbaññū sabbaññuno, sabbaññuṃ, sabbaññū sabbaññuno iccādi.
analyzed: na ca vokāraḥ sabbaññunaḥ bho sabbaññu bhonto sabbaññū sabbaññuno sabbaññum sabbaññū sabbaññuno iccādi
translated: All-knowing, all-knowing ones, all-knowing one, all-knowing ones, all-knowing one, all-knowing ones, all-knowing one, all-knowing ones, etc.

original: Evaṃ maggaññū dhammaññū atthaññū kālaññū rattaññū mattaññū kataññū tathaññū viññū vidū vedagū pāragū iccādayo.
analyzed: evam maggaññū dhammaññū atthaññū kālaññū rattaññū mattaññū kataññū tathaññū viññū vidū vedagū pāragū iccādayaḥ
translated: So too with the words path-knowing, Dhamma-knowing, meaning-knowing, time-knowing, moderation-knowing, enough-knowing, gratitude-knowing, truth-knowing, understanding, discernment, one with spiritual power, one who has crossed over, etc.

original: Ūkārantaṃ.🔽Ekāranto appasiddho.
analyzed: ūkāra antam  eka a ra antaḥ appasiddhaḥ
translated: The word ending in ū.🔽The word ending in e is not well known.

original: Okāranto pulliṅgo gosaddo.
analyzed: okāra antaḥ pulliṅgaḥ go saddaḥ
translated: The word ending in o is a masculine noun.

original: Tato syādyuppatti, silopo, go gacchati.
analyzed: tatas si lopaḥ goḥ gacchati
translated: The word ending in a is derived from it. Silopo, a bull goes.

original: “Gāva se”ti ito “go”ti adhikāro, “āvā”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: gāva seti itas adhikāraḥ āvāti ca vattate
translated: The word “go” is derived from the word “gāva” in the sense of “se”.

original: 169. Yosu ca.
analyzed: yosu ca
translated: And in the feminine.
