translated: Sambhave himavatā gaṅgā pabhavati, the Ganges has its source in the Himalayas; in tittiyaṃ pahūtamannaṃ, abundant food for the herons; in anāvile pasannamudakaṃ, clear water unruffled; in patthane paṇihitaṃ, a source of the deposit.🔽Parāiti is going away, as in parāyānaṃ, going away; parābhavo, defeat; parājayo, defeat; gativikkamo, going away; asanā, etc., as in parāmasanaṃ, touching.🔽Niiti is remainder, as in nirutti, language; niravasesaṃ deti, he gives without remainder; niggate, as in nikkileso, without defilement; niyyāti, he goes out; nīharaṇe, as in niddhāraṇaṃ, taking out; antopavesane, as in nikhāto, thrown in; abhāve, as in nimmakkhikaṃ, without salt;

original: Niiti nissesa niggata nīharaṇa’ntopavesanā’bhāvanisedha nikkhanta pātubhāvā’vadhāraṇa
analyzed: nissesa niggata nīharaṇa anta upavesanā bhāva nisedha nikkhanta pātubhāva avadhāraṇa
translated: Translation: Pabhū is a source, as in pabhū antobhāve, a source within; in viyoge pavāsī, a source of separation; in tappare pācariyo, a source of heat; in bhusatthe pavuddhakāyo, a source of the body’s being stretched out.🔽Sambhave himavatā gaṅgā pabhavati, the Ganges has its source in the Himalayas; in tittiyaṃ pahūtamannaṃ, abundant food for the herons; in anāvile pasannamudakaṃ, clear water unruffled; in patthane paṇihitaṃ, a source of the deposit.🔽Parāiti is going away, as in parāyānaṃ, going away; parābhavo, defeat; parājayo, defeat; gativikkamo, going away; asanā, etc., as in parāmasanaṃ, touching.

original: vibhajana upamū’padhāraṇā’vasānachekādīsu. Nissese nirutti, niravasesaṃ deti, niggate🔽nikkileso, niyyāti, nīharaṇe niddhāraṇaṃ, antopavesane nikhāto, abhāve nimmakkhikaṃ,
analyzed: vibhajane upama upadhāraṇa avasāna cheka ādīsu nissese nirutti niravasesam deti niggate 🔽nikkilesaḥ niyyāti nīharaṇe niddhāraṇam anta upavesane nikhātaḥ abhāve nimmakkhikam
translated: Niiti is remainder, as in nirutti, language; niravasesaṃ

original: nisedhe nivāreti, nikkhante nibbāno, nibbānaṃ, pātubhāve nimmitaṃ, avadhāraṇe nicchayo,
analyzed: nisedhe nivāreti nikkhante nibbānaḥ nibbānam pātubhāve nimmitam avadhāraṇe nicchayaḥ
translated: In the sense of ‘stopping’, it is a ‘restraint’; in the sense of ‘gone out’, it is ‘extinction’; in the sense of ‘manifestation’, it is ‘creation’; in the sense of ‘certainty’, it is ‘conviction’;

original: vibhajane niddeso, upamāyaṃ nidassanaṃ, upadhāraṇe nisāmanaṃ, avasāne niṭṭhitaṃ, cheke nipuṇo.
analyzed: vibhajane niddesaḥ upamāyam nidassanam upadhāraṇe nisāmanam avasāne niṭṭhitam cheke nipuṇaḥ
translated: in the sense of ‘distinction’, it is ‘definition’; in the sense of ‘simile’, it is ‘illustration’; in the sense of ‘recollection’, it is ‘remembrance’; in the sense of ‘end’, it is ‘finished’; in the sense of ‘skill’, it is ‘clever’.

original: Nīiti nīharaṇā’varaṇādīsu. Nīharaṇe nīharati, āvaraṇe nīvaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: nīharaṇa āvaraṇa ādīsu nīharaṇe nīharati āvaraṇe nīvaraṇam
translated: In the sense of ‘removing’ and ‘covering’, etc., it is ‘removal’. In the sense of ‘removing’, it is ‘removal’; in the sense of ‘covering’, it is ‘hindrance’.

original: Uiti uggatu’ddhakamma padhāna viyoga sambhava atthalābhasatti sarūpakathanādīsu.
analyzed: padhāna viyoga sambhava attha lābha satti sarūpa kathana ādīsu
translated: In the sense of ‘arisen’, ‘excessive work’, ‘exertion’, ‘separation’, ‘occurrence’, ‘gain of meaning’, ‘capacity’, ‘statement of the same form’, etc., it is ‘arisen’.

original: Uggate uggacchati, uddhakamme āsanā uṭṭhito, ukkhepo, padhāne uttamo, lokuttaro,
analyzed: uggate uggacchati uddha kamme āsanā uṭṭhitaḥ ukkhepaḥ padhāne uttamaḥ lokuttaro
translated: In the sense of ‘arisen’, it is ‘arisen’; in the sense of ‘excessive work’, he is ‘risen from his seat’; in the sense of ‘casting off’, it is ‘casting off’; in the sense of ‘exertion’, it is ‘supreme’; in the sense of ‘beyond the world’, it is ‘supramundane’;

original: viyoge ubbāsito, sambhave ubbhūto, atthalābhe uppannaṃ ñāṇaṃ, sattiyaṃ ussahati gantuṃ,
analyzed: viyoge ubbāsitaḥ sambhave ubbhūtaḥ attha lābhe uppannam ñāṇam sattiyam ussahati gantum
translated: in the sense of ‘separation’, it is ‘separated’; in the sense of ‘occurrence’, it is ‘occurred’; in the sense of ‘gain of meaning’, it is ‘knowledge arisen’; in the sense of ‘capacity’, it is ‘able to go’;

original: sarūpakathane uddisati suttaṃ.
analyzed: sarūpa kathane uddisati suttam
translated: in the sense of ‘statement of the same form’, it is ‘recites the sutta’.

original: Duiti asobhanā’bhāvakucchitā’samiddhi kiccha virūpatādīsu. Asobhane duggandho, abhāve
analyzed: asobhane duggandhaḥ abhāve
translated: In the sense of ‘unsightly’, ‘non-existence’, ‘discontent’, ‘non-abundance’, ‘difficulty’, ‘dissimilarity’, etc., it is ‘unsightly’. In the sense of ‘unsightly’, it is ‘bad smell’; in the sense of ‘non-existence’, it is ‘non-existence’;

original: dubbhikkhaṃ, kucchite dukkaṭaṃ, asamiddhiyaṃ dussassaṃ, kicche dukkaraṃ, virūpatāyaṃ dubbaṇṇo, dummukho.
analyzed: dubbhikkham kucchite dukkaṭam a samiddhiyam dussassam kicche dukkaram virūpa tāyam dubbaṇṇaḥ dummukhaḥ
translated: In the sense of scarcity, famine, in the sense of a belly, a misdeed, in the sense of not being put out, a bad fire, in the sense of difficulty, a hard task, in the sense of ugliness, an ugly face.

original: Saṃiti samodhāna sammāsama samantabhāvasaṅgata saṅkhepabhusattha sahattha appattha🔽pabhavā’bhimukhabhāva saṅgaha pidhāna punappunakaraṇa samiddhādīsu. Samodhāne sandhi,
analyzed: saṃiti samodhāna sammāsama samanta bhāva saṅgata saṅkhepa bhusattha sahattha appattha  pabhava abhimukha bhāva saṅgaha pidhāna punappunakaraṇa samiddha ādīsu samodhāne sandhi
translated: In the sense of a gathering, a meeting, a right gathering, a complete gathering, a connection, a summary, a word, a hand, a non-attainment,🔽an origin, a facing, a collection, a covering, a repetition, a putting out, etc. In the sense of a gathering, a connection,

original: sammāsamesu samādhi, sampayutto, samantabhāve saṃkiṇṇā samullapanā, saṅgate saṅgamo,
analyzed: sammā samesu samādhi sampayuttaḥ samanta bhāve saṃkiṇṇā samullapanā saṅgate saṅgamaḥ
translated: in the sense of a right gathering, a concentration, a connection, in the sense of a complete gathering, a mixture, a development, in the sense of a connection, a meeting,

original: saṅkhepe samāso, bhusatthe sāratto, sahatthe saṃvāso, appatthe samaggho. Pabhave
analyzed: saṅkhepe samāsaḥ bhusatthe sārattaḥ sahatthe saṃvāsaḥ appatthe samagghaḥ pabhave
translated: in the sense of a summary, a compound, in the sense of a word, a love, in the sense of a hand, a living together, in the sense of a non-attainment, a unity. In the sense of an origin,

original: sambhavo, abhimukhabhāve sammukhaṃ, saṅgahe saṅgaṇhāti, pidhāne saṃvutaṃ, punappunakaraṇe
analyzed: sambhavaḥ abhimukha bhāve sammukham saṅgahe saṅgaṇhāti pidhāne saṃvutam punappunakaraṇe
translated: a becoming, in the sense of a facing, a presence, in the sense of a collection, a collection, in the sense of a covering, a covering, in the sense of a repetition,

original: sandhāvati, samiddhiyaṃ sampanno.
analyzed: sandhāvati samidh hiyam sampannaḥ
translated: a running back, in the sense of a putting out, a success.

original: Viiti visesa vividha viruddha vigata viyoga virūpatādīsu. Visese vimutti visiṭṭho, vividhe vimati vicitraṃ, viruddhe vivādo, vigate vimalaṃ, viyoge vippayutto, virūpatāyaṃ virūpo.
analyzed: viiti visesa vividha viruddha vigata viyoga virūpa tā ādīsu visese vimutti visiṭṭhaḥ vividhe vimati vicitram viruddhe vivādaḥ vigate vimalam viyoge vippayuttaḥ virūpa tā ayam virūpaḥ
translated: In the sense of ‘distinction’, ‘variety’, ‘contradiction’, ‘absence’, ‘separation’, ‘difference’, etc. In the sense of ‘distinction’, ‘liberation’ is distinguished; in the sense of ‘variety’, ‘doubt’ is various; in the sense of ‘contradiction’, ‘dispute’ is contradictory; in the sense of ‘absence’, ‘purity’ is stainless; in the sense of ‘separation’, ‘one who is separated’ is disjoined; in the sense of ‘difference’, ‘one who is different’ is different.

original: Avaiti adhobhāga viyoga paribhava jānana suddhi nicchayadesa theyyādīsu. Adhobhāge
analyzed: avaiti adhobhāga viyoga paribhava jānana suddhi nicchayadesa theyyādīsu adhobhāge
translated: In the sense of ‘below’, ‘separation’, ‘contempt’, ‘knowledge’, ‘purity’, ‘certainty’, ‘place’, ‘theft’, etc. In the sense of ‘below’,

original: avakkhittacakkhu, viyoge omukkaupāhano avakokilaṃ vanaṃ, paribhave avajānanaṃ avamaññati,🔽jānane avagacchati, suddhiyaṃ vodānaṃ, nicchaye avadhāraṇaṃ, dese avakāso, theyye avahāro.🔽Anuiti anugatā’nupacchinna pacchattha bhusattha sādissa hīnatatiyattha lakkhaṇi’tthambhūtakkhāna
analyzed: viyoge omukka aupāhanaḥ avakokilam vanam paribhave avajānanam avamaññati  jānane avagacchati suddhiyam vodānam nicchaye avadhāraṇam dese avakāsaḥ theyye avahāro  anuiti anugata anupacchinna pacchattha bhusattha sa ādissa hīna tatiyattha
translated: one who looks down is ‘one whose eyes are cast down’; in the sense of ‘separation’, ‘one who is separated’ is ‘one who has turned his face away’; in the sense of ‘contempt’, ‘one who despises’ is ‘one who looks down upon’;🔽in the sense of ‘knowledge’, ‘one who understands’ is ‘one who knows’; in the sense of ‘purity’, ‘purification’ is ‘cleansing’; in the sense of ‘certainty’, ‘determination’ is ‘decision’; in the sense of ‘place’, ‘opportunity’ is ‘occasion’; in the sense of ‘theft’, ‘one who steals’ is ‘a thief’.🔽In the sense of ‘following’, ‘consequent’, ‘uninterrupted’, ‘latter’, ‘wealth’, ‘similar’, ‘inferior’, ‘third’, ‘characteristic’, ‘become’, ‘moment’,

original: bhāga vicchādīsu. Anugate anveti, anupacchinne anusayo, pacchāsaddatthe anurathaṃ,
analyzed: bhāga vicchā ādīsu anugate anveti anupacchinne anusayo pacchāsaddatthe anuratham
translated: ‘part’, ‘covering’, etc. In the sense of ‘following’, ‘one who follows’ is ‘one who goes after’; in the sense of ‘uninterrupted’, ‘latent tendency’ is ‘underlying tendency’;🔽in the sense of ‘latter’, ‘one who is delighted’ is ‘one who is pleased’;

original: bhusatthe anuratto, sādisse anurūpaṃ. Hīne anusāriputtaṃ paññavanto, tatiyatthe nadimanvavasitā
analyzed: bhusatthe anurattaḥ sādisse anurūpam hīne anusāri puttam paññavanto tatiya tthe nadim anvavasitā
translated: In the word ‘bhusā’ he delights, in the word ‘sādisa’ he is suitable. In the word ‘hīna’ he is a follower of the son of Anusāri, in the word ‘paññavanto’ he is wise, in the word ‘tatiya’ he is one who is satisfied with the river.

original: senā, lakkhaṇe rukkhaṃ anu vijjotate vijju, itthambhūtakkhāne sādhu devadatto mātaraṃ🔽anu, bhāge yadettha maṃ anusiyā taṃ dīyatu, vicchāyaṃ rukkhaṃ rukkhaṃ anu vijjotate cando.🔽Pariiti samantatobhāva pariccheda vajjanā’liṅgana nivāsanapūjābhojanā’vajānana dosakkhāna
analyzed: senā lakkhaṇe rukkham anu vijjotate vijju itthambhūta khāne sādhu devadattaḥ mātaram  anu bhāge yat ettha mama anusiyā tam dīyatu vicchāyam rukkham rukkham anu vijjotate candaḥ  pari iti samantatobhāva pariccheda vajjana āliṅgana nivāsana pūjā bhojana avajānana dosa kkhāna
translated: In the case of a multitude, in the case of a sound, in the case of a low person, in the case of a wise man, in the case of a third place, in the case of an army, in the case of a tree, in the case of a flash of lightning, in the case of a person of such a kind, in the case of a mother, in the case of a share, in the case of a bird, in the case of a tree.🔽Surrounding, to be fully understood, to be avoided, to embrace, to clothe, to worship, to serve, to despise, to reprove, in the case of characteristics, etc.

original: lakkhaṇādīsu. Samantatobhāve parivuto, paricchede pariññeyyaṃ, vajjane pariharati,
analyzed: lakkhaṇa ādīsu samantatobhāve parivutaḥ paricchede pariññeyyam vajjane pariharati
translated: In the case of surrounding, he is surrounded; in the case of fully understanding, it is to be fully understood; in the case of avoiding, he avoids;

original: āliṅgane parissajati, nivāsane vatthaṃ paridhassati, pūjāyaṃ pāricariyā, bhojane
analyzed: āliṅgane parissajati nivāsane vattham paridhassati pūjā ayam pāricariyā bhojane
translated: in the case of embracing, he embraces; in the case of clothing, he will put on a robe; in the case of worshipping, he attends; in the case of serving,

original: bhikkhuṃ parivisati. Avajānane paribhavati, dosakkhāne paribhāsati, lakkhaṇādīsu
analyzed: bhikkhum parivisati avajānane paribhavati dosa kkhāne paribhāsati lakkhaṇa ādīsu
translated: he serves a bhikkhu. In the case of despising, he despises; in the case of reproving, he reproves; in the case of characteristics, etc.,

original: rukkhaṃ pari vijjotate vijjuiccādi.
analyzed: rukkham pari
translated: in the case of a tree, a flash of lightning, etc. shines around.

original: Adhiiti adhiki’ssa’rūparibhāvā’dhibhavanajjhāyanā’dhiṭṭhānanicchayapāpuṇanādīsu.
analyzed: adhi iti
translated: Adhi is used in the sense of superiority, as in adhimutto, adhimutta is he who has superior mental development; adhibhavana-jhāyana, adhibhavana-jhāyana is the meditation of one who has superior mental development; adhiṭṭhāna, adhiṭṭhāna is the attainment of what is intended by resolve; and so on.

original: Adhike adhisīlaṃ, issare adhipati, adhi brahmadatte pañcālā, uparibhāve adhirohati,
analyzed: adhike adhisīlam issare adhipati adhi brahmadatte pañcālā upari bhāve adhirohati
translated: Adhike adhisīlaṃ, issare adhipati, adhi brahmadatte pañcālā, uparibhāve adhirohati,

original: pathaviṃ adhisessati, adhibhavane adhibhavati, ajjhāyane byākaraṇamadhīte, adhiṭṭhāne
analyzed: pathavim adhisessati adhibhavane adhibhavati ajjhāyane byākaraṇam adhīte adhiṭṭhāne
translated: pathaviṃ adhisessati, adhibhavane adhibhavati, ajjhāyane byākaraṇamadhīte, adhiṭṭhāne

original: bhūmikampādiṃ adhiṭṭhāti, nicchaye adhimokkho, pāpuṇane bhogakkhandhaṃ adhigacchati.🔽Abhiiti abhimukhabhāva visiṭṭhā’dhi ku’ddhakamma kula sāruppavandana lakkhaṇi’tthambhūtakkhāna🔽vicchādīsu. Abhimukhabhāve abhimukho abhikkamati, visiṭṭhe abhidhammo, adhike abhivassati,
analyzed: bhūmi kampa ādim adhiṭṭhāti nicchaye adhimokkhaḥ pāpuṇane bhoga kkhandham adhigacchati  abhi iti abhimukha bhāva visiṭṭha adhi kuddha kamma kula sāruppa vandana  vicchā ādīsu abhimukha bhāve abhimukhaḥ abhikkamati visiṭṭhe abhidhammaḥ adhike abhivassati
translated: bhūmikampādiṃ adhiṭṭhāti, nicchaye adhimokkho, pāpuṇane bhogakkhandhaṃ adhigacchati.

original: uddhakamme abhiruhati, kule abhijāto, sāruppe abhirūpo, vandane abhivādeti, lakkhaṇādīsu purimasamaṃ.
analyzed: uddha kamme abhiruhati kule abhijātaḥ sāruppe abhirūpaḥ vandane abhivādeti lakkhaṇa ādīsu purima samam
translated: Abhi is used in the sense of facing, as in abhimukhabhāva, abhimukhabhāva is the state of facing; visiṭṭhā, visiṭṭhā is the superior; adhi, adhi is the higher; ku, ku is the family; uddhaka, uddhaka is the name of a man; kamma, kamma is the action; kula, kula is the family; sāruppa, sāruppa is the suitable; vandana, vandana is the saluting; lakkhaṇi, lakkhaṇi is the characteristic; ittham, ittham is the thus; bhūta, bhūta is the being; akkhāna, akkhāna is the telling; vicchāda, vicchāda is the covering; and so on. In the sense of facing: abhimukho abhikkamati, he faces and goes forward. In the sense of superior: abhidhammo, the Abhidhamma is superior. In the sense of higher: abhivassati, it rains higher.🔽In the sense of higher action: abhiruhati, he ascends. In the sense of family: abhijāto, he is of high birth. In the sense of suitable: abhirūpo, he is suitable. In the sense of saluting: abhivādeti, he salutes. In the sense of characteristic, etc., it is the same as above.

original: Patiiti patigata paṭilomapatinidhi patidāna nisedhanivattana sādissa patikaraṇā’dāna
analyzed: pati iti pati gata paṭiloma pati nidhi pati dāna nisedha nivattana sa ādissa pati karaṇa ādāna
translated: Pati is used in the sense of “going to,” “facing,” “in the opposite direction,” “a pupil,” “giving back,” “prohibition,” “turning back,” “a substitute,” “doing in return,” “taking,”

original: patibodha paṭicca lakkhaṇi’tthambhūtakkhāna bhāgavicchādīsu. Patigate paccakkhaṃ,🔽paṭilome patisotaṃ, patinidhimhi ācariyato pati sisso, patidāne telatthikassa ghataṃ
analyzed: pati bodha paṭicca lakkhaṇitthambhūtakkhāna bhāga vicchā ādīsu patigate paccakkham  paṭilome pati sotam pati nidhimhi ācariyato pati sisso pati dāne telatthikassa
translated: “awakening,” “condition,” “characteristic,” “etc.,” “a part,” “covering up,” etc. In the sense of “going to,” it is used in the expression “paccakkhaṃ pati” (facing).🔽In the sense of “in the opposite direction,” it is used in the expression “patisotaṃ” (against the stream). In the sense of “a pupil,” it is used in the expression “patisiso ācariyato” (a pupil from a teacher). In the sense of “giving back,” it is used in the expression “telatthikassa ghaṭaṃ pati dadāti” (he gives back a pot to one who wants oil).

original: pati dadāti, nisedhe paṭisedhanaṃ, nivattane paṭikkamati, sādisse patirūpakaṃ, patikaraṇe
analyzed: pati dadāti nisedhe paṭisedhanam nivattane paṭikkamati sā ādisse patirūpakam patikaraṇe
translated: In the sense of “prohibition,” it is used in the expression “paṭisedhanaṃ pati” (in accordance with the prohibition). In the sense of “turning back,” it is used in the expression “paṭikkamati nivattane” (he turns back). In the sense of “a substitute,” it is used in the expression “patirūpakaṃ sādise” (a substitute for a similar one). In the sense of “doing in return,” it is used in the expression “patikāro patikaraṇe” (a return, a doing in return).

original: patikāro, ādāne patiggaṇhāti, patibodhe paṭivedho, paṭicce paccayo, lakkhaṇādīsu purimasamaṃ.
analyzed: patikāraḥ ādāne patiggaṇhāti pati bodhe paṭivedhaḥ paṭicce paccayaḥ lakkhaṇa ādīsu purima samam
translated: In the sense of “taking,” it is used in the expression “patiggaṇhāti ādāne” (he takes, he receives). In the sense of “awakening,” it is used in the expression “paṭivedho patibodhe” (awakening). In the sense of “condition,” it is used in the expression “paccayo paṭicce” (condition). In the sense of “characteristic,” etc., it is used in the same way as in the previous section.

original: Suiti sobhana suṭṭhusammā samiddhi sukhatthādīsu. Sobhane sugandho, suṭṭhusammādatthesu suṭṭhu gato sugato, sammā gatotipi sugato, samiddhiyaṃ subhikkhaṃ, sukhatthe sukaro.🔽Āiti abhimukhabhāvu’ddhakamma mariyādā’bhividhi patti’cchāparissajana ādikammaggahaṇa
analyzed: su iti sobhana suṭṭhu sammā samiddhi sukha attha ādīsu sobhane sugandho suṭṭhu sammā datthesu suṭṭhu gataḥ sugataḥ sammā gataḥ iti pi sugataḥ samiddhiyam subhikkham sukha atthe sukaraḥ 🔽ā iti
translated: Su is used in the sense of “beautiful,” “thorough,” “right,” “prosperity,” “happiness,” etc. In the sense of “beautiful,” it is used in the expression “sugandho su” (beautiful smell). In the sense of “thorough,” “right,” it is used in the expression “sugato suṭṭhu gato, sammā gato” (the well-gone,

original: nivāsa samīpa’vhānādīsu. Abhimukhabhāve āgacchati, uddhakamme ārohati, mariyādāyaṃ🔽āpabbatā khettaṃ, abhividhimhi ākumāraṃ yaso kaccāyanassa, pattiyaṃ āpattimāpanno,
analyzed: nivāsa samīpa vhāna ādīsu abhimukha bhāve āgacchati uddha kamme ārohati  āpabbatā khettam abhividhimhi ākumāram yaso kaccāyanassa pattiyam āpattim āpanno
translated: In the vicinity of a dwelling, etc.🔽In the sense of facing: He comes facing; he ascends a ladder; he goes to the boundary;🔽he goes to the field. In the sense of a method: The fame of Kassapa went up to the prince; he has incurred an offence.

original: icchāyaṃ ākaṅkhā, parissajane āliṅganaṃ, ādikamme ārambho, gahaṇe ādīyati ālambati,
analyzed: icchā ayam ākaṅkhā parissajane āliṅganam ādikamme ārambhaḥ gahaṇe ādīyati ālambati
translated: In the sense of desire: He desires; he is willing. In the sense of giving up: He embraces; he gives up. In the sense of beginning: He undertakes; he commences. In the sense of seizing: He is seized; he is taken hold of.

original: nivāse āvasatho, samīpe āsannaṃ, avhāne āmantesi.🔽Atiiti abhikkamanā’tikkantā’tisaya bhusatthādīsu. Atikkamane atirocati amhehi, atīto, atikkante accantaṃ, atisaye atikusalo, bhusatthe atikkodho ativuddhi.
analyzed: nivāse āvasathaḥ samīpe āsannam avhāne āmantesi  ati iti abhikkamana atikkanta atisaya bhusattha ādīsu atikkamane atirocati amhehi atītaḥ atikkante accantam atisaye ati kusalaḥ bhusatthe ati kkodhaḥ ati vuddhi
translated: In the sense of dwelling: He dwells; he lives. In the sense of near: He is near. In the sense of calling: He calls.🔽In the sense of beyond: He goes beyond; he has gone beyond; he has passed beyond; he has gone further; he is more distinguished; he is more abundant.

original: Apiiti sambhāvanā’pekkhā samuccaya garaha pañhādīsu. Sambhāvanāyaṃ api dibbesu kāmesu,
analyzed: api iti sambhāvanā apekkhā samuccaya garaha pañha ādīsu sambhāvanā ayam api dibbesu kāmesu
translated: In the sense of esteeming: He is esteemed; he is looked up to; he is included; he is blamed; he is asked, etc. In the sense of esteeming: He is esteemed even among the divine beings;

original: merumpi vinivijjhitvā gaccheyya, apekkhāyaṃ ayampi dhammo aniyato, samuccaye itipi
analyzed: merum pi vinivijjhitvā gaccheyya apekkha ayam ayam pi dhammo aniyataḥ samuccaye iti pi
translated: he would go through even Mount Meru. In the sense of looking up to: This rule too is indeterminate. In the sense of including: This is also called …

original: arahaṃ, antampi antaguṇampi ādāya, garahe api amhākaṃ paṇḍitaka, pañhe api bhante bhikkhaṃ labhittha.🔽Apaiti apagata garaha vajjana pūjā padussanādīsu. Apagate apamāno apeto, garahe apagabbho, vajjane apasālāya āyanti vāṇijā, pūjāyaṃ vuddhāpacāyī, padussane aparajjhati.🔽Upaiti upagamana samīpū’papatti sādissā’dhikū’paribhāvā’nasana dosakkhāna saññā pubbakamma
analyzed: araham antam pi anta guṇam pi ādāya garahe api amhākam paṇḍitaka pañhe api bhante bhikkham labhittha  apaiti apagata garaha vajjana pūjā padussana ādīsu apagate apamānaḥ apetaḥ garahe apagabbhaḥ vajjane apasālāya āyanti vāṇijā pūjā ayam vuddha apacāyī padussane aparajjhati  upaiti upagamana samīpa upapatti sādissa adhika upari bhāva ānasana dosa kkhāna saññā pubba kamma
translated: and he is an Arahant, he takes away the inside and the intestines, and he is a wise man, and he asked questions, and he got almsfood.

original: pūjā gayhākāra bhusatthādīsu. Upagamane nisinnaṃ vā upanisīdeyya, samīpe upanagaraṃ,🔽upapattiyaṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati, atha vā upapatti yutti, yathā – upapattito ikkhatīti🔽upekkhā, sādisse upamānaṃ upamā, adhike upa khāriyaṃ doṇo, uparibhāve upasampanno,
analyzed: pūjā gayhākāra bhusattha ādīsu upagamane nisinnam vā upanisīdeyya samīpe upanagaram 🔽upapattiyam saggam lokam upapajjati atha vā upapatti yutti yathā upapattitaḥ ikkhati iti 🔽upekkhā sā ādisse upamānam upamā adhike upa khāriyam doṇaḥ upari bhāve upasampannaḥ

original: anasane upavāso, dosakkhāne paraṃ upapadati, saññāyaṃ upadhā upasaggo, pubbakamme
analyzed: an asane upavāsaḥ dosa kkhāne param upapadati saññā ayam upadhā upasaggaḥ pubba kamme
translated: The upavāsa is not a meal, In the dosaka-khandhaka, one who is superior to another, In saññā, upadhā, upasagga, In the past,

original: upakkamo upakāro, pūjāyaṃ buddhupaṭṭhāko, mātupaṭṭhānaṃ, gayhākāre soceyyapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: upakkamaḥ upakāro pūjā ayam buddhupaṭṭhākaḥ mātupaṭṭhānam gayhākāre soceyya paccupaṭṭhānam
translated: Upaccheda, upacāra, In pūjā, a Buddha’s attendant, In mātupaṭṭhāna, In the mode of carrying, the support of virtue,

original: bhusatthe upādānaṃ, upāyāso, upanissayoti. Iti anekatthā hi upasaggā.
analyzed: bhusatthe upādānam upāyāsaḥ upanissayaḥ ti iti anekatthāḥ hi upasaggā
translated: In bhusatta, upādāna, upāyāsa, upanissaya. Thus upasaggas have many meanings.

original: Vuttañca –
analyzed: vuttam ca
translated: And it is said:

original: “Upasagga nipātā ca, paccayā ca ime tayo;
analyzed: upasagga nipātā ca paccayā ca ime tayo
translated: “Upasaggas, nipātas, and these three conditions,

original: Nekenekatthavisayā, iti neruttikābravu”nti.
analyzed: iti neruttikāḥ bravunti
translated: Have many meanings, it is said, by the grammarians.”

original: Tattha upasaggānaṃ nāmākhyātavisesakattā liṅgasaññāyaṃ aniyamena syādimhi sampatte tesaṃ saṅkhyākammādibhedābhāvā tehi paṭhamekavacanameva bhavati.
analyzed: tattha upasaggānam nāma ākhyāta visesaka ttā liṅga saññā ayam aniyamena sya ādimhi sampatte tesam saṅkhyā kamma ādi bheda abhāvā tehi paṭhama ekavacanam eva bhavati
translated: Herein, because upasaggas are a kind of name-base, they are not included in the declensions, and when the syādi system is applied to them, they have no such divisions as number, case, and so on, so that their number is always singular in the first place.🔽When it is said “lopa”

original: “Lopa”nti vattamāne
analyzed: vattamāne
translated: “Loss” is said.

original: 282. Sabbāsamāvusopasagganipātādīhi ca.
analyzed: sabba asama avusa upasagga nipāta ādīhi ca
translated: And with all the endings, with the upasaggas, nipātas, and so on.

original: Āvusosaddato, upasagganipātehi ca sabbāsaṃ parāsaṃ vibhattīnaṃ lopo hoti. Ādisaddena
analyzed: āvuso saddataḥ upasagga nipātehi ca sabbāsam parāsam vibhattīnam lopaḥ hoti ādi saddena
translated: The elision of all the endings, of the parā endings, is effected by the āvusos affix and by the upasagga nipātas. The ādi word includes🔽.

original: kvaci suttapadādīhi ca. Ettha ca āvusotimassa visuṃ gahaṇaṃ sasaṅkhyattadīpanatthanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: kvaci sutta pada ādīhi ca ettha ca āvuso timassa visum gahaṇam sasaṅkhya tta dīpana atthanti daṭṭhabbam
translated: and in some places by the Thread-text, etc. And here the word āvuso is to be regarded as taken separately in order to illustrate the use of the numeral word .

original: Upeccatthaṃ sajjantīti, upasaggā hi pādayo;
analyzed: upeccattham sajjanti iti upasaggāḥ hi pādayaḥ
translated: The feet are called upasagga because they go up to (upa-saṅkamanti) the syllables,

original: Cādī padādimajjhante, nipātā nipatantiti.
analyzed: ca ādī pada ādi majjha ante nipātāḥ nipatanti iti
translated: and the nipāta syllables are called nipāta because they fall (nip-atanti) at the beginning, etc., of words.

original: Paharaṇaṃ pahāro, evaṃ parābhavo, nivāso, nīhāro, uhāro, duhāro, saṃhāro, vihāro,
analyzed: paharaṇam pahāraḥ evam parābhavaḥ nivāsaḥ nīhāraḥ uhāraḥ duhāraḥ saṃhāraḥ vihāraḥ
translated: The words pahāra, parābhava, nivāsa, nīhāra, uhāra, duhāra, saṃhāra, vihāra,

original: avahāro, anuhāro, parihāro, adhihāro, abhihāro, patihāro, suhāro, āhāro, atihāro,
analyzed: avahāraḥ anuhāraḥ parihāraḥ adhihāraḥ abhihāraḥ patihāraḥ suhāraḥ āhāraḥ atihāraḥ
translated: avahāra, anuhāra, parihāra, adhihāra, abhihāra, paṭihāra, suhāro, āhāro, atihāro,

original: apihāro, apahāro, upahāro. Paharati, parābhavati, nivasati, nīharati, uddharati iccādi yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: apihāraḥ apahāraḥ upahāro paharati parābhavati nivasati nīharati uddharati iccādi yojetabbam
translated: apihāro, apahāro, upahāra are to be construed as follows: he strikes, he is defeated, he dwells, he takes out, he takes up, etc.

original: Dhātvatthaṃ bādhate koci, koci tamanuvattate;🔽Tamevañño viseseti, upasaggagatī tidhā.
analyzed: dhātvattham bādhate koci koci tam anuvattate  viseseti upasagga gatī tidhā
translated: In some cases the meaning of a verbal root is contradicted,🔽in some cases it is followed,

original: Opasaggikapadaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.🔽Nepātikapada🔽Samuccayavikappanapaṭisedhapūraṇādiatthaṃ asatvavācakaṃ nepātikaṃ padaṃ.
analyzed: opasaggika padam niṭṭhitam 🔽nepātika pada 🔽samuccaya vikappana paṭisedha pūraṇa ādi attham asatva vācakam nepātikam padam
translated: in some cases it is specialized. Thus the upasagga is threefold in occurrence.

original: Tatra caiti samuccayā’nvācaye’tarītarayogasamāhārā’vadhāraṇādīsu.
analyzed: tatra ca eti samuccaya anvācaya itarītara yoga samāhāra avadhāraṇa ādīsu
translated: And is used in the sense of addition, alternative, combination, mutual relationship, collection, limitation, etc.

original: Vāiti vikappanū’pamāna samuccaya vavatthitavibhāsāsu.
analyzed: vā iti
translated: Or is used in the sense of conjecture, comparison, addition, distinction, and analysis.

original: Na no mā a alaṃ halaṃ iccete paṭisedhanatthe.
analyzed: na no mā a alam halam icc ete paṭisedhana tthe
translated: No, mā, a, alaṃ, halaṃ are used in the sense of prohibition.

original: Alaṃ pariyatti bhūsanesu ca.
analyzed: alam bhūsanesu ca
translated: Alaṃ is also used in the sense of adornment of the scriptures.

original: Pūraṇatthaṃ duvidhaṃ atthapūraṇaṃ padapūraṇañca.
analyzed: pūraṇa ttham duvidham attha pūraṇam pada pūraṇam ca
translated: Pūraṇa is twofold: fulfilling the meaning and fulfilling the word.

original: Tattha atha khalu vata vatha atho assu yagghe hi carahi naṃ taṃ vā ca tuva vo pana have kīva ha tato yathā sudaṃ kho ve haṃ enaṃ seyyathidaṃ iccevamādīni padapūraṇāni.
analyzed: tattha atha khalu vata vatha atho assu hi carahi nam tam vā ca have kīva ha tatas yathā sudam kho ve haṃ enam seyyathidam iti ca ivamādīni pada pūraṇāni
translated: Among them, atha khalu vata vatha atho assu yagghe hi carahi naṃ taṃ vā ca tuva vo pana have kīva ha tato yathā sudaṃ kho ve haṃ enaṃ seyyathidaṃ iccevamādīni are fulfillers of the word.

original: Tattha – athaiti pañhā’nantariyā’dhikārādīsu ca.🔽Khaluiti paṭisedhā’vadhāraṇa pasiddhīsu ca.
analyzed: tattha atha eti pañha ānantariya adhikāra ādīsu ca  khalu iti ca
translated: Among them, atha is used in the sense of question, immediate succession, and undertaking, etc.🔽Khalo is used in the sense of prohibition, limitation, and establishment.

original: Vataiti ekaṃsa khedā’nukampasaṅkappesu ca.
analyzed: vata eti ekaṃsa kheda anukampa saṅkappesu ca
translated: Vata is used in the sense of one-sidedness, weariness, compassion, and reflection.

original: Athoiti anvādese ca.🔽Hiiti hetu avadhāraṇesu ca.
analyzed: atha u iti anvādese ca  hi iti hetu avadhāraṇesu ca
translated: Atho is used in the sense of alternative.🔽Hi is used in the sense of cause and limitation.

original: Tuiti visesa hetu nivattanādīsu ca.
analyzed: tuiti visesa hetu nivattana ādīsu ca
translated: Tu is used in the sense of distinction, cause, reversal, etc.

original: Panaiti visesepi.
analyzed: pana eti visese pi
translated: Pana is used in the sense of distinction.

original: Have, veiccete ekaṃsatthepi.
analyzed: have ve icca ite ekaṃ satthe pi
translated: Have and ve are used in the sense of one-sidedness.

original: Haṃiti visāda sambhamesupi.
analyzed: haṃ iti visāda sambhame supi
translated: Haṃ is used in expressions of sorrow.

original: Seyyathidanti taṃ katamanti atthepi.
analyzed: tam katamanti
translated: Seyyathidanti is used in the sense of “that which is so.”

original: Atthapūraṇaṃ duvidhaṃ vibhattiyuttaṃ, avibhattiyuttañca.
analyzed: attha pūraṇam duvidham vibhatti yuttam a vibhatti yuttam ca
translated: The fulfilment of the meaning is twofold: that which is expressed by case-endings, and that which is not so expressed.

original: Atthi sakkā labbhā iccete paṭhamāyaṃ.
analyzed: atthi sakkā labbhā icca ete
translated: Atthi, sakkā, labbhā, iccete are used in the first case.

original: Āvuso ambho hambho re are hare jeiccete āmantane.
analyzed: āvuso ambhaḥ hambho re are hare āmantane
translated: Āvuso, ambho, hambho, re, are, hare, je, iccete are used in the vocative.

original: Divā bhiyyo namo iccete paṭhamāyaṃ, dutiyāyañca.
analyzed: divā bhiyyaḥ namaḥ icca ete paṭhama ayam dutiya ayam ca
translated: Divā, bhiyyo, namo, iccete are used in the first and second cases.

original: Sayaṃ sāmaṃ saṃ sammā kinti iccete tatiyatthe, soto dhāpaccayantā ca. Suttaso padaso aniccato dukkhato ekadhā dvidhā iccādi.
analyzed: sayam sāmam sam sammā kinti icca ete tatiya tthe so taḥ dhā paccaya ntā ca suttasaḥ padasaḥ aniccataḥ dukkhataḥ ekadhā dvidhā iccādi
translated: Sayaṃ, sāmaṃ, saṃ, sammā, kiṃ, iccete are used in the third case, and also in the sense of a river, a stream, a condition, a verse, a word, impermanence, suffering, in the sense of one, two, etc.

original: Tave tuṃpaccayantā catutthiyā, kātave dātave kātuṃ kāretuṃ dātuṃ dāpetuṃ iccādi.
analyzed: tave tum pacca yantā catutthiyā kātave dātave kātum kāretum dātum dāpetum iccādi
translated: Tave, tuṃ, iccete are used in the fourth case: kātave, dātave, kātuṃ, kāretuṃ, dātuṃ, dāpetuṃ, etc.

original: So topaccayantā pañcamiyatthe, dīghaso oraso rājato vā corato vā iccādi.
analyzed: saḥ taḥ pacca yantā pañcamiya tthe dīgha saḥ orasaḥ rājataḥ vā corataḥ vā iti ādi
translated: So, top, iccete are used in the fifth case: dīghaso, oraso, rājato, vā, corato, vā, etc.

original: To sattamyatthepi, trathādipaccayantā ca. Ekato purato pacchato passato piṭṭhito pādato sīsato aggato mūlato yatra yattha yahiṃ tatra tattha tahiṃ tahaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: to sattamī atthe pi tratha ādi paccaya antā ca ekatas puratas pacchatas passatas piṭṭhitas pādataḥ sīsataḥ aggataḥ mūlataḥ yatra yattha tatra tattha tahiṃ tahaṃ iccādi
translated: To is used in the seventh case, and also in the sense of together, in front, behind, in front of, behind, at the foot, at the head, at the beginning, at the end, wherever, wherever, there, there, thus, etc.

original: Samantā sāmantā parito abhito samantato ekajjhaṃ ekamantaṃ heṭṭhā upari uddhaṃ adho
analyzed: samantā sāmantā paritas abhitas samantataḥ ekajjham ekamantam heṭṭhā upari uddham adhas
translated: All round, about, on all sides, on every side, all together, in one place, below, above, upwards, downwards,

original: tiriyaṃ sammukhā parammukhā āvi raho tiro uccaṃ nīcaṃ anto antarā ajjhattaṃ bahiddhā
analyzed: tiriyam sammukhā parammukhāḥ āvi raho tiras uccam nīcam antar antarā ajjhattam bahiddhā
translated: across, in front, behind, in the open, in secret, far, near, inside, outside, in the middle, on the outside, on the outside, on the other side, on the further side, far away, behind, in front, yonder, over there, once,

original: bāhirā bāhiraṃ bahi oraṃ pāraṃ ārā ārakā pacchā pure huraṃ pecca iccete sattamiyā.🔽Sampati āyati ajja aparajju parajja suve sve parasuve hiyyo pare sajju sāyaṃ pāto
analyzed: bāhirā bāhiram bahi oram pāram ārā ārakā pacchā pure huram pecca icca ete sattamiyā  sampati āyati ajja aparajju parajja suve sve parasuve hiyyo pare sajju sāyam pāto
translated: today, yesterday, the day before, tomorrow, the day after, the day before yesterday, the day after tomorrow, the other day, in the evening, in the morning,

original: kālaṃ kallaṃ divā nattaṃ niccaṃ satataṃ abhiṇhaṃ abhikkhaṇaṃ muhuṃ muhuttaṃ bhūtapubbaṃ
analyzed: kālam kallam divā nattam niccam satatam abhiṇham abhikkhaṇam muhum muhuttam bhūta pubbam
translated: at the right time, at the proper time, by day, by night, constantly, always, frequently, continually, again and again, for a moment, once upon a time,

original: purā yadā tadā kadā iccādayo kālasattamiyā. Iti vibhattiyuttāni.
analyzed: purā yadā tadā kadā iti vibhatti yuttāni
translated: formerly, when, then, sometime, thus, etc., are used with the seventh case. Thus they are used with a case-ending.

original: Avibhattiyuttesu ca appeva appevanāma nu iccete saṃsayatthe.
analyzed: a vibhatti yuttesu ca appa iva appa iva nāma nu icca ete saṃsaya tthe
translated: And in the case of those used without a case-ending, too, it is, it is not, is it so? is it not so? is it not? is it not so? are used in the sense of doubt.

original: Addhā aññadatthu taggha jātu kāmaṃ sasakkaṃiccete ekaṃsatthe.
analyzed: addhā aññadatthu taggha jātu kāmam sa sakkam itca ete ekaṃsatthe
translated: Surely, indeed, surely, at one time, if it is so, certainly, are used in the sense of certainty.

original: Evaiti avadhāraṇe.
analyzed: eva eti avadhāraṇe
translated: Thus is used in the sense of definition.

original: Kaccinu’kinnunanukathaṃ kiṃsu kiṃiccete pucchanatthe.
analyzed: kaccinu kinnu nanu katham kiṃsu kiṃit ca ete pucchana tthe
translated: Is it so? is it not? is it not so? is it not? what? what is it? are used in the sense of asking.

original: Evaṃ iti itthaṃ iccete nidassane.🔽Iti hetu vākyaparisamattīsu ca.🔽Yāva tāva yāvatā tāvatā kittāvatā ettāvatā kīva iccete paricchedanatthe.🔽Evaṃ sāhu lahu opāyikaṃ patirūpaṃ āma sādhu iti sampaṭicchanatthe.🔽Yathā tathā yatheva tatheva evaṃ evameva evamevaṃ evampi yathāpi seyyathāpi seyyathāpināma🔽viya iva yathariva tathariva yathānāma tathānāma yathāhi tathāhi yathācatathāca iccete paṭibhāgatthe.🔽Yathāiti yoggatā vicchā padatthānativattanidassanesu ca.
analyzed: evam iti ittham icca ete nidassane  iti hetu vākya parisamattīsu ca  yāva tāva yāvatā tāvatā kittāvatā ettāvatā kīva id ca ete paricchedana tthe  evam sāhu lahu opāyikam patirūpam sādhu iti  yathā tathā yathā iva tathā iva evam evam eva evam evam evam yathā api seyyathā api seyyathā api nāma  viyaḥ iva tathariva yathānāma tathānāma yathāhi tathāhi yathāca tathāca it ca ete paṭibhāga tthe  yathā iti yoggatā vicchā padattha anativatta nidassanesu ca

original: Evaṃiti upadesa pañhādīsu ca.🔽Kiñcāpiiti anuggahatthe.🔽Ahoiti garaha pasaṃsana patthanesu ca.🔽Nāmaiti garaha pasaṃsana saññā pañhesu ca.🔽Sādhuiti pasaṃsana yācanesu ca.
analyzed: evaṃiti upadesa pañha ādīsu ca  kiñca api iti anuggaha tthe  ahoiti garaha pasaṃsana patthanesu ca  nāmaiti garaha pasaṃsana saññā pañhesu ca  sādhuiti pasaṃsana yācanesu ca
translated: Thus, in this way, like this, thus, are the demonstratives.

original: Iṅgha handa iccete codanatthe.🔽Sādhu suṭṭhu evametanti anumodane.
analyzed: iṅgha handaḥ i t ca ete codanatthe 🔽sādhu suṭṭhu evam etat ti anumodane

original: Kiraiti anussavaṇa assaddheyyesu.
analyzed: kiraiti anussavaṇa assaddheyyesu
translated: Kira is used for hearsay, in the sense of ‘they say’.

original: Nūnaiti anumānā’nussaraṇa parivitakkanesu.
analyzed: nūna eti anumāna anussaraṇa parivitakkanesu
translated: Nūna is used for inference, for recollection, for conjecture, and for reflection.

original: Kasmāiti kāraṇapucchane.
analyzed: kasmai iti kāraṇa pucchane
translated: Kasmā is used for a question asking a reason.

original: Yasmā tasmā tathāhi tena iccete kāraṇacchedanatthe.
analyzed: yasmai tasmai tathā hi tena id ca ete kāraṇa chedana tthe
translated: Yasmā, tasmā, tathā, hi, tena, icc-ete are used for the purpose of supplying a reason.

original: Saha saddhiṃ samaṃ amāiti samakriyāyaṃ.
analyzed: saha saddhim samam
translated: Saha, saddhiṃ, samaṃ, amā are used for equality.

original: Vinā riteiti vippayoge.
analyzed: vinā rite iti vip payoge
translated: Vinā, rite are used for separation.

original: Nānā puthu bahuppakāre.
analyzed: nānā puthu bahuppakāre
translated: Nānā, puthu, bahu, pakāra, are used for variety.

original: Puthu visuṃ asaṅghāte ca.🔽Duṭṭhu ku jigucchāyaṃ.
analyzed: puthu visum a saṅghāte ca  duṭṭhu ku jiguccha ayam
translated: Puthu, visuṃ, asaṅghāte are used for distinctness.🔽Duṭṭhu is used for disgust.

original: Puna appaṭhame.🔽Kathañci kicchatthe ca.
analyzed: puna appaṭhame  kathañci kicchatthe ca
translated: Puna is used for the second time.🔽Kathañci is used for the purpose of difficulty.

original: Dhā kkhattuṃ sakiñca saṅkhyāvibhāge.
analyzed: dhā kkhattum sakin ca saṅkhyā vibhāge
translated: Dhā is used for the purpose of counting.

original: Īsakaṃ appatthe.
analyzed: īsakam appatthe
translated: Īsaka is used for the purpose of a small amount.

original: Saṇikaṃ mandatthe.🔽Khippaṃ araṃ lahu āsuṃ tuṇṇaṃ aciraṃ sīghatthe.
analyzed: saṇikam mandatthe  khippam aram lahu āsum tuṇṇam aciram sīghatthe
translated: Saṇika is used for the purpose of slowness.🔽Khippaṃ, araṃ, lahu, āsuṃ, tuṇṇa, acira, sīgha are used for the purpose of speed.

original: Ciraṃ cirassaṃ dīghakāle.
analyzed: ciram cirassam dīgha kāle
translated: Ciraṃ, cirassaṃ, dīghakāla are used for the purpose of a long time.

original: Ce yadi saṅkāvaṭṭhāne.
analyzed: ce yadi saṅkāvaṭṭhāne
translated: Ce is used for the purpose of a conditional clause.

original: Dhuvaṃ thirāvadhāraṇesu.🔽Hā visāde.
analyzed: dhuvam thira avadhāraṇesu  hā visāde
translated: Dhuva is used for the purpose of firmness and certainty.🔽Hā is used for the purpose of lamentation.

original: Tuṇhī abhāsane.
analyzed: tuṇhī a bhāsane
translated: Tuṇhī is used for the purpose of silence.

original: Sacchi paccakkhe.
analyzed: sacchi paccakkhe
translated: Sacchi is used for the purpose of truth.

original: Musā micchā alikaṃ asacce.
analyzed: musā micchā alikam asacce
translated: Musā, micchā, alika, asacca are used for the purpose of falsehood.

original: Suvatthi āsīsatthe iccādi.
analyzed: suvatthi āsīsatthe iccādi
translated: Suvatthi is used for the purpose of well-being.

original: Tuna tvāna tvāpaccayantā ussukkanatthe bhavanti.
analyzed: tuna tvāna tvā paccayantāḥ ussukkana tthe bhavanti
translated: Tuna, tvāna, tvāpaccaya are used for the purpose of exertion.

original: Yathā – passituna passiya passitvāna passitvā disvā disvānadassetvā dātuna datvāna🔽datvā upādāya dāpetvā viññāpetvā viceyya vineyya nihacca samecca apecca upecca ārabbha āgamma iccādi.🔽Evaṃ nāmākhyātopasaggavinimuttaṃ yadabyayalakkhaṇaṃ, taṃ sabbaṃ nipātapadanti veditabbaṃ.🔽Vuttañca –
analyzed: yathā passituna passiya passitvāna passitvā disvā disvāna dassetvā dātuna  datvā upādāya dāpetvā viññāpetvā viceyya vineyya nihacca samecca apecca upecca ārabbha āgamma iccādi  evam nāma ākhyāta upasagga vinimuttam yat abyaya lakkhaṇam tat sabbam nipāta padam ti veditabbam  vuttam ca

Kārakakaṇḍa🔽Atha vibhattīnamatthabhedā vuccante.

original: Tattha ekampi atthaṃ kammādivasena, ekattādivasena ca vibhajantīti vibhattiyo, syādayo. Tā pana paṭhamādibhedena sattavidhā.
analyzed: tattha ekam pi attham kamma ādi vasena ekatta ādi vasena ca vibhajanti iti vibhattiyaḥ syādayo tā pana paṭhama ādi bhedena sattavidhā
translated: Herein, they are called “endings” because they are divided up according to the meaning, and according to the action, etc., and according to the singleness, etc. The particles are the endings. They are of seven kinds as first, etc.,

original: Tattha kasmiṃ atthe paṭhamā?
analyzed: tattha kasmin atthe paṭhamā
translated: Herein, in what meaning is the first?

original: 283. Liṅgatthe paṭhamā.
analyzed: liṅga tthe paṭhamā
translated: The first is in the meaning of gender.

original: Liṅgatthābhidhānamatte paṭhamāvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: liṅga attha abhidhāna matte paṭhamā vibhatti
translated: The first case-ending is in the mere expression of the meaning of gender.

original: Liṅgassa attho liṅgattho. Ettha ca līnaṃ aṅganti liṅgaṃ, apākaṭo avayavo, purisotiādīnañhi
analyzed: liṅgassa atthaḥ liṅga tthaḥ ettha ca līnam aṅganti liṅgam apākaṭaḥ avayavaḥ purisaḥ ti ādīnam hi
translated: The meaning of gender is the meaning of gender. And here gender is what is hidden , what is not manifest , what is a part . For the noun-inflected words such as “man” are

original: pakatippaccayādivibhāgakappanāya nipphāditānaṃ saddappatirūpakānaṃ nāmikapadānaṃ🔽paṭhamaṃ ṭhapetabbaṃ pakatirūpaṃ apākaṭattā, avayavattā ca liṅganti vuccati. Atha🔽vā visadāvisadobhayarahitākāravohārasaṅkhātena tividhaliṅgena sahitatthassa, tabbinimuttassupasaggādīnamatthassa
analyzed: pakati paccaya ādi vibhāga kappanāya nipphāditānam sadda patirūpakānam nāmika padānam  paṭhamam ṭhapetabbam pakati rūpam apākaṭa ttā avayava ttā ca liṅgam ti vuccati atha  vā visada avisada ubhaya rahita ākāra vohāra saṅkhātena tividha liṅgena sahita atthassa
translated: formed by the addition of the first-case-ending to the stem-form, which is not manifest because it has to be inferred by the rules of grammar, etc.,🔽and it is called “gender” because it is a part. Or alternatively, the meaning of gender is the meaning that is associated with the three kinds of gender called “masculine,” “feminine,” and “neuter,” which are a mode of expression that is free from the two, that is to say, from the manifest and the unmanifest ,

original: ca līnassa gamanato, liṅganato vā liṅganti anvatthanāmavasena vā “dhātuppaccayavibhattivajjitamatthavaṃ
analyzed: ca līnassa gamanataḥ liṅganataḥ vā liṅganti anvattha nāma vasena vā
translated: and it is called “gender” because it is the going of the meaning, or because it is the cause, of the meaning of the unmanifest , or else because it is a name formed by the addition of the suffix -a to the stem form of the word anvatta , which is derived by adding the suffix -a to the word anvatta , which is itself derived by adding the suffix -a to the word anvatta , which is itself derived by adding the suffix -a to the word anvatta , which is itself derived by adding the suffix -a to the word anvatta , which is itself derived by adding the suffix -a to the word anvatta , which is itself derived by adding the suffix -a to the word anvatta , which is itself derived by adding the suffix -a to the word anvatta , which is itself derived by adding the suffix -a to the word anvatta , which is itself derived by adding the suffix -a to the word anvatta , which is itself derived by adding the suffix -a to the word anvatta , which is itself derived by adding the suffix -a to the word anvatta , which is itself derived by adding the suffix -a to the word anvatta , which is itself derived by adding the suffix

original: liṅga”nti vacanato parasamaññāvasena vā liṅganti idha pāṭipadikāparanāmadheyyaṃ syādivibhatyantapadapakatirūpameva🔽vuccatīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: liṅganti vacanataḥ para samaññā vasena vā liṅganti pāṭipadika apara nāmadheyyam eva  vuccati iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: “Gender” is a word that is a name for something else, or it is a word that ends in a case-ending, and it is called “gender” because of the word “liṅga” .

original: Liṅgassattho nāma pabandhavisesākārena pavattamāne rūpādayo upādāya paññāpīyamāno
analyzed: liṅgaḥ satthaḥ nāma pabandha visesa ākārena pavattamāne rūpa ādayaḥ upādāya paññāpīyamānaḥ
translated: The meaning of gender is the meaning of a pot, a cloth, etc., which is called “individuality” and is designated by the aggregates, etc., that occur in the form of a particular arrangement,

original: tadaññānaññabhāvena anibbacanīyo samūhasantānādibhedo upādāpaññattisaṅkhāto ghaṭapaṭādivohārattho
analyzed: tad añña anañña bhāvena a nibbacanīyaḥ samūha santāna ādi bhedaḥ upādā paññatti saṅkhātaḥ ghaṭa paṭa ādi vohāra attho
translated: and which cannot be pointed out as “this” by way of difference from something else, and it is the meaning of the general characteristics of hardness, smoothness, etc., which are called “universal” and are established by the imposition of a convention according to kind,

original: ca pathavīdhātuphassādīnaṃ sabhāvadhammānaṃ kāladesādibhedabhinnānaṃ vijātiyavinivatto🔽sajātiyasādhāraṇo yathāsaṅketamāropasiddho tajjāpaññattisaṅkhāto kakkhaḷattaphusanādisāmaññākāro ca.
analyzed: ca pathavī dhātu phassa ādīnam sa bhāva dhammānam kāla desa ādi bheda bhinnānam vijātiya vinivatto  sajātiya sādhāraṇaḥ yathā saṅketam āropa siddho tajjā paññatti saṅkhāto kakkhaḷatta phusana ādi sāmañña ākāro ca
translated: and which are distinguished by the difference of kind, place, time, etc., of the individual dhammas such as the earth element, contact, etc.

original: So pana kammādisaṃsaṭṭho, suddho cāti duvidho. Tattha kammādīsu dutiyādīnaṃ vidhīyamānattā
analyzed: so pana kamma ādi saṃsaṭṭhaḥ suddhaḥ ca ati duvidhaḥ tattha kamma ādīsu dutiya ādīnam vidhīyamāna ttā
translated: It is twofold as mixed with kamma, etc., and pure. Herein, since the second, etc., are prescribed in kamma, etc.,

original: kammādisaṃsaggarahito liṅgasaṅkhyāparimāṇayutto, tabbinimuttupasaggādipadatthabhūto
analyzed: kamma ādi saṃsagga rahitaḥ liṅga saṅkhyā parimāṇa yuttaḥ tad vinimutta upasagga ādi padattha bhūtaḥ
translated: the meaning of gender is the meaning of a word that is devoid of the mixture of kamma, etc., that is endowed with number, gender, and measure, and that is the meaning of a word such as “tree,” etc., which is the cause of the manifestation of the meaning of a word such as “tree,” etc.,

original: ca suddho saddattho idha liṅgattho nāma.🔽Yo pana ākhyātakitakataddhitasamāsehi vutto kammādisaṃsaṭṭho attho, sopi dutiyādīnaṃ
analyzed: ca suddhaḥ saddatthaḥ idha liṅgatthaḥ nāma  yaḥ pana ākhyāta kitaka taddhita samāsehi vuttaḥ kamma ādi saṃsaṭṭhaḥ attho saḥ api dutiya ādīnam
translated: and the word sadda is pure in meaning, and the word liṅga is a name.🔽But the meaning associated with a noun, which is expressed by the verbal prefixes, the verbal bases, and the nominal suffixes, is also the domain of the first case.

original: puna attanā vattabbassa atthavisesassābhāvena avisayattā, liṅgatthamattassa sambhavato
analyzed: puna attanā vattabbassa attha visesassa abhāvena avisaya ttā liṅga attha mattassa sambhavato
translated: Because it is not the domain of the second and following cases, since they have no particular meaning to be expressed by themselves,

original: ca paṭhamāyeva visayo.
analyzed: ca paṭhamāya iva
translated: and because the mere meaning of the noun is possible.

original: Hoti cettha –
analyzed: hoti ca itthā
translated: And here there is this:

original: Paṭhamāvupasaggatthe, kesañcatthe nipātasaddānaṃ;
analyzed: paṭhamau upasagga atthe kesañcatthe nipāta saddānam
translated: The first case is the domain of the upasagga, and of some indeclinable words,

original: Liṅgādike ca suddhe-bhihite kammādiatthepi.
analyzed: liṅga ādike ca kamma ādi atthe pi
translated: And of pure nouns, etc., and of the meaning of action, etc.

original: Saliṅge tāva – eso puriso, ete purisā, esā kaññā, etā kaññāyo, etaṃ cittaṃ, etāni cittāni.
analyzed: saliṅge tāva esaḥ puriso ete purisāḥ esā kaññā etā kaññāyaḥ etam cittam etāni cittāni
translated: First, in the case of nouns without gender: this man, these men; this girl, these girls; this mind, these minds.

original: Sasaṅkhye – eko dve.
analyzed: sa saṅkhye ekaḥ dve
translated: In the case of nouns with number: one, two.

original: Saparimāṇe – doṇo khārī āḷhakaṃ.
analyzed: sa parimāṇe khārī āḷhakam
translated: In the case of nouns with measure: a doṇa, a khāri, a āḷhaka.

original: Liṅgādivinimutte sattāmatte – ca vā ha ahaṃ atthi sakkālabbhā iccādi.
analyzed: liṅga ādi vinimutte sattā matte ca vā ha aham atthi sakkā labbhā iccādi
translated: In the case of nouns without gender, etc., in the mere sevenfold being: and, or, I, he, there is, it is possible, etc.

original: “Liṅgatthe paṭhamā”ti adhikicca “ālapane cā”ti ālapanatthe ca paṭhamā, abhimukhaṃ katvā lapanaṃ ālapanaṃ, āmantanaṃ avhānanti attho.
analyzed: liṅga atthe paṭhamā ati adhikicca ālapane ca ati ālapana tthe ca paṭhamā abhimukham katvā lapanam ālapanam āmantanam avhānanti atthaḥ
translated: “The first case is the domain of the noun” is a general statement. “And also in the case of address” is a particular statement. Address is speaking to someone face to face. The meaning is: inviting, summoning.

original: Ettha ca āmantanaṃ nāma pageva laddhasarūpassa saddena abhimukhīkaraṇaṃ, katābhimukho
analyzed: ettha ca āmantanam nāma pagā iva laddha sarūpassa saddena abhimukhīkaraṇam kata abhimukhaḥ
translated: And here the calling is the facing of one who has a visible form by means of the sound, and the one who is faced

original: pana “gacchā”tiādinā nayena kriyāya yojīyati, tasmā āmantanasamaye kriyāyogābhāvato
analyzed: pana tasmai āmantana samaye kriyā yojīyati tasmai āmantana samaye kriyā yoga abhāvataḥ
translated: is joined to the verb by means of the word ‘ go ’ , etc., thus: ‘ Go, man! ’ ‘ Go, men! ’ ‘ Come, man! ’ ‘ Come, men! ’ ‘ Come, sirs! ’ ‘ Come, sirs! ’ Therefore, since at the time of the calling there is no joining to a verb,

original: idaṃ kārakavohāraṃ na labhati.
analyzed: idam kāraka vohāram na labhati
translated: this does not get the name of a case.

original: Vuttañca
analyzed: vuttam ca
translated: And it is said:🔽‘ The facing of one who has a visible form

original: “Saddenābhimukhīkāro, vijjamānassa vatthuno;
analyzed: saddena abhimukhīkāraḥ vijjamānassa vatthunaḥ
translated: By means of the sound is the calling;🔽When it is done there is no “ may be ”

original: Āmantanaṃ vidhātabbe, natthi ‘rājā bhave’tida”nti.
analyzed: āmantanam vidhātabbe na atthi rājā
translated: In the case of “ king ” and the rest ’ .

original: Bho purisa ehi, bho purisā vā, bhavanto purisā etha.
analyzed: bho purisa ehi bho purisāḥ vā bhavantaḥ purisāḥ etha
translated: ‘ Come, man! ’ ‘ Come, men! ’ ‘ Come, sirs! ’ ‘ Come, sirs! ’

original: Kasmiṃ atthe dutiyā?🔽284. Kammatthe dutiyā.
analyzed: kasmin atthe dutiyā  kammatthe dutiyā
translated: In what sense is the second case?🔽In the sense of action.

original: Kammatthe liṅgamhā dutiyāvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: kammatthe liṅgamhā dutiyā vibhatti hoti
translated: The second case is the case ending in the sense of action.

original: Anabhihite evāyaṃ, “kammani dutiyāyaṃ tto”ti vacanañcettha ñāpakaṃ.
analyzed: an abhihite eva ayam kammani vacanam ca ittha ñāpakam
translated: This is only when there is no prefix. The statement ‘ In the sense of action, the second case ending in the t-stem ’ is the reason here.

original: Kiṃ kammaṃ?
analyzed: kim kammam
translated: What is the action?

original: “Yena vā kayirate taṃ karaṇa”nti ito “vā”ti vattate.
analyzed: yena vā tam itas vāti vattate
translated: The word ‘ or ’ is stated from here ‘ by which it is done that is the instrument ’ .

original: 285. Yaṃ karoti taṃ kammaṃ.
analyzed: yam karoti tam kammam
translated: What one does is the action.

original: Yaṃ vā karoti, yaṃ vā vikaroti, yaṃ vā pāpuṇāti, taṃ kārakaṃ kammasaññaṃ hoti.
analyzed: yam vā karoti yam vā vikaroti yam vā pāpuṇāti tam kārakam kamma saññam hoti
translated: Or what one does, what one modifies, what one reaches, that is the agent, which has the name of the action.

original: Idha liṅgakālavacanamatantaṃ. Karīyatīti kammaṃ. Tattha kārakaṃ, sādhakaṃ kriyānipphattiyā
analyzed: idha karīyati iti kammam tattha kārakam sādhakam kriyā nipphattiyā
translated: Here the gender, the time, and the verbal termination are secondary. The word kammam is derived from the verb karīyati, to be done. Herein, the agent is the doer, the instrument is the means, the cause is the reason for the occurrence of the action.

original: kāraṇamuccate, taṃ pana kārakaṃ chabbidhaṃ kammaṃ kattā karaṇaṃ sampadānamapādānamokāso🔽cāti. Tattha sabhāvato, parikappato vā kammādimhi satiyeva kriyābhāvato kammādīnaṃ
analyzed: kāraṇam uccate tam pana kārakam chabbidham kammam kattā karaṇam sampadānam apādānam okāsaḥ  ca ati tattha sabhāvato parikappataḥ vā kamma ādimhi satiyā iva kriyā bhāvataḥ kamma ādīnam
translated: But that agent is of six kinds: the object, the instrument, the recipient, the source, the target, and the experiencer.

original: channampi kārakavohāro siddhova hoti.🔽Taṃ pana kammaṃ tividhaṃ nibbattanīyaṃ vikaraṇīyaṃ pāpaṇīyañcāti. Yathā – mātā puttaṃ🔽vijāyati, āhāro sukhaṃ janayati. Ghaṭaṃ karoti devadatto, kaṭṭhamaṅgāraṃ karoti,
analyzed: kāraka vohāro siddhaḥ uva hoti  tam pana kammam tividham nibbattanīyam vikaraṇīyam pāpaṇīyam ca ati yathā mātā puttam  vijāyati āhāraḥ sukham janayati ghaṭam karoti devadatto kaṭṭham aṅgāram karoti
translated: Herein, the verbal expression “agent” is established only when there is an action, whether in the sense of an entity or in the sense of a supposition.

original: suvaṇṇaṃ keyūraṃ, kaṭakaṃ vā karoti, vīhayo lunāti. Devadatto nivesanaṃ pavisati,🔽ādiccaṃ passati, dhammaṃ suṇāti, paṇḍite payirupāsati.
analyzed: suvaṇṇam keyūram kaṭakam vā karoti vīhayaḥ lunāti devadattaḥ nivesanam pavisati  ādiccam passati dhammam suṇāti paṇḍite payirupāsati
translated: But that action is of three kinds: that which is to be brought into existence, that which is to be transformed, and that which is to be produced. For example: a mother gives birth to a son; food produces pleasure; Devadatta makes a pot; he makes charcoal from wood; he makes a bracelet or an armlet from gold; he cuts grass; Devadatta enters the house; he sees the sun; he hears the Dhamma; he attends on the wise.

original: Vuttañca
analyzed: vuttam ca
translated: And it is said:🔽“It is held to be of three kinds,

original: “Nibbattivikatippatti-bhedena tividhaṃ mataṃ;
analyzed: tividham matam
translated: As that which is to be brought into existence, that which is to be transformed, and that which is to be produced.”

original: Kattu kriyābhigammaṃ taṃ, sukhaṅgāraṃ nivesana”nti.🔽Ettha ca icchitānicchitakathitākathitādibhedamanapekkhitvā sabbasaṅgāhakavasena “yaṃ
analyzed: tam  ettha ca icchita an icchita kathita a kathita ādi bhedam an apekkhitvā sabba saṅgāhaka vasena yam
translated: The act is the means of doing it, The axe is the implement for the wood.

original: karoti taṃ kamma”nti vuttattā, atthantaravikappanavādhikārato ca sabbattha imināva kammasaññā hoti.
analyzed: karoti tam kamman ti vutta ttā ca sabbattha iminā ava kamma saññā hoti
translated: And here, without regard to what is wished for or not wished for, or to what is mentioned or not mentioned, etc., it is said in the most comprehensive way, “What he does is kamma,” and so the perception of kamma is of all these in all instances, since it is a perception that is based on the assumption of a meaning other than the literal one.

original: Tattha anicchitakammaṃ yathā – kaṇṭakaṃ maddati, visaṃ gilati, gāmaṃ gacchanto rukkhamūlaṃ upagacchati.
analyzed: tattha anicchita kammam yathā kaṇṭakam maddati visam gilati gāmam gacchantaḥ rukkha mūlam upagacchati
translated: Herein, what is not wished for is such kamma as the following: he thrashes the pestle, he swallows poison, he goes to the village, he goes to the foot of the tree.

original: Akathitakammaṃ yathā – yaññadattaṃ kambalaṃ yācate brāhmaṇo. Ettha hi “kambala”miti
analyzed: a kathita kammam yathā yaññadattam kambalam yācate brāhmaṇaḥ ettha hi kambalam iti
translated: What is not mentioned is such kamma as the following: he asks for a blanket from Yaññadatta. Herein, “blanket” is mentioned,

original: kathitakammaṃ dvikammikāya yācanakriyāya pattumicchitatarattā. “Yaññadatta”miti appadhānattā🔽akathitakammaṃ. Tathā samiddhaṃ dhanaṃ bhikkhate, ajaṃ gāmaṃ nayati, parābhavantaṃ
analyzed: kathita kammam dvikammikāya yācana kriyāya pattum icchitatara ttā yañña dattam iti appadhāna ttā  a kathita kammam tathā samiddham dhanam bhikkhate ajam gāmam nayati parābhavantam
translated: but “kamma” is not mentioned, since the act of asking is wished for as a means to obtaining the blanket. But “Yaññadatta” is not emphasized,

original: purisaṃ, mayaṃ pucchāma gotamaṃ, bhagavā bhikkhū etadavoca iccādi.
analyzed: purisam mayam pucchāma gotamam bhagavā bhikkhū etat avoca iccādi
translated: since it is not wished for as a means to obtaining the blanket. So too: he begs for wealth that is well stored, he leads the goat to the village, he leads the defeated man, we ask Gotama, the Blessed One said to the bhikkhus.

original: Abhihitakamme pana na hoti, yathā – kaṭo karīyate devadattena, sugatena desito dhammo, yaññadatto kambalaṃ yācīyate brāhmaṇena iccādi.
analyzed: abhihita kamme pana na hoti yathā kaṭaḥ karīyate devadattena sugatena desitaḥ dhammaḥ yaññadatto kambalam yācīyate brāhmaṇena iccādi
translated: But it is not so in the case of the expressed object, as in the following: “A cart is being made by Devadatta”, “The Dhamma taught by the Sugata”, “A blanket is being asked for by Yajñadatta from the brahmin”.

original: “Dutiyā”ti adhikāro.
analyzed: adhikāro
translated: “The second” is the topic.

original: 286. Gati buddhi bhuja paṭha hara kara sayādīnaṃ kārite vā.
analyzed: gati buddhi bhuja paṭha hara kara kārite vā
translated: In the case of the roots gati, buddhi, bhuja, paṭha, hara, kara, say, etc.,🔽the second case-ending is used optionally after the verb when the object is expressed,

original: Gamu sappa gatimhi, budha bodhane, budha avagamane vā, bhuja pālanabyavaharaṇesu,🔽paṭha byattiyaṃ vācāyaṃ, hara haraṇe, kara karaṇe, si saye iccevamādīnaṃ dhātūnaṃ
analyzed: gamu sappa gatimhi budha bodhane budha avagamane vā bhuja pālana byavaharaṇesu  paṭha vācāyam hara haraṇe kara karaṇe si iti ca evamādīnam dhātūnam
translated: as in the following: gamu in the sense of “going”, budha in the sense of “understanding”, budha in the sense of “awakening”, bhuja in the sense of “protecting” or “handling”,🔽paṭha in the sense of “reciting”, hara in the sense of “taking away”, kara in the sense of “doing”, si in the sense of “lying down”, etc.

original: payoge kārite sati payojjakakattubhūte kammani liṅgamhā dutiyāvibhatti hoti vā. Niccasampatte
analyzed: payoge kārite sati payojjaka kattu bhūte kammani liṅgamhā dutiyā vibhatti hoti vā nicca sampatte
translated: The second case-ending is used after the verb when the object is expressed,

original: vikappatthoyaṃ, tena tassa pakkhe tatiyā hoti.
analyzed: vikappa atthaḥ iyam tena tassa pakkhe tatiyā hoti
translated: but the third case-ending is used in the case of the option of the locative.

original: Yo koci puriso gāmaṃ gacchati, tamañño payojayati. Puriso purisaṃ gāmaṃ gamayati,
analyzed: yaḥ koci purisaḥ gāmam gacchati tam aññaḥ payojayati purisaḥ purisam gāmam gamayati
translated: “Any man who goes to the village, another employs him. A man makes a man go to the village,

original: purisena vā gāmaṃ gamayati. Evaṃ sissaṃ dhammaṃ bodheti ācariyo, mātā puttaṃ bhojanaṃ
analyzed: purisena vā gāmam gamayati evam sissam dhammam bodheti ācariyaḥ mātā puttam bhojanam
translated: or he makes a man go to the village. In the same way, a teacher awakens a pupil to the Dhamma, a mother gives food to her child,

original: bhojayati, sissaṃ dhammaṃ pāṭheti ācariyo, puriso purisaṃ bhāraṃ hāreti, tathā puriso
analyzed: bhojayati sissam dhammam pāṭheti ācariyaḥ puriso purisam bhāram hāreti tathā puriso
translated: a teacher teaches the Dhamma to a pupil, a man carries a load for another man, a man

original: purisaṃ kammaṃ kārayati, purisena vā kammaṃ kārāpayati, puriso purisaṃ sayāpayati.
analyzed: purisam kammam kārayati purisena vā kammam kārāpayati puriso purisam sayāpayati
translated: He causes to be fed. The teacher recites the Dhamma to the pupil. A man carries a load for a man. So too a man causes a man to do work, or he causes work to be done by a man, or a man causes a man to lie down.

original: Evaṃ sabbattha kārite kattukammani dutiyā.
analyzed: evam sabbattha kārite kattu kammani dutiyā
translated: Thus in all these cases the second case is used when the action is done.

original: Kāriteti kiṃ? Puriso gāmaṃ gacchati.
analyzed: kāritā iti kim purisaḥ gāmam gacchati
translated: What is the meaning of “done”? A man goes to the village.

original: Abhihite na bhavati, purisena puriso gāmaṃ gamīyate, sisso dhammaṃ bodhīyate iccādi.🔽287. Kāladdhānamaccantasaṃyoge.
analyzed: abhihite na bhavati purisena purisaḥ gāmam gamīyate sissaḥ dhammam bodhīyate iccādi  kāla d dhāna mac canta saṃyoge
translated: When the action is not done, the second case is not used: A man is caused to go to the village by a man. The pupil is caused to recite the Dhamma.🔽. The second case is used with words for time, place, and measure when there is uninterrupted connection.

original: Accantaṃ nirantaraṃ saṃyogoaccantasaṃyogo. Kāladdhānaṃ dabbaguṇakriyāhi accantasaṃyoge tehi kāladdhānavācīhi liṅgehi dutiyāvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: nirantaram saṃyogaḥ accanta saṃyogaḥ kāladdhānam dabba guṇa kriyāhi accanta saṃyoge tehi kāladdhāna vācīhi liṅgehi dutiyā vibhatti hoti
translated: Uninterrupted connection is connection without interval. The second case is used with words for time, place, and measure when there is uninterrupted connection with them.

original: Kāle tāva – sattāhaṃ gavapānaṃ, māsaṃ maṃsodanaṃ, saradaṃ ramaṇīyā nadī, sabbakālaṃ ramaṇīyaṃ nandanaṃ, māsaṃ sajjhāyati, tayo māse abhidhammaṃ desesi.
analyzed: kāle tāva sattāham gavapānam māsam maṃsodanam saradam ramaṇīyā nadī sabbakālam ramaṇīyam nandanam māsam sajjhāyati tayaḥ māse abhidhammam desesi
translated: First, as to time: He drinks milk for a week. He eats meat for a month. The river is delightful in autumn. The Nandana Grove is delightful at all times. He recites for a month. He taught the Abhidhamma for three months.

original: Addhāne – yojanaṃ vanarāji, yojanaṃ dīgho pabbato, kosaṃ sajjhāyati.
analyzed: addhāne yojanam vana rāji yojanam dīghaḥ pabbataḥ kosam sajjhāyati
translated: In the case of addhā, a yojana is a vanarājī, a yojana is the length of a mountain, he recites the Kosa.

original: Accantasaṃyogeti kiṃ? Māse māse bhuñjati, yojane yojane vihāraṃ patiṭṭhāpesi.
analyzed: acc anta saṃyoga iti kim māse māse bhuñjati yojane yojane vihāram patiṭṭhāpesi
translated: What is meant by accanta-saṃyoge? He eats every month, he had a monastery built every yojana.

original: 288. Kammappavacanīyayutte.
analyzed: kamma ppavacanīya yutte
translated: In the case of kammappavacanīyayutte.

original: Kammappavacanīyehi nipātopasaggehi yutte yoge sati liṅgamhā dutiyāvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: kammappavacanīyehi nipāta upasaggehi yutte yoge sati liṅgamhā dutiyā vibhatti hoti
translated: When there is a connection with kammappavacanīya nipāta and upasagga, the second case comes after the noun.

original: Kammaṃ pavacanīyaṃ yesaṃ te kammappavacanīyā, parasamaññāvasena vā anvādayo kammappavacanīyā.
analyzed: kammam pavacanīyam yesam te kamma ppavacanīyā para samaññā vasena vā anu ādayaḥ kamma ppavacanīyā
translated: Those that have kammappavacanīya are kammappavacanīyā. Or, by way of the designation of another, the anvādeya is kammappavacanīya.

original: Tattha anusaddassa lakkhaṇe, sahatthe, hīne ca kammappavacanīyasaññā vuttā. Yathā
analyzed: tattha anu saddassa lakkhaṇe sahatthe hīne ca kammappavacanīya saññā vuttā yathā
translated: Therein, the characteristic of anusaddā, in the case of sahattha, and in the case of hīna, the designation of kammappavacanīya is stated. As follows:

original: – pabbajitamanu pabbajiṃsu, nadimanvavasitā bārāṇasī, nadiyā saha avabaddhāti attho,
analyzed: pabbajitam anu pabbajiṃsu nadim anvavasitā bārāṇasī nadiyā saha avabaddhā iti attho
translated: After the one who went forth, they went forth, Bārāṇasī is dependent on the river, the meaning is: it is connected with the river,

original: anu sāriputtaṃ paññavā.
analyzed: anu sāriputtam paññavā
translated: after Sāriputta, the wise one.

original: Lakkhaṇādīsu “lakkhaṇi’tthambhūtakkhānabhāga vicchāsu pati pari anavo”ti pati pari anūnaṃ kammappavacanīyasaññā vuttā.
analyzed: lakkhaṇa ādīsu pati pari anavaḥ ti pati pari anūnam kammappavacanīya saññā vuttā
translated: In the case of lakkhaṇa, etc., the designation of kammappavacanīya is stated as follows: “Lakkhaṇi, ittham, bhūta, akkhāna, bhāga, vicchā, pati, pari, anu, nawo.”

original: Lakkhaṇe sūriyuggamanaṃ pati dibbā bhakkhā pātubhaveyyuṃ, rukkhaṃ pati vijjotate cando, rukkhaṃ pari, rukkhaṃ anu.
analyzed: lakkhaṇe sūri yuggamanam pati dibbāḥ bhakkhāḥ pātubhaveyyum rukkham pati vijjotate candaḥ rukkham pari rukkham anu
translated: In the case of the characteristic, the word pati is used in the sense of “at the time of the rising of the sun divine food becomes manifest,” “the moon shines at the tree,” “the moon shines around the tree,” “the moon shines along the tree.”

original: Itthambhūtakkhāne sādhu devadatto mātaraṃ pati, mātaraṃ pari, mātaraṃ anu.
analyzed: sādhu devadattaḥ mātaram pati mātaram pari mātaram anu
translated: In the case of the state, the word pati is used in the sense of “it is good if Devadatta goes to his mother,” “he goes around his mother,” “he goes along his mother.”

original: Bhāge yadettha maṃ pati siyā, maṃ pari, maṃ anu, taṃ dīyatu.
analyzed: bhāge yadā itthā mam pati siyāḥ mam pari mam anu tam dīyatu
translated: In the case of the portion, the word pati is used in the sense of “if it is mine here, give it to me,” “give it around me,” “give it along me.”

original: Vicchāyoge atthamatthaṃ pati saddo nivisati, rukkhaṃ rukkhaṃ pati vijjotate cando, rukkhaṃ rukkhaṃ pari, rukkhaṃ rukkhaṃ anu.
analyzed: vicchā yoge attham attham pati saddaḥ nivisati rukkham rukkham pati vijjotate cando rukkham rukkham pari rukkham rukkham anu
translated: In the case of the alternative, the word pati is used in the sense of “at the time of the good and the bad the sound is fixed,” “the moon shines at the tree,” “the moon shines around the tree,” “the moon shines along the tree.”

original: “Abhirabhāge”ti abhissa bhāgavajjitesu lakkhaṇādīsu kammappavacanīyasaññā vuttā. Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato, sādhu devadatto mātaraṃ abhi.
analyzed: abhissa bhāga vajjitesu lakkhaṇa ādīsu kammappavacanīya saññā vuttā tam kho pana bhavantam gotamam evam kalyāṇaḥ kitti saddaḥ abbhuggataḥ sādhu devadattaḥ mātaram abhi
translated: In the case of the portion, the word abhi is used in the sense of “at the time of the characteristic and so on,” which are to be taken as objects of the verb. The good report of the Blessed One has spread thus: “It is good if Devadatta goes to his mother.”

original: Nipāte dhi brāhmaṇassa hantāra miccevamādi.
analyzed: nipāte dhi brāhmaṇassa hantāram iti evamādi
translated: In the case of the prefix, the word dhi is used in the sense of “the killer of the brahmin,” and so on.

original: 289. Kvaci dutiyā chaṭṭhīnamatthe.
analyzed: kvaci dutiyā chaṭṭhī nama tthe
translated: In some instances the second and sixth cases are used in the sense of the accusative.

original: Chaṭṭhīnaṃ atthe kvaci dutiyāvibhatti hoti. Antarāabhito parito pati paṭibhātiyoge
analyzed: chaṭṭhīnam atthe kvaci dutiyā vibhatti hoti antarā abhitas paritas pati paṭibhā ati yoge
translated: This is the case with antarā, abhito, parito, pati, and paṭibhāti.

original: ayaṃ. Antarā ca rājagahaṃ antarā ca nāḷandaṃ addhānamaggappaṭipanno, rājagahassa🔽ca nāḷandāya ca majjheti attho. Abhito gāmaṃ vasati, parito gāmaṃ vasati, nadiṃ nerañjaraṃ
analyzed: ayam antarā ca rājagaham antarā ca nāḷandam addhāna magga paṭipannaḥ rājagahassa  ca nāḷandāya ca majjhe iti attho abhitas gāmam vasati paritas gāmam vasati nadim nerañjaram
translated: The meaning is: “He is travelling on the main road between Rājagaha and Nāḷandā, between Rājagaha and Nāḷandā.”🔽The meaning is: “He lives near the village, he lives around the village, he lives on the bank of the river.”

original: pati, nerañjarāya nadiyā samīpeti attho. Paṭibhantu taṃ cunda bojjhaṅgā, upamā maṃ🔽paṭibhāti, upamā mayhaṃ upaṭṭhahatīti attho.
analyzed: nerañjarāya nadiyā samīpā iti attho paṭibhantu tam cunda bojjhaṅgāḥ upamā mama  paṭibhāti upamā mayham upaṭṭhahati iti attho
translated: The meaning is: “May the factors of awakening be clear to you, Cunda, a simile occurs to me, a simile presents itself to me.”

original: “Kvaci dutiyā, atthe”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: kvaci dutiyā attha iti ca vattate
translated: “In the sense of the sixth, the second case is sometimes.”

original: 290. Tatiyāsattamīnañca.
analyzed: tatiyā sattamī nañ ca
translated: . And in the sense of the third and seventh.

original: Tatiyāsattamīnamatthe ca kvaci liṅgamhā dutiyāvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: tatiyā sattamī nama tthe ca kvaci liṅgamhā dutiyā vibhatti hoti
translated: In the sense of the third and seventh, the second case is sometimes after a feminine noun.

original: Tatiyatthe sace maṃ nālapissati, tvañca maṃ nābhibhāsasi, vinā saddhammaṃ kuto sukhaṃ, upāyamantarena na atthasiddhi.
analyzed: tatiya tthe sace mama na ālapissati tvam ca mama na abhibhāsasi vinā saddhammam kuto sukham upāyam antarena na attha siddhi
translated: In the sense of the third: “If he will not speak to me, and you will not address me, how can there be happiness without the true Dhamma? There is no success without a means.”🔽. In the sense of the seventh: “The Dhamma is the best, the Dhamma is the most excellent, the Dhamma is the highest of all things.”

original: Sattamiyatthe – kāle, upānvajjhāvasassa payoge, adhisiṭṭhāvasānaṃ payoge, tappānacāre ca dutiyā.🔽Kāle tāva – pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā, ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā. Imaṃ rattiṃ cattāro mahārājāno.🔽Upādipubbassa vasadhātussa payoge – gāmaṃ upavasati, gāmaṃ anuvasati, vihāraṃ adhivasati,🔽gāmaṃ āvasati, agāraṃ ajjhāvasati. Tathā pathaviṃ adhisessati, gāmaṃ adhitiṭṭhati, gāmaṃ ajjhāvasati.
analyzed: sattamiya tthe kāle payoge adhisiṭṭha avasānam payoge tad pāna cāre ca dutiyā  kāle tāva pubbaṇhasamayam nivāsetvā ekam samayam bhagavā imam rattim cattāraḥ mahā rājānaḥ  upa ādi pubbassa vasa dhātussa payoge gāmam upavasati gāmam anuvasati vihāram adhivasati  gāmam āvasati agāram ajjhāvasati tathā pathavim adhisessati gāmam adhitiṭṭhati gāmam ajjhāvasati
translated: In the seventh case: at the time, in the vicinity, in the vicinity of the place where he is living, in the vicinity of the place where he is staying, in the vicinity of the place where he is lying down, in the vicinity of the place where he is sitting, in the vicinity of the place where he is reclining, in the vicinity of the place where he is standing, in the vicinity of the place where he is walking, in the vicinity of the place where he is lying on his side, in the vicinity of the place where he is lying on his belly, in the vicinity of the place where he is lying on his back, in the vicinity of the place where he is lying on his left side, in the vicinity of the place where he is lying on his right side, in the vicinity of the place where he is lying on his buttocks,
