on his neck, in the vicinity of the place where he is lying on his shoulders

original: Tappānacāresu – nadiṃ pivati, gāmaṃ carati iccādi.🔽Kasmiṃ atthe tatiyā?🔽291. Karaṇe tatiyā.🔽Karaṇakārake tatiyāvibhatti hoti.🔽Kiṃ karaṇaṃ?🔽292. Yena vā kayirate taṃ karaṇaṃ.🔽Yena vā kattā upakaraṇabhūtena vatthunā kriyaṃ abyavadhānena karoti, yena vā vikaroti, yena vā pāpuṇāti, taṃ kārakaṃ karaṇasaññaṃ hoti.
analyzed: tad pāna cāresu nadim pivati gāmam carati iccādi 🔽kasmin atthe tatiyā 🔽karaṇe tatiyā 🔽karaṇa kārake tatiyā vibhatti hoti 🔽kim karaṇam 🔽yena vā tam karaṇam 🔽yena vā kattā upakaraṇa bhūtena vatthunā kriyam a byavadhānena karoti yena vā vikaroti yena vā pāpuṇāti tam kārakam karaṇa saññam hoti
translated: In the seventh case: at the time, in the use of the prefix upa- in the sense of ‘to approach’, in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to occupy’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi- in the sense of ‘to be intent upon’, and in the use of the prefix adhi

original: Karīyate anenāti karaṇaṃ, ettha ca satipi sabbakārakānaṃ kriyāsādhakatte “yena vā kayirate”ti visesetvā vacanaṃ kattūpakaraṇabhūtesu kārakesu sādhakatamasseva gahaṇatthaṃ.🔽Vuttañca
analyzed: anena ati karaṇam ettha ca sati pi sabba kārakānam kriyā sādhaka tte yena vā visesetvā vacanam kattu upakaraṇa bhūtesu kārakesu sādhakatamassa iva gahaṇa attham  vuttam ca
translated: And it is said:🔽“That which is considered

original: “Yassa sabbavisesena, kriyāsaṃsiddhihetutā;
analyzed: yassa sabba visesena kriyā saṃsiddhi hetu tā
translated: The means of accomplishing the action in all its aspects,🔽That is called the instrument,

original: Sambhāvīyati taṃ vuttaṃ, karaṇaṃ nāma kāraka”nti.
analyzed: sambhāvīyati tam vuttam karaṇam nāma kārakan ti
translated: A factor of action.”

original: Taṃ pana duvidhaṃ ajjhattika bāhiravasena.
analyzed: tam pana duvidham ajjhattika bāhira vasena
translated: And that is twofold as internal and external.

original: Yathā – hatthena kammaṃ karoti, cakkhunā rūpaṃ passati, manasā dhammaṃ viññāya. Dattena vīhayo lunāti, agginā kuṭiṃ jhāpeti.
analyzed: yathā hatthena kammam karoti cakkhunā rūpam passati manasā dhammam viññāya dattena vīhayaḥ lunāti agginā kuṭim jhāpeti
translated: For example: “He does the work with his hand,” “He sees visible objects with his eye,” “He discerns mental objects with his mind,” “He cuts down the forest with an axe,” “He burns the hut with fire.”🔽The third case

original: “Tatiyā”ti adhikāro.🔽293. Kattari ca.🔽Kattari ca kārake liṅgamhā tatiyāvibhatti hoti. Caggahaṇena itthambhūtalakkhaṇe,🔽kriyāpavagge, pubbasadisasamūnattha kalaha nipuṇa missaka sakhilatthādiyoge, kāladdhānesu,
analyzed: adhikāraḥ  kattari ca  kattari ca kārake liṅgamhā tatiyā vibhatti hoti ca ggahaṇena ittham bhūta lakkhaṇe  kriyā pavagge pubba sadisa samūnattha kalaha nipuṇa missaka sa khilattha ādi yoge kāla ddhānesu
translated: And in the doer.🔽The third case is also used in the doer as a factor of action. And by the word “also” the following are included:

original: paccattakammatthapañcamiyatthādīsu ca tatiyā.
analyzed: paccatta kamma ttha pañcamiya ttha ādīsu ca tatiyā
translated: in the sense of the state of being such, in the sense of the characteristic, in the sense of the class, in the sense of the collection, in the sense of the similar, in the sense of the past, in the sense of the future, in the sense of the present, in the sense of the near, in the sense of the far, in the sense of the long, in the sense of the short, in the sense of the small, in the sense of the great, in the sense of the few, in the sense of the many, in the sense of the quarrel, in the sense of the skilled, in the sense of the mixed, in the sense of the easy, in the sense of the difficult, in the sense of the time, in the sense of the portion, in the sense of the fifth, etc., in the sense of the individual action, etc., in the sense of the third.

original: Ko ca kattā?
analyzed: kaḥ ca kattā
translated: And who is the doer?

original: 294. Yo karoti sa kattā.
analyzed: yaḥ karoti sa kattā
translated: He who does is the doer.

original: Yo kriyaṃ attappadhāno hutvā karoti, so kattusañño hoti.🔽So tividho suddhakattā hetukattā kammakattāti. Tattha yo sayameva kriyaṃ karoti,
analyzed: yaḥ kriyam attappadhānaḥ hutvā karoti saḥ kattu saññaḥ hoti  saḥ tividhaḥ suddha kattā hetu kattā kamma kattā ati tattha yaḥ sayam eva kriyam karoti
translated: He who does an action, making himself the subject of the action, is called the doer.

original: so suddhakattā. Yo aññaṃ kātuṃ samatthaṃ akarontaṃ kammaṃ niyojeti, so hetukattā,
analyzed: saḥ suddha kattā yaḥ aññam kātum samattham a karontam kammam niyojeti saḥ hetukattā
translated: He is of three kinds as pure doer, instigator, and agent. Herein, he who does the action himself is the pure doer. He who, though able to do it himself, makes another do it is the instigator,

original: yathā – gantuṃ samattho devadatto, tamañño payojeti “gamayati devadatta”nti.
analyzed: yathā gantum samatthaḥ devadattaḥ tam aññaḥ gamayati devadatta nti
translated: like Devadatta, who, though able to go himself, makes someone else go, saying, “Devadatta makes go.”

original: Yaṃ pana tattha tattha gacchati devadatto, tamañño payojayati “gamayati devadatta”nti
analyzed: yam pana tattha tattha gacchati devadatto tam aññaḥ payojayati gamayati devadatta nti
translated: But he who makes Devadatta go here and there is the agent.

original: hetvatthanidassanaṃ, tampi sāmatthiyadassanavasena vuttanti gahetabbaṃ. Aññathā yadi
analyzed: hetvattha nidassanam tam pi sāmatthiya dassana vasena vuttan ti gahetabbam aññathā yadi
translated: The example is given to show the instigator, but it should be taken as said with reference to the visible fact of instigation. Otherwise,

original: sayameva gacchati, kiṃ tattha payojakabyāpārena akarontaṃ balena kārayati, pāsāṇaṃ
analyzed: sayam eva gacchati kim tattha payojaka byāpārena a karontam balena kārayati pāsāṇam
translated: if Devadatta goes himself, what instigation is there? He makes the other do it by force, though he is unwilling.

original: uṭṭhāpayatītiādikañca na sijjheyya.
analyzed: uṭṭhāpayati iti ādikam ca na sijjheyya
translated: “He makes the stone rise up,” etc., would not be established.

original: Ettha pana
analyzed: ettha pana
translated: But here

original: “Kattā”ti vattate.
analyzed: kattā ati vattate
translated: “Doer” is said.

original: 293. Yo kāreti sa hetu.
analyzed: yaḥ kāra iti sa hetu
translated: He who causes is the instigator.

original: Yo kattāraṃ kāreti, so hetusañño hoti, kattā cāti hetukattusaññā.
analyzed: yaḥ kattāram kāreti saḥ hetu saññaḥ hoti kattā ca ati hetu kattu saññā
translated: One who makes another do it is one who has a cause, and he is also a doer, thus he is one who has a cause and is a doer.

original: Yo pana parassa kriyaṃ paṭicca kammabhūtopi sukarattā sayameva sijjhanto viya hoti, so kammakattā nāma, yathā – sayaṃ karīyate kaṭo, sayameva paccate odanoti.
analyzed: yaḥ pana parassa kriyam paṭicca kamma bhūtaḥ api sukarattā sayam eva sijjhantaḥ viya hoti saḥ kamma kattā nāma yathā sayam karīyate kaṭaḥ sayam eva paccate odanaḥ ti
translated: But one who, although he is a doer, is as if himself successful through the ease of getting another to do it, is called one who is a doer of a deed. For example: “A cart is made by itself,” “Rice is cooked by itself.”

original: Vuttañca
analyzed: vuttam ca
translated: And it is said:🔽“The doer who produces a deed

original: “Attappadhāno kiriyaṃ, yo nibbatteti kārako;🔽Appayutto payutto vā, sa kattāti pavuccati.🔽Hetukattāti kathito,
analyzed: atta ppadhānaḥ kiriyam yaḥ nibbatteti kārakaḥ  appayuttaḥ payuttaḥ vā sa kattā ati pavuccati  kathitaḥ
translated: With self-exertion is called🔽One who has a cause and is a doer.

original: Kattuno yo payojako;
analyzed: kattunaḥ yaḥ payojakaḥ
translated: One who is a doer of a deed

original: Kammakattāti sukaro,
analyzed: kamma kattā ati sukaraḥ
translated: Is called a doer of a deed🔽Through the ease of getting another to do it,

original: Kammabhūto kathīyate”ti.
analyzed: kamma bhūtaḥ kathīyate iti
translated: Though he is a doer.”

original: Nanu ca “saṃyogo jāyate”tiādīsu kathaṃ pure asato jananakriyāya kattubhāvosiyāti?🔽Vuccate – lokasaṅketasiddho hi saddappayogo, avijjamānampi hi loko saddābhidheyyatāya
analyzed: nanu ca saṃyogaḥ jāyata iti ādīsu katham pure asataḥ janana kriyāya  vuccate loka saṅketa siddhaḥ hi sadda ppayogaḥ a vijjamānam pi hi lokaḥ sadda abhidheyya tāya
translated: But how can there be the state of a doer in the producing of a non-existent action in such passages as “A conjunction is born”?🔽It may be said: the use of words is established by social usage. For although something does not exist, still the world, taking it as if it existed as a name-able thing,

original: vijjamānaṃ viya gahetvā voharati, vikappabuddhigahitākāroyeva hi saddenābhidhīyate,
analyzed: vijjamānam viya gahetvā voharati vikappa buddhi gahita ākārā iva hi saddena abhidhīyate
translated: uses the expression. For only the aspect apprehended by the discriminating thought is what is named by the word.

original: na tu vatthusabhāvo, aññathā sutamayañāṇenapi paccakkhena viya vatthusabhāvasacchikaraṇappasaṅgo
analyzed: na tu vatthu sabhāvaḥ aññathā suta maya ñāṇena api paccakkhena viya vatthu sabhāva sacchikaraṇa ppasaṅgo
translated: but not the individual essence of the object. Otherwise, it would follow that the knowledge consisting in what is learnt would also make the individual essence of the object evident as if it were in the actual here-and-now.🔽And it would follow that lying, slander, and so on would be impossible.

original: ca musāvāda kudiṭṭhivādādīnamabhāvappasaṅgo ca siyā, tasmā buddhiparikappitapaññattivasenapi
analyzed: ca musāvāda kudiṭṭhi vāda ādīnam abhāva ppasaṅgo ca siyā tasmā buddhi parikappita paññatti vasena api
translated: So the occurrence of the sound is by means of a description that is a mental construction.

original: saddappavatti hotīti asato saṃyogādissapi hoteva jananakriyāya kattukārakatāti.
analyzed: sadda ppavatti hoti iti asataḥ hotā iva janana kriyāya kattu kāraka tā ati
translated: And so it is the sound that is the maker of the act of generation in the case of the non-existent conjunction and so on.

original: Yathāha
analyzed: yathā āha
translated: As it is said:🔽“The sound has for its domain of operation

original: “Vohāravisayo saddo, nekantaparamatthiko;🔽Buddhisaṅkappito attho, tassatthoti pavuccati.
analyzed: vohāra visayaḥ saddo nekanta paramatthiko  buddhi saṅkappito attho tassa attho ti pavuccati
translated: The conventional, not the absolute meaning.🔽The meaning is said to be its sense🔽Because it is apprehended by the understanding.

original: Buddhiyā gahitattā hi, saṃyogo jāyate iti;
analyzed: hi saṃyogaḥ jāyate iti
translated: And so the conjunction is produced.🔽The conjunction, though existent,

original: Saṃyogo vijjamānova, kattā bhavati jātiyā”ti.
analyzed: saṃyogaḥ vijjamānaḥ iva kattā bhavati jātiyā ati
translated: Is the maker by its generation.”

original: Tatra tatiyā jinena desito dhammo, buddhena jito māro, ahinā daṭṭho naro, buddhena bodhito loko, saddhehi kārito vihāro.
analyzed: tatra tatiyā jinena desitaḥ dhammaḥ buddhena jitaḥ māraḥ ahinā daṭṭhaḥ naraḥ buddhena bodhitaḥ loko saddhehi kāritaḥ vihāro
translated: Herein, the third is the Dhamma taught by the Victor; the demon Māra was conquered by the Buddha; a man bitten by a snake; the world was awakened by the Buddha; the monastery was built by those who had faith.

original: Abhihite na bhavati. Kaṭaṃ karoti devadatto, kāreti vā.
analyzed: abhihite na bhavati kaṭam karoti devadattaḥ kāra iti vā
translated: In the fourth case, the meaning is not present: “He makes a bowl,” “Devadatta makes,” “he causes to make.”

original: Itthambhūtassa lakkhaṇe – sā bhinnena sīsena paggharantena lohitena paṭivissakānaṃ
analyzed: itthambhūtassa lakkhaṇe sā bhinnena sīsena paggharantena lohitena paṭivissakānam
translated: In the section on the characteristic: She made the opponents boil with the blood flowing from her broken head.

original: ujjhāpesi, ūnapañcabandhanena pattena aññaṃ navaṃ pattaṃ cetāpeyya, tidaṇḍakena paribbājakamaddakkhi.
analyzed: ujjhāpesi ūna pañca bandhanena pattena aññam navam pattam cetāpeyya ti daṇḍakena paribbājakam addakkhi
translated: He should exchange his bowl for another if it has five mends or less. He should go forth with a staff of three sticks.

original: Apavagge – ekāheneva bārāṇasiṃ pāyāsi, navahi māsehi vihāraṃ niṭṭhāpesi, yojanena adhītaṃ byākaraṇaṃ, kriyāpavaggoti kriyāya āsuṃ pariniṭṭhāpanaṃ.
analyzed: apavagge eka ahena iva bārāṇasim pāyāsi navahi māsehi vihāram niṭṭhāpesi yojanena adhītam byākaraṇam kriyāpavaggo ti kriyāya āsum pariniṭṭhāpanam
translated: In the section on the verb: He went to Bārāṇasī in one day. In nine months he completed the monastery. He had studied grammar for a yojana. The completion of the action is called the section on the verb.

original: Pubbādiyoge – māsena pubbo, pitarā sadiso, mātarā samo, kahāpaṇena ūno, dhanena vikalo,
analyzed: pubba ādi yoge māsena pubbaḥ pitarā sadisaḥ mātarā samaḥ kahāpaṇena ūnaḥ dhanena vikalaḥ
translated: In the section on the past tense, etc.: He was a leper for a month. He was like his father. He was equal to his mother. He was less than a kahāpanas. He was deficient in wealth.

original: asinā kalaho, ācārena nipuṇo, vācāya nipuṇo, guḷena missakaṃ, tilena missakaṃ, vācāya
analyzed: asinā kalahaḥ ācārena nipuṇaḥ vācāya nipuṇaḥ guḷena missakam tilena missakam vācāya
translated: There was a quarrel with the sword. He was skilled in conduct. He was skilled in speech. He mixed with sugar. He mixed with sesame. He was

original: sakhilo, maṇinā attho, dhanena attho, pitarā tulyo.
analyzed: sakhilaḥ maṇinā atthaḥ dhanena atthaḥ pitarā tulyaḥ
translated: friendly in speech. He needed a jewel. He needed wealth. He was equal to his father.

original: Kāladdhānesu – māsena bhuñjati, yojanena gacchati.
analyzed: kāladdhānesu māsena bhuñjati yojanena gacchati
translated: In the section on time: He eats for a month. He goes for a yojana.

original: Paccatte – attanāva attānaṃ sammannati.
analyzed: paccatte attanāva attānam sammannati
translated: In the section on the reflexive: He appoints himself.

original: Kammatthe – tilehi khette vapati.
analyzed: kammatthe tilehi khette vapati
translated: In the section on the object: He sows seeds in the field with sesame.

original: Pañcamiyatthe – sumuttā mayaṃ tena mahāsamaṇena.
analyzed: sumuttā mayam tena mahā samaṇena
translated: In the fifth case: We are well freed from that great recluse.

original: 296. Sahādiyoge ca.
analyzed: saha ādi yoge ca
translated: In the compound saha, etc.

original: Saha saddhiṃ samaṃ nānā vinā alaṃ kimiccevamādīhi yoge liṅgamhā tatiyāvibhatti hoti, casaddena sahatthepi.🔽Tattha sahasaddena yogo kriyā guṇa dabba samavāye sambhavati. Yathā – vitakkena saha
analyzed: saha saddhim samam nānā vinā alam kim icca evamādīhi yoge tatiyā vibhatti hoti ca saddena saha atthe pi  tattha saha saddena yogaḥ kriyā guṇa dabba samavāye sambhavati yathā vitakkena saha
translated: The instrumental case is used in compounds with saha, saddhiṃ, samaṃ, nānā, vinā, alaṃ, etc., and also with the particle ca.

original: vattati, puttena saha thūlo, antevāsikasaddhivihārikehi saha ācariyupajjhāyānaṃ lābho,
analyzed: vattati puttena saha thūlaḥ antevāsika saddhivihārikehi saha ācariya upajjhāyānam lābhaḥ
translated: Herein, the compound saha is used in the sense of “together with” in the sense of action, quality, and substance. For example: He exists together with applied thought. He is stout together with his son. The gain of teachers and preceptors is together with pupils and co-residents.

original: nisīdi bhagavā saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena, sahassena samaṃ mitā, sabbehi me piyehi manāpehi
analyzed: nisīdi bhagavā saddhim bhikkhu saṅghena sahassena samam mitā sabbehi me piyehi manāpehi
translated: The Blessed One sat down together with the Community of Bhikkhus. It is measured together with a thousand.

original: nānābhāvo vinābhāvo, saṅgho vināpi gaggena uposathaṃ kareyya, alaṃ te idha vāsena,
analyzed: nānābhāvaḥ vinābhāvaḥ saṅghaḥ vinā api gaggena uposatham kareyya alam te vāsena
translated: All that is dear and beloved to me is subject to change. The Community can perform the Uposatha ceremony without Gagga. You have enough of living here.

original: kiṃ me ekena tiṇṇena, purisena thāmadassinā, kiṃ te jaṭāhi dummedha, kiṃ te ajinasāṭiyā.
analyzed: kim me ekena tiṇṇena purisena thāma dassinā kim te jaṭāhi dummedha kim te ajina sāṭiyā
translated: What is the use of one man, a mere man, who has crossed over? What is the use of matted hair to you, fool? What is the use of a garment of antelope hide?

original: Sahatthe – devadatto rājagahaṃ pāvisi kokālikena pacchāsamaṇena, dukkho bālehi saṃvāso.
analyzed: sahatthe devadattaḥ rājagaham pāvisi kokālikena pacchā samaṇena dukkhaḥ bālehi saṃvāso
translated: Together with the hand: Devadatta entered Rājagaha with Kokālika as his attendant monk. It is painful to live with fools.

original: 297. Hetvatthe ca.
analyzed: hetu atthe ca
translated: And in the sense of cause.

original: Yogaggahaṇamihānuvattate, hetvatthe, hetvatthappayoge ca liṅgamhā tatiyāvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: yoga ggahaṇam iha anuvattate hetu atthe hetu attha ppayoge ca liṅgamhā tatiyā vibhatti hoti
translated: The instrumental case is used in the sense of cause and in the expression of cause.

original: Kismiñci phale diṭṭhasāmatthiyaṃ kāraṇaṃ hetu, soyeva attho, tasmiṃ hetvatthe, annena vasati, dhammena vasati, vijjāya vasati.
analyzed: kismiñci phale diṭṭha sāmatthiyam kāraṇam hetu saḥ yā iva atthaḥ tasmin hetu atthe annena vasati dhammena vasati vijjāya vasati
translated: In any fruit that is seen to exist, the reason is a cause. That same meaning is in the sense of cause. He lives by food, he lives by Dhamma, he lives by knowledge.

original: Na jaccāvasalo hoti,
analyzed: na hoti
translated: Not by birth is one an outcaste,

original: Na jaccā hoti brāhmaṇo;
analyzed: na brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: not by birth is one a Brahmin;

original: Kammunā vasalo hoti,
analyzed: kammunā vasalaḥ hoti
translated: by action one is an outcaste,

original: Kammunā hoti brāhmaṇo.
analyzed: kammunā hoti brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: by action one is a Brahmin.

original: Dānena bhogavā, ācārena kulī.
analyzed: dānena bhogavā ācārena kulī
translated: By giving one is wealthy, by conduct one is of good family.

original: Kena pāṇi kāmadado, kena pāṇi madhussavo;
analyzed: kena pāṇi kāmadadaḥ kena pāṇi madhussavaḥ
translated: By what hand does one give what is desired? By what hand is the honey-sweet?🔽By what is your spiritual life successful,

original: Kena te brahmacariyena, puññaṃ pāṇimhi ijjhati.
analyzed: kena te brahmacariyena puññam pāṇimhi ijjhati
translated: by what is merit in the hand?

original: Hetvatthappayoge – kena nimittena, kena payojanena, kenaṭṭhena, kena hetunā vasati.
analyzed: hetu attha ppayoge kena nimittena kena payojanena kenaṭṭhena kena hetunā vasati
translated: In the expression of cause: by what sign, by what purpose, by what reason, by what cause does one live?

original: 298. Sattamyatthe ca.
analyzed: sattamī atthe ca
translated: And in the sense of the locative case.

original: Sattamyatthe ca liṅgamhā tatiyāvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: sattamī atthe ca liṅgamhā tatiyā vibhatti hoti
translated: The locative case is used in the sense of the locative case.

original: Kāladdhānadisādesādīsu cāyaṃ. Tena samayena, tena kālena, kālena dhammassavaṇaṃ,
analyzed: kāla ddhāna disā desa ādīsu ca ayam tena samayena tena kālena kālena dhamma ssavaṇam
translated: And this is in the case of time, space, direction, place, etc. At that time, at that occasion, by time listening to the Dhamma,

original: so vo mamaccayena satthā, māsena bhuñjati, yojanena dhāvati. Puratthimena dhataraṭṭho,
analyzed: saḥ vaḥ mamaccayena satthā māsena bhuñjati yojanena dhāvati puratthimena dhataraṭṭhaḥ
translated: He is your teacher after my passing, who eats once a month, who runs a league. To the east is Dhataraṭṭha,

original: dakkhiṇena virūḷhako, pacchimena virūpakkho, uttarena kasivanto janoghamaparena ca,
analyzed: dakkhiṇena virūḷhako pacchimena virūpakkho uttarena kasivantaḥ janogham aparena ca
translated: to the south Virūḷhaka, to the west Virūpakkha, to the north is Kasivanto, and Janoghamaparena,

original: yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami iccādi.🔽299. Yenaṅgavikāro.
analyzed: yena bhagavān tena upasaṅkami iccādi  yena aṅga vikāraḥ
translated: he approached the Lord.🔽. The third case is used to show the part of the body that is affected.🔽Herein, a body is a part of the body because it has a part . One-eyed in the eye, lame in the hand, crippled in the foot, bent in the back.

original: Yena byādhimatā aṅgena aṅgino vikāro lakkhīyate, tattha tatiyāvibhatti hoti. Ettha ca aṅgamassa atthīti aṅgaṃ, sarīraṃ. Akkhinā kāṇo, hatthena kuṇī, pādena khañjo, piṭṭhiyā khujjo.🔽300. Visesane ca.
analyzed: yena byādhimatā aṅgena aṅginaḥ vikāraḥ lakkhīyate tattha tatiyā vibhatti hoti ettha ca aṅgam assa atthi iti aṅgam sarīram akkhinā kāṇaḥ hatthena kuṇī pādena khañjaḥ piṭṭhiyā khujjo  visesane ca
translated: . The third case is used to show the distinguishing mark.

original: Visesīyati visesitabbaṃ anenāti visesanaṃ, gottādi. Tasmiṃ gottanāmajātisippavayoguṇasaṅkhāte visesanatthe tatiyāvibhatti hoti, casaddena pakatiādīhi ca. Gottena gotamo nātho.
analyzed: visesīyati visesitabbam anena ati visesanam gotta ādi tasmin gotta nāma jāti sippa vayaḥ guṇa saṅkhāte visesana atthe tatiyā vibhatti hoti ca saddena pakati ādīhi ca gottena gotamaḥ nātho
translated: That by which a distinguishing mark is distinguished is a distinguishing mark, a clan, etc. The third case is used in the sense of the distinguishing mark called clan, name, birth, craft, age, and quality, and also by the word “and” in the sense of nature, etc. The protector is a Gotama by clan.

original: Sāriputtoti nāmena, vissuto paññavā ca so;
analyzed: sāriputtaḥ ti nāmena vissutaḥ paññavā ca so
translated: He is known by the name of Sāriputta, and he is wise,

original: Jātiyā khattiyo buddho, loke appaṭipuggalo.
analyzed: jātiyā khattiyaḥ buddhaḥ loke appaṭipuggalaḥ
translated: The Buddha is a noble by birth, and he is without equal in the world.

original: Tadahu pabbajito santo, jātiyā sattavassiko;
analyzed: tat ahu pabbajitaḥ santaḥ jātiyā sattavassikaḥ
translated: On the very day he went forth, he was seven years old by birth.

original: Sopi maṃ anusāseyya, sampaṭicchāmi matthake.
analyzed: saḥ api mam anusāseyya sampaṭicchāmi matthake
translated: He too would instruct me, I would accept it on my head.

original: Sippena naḷakāro so, ekūnatiṃso vayasā, vijjāya sādhu, paññāya sādhu, tapasā uttamo, suvaṇṇena abhirūpo.
analyzed: sippena naḷakāro saḥ ekūnatiṃsaḥ vayasā vijjāya sādhu paññāya sādhu tapasā uttamaḥ suvaṇṇena abhirūpaḥ
translated: He was a reed-worker by craft, nineteen years old by age, good in knowledge, good in wisdom, excellent in austerity, handsome in gold.

original: Pakatiādīsu – pakatiyā abhirūpo, yebhuyyena mattikā, samena dhāvati, visamena dhāvati, dvidoṇena dhaññaṃ kiṇāti, sahassena assake kiṇāti iccādi.
analyzed: pakati ādīsu pakatiyā abhirūpaḥ yebhuyyena mattikā samena dhāvati visamena dhāvati dvi doṇena dhaññam kiṇāti sahassena assake kiṇāti iccādi
translated: In the natural state, etc.: He was handsome by nature, mostly clay, he ran straight, he ran crooked, he bought grain for two dhonas, he bought horses for a thousand, and so on.

original: Kasmiṃ atthe catutthī?🔽301. Sampadāne catutthī.
analyzed: kasmin a tthe catutthī  sampadāne catutthī
translated: In what sense is the fourth case?🔽The fourth case is used in the sense of the recipient.

original: Sampadānakārake liṅgamhā catutthīvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: sampadāna kārake liṅgamhā catutthī vibhatti hoti
translated: The fourth case ending is used with a noun in the sense of the recipient.

original: Kiñca sampadānaṃ?🔽302. Yassa dātukāmo rocate dhārayate vā taṃ sampadānaṃ.
analyzed: kiñca sampadānam  yassa dātu kāmaḥ rocate dhārayate vā tam sampadānam
translated: And what is the recipient?🔽. That which one wishes to give, that which one likes, that which one holds, is the recipient.

original: Yassa vā dātukāmo, yassa vā rocate, yassa vā dhārayate, taṃ kārakaṃ sampadānasaññaṃ hoti. Sammā padīyate assāti sampadānaṃ, paṭiggāhako.
analyzed: yassa vā dātu kāmaḥ yassa vā rocate yassa vā dhārayate tam kārakam sampadāna saññam hoti sammā padīyate assa ati sampadānam paṭiggāhako
translated: Or that which one wishes to give, that which one likes, that which one holds, that recipient is called the recipient. It is rightly given to him, the recipient is the receiver.

original: Taṃ pana tividhaṃ diyyamānassānivāraṇajjhesanānumativasena. Yathā – buddhassa pupphaṃ🔽yajati, bodhirukkhassa jalaṃ dadāti. Ajjhesane – yācakānaṃ dhanaṃ dadāti. Anumatiyaṃ🔽– bhikkhūnaṃ dānaṃ deti.
analyzed: tam pana tividham diyyamāna ssa anivāraṇa ajjhesana anumati vasena yathā buddhassa puppham  yajati bodhi rukkhassa jalam dadāti ajjhesane yācakānam dhanam dadāti anumatiyam  bhikkhūnam dānam deti
translated: But that is threefold as giving, requesting, and consenting. Giving is such as: he worships the Buddha with flowers, he gives water to the Bodhi Tree, he gives money to beggars. Requesting is such as: he requests the bhikkhus to eat, he requests the bhikkhus to accept robes, he requests the bhikkhus to accept alms foods. Consenting is such as: he consents to the bhikkhus’ acceptance of dwellings, he consents to the bhikkhus’ acceptance of the rains, he consents to the bhikkhus’ acceptance of the invitation day.

original: Yathāha🔽“Anirākaraṇārādha-nābbhanuññavasena hi;🔽Sampadānaṃ tidhā vuttaṃ, rukkha yācaka bhikkhavo”ti.
analyzed: yathā āha  hi  sampadānam tidhā vuttam rukkha yācaka bhikkhavaḥ ti
translated: But that is given in three ways, by the act of preventing, by the act of asking, and by the act of consenting. As follows: he worships the Buddha with flowers, he gives water to the Bodhi Tree, he gives wealth to beggars. By the act of asking: he gives the monks a gift. By the act of consenting: he gives the king the rod. As it is said: “For by the act of preventing, by the act of asking, and by the act of consenting, Giving is said to be of three kinds, to a tree, a beggar, and the monks” .

original: Dātukāmoti kiṃ? Rañño daṇḍaṃ dadāti.
analyzed: dātu kāmaḥ iti kim raññaḥ daṇḍam dadāti
translated: “What is the meaning of ‘desirous of giving’?” he gives the king the rod.

original: Rocanādīsu pana – samaṇassa rocate saccaṃ, māyasmantānampi saṅghabhedo ruccittha, yassāyasmato khamati, devadattassa suvaṇṇacchattaṃ dhārayate yaññadatto.
analyzed: rocana ādīsu pana samaṇassa rocate saccam mā ayasmantānam pi saṅgha bhedaḥ yassa ayasmataḥ khamati devadattassa suvaṇṇa chattam dhārayate yaññadatto
translated: But in the case of ‘agreeable’ and the rest: the ascetic is agreeable, the venerable ones’ schism in the Community is agreeable, to whomsoever it is agreeable, he should carry Devadatta’s golden parasol. Yaññadatta.

original: “Sampadānaṃ, vā”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: sampadānam vāti ca vattate
translated: “Or giving” is said.

original: 303. Silāgha hanu ṭhā sapa dhāra piha kudha duhi ssāsūya rādhikkha paccāsuṇa anupatigiṇapubbakattārocanatthatadattha
analyzed: si lāgha hanu ṭhā sapa dhāra piha kudha duhi ssāsūya rādhikkha paccāsuṇa anu pati giṇa pubba kattā rocanattha tadattha
translated: Silāgha hanu ṭhā sapa dhāra piha kudha duhi ssāsūya rādhikkha paccāsuṇa anupatigiṇapubbakattārocanatthatadattha

original: tumatthālamattha maññānādarappāṇini gatyatthakammani āsisattha sammuti bhiyyasattamyatthesu ca.
analyzed: tumattha alamattha maññāna ādara ppāṇini gati attha kammani āsi sattha sammuti bhiyya sattamī atthesu ca
translated: in the sense of ‘what is to be done’, ‘what is to be done is done’, ‘thinking’, ‘not respecting’, ‘not having life’, in the sense of ‘going’, in the sense of ‘action’, in the sense of ‘instrument’, in the sense of ‘collection’, in the sense of ‘more than the locative case’.

original: Catuppadamidaṃ. Silāgha katthane, hanu apanayane, ṭhā gatinivattimhi, sapa akkose,
analyzed: catuppadam idam si lāgha katthane hanu apanayane ṭhā gati nivattimhi sapa akkose
translated: This is fourfold. In the use of the roots silāgha ‘to cut’, katha ‘to speak’, hanu ‘to lead away’, ṭhā ‘to go’, ‘to stop’, sapa ‘to revile’,

original: dhara dhāraṇe, piha icchāyaṃ iccetesaṃ dhātūnaṃ payoge, kudha kope, duha jighaṃsāyaṃ,🔽issa issāyaṃ, usūya dosāvikaraṇe iccetesaṃ tadatthavācīnañca dhātūnaṃ payoge ca rādha
analyzed: dhara dhāraṇe piha iccha ayam dhātūnam payoge kudha kope duha jighaṃsa ayam  issaḥ issāyam usūya dosa a vikaraṇe dhātūnam payoge ca
translated: dhara ‘to hold’, piha ‘to desire’, in the use of the roots kudha ‘to be angry’, duha ‘to be hungry’,🔽issa ‘to be jealous’, usūya ‘to be envious’, in the use of the roots which express those meanings, and in the use of the roots rādha🔽‘to harm’, ‘to delight’, ikkha ‘to see’, ‘to be variegated’, in the use of these, and in the use of the root pati ‘to hear’, which has the prefix ā,

original: hiṃsāsaṃrādhesu, ikkha dassanaṅkesūti imesaṃ payoge ca pati āpubbassa su savaṇeti🔽imassa ca anupatipubbassa gesaddeti imassa ca pubbakattā ca ārocanatthappayoge, tadatthe,🔽tumatthe, alamatthappayoge ca maññatippayoge anādare appāṇini ca gatyatthānaṃ kammani
analyzed: hiṃsā saṃrādhesu ikkha dassa naṅkesu iti imesam payoge ca pati āpubbassa su savaṇā iti  imassa ca anu pati pubbassa gesadde ti imassa ca pubbaka ttā ca ārocana attha ppayoge tad atthe  tum atthe alam attha ppayoge ca maññati ppayoge anādare ap pāṇini ca gati atthānam kammani
translated: and in the use of the root gesa ‘to hear’, which has the prefix anupati, and in the use of the root de ‘to give’, which has the prefix ārocana, in the sense of that,🔽in the sense of ‘what is to be done’, in the use of the root maññati ‘to think’, in the sense of ‘not respecting’, in the sense of ‘not having life’, in the sense of ‘going’,🔽in the sense of ‘action’, in the use of the root āsi ‘to be’, in the sense of ‘instrument’, in the use of the root sammu ‘to agree’, in the sense of ‘collection’, in the use of the root bhiyya ‘to be more than’, in the sense of ‘more than the locative case’.

original: ca āsisatthappayoge ca sammuti bhiyyappayogesu ca sattamyatthe cāti taṃ kammādikārakaṃ
analyzed: ca āsi sattha ppayoge ca sammuti bhiyya ppayogesu ca sattamī atthe ca ati tam kamma ādi kārakam
translated: That which is the doer of the action, etc.,

original: sampadānasaññaṃ hoti, casaddaggahaṇena pahiṇatikappati pahoti upamāñjalikaraṇa phāsu
analyzed: sampadāna saññam hoti ca sadda ggahaṇena pahiṇati kappati upamā añjali karaṇa
translated: There is the notion of giving,

original: atthaseyyappabhutiyoge ca pure viya catutthī.
analyzed: attha seyya ppabhuti yoge ca pure catutthī
translated: and the fourth case is used with the words “a messenger,” “a request,” “a permission,” “a simile,” “a respectful salutation,” “a comfort,”🔽“a good night,” etc., as in the previous section.

original: Silāghādippayoge tāva – buddhassa silāghate. Upajjhāyassa silāghate, thometīti attho.
analyzed: silāghā ādi ppayoge tāva buddhassa silāghate upajjhāyassa silāghate thometi iti attho
translated: As regards the use of the locative, etc., first of all: “On the Buddha’s head,” “On the head of the preceptor,” meaning “he touches.”

original: Hanute mayhameva, hanute tuyhameva, apalapatīti attho.
analyzed: hanute mayham eva hanute tuyham eva apalapati iti
translated: “It belongs to me,” “It belongs to you,” meaning “he chatters.”

original: Upatiṭṭheyya sakyaputtānaṃ vaḍḍhakī, ettha ca upaṭṭhānaṃ nāma upagamanaṃ. Bhikkhussa bhuñjamānassa pānīyena vā vidhūpanena vā upatiṭṭheyya.
analyzed: upatiṭṭheyya sakyaputtānam vaḍḍhakī ettha ca upaṭṭhānam nāma upagamanam bhikkhussa bhuñjamānassa pānīyena vā vidhūpanena vā upatiṭṭheyya
translated: “He would attend on the Sakyan disciples,” and here “attendance” is approaching; he would attend on a bhikkhu who is eating by giving him water or fanning him.

original: Tuyhaṃ sapate, mayhaṃ sapate, ettha ca sapanaṃ nāma saccakaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: tuyham sapate mayham sapate ettha ca sapanam nāma sacca karaṇam
translated: “Yours is ripe,” “Mine is ripe,” and here “ripening” is the act of becoming true.

original: Dhārayatippayoge dhanikoyeva sampadānaṃ, suvaṇṇaṃ te dhārayate, iṇaṃ dhārayatīti attho. Tassa rañño mayaṃ nāgaṃ dhārayāma.
analyzed: dhārayati ppayoge sampadānam suvaṇṇam te dhārayate iṇam dhārayati iti tassa raññaḥ mayam nāgam dhārayāma
translated: As regards the use of the genitive, only the creditor has the notion of giving, “Your gold is kept by me,” meaning “I hold your debt.” “We keep the elephant for the king.”

original: Pihappayoge icchitoyeva, devāpi tassa pihayanti tādino, devāpi tesaṃ pihayanti, sambuddhānaṃ satīmataṃ, patthentīti attho.
analyzed: devā api tassa pihayanti tādinaḥ devāḥ api tesam pihayanti sambuddhānam satī matam patthenti iti atthaḥ
translated: In the case of the wish for a monastery site, the gods themselves wish for such a one, and the gods wish for those who are fully enlightened and mindful. The meaning is: they long for them.

original: Kodhādiatthānaṃ payoge yaṃ pati kopo, tassa kujjha mahāvīra, yadihaṃ tassa kuppeyyaṃ.
analyzed: kodha ādi atthānam payoge yam pati kopo tassa kujjha mahāvīra yat iham tassa
translated: In the case of the wish for the site of a quarrel, etc., the anger that is the cause of the quarrel is pati. The meaning is: “O Great Hero, if I were to get angry with him, I would be like him.”

original: Duhayati disānaṃ megho, yo mittānaṃ na dubbhati.
analyzed: duhayati disānam meghaḥ yaḥ mittānam na dubbhati
translated: The cloud rains on the directions, but does not rain on friends.

original: Titthiyā issanti samaṇānaṃ.
analyzed: titthiyāḥ issanti samaṇānam
translated: The sectarians envy the ascetics.

original: Dujjanā guṇavantānaṃ usūyanti, kā usūyā vijānataṃ.
analyzed: dujjanāḥ usūyanti kā usūyā vijānatam
translated: The wicked envy the virtuous. What envy is there for those who know?

original: Rādhikkhappayoge yassa vipucchanaṃ kammavikhyāpanatthaṃ, vādhikārato dutiyā ca. Ārādho
analyzed: rādh ikkha ppayoge yassa vipucchanam kamma vikhyāpana attham vā adhikārataḥ dutiyā ca ārādhaḥ
translated: In the case of the wish for a referee, the question is asked in order to make known the action. The second is from the point of view of the referee.

original: me rañño, rañño aparajjhati, rājānaṃ vā aparajjhati, kyāhaṃ ayyānaṃ aparajjhāmi,
analyzed: me raññaḥ raññaḥ aparajjhati rājānam vā aparajjhati kyā aham ayyānam aparajjhāmi
translated: I am pleased with the king, the king is pleased with me, the king is pleased with me, how can I displease the venerable ones?

original: kyāhaṃ ayye aparajjhāmi vā.
analyzed: kyā aham ayye aparajjhāmi vā
translated: How can I displease the venerable lady?

original: Āyasmato upālittherassa upasampadāpekkho upatisso, āyasmantaṃ vā.
analyzed: āyasmataḥ upāli ttherassa upasampada apekkhaḥ upatissaḥ āyasmantam vā
translated: The venerable elder Upāli’s candidate for higher ordination is Upatissa. The venerable one, or

original: Paccāsuṇa anupatigiṇānaṃ pubbakattā ca suṇotissa dhātussa paccāyoge, giṇassa ca anupatiyoge
analyzed: pacca a suṇa anu pati giṇānam pubba ka ttā ca suṇotissa dhātussa pacca āyoge giṇassa ca anu pati yoge
translated: In the case of the wish for a witness, the witness hears the statement of the one who is to be charged and the statement of the one who charges him. The witness hears the statement of the one who is to be charged. The witness hears the statement of the one who charges him. The witness hears the statement of the one who is to be charged. The witness hears the statement of the one who charges him.

original: pubbassa kammuno yo kattā, so sampadānasañño hoti. Yathā – bhagavā bhikkhū etadavoca,🔽ettha “bhikkhū”ti akathitakammaṃ, “eta”nti kathitakammaṃ, pubbassa vacanakammassa
analyzed: pubbassa kammunaḥ yaḥ kattā so sampadāna saññaḥ hoti yathā bhagavā bhikkhū etat avoca  ettha bhikkhu iti a kathita kammam etat ti kathita kammam pubbassa vacana kammassa
translated: The doer of the first action is the one who is called the “maker of the act of communicating”. As follows: the Blessed One said this to the bhikkhus,

original: kattā bhagavā. Bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ, āsuṇanti buddhassa bhikkhū, tathā bhikkhu
analyzed: kattā bhagavā bhikkhū bhagavataḥ paccassosum āsuṇanti buddhassa bhikkhū tathā bhikkhu
translated: Herein, “bhikkhus” is the action not yet done, “this” is the action done. The Blessed One is the doer of the first action of speaking. The bhikkhus listened to the Blessed One, the bhikkhus listen to the Buddha, so bhikkhus,

original: janaṃ dhammaṃ sāveti, tassa bhikkhuno jano anugiṇāti, tassa bhikkhuno jano patigiṇāti,
analyzed: janam dhammam sāveti tassa bhikkhunaḥ janaḥ anugiṇāti tassa bhikkhunaḥ janaḥ patigiṇāti
translated: he announces the Dhamma to people, people approve of that bhikkhu, people understand that bhikkhu,

original: sādhukāradānādinā taṃ ussāhayatīti attho.
analyzed: sādhukāra dāna ādinā tam ussāhayati iti
translated: the meaning is that he encourages him by giving him applause and so on.🔽He who speaks is the doer,

original: Yo vadeti sa kattāti, vuttaṃ kammanti vuccati;
analyzed: yaḥ vadeti sa kattā ati vuttam kammanti vuccati
translated: it is said, and the action is called the act of communicating;

original: Yo paṭiggāhako tassa, sampadānaṃ vijāniyāti.🔽Ārocanatthappayoge yassa āroceti, taṃ sampadānaṃ. Ārocayāmi vo bhikkhave, paṭivedayāmi
analyzed: yaḥ paṭiggāhako tassa sampadānam vijāniyāti  ārocana attha payoge yassa āroceti tam sampadānam ārocayāmi vaḥ bhikkhave paṭivedayāmi
translated: The one who receives it should understand the act of communicating.

original: vo bhikkhave, āmantayāmi te mahārāja, āmanta kho taṃ gacchāmāti vā. Ettha ca ārocanasaddassa
analyzed: vaḥ bhikkhave āmantayāmi te mahā rāja āmanta kho tam gacchāma ati vā ettha ca ārocana saddassa
translated: In the case of the expression of the purpose of announcing, the act of communicating is the one to whom he announces. I announce to you, bhikkhus, I inform you, bhikkhus, I invite you, great king, I call you, I am going, he said. And here the word “announce”

original: kathanappakāratthattā desanatthādippayogepi catutthī. Dhammaṃ vo desessāmi, desetu
analyzed: kathana ppakāra tthattā desana ttha ādi ppayoge pi catutthī dhammam vaḥ desessāmi desetu
translated: and the fourth is used in the sense of the manner of telling, in the case of the expression “for the sake of teaching, etc.” (desanatthādippayogepi catutthī). “I will teach you the Dhamma,” “Let the Blessed One teach the Dhamma,” “The Blessed One teaches the Dhamma,” “The Blessed One taught the Dhamma.”

original: bhante bhagavā dhammaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ, yathā no bhagavā byākareyya, niruttiṃ te pavakkhāmi iccādi.
analyzed: bhante bhagavā dhammam bhikkhūnam yathā naḥ bhagavā byākareyya niruttim te pavakkhāmi iccādi
translated: The fourth case is used for the purpose of teaching, etc., because of the meaning of manner of doing. “I will teach you the Dhamma,” “Let the Lord teach the Dhamma to the bhikkhus,” “I will expound the rules to you,” and so on.

original: Tadatthe sampadānasaññā, catutthī ca.
analyzed: tad atthe sampadāna saññā catutthī ca
translated: The fourth case is used for the purpose of that, because of the recognition of the giving of it.

original: “Ato, vā”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: atas vāti ca vattate
translated: “Or for the purpose of that” is said.

original: 304. Āya catutthekavacanassa tu.
analyzed: āya catuttha ekavacanassa tu
translated: But in the fourth case ending🔽in the feminine,

original: Akārantato liṅgamhā parassa catutthekavacanassa āyādeso hoti vā, saralopādi.
analyzed: akāra antataḥ liṅgamhā parassa catuttha ekavacanassa āya ādesaḥ hoti vā sara lopa ādi
translated: the fourth case ending in the feminine in the feminine, which ends in a vowel, has the substitution of ā for the final vowel, or the vowel is dropped, and so on.

original: Buddhassatthāya dhammassatthāya saṅghassatthāya jīvitaṃ pariccajāmi, piṇḍapātaṃ paṭisevāmi
analyzed: buddhassatthāya dhammassatthāya saṅghassatthāya jīvitam pariccajāmi piṇḍapātam paṭisevāmi
translated: “For the sake of the Enlightened One, for the sake of the Dhamma, for the sake of the Community, I give up my life, I enjoy alms food

original: neva davāya na madāya na maṇḍanāya na vibhūsanāya, ūnassa pāripūriyā, atthāya hitāya sukhāya saṃvattati.
analyzed: na iva davāya na madāya na maṇḍanāya na vibhūsanāya ūnassa pāripūriyā atthāya hitāya sukhāya saṃvattati
translated: not for the sake of pleasure, not for the sake of intoxication, not for the sake of smartening, not for the sake of embellishment, but only for the sake of this body’s maintenance, continuance, and continuance without affliction, for the ending of old feeling, and for the non-arising of new feeling.”

original: Tumatthe – lokānukampāya, lokamanukampitunti attho. Tathā phāsuvihārāya.
analyzed: tumun atthe loka anukampāya tathā phāsu vihārāya
translated: For the purpose of that: “Out of compassion for the world,” the meaning is: “having compassion on the world.” Likewise “for the sake of living comfortably.”

original: Alaṃsaddassa atthā arahapaṭikkhepā. Arahatthe – alaṃ me rajjaṃ, alaṃ bhikkhu pattassa, akkhadhutto purisapuggalo nālaṃ dārabharaṇāya, alaṃ mallo mallassa, arahati mallo mallassa.
analyzed: alaṃsaddassa atthāḥ araha paṭikkhepāḥ arahatthe alam me rajjam alam bhikkhu pattassa akkha dhuttaḥ purisa puggalo na alam dāra bharaṇāya alam mallaḥ mallassa arahati mallaḥ mallassa
translated: The meaning of ‘enough’ is ‘deserving of rejection’. In the sense of ‘deserving’: ‘Enough for me is kingship’, ‘Enough for me is the bowl’, ‘The gambler is not enough for the support of a wife’, ‘The wrestler is enough for the support of the wrestler’.

original: Paṭikkhepe – alaṃ te idha vāsena, alaṃ me hiraññasuvaṇṇena, kiṃ me ekena tiṇṇena, kiṃ te jaṭāhi dummedha, kiṃ tettha catumaṭṭhassa.
analyzed: paṭikkhepe alam te idha vāsena alam me hirañña suvaṇṇena kim me ekena tiṇṇena kim te jaṭāhi dummedha kim te ittha
translated: In the sense of ‘rejection’: ‘Enough for you is living here’, ‘Enough for me is gold and silver’, ‘What is one more dead?’, ‘What is the use of your matted hair, you fool?’, ‘What is the use of your four-cornered mat?’

original: Maññatippayoge anādare appāṇini kammaniyeva – kaṭṭhassa tuvaṃ maññe, kaḷiṅgarassa tuvaṃ maññe, jīvitaṃ tiṇāyapi na maññamāno.
analyzed: mañña ti payoge an ādare ap pāṇini kammaniyā iva kaṭṭhassa tuvam maññe kaḷiṅgarassa tuvam maññe jīvitam na maññamānaḥ
translated: In the sense of ‘contempt’ and ‘disrespect’ and ‘not being a means of livelihood’: ‘You are thought to be a piece of wood’, ‘You are thought to be a Kalinagara man’, ‘Not thinking life to be worth a straw’.

original: Anādareti kiṃ? Suvaṇṇaṃ taṃ maññe. Appāṇinīti kiṃ? Gadrabhaṃ tuvaṃ maññe.
analyzed: anādarā iti kim suvaṇṇam tam maññe appāṇinī iti kim gadrabham tuvam maññe
translated: What is the meaning of ‘disrespect’? ‘You are thought to be gold’. What is the meaning of ‘not being a means of livelihood’? ‘You are thought to be a donkey’.

original: Gatyatthakammani vādhikārato dutiyā ca. Appo saggāya gacchati, appo saggaṃ gacchati, nibbānāya vajantiyā, mūlāya paṭikasseyya, mūlaṃ paṭikasseyya.
analyzed: gati attha kammani vā adhikārataḥ dutiyā ca appaḥ saggāya gacchati appaḥ saggam gacchati nibbānāya vajantiyāḥ mūlāya paṭikasseyya mūlam paṭikasseyya
translated: In the sense of ‘going’ and ‘means of livelihood’ and ‘authority’ and ‘second’: ‘Few go to heaven’, ‘Few go to heaven’, ‘They go to Nibbāna’, ‘He would go back to the root’, ‘He would go back to the root’.

original: Āsīsanatthe āyubhaddakusalādiyogeyeva, āyasmato dīghāyu hotu, “totitā sasmiṃnāsū”ti🔽ntussa savibhattissa to ādeso. Bhaddaṃ bhavato hotu, kusalaṃ bhavato hotu, anāmayaṃ🔽bhavato hotu, sukhaṃ bhavato hotu, atthaṃ bhavato hotu, hitaṃ bhavato hotu, svāgataṃ
analyzed: āsīsana atthe āyu bhadda kusala ādi yoge iva āyasmataḥ dīgha āyu hotu toti tā  n tussa sa vibhattissa taḥ ādesaḥ bhaddam bhavataḥ hotu kusalam bhavataḥ hotu anāmayam  bhavataḥ hotu sukham bhavataḥ hotu attham bhavataḥ hotu hitam bhavataḥ hotu svāgatam
translated: In the sense of wishing, the following are compounded with the word āyu-bhaddaka, etc.: May the venerable one have long life, “to” is added to the nominative case ending “s” and the vowel “a” is changed to “o”. May there be well-being for you, may there be welfare for you, may there be health for you,🔽may there be happiness for you, may there be benefit for you, may there be what is good for you, may there be a good welcome for you,🔽

original: bhavato hotu, sotthi hotu sabbasattānaṃ.
analyzed: bhavataḥ hotu sotthi hotu sabba sattānam
translated: In the sense of ‘wishing’, in the combination ‘long-life-good-fortune’ , etc., as in ‘May the venerable one have long life’, ‘May the venerable one be well’, ‘May the venerable one be happy’, ‘May the venerable one be prosperous’, ‘May the venerable one be successful’, ‘May the venerable one be comfortable’, ‘May all beings be happy’.

original: Sammutippayoge – sādhu sammuti me tassa bhagavato dassanāya.
analyzed: sammuti ppayoge sādhu sammuti me tassa bhagavataḥ dassanāya
translated: In the sense of ‘agreement’, as in ‘It is good for me to agree to see that Blessed One’.

original: Bhiyyappayoge bhiyyoso mattāya.
analyzed: bhiyyappayoge bhiyyosaḥ mattāya
translated: In the sense of ‘excess’, as in ‘To an even greater extent’.

original: Sattamiyatthe āvikaraṇa pātubhavanādiyoge – tuyhañcassa āvikaromi, tassa me sakko pāturahosi.🔽Casaddaggahaṇena pahiṇādikriyāyoge, phāsuādināmapayoge ca – tassa pahiṇeyya, bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: sattamiya tthe āvikaraṇa pātubhavana ādi yoge āvikaromi tassa me sakko pāturahosi  ca sadda gahaṇena pahiṇa ādi kriyā yoge phāsu ādi nāma apayoge ca tassa pahiṇeyya bhikkhūnam
translated: In the sense of the locative case, as in ‘I announce to you’ and ‘He became manifest to me’.🔽By the word ‘etc.’ in the text is included the sense of ‘sending’, as in ‘He sent to him’, and the sense of ‘using a name’, as in ‘He used the name Phāsu’.

original: dūtaṃ pāhesi, kappati samaṇānaṃ āyogo, ekassa dinnaṃ dvinnaṃ tiṇṇaṃ pahoti, upamaṃ
analyzed: dūtam pāhesi kappati samaṇānam āyogaḥ ekassa dinnam dvinnam tiṇṇam pahoti upamam
translated: In the sense of ‘plurality’, as in ‘He would send to two or three bhikkhus’, ‘He sent a messenger to the bhikkhus’, ‘It is allowable for ascetics to use a name’, ‘What is given to one is enough for two or three’, ‘He used the simile

original: te karissāmi, añjaliṃ te paggaṇhāmi. Tathā tassa phāsu hoti, lokassattho, maṇinā
analyzed: te karissāmi añjalim te paggaṇhāmi tathā tassa phāsu hoti lokassatthaḥ maṇinā
translated: I will do it, I raise my joined palms to you. In that way it is comfortable for him, for the benefit of the world, with a jewel,

original: me attho, seyyo me attho iccādi.
analyzed: me attho seyyo me attho iccādi
translated: I will do it, I raise my clasped hands to you. It is comfortable for him in that way, the welfare of the world, I want a gem, I want what is better for me, and so on.

original: “Catutthī”ti vattate.
analyzed: catutthī iti vattate
translated: “The fourth” is said.

original: 305. Namoyogādīsvapi ca.
analyzed: namaḥ yoga ādīsu api ca
translated: And also in namoyogādīsu.

original: Namosaddayoge, sotthisvāgatādīhi ca yoge liṅgamhā catutthīvibhatti hoti. Namo te
analyzed: namaḥ sadda yoge sotthi svāgata ādīhi ca yoge liṅgamhā catutthī vibhatti hoti namo te
translated: In the combination with the word namo, and in the combination with sotthi, svāgata, and so on, the fourth case-ending is used. Homage to you

original: buddha vīratthu, namo karohi nāgassa, namatthu buddhānaṃ, namatthu bodhiyā, sotthi
analyzed: buddha vīratthu namaḥ karohi nāgassa namatthu buddhānam namatthu bodhiyā sotthi
translated: Buddha hero, you should pay homage to the nāga, homage to the Buddhas, homage to the Bodhi tree, safe

original: pajānaṃ, svāgataṃ te mahārāja, atho te adurāgataṃ.
analyzed: svāgatam te mahā rāja atho te adurāgatam
translated: for the people, welcome to you great king, and also it is not far for you to come.

original: “Kāle, bhavissatī”ti ca vattate.🔽306. Bhāvavācimhi catutthī.
analyzed: kāle bhavissati iti ca vattate  bhāva vācimhi catutthī
translated: “At the time, it will be” is said.

original: Bhāvavācimhi catutthīvibhatti hoti bhavissatikāle. Bhavanaṃ bhāvo. Paccissate, pacanaṃ vā pāko, pākāya vajati, pacituṃ gacchatīti attho. Evaṃ bhogāya vajati iccādi.
analyzed: bhāva vācimhi catutthī vibhatti hoti bhavissati kāle bhavanam bhāvaḥ paccissate pacanam vā pākaḥ pākāya vajati pacitum gacchati iti atthaḥ evam bhogāya vajati iccādi
translated: . The fourth case-ending is used in the future tense to express a state. The state is the future. It will cook, or the cooking, it goes for the cooking, the meaning is it goes for the cooking. In the same way it goes for the enjoyment, and so on.

original: Kasmiṃ atthe pañcamī?
analyzed: kasmin atthe pañcamī
translated: In what meaning is the fifth case?

original: 307. Apādāne pañcamī.
analyzed: apādāne pañcamī
translated: . The fifth case is used in the ablative.

original: Kimapādānaṃ?
analyzed: kim apādānam
translated: What is the ablative?

original: 308. Yasmādapeti bhayamādatte vā tadapādānaṃ.
analyzed: yasmāt apeti bhayam ādatte vā tat apādānam
translated: . That from which fear or danger is taken is the ablative.🔽.Here is the corrected and aligned text:

original: Yasmā vā avadhito apeti, yasmā vā bhayahetuto bhayaṃ bhavati, yasmā vā akkhātārā vijjaṃ ādadāti, taṃ kārakaṃ apādānasaññaṃ hoti. Apanetvā ito ādadātīti apādānaṃ.
analyzed: yasmai vā avadhitaḥ apeti yasmai vā bhaya hetutaḥ bhayam bhavati yasmai vā akkhātārā vijjam ādadāti tam kārakam apādāna saññam hoti apanetvā itas ādadāti iti apādānam
translated: Or alternatively, it is the reason why one goes away from what is confined, the reason why fear arises from a cause of fear, the reason why those who proclaim it take up knowledge, and that is the reason for the expression “going away from here and taking up there” .

original: Taṃ pana tividhaṃ visayabhedena niddiṭṭhavisayaṃ, upāttavisayaṃ, anumeyyavisayañcāti.
analyzed: tam pana tividham visaya bhedena niddiṭṭha visayam upātta visayam anumeyya visayam ca ati
translated: But that is threefold as shown by the division of the objective fields, namely, as having a shown objective field, as having a possessed objective field, and as having an inferred objective field.

original: Apādānasaññāvisayassa kriyāvisesassa niddiṭṭhattā niddiṭṭhavisayaṃ. Yathā – gāmā apenti munayo, nagarā niggato rājā.
analyzed: apādāna saññā visayassa kriyā visesassa niddiṭṭha ttā niddiṭṭha visayam yathā gāmāḥ apenti munayaḥ nagarāḥ niggataḥ rājā
translated: It is “having a shown objective field” because the particular action of the objective field of the expression “going away from” is shown. As in the following passages: “The seers go away from the village” , “The king goes away from the town” ,

original: Ettha ca “pāpā cittaṃ nivāraye, pāpā nivārentī”tiādīsu yadipi kāyasaṃyogapubbakāpagamanaṃ natthi, tathāpi cittasaṃyogapubbakassa apagamanassa sambhavato iminā ca apādānasaññā.
analyzed: ettha ca pāpā cittam nivāraye pāpāḥ nivārenti itiādīsu yadi api kāya saṃyoga pubbaka apagamanam na atthi tathā api citta saṃyoga pubbakassa apagamanassa sambhavato iminā ca apādāna saññā
translated: And here, although there is no going away preceded by bodily union in the passages “Keep the mind away from evil” , “They go away from evil” , nevertheless, since there is going away preceded by mental union, this is the expression “going away from” .

original: Yattha pana apagamanakriyaṃ upāttaṃ ajjhāhaṭaṃ visayaṃ katvā pavattati, taṃ upāttavisayaṃ.
analyzed: yattha pana apagamana kriyam upāttam ajjhāhaṭam visayam katvā pavattati tam upātta visayam
translated: But that which occurs making as its objective field what is possessed, that is, what is appropriated, is “having a possessed objective field.”

original: Yathā – valāhakā vijjotate vijju, kusūlato pacatīti. Ettha ca “valāhakā nikkhamma,🔽kusūlato apanetvā”ti ca pubbakriyā ajjhāharīyati.
analyzed: yathā valāhakā vijjotate vijju kusūlataḥ pacati iti ettha ca valāhakā nikkhamma  kusūlataḥ apanetvā iti ca pubba kriyā ajjhāharīyati
translated: As in the following: “The lightning flashes from the cloud” , “The rice cooks in the pot” . And here the prior action is supplied, namely, “having gone out from the cloud” and “having been put into the pot” .

original: Anumeyyavisayaṃ yathā – māthurā pāṭaliputtakehi abhirūpā. Ettha hi kenaci guṇena ukkaṃsīyantīti anumeyyova kriyāviseso. Idha pana dūrantikādisutte vibhattaggahaṇena apādānasaññā.
analyzed: anumeyya visayam yathā māthurā pāṭaliputtakehi abhirūpā ettha hi kenacid guṇena ukkaṃsīyanti iti anumeyyaḥ uva kriyā visesaḥ idha pana dūra antika ādi sutte vibhatta ggahaṇena apādāna saññā
translated: With an inferred object, as in “The women of Mathurā are beautiful to the men of Pāṭaliputta” . Here the difference in the action is inferred by some quality. But here in the passage under discussion the notion of apposition is by the use of the locative case-ending.

original: Vuttañca
analyzed: vuttam ca
translated: And it is said:

original: “Niddiṭṭhavisayaṃ kiñci, upāttavisayaṃ tathā;
analyzed: niddiṭṭha visayam kiñci upātta visayam tathā
translated: “With a visible object, and likewise with a directly perceived object,🔽And with an inferred object too—

original: Anumeyyavisayañcāti, apādānaṃ tidhā mata”nti.
analyzed: anumeyya visayam ca ati apādānam tidhā
translated: Apposition is held to be threefold.”

original: Tadeva calācalavasena duvidhampi hoti.
analyzed: tat eva cala acala vasena
translated: That same apposition is of two kinds as movable and immovable.

original: Calaṃ yathā – dhāvatā hatthimhā patito aṅkusadhārī.
analyzed: calam yathā dhāvatā hatthimhā patitaḥ aṅkusa dhārī
translated: Movable, as in “The goad-bearer fell from the running elephant” .

original: Acalaṃ yathā – pabbatā otaranti vanacarā.
analyzed: acalam yathā pabbatāḥ otaranti vana carā
translated: Immovable, as in “The foresters descend from the mountain” .

original: Bhayahetumhi – corā bhayaṃ jāyati, taṇhāya jāyatī bhayaṃ, pāpato uttasati, akkhātari – upajjhāyā sikkhaṃ gaṇhāti, ācariyamhā adhīte, ācariyato suṇāti.
analyzed: bhaya hetumhi corā bhayam jāyati taṇhāya jāyatī bhayam pāpataḥ uttasati akkhātari upajjhāyā sikkham gaṇhāti ācariyamhā adhīte ācariyataḥ suṇāti
translated: In a cause of fear, as in “Fear arises from thieves” , “Fear arises from craving” , “One is afraid of evil” . In a revealer, as in “He learns the training from the preceptor” , “He learns from the teacher” , “He listens to the teacher.”

original: “Apādāna”nti adhikāro.
analyzed: apādānanti adhikāraḥ
translated: “The Ablative” is the topic.

original: 309. Dhātunāmānamupasaggayogādīsvapi ca.
analyzed: dhātu nāmānam upasagga yoga ādīsu api ca
translated: In the use of a base and a name, and in the use of a prefix, etc.,

original: Dhātavo ca nāmāni ca dhātunāmāni, tesaṃ avihitalakkhaṇānaṃ dhātunāmānaṃ payoge, upasaggayoge ca ādisaddena nipātayoge ca taṃyuttaṃ kārakaṃ apādānasaññaṃ hoti.🔽Dhātuppayoge tāva – parājiyoge yo asayho, pabhūyoge pabhavo, janiyoge jāyamānassa
analyzed: dhātavaḥ ca nāmāni ca dhātu nāmāni tesam avihita lakkhaṇānam dhātu nāmānam payoge upasagga yoge ca ādi saddena nipāta yoge ca tat yuttam kārakam apādāna saññam hoti  dhātu payoge tāva parāji yoge yaḥ a sayhaḥ pabhū yoge pabhavaḥ jani yoge jāyamānassa
translated: The words “bases” and “names” are compounded in the sense of “bases and names.” The case that is used in the expression of those bases and names, which have no fixed characteristics, is called the Ablative, when it is used in the sense of a prefix, etc.

original: pakati ca. Yathā – buddhasmā parājenti aññatitthiyā. Himavatā pabhavanti pañca mahānadiyo,
analyzed: ca yathā  buddhasma parājenti añña titthiyāḥ himavatā pabhavanti pañca mahā nadiyo
translated: In the use of a base, first of all, in the use of a base in the sense of “superior to,” as in “The non-Buddhists are defeated by the Buddha,” “The five great rivers have their source in the Himalayas,”

original: anavatattamhā mahāsarā pabhavanti, aciravatiyā pabhavanti kunnadiyo. Kāmato jāyatī
analyzed: mahā sarā pabhavanti aciravatiyā pabhavanti kunnadiyā kāmataḥ jāyatī
translated: “The great lakes have their source in the snow-covered mountains,” “The streams have their source in the Aciravatī,” “Sorrow arises from love,”

original: soko, yasmā so jāyate gini, urasmā jāto putto, kammato jātaṃ indriyaṃ.
analyzed: sokaḥ yasmā saḥ jāyate urasmā jātaḥ putto kammataḥ jātam indriyaṃ
translated: “The son is born from the womb,” “The faculty is born from kamma.”

original: Nāmappayoge aññatthitarādīhi yutte – nāññatra dukkhā sambhoti, nāññaṃ dukkhā nirujjhati, tato aññena kammena, tato itaraṃ, ubhato sujāto putto iccādi.
analyzed: nāma ppayoge aññatthitara ādīhi yutte na aññatra dukkhā na aññam dukkhā nirujjhati tatas aññena kammena tatas itaram ubhatas sujātaḥ putto iccādi
translated: In the use of a name, when it is used with aññattha, etc., as in “There is no happiness apart from suffering,” “Nothing else than suffering ceases,” “By another kind of kamma than that,” “The other,” “The son is well born on both sides,” etc.

original: Upasaggayuttesu apaparīhi vajjanatthehi yoge, mariyādābhividhiatthe āyoge patinā🔽patinidhipatidānatthena yoge ca. Yathā – apasālāya āyanti vāṇijā, sālaṃ vajjetvāti
analyzed: upasagga yuttesu apa parīhi vajjana atthehi yoge mariyādā abhividhi atthe ā yoge patinā  pati nidhi pati dāna atthena yoge ca yathā apa sālāya āyanti vāṇijā sālam vajjetvā ati
translated: In the case of the compound with upasagga, in the sense of ‘going to’, as in the following:🔽In the sense of ‘going beyond’, as in the following:

original: attho. Tathā paripabbatā devo vassati, pabbataṃ vajjetvāti attho. Mariyādāyaṃ – āpabbatā
analyzed: attho tathā paripabbatā devaḥ vassati pabbatam vajjetvā ati attho mariyādāyam āpabbatā

original: khettaṃ. Abhividhimhi – ābrahmalokā saddo abbhuggacchati, brahmalokaṃ abhibyāpetvāti🔽attho. Patinidhimhi – buddhasmā pati sāriputto dhammadesanāya ālapati temāsaṃ. Patidāne
analyzed: khettam abhividhimhi ābrahmalokā saddaḥ abbhut gacchati brahma lokam abhibyāpetvā ati  attho patinidhimhi buddhasma pati sāriputto dhamma desanāya ālapati temāsam pati dāne
translated: In the sense of ‘going over’, as in the following:🔽In the sense of ‘going back’, as in the following:

analyzed: telasma pati dadāti kanakamassa hiraññasma pati dadāti
translated: In the sense of ‘going forth’, as in the following:

original: Nipātayuttesu rite nānā vinādīhi yoge – rite saddhammā kuto sukhaṃ labhati. Te bhikkhū🔽nānākulā pabbajitā. Vinā saddhammā natthañño koci nātho loke vijjati. Ariyehi puthagevāyaṃ
analyzed: nipāta yuttesu r ite nānā vina ādīhi yoge rite saddhammā kutas sukham labhati te bhikkhū 🔽nānā kulāḥ pabbajitāḥ vinā saddhammāḥ na tthaññaḥ koci nāthaḥ loke vijjati ariyehi puthak eva ayam
translated: In the case of the compound with nipāta, in the sense of ‘being joined with’, as in the following:

original: jano, yāva brahmalokā saddo abbhuggacchati.
analyzed: janaḥ yāva brahma lokā saddaḥ abbhut gacchati
translated: and the people, up to the world of Brahmā, heard the sound.

Rakkhaṇatthānamicchitaṃ.🔽Rakkhaṇatthānaṃ dhātūnaṃ payoge yaṃ icchitaṃ, taṃ kārakaṃ apādānasaññaṃ hoti, cakārādhikārato
analyzed: apiggahaṇena pañcamī migaṃ  luddako itas pakkhasmā migam vijjhati iti vuttam hoti evam māsasmā bhuñjati bhojanam  kosāḥ vijjhati kuñjaram  ca sadda ggahaṇena pa bhu ti ādi atthe tad attha ppayoge ca yatas ham bhagini ariyāya jātiyā  jātaḥ yatas sarāmi attānam yatas pattaḥ asmi viññutam yatvā adhikaraṇam enam yatas  yatas paṭṭhāya tatas paṭṭhāya iccādi  rakkhaṇa tthānam icchitam  rakkhaṇa atthānam dhātūnam payoge yam icchitam tam kārakam apādāna saññam hoti cakāra adhikārato

original: Anicchitaṃ yathā – pāpā cittaṃ nivāraye, pāpānivārenti, rājato vā corato vā aggito vā udakato vā nānābhayato vā nānārogato vā nānāupaddavato vā ārakkhaṃ gaṇhantu.
analyzed: an icchitam yathā pāpā cittam nivāraye rājataḥ vā corataḥ vā aggitaḥ vā udakataḥ vā nānā bhayataḥ vā nānā rogataḥ vā nānā upaddavataḥ vā ārakkham gaṇhantu
translated: Unwanted: as in “Keep off the evil thoughts,” “They keep off the evil thoughts,” “Let them take care against the king, against thieves, against fire, against water, against various dangers, against various diseases, against various calamities.”

original: “Icchita”miti vattate.
analyzed: icchitam iti vattate
translated: “Wanted” is said.

original: 311. Yena vā’dassanaṃ.
analyzed: yena
translated: By whom there is non-seeing.

original: Yena adassanamicchitaṃ antaradhāyantena, taṃ kārakaṃ apādānasaññaṃ hoti vā, antaradhānevāyaṃ. Upajjhāyā antaradhāyati sisso, nilīyatīti attho. Mātāpitūhi antaradhāyati putto.
analyzed: yena adassanam icchitam antaradhāyantena tam kārakam apādāna saññam hoti vā antaradhānā iva ayam upajjhāyā antaradhāyati sissaḥ nilīyati iti attho mātā pitūhi antaradhāyati putto
translated: By whom there is wanted non-seeing, that maker is the sign of the ablative case, or it is the ablative case itself. The pupil disappears by the preceptor; the meaning is, he vanishes. The son disappears by the parents.

original: Vāti kiṃ? Jetavane antarahito. Yenāti kiṃ? Yakkho tattheva antaradhāyati.
analyzed: vāti kim jetavane antarahitaḥ yena ati kim yakkhaḥ tattha iva antaradhāyati
translated: By what? As in “Disappeared in the Jeta Grove.” By what? As in “The ogre disappeared right there.”

original: 312. Dūrantikaddhakālanimmānatvālopadisāyogavibhattārappayoga suddhappamocana hetu vivittappamāṇa pubbayoga bandhana guṇavacana pañha kathanathokākattūsu ca.
analyzed: dūra antika ddha kāla nimmāna tva ālopa disā yoga vibhatta āra ppayoga suddha ppamocana hetu vivitta ppamāṇa pubbayoga bandhana guṇavacana pañha kathana thokākattūsu ca
translated: In the case of far, near, beginning, end, time, creation, illumination, addition, direction, conjunction, separation, attainment, application, purification, release, cause, solitude, measure, prior application, bondage, quality, statement, question, and answer, and in the case of the crow.

original: Dūratthe, antikatthe, addhanimmāne, kālanimmāne, tvālope, disāyoge, vibhatte, āratippayoge,
analyzed: dūra atthe antika atthe addha nimmāne kāla nimmāne tu ā lope disā yoge vibhatte āra tippayoge
translated: In the far-away, in the near-at-hand, in the middle, in the future, in the past, in the directions, in the combination of directions, in the case of the analysis, in the case of the application of the analysis,

original: suddhatthappayoge, pamocanatthappayoge, hetvatthe, vivittatthappayoge, pamāṇatthe,
analyzed: suddha ttha ppayoge pamocana ttha ppayoge hetu atthe vivitta ttha ppayoge pamāṇa tthe
translated: in the case of the application of the meaning of purity, in the case of the application of the meaning of release, in the case of the meaning of cause, in the case of the application of the meaning of seclusion, in the case of the meaning of measure,

original: pubbayoge, bandhanatthappayoge, guṇavacane, pañhe, kathane, thokatthe, akattari ca🔽yadavadhibhūtaṃ, hetukammādibhūtañca, taṃ kārakaṃ apādānasaññaṃ hoti, casaddena yathāyogaṃ
analyzed: pubba yoge bandhana ttha ppayoge guṇavacane pañhe kathane thokatthe a kattari ca  yad avadhi bhūtam hetu kamma ādi bhūtam ca tam kārakam apādāna saññam hoti ca saddena yathāyogam
translated: in the case of the application of the meaning of the past, in the case of the application of the meaning of bondage, in the case of the expression of a quality, in the case of a question, in the case of a statement, in the case of the meaning of a little, and in the case of the non-doing,

original: dutiyā, tatiyā, chaṭṭhī ca.
analyzed: dutiyā tatiyā chaṭṭhī ca
translated: that which is the limit, and that which is the cause, the action, etc., is the instrument, and it is called the ablative. By the word “and” is meant that it is the second, the third, and the sixth

original: Ettha ca dūrantikañca dūrantikatthañcāti dūrantikanti sarūpekasesaṃ katvā vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ, tena dūrantikatthappayoge, tadatthe ca apādānasañño hoti.🔽Dūratthappayoge tāva – kīvadūro ito naḷakāragāmo, tato have dūrataraṃ vadanti, gāmato
analyzed: ettha ca dūra antikam ca dūra antika attham ca ati dūra antikam iti sarūpa ekasesam katvā vuttanti daṭṭhabbam tena dūra antika attha payoge tad atthe ca apādāna saññaḥ hoti  dūra attha ppayoge tāva kīva dūraḥ itas naḷakāra gāmaḥ tatas have dūrataram vadanti gāmataḥ
translated: Herein, the far-away and the meaning of the far-away should be regarded as stated by way of the substitution of a synonym, namely, “the far-away.” Therefore, in the case of the application of the meaning of the far-away, and in the case of the meaning of that, it is called the ablative.

original: nātidūre. Ārakā te moghapurisā imasmā dhammavinayā, ārakā tehi bhagavā. Dūratthe
analyzed: na atidūre ārakā te moghapurisāḥ imasmai dhamma vinayāḥ ārakā tehi bhagavā dūratthe
translated: In the case of the application of the meaning of the far-away, first of all, “How far is the village of Nalakara from here?” “They say it is even further from there.” “Not too far from the village.” “Far away, O foolish man, are you from this Dhamma and Discipline.” “Far away are they from the Blessed One.” In the far-away

original: – dūratova namassanti, addasa dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
analyzed: dūratas iva namassanti addasa dūratas iva āgacchantam
translated: They worship him from afar: he saw him coming from afar.

original: Antikatthappayoge – antikaṃ gāmā, āsannaṃ gāmā, samīpaṃ gāmā, gāmassa samīpanti attho.
analyzed: antika attha ppayoge antikam gāmā āsannam gāmā samīpam gāmā gāmassa samīpam ti atthaḥ
translated: In the case of the locative of place, the meaning is ‘near the village’, ‘close to the village’, ‘in the vicinity of the village’, ‘in the neighbourhood of the village’.

original: Dutiyā, tatiyā ca, dūraṃ gāmaṃ āgato, dūrena gāmena āgato, dūrato gāmā āgatoti attho.
analyzed: dutiyā tatiyā ca dūram gāmam āgataḥ dūrena gāmena āgataḥ dūratas gāmā āgato iti attho
translated: The second and third are ‘he has come from the village’, ‘he has come from the distance of the village’, ‘he has come from the village’.

original: Dūraṃ gāmena vā. Antikaṃ gāmaṃ āgato, antikaṃ gāmena vā, āsannaṃ gāmaṃ, āsannaṃ gāmena vā iccādi.
analyzed: dūram gāmena vā antikam gāmam āgataḥ antikam gāmena vā āsannam gāmam āsannam gāmena vā iccādi
translated: ‘From the distance of the village’ is the meaning. ‘He has come near the village’, ‘he has come near the distance of the village’, ‘he has come close to the village’, ‘he has come close to the distance of the village’.

original: Addhakālanimmāne nimmānaṃ nāma parimāṇaṃ, tasmiṃ gamyamāne – ito mathurāya catūsu yojanesu saṅkassaṃ, rājagahato pañcacattālīsayojanamatthake sāvatthi.
analyzed: addhakāla nimmāne nimmānam nāma parimāṇam tasmin gamyamāne itas mathurāya catūsu yojanesu saṅkassam rājagahataḥ pañcacattālīsa yojana matthake sāvatthi
translated: In the case of the locative of time, the meaning is ‘in the middle of the creation’, ‘creation’ being the measure. When it is being gone to, the meaning is ‘four leagues from Mathurā’, ‘Sāvatthī is fifty-four leagues from Rājagaha’.

original: Kālanimmāne – ito ekanavutikappamatthake vipassī bhagavā loke udapādi, ito vassasahassaccayena buddho loke uppajjissati.
analyzed: kāla nimmāne itas ekanavuti kappa matthake vipassī bhagavā loke udapādi itas vassa sahassa cayena buddhaḥ loke uppajjissati
translated: In the case of the locative of time, the meaning is ‘ninety-one aeons ago the Blessed One Vipassī arose in the world’, ‘a thousand years from now a Buddha will arise in the world’.

original: Tvāpaccayantassa lopo nāma tadatthasambhavepi avijjamānatā, tasmiṃ tvālope kammādhikaraṇesu
analyzed: lopaḥ nāma tad attha sambhave pi avijjamāna tā tasmin tu ālope kamma adhikaraṇesu
translated: In the case of the locative of cause, the meaning is ‘loss of the tvā affix even when the sense is there’, ‘loss of the tvā affix’ being the non-existence of the affix. In the case of the locative of cause, the meaning is ‘in the case of the action and the instrument’.

original: – pāsādā saṅkameyya, pāsādaṃ abhiruhitvā saṅkameyyāti attho. Tathā hatthikkhandhā🔽saṅkameyya, abhidhammā pucchanti, abhidhammaṃ sutvā vā, abhidhammā kathayanti, abhidhammaṃ🔽paṭhitvā vā, āsanā vuṭṭhaheyya, āsane nisīditvā vā.🔽Disatthavācīhi yoge, disatthe ca – ito sā purimā disā, ito sā dakkhiṇā disā, ito
analyzed: pāsādā saṅkameyya pāsādam abhiruhitvā saṅkameyya ati tathā hatthi khandhā  saṅkameyya abhidhammā pucchanti abhidhammam sutvā vā abhidhammā kathayanti abhidhammam  paṭhitvā vā āsanā vuṭṭhaheyya āsane nisīditvā vā  dis attha vācīhi yoge dis atthe ca itas sā purimā disā itas sā dakkhiṇā disā itas
translated: He should go down from the stilt house and go up to the stilt house. He should go down from the elephant’s back and go up on the elephant’s back.🔽They ask about the Abhidhamma, or after hearing the Abhidhamma, or after reciting the Abhidhamma,🔽he should get up from his seat, or after sitting on the seat.🔽In the case of the directions and the meaning of the directions,🔽This is the eastern direction, this is the southern direction,

original: sā pacchimā disā, ito sā uttarā disā, avīcito uparibhavaggā, uddhaṃ pādatalā, adho🔽kesamatthakā iccādi. Disatthe – puratthimato dakkhiṇatotiādi. Ettha pana sattamiyatthe🔽topaccayopi bhavissati.🔽Vibhattaṃ nāma sayaṃ vibhattasseva tadaññato guṇena vibhajanaṃ, tasmiṃ vibhatte –🔽yato paṇītataro vā visiṭṭhataro vā natthi, attadanto tato varaṃ. Kiñcāpi dānato sīlameva
analyzed: sā pacchimā disā itas sā uttarā disā avīcitaḥ upari bha vaggāḥ uddham pāda talāḥ adhas 🔽kesa matthakāḥ iccādi disa atthe puratthimataḥ dakkhiṇatas tiādi ettha pana sattamiya tthe 🔽to paccayaḥ pi bhavissati 🔽vibhattam nāma sayam vibhattassa iva tad aññatas guṇena vibhajanam tasmim vibhatte 🔽yatas paṇītataraḥ vā visiṭṭhataraḥ vā natthi atta danto tatas varam kiñcā api dānataḥ sīlam eva

He might descend from the couch and ascend the chair. He might descend from the chair and ascend the bed. He might descend from the bed and ascend the couch. He might descend from the couch and ascend the chair. He might descend from the chair and ascend the bed. He might descend from the bed and ascend the couch. He might descend from the couch and ascend the chair. He might descend from the chair and ascend the bed. He might descend from the bed and ascend the couch. He might descend from the couch and ascend the chair. He might descend from the chair and ascend the bed. He might descend from the bed and ascend the couch. He might descend from the couch and ascend the chair. He might descend from the chair and ascend the bed. He might descend from the bed and ascend the couch. He might descend from the couch and ascend the chair. He might descend from the chair and ascend the bed. He might descend from the bed and ascend the couch. He might descend from the couch and ascend the chair. He might descend from the chair and ascend the bed. He might descend from the bed and ascend the couch. He might descend from the couch and ascend the chair. He might descend from the chair and ascend the bed. He might descend from the bed and ascend the couch. He might descend from the couch and ascend the chair. He might descend from the chair and ascend the bed. He might descend from the bed and ascend the couch. He might descend from the couch and ascend the chair.

original: varaṃ, tato mayā sutā assutameva bahutaraṃ, sīlameva sutā seyyo. Chaṭṭhī ca, channavutīnaṃ
analyzed: varam tatas mayā sutāḥ assutam eva bahutaram sīlam eva sutā chaṭṭhī ca channavutīnam
translated: But what I have heard is virtue, and that is better.

original: pāsaṇḍānaṃ pavaraṃ yadidaṃ sugatavinayo.
analyzed: yat idam sugata vinayaḥ
translated: And of the six heretical teachers, the most excellent is Nigantha Nāṭaputta.

original: Āratippayogo nāma viramaṇatthasaddappayogo. Tattha – asaddhammā ārati, virati pāpā, pāṇātipātā veramaṇī, adinnādānā paṭivirato, appaṭivirato musāvādā.
analyzed: āratippayogo nāma viramaṇa attha sadda ppayogo tattha asat dhammā ārati virati pāpā pāṇātipātā veramaṇī adinnādānā paṭivirataḥ appaṭivirataḥ musāvādā
translated: The meaning of ‘disinclination’ is the meaning of ‘discontinuance’. Herein, disinclination is from bad ideas, and discontinuance is from evil, and abstinence is from killing breathing things, and refraining is from taking what is not given, and not refraining is from lying.

original: Suddhatthappayoge – lobhanīyehi dhammehi suddho asaṃsaṭṭho, mātito ca pitito ca suddho anupakkuṭṭho agarahito.
analyzed: suddha ttha ppayoge lobhanīyehi dhammehi suddhaḥ a saṃsaṭṭhaḥ mātitaḥ ca pititaḥ ca suddhaḥ an upakkuṭṭhaḥ a garahito
translated: In the meaning of ‘purity’ it is pure and unadulterated by ideas provocative of greed, and he is pure in mother and father and is not reproved for not being reserved.

original: Pamocanatthappayoge – parimutto dukkhasmāti vadāmi, mutto mārabandhanā, na te muccanti maccunā, muttohaṃ sabbapāsehi.
analyzed: pamocana attha ppayoge parimuttaḥ dukkhasma ati vadāmi muttaḥ māra bandhanā na te muccanti maccunā muttaḥ aham sabba pāsehi
translated: In the meaning of ‘being freed’ it is that I say he is freed from suffering, and he is freed from Mara’s bonds, and they are not freed from death, and I am freed from all snares.

original: Hetvatthe, sarūpekasesassa gahitattā hetvatthappayoge ca sabbanāmato – kasmā nu tumhaṃ
analyzed: hetu atthe sarūpa ikasesassa gahita ttā hetu attha ppayoge ca sabba nāmataḥ kasmā nu tumham
translated: In the meaning of ‘cause’ and in the meaning of ‘being freed’ it is all the nouns in the case-ending, since the case-ending is taken as the same in form. Why is it that you,

original: daharā na mīyare, kasmā idheva maraṇaṃ bhavissati, kasmā hetunā, yasmā ca kammāni
analyzed: daharāḥ na mīyare kasmai idhā iva maraṇam bhavissati kasmai hetunā yasmai ca kammāni
translated: why is it that they, why is it that you are not dying young, why is it that death will be here, why is it that it is by cause, and why is it that it is by action?

original: karonti, yasmā tiha bhikkhave, tasmā tiha bhikkhave evaṃ sikkhitabbaṃ, tasmā buddhosmi
analyzed: karonti yasmā tiha bhikkhave tasmā tiha bhikkhave evam sikkhitabbam tasmā buddhaḥ asmi
translated: Because, monks, therefore, monks, thus, monks, therefore, monks, should train thus, therefore, I am

original: brāhmaṇa, yasmā kāraṇā, tasmā kāraṇā, kiṃ kāraṇā. Dutiyā, chaṭṭhī ca, kiṃ kāraṇaṃ,
analyzed: brāhmaṇa tasmai kāraṇā kim kāraṇā dutiyā chaṭṭhī ca kim kāraṇam
translated: a Buddha, monks, because, monks, for what reason, for what reason, for what reason? The second and sixth (cases) are: for what reason?

original: taṃ kissa hetu, kissa tumhe kilamatha.🔽Kena hetunā, kena kāraṇena, yena midhekacce sattā, tena nimittena, tena vuttamiccādīsu “hetvatthe cā”ti tatiyā.🔽Vivittaṃ nāma vivecanaṃ, tadatthappayoge – vivitto pāpakā dhammā, vivicceva kāmehi, vivicca akusalehi dhammehi.
analyzed: tam kissa hetu kissa tumhe  kena hetunā kena kāraṇena yena midhā ekacce sattā tena nimittena tena vuttam iccādīsu hetu atthe ca ati tatiyā  vivittam nāma vivecanam tad attha ppayoge pāpakāḥ dhammā vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi
translated: For what reason do you weary yourselves?

original: Pamāṇatthe tatiyā ca, āyāmato ca vitthārato ca yojanaṃ, gambhīrato ca puthulato ca yojanaṃ candabhāgāya parimāṇaṃ, parikkhepato navayojanasataparimāṇo majjhimapadeso.🔽Dīghaso nava vidatthiyo sugatavidatthiyā pamāṇikā kāretabbā.
analyzed: pamāṇa atthe tatiyā ca āyāmataḥ ca vitthārataḥ ca yojanam gambhīrataḥ ca puthulataḥ ca yojanam canda bhāgāya parimāṇam parikkhepataḥ nava yojana sata parimāṇaḥ majjhima padesaḥ 🔽nava vidatthiyaḥ sugata vidatthiyā pamāṇikā kāretabbā
translated: For what reason, for what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means, by what reason, by what means

original: Ettha ca “smāhismiṃna”miccādito “smā”ti ca “so, vā”ti ca vattamāne
analyzed: ettha ca sma ahi smiṃnam it ca āditas sma ati ca saḥ vāti ca vattamāne
