translated: And here the form smā is the substitute for smī in the first person singular, and the form so is the substitute for so in the first person singular.

original: 313. Dīghorehi.
analyzed: dīgha ūra ihi
translated: In dīghorehi,

original: Dīgha oraicceteti smāvacanassa soādeso hoti vā.
analyzed: dīghaḥ sma a vacanassa saḥ ādesaḥ hoti vā
translated: the form smā is the substitute for smī in the first person singular, and the form so is the substitute for so in the first person singular.

original: Dīghaso, dīghamhā vā, [oraso, oramhā vā] tatiyā ca, yojanaṃ āyāmena, yojanaṃ vitthārena, yojanaṃ ubbedhena sāsaparāsi.🔽Paṭhamatthavācakena pubbasaddena yogo pubbayogo, ettha ca pubbaggahaṇaṃ adisatthavuttino🔽pubbādiggahaṇassupalakkhaṇanti daṭṭhabbaṃ, tena parādiyogepi. Yathā – pubbeva me
analyzed: dīghasaḥ dīghamhā vā orasaḥ oramhā vā tatiyā ca yojanam āyāmena yojanam vitthārena yojanam ubbedhena  paṭhama attha vācakena pubba saddena yogaḥ pubba yogaḥ ettha ca pubba ggahaṇam adisa ttha vuttinaḥ  pubba ādi ggahaṇassa upalakkhaṇan ti daṭṭhabbam tena para ādi yoge pi yathā pubbā iva me
translated: Dīghaso, dīghamhā vā, [oraso, oramhā vā] tatiyā ca, yojanaṃ āyāmena, yojanaṃ vitthārena, yojanaṃ ubbedhena sāsaparāsi.🔽The compound pubbayoga is a compound consisting of a word denoting a former time together with the word pubbe. And here the word pubba should be regarded as a mere indication of the word denoting the former time,

original: bhikkhave sambodhā, ito pubbenāhosi, tato paraṃ paccantimā janapadā, dhātuliṅgehi
analyzed: bhikkhave sambodhau itas pubbena ahosi tatas param paccantimāḥ janapadāḥ dhātu liṅgehi
translated: so that it applies also in the case of the words denoting the latter time, etc., thus: Pubbeva me bhikkhave sambodhā, ito pubbenāhosi, tato paraṃ paccantimā janapadā, dhātuliṅgehi

original: parā paccayā, tato aparena samayena, tato uttarimpi iccādi.
analyzed: parā paccayā tatas aparena samayena tatas uttarimpi iccādi
translated: parā paccayā, tato aparena samayena, tato uttarimpi iccādi.

original: Bandhanatthappayoge bandhanahetumhi iṇe pañcamī, tatiyā ca hoti, satasmā baddho naro raññā, satena vā baddho naro.
analyzed: bandhana attha ppayoge bandhana hetumhi iṇe pañcamī tatiyā ca hoti satasmā baddhaḥ naraḥ raññā satena vā baddhaḥ naraḥ
translated: In the case of the compound bandhanatthappayoga, the fifth and third cases are used with the word iṇa in the sense of the cause of bondage, thus: Satasmā baddho naro raññā, satena vā baddho naro.

original: Phalasādhanahetubhūtassa guṇassa vacanaṃ guṇavacanaṃ, tasmiṃ guṇavacane pañcamī,🔽tatiyā ca, issariyā janaṃ rakkhati rājā, issariyena vā, sīlato naṃ pasaṃsanti, sīlena
analyzed: phala sādhana hetu bhūtassa guṇassa vacanam guṇa vacanam tasmim guṇa vacane pañcamī  tatiyā ca issariyā janam rakkhati rājā issariyena vā sīlataḥ nam pasaṃsanti sīlena
translated: The statement of a quality which is the cause of the success of the fruit is a statement of a quality. The fifth case is used with a statement of a quality,

original: vā, paññāya vimuttimano iccādi.
analyzed: vā paññāya vimutti manaḥ iccādi
translated: and the third case is used with sovereignty, as in “The king protects the people with sovereignty” or “They praise him for his virtue” or “He is liberated in mind through wisdom.”

original: Pañhakathanesu – kutosi tvaṃ, kuto bhavaṃ, pāṭaliputtato. Ettha ca kathanaṃ nāma vissajjanaṃ.🔽Thokatthe asatvavacane karaṇe tatiyā ca, thokā muccati, thokena muccati vā, appamattakā muccati, appamattakena vā, kicchā muccati, kicchena vā.
analyzed: pañha kathanesu kutas asi tvam kutas bhavam pāṭaliputtato ettha ca kathanam nāma vissajjanam  thoka atthe a sattva vacane karaṇe tatiyā ca thokā muccati thokena muccati vā appamattakā muccati appamattakena vā kicchā muccati kicchena vā
translated: In answers to questions: “Where are you from?” “Where does the lord come from?” “From Pāṭaliputta.” And here “answer” is replying.🔽The third case is used with a little in the sense of a small amount, as in “He is released with little” or “He is released with a little,” “He is released with a small amount” or “He is released with a small amount of effort.”

original: Akattari akārake ñāpakahetumhi – kammassa katattā upacitattā ussannattā vipulattā
analyzed: a kattari a kārake ñāpaka hetumhi kammassa kata ttā upacita ttā ussanna ttā vipula ttā
translated: The third case is used with a non-doer, a non-maker, an informer, and a cause, as in “Through the deed being done, accumulated, stored up, and increased,

original: uppannaṃ hoti cakkhuviññāṇa, na tāvidaṃ nāmarūpaṃ ahetukaṃ sabbattha sabbadā sabbesañca
analyzed: uppannam hoti cakkhu viññāṇa na tāva idam nāma rūpam ahetukam sabbattha sabbadā sabbesam ca
translated: eye-consciousness has arisen.” It is not that this name-and-form is without cause, because it is not the case that everywhere, always, and for everyone

original: ekasadisabhāvāpattito.
analyzed: eka sadisa bhāva āpattitaḥ
translated: it would come about in the same way.🔽Eternal because of non-existence after burning,

original: Hutvā abhāvato niccā, udayabbayapīḷanā;
analyzed: hutvā abhāvataḥ niccā udaya bbaya pīḷanā
translated: oppression by rise and fall,

original: Dukkhā avasavattittā, anattāti tilakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: dukkhā anattā ati ti lakkhaṇam
translated: Suffering, because of being without self-control, and not-self, are the three characteristics.

original: “Pañcamī”ti vattate.
analyzed: pañcamī iti vattate
translated: The fifth case is used.

original: 314. Kāraṇatthe ca.
analyzed: kāraṇatthe ca
translated: And in the sense of cause.

original: Karoti attano phalanti kāraṇaṃ, kārakahetu [janakahetu], tasmiṃ kāraṇatthe ca pañcamīvibhatti🔽hoti, vikappenāyaṃ, hetvatthe tatiyāya ca vihitattā, ananubodhā appaṭivedhā catunnaṃ
analyzed: karoti phalanti kāraṇam kāraka hetu janaka hetu tasmin kāraṇa atthe ca pañcamī vibhatti  hoti vikappena ayam hetu atthe tatiyāya ca vihita ttā ananubodhā appaṭivedhā catunnam
translated: A cause is that which causes its own fruit, a productive cause. The fifth case is used in the sense of cause, because the instrumental case is used in the sense of instrument, and the genitive case is used in the sense of cause.

original: ariyasaccānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ adassanā evamidaṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ sandhāvitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ,
analyzed: ariya saccānam yathābhūtam a dassanā evam idam dīgham addhānam sandhāvitam saṃsaritam
translated: Because of not knowing, not penetrating, not seeing as they really are the four noble truths, thus for a long time you have wandered and transmigrated,

original: avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇaṃ, avijjāya tveva asesavirāganirodhā
analyzed: avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā saṅkhāra paccayā viññāṇam avijjāya tu eva asesa virāga nirodhā
translated: with ignorance as condition there are volitional formations, with volitional formations as condition there is consciousness, but with the remainderless fading away and cessation of ignorance

original: saṅkhāranirodho, saṅkhāranirodhā viññāṇanirodho, viññāṇanirodhā iccādi.
analyzed: saṅkhāra nirodho saṅkhāra nirodhā viññāṇa nirodhaḥ viññāṇa nirodhā iccādi
translated: there is the cessation of volitional formations, with the cessation of volitional formations there is the cessation of consciousness, with the cessation of consciousness there is the cessation of mentality-materiality, and so on.

original: Kasmiṃ atthe chaṭṭhī?
analyzed: kasmin atthe chaṭṭhī
translated: In what sense is the sixth case used?

original: 315. Sāmismiṃ chaṭṭhī.
analyzed: sāmismin chaṭṭhī
translated: . The sixth case is used in the sense of possession.

original: Ko ca sāmī?
analyzed: kaḥ ca sāmī
translated: And what is a possessor?

original: 316. Yassa vā pariggaho taṃ sāmī.
analyzed: yassa vā pariggahaḥ tam sāmī
translated: . One who has possession is a possessor.

original: Pariggayhatīti pariggaho, yo yassa pariggaho āyatto sambandhī, taṃ pati so attho sāmisañño hoti. Vāggahaṇena sāmitabba rujādiyogepi.
analyzed: pariggayhati iti pariggahaḥ yaḥ yassa pariggahaḥ āyattaḥ sambandhī tam so attho sāmi saññaḥ hoti vāc gahaṇena rujā ādi yoge pi
translated: “Possession” is what is possessed. The meaning of what is possessed by a person is “possessed by him.” The word “and” includes pain, etc., which are to be possessed.

original: Ettha ca kriyābhisambandhābhāvā na kārakatā sambhavati. Sāmibhāvo hi kriyākārakabhāvassa🔽phalabhāvena gahito, tathā hi “rañño puriso”ti vutte yasmā rājā dadāti, puriso ca
analyzed: ettha ca kriyā abhisambandha abhāvā na kāraka tā sambhavati sāmibhāvaḥ hi kriyā kāraka bhāvassa  phala bhāvena gahito tathā hi rañño puriso ti vutte yasmā rājā dadāti puriso ca
translated: And here, since there is no relation to a verb, the function of a nominative is not possible. For the state of being a master is included in the state of being a result of a verb.🔽For when it is said “the king’s man,” it is understood that the king gives and the man receives,

original: patiggaṇhāti, tasmā “rājapuriso”ti viññāyati. Evaṃ yo yassa āyatto sevakādibhāvena
analyzed: patiggaṇhāti tasmā rāja purisaḥ ti viññāyati evam yaḥ yassa āyattaḥ sevaka ādi bhāvena
translated: so that the man is called “the king’s man.” So too, whatever is related to something else as a servant, etc., or as an object,

original: vā bhaṇḍabhāvena vā samīpa samūhāvayavavikāra kāriyaavatthā jāti guṇa kriyādivasena🔽vā, tassa sabbassāpi so sambandhādhārabhūto visesanaṭṭhānī āgamīvasena tividhopi
analyzed: vā bhaṇḍa bhāvena vā samīpa samūha avayava vikāra jāti guṇa kriyā ādi vasena  vā tassa sabbassa api so sambandha ādhāra bhūtaḥ visesana ṭṭhānī āgamī vasena tividhaḥ api
translated: or as something in the vicinity, or as a collection, or as a part, or as a transformation, or as something to be done, or as a class, or as a quality, or as an action, etc.,

original: attho sāmī nāmāti gahetabbo.
analyzed: atthaḥ sāmī nāma ati gahetabbo
translated: all that is to be taken as the meaning of “master” in the three senses of the master who comes, the master who is possessed, and the master who is related.

original: Vuttañca🔽“Kriyākārakasañjāto,
analyzed: vuttam ca  kriyā kāraka sañjātaḥ
translated: And it is said:🔽The relation of master and man,

original: Assedaṃ bhāvahetuko;
analyzed: bhāva hetukaḥ
translated: The cause of being, is without substance;

original: Sambandho nāma so attho,
analyzed: sambandhaḥ nāma saḥ attho
translated: The meaning of “relation” is that,

original: Tattha chaṭṭhī vidhīyate.
analyzed: tattha chaṭṭhī vidhīyate
translated: And the locative case is used there.

original: Pāratantyañhi sambandho,
analyzed: pāratantyam hi sambandhaḥ
translated: For the genitive case is a relation of dependence,

original: Tattha chaṭṭhī bhavetito;🔽Upādhiṭṭhānā gamito,
analyzed: tattha chaṭṭhī bhava iti  upādhiṭṭhānā gamitaḥ
translated: And here the sixth is stated

original: Na visesyādito tito”ti.
analyzed: na visesyā t itaḥ ti taḥ ti
translated: By the locative case, not by the ablative.

original: Visesanato tāva – rañño purisoti, ettha ca rājā purisaṃ aññasāmito viseseti nivattetīti
analyzed: visesanato tāva rañño puriso ti ettha ca rājā purisam añña sāmitaḥ viseseti nivatteti iti
translated: As to the distinction: in the expression “the king’s man” the king distinguishes the man from another man who is not his man, he sets him apart from him,

original: visesanaṃ, puriso tena visesīyatīti visesitabbo, evaṃ sabbattha visesitabbayoge visesanatova chaṭṭhī.
analyzed: visesanam puriso tena visesīyati iti visesitabbaḥ evam sabbattha visesitabba yoge visesanataḥ va chaṭṭhī
translated: and the man is what is distinguished by the king. So in all the rest the sixth is used with what is distinguished in the locative case.

original: Bhaṇḍena sambandhe – pahūtaṃ me dhanaṃ sakka, etassa paṭivīso, bhikkhussa pattacīvaraṃ.
analyzed: bhaṇḍena sambandhe pahūtam me dhanam sakka etassa bhikkhussa pattacīvaram
translated: As to the relation of ownership: “I have much wealth, Sakyan,” “This is his counterpart,” “The bhikkhu’s bowl and robes.”

original: Samīpasambandhe – ambavanassa avidūre, nibbānasseva santike.
analyzed: samīpa sambandhe ambavanassa avidūre nibbānassa iva santike
translated: As to the relation of proximity: “Not far from the mango grove,” “Near to Nibbāna.”

original: Samūhasambandhe – suvaṇṇassa rāsi, bhikkhūnaṃ samūho.
analyzed: samūha sambandhe suvaṇṇassa rāsi bhikkhūnam samūhaḥ
translated: As to the relation of collection: “A mass of gold,” “A collection of bhikkhus.”

original: Avayavasambandhe – manussasseva te sīsaṃ, rukkhassa sākhā.
analyzed: avayava sambandhe manussassa iva te sīsam rukkhassa sākhā
translated: As to the relation of part: “That is the head of a man,” “That is a branch of the tree.”

original: Vikārasambandhe – suvaṇṇassa vikati, bhaṭṭhadhaññānaṃ sattu.
analyzed: vikāra sambandhe suvaṇṇassa bhaṭṭhadhaññānam sattu
translated: As to the relation of modification: “An alteration of gold,” “Flour of ground rice.”

original: Kāriyasambandhe – yavassa aṅkuro, meghassa saddo, puttāpi tassa bahavo, kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko.
analyzed: kāriya sambandhe yavassa aṅkuraḥ meghassa saddo puttāḥ api tassa bahavaḥ kammānam phalam vipākaḥ
translated: In the case of the relation of action, e.g. , the sprout of the barley, the sound of the cloud, he has many sons, the fruit of action is the result.

original: Avatthāsambandhe – khandhānaṃ pātubhāvo, khandhānaṃ jarā, khandhānaṃ bhedo.
analyzed: avatthā sambandhe khandhānam pātubhāvaḥ khandhānam jarā khandhānam bhedaḥ
translated: In the case of the relation of state, e.g. , the manifestation of the aggregates, the decay of the aggregates, the dissolution of the aggregates.

original: Jātisambandhe – manussassa bhāvo, manussānaṃ jāti.
analyzed: jāti sambandhe manussassa bhāvaḥ manussānam jāti
translated: In the case of the relation of birth, e.g. , the state of a human being, the birth of human beings.

original: Guṇasambandhe – suvaṇṇassa vaṇṇo, vaṇṇo na khīyetha tathāgatassa, buddhassa guṇaghoso,
analyzed: guṇa sambandhe suvaṇṇassa vaṇṇaḥ vaṇṇaḥ na khīyetha tathāgatassa buddhassa guṇa ghoso
translated: In the case of the relation of quality, e.g. , the colour of gold, the colour of the Tathāgata does not fade, the fame of the Buddha,

original: pupphānaṃ gandho, phalānaṃ raso, cittassa phusanā, sippikānaṃ sataṃ natthi, tilānaṃ
analyzed: pupphānam gandhaḥ phalānam rasaḥ cittassa phusanā sippikānam satam natthi tilānam
translated: the fragrance of flowers, the taste of fruits, the delight of the mind, there is no hundred of crafts, a handful of sesame seeds,

original: muṭṭhi, tesaṃ samāyogo, sandhino vimokkho, tathāgatassa paññāpāramiṃ ārabbha, pubbacariyaṃ
analyzed: muṭṭhi tesam samāyogaḥ sandhinaḥ vimokkho tathāgatassa paññāpāramiṃ ārabbha pubba cariyam
translated: their combination, the release of the joints, with reference to the perfection of wisdom of the Tathāgata, or his previous conduct,

original: vā, sukhaṃ te, dukkhaṃ te, cetaso parivitakko udapādi, paññāya paṭubhāvo, rūpassa
analyzed: vā sukham te dukkham te cetasaḥ parivitakkaḥ udapādi paññāya paṭu bhāvaḥ rūpassa
translated: are you happy? are you suffering? a thought occurred to your mind, the sharpness of wisdom, the lightness of form,

original: lahutā, rūpassa mudutā, rūpassa upacayo.
analyzed: lahu tā rūpassa mudu tā rūpassa upacayo
translated: the softness of form, the growth of form.

original: Kriyāsambandhe – pādassa ukkhipanaṃ, pādassa avakkhepanaṃ vā, hatthassa samiñjanaṃ,
analyzed: kriyā sambandhe pādassa ukkhipanam pādassa avakkhepanam vā hatthassa samiñjanam
translated: In the case of the relation of action, e.g. , the lifting up of the foot or the putting down of the foot, the bending of the hand,

original: pādānaṃ pasāraṇaṃ, dhātūnaṃ gamanaṃ, dhātūnaṃyeva ṭhānaṃ, nisajjā, sayanaṃ vā. Tathā🔽tassa nāmagottādi, tassa kāraṇaṃ, tassa mātāpitaro, tassa purato pāturahosi, tassa
analyzed: pasāraṇam dhātūnam gamanam ṭhānam nisajjā sayanam vā tathā  tassa nāma gotta ādi tassa kāraṇam tassa mātā pitaraḥ tassa puratas tassa
translated: the stretching of the feet, the going of the elements, the standing of the elements, sitting, lying down.

original: pacchato, nagarassa dakkhiṇato, vassānaṃ tatiye māse, na tassa upamā, kuverassa bali iccādi.
analyzed: pacchatas nagarassa dakkhiṇatas vassānam tatiye māse na tassa upamā kuverassa iccādi
translated: So too: his name and clan, his reason, his parents, he appeared in front of him, he appeared behind him, to the south of the town, in the third month of the rains, there is no simile for him, Kuvera’s offering, and so on.

original: Ṭhānito – yamedantassādeso, o avassa.
analyzed: ṭhāni taḥ ya m e t antassa ādesaḥ o avassa
translated: From place: the place where he was born, he did not rain.

original: Āgamito – puthassāgamo iccādi.
analyzed: āgamitaḥ puthassa āgamaḥ iccādi
translated: From coming: the coming of the multitude, and so on.

original: Sāmiyoge – devānamindo, migānaṃ rājā.
analyzed: sāmi yoge devānam indo migānam rājā
translated: In the compound: lord of the gods, king of the deer.

original: Tabba rujādiyoge – mahāsenāpatīnaṃ ujjhāpetabbaṃ vikanditabbaṃ viravitabbaṃ, devadattassa rujati, tassa rogo uppajjati, rajakassa vatthaṃ dadāti, musāvādassa ottappaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: mahā senāpatīnam ujjhāpetabbam vikanditabbam viravitabbam devadattassa rujati tassa rogaḥ uppajjati rajakassa vattham dadāti musāvādassa ottappam iccādi
translated: In the compound of what should be done, pain, etc.: for the generals it should be heated, it should be wailed, it should be lamented, Devadatta has pain, his sickness arises, he gives cloth to the laundryman, he is ashamed of lying, and so on.

original: “Kvaci, tatiyāsattamīna”nti ca vattate.
analyzed: kvaci tatiyā sattamī nanti ca vattate
translated: “Sometimes in the third and seventh” is said.

original: 317. Chaṭṭhī ca.
analyzed: chaṭṭhī ca
translated: And the sixth.

original: Tatiyāsattamīnamatthe kvaci chaṭṭhīvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: tatiyā sattamī nama tthe kvaci chaṭṭhī vibhatti hoti
translated: Sometimes the sixth case-ending is used in the sense of the third and seventh.

original: Yajassa karaṇe – pupphassa buddhaṃ yajati, pupphena vā, ghatassa aggiṃ juhoti.
analyzed: yajassa karaṇe pupphassa buddham yajati pupphena vā ghatassa aggim juhoti
translated: In the case of the doing of what is to be done: he worships the Buddha with a flower, or with flowers; he offers the fire sacrifice with a pot, or with a potful.

original: Suhitatthayoge – pattaṃ odanassa pūretvā, odanenāti attho. Imameva kāyaṃ pūraṃ nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati, pūraṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇassa, pūrati bālo pāpassa.
analyzed: su hita attha yoge pattam odanassa pūretvā odanena ati attho imam eva kāyam pūram nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati pūram hirañña suvaṇṇassa pūrati bālaḥ pāpassa
translated: In the case of the purpose of what is to be joined: having filled the bowl with rice, with rice, is the meaning. He considers this very body as filled with various kinds of impurities. Filled with gold and silver. The fool is filled with evil.

original: Tulyatthakimalamādiyoge – pitussa tulyo, pitarā vā tulyo, mātu sadiso, mātarā sadiso vā, kiṃ tassa ca tuṭṭhassa, kiṃ tena tuṭṭhenāti attho. Alaṃ tassa ca tuṭṭhassa.
analyzed: tulya attha kim alam ādi yoge pitussa tulyaḥ pitarā vā tulyaḥ mātu sadisaḥ mātarā sadisaḥ vā kim tassa ca tuṭṭhassa kim tena tuṭṭhena ati atthaḥ alam tassa ca tuṭṭhassa
translated: In the case of the joining of what has the same meaning as the prefix: equal to his father, or equal with his father; like his mother, or like with his mother. What is the use of his being pleased? What is the use of his being pleased with that? is the meaning. Enough of his being pleased.

original: Kattari kitappaccayayoge – sobhanā kaccāyanassa kati, kaccāyanena vā, rañño sammato,🔽raññā vā, evaṃ rañño pūjito, rañño sakkato, rañño apacito, rañño mānito, amataṃ tesaṃ
analyzed: kattari kitap paccaya yoge sobhanā kaccāyanassa kati kaccāyanena vā rañño sammataḥ  raññā vai evam raññaḥ pūjitaḥ raññaḥ sakkataḥ raññaḥ apacitaḥ raññaḥ mānitaḥ amatam tesam
translated: In the case of the joining of the agent and the instrument: how many are good for Kaccāyana? or with Kaccāyana; approved by the king,

original: bhikkhave aparibhuttaṃ, yesaṃ kāyagatāsati aparibhuttā iccādi.
analyzed: bhikkhave a paribhuttam yesam kāyagatā asati a paribhuttā iccādi
translated: or by the king; thus worshipped by the king, respected by the king, honoured by the king, esteemed by the king. The deathless, bhikkhus, is not to be tasted by those who have not tasted the mindfulness occupied with the body.

original: Sattamiyatthe kusalādiyoge – kusalā naccagītassa sikkhitā cāturitthiyo, kusalo tvaṃ🔽rathassa aṅgapaccaṅgānaṃ, kusalo maggassa, kusalo amaggassa, santi hi bhante uḷārā
analyzed: sattamiya tthe kusala ādi yoge kusalā nacca gītassa sikkhitā cāturitthiyaḥ kusalaḥ tvam  rathassa aṅga paccaṅgānam kusalaḥ maggassa kusalaḥ amaggassa santi hi bhante uḷārā
translated: In the sense of a group, as in the case of the seven kinds of consciousnesses, etc., there are the four kinds of women who are skilled in dancing and singing, you are skilled in the parts and sub-parts of a chariot, you are skilled in the path, you are skilled in the non-path, there are, venerable sir, great

original: yakkhā bhagavato pasannā, divasassa tikkhattuṃ, divase tikkhattuṃ vā, māsassa dvikkhattuṃ iccādi.
analyzed: yakkhāḥ bhagavataḥ pasannāḥ divasassa tikkhattum divase tikkhattum vā māsassa dvi kkhattum iccādi
translated: In the sense of the seventh case, in the combination of the profitable, etc., the seventh case is sometimes used: The four women skilled in dancing and singing are profitable, You are skilled in the parts and sub-parts of a chariot, You are skilled in the path, You are skilled in the non-path, For there are exalted yakkhas, venerable sir, who have confidence in the Blessed One, Three times a day, three times a night, Three times a day or three times a night, Two times a month, etc.

original: “Kvaci, chaṭṭhī”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: kvacid chaṭṭhī iti ca vattate
translated: And it is said: “Sometimes in the sixth case.”

original: 318. Dutiyāpañcamīnañca.
analyzed: dutiyā pañcamī nañca
translated: And in the second and fifth cases.

original: Dutiyāpañcamīnamatthe ca kvaci chaṭṭhīvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: dutiyā pañcamīnam atthe ca kvaci chaṭṭhī vibhatti hoti
translated: And in the sense of the second and fifth cases the seventh case is sometimes used.

original: Dutiyatthe kammani kitakayoge – tassa bhavanti vattāro, sahasā kammassa kattāro,🔽amatassa dātā, bhinnānaṃ sandhātā, sahitānaṃ anuppadātā, bodhetā pajāya, kammassa
analyzed: dutiya tthe kammani kitaka yoge tassa bhavanti vattāraḥ sahasā kammassa kattāraḥ  amatassa dātā bhinnānam sandhātā sahitānam anuppadātā bodhetā pajāya kammassa
translated: In the sense of the second case, in the combination of the doing and the cause of doing, they are his speakers, they are the doers of the deed suddenly,🔽They are the givers of the deathless, they are the unifiers of the divided, they are the non-arisers of those united, they are the enlighteners of the world, there is no doer of the deed,

original: kārako natthi, vipākassa ca vedako, avisaṃvādako lokassa, pāpānaṃ akaraṇaṃ sukhaṃ,
analyzed: kārakaḥ natthi vipākassa ca vedakaḥ a visaṃvādakaḥ lokassa pāpānam a karaṇam sukham
translated: And there is no experiencer of the result, he is not a deceiver of the world, the non-doing of evil is bliss,

original: catunnaṃ mahābhūtānaṃ upādāya pasādo, acchariyo arajakena vatthānaṃ rāgo, acchariyo
analyzed: catunnam mahābhūtānam upādāya pasādaḥ acchariyaḥ arajakena vatthānam rāgaḥ acchariyaḥ
translated: the clearness that is derived from the four great elementals, the dye of the cloth that is not made from lac, the dye of the cloth that is made from lac,

original: agopālakena gāvīnaṃ doho.
analyzed: a gopālakena gāvīnam dohaḥ
translated: The faith that is derived from the four great entities, the passion in the cloth that is not woven by a slave, the milk of the cow that is not tended by a cowherd.

original: Tathā saricchādīnaṃ kammani – mātu sarati, mātaraṃ sarati, na tesaṃ koci sarati, sattānaṃ kammappaccayā, puttassa icchati, puttamicchati.
analyzed: tathā sariccha ādīnam kammani mātu sarati mātaram sarati na tesam koci sarati sattānam kamma ppaccayā puttassa icchati puttam icchati
translated: So too in the case of the verbs sarati, etc., in the following: He remembers his mother, he remembers his father, no one remembers them, by kamma as condition, he desires a son, he desires a daughter.

original: Karotissa patiyatane ca – patiyatanaṃ abhisaṅkhāro, udakassa patikurute, udakaṃ patikurute, kaṇḍassa patikurute, kaṇḍaṃ patikurute.
analyzed: karotissa patiyatane ca patiyatanam abhisaṅkhāraḥ udakassa patikurute udakam patikurute kaṇḍassa patikurute kaṇḍam patikurute
translated: In the case of the verbs patiyatati and patiyatte: the formation is a formation, he conforms to the water, he conforms with the water, he conforms to the mud, he conforms with the mud.

original: Pañcamiyatthe parihānibhayatthayoge – assavanatā dhammassa parihāyanti, kiṃ nu kho🔽ahaṃ tassa sukhassa bhāyāmi, sabbe tasanti daṇḍassa, sabbe bhāyanti maccuno, bhīto
analyzed: pañcamiya atthe parihāni bhaya attha yoge a savana tā dhammassa parihāyanti kim nu kho  aham tassa sukhassa bhāyāmi sabbe tasanti daṇḍassa sabbe bhāyanti maccunaḥ bhīto
translated: In the case of the verbs assavanati, etc., in the following: they fall away from the non-hearing of the Dhamma, what should I fear

original: catunnaṃ āsivisānaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: catunnam āsi visānam it cādi
translated: of that happiness? All fear the rod, all fear death, he fears the fourfold poison, etc.

original: Kvacīti kiṃ? Gambhīrañca kathaṃ kattā, kālena dhammiṃ kathaṃ bhāsitā hoti, paresaṃ puññāni anumoditā, bujjhitā saccāni, kaṭaṃ kārako, pasavo ghātako.
analyzed: kvaci iti kim gambhīram ca katham kattā kālena dhammim katham bhāsitā hoti paresam puññāni anumoditā bujjhitā saccāni kaṭam kārako pasavaḥ ghātako
translated: Where? What? The speaker of profound talk, the one who spoke timely talk on Dhamma, the one who rejoiced in others’ merit, the one who understood the Truths, the one who made a cart, the one who killed an animal.

original: Tathā na niṭṭhādīsu ca – sukhakāmī vihāraṃ kato, rathaṃ katavanto, rathaṃ katāvī, kaṭaṃ katvā, kaṭaṃ karonto, kaṭaṃ karāno, kaṭaṃ kurumāno iccādi.
analyzed: tathā na niṭṭhā ādīsu ca sukha kāmī vihāram kataḥ ratham katavantaḥ ratham katāvī kaṭam katvā kaṭam karontaḥ kaṭam karāno kaṭam kurumānaḥ iccādi
translated: And so in the case of niṭṭhā, etc., the one who made a dwelling because he wanted happiness, the one who made a chariot, the one who made a chariot, the one who having made a cart, the one who is making a cart, the one who is making a cart, the one who is making a cart, etc.

original: Kasmiṃ atthe sattamī?🔽319. Okāse sattamī.
analyzed: kasmin atthe sattamī  okāse sattamī
translated: In what sense is the locative case?🔽. The locative is in the sense of location.

original: Okāsakārake sattamīvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: okāsa kārake sattamī vibhatti hoti
translated: The locative case-ending is used in the sense of location.

original: Ko ca okāso?
analyzed: kaḥ ca okāsaḥ
translated: And what is location?

original: 320. Yodhāro tamokāsaṃ.
analyzed: yodhāraḥ tamaḥ kāsam
translated: . The location is the container.

original: Ādhārīyati asminti ādhāro, adhikaraṇaṃ. Kattukammasamavetānaṃ nisajjapacanādikriyānaṃ patiṭṭhānaṭṭhena yo ādhāro, taṃ kārakaṃ okāsasaññaṃ hoti.
analyzed: ādhārīyati asmin ti ādhāraḥ adhikaraṇam kattu kamma samavetānam nisajja pacana ādi kriyānam patiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena yaḥ ādhāraḥ tam kārakam okāsa saññam hoti
translated: That which is located is a container, a basis. The location is the name of the case that is the container in the sense of the support for the actions of sitting, cooking, etc., that are associated with the doer.

original: Kaṭe nisīdati devadatto, thāliyaṃ odanaṃ pacati. Ettha hi devadattataṇḍulānaṃ kattukammānaṃ dhāraṇato taṃsamavetaṃ āsanapacanasaṅkhātaṃ kriyaṃ dhāreti nāma.
analyzed: kaṭe nisīdati devadattaḥ thāliyam odanam pacati ettha hi devadatta taṇḍulānam kattu kammānam dhāraṇato tat samavetam āsana pacana saṅkhātam kriyam dhārā iti nāma
translated: Devadatta sits on the mat, he cooks rice in the pot. Herein, since the action called sitting and cooking is borne by the mat and the pot, which are the bearers of Devadatta’s rice, it is called “bearing.”

original: So panāyamokāso catubbidho byāpiko opasilesiko sāmīpiko vesayikoti.
analyzed: so pana ayam okāso catubbidhaḥ byāpikaḥ opasilesikaḥ sāmīpikaḥ vesayikaḥ ti
translated: This mode is of four kinds: pervasive, contaminating, proximate, and possessive.

original: Tattha byāpiko nāma yattha sakalopi ādhārabhūto attho ādheyyena patthaṭo hoti, yasmiñca
analyzed: tattha byāpikaḥ nāma yattha sakalaḥ api ādhāra bhūtaḥ atthaḥ ādheyyena patthaṭaḥ hoti yasmin ca
translated: Herein, the pervasive is that in which the whole meaning that is the bearer is pervaded by the meaning that is borne, and in which

original: ādheyyabhūtaṃ kiñci byāpetvā tiṭṭhati, taṃ yathā – tilesu telaṃ atthi, khīlesu jalaṃ, dadhimhi sappīti.🔽Opasilesiko nāma paccekasiddhānaṃ bhāvānaṃ yattha upasilesena upagamo hoti, yasmiñca
analyzed: ādheyya bhūtam kiñci byāpetvā tiṭṭhati tam yathā tilesu telam atthi khīlesu jalam dadhimhi sappi iti  opasilesikaḥ nāma paccekasiddhānam bhāvānam yattha upasilesena upagamaḥ hoti yasmin ca
translated: the latter occurs by pervading it, as in “There is oil in the sesamum seeds,” “There is water in the wells,” “There is honey in the rock.”

original: ādheyyo upasilissati allīyitvā tiṭṭhati, taṃ yathā – āsane nisinno saṅgho, thāliyaṃ
analyzed: ādheyyaḥ upasilissati allīyitvā tiṭṭhati tam yathā āsane nisinnaḥ saṅghaḥ thāliyam
translated: The contaminating is that in which there is contamination by the borne meaning, and in which the latter occurs by adhering to it, as in “The Saṅgha sits on the seats,”

original: odanaṃ pacati, ghaṭesu udakaṃ atthi, dūre ṭhito, samīpe ṭhitoti.
analyzed: odanam pacati ghaṭesu udakam atthi dūre ṭhito samīpe ṭhitoti
translated: “He cooks rice in the pot,” “There is water in the pots,” “He is far,” “He is near.”

original: Sāmīpiko nāma yattha samīpe samīpivohāraṃ katvā tadāyattavuttitādīpanatthaṃ ādhārabhāvo
analyzed: sāmīpikaḥ nāma yattha samīpe samīpi vohāram katvā tad āyatta vutti tā dīpana ttham ādhāra bhāvaḥ
translated: The proximate is that which is proximate to something else, and is used to express dependence on it, etc., by the use of the locative case.

original: vikappīyati, taṃ yathā – gaṅgāyaṃ ghoso vasati, gaṅgāya samīpe vajo vasatīti attho.
analyzed: tam yathā gaṅgāyam ghosaḥ vasati gaṅgāya samīpe vajaḥ vasati iti attho
translated: The locative case is that in which the locative case-ending is used to show dependence on a location, etc., as in the following: “The sound dwells in the Ganges,” meaning that it dwells near the Ganges.

original: Bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane, sāvatthiyā samīpeti attho.🔽Vesayiko nāma yattha aññatthābhāvavasena, desantarāvacchedavasena vā ādhārabhāvo
analyzed: bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane sāvatthiyā samīpe iti attho  vesayikaḥ nāma yattha aññattha abhāva vasena desantara avaccheda vasena vā ādhāra bhāvaḥ
translated: “The Blessed One dwells at Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Wood,” meaning that he dwells near Sāvatthī.

original: parikappo, taṃ yathā – ākāse sakuṇā pakkhanti, bhūmīsu manussā caranti, jalesu macchā,🔽pādesu patito, pāpasmiṃ ramatī mano, pasanno buddhasāsane, paññāya sādhu, vinaye🔽nipuṇo, mātari sādhu, pitari nipuṇo iccādi.🔽Sabbopi cāyamādhāro padhānavasena vā parikappitavasena vā kriyāya patiṭṭhā bhavatīti okāsotveva vuttoti veditabbo.
analyzed: parikappaḥ tam yathā ākāse sakuṇā pakkhanti bhūmīsu manussā caranti jalesu macchā  pādesu patitaḥ pāpasmin ramati pasannaḥ buddha sāsane paññāya sādhu vinaye  nipuṇaḥ mātari sādhu pitari nipuṇaḥ iccādi  sabbaḥ api ca ayam ādhāraḥ padhāna vasena vā parikappita vasena vā kriyāya patiṭṭhā bhavati iti okāsaḥ tu eva vuttaḥ iti veditabbo
translated: The instrumental case is that in which the instrumental case-ending is used to show the function of a thing as a means of accomplishing an action, as in the following: “The bhikkhu attains Nibbāna by means of the path,” meaning that he attains it by making the path the means of accomplishing it.🔽The dative case is that in which the dative case-ending is used to show the function of a thing as a recipient of an action, as in the following: “He gives a gift to the Sangha,” meaning that he gives it to the Sangha as the recipient of the gift.

original: Vuttañcetaṃ🔽“Kiriyā kattukammānaṃ,
analyzed: vuttam ca itam 🔽kiriyā kattu kammānam
translated: The ablative case is that in which the ablative case-ending is used to show the function of a thing as the source of an action, as in the following: “He has come from Rājagaha,” meaning that he has come from Rājagaha as the source of his coming.🔽The genitive case is that in which the genitive case-ending is used to show the function of a thing as the owner of an action, as in the following: “The bhikkhu’s Nibbāna is by means of the path,” meaning that the bhikkhu is the owner of the Nibbāna.

original: Yattha hoti patiṭṭhitā;
analyzed: yattha hoti patiṭṭhitā
translated: Where it is found to be established,

original: ‘Okāso’ti pavutto so,🔽Catudhā byāpikādito.🔽Byāpiko tilakhīrādi,
analyzed: okāsaḥ ti pavutto so  catudhā  tila khīra ādi
translated: That is called the locative case,🔽Which is of four kinds, beginning with the all-pervading.

original: Kaṭo opasilesiko;
analyzed: kaṭaḥ opasilesikaḥ
translated: The all-pervading, the near, the native,

original: Sāmīpiko tu gaṅgādi,
analyzed: sāmīpikaḥ tu gaṅgā ādi
translated: The local, the proximate, the Ganges, etc.,

original: Ākāso visayo mato”ti.
analyzed: ākāsaḥ visayaḥ mataḥ iti
translated: Are held to be the objective sphere.

original: “Chaṭṭhī, sattamī”ti ca adhikāro.
analyzed: chaṭṭhī sattamī iti ca adhikāraḥ
translated: The sixth and seventh cases are also mentioned.

original: 321. Sāmissarādhipatidāyādasakkhīpatibhūpasūtakusalehi ca.
analyzed: ca
translated: With the lord, the master, the owner, the heir, the witness, the counterpart, the debtor, and the skilled.

original: Sāmī issara adhipati dāyāda sakkhipatibhū pasūta kusalaiccetehi yoge chaṭṭhīvibhatti hoti, sattamī ca. Ubhayatthaṃ vacanaṃ.
analyzed: sāmī issara adhipati dāyāda sakkhi patibhū pasūta kusala aicca itehi yoge chaṭṭhī vibhatti hoti sattamī ca ubhayattham vacanam
translated: The sixth and seventh case endings are used with these relationships: lord, master, owner, heir, witness, counterpart, debtor, and skilled. The statement is dual.

original: Gavaṃ sāmi, gosu sāmi, gavaṃ issaro, gosu issaro, gavaṃ adhipati, gosu adhipati,
analyzed: gavam sāmi gosu sāmi gavam issaraḥ gosu issaraḥ gavam adhipati gosu adhipati
translated: He is the lord of the cow, he is the lord of the cows; he is the master of the cow, he is the master of the cows; he is the owner of the cow, he is the owner of the cows;

original: gavaṃ dāyādo, gosu dāyādo, gavaṃ sakkhi, gosu sakkhi, gavaṃ patibhū, gosu patibhū,
analyzed: gavam dāyādaḥ gosu dāyādaḥ gavam sakkhi gosu sakkhi gavam patibhū gosu patibhū
translated: he is the heir of the cow, he is the heir of the cows; he is the witness of the cow, he is the witness of the cows; he is the counterpart of the cow, he is the counterpart of the cows;

original: gavaṃ pasūto, gosu pasūto, gavaṃ kusalo, gosu kusalo.
analyzed: gavam pasūtaḥ gosu pasūtaḥ gavam kusalaḥ gosu kusalaḥ
translated: he is the debtor of the cow, he is the debtor of the cows; he is the skilled in the cow, he is the skilled in the cows.

original: 322. Niddhāraṇe ca.
analyzed: niddhāraṇe ca
translated: And in the sense of singling out.

original: Nīharitvā dhāraṇaṃ niddhāraṇaṃ, jāti guṇa kriyā nāmehi samudāyato ekadesassa puthakkaraṇaṃ,
analyzed: nīharitvā dhāraṇam niddhāraṇam jāti guṇa kriyā nāmehi samudāyataḥ ekadesassa puthakkaraṇam
translated: Singling out is the separation of a part from a whole by means of a class, a quality, or an action.

original: tasmiṃ niddhāraṇatthe gamyamāne tato samudāyavāciliṅgamhā chaṭṭhīvibhatti hoti, sattamī ca.
analyzed: tasmin niddhāraṇa atthe gamyamāne tatas samudāya vāci liṅgamhā chaṭṭhī vibhatti hoti sattamī ca
translated: When the meaning of definition is intended, then the sixth and seventh case- endings are used from the collective noun and from the noun in the feminine gender.

original: Manussānaṃ khattiyo sūratamo, manussesu khattiyo sūratamo, kaṇhā gāvīnaṃ sampannakhīratamā,🔽kaṇhā gāvīsu sampannakhīratamā, addhikānaṃ dhāvanto sīghatamo, addhikesu dhāvanto
analyzed: manussānam khattiyaḥ sūratamaḥ manussesu khattiyaḥ sūratamaḥ kaṇhā gāvīnam sampanna khīratamā  kaṇhāḥ gāvīsu sampanna khīratamāḥ addhikānam dhāvantaḥ sīghatamaḥ addhikesu dhāvantaḥ
translated: The Khattiya is the most courageous of men, the Khattiya is the most courageous among men; the black cow is the best milk-giver of cows,

original: sīghatamo, āyasmā ānando arahataṃ aññataro ahosi, arahantesu vā iccādi.
analyzed: sīghatamaḥ āyasmai ānandaḥ arahatam aññataraḥ ahosi arahantesu vā iccādi
translated: the black cow is the best milk-giver among cows; the runner is the swiftest of horses, the runner is the swiftest among horses; the venerable Ananda was one of the Arahants, or among the Arahants.

original: 323. Anādare ca.
analyzed: an ādare ca
translated: . And in the sense of disregard.

original: Anādare gamyamāne bhāvavatā liṅgamhā chaṭṭhīvibhatti hoti, sattamī ca. Akāmakānaṃ mātāpitūnaṃ rudantānaṃ pabbaji, mātāpitūsu rudantesu pabbaji.
analyzed: anādare gamyamāne bhāvavatā liṅgamhā chaṭṭhī vibhatti hoti sattamī ca akāmakānam mātā pitūnam rudantānam pabbaji mātā pitūsu rudantesu pabbaji
translated: When the meaning of disregard is intended, then the sixth and seventh case- endings are used from the noun in the feminine gender. He went forth while his unwilling parents were weeping, he went forth while his parents were weeping.

original: Ākoṭayanto so neti,
analyzed: ākoṭayantaḥ saḥ na iti
translated: He goes on striking,

original: Sivirājassa pekkhato;
analyzed: sivirājassa pekkhato
translated: while King Sivi looks on;

original: Maccu gacchati ādāya,
analyzed: maccu gacchati ādāya
translated: Death goes on taking,

original: Pekkhamāne mahājane.🔽324. Kammakaraṇanimittatthesu sattamī.
analyzed: pekkhamāne mahājane  kamma karaṇa nimitta atthesu sattamī
translated: while the great crowd looks on.🔽. In the sense of cause, instrument, and reason, the seventh case-ending is used.

original: Kammakaraṇanimittaiccetesvatthesu liṅgamhā sattamīvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: kamma karaṇa nimitta e c ca i tesu atthesu liṅgam hā sattamī vibhatti hoti
translated: In the sense of cause, instrument, and reason, the seventh case-ending is used.

original: Kammatthe – bhikkhūsu abhivādenti, muddhani cumbitvā, purisassa bāhāsu gahetvā.
analyzed: kammatthe bhikkhūsu abhivādenti muddhani cumbitvā purisassa bāhāsu gahetvā
translated: In the sense of purpose: They pay homage to the monks, kissing their heads and holding their arms.

original: Karaṇatthe – hatthesu piṇḍāya caranti, pattesu piṇḍāya caranti, pathesu gacchanti, sopi maṃ anusāseyya, sampaṭicchāmi matthake.
analyzed: karaṇa atthe hatthesu piṇḍāya caranti pattesu piṇḍāya caranti pathesu gacchanti saḥ api mama anusāseyya sampaṭicchāmi matthake
translated: In the sense of instrument: They go for alms in the hands, they go for alms in the bowls, they go on the paths, he would instruct me, I consent on the head.

original: Nimittatthe – dīpi cammesu haññate, kuñjaro dantesu haññate, aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, sampajānamusāvāde pācittiyaṃ, musāvādanimittaṃ musāvādappaccayāti attho.
analyzed: nimitta atthe dīpi cammesu haññate kuñjaraḥ dantesu haññate aṇu mattesu vajjesu bhaya dassāvī sampajāna musāvāde pācittiyam musāvāda nimittam musāvāda ppaccayā ati attho
translated: In the sense of sign: The leopard is killed for its hide, the elephant is killed for its tusks, one who sees fear in the slightest fault, for telling a deliberate lie there is an offense entailing confession, the sign of lying, the reason for lying.

original: “Sattamī”ti adhikāro.
analyzed: sattamī iti adhikāraḥ
translated: The seventh is the context.

original: 325. Sampadāne ca.
analyzed: sampadāne ca
translated: And in the sense of completion.

original: Sampadānatthe ca liṅgamhā sattamīvibhatti hoti. Saṅghe dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ, saṅghe gotami dehi, saṅghe te dinne ahañceva pūjito bhavissāmi.
analyzed: sampadāna atthe ca liṅgamhā sattamī vibhatti hoti saṅghe dinnam mahat phalam saṅghe gotami dehi saṅghe te dinne aham ca iva pūjitaḥ bhavissāmi
translated: The locative case is also used in the sense of completion: Given to the Sangha, it is of great fruit; give to the Sangha, Gotami; when you give to the Sangha, I will be worshipped.🔽The woman who gave a garland of straw

original: Yā palālamayaṃ mālaṃ, nārī datvāna cetiye;
analyzed: yā palāla mayam mālam nārī cetiye
translated: to the shrine,

original: Alattha kañcanamayaṃ, mālaṃ bojjhaṅgikañca sā.
analyzed: alattha kañcana mayam mālam bojjhaṅgikam ca sā
translated: received a golden garland and the factors of awakening.

original: 326. Pañcamyatthe ca.
analyzed: pañcamī a tthe ca
translated: And in the sense of the fifth.

original: Pañcamyatthe ca liṅgamhā sattamīvibhatti hoti. Kadalīsu gaje rakkhanti.
analyzed: pañcamī atthe ca liṅgamhā sattamī vibhatti hoti kadalīsu gaje rakkhanti
translated: And in the fifth case the locative case is used. In the kadalīs the elephants are guarded.

original: 327. Kālabhāvesu ca.🔽Kālo nāma nimesa khaṇa laya muhutta pubbaṇhādiko, bhāvo nāma kriyā, sā cettha kriyantarūpalakkhaṇāva
analyzed: kāla bhāvesu ca  kālaḥ nāma nimesa khaṇa laya muhutta pubbaṇha ādikaḥ bhāvaḥ nāma kriyā sā ca ittha
translated: And in the time-division.

original: adhippetā, tasmiṃ kālatthe ca bhāvalakkhaṇe bhāvatthe ca liṅgamhā sattamīvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: adhippetā tasmin kāla tthe ca bhāva lakkhaṇe bhāva tthe ca liṅgamhā sattamī vibhatti hoti
translated: Time is a winking, a moment, a second, a half-month, a month, etc.; the division is an action. That is intended here as the characteristic of another action. And in the time-meaning and in the division-meaning the locative case is used.

original: Kāle – pubbaṇhasamaye gato, sāyanhasamaye āgato, akāle vassati tassa, kāle tassa na vassati, phussamāsamhā tīsu māsesu vesākhamāso, ito satasahassamhi, kappe uppajji cakkhumā.
analyzed: kāle pubbaṇha samaye gataḥ sāyanha samaye āgataḥ akāle vassati tassa kāle tassa na vassati phussa māsamhā tīsu māsesu vesākha māso ito sata sahassamhi kappe uppajji cakkhumā
translated: In time: He went at cockcrow, he came at evening, It rains for him out of season, It rains for him in season, Of the three months beginning with Phussa, the month of Vesakha is the first, A hundred thousand cycles of time ago the Enlightened One arose in the world.

original: Bhāvenabhāvalakkhaṇe – bhikkhusaṅghesu bhojīyamānesu gato, bhuttesu āgato, gosu duyhamānāsu
analyzed: bhāvenabhāva lakkhaṇe bhikkhu saṅghesu bhojīyamānesu gataḥ bhuttesu āgataḥ gosu duyhamānāsu
translated: In the division-meaning, the characteristic of division: He went while the Community of Bhikkhus was being fed, he came when they had eaten, He went while the cows were being milked,

original: gato, duddhāsu āgato, jāyamāne kho sāriputta bodhisatte ayaṃ dasasahassilokadhātu
analyzed: gataḥ duddhāsu āgataḥ jāyamāne kho sāriputta bodhisatte ayam dasa sahassi lokadhātu
translated: he came when they had been milked, When the Enlightened One was being born, Sāriputta, this ten-thousandfold world system

original: saṃkampi sampakampi sampavedhi.
analyzed: saṃkampi sampakampi sampavedhi
translated: shook, quivered, and trembled.

original: Pāsāṇā sakkharā ceva, kaṭhalā khāṇukaṇṭakā;
analyzed: pāsāṇā sakkharā ca iva kaṭhalā khāṇukaṇṭakā
translated: Stones, pebbles, potsherds, stumps, thorns,

original: Sabbe maggā vivajjenti, gacchante lokanāyake.
analyzed: sabbe maggāḥ vivajjenti gacchante loka nāyake
translated: All these the path avoids, when the world’s Leader goes.

original: Imasmiṃ sati idaṃ hoti iccādi.
analyzed: imasmin sati idam iti id ca ādi
translated: “When this is, that comes to be” , etc.

original: 328. Upājhādhikissaravacane.
analyzed: upa ajha adhi kissara vacane
translated: In the sense of superiority and sovereignty.

original: Dvipadamidaṃ. Adhikatthe, issaratthe ca vattamānehi upaadhiiccetehi yoge adhikissaravacane gamyamāne liṅgamhā sattamīvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: dvipadam idam adhika atthe issara atthe ca vattamānehi upa adhi icca itehi yoge adhika issara vacane gamyamāne liṅgamhā sattamī vibhatti hoti
translated: This is twofold. When the words upa and adhi are used in the sense of superiority and sovereignty, the locative case is used with the words upa and adhi in the sense of superiority and sovereignty.🔽In the sense of superiority: upa doṇo khāriyaṃ, doṇo is superior to khāriyaṃ.

original: Adhikavacane – upa khāriyaṃ doṇo, khāriyā doṇo adhikoti attho. Tathā upa nikkhe kahāpaṇaṃ,🔽adhi devesu buddho, sammutiupapattivisuddhidevasaṅkhātehi tividhehipi devehi sabbaññū
analyzed: adhika vacane upa khāriyam doṇaḥ khāriyā doṇaḥ adhikaḥ iti attho tathā upa nikkhe kahāpaṇam  adhi devesu buddhaḥ sammuti upapatti visuddhi deva saṅkhātehi tividhehi pi devehi sabbaññū
translated: So too: upa nikkhā kahāpaṇaṃ,

original: buddhova adhikoti attho.
analyzed: buddhaḥ uva adhikaḥ ti attho
translated: adhi buddho devesu, the Omniscient Buddha is superior to the gods of the three kinds, namely, gods purified by faith, gods purified by their deeds, and gods of the Pure Abodes.

original: Issaravacane – adhi brahmadatte pañcālā, brahmadattissarā pañcālāti attho.
analyzed: is sara vacane adhi brahmadatte pañcālā brahmadatti ssarā pañcālā ati attho
translated: So too: adhi pañcālā brahmadatte, the people of Pañcāla are subject to Brahmadatta.

original: 329. Maṇḍitussukkesu tatiyā ca.
analyzed: maṇḍi tus sukkesu tatiyā ca
translated: And the third after maṇḍita and sukka.

original: Maṇḍitaussukkaiccetesvatthesu gamyamānesu liṅgamhā tatiyāvibhatti hoti, sattamī ca.
analyzed: maṇḍita aus suk ka e c ca ite su atthesu gamyamānesu liṅgamhā tatiyā vibhatti hoti sattamī ca
translated: When the words maṇḍita, sukka, and so on, are used in the sense of “adorned,” “white,” and so on, the locative case is used with them, and the seventh case is used.

original: Maṇḍitasaddo panettha pasannatthavācako, ussukkasaddo saīhattho. Ñāṇena pasanno,
analyzed: maṇḍita saddo pana ittha pasanna attha vācakaḥ ussukka saddo saīha atthaḥ ñāṇena pasanno
translated: The word “adorned” here is a synonym for “pleased,” the word “diligent” is a synonym for “zealous.”

original: ñāṇasmiṃ pasanno, ñāṇena ussukko, ñāṇasmiṃ ussukko sappuriso.🔽Kārakaṃ chabbidhaṃ saññā-vasā chabbīsatīvidhaṃ;
analyzed: ñāṇasmim pasannaḥ ñāṇena ussukkaḥ ñāṇasmim ussukkaḥ sappuriso  kārakam chabbidham saññā vasā chabbīsatīvidham
translated: The word “adorned” here is a synonym for “pleased,” and the word “zeal” is a synonym for “eagerness.” The good person is pleased with knowledge, pleased in knowledge, eager for knowledge, eager in knowledge.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.

original: Pabhedā sattadhā kammaṃ, kattā pañcavidho bhave.🔽Karaṇaṃ duvidhaṃ hoti, sampadānaṃ tidhā mataṃ;
analyzed: sattadhā kammam kattā pañcavidhaḥ bhave  karaṇam duvidham sampadānam tidhā matam
translated: The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.

original: Apādānaṃ pañcavidhaṃ, ādhāro tu catubbidho.🔽Vibhattiyo pana paccattavacanādivasena aṭṭhavidhā bhavanti. Yathāha
analyzed: apādānam pañcavidham ādhāraḥ tu catubbidhaḥ  vibhattiyaḥ pana paccatta vacana ādi vasena aṭṭhavidhāḥ bhavanti yathā āha
translated: The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.

original: “Paccattamupayogañca, karaṇaṃ sampadāniyaṃ;🔽Nissakkaṃ sāmivacanaṃ, bhummālapanamaṭṭhama”nti.
analyzed: paccattam upayogam ca karaṇam sampadāniyam  nissakkam sāmi vacanam bhumma ālapanam aṭṭhamanti
translated: The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.

original: Iti padarūpasiddhiyaṃ kārakakaṇḍo🔽Tatiyo.🔽4. Samāsakaṇḍa
analyzed: iti  tatiyaḥ  samāsa kaṇḍa
translated: The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.🔽The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the case endings.

original: Atha nāmameva aññamaññasambandhīnaṃ samāsoti nāmanissitattā, sayañca nāmikattā nāmānantaraṃ samāso vuccate.
analyzed: atha nāmam eva aññamañña sambandhīnam samāsaḥ ti nāma nissita ttā sayam ca nāmika ttā nāma anantaram samāsaḥ vuccate
translated: The sixfold function is the basis for the classification of the

original: So ca saññāvasena chabbidho abyayībhāvo kammadhārayo digu tappuriso bahubbīhi dvando cāti.
analyzed: so ca saññā vasena chabbidhaḥ abyayībhāvaḥ kammadhārayaḥ digu tappurisaḥ bahuppurisaḥ dvandaḥ ca ati
translated: And that is of six kinds as a copulative compound, a determinative compound, a dvanda compound, a taddhita compound, a bahubbīhi compound, and a copulative compound.

original: Abyayībhāvasamāsa
analyzed: abyayībhāva samāsa
translated: Copulative compound

original: Tatra paṭhamaṃ abyayībhāvasamāso vuccate;
analyzed: tatra paṭhamam abyayībhāva samāsaḥ vuccate
translated: First of all, the copulative compound is stated thus:

original: So ca niccasamāsoti assapadaviggaho.🔽“Upanagaraṃ”itīdha – upasaddato paṭhamekavacanaṃ si, tassa upasaggaparattā “sabbāsamāvusopasagganipātādīhi
analyzed: saḥ ca nicca samāsaḥ ti assa pada viggaho  upa nagaram iti idha upasaddataḥ paṭhama ekavacanam si tassa upasagga para ttā sabba asama avusa upasagga nipāta ādīhi
translated: And that is a permanent compound, and it is analysed by the word “and”.

original: cā”ti lopo, nagarasaddato chaṭṭhekavacanaṃ sa, nagarassa samīpanti aññapadena viggahe –
analyzed: ca ati lopaḥ nagara saddataḥ chaṭṭha ekavacanam sa nagarassa samīpan ti añña padena viggahe
translated: Herein, in the phrase “near the town” the singular ending -si is in accordance with the rule “Upasaddato paṭhamekavacanam si” . The elision of the -a- is in accordance with the rule “Cā sabbāsamāvusopasagganipātādīhi” . The singular ending -sa is in accordance with the rule “Chaṭṭhekavacanam sa” . The analysis by means of another word is as follows:

original: “Nāmānaṃ samāso yuttattho”ti samāsavidhāne sabbattha vattate.
analyzed: samāsaḥ yutta atthaḥ iti samāsa vidhāne sabbattha vattate
translated: “A compound of nouns has a collective meaning” . This rule of compounding applies in all instances.

original: 330. Upasagganipātapubbako abyayībhāvo.🔽Upasaggapubbako, nipātapubbako ca nāmiko yuttattho teheva attapubbakehi upasagganipātehi
analyzed: upasagga nipāta pubbakaḥ abyayībhāvaḥ  upasagga pubbakaḥ nipāta pubbakaḥ ca nāmikaḥ yutta atthaḥ tehi iva atta pubbakehi upasagga nipātehi
translated: The copulative compound is preceded by a preposition or a particle.

original: saha niccaṃ samasīyate, so ca samāso abyayībhāvasañño hoti. Idha abyayībhāvādisaññāvidhāyakasuttāneva
analyzed: saha niccam samasīyate saḥ ca samāsaḥ abyayībhāva saññaḥ hoti idha abyayībhāva ādi saññā vidhāyaka suttāna iva
translated: A compound of nouns preceded by a preposition or a particle has a collective meaning. It is compounded permanently with those same prepositions and particles that precede it. And that compound is called a copulative compound. Herein, the suttas that lay down the names copulative compound, etc., are as follows:

original: vā saññāvidhānamukhena samāsavidhāyakānīti daṭṭhabbāni.
analyzed: vā saññā vidhāna mukhena samāsa vidhāyakāni iti daṭṭhabbāni
translated: and the compound words are to be regarded as having the function of expressing the meaning of the indeclinable word by means of the function of expressing the meaning of a declinable word.

original: Tattha abyayamiti upasagganipātānaṃ saññā, liṅgavacanabhedepi byayarahitattā, abyayānaṃ
analyzed: tattha abyayam iti upasagga nipātānam saññā liṅga vacana bhede pi byaya rahita ttā abyayānam
translated: Herein, the indeclinables are the indeclinables of the upasagga and nipāta classes.

original: atthaṃ vibhāvayatīti abyayībhāvo abyayatthapubbaṅgamattā, anabyayaṃ abyayaṃ bhavatīti🔽vā abyayībhāvo. Pubbapadatthappadhāno hi abyayībhāvo, ettha ca “upasagganipātapubbako”ti
analyzed: attham vibhāvayati iti abyayībhāvaḥ abyaya attha pubbaṅgamattā anabyayam abyayam bhavati iti  vā abyayībhāvaḥ pubba pada attha ppadhānaḥ hi abyayībhāvaḥ ettha ca upasagga nipāta pubbakaḥ ti
translated: The indeclinable-state is the state of the indeclinables.🔽Or the indeclinable-state is the state of the indeclinable.🔽For the indeclinable-state is the state of the first word in an indeclinable compound.

original: vuttattā upasagganipātānameva pubbanipāto.
analyzed: vutta ttā upasagga nipātānam eva pubba nipātaḥ
translated: And since it is said here that “the indeclinable is the first member,” the first member is an indeclinable.

original: 331. Nāmānaṃ samāso yuttattho.🔽Tesaṃ nāmānaṃ payujjamānapadatthānaṃ yo yuttattho, so samāsasañño hoti, tadaññaṃ vākyamiti ruḷhaṃ.
analyzed: tesam nāmānam payujjamāna padatthānam yaḥ yut tattho saḥ samāsa saññaḥ hoti tad aññam vākyam iti ruḷham
translated: A compound is the combination of nouns with a single meaning.🔽The combination of the meanings of the words used as nouns is called a compound, or else it is a sentence.🔽The nouns are the words ending in case endings beginning with the nominative.

original: Nāmāni syādivibhatyantāni, samassateti samāso, saṅkhipiyatīti attho.
analyzed: nāmāni sya ādi vibhati antāni samassate iti samāsaḥ attho
translated: The compound is the combining of them. The meaning is “they are combined.”

original: Vuttañhi
analyzed: vuttam hi
translated: For this is said:🔽“A compound is a combination of words,

original: “Samāso padasaṅkhepo, padappaccayasaṃhitaṃ;
analyzed: samāsaḥ pada saṅkhepaḥ pada ppaccaya saṃhitam
translated: A word is a combination of syllables,🔽A syllable is a combination of letters,

original: Taddhitaṃ nāma hotevaṃ, viññeyyaṃ tesamantara”nti.
analyzed: taddhitam nāma hotā ivam viññeyyam
translated: A letter is a combination of sound.

original: Duvidhañcassa samasanaṃ saddasamasanamatthasamasanañca, tadubhayampi luttasamāse
analyzed: duvidham ca assa samasanam sadda samasanam attha samasanam ca tat ubhayam pi lutta samāse
translated: And its analysis is twofold as analysis of the word and analysis of the meaning. Both of these are found only in a compound with a preposition.

original: paripuṇṇameva labbhati. Aluttasamāse pana atthasamasanameva vibhattilopābhāvato,
analyzed: paripuṇṇam eva labbhati a lutta samāse pana vibhatti lopa abhāvato
translated: But in a compound without a preposition only the analysis of the meaning is found, because there is no elision of a case-ending.

original: tatthāpi vā ekapadattūpagamanato duvidhampi labbhateva. Dve hi samāsassa payojanāni
analyzed: tattha api vā eka padattu upagamanataḥ duvidham pi labbhatā iva dve hi samāsassa payojanāni
translated: And in that case too both kinds are found, because of the inclusion of the single word. For there are two purposes of a compound:

original: ekapadattamekavibhattittañcāti.
analyzed: eka pada ttam eka vibhatti ttam ca ati
translated: to make a single word and to make a single case-relation.

original: Yutto attho yuttatto, atha vā yutto saṅgato, sambandho vā attho yassa soyaṃ yuttattho,
analyzed: yuttaḥ atthaḥ yuttatto atha vā yuttaḥ saṅgataḥ sambandhaḥ vā atthaḥ yassa saḥ ayam yuttattho
translated: The meaning that is connected is the connected meaning. Or alternatively, the meaning that is connected, associated, related, is the connected meaning.

original: etena saṅgatatthena yuttatthavacanena bhinnatthānaṃ ekatthībhāvo samāsalakkhaṇanti🔽vuttaṃ hoti. Ettha ca “nāmāna”nti vacanena “devadatto pacatī”tiādīsu ākhyātena samāso
analyzed: etena saṅga tatthena yut tattha vacanena bhinnatthānam ekatthībhāvaḥ samāsa lakkhaṇam ti  vuttam hoti ettha ca vacanena devadattaḥ pacati iti ādīsu ākhyātena samāsaḥ
translated: What is meant by this expression “connected meaning” is that the characteristic of a compound is the state of having a single meaning of the different words.🔽And here the words “in a name” show that in such expressions as “Devadatta cooks” there is no compound with a verbal basis.

original: na hotīti dasseti. Sambandhatthena pana yuttatthaggahaṇena “bhaṭo rañño putto devadattassā”tiādīsu
analyzed: na hoti iti dasseti sambandha tthena pana yutta attha ggahaṇena bhaṭaḥ raññaḥ puttaḥ devadattassa ati ādīsu
translated: But by the expression “connected meaning” the inclusion of the meaning of relation is shown in such expressions as “The king’s son, Devadatta’s servant.”

original: aññamaññānapekkhesu, “devadattassa kaṇhā dantā”tiādīsu ca aññasāpekkhesu ayuttatthatāya🔽samāso na hotīti dīpeti.
analyzed: aññamañña anapekkhesu devadattassa kaṇhā danta ati ādīsu ca añña sāpekkhesu ayutta ttha tāya  samāsaḥ na dīpa iti
translated: and in “Devadatta’s black teeth” and so on, where there is a reference to something else, it is not a compound because it is not appropriate.🔽This is what is shown.

original: “Atthavasā vibhattivipariṇāmo”ti vipariṇāmena “yuttatthāna”nti vattate.
analyzed: attha vasā vibhatti vipariṇāmaḥ ti vipariṇāmena vattate
translated: “The case-ending is changed for the sake of meaning” .

original: 332. Tesaṃ vibhattiyo lopā ca.
analyzed: tesam vibhattiyaḥ lopāḥ ca
translated: The case- endings of those and their elision.

original: Idha padantarena vā taddhitappaccayehi vā āyādippaccayehi vā ekatthībhūtā yuttatthā🔽nāma, tena “tesaṃ yuttatthānaṃ samāsānaṃ, taddhitāyādippaccayantānañca vibhattiyo
analyzed: idha pada antarena vā taddhita ppaccayehi vā āya ādi ppaccayehi vā ekatthībhūtā  nāma tena tesam yutta tthānam samāsānam taddhita āya ādi ppaccaya antānam ca vibhattiyaḥ
translated: Herein, the meaning of “appropriate” is that which has become one meaning by means of another word or by means of a nominal suffix or by means of a case-ending beginning with ā .

original: lopanīyā hontī”ti attho. Samāsaggahaṇādhikāre pana sati tesaṃgahaṇena vā taddhitāyādippaccayanta
analyzed: lopanīyāḥ honti iti atthaḥ samāsa ggahaṇa adhikāre pana sati vā
translated: So the meaning is: “The case-endings of those compounds that have an appropriate meaning and of those that have a nominal suffix or a case-ending beginning with ā are elided.” But in the section on the heading “compounds” , the inclusion of those by the word “compounds” and the inclusion of those that have a nominal suffix or a case-ending beginning with ā by the word “nominal suffix” and the inclusion of those that have a case-ending by the word “case-ending” are for the purpose of showing the elision of the case-ending.

original: vibhattilopo. Caggahaṇaṃ “pabhaṅkaro”tiādīsu lopanivattanatthaṃ.
analyzed: vibhatti lopaḥ ca ggahaṇam pabhaṅkaroti ādīsu lopa nivattana attham
translated: And the inclusion of those that have a case-ending is for the purpose of precluding elision in such instances as “pabhaṅkaro” .

original: Vipariṇāmena “luttāsu, vibhattīsū”ti vattate, yuttatthaggahaṇañca.
analyzed: vipariṇāmena luttāsu vibhattīsu iti vattate yut tad tha gahaṇam ca
translated: “The case-endings are changed” and “the appropriate meaning is included” are said by way of the change .

original: 333. Pakati cassa sarantassa.
analyzed: pakati cassa sarantassa
translated: And the natural-state of the one remembering.

original: Luttāsu vibhattīsu sarantassa assa yuttatthabhūtassa tividhassapi liṅgassa pakatibhāvo
analyzed: luttāsu vibhattīsu sarantassa assa yutta attha bhūtassa tividhassa api liṅgassa pakati bhāvaḥ
translated: In the case of the inflected forms of the feminine, the state of being the base of the three genders of the word which is the meaning of the compound is

original: hoti. Casaddena kiṃsamudaya idappaccayatādīsu niggahītantassapi. Nimittābhāve nemittakābhāvassa
analyzed: hoti ca saddena kim samudaye idappaccaya tā ādīsu niggahīta antassa api nimitta abhāve nemittaka abhāvassa
translated: his, of the one who remembers it. And by the word “also” is included the state of being the base of the three genders of the word which is the meaning of the compound, in the case of the one who has been checked in such expressions as “kiṃsamudaya idappaccayatā” .🔽Since the absence of a sign is here not intended, the absence of a foreteller is

original: idha anicchitattā ayamatideso.
analyzed: idha an icchita ttā ayam atidesaḥ
translated: here the place of the indeclinable.

original: Sakatthavirahenidha samāsassa ca liṅgabhāvābhāvā vibhattuppattiyamasampattāyaṃ nāmabyapadesātidesamāha.
analyzed: samāsassa ca liṅga bhāva abhāvā nāma byapadesa atidesam āha
translated: And since the state of being the base of the three genders of the word which is the meaning of the compound is not established here in the case of the compound because of the absence of the meaning of the individual words, he says that the indeclinable is a substitute for the noun.

original: 334. Taddhitasamāsakitakā nāmaṃvā’tavetunādīsu ca.
analyzed: taddhita samāsa kitakāḥ ca
translated: . The indeclinable is like a noun in the case of the indeclinables, the compounds, and the kit-words.

original: Taddhitantā, kitantā, samāsā ca nāmamiva daṭṭhabbā tavetuna tvāna tvādippaccayante🔽vajjetvā. Caggahaṇaṃ kiccappaccayaāīinīitthippaccayantādissapi nāmabyapadesatthaṃ.
analyzed: taddhi tantā ki tantā samāsā ca nāmam iva daṭṭhabbā  vajjetvā ca ggahaṇam nāma byapadesa attham
translated: The indeclinables, the kit-words, and the compounds are to be regarded as like a noun, except in the case of the indeclinables tavetuna, tvāna, etc.,🔽and the suffixes of the feminine. And the word “also” is for the purpose of including the suffixes of the nominative case, the suffixes of the accusative case, and the suffixes of the feminine.

original: Idha samāsaggahaṇaṃ atthavataṃ samudāyānaṃ nāmabyapadeso samāsassevāti niyamatthanti apare.
analyzed: idha samāsa ggahaṇam atthavatam samudāyānam nāma byapadesaḥ samāsassa iva ati niyama ttham ti apare
translated: Others say that the inclusion of the compounds here is for the purpose of restricting the indeclinable to the compound only, since the indeclinable is a substitute for the noun in the case of the compounds which have a meaning.

original: “Abyayībhāvo”ti vattate.
analyzed: abyayībhāvaḥ iti vattate
translated: . It is called an indeclinable.

original: 335. So napuṃsakaliṅgo.
analyzed: saḥ napuṃsaka liṅgaḥ
translated: . It has the neuter gender.

original: So abyayībhāvasamāso napuṃsakaliṅgova daṭṭhabboti napuṃsakaliṅgattaṃ. Ettha hi satipi
analyzed: saḥ abyayībhāva samāsaḥ napuṃsaka liṅgaḥ iva daṭṭhabbaḥ iti napuṃsaka liṅga ttam ettha hi satipi
translated: It should be regarded as a compound in apposition, and as neuter.

original: liṅgātidese “adhipañña”ntiādīsu “adhiñāṇaṃ”ntiādi rūpappasaṅgo na hoti saddantarattā,
analyzed: liṅga atidese adhi pañña nti ādīsu rūpa ppasaṅgaḥ na hoti
translated: For although there is a change of gender, as in the case of the words adhipañña, etc., there is no such syntactical relation as there is in the case of the words adhiññāṇa, etc., because the latter are different words;🔽and it should be regarded as like the words tipañña, etc.

original: “tipañña”ntiādīsu viyāti daṭṭhabbaṃ, na cāyaṃ atideso, sutte atidesaliṅgassa ivasaddassa
analyzed: ti pañña nti ādīsu viya iti daṭṭhabbam na ca ayam atidesaḥ sutte atidesa liṅgassa iva saddassa
translated: And this is not a change of gender, because the word iva, which is the word that changes the gender in a sutta, is not found here.

original: adassanato. Pure viya syādyuppatti.
analyzed: a dassanataḥ pure viya syādi uppatti
translated: The origin of the syllable ya is as before.

original: “Kvacī”ti vattate.
analyzed: kvaci iti vattate
translated: “In some instances” is said.

original: 336. Aṃ vibhattīnamakārantā abyayībhāvā.
analyzed: am vibhattī na makāra antāḥ abyayībhāvā
translated: The indeclinable aṃ is the compound in apposition ending in a vowel.

original: Tasmā akārantā abyayībhāvā parāsaṃ vibhattīnaṃ kvaci aṃ hoti, sesaṃ neyyaṃ.
analyzed: tasmai akāra antāḥ abyayībhāvā parāsam vibhattīnam kvaci aṃ hoti sesam na iyyam
translated: Therefore, in some instances, aṃ is substituted for the final vowel of the indeclinable words in apposition ending in a vowel, and the rest is to be understood.

original: Taṃ upanagaraṃ, nagarassa samīpaṃ tiṭṭhatīti attho. Tāni upanagaraṃ, ālapanepevaṃ, taṃ upanagaraṃ passa, tāni upanagaraṃ.
analyzed: tam upanagaram nagarassa samīpam tiṭṭhati iti tāni upanagaram tam upanagaram tāni upanagaram
translated: That is near the city, the meaning is it stands near the city. Those are near the city. In addressing, it is like this: See that near the city, see those near the city.

original: Na pañcamyāyamambhāvo, kvacīti adhikārato;
analyzed: na kvaci iti adhikārataḥ
translated: This aṃ is not in the fifth case, because of the general rule “in some instances”;

original: Tatiyāsattamīchaṭṭhī-nantu hoti vikappato.
analyzed: tatiyā sattamī chaṭṭhīnam tu hoti vikappataḥ
translated: but it is in the third, seventh, and sixth cases, by exception.

original: Tena upanagaraṃ kataṃ, upanagarena vā, tehi upanagaraṃ, upanagarehi vā, tassa upanagaraṃ🔽dehi, tesaṃ upanagaraṃ, upanagarā ānaya, upanagaramhā upanagarasmā, upanagarehi,🔽upanagaraṃ santakaṃ, upanagarassa vā, tesaṃ upanagaraṃ, upanagarānaṃ vā, upanagaraṃ
analyzed: tena upanagaram katam upanagarena vā tehi upanagaram upanagarehi vā tassa upanagaram  dehi tesam upanagaram upanagarāḥ ānaya upanagaramhā upanagarasmā upanagarehi  upanagaram santakam upanagarassa vā tesam upanagaram upanagarānam vā upanagaram
translated: By that, it is made a town near a town, by the town near a town, by those, a town near a town, by the town near a town, to him a town near a town,🔽give, to them a town near a town, bring a town near a town, from a town near a town, from a town near a town, by the town near a town,🔽a town near a town is given, of a town near a town, to them a town near a town, of the town near a town, of the town near a town.

original: nidhehi, upanagaramhi upanagarasmiṃ, upanagaraṃ upanagaresu vā. Evaṃ upakumbhaṃ.🔽Abhāve – darathānaṃ abhāvo niddarathaṃ, nimmasakaṃ.🔽Pacchāatthe – rathassa pacchā anurathaṃ, anuvātaṃ.🔽Yoggatāyaṃ – yathāsarūpaṃ, anurūpaṃ, rūpayogganti attho.🔽Vicchāyaṃ – attānamattānaṃ pati paccattaṃ, addhamāsaṃ addhamāsaṃ anu anvaddhamāsaṃ.🔽Anupubbiyaṃ – jeṭṭhānaṃ anupubbo anujeṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: nidhehi upanagaramhi upanagarasmin upanagaram upanagaresu vā evam upakumbham 🔽abhāve darathānam abhāvaḥ niddaratham nimmasakam 🔽pacchāatthe rathassa pacchā anuratham anuvātam 🔽yathā sarūpam anurūpam rūpa yogganti attho 🔽vicchāyam attānam attānam pati paccattam addha māsam addha māsam anu anvaddha māsam 🔽anupubbiyam jeṭṭhānam anupubbaḥ anujeṭṭham
translated: By them a town was made, or they made a town, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made a town for him, or they made a town for them, or they made

original: Paṭilome – sotassa paṭilomaṃ paṭisotaṃ, paṭipathaṃ, pativātaṃ, attānaṃ adhikicca pavattā ajjhattaṃ.
analyzed: paṭilome sotassa paṭilomam paṭisotam paṭipatham pativātam attānam adhikicca pavattā ajjhattam
translated: In the opposite direction: flowing in the opposite direction to the stream, against the stream, against the path, against the wind, and occurring in the internal direction, making the self the object.

original: Pariyādābhividhīsu āpāṇakoṭiyā āpāṇakoṭikaṃ, “kvaci samāsantagatānamakāranto”ti kappaccayo, ākumārehi yaso kaccāyanassa ākumāraṃ.
analyzed: āpāṇakoṭiyāḥ āpāṇakoṭikam kvaci kappa ccayaḥ ā kumārehi kaccāyanassa ākumāram
translated: In the analysis of the prefix pari: up to the end of the nose, up to the end of the nose; “up to the end of the nose” is a bahubbīhi compound.

original: Samiddhiyaṃ – bhikkhāya samiddhīti atthe samāseva napuṃsakaliṅgatte ca kate –
analyzed: samiddhiyam bhikkhāya samiddhī iti atthe samāsa iva napuṃsaka liṅga tte ca kate
translated: In the analysis of samiddhi: because of the alms food, in the sense of “because of the alms food,” the analysis is made in the neuter gender.

original: “Samāsassa, anto”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: samāsassa antaḥ iti ca vattate
translated: “Of a compound, inside” is said.

original: 337. Saro rasso napuṃsake.
analyzed: saraḥ rassaḥ napuṃsake
translated: The vowel of a neuter compound is short.

original: Napuṃsake vattamānassa samāsassa anto saro rasso hoti. Ettha ca abyayībhāvaggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: napuṃsake vattamānassa samāsassa antaḥ saraḥ rassaḥ hoti ettha ca abyayībhāva ggahaṇam
translated: The vowel of a neuter compound that is in the middle is short. And here the inclusion of the indeclinable word is

original: nānuvattetabbaṃ, tena digudvandabahubbīhīsupi napuṃsake vattamānassa samāsantassarassa🔽rassattaṃ siddhaṃ hoti. “Aṃ vibhattīna”miccādinā amādeso, subhikkhaṃ. Gaṅgāya samīpe
analyzed: na anuvattetabbam tena diś udvanda bahup bīhī supi napuṃsake vattamānassa samāsa antassarassa  rassa ttam siddham hoti aṃ vibhattīnam icca ādinā am ādesaḥ subhikkham gaṅgāya samīpe
translated: not to be followed. Therefore the vowel of a compound in the neuter that is in the middle is also short in the case of the indeclinable words dig, upa, and bahu.🔽“The vowel a” is substituted by the rule “aṃ vibhattīnaṃ” and so on. There is prosperity.

original: vattatīti upagaṅgaṃ, maṇikāya samīpaṃ upamaṇikaṃ.
analyzed: vattati iti upagaṅgam maṇikāya samīpam upamaṇikam
translated: It occurs near the Ganges, therefore it is upagaṅgaṃ. It is near the Maṇika, therefore it is upamaṇikaṃ.

original: Itthīsu amikiccāti atthe samāsanapuṃsakarassattādīsu katesu –
analyzed: itthīsu ami kicca ati atthe samāsa napuṃsaka rassatta ādīsu katesu
translated: In the feminine, the compound is amikicca,

original: “Abyayībhāvā, vibhattīna”nti ca vattate.
analyzed: abyayībhāvāḥ ca vattate
translated: and the feminine endings are elided, as it is said, “In the indeclinable compounds, the case-endings are elided.”

original: 338. Aññasmā lopo ca.
analyzed: aññasmā lopaḥ ca
translated: And there is elision of the other.

original: Akārantato aññasmā abyayībhāvasamāsā parāsaṃ vibhattīnaṃ lopo ca hoti. Adhitti, itthīsu
analyzed: akāra antataḥ aññasmai abyayībhāva samāsā parāsam vibhattīnam lopaḥ ca hoti itthīsu
translated: The feminine endings are elided in the indeclinable compounds that follow after those ending in a vowel, and also in those ending in a consonant. Adhitti, itthīsu,

original: adhikicca kathā pavattatīti attho. Adhitthi passa, adhitthi kataṃ iccādi, evaṃ adhikumāri,
analyzed: adhik icca kathā pavattati iti atthaḥ adhitthi passa adhitthi katam iccādi evam adhikumāri
translated: the talk proceeds with the meaning “having authority over women.” Adhitthi passa, adhitthi kataṃ, etc.; so too, adhikumāri,

original: vadhuyā samīpaṃ upavadhu, gunnaṃ samīpaṃ upagu, okārassa rassattaṃ ukāro. Evaṃ upasaggapubbako.
analyzed: vadhuyā samīpam upavadhu gunnam samīpam upagu okārassa ukāraḥ evam upasagga pubbakaḥ
translated: upavadhu, upagu, the u is the ra-sign. So too, with a prefix.

original: Nipātapubbako yathā – vuḍḍhānaṃ paṭipāṭi, ye ye vuḍḍhā vā yathāvuḍḍhaṃ, padatthānatikkame
analyzed: nipāta pubbakaḥ yathā vuḍḍhānam paṭipāṭi ye ye vuḍḍhāḥ vā yathāvuḍḍham padattha an atikkame
translated: With a noun-declension as prefix, e.g. vuḍḍhānaṃ paṭipāṭi, ye ye vuḍḍhā vā yathāvuḍḍhaṃ, padatthānatikkame,

original: – yathākkamaṃ, yathāsatti, yathābalaṃ karoti, balamanatikkamitvā karotīti attho.
analyzed: yathākkamam yathāsatti yathābalam karoti balam an atikkamitvā karoti iti
translated: yathākkamaṃ, yathāsatti, yathābalaṃ karoti, the meaning is “he does it without exceeding his strength.”

original: Jīvassa yattako paricchedo yāvajīvaṃ, yāvatāyukaṃ, kappaccayo. Yattakena attho yāvadatthaṃ,
analyzed: jīvassa yattakaḥ paricchedaḥ yāvajīvam yāvatā āyukam kappa cayaḥ yattakena atthaḥ yāvadattham
translated: Yāvajīvaṃ, yāvatāyukaṃ, kappaccayo, yattakena attho yāvadatthaṃ,

original: pabbatassa parabhāgo tiropabbataṃ, tiropākāraṃ, tirokuṭṭaṃ, pāsādassa anto antopāsādaṃ,
analyzed: pabbatassa parabhāgaḥ tiropabbatam tiropākāram tirokuṭṭam pāsādassa antaḥ antopāsādam
translated: The other side of a mountain is “beyond the mountain,” beyond a rampart, beyond a wall. Inside a stilt house is “inside the stilt house.”

original: antonagaraṃ, antovassaṃ, nagarassa bahi bahinagaraṃ, pāsādassa upari uparipāsādaṃ,
analyzed: antonagaram antovassam nagarassa bahi bahinagaram pāsādassa upari upari pāsādam
translated: Inside a town is “inside the town.” During the Rains is “during the Rains.” Outside a town is “outside the town.” On top of a stilt house is “on top of the stilt house.”

original: uparimañcaṃ, mañcassa heṭṭhā heṭṭhāmañcaṃ, heṭṭhāpāsādaṃ, bhattassa pure purebhattaṃ, evaṃ pacchābhattaṃ.
analyzed: upari mañcam mañcassa heṭṭhā heṭṭhā mañcam heṭṭhā pāsādam bhattassa pure purebhattam evam pacchābhattam
translated: On top of a bed is “on top of the bed.” Under a bed is “under the bed.” Under a stilt house is “under the stilt house.” Before a meal is “before the meal.” After a meal is “after the meal.”

original: Sākallatthe – saha makkhikāya samakkhikaṃ bhuñjati, na kiñci parivajjetīti attho. “Tesu vuddhī”tiādinā sahasaddassa sādeso. Gaṅgāya oraṃ oragaṅgamiccādi.
analyzed: sākalla atthe saha makkhikāya sa makkhikam bhuñjati na kiñci parivajjeti iti attho tesu vuddhi iti ādinā saha saddassa sa ādesaḥ gaṅgāya oram oragaṅgam iccādi
translated: In the sense of “together with” : “Together with flies” is “with flies.” He eats together with flies, he does not avoid anything, is the meaning. “Among them, growth” , etc., is the substitution of the syllable sa for the syllable ha in the compound saha. “This side of the Ganges” is “this side of the Ganges.”

original: Abyayībhāvasamāso niṭṭhito.
analyzed: abyayībhāva samāsaḥ niṭṭhito
translated: The indeclinable compound is completed.

original: Kammadhārayasamāsa
analyzed: kammadhāraya samāsa
translated: The co-ordinative compound

original: Atha kammadhārayasamāso vuccate.
analyzed: atha kammadhāraya samāsaḥ vuccate
translated: Now the co-ordinative compound is stated.

original: So ca navavidho visesanapubbapado visesanuttarapado visesanobhayapado upamānuttarapado sambhāvanāpubbapado avadhāraṇapubbapado nanipātapubbapado kupubbapado pādipubbapado cāti.
analyzed: so ca navavidhaḥ visesana pubba padaḥ visesana uttara padaḥ visesana ubhaya padaḥ upamāna uttara padaḥ sambhāvanā pubba padaḥ avadhāraṇa pubba padaḥ na nipāta pubba padaḥ ku pubba padaḥ pādi pubba padaḥ ca ati
translated: And that is of nine kinds as the word-group with a distinction at the beginning, with a distinction at the end, with a distinction in both places, with a simile at the end, with a supposition at the beginning, with a limitation at the beginning, with a negative at the beginning, with a ku at the beginning, and with a pa at the beginning.

original: Tattha visesanapubbapado tāva – “mahanta purisa”itīdha ubhayattha paṭhamekavacanaṃ si, tulyādhikaraṇabhāvappasiddhatthaṃ casadda tasaddappayogo, mahanto ca so puriso cāti viggahe –
analyzed: tattha visesana pubba padaḥ tāva mahanta purisa etīdha ubhayattha paṭhama ekavacanam si tulya adhikaraṇa bhāva ppasiddhattham ca sadda ta sadda ppayogaḥ mahantaḥ ca saḥ puriso ca ati viggahe
translated: Herein, the word “great” is the first member of the compound, and the word “man” is the second member. The first word is in the singular number in both cases, and the word “and” is used in order to show that the two words have the same case-relation. The compound is analysed as follows:

original: Ito paraṃ “vibhāsā rukkhatiṇa”iccādito “vibhāsā”ti samāsavidhāne sabbattha vattate.🔽339. Dvipade tulyādhikaraṇe kammadhārayo.
analyzed: itas param vibhāsā vibhāsā ati samāsa vidhāne sabbattha vattate  dvipade tulya adhikaraṇe kammadhārayo
translated: From here on, the compound “vibhāsā rukkhatiṇa” and so on is formed according to the rule:🔽“A dvandva compound is a karmadhāraya when the members have the same case-relation.”
