original: Dve padāni nāmikāni tulyādhikaraṇāni aññamaññena saha vibhāsā samasyante, tasmiṃ dvipade tulyādhikaraṇe sati so samāso kammadhārayasañño ca hoti.
analyzed: dve padāni nāmikāni tulya adhikaraṇāni aññam aññena saha vibhāsā samasyante tasmin dvipade tulya adhikaraṇe sati saḥ samāso kammadhāraya sañño ca hoti
translated: Two words are called “two-footed” . When they have the same case-relation, they are compounded in the dvandva manner, and that compound is called a karmadhāraya.🔽Two words are “two-footed” . When the two words have the same case-relation,

original: Dve padāni dvipadaṃ, tulyaṃ samānaṃ adhikaraṇaṃ attho yassa padadvayassa taṃ tulyādhikaraṇaṃ,🔽tasmiṃ dvipade tulyādhikaraṇe. Bhinnappavattinimittānaṃ dvinnaṃ padānaṃ visesanavisesitabbabhāvena
analyzed: dve padāni dvi padam tulyam samānam adhikaraṇam atthaḥ yassa pada dvayassa tam tulya adhikaraṇam 🔽tasmin dvipade tulya adhikaraṇe bhinna pavatti nimittānam dvinnam padānam visesana visesitabba bhāvena
translated: in that dvandva compound with the same case-relation,

original: ekasmiṃ atthe pavatti tulyādhikaraṇatā. Kammamiva dvayaṃ dhārayatīti kammadhārayo.
analyzed: ekasmin atthe tulya adhikaraṇa tā kammam iva dvayam dhārayati iti kammadhārayaḥ
translated: They are called “having the same case-relation” because they hold the two together as if they were an action.🔽For just as an action holds together the doing and the purpose,

original: Yathā hi kammaṃ kriyañca payojanañca dvayaṃ dhārayati, kamme sati kriyāya, payojanassa🔽ca sambhavato, tathā ayaṃ samāso ekassa atthassa dve nāmāni dhārayati, tasmiṃ samāse
analyzed: yathā hi kammam kriyam ca payojanam ca dvayam dhārayati kamme sati kriyāya payojanassa  ca sambhavataḥ tathā ayam samāsaḥ ekassa atthassa dve nāmāni dhārayati tasmin samāse
translated: since when there is an action, the doing and the purpose come into existence,🔽so too this compound holds together the two names for one meaning,

original: sati ekatthajotakassa nāmadvayassa sambhavato.🔽Pure viya samāsasaññāvibhattilopapakatibhāvā, samāseneva tulyādhikaraṇabhāvassa vuttattā “vuttatthānamappayogo”ti casadda tasaddānamappayogo.
analyzed: sati eka attha jotakassa nāma dvayassa sambhavataḥ  pure viya samāsa saññā vibhatti lopa pakati bhāvā samāsena iva tulya adhikaraṇa bhāvassa vutta ttā vutta tthānam appayogo iti ca sadda ta saddānam appayogo
translated: since when there is the compound, the two names that signify one meaning come into existence.🔽As in the past, there is the compound-sign, the elision of the case-ending, and the normal form.

original: 340. Mahataṃ mahā tulyādhikaraṇe pade.
analyzed: mahatam tulya adhikaraṇe pade
translated: The word “great” has the form “mahā” when it has the same case-relation as a word that means “great.”🔽The word “great” has the form “mahā” when it has the same case-relation as a word that means “great” that follows it.

original: Mahanta saddassa mahā hoti tulyādhikaraṇe uttarapade pare. Mahatanti bahuvacanaggahaṇena
analyzed: mahanta saddassa mahā hoti tulya adhikaraṇe uttara pade pare bahuvacana ggahaṇena
translated: The plural form “mahat” is mentioned🔽in order to show that sometimes the form “mahā” occurs.

original: kvaci mahaādeso ca, ettha ca visesanassa pubbanipāto visesanabhūtassa pubbapadassa
analyzed: kvaci maha ādesaḥ ca ettha ca visesanassa pubba nipātaḥ visesana bhūtassa pubba padassa
translated: And here the order of the qualifier is at the beginning, and the order of the qualified is at the beginning,

original: mahādesavidhānatova viññāyati.
analyzed: mahā desa vidhānataḥ va viññāyati
translated: which is known from the statement of the form “mahā” itself.

original: “Kammadhārayo, digū”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: kammadhārayaḥ diś iti ca vattate
translated: and it is called a “compound with a case-ending”.

original: 341. Ubhe tappurisā.🔽Ubhe kammadhārayadigusamāsā tappurisasaññā honti.🔽Tassa puriso tappuriso, tappurisasadisattā ayampi samāso anvatthasaññāya tappurisoti
analyzed: ubhe tappurisā  ubhe kammadhāraya digu samāsā tappurisa saññāḥ honti  tassa purisaḥ tappurisaḥ tappurisa sadisa ttā ayam pi samāsaḥ anvattha saññāya tappurisaḥ ti
translated: Both are tappurisas.🔽Both these compounds with a case-ending and a tappurisas are called tappurisas.

original: vutto. Yathā hi tappurisasaddo guṇamativatto, tathā ayaṃ samāsopi. Uttarapadatthappadhāno
analyzed: vuttaḥ yathā hi tappurisa saddaḥ guṇam ativatto tathā ayam samāsaḥ api uttara padattha ppadhānaḥ
translated: A man of him is a tappurisas, because he is like a tappurisas. This compound is called a tappurisas because it has the same name as a tappurisas. For just as the word tappurisas is used in the sense of a quality, so too is this compound. For a tappurisas is a compound in which the word for the second member is predominant.

original: hi tappurisoti. Tato nāmabyapadeso syādyuppatti. Ayaṃ pana tappuriso abhidheyyavacano, paraliṅgo ca.🔽Mahāpuriso, mahāpurisā iccādi purisasaddasamaṃ, evaṃ mahāvīro, mahāmuni, mahantañca
analyzed: hi tappurisaḥ iti tatas nāma byapadesaḥ ayam pana tappurisaḥ abhidheyya vacano para liṅgo ca  mahā purisaḥ mahā purisāḥ iccādi purisa sadda samam evam mahāvīraḥ mahā muni mahantam ca
translated: The word tappurisas is formed by the addition of a suffix to a noun. But this tappurisas is a word that expresses a name and has a different gender.

original: taṃ balañcāti mahābalaṃ, mahabbhayaṃ, mahaādeso. Santo ca so puriso cāti sappuriso,
analyzed: tam balam ca ati mahābalam mahabbhayam mahaādesaḥ santaḥ ca saḥ purisaḥ ca ati sappurisaḥ
translated: A great man, great men, etc., are like the word purisa. So too: a great hero, a great sage, and great is that strength, thus great strength, great fear, great country. A good man is a peaceful man.

original: “santasaddassa so bhe bo cante”ti ettha casaddena santasaddassa samāse abhakārepi
analyzed: santa saddassa saḥ bhe bo canta iti ettha ca saddena santa saddassa samāse a bhakāre pi
translated: In the case of the compound of the word santa with the word bhe bo cante, the word cante is used in the sense of “and” in the compound.

original: sādeso, tathā pubbapuriso, parapuriso, paṭhamapuriso, majjhimapuriso, uttamapuriso,
analyzed: sa ādesaḥ tathā pubba purisaḥ para purisaḥ paṭhama purisaḥ majjhima purisaḥ uttama purisaḥ
translated: a place, a man of old, a man of another, a first man, a middle man, a best man,

original: dantapuriso, paramapuriso, vīrapuriso, setahatthī, kaṇhasappo, nīluppalaṃ, lohitacandanaṃ.
analyzed: dantapurisaḥ parama purisaḥ vīra purisaḥ setahatthī kaṇha sappaḥ nīluppalam lohita candanam
translated: a tamed man, a supreme man, a man of courage, a white-handed man, a black-snake man, a blue-lotus man, a red-sandalwood man.

original: Kvaci vibhāsādhikārato na bhavati, yathā – puṇṇo mantāniputto, citto gahapati, sakko devarājāti.
analyzed: kvaci vibhāsa adhikārataḥ na bhavati yathā puṇṇaḥ mantāniputto cittaḥ gahapati sakkaḥ devarājā ati
translated: Sometimes it does not occur because of the explanation of the compound, as in: Puṇṇo mantāniputto, Citto gahapati, Sakko devarājāti.

original: Pumā ca so kokilo cāti atthe samāse kate –
analyzed: pumā ca saḥ kokilo ca ati atthe samāse kate
translated: And he is a male and he is a cuckoo, when the meaning of the compound is made,

original: “Lopa”nti vattate.
analyzed: vattate
translated: “The vowel” is said.

original: 342. Pumassa liṅgādīsu samāsesu.
analyzed: pumassa liṅga ādīsu samāsesu
translated: In the case of the gender, etc., of a male in compounds.

original: Pumaiccetassa anto akāro lopamāpajjate liṅgādīsu parapadesu samāsesu, “aṃmo niggahītaṃ jhalapehī”ti makārassa niggahītaṃ. Puṅkokilo. Evaṃ punnāgo.
analyzed: antaḥ akāraḥ lopam āpajjate liṅga ādīsu para padesu samāsesu niggahītam jha l apehi iti makārassa niggahītam puṅkokilaḥ evam punnāgaḥ
translated: The vowel a inside the word of a male is dropped in the case of the gender, etc., in compounds, as in “aṃmo niggahītaṃ jhalapehī”, the vowel a of the word jhala is dropped. Puṅkokilo. Thus also punnāgo.

original: Khattiyā ca sā kaññā cāti viggayha samāse kate –
analyzed: khattiyā ca sā kaññā ca ati viggayha samāse kate
translated: And she is a noble and she is a girl, when the meaning of the compound is made,

original: “Tulyādhikaraṇe, pade, itthiyaṃ bhāsitapumitthī pumāva ce”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: tulya adhikaraṇe pade itthiyam bhāsita pumitthī pum ava ca iti ca vattate
translated: “In the case of a word with the same case ending, if the word is feminine, the male and feminine are said to be.”

original: 343. Kammadhārayasaññe ca.
analyzed: kammadhāraya saññe ca
translated: In the case of a compound called a copulative compound.

original: Kammadhārayasaññe ca samāse itthiyaṃ vattamāne tulyādhikaraṇe uttarapade pare pubbabhūto
analyzed: kammadhāraya saññe ca samāse itthiyam vattamāne tulya adhikaraṇe uttara pade pare pubba bhūtaḥ
translated: And in a compound with a co-ordinate term, when the feminine is expressed, the feminine ending is dropped in the prior member

original: itthivācako saddo pubbe bhāsitapumā ce, so pumā iva daṭṭhabboti pubbapade itthippaccayassa nivatti hoti.
analyzed: itthi vācako saddo pubbe bhāsita pumā ce saḥ pumā iva daṭṭhabbaḥ iti pubba pade itthi ppaccayassa hoti
translated: if the word expressing the feminine is uttered first, and if the subsequent term is a word expressing a male.

original: Khattiyakaññā, khattiyakaññāyo iccādi. Evaṃ rattalatā, dutiyabhikkhā, brāhmaṇī ca sā dārikā cāti brāhmaṇadārikā, nāgamāṇavikā.
analyzed: khattiya kaññā iccādi evam ratta latā dutiya bhikkhā brāhmaṇī ca sā dārikā ca ati brāhmaṇa dārikā nāga māṇavikā
translated: Khattiyakaññā, khattiyakaññāyo, etc.; thus rattalatā, dutiyabhikkhā, brāhmaṇī ca sā dārikā cāti brāhmaṇadārikā, nāgamāṇavikā.

original: Pubbapadassevāyaṃ pumbhāvātideso, tena “khattiyakumārī kumārasamaṇī taruṇabrāhmaṇī”tiādīsu uttarapadesu itthippaccayassa na nivatti hoti.
analyzed: pubba padassa iva ayam pumbhāva atideso tena khattiya kumārī kumāra samaṇī taruṇa brāhmaṇī iti ādīsu uttara padesu itthi paccayassa na hoti
translated: This is a substitution of the masculine for the prior member. Therefore in such expressions as khattiyakumārī, kumārasamaṇī, taruṇabrāhmaṇī, the feminine ending is not dropped in the subsequent terms.

original: Itthiyamicceva kiṃ? Kumārīratanaṃ, samaṇīpadumaṃ.
analyzed: itthiyam itthiyam ca iva kim kumārī ratanam
translated: Why only if the feminine is expressed? Kumārīratanaṃ, samaṇīpadumaṃ.

original: Bhāsitapumāti kiṃ? Gaṅgānadī, taṇhānadī, pathavīdhātu. “Nandāpokkharaṇī, nandādevī”tiādīsu pana saññāsaddattā na hoti.
analyzed: bhāsita pumā ati kim gaṅgā nadī taṇhā nadī pathavī dhātu nandā pokkharaṇī nandādevī iti ādīsu pana saññā saddattā na hoti
translated: What is the point of “if the word expressing the feminine is uttered first”? Gaṅgānadī, taṇhānadī, pathavīdhātu. But in such expressions as Nandāpokkharaṇī, Nandādevī, it is not so because of the conventional meaning.

original: Tathā puratthimo ca so kāyo cāti puratthimakāyo, ettha ca kāyekadeso kāyasaddo. Evaṃ
analyzed: tathā puratthimo ca so kāyo ca ati puratthima kāyaḥ ettha ca kāya ekadesaḥ kāya saddo evam
translated: Likewise, the front and the body are the front part of the body. Here the word ‘body’ is a part of the body. Thus,

original: pacchimakāyo, heṭṭhimakāyo, uparimakāyo, sabbakāyo, purāṇavihāro, navāvāso, kataranikāyo,🔽katamanikāyo, hetuppaccayo, abahulaṃ bahulaṃ katanti bahulīkataṃ, jīvitappadhānaṃ🔽navakaṃ jīvitanavakaṃ iccādi.🔽Visesanuttarapade jinavacanānuparodhato therācariyapaṇḍitādi visesanaṃ parañca bhavati.🔽Yathā – sāriputto ca so thero cāti sāriputtatthero. Evaṃ mahāmoggallānatthero, mahākassapatthero,🔽buddhaghosācariyo, dhammapālācariyo, ācariyaguttiloti vā, mahosadho ca so paṇḍito🔽cāti mahosadhapaṇḍito. Evaṃ vidhurapaṇḍito, vatthuviseso.
analyzed: pacchima kāyo heṭṭhima kāyo uparima kāyo sabba kāyo purāṇa vihāro nava āvāso katara nikāyo  katama nikāyaḥ hetu ppaccayaḥ abahulam bahulam katanti bahulīkatam jīvita ppadhānam  navakam jīvita navakam it ca ādi  visesana uttara pade jina vacana an uparodhato thera ācariya paṇḍita ādi visesanam param ca bhavati  yathā sāriputto ca so thero ca ati sāriputta theraḥ evam mahāmoggallāna ttheraḥ mahākassapa ttheraḥ  buddhaghosa ācariyaḥ dhammapāla ācariyaḥ ācariya guttilo ti vā mahosadhaḥ ca so paṇḍito  ca ati mahosadha paṇḍitaḥ evam vidhura paṇḍitaḥ vatthu viseso
translated: the back part of the body, the lower part of the body, the upper part of the body, the whole body, the old monastery, the new dwelling, the group of which one is a member,

original: Visesanobhayapado yathā – sītañca taṃ uṇhañcāti sītuṇhaṃ, siniddho ca so uṇho cāti
analyzed: visesana ubhaya padaḥ yathā sītam ca tam uṇham ca ati sītuṇham siniddhaḥ ca saḥ uṇhaḥ ca ati
translated: the group of which another is a member, the condition of cause, the condition of predominance, the condition of proximity, the condition of contiguity, the condition of absence, the condition of disappearance, the condition of repetition, the condition of repetition in abundance, the condition of repetition in abundance, the condition of repetition in abundance, the condition of abundance, the condition of repetition in abundance,

original: siniddhuṇho, māso. Khañjo ca so khujjo cāti khañjakhujjo. Evaṃ andhabadhiro, katākataṃ,
analyzed: siniddhuṇhaḥ māsaḥ khañjaḥ ca saḥ khujjaḥ ca ati khañjakhujjaḥ evam andha badhiraḥ kata akatam
translated: and the moon is siniddhuṇho. He is both lame and crooked, thus khañjakhujjo. So too, andha-badhiro, katākataṃ,

original: chiddāvachiddaṃ, uccāvacaṃ, chinnabhinnaṃ, sittasammaṭṭhaṃ, gatapaccāgataṃ.
analyzed: chidda avachiddam uccāvacam chinna bhinnam sitta sammaṭṭham gata paccāgatam
translated: chiddā-vachiddaṃ, uccā-vacam, chinna-bhinnaṃ, sitta-sammattaṃ, gata-paccāgataṃ.

original: Upamānuttarapade abhidhānānurodhato upamānabhūtaṃ visesanaṃ paraṃ bhavati. Yathā
analyzed: upamāna uttara pade abhidhāna anurodhataḥ upamāna bhūtam visesanam param bhavati yathā
translated: In the case of the word upamānuttara, the word that is the correlative of the word that is the simile is the last, in accordance with the rule of construing the simile in the way beginning with “as”.

original: – sīho viya sīho, muni ca so sīho cāti munisīho. Evaṃ munivasabho, munipuṅgavo, buddhanāgo,
analyzed: sīhaḥ ca saḥ sīhaḥ ca ati muni sīhaḥ evam muni vasabhaḥ muni puṅgavaḥ buddha nāgo
translated: Thus: he is a lion and a sage, thus munisīho. So too, munivasabho, munipuṅgavo, buddhanāgo,

original: buddhādicco, raṃsi viya raṃsi, saddhammo ca so raṃsi cāti saddhammaraṃsi. Evaṃ vinayasāgaro,
analyzed: buddha ādiccaḥ raṃsi viya raṃsi saddhammo ca saḥ raṃsi ca ati saddhamma raṃsi evam vinaya sāgaraḥ
translated: buddhādicco, he is the radiance and the True Idea, thus saddhammaraṃsi. So too, vinayasāgaro,

original: puṇḍarīkamiva puṇḍarīko, samaṇo ca so puṇḍarīko cāti samaṇapuṇḍarīko, samaṇapadumo.
analyzed: puṇḍarīkam iva puṇḍarīkaḥ samaṇaḥ ca saḥ puṇḍarīkaḥ ca ati samaṇa puṇḍarīkaḥ samaṇa padumaḥ
translated: he is a lotus and an ascetic, thus samaṇapuṇḍarīko, samaṇapadumo.

original: Cando viya cando, mukhañca taṃ cando cāti mukhacando. Evaṃ mukhapadumaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: candaḥ candaḥ mukham ca tam cando ca ati mukhacando evam mukhapadumam iccādi
translated: He is the moon and the face, thus mukhacando. So too, mukhapadumaṃ iccādi.

original: Sambhāvanāpubbapado yathā – dhammo iti buddhi dhammabuddhi. Evaṃ dhammasaññā, dhammasaṅkhāto,
analyzed: sambhāvanā pubba padaḥ yathā dhammo iti buddhi dhamma buddhi evam dhamma saññā dhamma saṅkhāto
translated: In the case of the word dhammabuddhi, the word that is the object of respect is the first, thus: the understanding that is the True Idea is dhammabuddhi. So too, dhammasaññā, dhammasaṅkhāto,

original: dhammasammato, pāṇasaññitā, asubhasaññā, aniccasaññā, anattasaññā, dhātusaññā, dhītusaññā,
analyzed: dhamma sammataḥ pāṇa saññitā asubha saññā anicca saññā anatta saññā dhātu saññā dhītu saññā
translated: The word dhamma is a term of approval. The words pāṇasaññitā, asubhasaññā, aniccasaññā, anattasaññā, dhātusaññā, dhītusaññā,

original: attasaññā, atthisaññā, attadiṭṭhi iccādi.
analyzed: atta saññā atthi saññā atta diṭṭhi iccādi
translated: attasaññā, atthisaññā, attadiṭṭhi, etc., are terms of approval.

original: Avadhāraṇapubbapado yathā – guṇo eva dhanaṃ guṇadhanaṃ. Evaṃ saddhādhanaṃ, sīladhanaṃ,
analyzed: avadhāraṇa pubba padaḥ yathā guṇaḥ eva dhanam guṇa dhanam evam saddhā dhanam sīla dhanam
translated: The word guṇa is a term of approval. The compound guṇadhanaṃ is a bahubbīhi compound. The words saddhādhanaṃ, sīladhanaṃ,

original: paññādhanaṃ, cakkhu eva indriyaṃ cakkhundriyaṃ. Evaṃ cakkhāyatanaṃ, cakkhudhātu,
analyzed: paññā dhanam cakkhu eva indriyam cakkhu indriyam evam cakkha āyatanam cakkhu dhātu
translated: paññādhanaṃ, cakkhu eva indriyaṃ cakkhundriyaṃ. The words cakkhāyatanaṃ, cakkhudhātu,

original: cakkhudvāraṃ, rūpārammaṇamiccādi.
analyzed: cakkhu dvāram rūpa ārammaṇam iccādi
translated: cakkhudvāraṃ, rūpārammaṇaṃ, etc., are bahubbīhi compounds.

original: Nanipātapubbapado yathā – na brāhmaṇoti atthe kammadhārayasamāse, vibhattilopādimhi ca kate –
analyzed: na nipāta pubba padaḥ yathā na brāhmaṇaḥ iti atthe kammadhāraya samāse vibhatti lopa ādimhi ca kate
translated: The word na is a negative particle. The compound na brāhmaṇo is a kammadhāraya compound. The words ubhe tappurisā are a tappurisa compound.

original: “Ubhe tappurisā”ti tappurisasaññā.
analyzed: ubhe tappurisā ati tappurisa saññā
translated: The word tappurisā is a tappurisa compound.

original: 344. Attaṃ nassa tappurise.
analyzed: attam nassa tappurise
translated: The word attaṃ is a tappurisa compound.

original: Nassa nipātapadassa tappurise uttarapade pare sabbasseva attaṃ hoti. Tappurisekadesattā tappuriso, abrāhmaṇo.
analyzed: nassa nipāta padassa tappurise uttara pade pare sabbassa iva attam hoti tappurisa ikadesa ttā tappurisaḥ a brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: The word attaṃ is a tappurisa compound. The word attaṃ is added to the negative particle na and to the word tappurisā. The word tappuriso is a tappurisa compound. The word abrāhmaṇo is a tappurisa compound.

original: Na nisedho sato yutto,
analyzed: na nisedhaḥ sataḥ yutto
translated: The negative particle na is not suitable

original: Desādiniyamaṃ vinā;
analyzed: vinā
translated: without restriction of place, etc.;

original: Asato cāphalo tasmā,
analyzed: asataḥ ca aphalaḥ tasmā
translated: and it is fruitless when there is no negation,

original: Kathamabrāhmaṇoti ce?
analyzed: katham abrāhmaṇāḥ iti ce
translated: so how is it that na brāhmaṇo is not a negation?

original: Nisedhatthānuvādena, paṭisedhavidhi kvaci;🔽Parassa micchāñāṇattā-khyāpanāyopapajjate.
analyzed: nisedha ttha anuvādena paṭisedha vidhi kvaci  parassa micchā ñāṇa ttā khyāpanāya upapajjate
translated: And in the sense of preclusion, in some cases.

original: Duvidho cassattho pasajjappaṭisedhapariyudāsavasena.
analyzed: duvidhaḥ pasajja ppaṭisedha pariyudāsa vasena
translated: And the meaning of the negative particle is twofold, as denial and as preclusion.

original: Tattha yo “asūriyapassā rājadārā”tiādīsu viya uttarapadatthassa sabbathā abhāvaṃ
analyzed: tattha yaḥ rāja dārāti ādīsu viya uttara padatthassa sabbathā abhāvam
translated: Herein, that which shows the utter absence of the meaning of the latter term, as in the case of “non-sun-viewers” and “non-king’s wives,”

original: dīpeti, so pasajjappaṭisedhavācī nāma. Yo pana “abrāhmaṇa amanussā”tiādīsu viya uttarapadatthaṃ
analyzed: dīpeti so pasajjappaṭisedha vācī nāma yaḥ pana uttara pada ttham
translated: is said to have the function of denial. But that which, as in the case of “non-Brahmans” and “non-human beings,”

original: pariyudāsitvā taṃsadise vatthumhi kāriyaṃ paṭipādayati, so pariyudāsavācī nāma.
analyzed: pariyudāsitvā taṃsadise vatthumhi kāriyam paṭipādayati saḥ pariyudāsavācī nāma
translated: sets aside the meaning of the latter term and enjoins action in regard to what is similar to that, is said to have the function of preclusion.

original: Vuttañca
analyzed: vuttam ca
translated: And it is said:

original: “Pasajjappaṭisedhassa, lakkhaṇaṃ vatthunatthitā;
analyzed: pasajja ppaṭisedhassa lakkhaṇam vatthu natthi tā
translated: “The characteristic of the negative particle in the sense of denial🔽Is the non-existence of the substratum;🔽The characteristic of preclusion is the use

original: Vatthuto aññatra vutti, pariyudāsalakkhaṇa”nti.
analyzed: vatthutaḥ aññatra vutti pariyudāsa lakkhaṇa nti
translated: Of the word in a sense other than the substratum.”

original: Nanvevaṃ santepi “abrāhmaṇo”tiādīsu kathamuttarapadatthappadhānatā siyāti?
analyzed: nanu evam sante pi abrāhmaṇa uti ādīsu katham uttara padattha ppadhāna tā siyāti
translated: But in that case, how can there be predominance of the meaning of the latter term in such expressions as “non-Brahman”?

original: Vuccate – brāhmaṇādisaddānaṃ brāhmaṇādiatthasseva taṃsadisādiatthassāpi vācakattā,
analyzed: vuccate brāhmaṇa ādi saddānam brāhmaṇa ādi atthassa iva vācaka ttā
translated: It may be said: because the words “Brahman” and so on denote not only the meaning of “Brahman” and so on but also the meaning of what is similar to that.

original: brāhmaṇādisaddā hi kevalābrāhmaṇādiatthesveva pākaṭā, bhūsaddo viyasattāyaṃ, yadā
analyzed: brāhmaṇa ādi saddāḥ hi kevala abrāhmaṇa ādi atthesu eva pākaṭāḥ bhū saddaḥ yadā
translated: For the words brāhmaṇa, etc., are only obvious in the sense of brāhmaṇa, etc., but the word bhū is in the sense of earth.

original: te pana aññena sadisādivācakena naiti nipātena yujjanti, tadā taṃsadisatadaññatabbiruddhatadabhāvesupi
analyzed: te pana aññena sadisa ādi vācakena na eti nipātena yujjanti tadā tad sadisa tad añña tad viruddha tad abhāvesu pi
translated: But when they are coupled with the indeclinable na, which expresses similarity, etc., then they also occur in the sense of the opposite of that, and in the sense of the absence of that,

original: vattanti, bhūsaddo viya anvabhiyādiyoge anubhavanaabhibhavanādīsu, tasmā uttarapadatthajotakoyevettha
analyzed: vattanti bhū saddaḥ anu abhi ādi yoge anubhavana abhibhavana ādīsu tasmai
translated: just as the word bhū does in the compounds anvabhiyā, abhibhavana, etc., in the sense of ‘experiencing’, ‘subjugating’, etc. Therefore the indeclinable na here

original: naiti nipātoti na doso, tena abrāhmaṇoti brāhmaṇasadisoti vuttaṃ hoti. Evaṃ amanusso, assamaṇo.
analyzed: na eti nipāto ti na doso tena abrāhmaṇaḥ ti brāhmaṇa sadisaḥ ti vuttam hoti evam amanussaḥ a samaṇaḥ
translated: only indicates the meaning of the second member of the compound, and so there is no fault. Thus abrāhmaṇa means ‘similar to a brāhmaṇa’. So too amanussa, assamaṇa.

original: Aññatthe – na byākatā abyākatā, asaṃkiliṭṭhā, apariyāpannā.
analyzed: aññatthe na byākatā a byākatā a saṃkiliṭṭhā a pariyāpannā
translated: In the sense of other: abyākatā = na byākatā, asaṃkiliṭṭhā = na saṃkiliṭṭhā, apariyāpannā = na pariyāpannā.

original: Viruddhatthe – na kusalā akusalā, kusalapaṭipakkhāti attho. Evaṃ alobho, amitto.
analyzed: viruddha atthe na kusalā akusalā kusala paṭipakkhā ati atthaḥ evam alobhaḥ amitto
translated: In the sense of the opposite: akusalā = na kusalā, kusalapaṭipakkho = na kusalapaṭipakkho. So too alobho, amitto.

original: Pasajjappaṭisedhe – na katvā akatvā, akātuna puññaṃ akaronto.
analyzed: na katvā a katvā puññam a karontaḥ
translated: In the sense of the prevention of addition: akatvā = na katvā, akaronto = na karont o, akatvā puññaṃ = na katvā puññaṃ.

original: “Nassa, tappurise”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: nassa tappurisa iti ca vattate
translated: And na is also used in the sense of ‘that person’.

original: 345. Sare ana.
analyzed: sare ana
translated: In the sense of ‘not’ in the sense of ‘not that’: ana.

original: Naiccetassa padassa tappurise uttarapade ana hoti sare pare.
analyzed: na e c ca itassa padassa tappurise uttara pade ana hoti sare pare
translated: When the word na is followed by the word tappurisa, ana is used in the sense of ‘not that’ when the following word is a noun.

original: Na asso anasso, na ariyo anariyo. Evaṃ anissaro, aniṭṭho, anupavādo, na ādāya anādāya, anoloketvā iccādi.
analyzed: na assaḥ an assaḥ na ariyaḥ an ariyaḥ evam anissaraḥ aniṭṭhaḥ an upavādaḥ na ādāya an ādāya anoloketvā iccādi
translated: not a horse, not a non-horse, not a noble, not a non-noble. Thus: not dependent, not unloved, not unblamed, not taking, not not taking, not looking, and so on.

original: Kupubbapado yathā – kucchitamannanti niccasamāsattā aññapadena viggaho, kammadhārayasamāse kate –
analyzed: ku pubba padaḥ yathā nicca samāsa ttā añña padena viggahaḥ kammadhāraya samāse kate
translated: The prefix ku- is as follows: “kuccarita” is a compound word, so it cannot be separated by another word. When a kammadhāraya compound is made,

original: “Tappurise, sare”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: tappurise sara iti ca vattate
translated: “tappurisare” is said.

original: 346. Kadada kussa.
analyzed: kadada kussa
translated: Kadada kussa.

original: Kuiccetassa nipātassa tappurise uttarapade kada hoti sare pare. Kadannaṃ. Evaṃ kadasanaṃ.
analyzed: ku it ca itassa nipātassa tappurise uttara pade kada hoti sare pare kadannam evam kadasanam
translated: When the indeclinable ku- is in the sense of “bad,” kad- is used before the following word tappurisare. Kadannaṃ. Thus, kadasanaṃ.

original: Sareti kiṃ? Kudārā, kuputtā, kudāsā, kudiṭṭhi.
analyzed: sarā iti kim ku dārā ku puttā ku dāsā ku diṭṭhi
translated: What is the meaning of sare? Kudārā, kuputtā, kudāsā, kudiṭṭhi.

original: “Kussā”ti vattate.
analyzed: kussā ati vattate
translated: “Kussā” is said.

original: 347. Kāppatthesu ca.
analyzed: kāppatthesu ca
translated: . And in the sense of “small.”

original: Kuiccetassa appatthe vattamānassa kā hoti tappurise uttarapade pare. Bahuvacanuccāraṇato
analyzed: ku iccā itassa appatthe vattamānassa kā hoti tappurise uttara pade pare bahuvacana uccāraṇataḥ
translated: When ku- is used in the sense of “small,” kā is used before the following word tappurisare. Because it is recited in the plural,

original: kucchitatthe ca kvaci tappurise. Appakaṃ lavaṇaṃ kālavaṇaṃ. Evaṃ kāpupphaṃ, kucchito
analyzed: kucchi tatthe ca kvaci tappurise appakam lavaṇam kālavaṇam evam kāpuppham kucchitaḥ
translated: and in some cases tappurisare in the sense of “small.” A little salt is kālavaṇa. Thus, kāpupphaṃ, kucchito

original: puriso kāpuriso, kupuriso vā.
analyzed: purisaḥ kāpurisaḥ kupurisaḥ vā
translated: puriso kāpuriso, kupuriso.

original: Pādipubbapado ca niccasamāsova, padhānaṃ vacanaṃ pāvacanaṃ, bhusaṃ vaddhaṃ pavaddhaṃ,
analyzed: pa ādi pubba padaḥ ca nicca samāsaḥ uva padhānam vacanam pā vacanam bhusam vaddham pavaddham
translated: And the first member of a compound is always compounded, as in padhānaṃ, pāvacanaṃ, bhusaṃ, pavaddhaṃ,

original: sarīraṃ, samaṃ, sammā vā ādhānaṃ samādhānaṃ, vividhā mati vimati, vividho kappo vikappo,🔽visiṭṭho vā kappo vikappo, adhiko devo atidevo. Evaṃ adhidevo, adhisīlaṃ, sundaro
analyzed: sarīram samam sammā vai ādhānam samādhānam vividhā mati vimati vividhaḥ kappaḥ vikappo  visiṭṭhaḥ vā kappaḥ vikappaḥ adhikaḥ devaḥ atidevaḥ evam adhidevaḥ adhisīlam sundaraḥ
translated: sarīraṃ, samaṃ, sammā, samādhānaṃ, vimati, vikappo,

original: gandho sugandho, kucchito gandho duggandho, sobhanaṃ kataṃ sukataṃ, asobhanaṃ kataṃ dukkaṭaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: gandhaḥ sugandhaḥ kucchitaḥ gandhaḥ duggandhaḥ sobhanam katam su katam asobhanam katam dukkaṭam iccādi
translated: vikappo, atidevo, adhidevo, adhisīlaṃ, sugandho, duggandho, sukataṃ, dukkaṭaṃ, etc.

original: Ye idha avihitalakkhaṇā nāmanipātopasaggā, tesaṃ “nāmānaṃ samāso”ti yogavibhāgena
analyzed: ye idha avihita lakkhaṇāḥ nāma nipāta upasaggā tesam nāmānam yogavibhāgena
translated: Those which are not mentioned here as having a particular characteristic, but which are compounds of a prefix and a noun, should be regarded as compounds of a noun with a noun,

original: samāso daṭṭhabbo. Yathā – apunageyyā gāthā, acandamullokikāni mukhāni, assaddhabhojī,
analyzed: samāsaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ yathā a puna geyyā gāthā mukhāni a saddha bhojī
translated: as in apunageyyā gāthā, acandamullokikāni mukhāni, assaddhabhojī,

original: alavaṇabhojītiādīsu ayuttatthattā nāññena samāso.
analyzed: a lavaṇa bhojī iti ādīsu ayutta attha ttā na aññena samāsaḥ
translated: alavaṇabhojī, etc., where there is no compound with another part of speech because it would be meaningless.

original: Tathā diṭṭho pubbanti diṭṭhapubbo tathāgataṃ. Evaṃ sutapubbo dhammaṃ, gatapubbo maggaṃ,
analyzed: tathā diṭṭhaḥ pubbanti diṭṭha pubbaḥ tathāgatam evam suta pubbaḥ dhammam gata pubbaḥ maggam
translated: So too, diṭṭhapubbaṃ = diṭṭhapubbo, tathāgataṃ, sutapubbaṃ = sutapubbaṃ, dhammaṃ, gatapubbaṃ = gatapubbaṃ, maggaṃ,

original: kammani diṭṭhā pubbanti diṭṭhapubbā devā tena. Evaṃ sutapubbā dhammā, gatapubbā disā,
analyzed: kammani diṭṭhā pubbanti diṭṭha pubbā devā tena evam suta pubbāḥ dhammāḥ gata pubbāḥ disā
translated: The gods have seen it before, thus they are called “those who have seen before” (diṭṭhapubbā devā). So too, “those who have heard before” (sutapubbā dhammā), “those who have gone before” (gatapubbā disā),

original: pahāro, parābhavo, vihāro, āhāro, upahāro iccādi.
analyzed: pahāraḥ parābhavaḥ vihāraḥ āhāraḥ upahāraḥ iccādi
translated: “a blow” (pahāro), “a defeat” (parābhavo), “a dwelling” (vihāro), “nourishment” (āhāra), “a gift” (upahāra), and so on.

original: Kammadhārayasamāso.
analyzed: kammadhāraya samāsaḥ
translated: This is a compound of the co-ordination class.

original: Digusamāsa
analyzed: digu samāsa
translated: The compound of the long class

original: Atha digusamāso vuccate.
analyzed: atha digu samāsaḥ vuccate
translated: Now the compound of the long class is stated.

original: Tayo lokā samāhaṭā cittena sampiṇḍitā, tiṇṇaṃ lokānaṃ samāhāroti vā atthe –
analyzed: tayaḥ lokā samāhaṭā cittena sampiṇḍitā tiṇṇam lokānam samāhāro ti vā atthe
translated: The three worlds are collected together, combined by the mind, or the meaning is: “the collection of the three worlds” (tiṇṇaṃ lokānaṃ samāhāro).

original: “Nāmānaṃ samāso yuttattho”ti vattamāne “dvipade”tiādinā kammadhārayasamāso, tato samāsasaññāyaṃ, vibhattilope, pakatibhāve ca kate –
analyzed: samāsaḥ vattamāne dvipada iti ādinā kammadhāraya samāso tatas samāsa saññā ayam vibhatti lope pakati bhāve ca kate
translated: When it is said “The compound of names has a connected meaning,” the compound of the co-ordination class beginning with “two-footed” (dvipada) is stated. Then, when the compound is given the name “long,” the case endings are elided, and the original forms are restored,

original: “Kammadhārayo”ti vattate.🔽348. Saṅkhyāpubbo digu.
analyzed: kammadhārayā iti vattate  saṅkhyā pubbaḥ digu
translated: it is said “The co-ordination class.”🔽The long class has a numeral as its first member

original: Saṅkhyāpubbo kammadhārayasamāso digusañño hoti.🔽Dve gāvo digu, digusadisattā ayampi samāso digūti vutto. Atha vā saṅkhyāpubbattanapuṃsakekattasaṅkhātehi
analyzed: saṅkhyā pubbaḥ kammadhāraya samāsaḥ digu saññaḥ hoti  dve gāvaḥ digu digu sadisa ttāḥ ayam pi samāsaḥ digu iti vuttaḥ atha vā saṅkhyā pubbatta napuṃsaka ikatta saṅkhātehi
translated: The compound of the co-ordination class that has a numeral as its first member is given the name “long.”🔽Two cows is long. Because it is similar to long, this compound is also said to be long. Or alternatively, it is said to be long because it has gone, is understood, by means of the two characteristics called “having a numeral as its first member” and “being a compound of a neuter noun and a singular common noun.”

original: dvīhi lakkhaṇehi gato avagatoti digūti vuccati, dvīhi vā lakkhaṇehi gacchati pavattatīti
analyzed: dvīhi lakkhaṇehi gataḥ avagataḥ ti vuccati dvīhi vā lakkhaṇehi gacchati pavattati iti
translated: Or else, it is said to be long because it goes, it occurs, by means of two characteristics.

original: digu. Ettha ca “saṅkhyāpubbo”ti vuttattā saṅkhyāsaddasseva pubbanipāto, “ubhe tappurisā”ti tappurisasaññā.
analyzed: ettha ca saṅkhyā pubbaḥ iti vutta ttā saṅkhyā saddassa iva pubbanipātaḥ ubhe tappurisā ti tappurisa saññā
translated: And here, because it is said “with a numeral as its prefix,” the prefix is only the numeral word, and the compound is called “with a dual-gender word as its second member.”

original: “Napuṃsakaliṅgo”ti vattate.
analyzed: napuṃsaka liṅgā iti vattate
translated: It is called “having a neuter gender.”

original: 349. Digussekattaṃ.
analyzed: diś usseka ttam
translated: The singleness of a dual compound.

original: Digussa samāsassa ekattaṃ hoti, napuṃsakaliṅgattañca.
analyzed: samāsassa eka attam hoti napuṃsaka liṅga attam ca
translated: The singleness and the neuter gender of a dual compound is made singular.

original: Samāhāradigussetaṃ gahaṇaṃ, tattha sabbatthekavacanameva hoti, aññatra pana bahuvacanampi, nāmabyapadesasyādyuppatti amādesādi.🔽Tilokaṃ, he tiloka, tilokaṃ, tilokena, tilokassa, tilokā tilokasmā tilokamhā, tilokassa, tiloke tilokamhi tilokasmiṃ.
analyzed: gahaṇam tattha sabbattha ekavacanam eva hoti aññatra pana bahuvacanam pi  tilokam he tiloka tilokam tilokena tilokassa tilokā tilokasmā tilokamhā tilokassa tiloke tilokamhi tilokasmin
translated: This is a general statement, but in other cases the plural is also used. The origin of the name is from the substitution of the vowel a for the final vowel of the first member.🔽The three worlds, the three worlds, the three worlds, by the three worlds, of the three worlds, the three worlds, from the three worlds, from the three worlds, of the three worlds, in the three worlds, in the three worlds.

original: Evaṃ tayo daṇḍā tidaṇḍaṃ, tīṇi malāni samāhaṭāni, tiṇṇaṃ malānaṃ samāhāroti vā timalaṃ,
analyzed: evam tayaḥ daṇḍā ti daṇḍam tīṇi malāni samāhaṭāni vā ti malam
translated: Thus, three sticks, a triple stick, the three taints collected, or the three taints collected, a taint of three,

original: tilakkhaṇaṃ, catussaccaṃ, catasso disā catuddisaṃ, “saro rasso napuṃsake”ti rassattaṃ,
analyzed: ti lakkhaṇam catussaccam catasso disā catuddisam saraḥ rassaḥ napuṃsaka iti rassattam
translated: the three characteristics, the four truths, the four directions, the four quarters, “saro rasso napuṃsake” (Pā. 1.2.58), the singleness,

original: pañcasikkhāpadaṃ, saḷāyatanaṃ, sattāhaṃ, aṭṭhasīlaṃ, navalokuttaraṃ, dasasīlaṃ, satayojanaṃ.
analyzed: pañca sikkhāpadam saṭāyatanam satta aham aṭṭha sīlam nava lokuttaram dasa sīlam sata yojanam
translated: Five training precepts, six sense bases, seven days, eight precepts, nine supramundane, ten precepts, a distance of a hundred leagues.

original: Tathā – dve rattiyo dvirattaṃ, tisso rattiyo tirattaṃ, dve aṅguliyo dvaṅgulaṃ, satta godāvariyo, tāsaṃ samāhāroti vā sattagodāvaraṃ.
analyzed: tathā dve rattiyaḥ dvi rattam tissaḥ rattiyaḥ tirattam dve aṅguliyaḥ dvaṅgulam satta godāvariyo tāsam vā satta godāvaram
translated: Likewise: two nights, for two nights; three nights, for three nights; two fingers, two fingerbreadths; seven Godhāvaris, a distance of seven Godhāvaris.

original: Ettha ca ratti aṅguli godāvarīnamantassa –
analyzed: ettha ca ratti aṅguli godāvarīnamantassa
translated: And here, in the case of the words ratti, aṅguli, and godhāvarī,

original: 350. Kvaci samāsantagatānamakāranto.
analyzed: kvaci samāsa anta gata anama kāra antaḥ
translated: In some instances the final vowel of the first member is not elided when a compound is formed.

original: Rājādigaṇassetaṃ gahaṇaṃ, tena samāsantagatānaṃ rājādīnaṃ nāmānaṃ anto kvaci akāro
analyzed: rāja ādi gaṇassa etam gahaṇam tena samāsa anta gatānam rāja ādīnam antaḥ kvaci akāraḥ
translated: This is the case with the words rājā, etc., which are taken as a class. Therefore the meaning is: in some instances the final vowel of the first member of compounds such as rājā, etc., is not elided.

original: hotīti attho. Kāraggahaṇena bahubbīhādimhi samāsante kvaci kappaccayo hoti, surabhi🔽su du pūtīhi gandhantassikāro ca.
analyzed: hoti iti atthaḥ kāra ggahaṇena bahu bīha ādimhi samāsa ante kvaci kappaccayaḥ hoti surabhi  su du pūtīhi ca
translated: By the word kāra, the elision of the final vowel of the first member is also included in bahubbīhi compounds, etc. The letter s is elided in the case of the words surabhi, sudu, and pūti.

original: Atha vā a ca ko ca akā, rakāro padasandhikaro, tena kvaci samāsantagatānamanto hutvā
analyzed: atha vā a ca kaḥ ca akāraḥ pada sandhi karaḥ tena kvaci hutvā
translated: Or else: a and k are ak; the letter r is a word-connector. Therefore the meaning is: in some instances the final vowel of the first member of compounds is elided and becomes a, k, or r.🔽By the word kāra, the elision of the final vowel of the first member is also included in bahubbīhi compounds, etc. The letter s is elided in the case of the words surabhi, sudu, and pūti.

original: a ka iccete paccayā hontīti attho. Tena pañca gāvo samāhaṭāti atthe samāsādiṃ katvā
analyzed: a ke icca ete paccayāḥ honti iti tena pañca gāvaḥ ati atthe samāsādim katvā
translated: Or else: a and k are ak; the letter r is a word-connector. Therefore the meaning is: in some instances the final vowel of the first member of compounds is elided and becomes a, k, or r.🔽By the word kāra, the elision of the final vowel of the first member is also included in bahubbīhi compounds, etc. The letter s is elided in the case of the words surabhi, sudu, and pūti.🔽Or else: a and k are ak; the letter r is a word-connector. Therefore the meaning is: in some instances the final vowel of the first member of compounds is elided and becomes a, k, or r.🔽By the word kāra, the elision of the final vowel of the first member is also included in bahubbīhi compounds, etc. The letter s is elided in the case of the

original: samāsante appaccaye, “o sare cā”ti avādese ca kate “pañcagava”ntiādi ca sijjhati.
analyzed: samāsa ante a p paccaye o sare ca ati ava ādese ca kate pañcagavanti ādi ca sijjhati
translated: In short, when there is no elision, and when there is no elision of the first syllable, the compound is resolved as “five cows” and so on.

original: “Dviratta”ntiādīsu pana appaccaye kate pubbasarassa “saralopo”tiādinā lopo.
analyzed: dvi ratta nti ādīsu pana appaccaye kate pubba sarassa sara lopa iti ādinā lopaḥ
translated: But when there is elision of the first syllable, the compound is resolved as “two nights” and so on.🔽The compound of the type “two men” is resolved as “one and a man” = “one man.” So too, “one idea,” “one son,” “three worlds,” “four quarters,” “ten thousand world-spheres,” and so on.

original: Asamāhāradigu yathā – eko ca so puggalo cāti ekapuggalo. Evaṃ ekadhammo, ekaputto, tayo bhavā tibhavā, catasso disā catuddisā, dasasahassacakkavāḷāni iccādi.🔽Digusamāso.
analyzed: yathā ekaḥ ca so puggalo ca ati eka puggalo evam eka dhammo eka putto tayaḥ bhavā ti bhavā catasso disā catuddisā dasa sahassa cakkavāḷāni iccādi  digu samāsaḥ
translated: This is the compound of the type “two men.”

original: Tappurisasamāsa
analyzed: tappurisa samāsa
translated: The compound of the type “one man”

original: Atha tappurisasamāso vuccate.
analyzed: atha tappurisa samāsaḥ vuccate
translated: Now the compound of the type “one man” is stated.

original: So pana dutiyādīsu chasu vibhattīsu bhāvato chabbidho. Tattha dutiyātappuriso gatanissitātītātikkantappattāpannādīhi bhavati.
analyzed: so pana dutiya ādīsu chasu vibhattīsu bhāvataḥ chabbidhaḥ tattha dutiya atappurisaḥ gata nissita atīta atikkanta ppatta āpanna ādīhi bhavati
translated: But that is of six kinds according to the six cases beginning with the second. Herein, the compound of the type “one man” is in the second case with “gone,” “dependent,” “past,” “transcended,” “attained,” “obtained,” and so on.

original: Saraṇaṃ gatoti viggahe –
analyzed: saraṇam gataḥ iti viggahe
translated: When resolved as “gone to the refuge”

original: “Tappuriso”ti vattate.
analyzed: tappurisaḥ iti vattate
translated: it is called “of the type ‘one man.’”

original: 351. Amādayo parapadebhi.
analyzed: am ādayaḥ para padebhiḥ
translated: With others than the first

original: Amādivibhatyantāni yuttatthāni pubbapadāni nāmehi parapadebhi saha vibhāsā samasyante, so samāso tappurisasañño hoti. Ayañca tappuriso abhidheyyavacanaliṅgo.
analyzed: am ādi vibhati antāni yut tatthāni pubba padāni nāmehi para padebhi saha vibhāsā samasyante saḥ samāsaḥ tappurisa saññaḥ hoti ayam ca tappurisaḥ abhidheyya vacana liṅgaḥ
translated: The first words ending in a case-ending and having a meaning are compounded with the following nouns, and that compound is called a “tappurisa”. And this tappurisa has the gender of the last member.

original: Gatādisaddā kitantattā tiliṅgā, vibhattilopādi sabbaṃ pubbasamaṃ. So saraṇagato,🔽te saraṇagatā. Sā saraṇagatā, tā saraṇagatāyo. Taṃ kulaṃ saraṇagataṃ, tāni kulāni
analyzed: gata ādi saddā ki tad anta ttā ti liṅgā vibhatti lopa ādi sabbam pubba samam saḥ saraṇa gataḥ  te saraṇa gatā sā saraṇa gatā tā saraṇa gatāya u tam kulam saraṇa gatam tāni kulāni
translated: The words gatā, etc., are of three genders because of the kitakāra. The elision of the case-ending, etc., is all the same as before. He who has gone for refuge is saraṇagato;

original: saraṇagatāni iccādi.
analyzed: saraṇa gatāni i c ādi
translated: they who have gone for refuge are saraṇagatā. She who has gone for refuge is saraṇagatā; they who have gone for refuge are saraṇagatāyo. The family that has gone for refuge is saraṇagataṃ; those families that have gone for refuge are saraṇagatāni.🔽And so on.

original: Evaṃ araññagato, bhūmigato, dhammaṃ nissito dhammanissito, atthanissito, bhavaṃ atīto
analyzed: evam arañña gataḥ bhūmi gataḥ dhammam nissitaḥ dhamma nissitaḥ attha nissitaḥ bhavam atītaḥ
translated: He who has gone to the forest is araññagato; he who has gone to the earth is bhūmigato; he who is dependent on the Dhamma is dhammanissito; he who is dependent on the meaning is atthanissito; he who has gone beyond becoming is bhavātīto;

original: bhavātīto, kālātīto, pamāṇaṃ atikkantaṃ pamāṇātikkantaṃ. Lokātikkantaṃ, sukhaṃ patto
analyzed: bhava atītaḥ kāla atītaḥ pamāṇam atikkantam pamāṇa atikkantam loka atikkantam sukham pattaḥ
translated: he who has gone beyond the time is kālātīto; he who has gone beyond measure is pamāṇātikkantaṃ; he who has gone beyond the world is lokatīto; he who has attained happiness is sukhappatto;

original: sukhappatto, dukkhappatto, sotaṃ āpanno sotāpanno, nirodhasamāpanno, rathaṃ āruḷho
analyzed: sukha ppattaḥ dukkha ppattaḥ sotam āpannaḥ sotāpannaḥ nirodha samāpannaḥ ratham āruḷhaḥ
translated: he who has attained suffering is dukkhappatto; he who has entered the stream is sotāpanno; he who has attained cessation is nirodhasamāpanno; he who has mounted the chariot is rathāruḷho;

original: rathāruḷho, sabbarattiṃ sobhano sabbarattisobhano, muhuttasukhaṃ.
analyzed: ratha āruḍhaḥ sabba rattim sobhanaḥ sabba ratti sobhanaḥ muhutta sukham
translated: he who is beautiful all night is sabbarattisobhano; the happiness of a moment is muhuttasukhaṃ.

original: Upapadasamāse pana vuttiyeva tassa niccattā. Yathā – kammaṃ karotīti kammakāro, kumbhakāro,
analyzed: upapada samāse pana vuttiyā iva tassa niccattā yathā kammam karoti iti kammakāro kumbhakāro
translated: But in a compound with a preposition, it is a phrase, because it is invariable. As: “He does work” = kammakāro, kumbhakāro,🔽“He desires welfare” = atthakāmo, dhammakāmo,

original: atthaṃ kāmetīti atthakāmo, dhammakāmo, dhammaṃ dhāretīti dhammadharo, vinayadharo,
analyzed: attham kāmeti iti attha kāmaḥ dhamma kāmaḥ dhammam dhāreti iti dhamma dharaḥ vinaya dharaḥ
translated: “He bears the Dhamma” = dhammadharo, vinayadharo,

original: saccaṃ vadituṃ sīlamassāti saccavādī iccādi.
analyzed: saccam vaditum sīlam assa ati sacca vādī iccādi
translated: “He has the habit of speaking the truth” = saccavādi.

original: Tavantumānantādikitantehi vākyameva vavatthitavibhāsādhikārato. Yathā – odanaṃ bhuttavā,
analyzed: vākyam eva vavatthita vibhāsa adhikārataḥ yathā
translated: Or it is a sentence, by the words tavantu, mā, ananta, and so on, because of the function of defining and explaining. As: “Having eaten rice,”

original: dhammaṃ suṇamāno, dhammaṃ suṇanto, kaṭaṃ karāno, anabhidhānato vā, abhidhānalakkhaṇā
analyzed: dhammam suṇamānaḥ dhammam suṇantaḥ kaṭam karānaḥ anabhidhānataḥ vā abhidhāna lakkhaṇā
translated: “listening to the Dhamma,” “listening to the Dhamma,” “making a bowl,” or by the absence of a name-base,

original: hi taddhitasamāsakitakāti.
analyzed: hi taddhita samāsa kitaka ati
translated: because the characteristic of a name-base is a compound with a suffix.

original: Dutiyātappuriso.
analyzed: dutiyā tappurisaḥ
translated: The second is a man.

original: Tatiyā kitaka pubba sadisa samūnattha kalaha nipuṇa missasakhilādīhi.
analyzed: tatiyā kitaka pubba sadisa samūnattha kalaha nipuṇa missa sa khila ādīhi
translated: The third is a suffix, as follows: pubba, sadisa, samūna, attha, kalaha, nipuṇa, missaka, sakhila, and so on.

original: Buddhena bhāsito buddhabhāsito, dhammo. Evaṃ jinadesito, satthārā vaṇṇito satthuvaṇṇito,
analyzed: buddhena bhāsitaḥ buddha bhāsitaḥ dhammaḥ evam jina desito satthārā vaṇṇito satthu vaṇṇito
translated: “Spoken by the Buddha” = buddhabhāsito, dhammo. “Taught by the Victor” = jinadesito, “Praised by the Teacher” = satthuvaṇṇito,

original: viññūhi garahito viññugarahito, viññuppasattho, issarakataṃ, sayaṃkataṃ, sukehi āhaṭaṃ
analyzed: viññūhi garahitaḥ viññu garahitaḥ viññu pasatthaḥ issarakatam sayaṃkatam sukehi āhaṭam
translated: “Despised by the wise” = viññugarahito, “Esteemed by the wise” = viññuppasattho, “Made by a lord” = issarakataṃ, “Made by oneself” = sayaṃkataṃ, “Brought by parrots” = sukehi āhaṭaṃ,

original: sukāhataṃ, raññā hato rājahato, rogapīḷito, aggidaḍḍho, sappadaṭṭho, sallena viddho
analyzed: sukā hatam raññā hataḥ rāja hataḥ roga pīḍitaḥ aggi daḍḍhaḥ sappa daṭṭhaḥ sallena viddhaḥ
translated: well-struck, struck by the king, struck by the king, afflicted by disease, burnt by fire, bitten by a snake, pierced by a dart

original: sallaviddho, icchāya apakato icchāpakato, sīlena sampanno sīlasampanno. Evaṃ sukhasahagataṃ,
analyzed: salla viddhaḥ icchāya apakataḥ icchā apakataḥ sīlena sampannaḥ sīla sampannaḥ evam sukha sahagatam
translated: pierced by a dart, deprived by desire, deprived by desire, endowed with virtue, endowed with virtue. Thus: accompanied by pleasure,

original: ñāṇasampayuttaṃ, mittasaṃsaggo, piyavippayogo, jātitthaddho, guṇahīno, guṇavuḍḍho,
analyzed: ñāṇa sampayuttam mitta saṃsaggaḥ piya vippayogaḥ jātitthaddhaḥ guṇa hīnaḥ guṇa vuḍḍhaḥ
translated: accompanied by knowledge, association with friends, separation from the dear, intoxicated with birth, lacking in virtue, increased in virtue,

original: catuvaggakaraṇīyaṃ, catuvaggādikattabbaṃ, kākehi peyyā kākapeyyā, nadī.
analyzed: catuvagga karaṇīyam catuvagga ādi kattabbam kākehi peyyā kākapeyyā nadī
translated: to be done by a group of four, to be done by a group of four or more, to be drunk by crows, to be drunk by crows, a river.

original: Kvaci vuttiyeva, urena gacchatīti urago, pādena pivatīti pādapo. Kvaci vākyameva, parasunā chinnavā, kākehi pātabbā, dassanena pahātabbā.
analyzed: kvaci vuttiyā iva urena gacchati iti uragaḥ pādena pivati iti pādapaḥ kvaci vākyam eva kākehi pātabbā dassanena pahātabbā
translated: In some cases it is only the usage: going on the chest, therefore a snake; drinking with the foot, therefore a tree. In some cases it is only the sentence: cut with another’s knife, to be drunk by crows, to be abandoned by seeing.

original: Pubbādiyoge – māsena pubbo māsapubbo. Evaṃ mātusadiso, pitusamo, ekūnavīsati, sīlavikalo,
analyzed: pubba ādi yoge māsena pubbaḥ māsa pubbaḥ evam mātu sadisaḥ pitu samaḥ ekūnavīsati sīla vikalaḥ
translated: In the compound beginning with “before” : before the month, before the month. Thus: similar to the mother, equal to the father, nineteen, deficient in virtue,

original: asikalaho, vācānipuṇo, yāvakālikasaṃmissaṃ, vācāsakhilo, satthārā sadiso satthukappo,
analyzed: asi kalahaḥ vācā nipuṇaḥ vācā sa khilaḥ satthārā sadisaḥ satthu kappo
translated: lacking in virtue, quarrelling with speech, skilled in speech, mixed with what is temporary, confused in speech, similar to the Teacher, equal to the Teacher,

original: puññena atthiko puññatthiko, guṇādhiko, guḷena saṃsaṭṭho odano guḷodano, khīrodano,
analyzed: puññena atthikaḥ puññatthikaḥ guṇa adhikaḥ guḷena saṃsaṭṭhaḥ odanaḥ guḷodano khīrodano
translated: One who needs merit, who is in need of merit, is puññatthiko. One who is superior in virtue is guṇādhiko. Rice mixed with sugar is guḷodana. Rice with milk is khīrodana.

original: assena yutto ratho assaratho, maggacittaṃ, jambuyā paññāto lakkhito dīpo jambudīpo,
analyzed: assena yuttaḥ rathaḥ assa rathaḥ magga cittam jambuyā paññātaḥ lakkhitaḥ dīpaḥ jambu dīpo
translated: A chariot yoked with horses is assaratha. The mind of the path is maggacitta. The island known as Jambu is jambudīpa.

original: ekena adhikā dasa ekādasa, jātiyā andho jaccandho, pakatiyā medhāvī pakatimedhāvī iccādi.
analyzed: ekena adhikāḥ dasa ekādasa jātiyāḥ andhaḥ jaccandho pakatiyāḥ medhāvī pakati medhāvī iccādi
translated: Ten plus one is ekādasa. One who is blind from birth is jaccandho. One who is naturally intelligent is pakatimedhāvī.

original: Tatiyātappuriso.
analyzed: tatiyā tappurisaḥ
translated: In the third case, the man is tappurisa.

original: Catutthī tadatthaatthahitadeyyādīhi.🔽Tadatthe – kathinassa dussaṃ kathinadussaṃ, kathinacīvaratthāyāti attho. Evaṃ cīvaradussaṃ,
analyzed: catutthī tad attha attha hita deyī ādīhi  tad atthe kathinassa dussam kathina dussam kathina cīvara atthāya ati attho evam cīvara dussam
translated: In the fourth case, the compound is tadatthaatthahitadeyyādi.🔽In the sense of “for the sake of”: Cloth for the kathina is kathinadussa. The meaning is: “for the purpose of the kathina cloth.” So too: cloth for dyeing,

original: cīvaramūlyaṃ, yāguyā atthāya taṇḍulā yāgutaṇḍulā, bhattataṇḍulā, saṅghassatthāya
analyzed: cīvara mūlyam yāguyāḥ atthāya taṇḍulāḥ yāgu taṇḍulāḥ bhatta taṇḍulā saṅghaḥ atthāya
translated: rice for making gruel, rice for making rice,🔽food for the Community,

original: bhattaṃ saṅghabhattaṃ, āgantukānamatthāya bhattaṃ āgantukabhattaṃ. Evaṃ gamikabhattaṃ,
analyzed: bhattam saṅgha bhattam āgantukānam atthāya bhattam āgantuka bhattam evam gamika bhattam
translated: food for newcomers, food for those who are going away,

original: pāsādāya dabbaṃ pāsādadabbaṃ.
analyzed: pāsādāya dabbam pāsāda dabbam
translated: a gift for the monastery.

original: Atthe bhikkhusaṅghassatthāya vihāro bhikkhusaṅghattho vihāro, bhikkhusaṅghatthā yāgu,
analyzed: atthe bhikkhu saṅghassa atthāya vihāraḥ bhikkhu saṅgha atthaḥ vihāraḥ bhikkhu saṅgha tthā yāgu
translated: In the sense of “for the sake of”: A dwelling for the Community of monks is bhikkhusaṅghattho vihāra. Gruel for the Community of monks is bhikkhusaṅghatthā yāgu.

original: bhikkhusaṅghatthaṃ cīvaraṃ. Yassatthāya yadattho, yadatthā, yadatthaṃ. Evaṃ tadattho,
analyzed: bhikkhu saṅghattham cīvaram yassa atthāya yad atthaḥ yad atthā yad attham evam tad atthaḥ
translated: For the sake of the Community of monks, robe-cloth. For the sake of what, for the sake of which, for the sake of which, for the sake of what. Thus for the sake of that,

original: tadatthā. Tadatthaṃ. Etadattho vāyāmo, etadatthā kathā, etadatthaṃ sotāvadhānaṃ.
analyzed: tadatthā tadattham etadatthaḥ etadatthaḥ etadatthaḥ etadatthaḥ etadatthaḥ etadatthaḥ sotā avadhānam
translated: for the sake of that, for the sake of that. For the sake of this, endeavour, for the sake of this, talk, for the sake of this, listening.

original: Kimatthaṃ, attatthaṃ, paratthaṃ, vinayo saṃvaratthāya, sukhaṃ samādhatthāya, nibbidā
analyzed: kimattham attattham parattham vinayo saṃvara tthāya sukham samādhatthāya nibbidā
translated: For the sake of what? For the sake of self, for the sake of another, the training is for the sake of restraint, happiness is for the sake of concentration, dispassion

original: virāgatthāya, virāgo vimuttatthāya. Tathā lokassa hito lokahito, buddhassa deyyaṃ
analyzed: virāga tthāya virāgaḥ vimutta tthāya tathā lokassa hitaḥ loka hitaḥ buddhassa deyyam
translated: is for the sake of fading away, fading away is for the sake of freedom. Likewise, for the sake of the world, for the world’s welfare, for the Buddha, to be given to the Buddha,

original: buddhadeyyaṃ, pupphaṃ. Saṅghadeyyaṃ, cīvaraṃ. Idha na bhavati, saṅghassa dātabbaṃ,
analyzed: buddha deyyam puppham saṅgha deyyam cīvaram idha na bhavati saṅghassa dātabbam
translated: a flower. To be given to the Community, a robe. Here it does not exist, to be given to the Community,

original: saṅghassa dātuṃ iccādi.
analyzed: saṅghassa dātum iccādi
translated: to give to the Community, and so on.

original: Catutthītappuriso.🔽Pañcamī apagamana bhaya virati mocanatthādīhi.
analyzed: catutthī tappurisaḥ  pañcamī apagamana bhaya virati mocanattha ādīhi
translated: The fourth case is for a person.🔽The fifth case is for the sake of going away, for the sake of fear, for the sake of abstention, for the sake of release, and so on.

original: Methunasmā apeto methunāpeto. Evaṃ palāpāpagato, nagaraniggato, piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto.
analyzed: methunasmai apetaḥ methuna apetaḥ evam palāpa apagataḥ nagara niggataḥ piṇḍapāta paṭikkanto
translated: Free from sexual intercourse, free from sexual intercourse. Thus free from malicious speech, gone out of the town, returned from almsround.

original: Gāmato nikkhantaṃ gāmanikkhantaṃ, rukkhaggā patito rukkhaggapatito, sāsanacuto, āpattivuṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: gāmataḥ nikkhantam gāma nikkhantam rukkha aggā patitaḥ rukkha agga patitaḥ sāsana cutaḥ āpatti vuṭṭhānam
translated: Gone out from the village, gone out from the village, fallen from the top of a tree, fallen from the top of a tree, fallen away from the Dispensation, the arising of an offence,

original: dharaṇitaluggato, sabbabhavehi nissaṭo sabbabhavanissaṭo.🔽Bhayatthādiyoge yathā – rājato bhayaṃ rājabhayaṃ, corehi bhayaṃ corabhayaṃ, amanussehi
analyzed: dharaṇi taluk gataḥ sabba bhavehi nissaṭaḥ sabba bhava nissaṭaḥ  bhayattha ādi yoge yathā rājataḥ bhayam rāja bhayam corehi bhayam cora bhayam amanussehi
translated: He has gone to the earth’s base, he has gone forth from all becoming, he has gone forth from all kinds of becoming.

original: bhayaṃ amanussabhayaṃ, aggito bhayaṃ aggibhayaṃ. Pāpato bhīto pāpabhīto, pāpabhīruko,
analyzed: bhayam amanussa bhayam aggitaḥ bhayam aggi bhayam pāpataḥ bhītaḥ pāpa bhītaḥ pāpa bhīrukaḥ
translated: As in the case of the compound bhayatthādiyoge yathā—rājato bhayaṃ rājabhayaṃ, corehi bhayaṃ corabhayaṃ, amanussehi bhayaṃ amanussabhayaṃ, aggito bhayaṃ aggibhayaṃ. Pāpato bhīto pāpabhīto, pāpabhīruko,

original: akattabbato virati akattabbavirati. Evaṃ kāyaduccaritavirati, vacīduccaritavirati,
analyzed: a kattabbataḥ virati a kattabba virati evam kāya duccarita virati vacī duccarita virati
translated: akattabbato virati akattabbavirati. So too: abstinence from bodily misconduct, abstinence from verbal misconduct,

original: bandhanā mutto bandhanamutto, vanamutto, bandhanamokkho, kammato samuṭṭhitaṃ kammasamuṭṭhitaṃ,
analyzed: bandhanā muttaḥ bandhana muttaḥ vana muttaḥ bandhana mokkho kammataḥ samuṭṭhitam kamma samuṭṭhitam
translated: freed from bondage, freed from bondage, freed from the forest, freed from bondage, arisen from action, arisen from action,

original: ukkaṭṭhukkaṭṭhaṃ, omakomakaṃ.
analyzed: ukkaṭṭha ukkaṭṭham omaka umakam
translated: very great, very small.

original: Kvaci vuttiyeva, kammato jātaṃ kammajaṃ. Evaṃ cittajaṃ, utujaṃ, āhārajaṃ. Idha na bhavati, pāsādā patito.
analyzed: kvaci vuttiyā iva kammataḥ jātam kamma jam evam citta jam utu jam āhāra jam idha na bhavati patitaḥ
translated: Sometimes it is only the usage: arisen from action, arisen from action. So too: arisen from consciousness, arisen from heat, arisen from nutriment. Here it does not occur: fallen from the palace.

original: Pañcamītappuriso.
analyzed: pañcamī tappurisaḥ
translated: A person with five.

original: Chaṭṭhī rañño putto rājaputto. Evaṃ rājapuriso, ācariyapūjako, buddhasāvako, buddharūpaṃ,
analyzed: chaṭṭhī rañño putto rāja putto evam rāja purisaḥ ācariya pūjakaḥ buddha sāvakaḥ buddha rūpam
translated: The genitive in rājño putto rājaputto. So too: a man of the king, one who honours the teacher, a disciple of the Enlightened One, an image of the Enlightened One,

original: jinavacanaṃ, samuddaghoso, dhaññānaṃ rāsi dhaññarāsi, pupphagandho, phalaraso, kāyassa🔽lahutā kāyalahutā, maraṇassati, rukkhamūlaṃ, ayassa patto ayopatto, evaṃ suvaṇṇakaṭāhaṃ,
analyzed: jina vacanam samudda ghosaḥ dhaññānam rāsi dhañña rāsi puppha gandho phala rasaḥ kāyassa  lahu tā kāya lahu tā maraṇa sati rukkha mūlam ayassa patto ayas patto evam suvaṇṇa kaṭāham
translated: the word of the Victor, Samuddaghosa, a heap of grain is a grain-heap, the scent of flowers, the taste of fruit,🔽lightness of body, mindfulness of death, the foot of a tree, an iron bowl, a golden casket,🔽

original: pānīyathālakaṃ, sappikumbho.
analyzed: sappi kumbhaḥ
translated: The word of the Victor, Samuddaghoso, a heap of grain is a grain-heap, the scent of flowers, the juice of fruits, the lightness of the body is bodily lightness, mindfulness of death, the foot of a tree, an iron bowl is an iron-bowl, so a golden casket, a water-pot, a pot of oil.

original: “Devānaṃ rājā”ti atthe samāsādimhi kate “kvaci samāsantagatānamakāranto”ti akāro,
analyzed: devānam rājā ati atthe samāsa ādimhi kate kvaci akāraḥ
translated: When the compound “king of the gods” is made, the “a” is not elided because of the rule “Sometimes the final letter of a compound is not elided”,

original: tato “syā cā”ti āttaṃ na bhavati. Devarājo, devarājā, devarājaṃ, devarāje iccādi
analyzed: tatas syā ca ati āttam na bhavati devarājaḥ devarājā devarājam devarāje icca ādi
translated: and then the “a” is not attached because of the rule “The ‘a’ is not attached to the final letter of a compound”. Devārāja, devārājā, devārājaṃ, devārāje, etc.,

original: purisasaddasamaṃ. Attābhāve so devarājā, te devarājāno iccādi rājasaddasamaṃ. Tathā
analyzed: purisa saddasamam attā abhāve saḥ deva rājā te deva rājānaḥ iccādi rāja saddasamam tathā
translated: are like the word “man”. In the absence of the reflexive, that devārāja, those devārājānā, etc., are like the word “king”. So too

original: devānaṃ sakhā devasakho, devasakhā, so devasakhā, te devasakhāno iccādi.
analyzed: devānam sakhā deva sakhaḥ deva sakhā saḥ deva sakhā te deva sakhānaḥ icca ādi
translated: a friend of the gods is a god-friend, god-friends, that god-friend, those god-friends, etc.

original: Pumassa liṅgaṃ pulliṅgaṃ. Evaṃ pumbhāvo, pumantalopādi.
analyzed: liṅgam put liṅgam evam pumbhāvaḥ pum anta lopa ādi
translated: The gender of a male is the male gender. So too the state of being a male, the elision of the final “a” of a male, etc.

original: Hatthipadaṃ, itthirūpaṃ, bhikkhunisaṅgho, jambusākhā, ettha ca “kvacādimajjhuttarāna”ntiādinā majjhe īkārūkārānaṃ rassattaṃ.
analyzed: hatthi padam itthi rūpam bhikkhuni saṅghaḥ jambu sākhā ettha ca kvac ādi majjha uttara an anti ādinā majjhe rassa ttam
translated: The foot of an elephant, the form of a woman, the Bhikkhunī Order, the branch of the rose-apple tree, and here the laxity of the ī and ū in the middle in kvacādimajjhuttarāna.

original: Vibhāsādhikārato kvaci vākyameva, sahasā kammassa kattāro, bhinnānaṃ sandhātā, kappassa tatiyo bhāgo, yā ca pakkhassa aṭṭhamī, manussānaṃ khattiyo sūratamo.
analyzed: vibhāsa adhikārataḥ kvaci vākyam eva sahasā kammassa kattāraḥ bhinnānam sandhātā kappassa tatiyaḥ bhāgaḥ yā ca pakkhassa aṭṭhamī manussānam khattiyaḥ sūratamaḥ
translated: In the sense of “explanation” sometimes the sentence itself, the doers of the deed suddenly, the uniter of the divided, the third part of the aeon, and the eighth of the fortnight, the warrior is the most courageous of men.

original: Yuttattho icceva? “Bhaṭo rañño puriso devadattassā”ti ettha “bhaṭasambandhe chaṭṭhī”ti
analyzed: iti ca iva bhaṭaḥ rañño puriso devadattassa ati ettha bhaṭa sambandhe chaṭṭhī iti
translated: In the sense of “connection” ? “The king’s servant, Devadatta’s man” here “the sixth case in the sense of the relation of ownership” .

original: aññamaññānapekkhatāya ayuttatthabhāvato samāso na bhavati, “kosalassa rañño putto”tiādīsu
analyzed: aññamañña anapekkha tāya ayutta attha bhāvataḥ samāsaḥ na bhavati kosalassa rañño putto ti ādīsu
translated: Because of the mutual dependence there is no compound because of the meaninglessness. But in “the king of Kosala’s son” and so on

original: pana sāpekkhatāya asamatthattā na bhavati, sambandhīsaddānaṃ pana niccaṃ sāpekkhattepi
analyzed: pana sāpekkha tāya asamattha ttā na bhavati sambandhī saddānam pana niccam sāpekkha tte pi
translated: it is not because of the inability due to the dependence. But in the case of the words in a relation there is

original: gamakattā samāso, yathā – devadattassa gurukulaṃ, bhagavato sāvakasaṅghotiādi.
analyzed: gamaka ttā samāsaḥ yathā devadattassa guru kulam bhagavataḥ sāvaka saṅgha uti ādi
translated: a compound because of the connection, as in Devadatta’s teacher’s family, the Blessed One’s disciple’s Order, and so on.

original: Chaṭṭhītappuriso.
analyzed: chaṭṭhī tappurisaḥ
translated: The sixth case is a person.

original: Sattamī rūpe saññā rūpasaññā, evaṃ rūpasañcetanā, saṃsāradukkhaṃ, cakkhumhi sannissitaṃ
analyzed: sattamī rūpe saññā rūpa saññā evam rūpa sañcetanā saṃsāra dukkham cakkhumhi sannissitaṃ
translated: The seventh, perception of visible objects, is perception of visible objects. So also, volition of visible objects, suffering of the round of rebirths, consciousness dependent on the eye,

original: viññāṇaṃ cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, dhamme rato dhammarato, dhammābhirati, dhammaruci, dhammagāravo,
analyzed: viññāṇam cakkhu viññāṇam dhamme rataḥ dhamma rataḥ dhamma abhirati dhamma ruci dhamma gāravo
translated: consciousness of the eye, delighting in ideas, delighting in ideas, delight in ideas, liking for ideas, respect for ideas,

original: dhammesu nirutti dhammanirutti, dānādhimutti, bhavantarakataṃ, dassane assādo dassanassādo,
analyzed: dhammesu nirutti dhamma nirutti dāna adhimutti bhavantarakatam dassane assādaḥ dassana ssādaḥ
translated: verbal expression in ideas, verbal expression in ideas, resolve on giving, that which is done in the interval between existences, satisfaction in seeing, satisfaction in seeing,

original: araññe vāso araññavāso, vikāle bhojanaṃ vikālabhojanaṃ, kāle vassaṃ kālavassaṃ, vane
analyzed: araññe vāsaḥ arañña vāsaḥ vikāle bhojanam vikāla bhojanam kāle vassam kāla vassam vane
translated: dwelling in the forest, dwelling in the forest, eating at the wrong time, eating at the wrong time, raining in season, raining in season, flowers in the forest,

original: pupphaṃ vanapupphaṃ. Evaṃ vanamahiso, gāmasūkaro, samuddamaccho, āvāṭakacchapo, āvāṭamaṇḍūko,
analyzed: puppham vana puppham evam vana mahisaḥ gāma sūkaraḥ samudda macchaḥ āvāṭa kacchapaḥ āvāṭa maṇḍūkaḥ
translated: flowers in the forest. So also, a boar in the forest, a boar in the village, a fish in the ocean, a turtle in a pool, a frog in a pool,

original: kūpamaṇḍūko, titthanāvā, itthīsu dhutto itthidhutto chāyāya sukkho chāyāsukkho, aṅgārapakkaṃ, cārakabaddho.
analyzed: kūpa maṇḍūkaḥ tittha nāvā itthīsu dhuttaḥ itthi dhuttaḥ chāyāya sukkho chāyā sukkhaḥ aṅgāra pakkam cāraka baddhaḥ
translated: a frog in a pit, a boat in a ford, a man addicted to women, a man addicted to women, dried up in the shade, dried up in the shade, cooked in embers, bound in a fetter.

original: Idha vuttiyeva, yathā – vane caratīti vanacaro, kucchimhi sayatīti kucchisayo, thale
analyzed: idha vuttiyā iva yathā vane carati iti vana caro kucchimhi sayati iti kucchi sayaḥ thale
translated: Herein, the following are just terms of expression: as one who wanders in the forest, a forest-wanderer; as one who lies in the womb, a womb-dweller; as one who stands on the ground, a ground-stander,

original: tiṭṭhatīti thalaṭṭho. Evaṃ jalaṭṭho, pabbataṭṭho, maggaṭṭho, paṅke jātaṃ paṅkajaṃ,
analyzed: tiṭṭhati iti thala aṭṭhaḥ evam jala aṭṭhaḥ pabbata aṭṭhaḥ magga aṭṭhaḥ paṅke jātam paṅkajam
translated: “It stands on the ground” is the meaning of “ground-standing.” So too: “water-standing,” “mountain-standing,” “road-standing,” “born in mud” is the meaning of “mud-born,”

original: sire ruhatīti siroruhaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: sire ruhati iti siroruham i t ca ādi
translated: “it grows on the head” is the meaning of “head-grown,” and so on.

original: Idha na bhavati, bhojane mattaññutā, indriyesu guttadvāratā, āsane nisinno, āsane nisīditabbaṃ.
analyzed: idha na bhavati bhojane mattaññu tā indriyesu gutta dvāra tā āsane nisinnaḥ āsane nisīditabbam
translated: Here it does not occur: “moderation in food,” “guarding of the doors of the sense faculties,” “seated on the seat,” “one should sit on the seat.”

original: Sattamītappuriso.
analyzed: sattamī tappurisaḥ
translated: “A person of the seventh” is the meaning of “seventh-person.”

original: “Tadanuparodhenā”ti vuttattā yathābhidhānaṃ tappurise kvaci accantādīsu amādivibhatyantaṃ pubbapadaṃ paraṃ sambhavati.
analyzed: tad an uparodhena iti vutta ttā yathā abhidhānam tappurise kvaci a c canta ādīsu am ādi vibhati antam pubba padam param sambhavati
translated: Since it is said “in accordance with that,” in some instances the preceding word ending in the case-ending m, etc., is combined with the following word in the sense of “extreme,” etc., according to the expression.

original: Yathā – antaṃ atikkantaṃ accantaṃ, accantāni, velaṃ atikkanto ativelo, rassattaṃ.
analyzed: yathā antam atikkantam accantam accantāni velam atikkantaḥ ativelaḥ rassattam
translated: As: “gone beyond the end” is the meaning of “extreme,” “extreme-nesses,” “gone beyond the time” is the meaning of “beyond the time,” “very long,”

original: Evaṃ mālaṃ atīto atimālo, pattajīviko, āpannajīviko, akkhaṃ patigataṃ nissitanti
analyzed: evam mālam atītaḥ atimālaḥ patta jīvikaḥ āpanna jīvikaḥ akkham patigatam nissitanti
translated: So too: “gone beyond the garland” is the meaning of “beyond the garland,” “one who lives on alms,” “one who lives on what he gets by begging,” “gone to the wheel” is the meaning of “wheel-gone,” “dependent,”

original: paccakkhaṃ dassanaṃ, paccakkho attabhāvo, paccakkhā buddhi, atthaṃ anugataṃ anvatthaṃ,
analyzed: paccakkham dassanam paccakkhaḥ atta bhāvo paccakkhā buddhi attham anugatam anvattham
translated: “direct seeing” is the meaning of “direct-seeing,” “direct-seeing individuality,” “direct-seeing understanding,” “gone after the meaning” is the meaning of “after-meaning,”

original: kokilāya avakuṭṭhaṃ avakokilaṃ vanaṃ, pariccattanti attho. Avamayūraṃ, ajjhayanāya
analyzed: kokilāya avakuṭṭham avakokilam vanam pariccattanti attho avamayūram ajjhayanāya
translated: “the cuckoo-struck forest” is the meaning of “cuckoo-struck,” “the peacock-struck forest” is the meaning of “peacock-struck,” “the forest struck by the female peacock” is the meaning of “peahen-struck,” “given up” is the meaning of “given up.”

original: parigilāno pariyajjhayano, kammassa alaṃ samatthoti alaṃkammo, vacanāya alanti alaṃvacano,
analyzed: parigilānaḥ pariyajjhayanaḥ kammassa alam samatthaḥ ti alaṃkammaḥ vacanāya alam ti alaṃvacanaḥ
translated: who has overcome, who has fully understood, who is able, who is fit, who is able to speak, who is fit to speak,

original: vānato nikkhantaṃ nibbānaṃ, kilesehi nikkhanto nikkileso, niraṅgaṇo, kosambiyā nikkhanto
analyzed: vānataḥ nikkhantam nibbānam kilesehi nikkhantaḥ nikkilesaḥ niraṅgaṇaḥ kosambiyāḥ nikkhantaḥ
translated: Parigilāno pariyajjhayano = one who is exhausted and who is reflecting. Kammassa alaṃ samattho = one who is able to do a deed. Vacanāya alanti = one who is able to speak. Vānato nikkhantaṃ nibbānaṃ = Nibbāna which has gone out from speech. Kilesehi nikkhanto = one who has gone out from defilements. Niraṅgaṇo = one who is free from the undergrowth. Kosambiyā nikkhanto = one who has gone out from Kosambī.

original: nikkosambī, vanato niyyāto nibbano, ācariyato paro pācariyo. Evaṃ payyako, parahiyyo,
analyzed: nikkosambī vanataḥ niyyātaḥ nibbanaḥ ācariyataḥ paraḥ pācariyaḥ evam payyako para hiyyaḥ
translated: Nikkosambī = one who has gone out from the forest. Vanato niyyāto nibbano = one who has gone out from the forest and who is emancipated. Ācariyato paro pācariyo = one who is beyond the teacher. Evaṃ payyako = one who is beyond the river. Parahiyyo = one who is beyond the other side.

original: gaṅgāya upari uparigaṅgaṃ. Evaṃ heṭṭhānadī, antosamāpatti, haṃsānaṃ rājā rājahaṃso,
analyzed: gaṅgāya upari uparigaṅgam evam heṭṭhānadī antosamāpatti haṃsānam rājā rājahaṃsaḥ
translated: Gaṅgāya upari uparigaṅgaṃ = the upper Gaṅgā. Evaṃ heṭṭhānadī = the lower river. Antosamāpatti = the internal attainment. Haṃsānaṃ rājā rājahaṃso = the king of the geese.

original: haṃsarājā vā, māsassa addhaṃ addhamāsaṃ, māsaddhaṃ vā, āmalakassa addhaṃ addhāmalakaṃ,
analyzed: haṃsa rājā vā māsassa addham addha māsam māsaddham vā āmalakassa addham addha āmalakam
translated: Haṃsarājā vā = the king of the geese. Māsassa addhaṃ addhamāsaṃ = half a month. Māsaddhaṃ vā = half a month. Āmalakassa addhaṃ addhāmalakaṃ = half a myrobalan.

original: āmalakaddhaṃ vā, kahāpaṇassa aḍḍhaṃ aḍḍhakahāpaṇaṃ, aḍḍhamāsakaṃ, rattiyā aḍḍhaṃ🔽aḍḍharattaṃ, rattiyā pubbaṃ pubbarattaṃ, rattiyā pacchā pacchārattaṃ. Ettha ca “kvaci
analyzed: āmalakaddham vā kahāpaṇassa aḍḍham aḍḍha kahāpaṇam aḍḍha māsakam rattiyā aḍḍham  aḍḍharattam rattiyā pubbam pubbarattam rattiyā pacchā pacchārattam ettha ca kvacid
translated: Āmalakaddhaṃ vā = half a myrobalan. Kahāpaṇassa aḍḍhaṃ aḍḍhakahāpaṇaṃ = half a kahāpaṇa. Aḍḍhamāsakaṃ = half a month. Rattiyā aḍḍhaṃ aḍḍharattaṃ = half the night.

original: samāsantagatānamakāranto”ti rattisaddantassa attaṃ, ahassa pubbaṃ pubbanhaṃ. Evaṃ
analyzed: samāsa anta gatānam akāra antaḥ iti ratti sadda antassa attam ahassa pubbam pubbanham evam
translated: Rattiyā pubbaṃ pubbarattaṃ = the first part of the night. Rattiyā pacchā pacchārattaṃ = the latter part of the night. And here, “kvaci samāsantagatānaṃ akāranto” = the word ratti has its own meaning. Ahassa pubbaṃ pubbanhaṃ = the forenoon.

original: sāyanhaṃ, “tesu vuddhī”tiādinā ahassa anhādeso.
analyzed: tesu vuddhi iti ādinā ahassa an ha ādesaḥ
translated: In the evening, “in them there is growth” and so on.

original: Amādiparatappuriso.
analyzed: am ādi para tap purisaḥ
translated: The man is after the first syllable.

original: Kvaci tappurise “pabhaṅkarā”dīsu vibhattilopo na bhavati.
analyzed: kvaci tappurise pabhaṅkara ādīsu vibhatti lopaḥ na bhavati
translated: In some instances the elision of the case-ending does not take place in the man, as in “pabhaṅkaro” and so on.🔽As follows: “He makes light” is the meaning of “pabhaṅkaro.” The compound is formed by “amādayo parapadebhī.”

original: Yathā – pabhaṃ karotīti atthe “amādayo parapadebhī”ti samāso, “nāmānaṃ samāso yuttattho”ti
analyzed: yathā pabham karoti iti atthe am ādayaḥ para padebhi iti samāsaḥ nāmānam samāsaḥ
translated: The compound is regarded as a noun by “nāmānaṃ samāso yuttattho.”

original: samāsasaññā, tato “tesaṃ vibhattiyo lopā cā”ti vibhattilope sampatte tattheva caggahaṇena
analyzed: samāsa saññā tatas tesam vibhattiyaḥ lopā ca ati vibhatti lope sampatte tattha iva ca ggahaṇena
translated: When the elision of the case-ending has taken place by “tesaṃ vibhattiyo lopā cā,”

original: pubbapade vibhattilopābhāvo. Sesaṃ samaṃ. Pabhaṅkaro, amataṃ dadātīti amatandado,
analyzed: pubba pade vibhatti lopa abhāvaḥ sesam samam pabhaṅkaraḥ amatam dadāti iti amatandadaḥ
translated: the elision of the case-ending in the first member does not take place by the inclusion of the word “tattha” . The rest is the same. “Pabhaṅkaro,” “amatandado,” he gives the deathless.

original: raṇaṃ jahātīti raṇañjaho, jutiṃ dhāretīti jutindharo, tathā sahasākataṃ, parassapadaṃ.
analyzed: raṇam jahāti iti raṇañjahaḥ jutim dhāreti iti jutindharaḥ tathā sahasākatam parassapadam
translated: “Raṇañjaho,” he abandons the fight. “Jutindharo,” he bears the light. Likewise, “sahasākataṃ,” the chariot of the sun. “Parassapadaṃ,” the word of another.

original: Attanopadaṃ, bhayato upaṭṭhānaṃ bhayatūpaṭṭhānaṃ, paratoghoso, gavaṃpatitthero, manasikāro,
analyzed: attanopadam bhayataḥ upaṭṭhānam bhayatu upaṭṭhānam paratoghosaḥ gavaṃpati theraḥ manasikāro
translated: “Attanopadaṃ,” the near-attainment of fear. “Bhayatūpaṭṭhānaṃ,” the appearance of fear. “Paratoghoso,” the sound from another. “Gavaṃpatitthero,” the elder Gavampati. “Manasikāro,” attention.

original: pubbenivāso, pubbenivāsānussati, majjhekalyāṇaṃ, antevāsī, antevāsiko, janesuto,
analyzed: pubbenivāsaḥ pubbenivāsa anussati majjhe kalyāṇam antevāsī antevāsikaḥ janesutaḥ
translated: “Pubbenivāso,” past-life. “Pubbenivāsānussati,” recollection of past-life. “Majjhekalyāṇaṃ,” good in the middle. “Antevāsī,” a pupil. “Antevāsiko,” a pupil. “Janesuto,” a son of a slave woman.

original: urasilomo, kaṇṭhekāḷo, sarasijamiccādi.
analyzed: kaṇṭhekāḷaḥ sarasijam iccādi
translated: “Urasilomo,” one with a hairy chest. “Kaṇṭhekāḷo,” one with a black neck. “Sarasijamiccādi,” the moon, etc.

original: Alopatappuriso.
analyzed: a lopa tap purisaḥ
translated: A man without hair on the head.

original: Tappurisasamāso niṭṭhito.
analyzed: tappurisa samāsaḥ niṭṭhito
translated: The compound of a man and that man is ended.

original: Bahubbīhisamāsa
analyzed: bahup bīhi samāsa
translated: The bahubbīhi compound

original: Atha bahubbīhisamāso vuccate.
analyzed: atha bahup bīhi samāsaḥ vuccate
translated: Now the bahubbīhi compound is stated.

original: So ca navavidho dvipado tulyādhikaraṇo, dvipado bhinnādhikaraṇo, tipado nanipātapubbapado, sahapubbapado upamānapubbapado saṅkhyobhayapado disantarāḷattho byatihāralakkhaṇo cāti.
analyzed: so ca navavidhaḥ dvipadaḥ tulya adhikaraṇaḥ dvipadaḥ bhinna adhikaraṇaḥ ti padaḥ na nipāta pubba pado saha pubba pado upamāna pubba pado saṅkhyā ubhaya pado disantarāḷattho byatihāra lakkhaṇo ca ati
translated: And it is of nine kinds: the two-footed equal-reference, the two-footed different-reference, the three-footed where the non-case-ending word is first, the saha-first, the upamāna-first, the number-both-first, the one with a locative-case-ending meaning, and the one characterized by the byatireka.

original: Tattha dvipado tulyādhikaraṇo bahubbīhi kammādīsu chasu vibhatyatthesu bhavati.
analyzed: tattha dvipadaḥ tulya adhikaraṇaḥ bahu bbīhi kamma ādīsu chasu vibhati atthesu bhavati
translated: Herein, the two-footed equal-reference bahubbīhi is in the six case-relations beginning with the nominative.

original: Tattha dutiyatthe tāva – “āgatā samaṇā imaṃ saṅghārāma”nti viggahe –
analyzed: tattha dutiya tthe tāva āgatā samaṇāḥ imam viggahe
translated: Herein, firstly as to the second-noun relation: “Monks have come to this monastery” . In the analysis of this:

original: 352. Aññapadatthesu bahubbīhi.
analyzed: añña pada tthesu bahup bīhi
translated: In the other-noun relations the bahubbīhi

original: Samasyamānapadato aññesaṃ paṭhamadutiyādivibhatyantānaṃ padānamatthesu yuttatthāni nāmāni vibhāsā samasyante, so samāso bahubbīhisañño ca hoti.
analyzed: samasyamāna padataḥ aññesam paṭhama dutiya ādi vibhati antānam padānam atthesu yut tatthāni nāmāni vibhāsā samasyante saḥ samāsaḥ bahu bīhi sañño ca hoti
translated: The names that are appropriate in the meanings of the words that are the first, second, etc., case-endings, other than the one that is compounded, are analysed in the Vibhatti Book as compounded, and that compound is called a bahubbīhi compound.

original: Bahavo vīhayo yassa so bahubbīhi, bahubbīhisadisattā ayampisamāso anvatthasaññāvasena bahubbīhīti vutto, aññapadatthappadhāno hi bahubbīhi.
analyzed: bahavaḥ vīhayaḥ yassa saḥ bahu bīhi bahu bīhi sadisa ttā ayam pi samāsaḥ anvattha saññā vasena bahu bīhi iti vuttaḥ añña padattha ppadhānaḥ hi bahu bīhi
translated: It is called bahubbīhi because it is like bahubbīhi, which is a compound consisting of more than two words. For bahubbīhi is a compound consisting of the meaning of another word as its head.

original: Duvidho cāyaṃ bahubbīhi tagguṇasaṃviññāṇātagguṇasaṃviññāṇavasena, tesu yattha visesanabhūto attho aññapadatthaggahaṇena gayhati, so tagguṇasaṃviññāṇo, yathā – lambakaṇṇamānayāti.
analyzed: duvidhaḥ ca ayam bahu bbīhi tad guṇa saṃviññāṇa a tad guṇa saṃviññāṇa vasena tesu yattha visesana bhūtaḥ atthaḥ añña padattha ggahaṇena gayhati saḥ tad guṇa saṃviññāṇaḥ yathā
translated: And this bahubbīhi is of two kinds, as conveying the meaning of the head by the head and as conveying the meaning of the head by a subordinate. Herein, that in which the meaning that is the head is conveyed by the taking of the head consisting of another word is conveying the meaning of the head by the head, as in “Bring the long-eared one” .

original: Yattha pana na gayhati, so atagguṇasaṃviññāṇo, yathā – bahudhanamānayāti.
analyzed: yattha pana na gayhati saḥ a tad guṇa saṃviññāṇaḥ yathā
translated: That in which it is not conveyed is conveying the meaning of the head by a subordinate, as in “Bring the one with much wealth” .

original: Idha bahubbīhisadde viya visesanassa pubbanipāto, sesaṃ pubbasamaṃ.
analyzed: idha bahu bbīhi sadde viya visesanassa pubba nipātaḥ sesam pubba samam
translated: Herein, the distinction is placed first, as in the bahubbīhi consisting of more than two words, and the rest is the same as before.🔽A monk who has come to the monastery. And here the words “who has come” and the word “monk”

original: Āgatasamaṇo saṅghārāmo. Ettha ca āgatasaddo, samaṇasaddo ca attano atthe aṭṭhatvā
analyzed: āgata samaṇaḥ saṅgha ārāmaḥ ettha ca āgata saddo samaṇa saddo ca attanaḥ atthe
translated: do not stand in their own meaning but

original: dutiyāvibhatyatthabhūte saṅghārāmasaṅkhāte aññapadatthe vattanti, tadatthajotanatthameva
analyzed: dutiyā vibhati attha bhūte saṅghārāma saṅkhāte añña padatthe vattanti tad attha jotana attham eva
translated: they are used in the meaning of another word, namely, “monastery,” which is the meaning of the second case.

original: tadanantaraṃ “saṅghārāmo”ti padantaraṃ payujjati, tato samāseneva kammatthassa abhihitattā
analyzed: tad anantaram saṅghārāmaḥ iti pada antaram payujjati tatas samāsena iva kammatthassa
translated: Then the word ‘monastery’ is used as a separate word, and after that, since the business of the compound is stated by the compound itself,

original: puna dutiyā na hoti. Idaṃsaddassa ca appayogo, evaṃ sabbattha. Bahubbīhi cāyaṃ abhidheyyaliṅgavacano.
analyzed: puna dutiyā na hoti idam saddassa ca appayogaḥ evam sabbattha bahu bbīhi ca ayam abhidheyya liṅga vacanaḥ
translated: there is no second ‘and’ and no need for the word ‘the’. And this is so in all the other examples. And this is a bahubbīhi compound with a substantive as its last member.

original: Tathā āgatasamaṇā sāvatthi, āgatasamaṇaṃ jetavanaṃ, paṭipannā addhikā yaṃ pathaṃ
analyzed: tathā āgata samaṇā sāvatthi āgata samaṇam jetavanam paṭipannāḥ addhikāḥ yam patham
translated: So too: ‘the monks who have come’, ‘the Jeta Grove where the monks have come’, ‘the road on which those who have gone are many’,

original: soyaṃ paṭipannaddhiko patho, abhiruḷhā vāṇijā yaṃ nāvaṃ sā abhiruḷhavāṇijā nāvā.
analyzed: sā ayam paṭipannaddhikaḥ pathaḥ abhiruḍhāḥ vāṇijāḥ yam nāvam sā abhiruḍha vāṇijā nāvā
