translated: so this is ‘the road on which those who have gone are many’, ‘the ship on which the merchants have embarked’, so this is ‘the ship on which the merchants have embarked’.

original: Evaṃ kammatthe bahubbīhi.
analyzed: evam kammatthe bahup bīhi
translated: So it is in the sense of the object of the action in a bahubbīhi compound.

original: Tatiyatthe bahubbīhi yathā – jitāni indriyāni yena samaṇena soyaṃ jitindriyo samaṇo.
analyzed: tatiya tthe yathā jitāni indriyāni yena samaṇena saḥ ayam jitindriyaḥ samaṇaḥ
translated: In the sense of the third member of a compound, as in ‘the monk who has conquered the faculties’,

original: Evaṃ diṭṭhadhammo, pattadhammo, katakicco, jitā mārā anenāti jitamāro bhagavā, paṭividdhasabbadhammo.
analyzed: evam diṭṭhadhammo pattadhammo kata kiccaḥ jitāḥ mārāḥ anena ati jita māraḥ bhagavā paṭividdha sabba dhammo
translated: so this is ‘the monk who has conquered the faculties’. So too: ‘the one who has seen the Dhamma’, ‘the one who has attained the Dhamma’, ‘the one who has done what had to be done’, ‘the one in whom the Māras have been conquered’, so this is ‘the Blessed One in whom the Māras have been conquered’, ‘the one who has penetrated all dhammas’.

original: Catutthiyatthe bahubbīhi yathā – dinno suṅko yassa rañño soyaṃ dinnasuṅko rājā, upanītaṃ bhojanaṃ assa samaṇassāti upanītabhojano samaṇo, upahaṭo bali assāti upahaṭabali yakkho.🔽Pañcamiyatthe bahubbīhi yathā – niggatā janā asmā gāmā soyaṃ niggatajano gāmo, niggato
analyzed: catutthiya tthe bahu bbīhi yathā dinnaḥ suṅkaḥ yassa raññaḥ saḥ ayam dinna suṅkaḥ rājā upanītam bhojanam assa samaṇassa ati upanīta bhojanaḥ samaṇaḥ upahaṭaḥ bali assa ati upahaṭa bali yakkho  pañcamiya tthe bahu bīhi yathā niggatāḥ janāḥ asmai gāmā saḥ ayam niggata janaḥ gāmaḥ niggataḥ
translated: In the fourth instance, in a bahubbīhi such as “The king to whom the boon was given”, “the king to whom the boon was given”, “the ascetic to whom the food was brought”, “the ascetic to whom the food was brought”, “the ogre to whom the offering was made”, “the ogre to whom the offering was made”.

original: ayo asmāti nirayo, niggatā kilesā etasmāti nikkileso, apetaṃ viññāṇaṃ asmāti apetaviññāṇo🔽matakāyo, apagataṃ bhayabheravaṃ asmāti apagatabhayabheravo arahā.🔽Chaṭṭhiyatthe bahubbīhi yathā – chinnā hatthā yassa purisassa soyaṃ chinnahattho🔽puriso. Evaṃ paripuṇṇasaṅkappo, khīṇāsavo, vīto rāgo assāti vītarāgo, dve padāni
analyzed: ayaḥ asmā iti nirayaḥ niggatāḥ kilesāḥ etasmā ati nikkilesaḥ apetam viññāṇam asmā iti apeta viññāṇaḥ  mata kāyaḥ apagatam bhaya bheravam apagata bhaya bheravaḥ arahā  chaṭṭhiya tthe bahu bbīhi yathā chinnāḥ hatthāḥ yassa purisassa saḥ ayam chinnahatthaḥ  purisaḥ evam paripuṇṇa saṅkappaḥ khīṇa āsavaḥ vītaḥ rāgaḥ assa ati vīta rāgaḥ dve padāni
translated: In the fifth instance, in a bahubbīhi such as “The village from which the people went out”, “the village from which the people went out”, “The hell from which iron is”, “the hell from which iron is”, “The one from which defilements have gone”, “the one from which defilements have gone”, “The body from which consciousness has departed”, “the body from which consciousness has departed”, “The one in whom fear and trembling have gone”, “the one in whom fear and trembling have gone”.

original: assāti dvipado, dvihattho paṭo, tevijjo, catuppado, pañca cakkhūni assāti pañcacakkhu
analyzed: assa ati dvipadaḥ dvi hatthaḥ paṭaḥ tevijjaḥ catuppadaḥ pañca cakkhūni assa ati pañcacakkhu
translated: In the sixth instance, in a bahubbīhi such as “The man in whom the hand was cut off”, “the man in whom the hand was cut off”. “The one whose wishes are fulfilled”, “the one whose taints are destroyed”, “The one in whom passion has gone”, “the one in whom passion has gone”, “The one having two feet”, “the one having two feet”, “The cloth having two ends”, “the cloth having two ends”, “The one having three knowledges”, “the one having three knowledges”, “The one having four feet”, “the one having four feet”, “The one having five eyes”, “the one having five eyes”.

original: bhagavā, chaḷabhiñño, rassattaṃ, navaṅgaṃ satthusāsanaṃ, dasabalo, anantañāṇo, tīṇi
analyzed: bhagavā chaḷabhiññaḥ rassattam navaṅgam satthu sāsanam dasa balaḥ ananta ñāṇo tīṇi
translated: The Blessed One, the One of the Six Kinds of Knowledge, the One of the Great Strength, the One of the Nine-fold Teaching of the Master, the One of the Ten Powers, the One of Infinite Knowledge, the Three

original: dasa parimāṇametesanti tidasā devā, samāsantassa attaṃ, idha parimāṇasaddassa sannidhānato
analyzed: tidasā devā tidasā devā idha parimāṇa saddassa sannidhānato
translated: Ten is the measure of these: the Thirty-Three Gods. The self of the compound is the first member, because of the proximity of the word measure here.

original: dasasaddo saṅkhyāne vattate, ayaṃ paccayo etesanti idappaccayā, ko pabhavo assāti
analyzed: dasa saddaḥ saṅkhyāne vattate ayam paccayaḥ etesan ti idappaccayā ko pabhavaḥ assa ati
translated: The word ten is used in the sense of number. These are the conditions: the conditions here. What is the origin of this?

original: kiṃpabhavo ayaṃ kāyo, vigataṃ malamassāti vimalo, sundaro gandho assāti sugandhaṃ🔽candanaṃ. Evaṃ susīlo, sumukho, kucchito gandho assāti duggandhaṃ kuṇapaṃ, duṭṭhu
analyzed: kiṃpabhavaḥ ayam kāyaḥ vigatam malam assa ati vimalaḥ sundaraḥ gandhaḥ assa ati sugandham  candanam evam su sīlaḥ su mukhaḥ kucchitaḥ gandhaḥ assāti duggandham kuṇapam duṭṭhu
translated: What is the origin of this body? The one who has removed the stain is the stainless one. The one who has a beautiful smell is the one with a good smell.

original: mano assāti dummano. Evaṃ dussīlo, dummukho, tapo eva dhanaṃ assāti tapodhano, khantisaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: manaḥ assa ati dummanaḥ evam dussīlaḥ dummukhaḥ tapaḥ eva dhanam assa ati tapodhanaḥ khanti saṅkhātam
translated: The one with a bad smell is the one with a bad smell. The one with a bad mind is the one with a bad mind. Thus the one with bad virtue, the one with a bad face, the one with a bad smell. The one for whom austerity is wealth is the one with austerity as wealth. The one for whom patience is the strength is the one with patience as strength.

original: balaṃ assāti khantibalo, indoti nāmaṃ etassāti indanāmo.
analyzed: balam assa ati khantibalaḥ indo iti nāmam etassa ati inda nāmaḥ
translated: The one who has the name Indra is the one with the name Indra.

original: Chandajātādīsu visesanavisesitabbānaṃ yathicchitattā ubhayaṃ pubbaṃ nipatati, yathā
analyzed: chanda jāta ādīsu visesana visesitabbānam yathicchita ttā ubhayam pubbam nipatati yathā
translated: In the case of those beginning with “one who has arisen from desire,” both are placed first because of the desire to specify the particular.

original: – chando jāto assāti chandajāto, jāto chando assātipi jātachando. Evaṃ sañjātapītisomanasso,
analyzed: chandaḥ jātaḥ assa ati chanda jātaḥ jātaḥ chandaḥ assa ati pi jāta chandaḥ evam sañjāta pīti somanassaḥ
translated: “He has arisen with zeal” is “arisen with zeal” . “He has arisen and zeal is his” is “arisen and zeal is his” . So he is one who has arisen with zeal and with happiness and gladness.

original: pītisomanassasañjāto, māsajāto, jātamāso, chinnahattho, hatthacchinno.🔽“Dīghā jaṅghāyassā”ti viggayha samāsādimhi kate –
analyzed: pīti somanassa sañjātaḥ māsa jātaḥ jāta māsaḥ chinna hatthaḥ hattha chinno  dīghā jaṅghāyassa ati viggayha samāsa ādimhi kate
translated: “He has arisen with desire” is “arisen with desire,” “he has desire arisen” is “desire arisen.” So also: “He has arisen with rapture and joy” is “arisen with rapture and joy,” “arisen month” is “month arisen,” “hand cut off” is “hand-cut,”🔽“He has long shanks” is “long-shanked.” After the analysis is made, the compound is formed.

original: “Tulyādhikaraṇe, pade”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: tulya adhikaraṇe pada iti ca vattate
translated: “When the base is the same, in a word” is said.

original: 353. Itthiyaṃ bhāsitapumitthī pumāva ce.🔽Itthiyaṃ vattamāne tulyādhikaraṇe pade pare pubbe bhāsitapumā itthivācako saddo atthi
analyzed: itthiyam bhāsita pumitthī pum āva ce  itthiyam vattamāne tulya adhikaraṇe pade pare pubbe bhāsita pumā itthi vācako saddo atthi
translated: . If the word for a man is used for a woman,🔽if there is a word for a woman used before in a sentence where the base is the same as that of the word for a man that follows,

original: ce, so pumā iva daṭṭhabboti pubbapade itthippaccayābhāvo, bahubbīhivisayoyaṃ, upari
analyzed: ce saḥ pumā iva daṭṭhabbaḥ iti pubba pade itthi paccaya abhāvaḥ upari
translated: that word for a woman should be regarded as a word for a man. So the absence of a condition for a feminine is in the preceding word. This applies to a bahubbīhi compound,

original: “kammadhārayasaññe cā”ti vakkhamānattā.
analyzed: kammadhāraya saññe ca ati vakkhamāna ttā
translated: because it will be said below “And in a kammadhāraya compound.”🔽. And in some cases, in the first, middle, and last,

original: 354. Kvacādimajjhuttarānaṃ dīgharassāpaccayesu ca.
analyzed: kva ca ādi majjha uttarānam dīgha rassa a paccayesu ca
translated: and in the conditions for long and short.

original: Kvaci taddhitasamāsanāmopasaggādīsu padesu ādimajjhuttarabhūtānaṃ sarānaṃ jinavacanānuparodhena dīgharassā honti paccayesu, apaccayesu paresu, aparabhūtesu ca.
analyzed: kvaci taddhita samāsa nāma upasagga ādīsu padesu ādi majjhuttara bhūtānam sarānam jina vacana an uparodhena dīgha rassāḥ honti paccayesu a paccayesu paresu apara bhūtesu ca
translated: In some instances, such as in the case-endings beginning with the locative, the long and short vowels of the words that are first, middle, and last become long and short respectively in accordance with the Buddha’s word, in the conditions, in the non-conditions, and in the other instances.

original: Tattha
analyzed: tattha
translated: Herein,

original: Dīghattaṃ pākaṭānūpa- ghātādo madhuvādisu;
analyzed: dīghattam ghātādaḥ madhu vādisu
translated: Longness is in honey, etc., and in the words beginning with “injury,”

original: Rassattaṃ ajjave itthi- rūpādo ca ka, tādisūti.
analyzed: rassattam ajjave itthi rūpa ādaḥ ca ka ta ādisu iti
translated: Shortness is in “woman,” etc., and in the words beginning with “ka.”

original: Bahubbīhisamāse sati pulliṅge uttarapadantassa rassattaṃ. Dīghajaṅgho puriso, tathā
analyzed: bahup bīhi samāse sati pul liṅge uttara pada antassa dīgha jaṅghaḥ purisaḥ tathā
translated: When there is a bahubbīhi compound, the last word has shortness if it is in the masculine gender. A man with long legs, thus

original: pahūtā jivhā assāti pahūtajivho bhagavā. Mahatī paññā assāti mahāpañño. “Mahataṃ
analyzed: pahūtā jivhā assa ati pahūta jivhaḥ bhagavā mahatī paññā assa ati mahā paññaḥ mahatam
translated: The Blessed One has a large tongue, thus he is “pahūtajivho.” He has great wisdom, thus he is “mahāpañño.” “Great is in the word

original: mahā tulyādhikaraṇe pade”ti mahādeso.
analyzed: tulya adhikaraṇe
translated: when there is equality of the base,” thus he is “mahādeso.”

original: Itthiyamiti kiṃ? Khamādhano. Bhāsitapumāti kiṃ? Saddhādhuro, saddhāpakatiko, paññāpakatiko,
analyzed: itthiyam iti kim kim saddhā dhuro saddhā pakatiko paññā pakatiko
translated: What is the meaning of “in the feminine gender”? Khamādhano. What is the meaning of “in the masculine gender”? Saddhādhuro, saddhāpakatiko, paññāpakatiko,

original: paññāvisuddhiko, ettha ca “kvaci samāsantagatānamakāranto”ti kappaccayo. Tulyādhikaraṇe
analyzed: ettha ca kvaci samāsa anta gatānam akāra antaḥ ti kappa ccayaḥ tulya adhikaraṇe
translated: paññāvisuddhiko. And here the condition is “kvaci samāsantagatānaṃ akāranto,” thus. When there is equality of the base,

original: icceva? Samaṇibhattiko, kumāribhattiko, kumāribhatti.
analyzed: iccā iva sa maṇibhattiko kumāribhattiko kumāribhatti
translated: is it only in this way? Samaṇibhattiko, kumāribhattiko, kumāribhatti.

original: Pubbapadassevāyaṃ pumbhāvātideso, tena idha na bhavati. Bahudāsiko puriso. Bahukumārikaṃ kulaṃ.
analyzed: pubba padassa iva ayam pumbhāva atideso tena idha na bhavati bahu dāsikaḥ purisaḥ bahu kumārikam kulam
translated: The difference in the masculine form here is due to the preceding word; thus there is no such form as bahudāsiko puriso, bahukumārikaṃ kulaṃ.

original: “Gāṇṭhivo dhanu assā”ti viggayha samāsādimhi kate –
analyzed: gāṇṭhivaḥ dhanu assa ati viggayha samāsa ādimhi kate
translated: The compound gāṇṭhivo dhanu assā is made by analysis as follows:

original: 355. Dhanumhā ca.
analyzed: dhanumhā ca
translated: Dhanumhā ca.

original: Tipadamidaṃ. Kvacisamāsantagatā dhanusaddā āpaccayo hoti, casaddena dhammādito ca, “vamodudantāna”nti vakāro, gāṇṭhivadhanvā. Evaṃ paccakkhadhammā.
analyzed: ti padam idam kvaci samāsa anta gatāḥ dhanu saddāḥ ā paccayaḥ hoti ca saddena dhamma āditas ca vakāraḥ gāṇṭhivadhanvā evam paccakkhadhammā
translated: This is a three-part compound. The word dhanu is a postpositive in some instances, and the word ca is used to include dhammādito. The vowel o in gāṇṭhivo is due to the rule: vamodudantāna. Thus it is a postpositive in some instances.

original: Kvacīti kiṃ? Sahassathāmadhanu, paccakkhadhammo, viditadhammo.🔽Nānādumapatitapupphavāsitasānu iccatra – nānappakārā dumā nānādumā, nānādumehi patitāni🔽nānādumapatitāni, nānādumapatitāni ca tāni pupphāni cāti nānādumapatitapupphāni,
analyzed: kvaci iti kim sahassa thāma dhanu paccakkha dhammaḥ vidita dhammaḥ  nānā duma patita puppha vāsita sānu iccatra nānappakārā dumā nānā dumā nānā dumehi patitāni  nānā duma patitāni nānā duma patitāni ca tāni pupphāni ca ati nānā duma patita pupphāni
translated: In some instances: what is the form when it is not a postpositive? Sahassathāmadhanu. It is a postpositive in the sense of known.🔽Nānādumapatitapupphavāsitasānu: here there are various kinds of trees, thus they are various trees, nānāduma. They fall from the various trees, thus they are fallen from various trees, nānādumapatitā. And they are flowers, thus they are fallen from various trees and flowers, nānādumapatitapupphāni.

original: tehi vāsitā nānādumapatitapupphavāsitā, nānādumapatitapupphavāsitā sānū yassa pabbatassa
analyzed: tehi vāsitā nānā duma patita puppha vāsitā nānā duma patita puppha vāsitā sānū yassa pabbatassa
translated: They perfume the mountain slopes, thus they are fallen from various trees and flowers and perfume the mountain slopes, nānādumapatitapupphavāsitasānu.🔽The mountain slopes are perfumed by the flowers fallen from the various trees.

original: soyaṃ nānādumapatitapupphavāsitasānu pabbato. Ayaṃ pana kammadhārayatappurisagabbho
analyzed: saḥ ayam nānā duma patita puppha vāsita sānu pabbataḥ ayam pana kammadhāraya tappurisa gabbho
translated: This mountain is perfumed with flowers fallen from various trees.

original: tulyādhikaraṇabahubbīhi.
analyzed: tulya adhikaraṇa bahup bīhi
translated: This is a man’s body with a backbone.

original: Tathā byālambo ambudharo byālambambudharo, tassa bindūni byālambambudharabindūni,
analyzed: tathā byālambaḥ ambudharaḥ byālamba mbudharaḥ tassa bindūni byālamba mbudhara bindūni
translated: So too: Byālambambudharo , byālambambudharabindūni ,

original: tehi cumbito byālambambudharabinducumbito, tādiso kūṭo yassa soyaṃ byālambambudharabinducumbitakūṭo iccādi.
analyzed: tehi cumbitaḥ byālamba ambudhara bindu cumbitaḥ tādisaḥ kūṭaḥ yassa saḥ yam iccādi
translated: byālambambudharabinducumbito , byālambambudharabinducumbitakūṭo .

original: Sattamiyatthe bahubbīhi yathā – sampannāni sassāni yasmiṃ janapade soyaṃ sampannasasso
analyzed: sattamiya tthe bahu bbīhi yathā sampannāni sassāni yasmin janapade saḥ ayam sampanna sassaḥ
translated: In the sense of the locative the bahubbīhi is like this: Sampannasasso ,

original: janapado, sulabho piṇḍo imasminti sulabhapiṇḍo deso. Ākiṇṇā manussā yassaṃ rājadhāniyaṃ🔽sā ākiṇṇamanussā rājadhānī, bahavo tāpasā etasminti bahutāpaso assamo, upacitaṃ maṃsalohitaṃ
analyzed: janapadaḥ sulabhaḥ piṇḍaḥ imasmin ti sulabha piṇḍaḥ deso ākiṇṇāḥ manussāḥ yassam rājadhāniyam  sā ākiṇṇa manussā rājadhānī bahavaḥ tāpasāḥ etasmin ti bahu tāpasaḥ assamaḥ upacitam maṃsa lohitam
translated: sulabhapiṇḍo , ākiṇṇamanussā ,🔽bahutāpaso , upacitamaṃsalohitaṃ ,

original: asminti upacitamaṃsalohitaṃ sarīraṃ, bahavo sāmino asminti bahussāmikaṃ nagaraṃ.
analyzed: asmin ti upacita maṃsa lohitam sarīram bahavaḥ sāminaḥ asmin ti bahussāmikam nagaram
translated: bahussāmikaṃ .

original: “Bahū nadiyo asmi”nti atthe samāsādimhi kate –
analyzed: bahū nadiyaḥ asmin ti atthe samāsa ādimhi kate
translated: In the sense of the locative the bahubbīhi is like this: “In this there are many rivers” .

original: Samāsantaggahaṇaṃ, kappaccayo ca vattate.
analyzed: samāsa anta ggahaṇam ca vattate
translated: The compound ending in -anta is also used with the instrumental case.

original: 356. Nadimhā ca.
analyzed: nadimhā ca
translated: And with the locative.

original: Samāsantagatā nadimhā kappaccayo hoti, casaddena tuantā ca. Niccatthaṃ vacanaṃ. Nadīti
analyzed: samāsa anta gatā nadimhā kappa ccayaḥ hoti ca saddena tu antā ca niccattham vacanam nadī iti
translated: The compound ending in -anta is also used with the locative case. The word ca is used to include the ablative case. The locative case is the meaning of the word nadī.

original: cettha itthivācakānaṃ īkārūkārānaṃ parasamaññā, tato “kvacādimajjhuttarāna”ntiādinā
analyzed: ca itthaḥ itthi vācakānam īkāra ukārānam para samaññā tatas kva ca ādi majjha uttara ananti ādinā
translated: Herein, the words ī and ū are synonyms for the feminine ending -ī and -ū. Then, because of the words kvacādimajjhuttarāna,

original: nadisaññassa kappaccaye rassattaṃ, bahunadiko janapado. Evaṃ bahujambukaṃ vanaṃ.
analyzed: nadi saññassa kappa ccaye rassattam bahu nadikaḥ janapadaḥ evam bahu jambukam vanam
translated: the locative case ending in -ī is shortened in the compound ending in -anta. The country has many rivers. So too, the forest has many jackfruit trees.

original: Bahunārikoti chaṭṭhībahubbīhinā siddhaṃ. Bahavo kattāro asmiṃ, assāti vā bahukattuko
analyzed: bahu nārikā iti chaṭṭhī bahu bīhinā siddham bahavaḥ kattāraḥ asmin assa ati vā bahu kattukaḥ
translated: The word bahunāriko is formed by the sixth-case plural of the bahubbīhi compound. It has many makers. Or it is the place where many are made.

original: deso. Evaṃ bahubhattuko.🔽Bhinnādhikaraṇo yathā – ekarattiṃ vāso assāti ekarattivāso, samānena janena saddhiṃ🔽vāso assāti samānavāso puriso. Ubhato byañjanamassa atthīti ubhabhobyañjanako, chattaṃ
analyzed: desaḥ evam bahu bhattukaḥ  bhinna adhikaraṇaḥ yathā eka rattim vāsaḥ assa ati eka ratti vāsaḥ samānena janena saddhim  vāsaḥ assa ati samāna vāsaḥ puriso ubhatas byañjanam assa atthi iti chattam
translated: So too, bahubhattuko.

original: pāṇimhi assāti chattapāṇi puriso. Evaṃ daṇḍapāṇi, satthapāṇi, vajirapāṇi, khaggahattho,
analyzed: pāṇimhi assa ati chatta pāṇi purisaḥ evam daṇḍa pāṇi sattha pāṇi vajira pāṇi khagga hatthaḥ
translated: When the case endings are different, as in ekarattiṃ vāso assāti ekarattivāso, the meaning is “he has a stay of one night.” Samānena janena saddhiṃ vāso assāti samānavāso puriso, the meaning is “he has a stay with a companion.” Ubhato byañjanamassa atthīti ubhabhobyañjanako, chattaṃ pāṇimhi assāti chattapāṇi puriso, the meaning is “he has an umbrella in his hand.” So too, daṇḍapāṇi, satthapāṇi, vajirapāṇi, khaggahattho,

original: satthahattho, dāne ajjhāsayo assāti dānajjhāsayo, dānādhimuttiko, buddhabhattiko,
analyzed: sattha hatthaḥ dāne ajjhāsayaḥ assa ati dāna ajjhāsayaḥ dāna adhimuttikaḥ buddha bhattikaḥ
translated: He has the staff in his hand, he is intent on giving, he is intent on generosity, he is devoted to giving, he is devoted to the Buddha,

original: saddhammagāravo iccādi.
translated: He has a hand in the knife, he has a disposition to giving, he is disposed to giving, he is intent on giving, he is a devotee of the Buddha, he has respect for the True Idea, and so on.

original: Tipado yathā – parakkamenādhigatā sampadā yehi te bhavanti parakkamādhigatasampadā
analyzed: tipadaḥ yathā parakkamena adhigatā sampadā yehi te bhavanti parakkama adhigata sampadā
translated: The three-word compound is like this: They have the excellence that is attained by exertion, thus they are those who have the excellence that is attained by exertion,

original: mahāpurisā. Evaṃ dhammādhigatabhogā, oṇīto pattato pāṇi yena soyaṃ oṇītapattapāṇi,🔽sīhassa pubbaddhaṃ viya kāyo assāti sīhapubbaddhakāyo, mattā bahavo mātaṅgā asminti
analyzed: mahā purisāḥ evam dhamma adhigata bhogāḥ oṇītaḥ pattataḥ pāṇi yena saḥ ayam oṇīta patta pāṇi  sīhassa pubbaddham viya kāyaḥ assa ati sīha pubbaddha kāyaḥ mattāḥ bahavaḥ mātaṅgāḥ asmin ti
translated: they are Great Men. So too, they have wealth that is attained by the True Idea, he has a hand that is lowered from the bowl, thus he is one whose hand is lowered from the bowl,

original: mattabahumātaṅgaṃ vanaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: matta bahu mātaṅgam vanam it ca ādi
translated: his body is like the front part of a lion, thus he is one whose body is like the front part of a lion, this wood has many intoxicated elephants, thus it is a wood with many intoxicated elephants, and so on.

original: Nanipātapubbapado yathā – natthi etassa samoti asamo bhagavā. Idha “attaṃ nassa tappurise”ti
analyzed: na nipāta pubba padaḥ yathā na atthi etassa samaḥ ti asamaḥ bhagavā idha attam nassa tappurisa iti
translated: The first word of the Nanipāṭha is like this: He has no equal, thus he is the Unequaled Blessed One. Here in the sutta ‘attaṃ nassa tappurise’

original: sutte “attaṃ nassā”ti yogavibhāgena nassa attaṃ. Evaṃ appaṭipuggalo, aputtako, ahetuko,
analyzed: sutte attam nassa ati yogavibhāgena attam evam appaṭipuggalaḥ aputtakaḥ ahetukaḥ
translated: the ‘attaṃ nassā’ is ‘attaṃ nassā’ by the analysis of the compound. So too, he has no counterpart, he has no son, he has no cause,

original: “kvaci samāsanta”iccādinā kappaccayo, natthi saṃvāso etesanti asaṃvāsā, na vijjate
analyzed: kvaci samāsa anta e c ca ādinā na atthi saṃvāsaḥ a saṃvāsāḥ na vijjate
translated: ‘kvaci samāsanta’ and so on, is the postposition. They have no living in common, thus they are those that have no living in common. They are not found,

original: vuṭṭhi etthāti avuṭṭhiko janapado, abhikkhuko vihāro, natthi etassa uttaroti anuttaro,
analyzed: ettha ati avuṭṭhikaḥ janapadaḥ abhikkhukaḥ vihāro na atthi etassa uttaro ti anuttaraḥ
translated: A country where there is no rain is a non-rainy country . A monastery where there is no alms is an alms-free monastery . There is no superior to this, thus it is unsurpassed .🔽The word ana is formed with the prefix a- and the root na, and the affix ana is added.

original: “sare ana”ti ana, tappurisaggahaṇamupalakkhaṇaṃ, athavā “tesu vuddhī”tiādinā nassa
analyzed: sare tappurisa ggahaṇam upalakkhaṇam athavā tesu vuddhi iti ādinā nassa
translated: Or the affix ana is added to the word tesu with the prefix a-.

original: ana. Evaṃ natthi anto assāti anantaṃ, na vijjanti āsavā etesanti anāsavā iccādi.
analyzed: anaḥ evam na atthi antaḥ assa ati anantam na vijjanti āsavāḥ etesanti anāsavāḥ iccādi
translated: Thus: there is no end to it, thus it is endless . There are no cankers in them, thus they are without cankers .

original: Paṭhamāyatthe sahapubbapado yathā – saha hetunā yo vattateti sahetuko, sahetu vā,
analyzed: saha pubba padaḥ yathā saha hetunā yaḥ vattate iti sa hetukaḥ sa hetu vā
translated: In the sense of “together with,” the prefix saha- is used as follows: He who occurs together with a cause is caused , or he is with a cause .

original: “tesu vuddhī”tiādinā sahasaddassa sādeso, “kvaci samāsanta”iccādinā kappaccayo ca,
analyzed: tesu vuddhi iti ādinā saha saddassa sa ādesaḥ kvaci samāsa anta e c ca ādinā kappa ccayaḥ ca
translated: The word saha is changed to sā- by the rule “tesu vuddhī” , and the affix -ya is added by the rule “kvaci samāsanta” ,

original: saha pītiyā ime vattantīti sappītikā. Evaṃ saha paccayehi vattantīti sappaccayā,
analyzed: saha pītiyā ime vattanti iti sa pītikāḥ evam saha paccayehi vattanti iti sa paccayāḥ
translated: Thus: they occur together with joy, thus they are joyful . So too: they occur together with conditions, thus they are conditional .

original: sakileso, saupādāno, saparivāro, saha mūlena uddhato samūluddhato rukkho.
analyzed: sa kilesaḥ sa upādānaḥ sa parivāraḥ saha mūlena uddhataḥ sa mūla uddhataḥ rukkho
translated: They are defiled , they are with attachment , they are with a retinue , the tree is uprooted together with its root .

original: Upamānapubbapado paṭhamāyatthe tāva – upamānopameyyabhāvappasiddhatthaṃ ivasaddappayogo,
analyzed: upamāna pubba padaḥ tāva upamāna upameyya bhāva ppasiddha ttham iva sadda ppayogaḥ
translated: In the sense of “first,” the prefix upa- is used as follows: The word ivas is used in order to establish the relationship of simile and similissimum .

original: kāyabyāmānaṃ samappamāṇatāya nigrodho iva parimaṇḍalo yo rājakumāro soyaṃnigrodhaparimaṇḍalo
analyzed: kāya byāmānam nigrodhaḥ iva parimaṇḍalaḥ yaḥ rāja kumāraḥ saḥ iyam nigrodha parimaṇḍalaḥ
translated: He was well-proportioned in his body, and so he was round like a banyan tree, and so he was called Nigrodha, “the banyan tree.”

original: rājakumāro. “Vuttatthānamappayogo”ti ivasaddassa appayogo, saṅkho viya paṇḍaro ayanti
analyzed: rāja kumāraḥ vutta tthānam appayogo ti iva saddassa appayogo saṅkhaḥ viya paṇḍaraḥ ayanti
translated: The word iva is not used in the sense of “the place where it was said,” and so he was white like a shell, and so he was called Saṅkhapaṇḍita, “the wise one like a shell.”🔽He was brave like a crow, and so he was called Kākasūra, “the crow-brave.”

original: saṅkhapaṇḍaro, kāko viya sūro ayanti kākasūro, cakkhu iva bhūto ayaṃ paramatthadassanatoti🔽cakkhubhūto bhagavā. Evaṃ atthabhūto. Dhammabhūto, brahmabhūto, andho viya bhūto
analyzed: saṅkha paṇḍaro kākaḥ viya sūraḥ ayanti kāka sūraḥ cakkhu iva bhūtaḥ ayam paramattha dassanato ti  cakkhu bhūtaḥ bhagavā evam attha bhūtaḥ dhamma bhūtaḥ brahma bhūtaḥ andhaḥ viya bhūtaḥ
translated: He was like an eye in the sense of seeing the ultimate truth, and so he was called Cakkhubhūta, “the eye-become,” the Blessed One.🔽Thus he is the one who has become the meaning. He is the one who has become the Dhamma, the one who has become the Brahmā. He is the one who has become blind, and so he is called Andhabhūta, “the blind-become,” the fool.

original: ayanti andhabhūto bālo. Muñjapabbajamiva bhūtā ayanti muñjapabbajabhūtā kudiṭṭhi.
analyzed: ayanti andha bhūtaḥ bālaḥ muñja pabbajam iva bhūtāḥ ayanti muñja pabbaja bhūtā kudiṭṭhi
translated: He is the one who has become the muñja grass, and so he is called Muñjapabbajabhūta, “the muñja grass-become,” the evil view.

original: Tantākulakamiva jātā ayanti tantākulakajātā.
analyzed: tantā kulakam iva jātāḥ ayanti tantā kulaka jātā
translated: He is the one who has become the spider’s web, and so he is called Tantākulakajāta, “the spider’s web-become.”🔽In the sixth case: He had a complexion like the color of gold, and so he was called Suvaṇṇavaṇṇo, “the gold-complexioned,” the Blessed One.

original: Chaṭṭhiyatthe – suvaṇṇavaṇṇo viya vaṇṇo yassa soyaṃ suvaṇṇavaṇṇo bhagavā. Uttarapadalopo,
analyzed: suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ viya vaṇṇaḥ yassa saḥ ayam suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ bhagavā uttara pada lopaḥ
translated: The last word is elided.

original: nāgassa viya assa gatīti nāgagati. Evaṃ sīhagati, nāgavikkamo, sīhavikkamo, sīhahanu,
analyzed: nāgassa viya assa gatī iti nāga gati evam sīha gati nāga vikkamaḥ sīha vikkamaḥ sīha hanu
translated: He had the gait of a nāga, and so he was called Nāgagati, “the nāga-gaited.” Thus he is the one who has the gait of a lion, the one who has the gait of a nāga, the one who has the stride of a lion, the one who has the stride of a nāga, the one who has the jaw of a lion,

original: eṇissa viya assa jaṅghāti eṇijaṅgho, sīhassa pubbaddhaṃ viya assa kāyoti sīhapubbaddhakāyo,
analyzed: eṇissa viya assa jaṅghā ati eṇi jaṅghaḥ sīhassa pubbaddham viya assa kāyo iti sīha pubbaddha kāyaḥ
translated: He has shanks like a deer’s, thus he is “antelope-shanked” . He has a body like the front part of a lion, thus he is “lion-fronted” .

original: brahmuno viya aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgato saro assāti brahmassaro.🔽Vāsaddatthe saṅkhyobhayapado yathā – dve vā tayo vā pattā dvattipattā, “dvekaṭṭhānamākāro
analyzed: brahmunaḥ viya aṭṭhaṅga samannāgato saraḥ assa ati brahmassaro  saṅkhyā ubhaya padaḥ yathā dve vā tayaḥ vā pattāḥ dvatti pattāḥ
translated: He has a voice endowed with the eight qualities like Brahmā’s, thus he is “Brahma-voiced” .🔽The word “pair” is used in the sense of “two” and “both” : two or three bowls, a “pair of two bowls” ;

original: vā”ti dvisaddantassa āttaṃ, rassattaṃ, dvīhaṃ vā tīhaṃ vā dvīhatīhaṃ, cha vā pañca
analyzed: vāti dvi sadda antassa āttam rassattam dvīham vā tīham vā dvīhatīham cha vā pañca
translated: “The form of the place of two” is the meaning. The word “pair” is used in the sense of “long” : a long two, a long three, a long two or three,

original: vā vācā chappañcavācā. Evaṃ sattaṭṭhamāsā, ekayojanadviyojanāni.
analyzed: vā vācā cha pañca vācā evam satta ṭṭha māsāḥ eka yojana dvi yojanāni
translated: six or five statements, six or five statements. So too, seven or eight months, one league or two leagues.

original: Disantarāḷattho yathā – pubbassā ca dakkhiṇassā ca disāya yadantarāḷaṃ sāyaṃ pubbadakkhiṇā
analyzed: dis antarāḷa tthaḥ yathā pubbassā ca dakkhiṇassā ca disāya yat antarāḷam sāyam pubba dakkhiṇā
translated: The word “pair” is used in the sense of “the space between directions” : the space between the eastern and the southern direction is the southeast.

original: vidisā. Ettha tulyādhikaraṇapadaparattābhāvā na pumbhāvātideso, “kvacādimajjhuttarāna”ntiādinā
analyzed: vidisāḥ ettha na pumbhāva atidesaḥ
translated: Here, because of the absence of the state of being a compound word with a common base, there is no change of the masculine gender.

original: disantarāḷatthe pubbapadassa rassattaṃ. Evaṃ pubbuttarā, aparadakkhiṇā, pacchimuttarā.
analyzed: dis anta rāḷ atthe pubba padassa rassa ttam evam pubba uttarā apara dakkhiṇā pacchima uttarā
translated: The word “pair” is used in the sense of “the space between directions” in the way beginning “sometimes the beginning, middle, and end” . So too, the northeast, the southwest, the northwest.

original: Yadā pana dakkhiṇā ca sā pubbā cāti kammadhārayasamāso hoti, tadā pumbhāvātideso
analyzed: yadā pana dakkhiṇā ca sā pubbā ca ati kammadhāraya samāsaḥ hoti tadā pumbhāva atidesaḥ
translated: But when the compound is a copulative one, then the feminine is changed to the masculine

original: uttarapadatthappadhānattā, sabbanāmikavidhānampi niccaṃ bhavatiyeva, yathā – dakkhiṇapubbassā,
translated: because the meaning of the last word predominates, and the rule for the feminine is always applicable, as in dakkhiṇapubbassā,

original: dakkhiṇapubbassamiti.
analyzed: dakkhiṇa pubbassam iti
translated: dakkhiṇapubbassam.

original: Byatihāralakkhaṇo yathā – kesesu ca kesesu ca gahetvā idaṃ yuddhaṃ pavattatīti kesākesi,
analyzed: byatihāra lakkhaṇaḥ yathā kesesu ca kesesu ca gahetvā idam yuddham pavattati iti kesākesi
translated: The characteristic of the bahubbīhi compound is excess, as in kesākesu,🔽“in the hair and in the hair,” where the war is going on, and in daṇḍādaṇḍi,

original: daṇḍehi ca daṇḍehi ca paharitvā idaṃ yuddhaṃ pavattatīti daṇḍādaṇḍi, “kvacādimajjhuttarāna”ntiādinā
analyzed: daṇḍehi ca daṇḍehi ca paharitvā idam yuddham pavattati iti daṇḍādaṇḍi
translated: “with stick and with stick,” where the blows are being struck.🔽The majjhe dīgho is according to kvacādimajjhuttarānaṃ,

original: majjhedīgho, “tesu vuddhī”tiādinā antassikāro.
analyzed: majjhe dīghaḥ tesu vuddhi iti ādinā antassikāraḥ
translated: and the antassikāro is according to tesu vuddhī.

original: Paṭhamāvibhatyatthabahubbīhi.
analyzed: paṭhamā vibhati attha bahup bīhi
translated: The bahubbīhi compound with the first case is ended.

original: Bahubbīhisamāso niṭṭhito.
analyzed: bahup bīhi samāsaḥ niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The bahubbīhi compound is ended.

original: Dvandasamāsa
analyzed: dvanda samāsa
translated: The dvanda compound

original: Atha dvandasamāso vuccate.
analyzed: atha dvanda samāsaḥ vuccate
translated: Now the dvanda compound is stated.

original: So ca duvidho itarītarayoga samāhāratthabhedena.
analyzed: saḥ ca duvidhaḥ samāhāra ttha bhedena
translated: And it is of two kinds as consisting in the connection of the other and as having the meaning of collection.

original: Tattha itarītarayoge tāva – “sāriputtamoggallāna”itīdha ubhayatthāpi paṭhamekavacanaṃ, samuccayajotanatthaṃ casaddappayogo ca.
analyzed: tattha itarītara yoge tāva ubhayattha api paṭhama ekavacanam samuccaya jotana attham ca
translated: Herein, firstly, as regards the combination of the two kinds of terms, in the phrase “Sāriputtamoggallāna” the first singular is in both instances, and the word ca is used in the sense of accumulation.

original: “Sāriputto ca moggallāno cā”ti viggahe –
analyzed: sāriputto ca moggallāno ca ati viggahe
translated: In the analysis “Sāriputta and Moggallāna”

original: 357. Nāmānaṃ samuccayo dvando.
analyzed: nāmānam samuccayaḥ dvando
translated: The copulative compound is an accumulation of names.

original: Nānānāmānameva ekavibhattikānaṃ yuttatthānaṃ yo samuccayo, so vibhāsā samāso bhavati, dvandasañño ca.
analyzed: nānā nāmānam eva eka vibhattikānam yutta tthānam samuccayo saḥ vibhāsā samāsaḥ bhavati ca
translated: The copulative compound is a compound consisting of two or more terms that are connected in meaning and have the same case ending.

original: Ettha ca samuccayo nāma sampiṇḍanaṃ, so pana atthavasena kevalasamuccayo anvācayo itarītarayogo samāhāro cāti catubbidho.
analyzed: ettha ca samuccayaḥ nāma sampiṇḍanam saḥ pana attha vasena kevala samuccayaḥ anvācayaḥ itarītara yogo samāhāro ca ati catubbidhaḥ
translated: And here an accumulation is a lumping together. It is of four kinds as mere accumulation, enumeration, combination of the two, and collection.

original: Tattha kevalasamuccaye, anvācaye ca samāso na bhavati, kriyāsāpekkhatāya nāmānaṃ
analyzed: kevala samuccaye anvācaye ca samāsaḥ na bhavati kriyā sāpekkhatāya
translated: Herein, in mere accumulation and in enumeration the compound does not occur, because the names are not connected in meaning, since they require different actions,

original: aññamaññaṃ ayuttatthabhāvato, yathā – cīvaraṃ piṇḍapātañca paccayaṃ sayanāsanaṃ adāsi,
analyzed: aññam aññam ayutta attha bhāvataḥ yathā cīvaram piṇḍapātam ca paccayam sayanāsanam adāsi
translated: like “He gave robe-material, alms food, requisites, and medicine when sick,

original: dānañca dehi, sīlañca rakkhāhi. Itarītarayoge, samāhāre ca samāso bhavati, tattha
analyzed: dānañca dehi sīlañca rakkhāhi itarītara yoge samāhāre ca samāsaḥ bhavati tattha
translated: and give a gift, and observe morality.” In combination of the two and in collection the compound does occur. Herein,

original: nāmānaṃ aññamaññaṃ yuttatthabhāvato.
analyzed: nāmānam aññam aññam yutta attha bhāvato
translated: and the meaning of the compound is the meaning of the individual words in conjunction.

original: Dve dve padāni dvandā, dvandaṭṭhā vā dvandā, dvandasadisattā ayaṃ samāsopi anvatthasaññāya dvandoti vuccati, ubhayapadatthappadhāno hi dvando.
analyzed: dve dve padāni dvandāḥ dvandaṭṭhāḥ vā dvandāḥ dvanda sadisa ttā ayam samāsaḥ api anvattha saññāya dvando ti vuccati ubhaya padattha ppadhānaḥ hi dvando
translated: Two words in apposition are a dvanda, or a dvanda is a place for a dvanda, or this compound is called a dvanda by the name of its constituent part, because it is similar to a dvanda, for a dvanda is a place for the meaning of both words.

original: Nanu ca ubhayapadatthappadhānatte sati dvande kathamekatthībhāvo siyāti? Vuccate🔽– sadisādiatthepi saddappavattisambhavenadvinnaṃ padānaṃ ekakkhaṇeyeva atthadvayadīpakattā
analyzed: nanu ca ubhaya padattha ppadhāna tte sati dvande katham ekatthībhāvaḥ siyā iti vuccate  sadisa ādi atthe pi padānam eka kkhaṇe iya iva attha dvaya dīpaka ttā
translated: But if it is a place for the meaning of both words, how can it be a single meaning?🔽It is said:🔽there is no contradiction because the word occurs in the sense of similarity, etc., and because the two words indicate two meanings, etc., at one moment only.🔽And that is only in the domain of dvandas, because they indicate two meanings, etc.

original: na virodho, tañca dvandavisayameva, tesamatthadvayadīpakattā. Yathā hi bhūsaddo anubhavaabhibhavādike
analyzed: na virodhaḥ tat ca dvanda visayam eva tesam attha dvaya dīpaka ttā yathā hi bhū saddaḥ anubhava abhibhava ādike
translated: For just as the word bhū, when accompanied by the prefixes anubhi, etc., indicates the meanings of “experience,” “overcome,” etc.,

original: atthe anvabhiādiupasaggasahitova dīpeti, na kevalo, evaṃ “gavassaka”ntiādīsu gavādīnaṃ
analyzed: atthe anu abhi ādi upasagga sahitaḥ iva dīpeti na kevalaḥ evam gavassakanti ādīsu go ādīnam
translated: and not by itself, so too, in such passages as “gavassaka,” etc., it is only the words such as “go” that,

original: assādisaddantarasahitānameva atthadvayadīpanaṃ, na kevalānanti tañca dvandavisayameva,
analyzed: attha dvaya dīpanam na tat ca dvanda visayam eva
translated: accompanied by other words such as “assā,” etc., indicate two meanings, etc., and not by themselves. And that is only in the domain of dvandas,

original: na sabbatthāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Atha vā dvinnampi yathāvuttasamuccayadīpakattā atthi dvandepekatthitāti
analyzed: na sabbattha ati daṭṭhabbam atha vā dvinnam pi yathāvutta samuccaya dīpaka ttā atthi dvandepekatthi tā ati
translated: Or else, since both are declarers of the combination stated thus, there is a single meaning in the dvanda compound.

original: na koci virodho, tato samāsasaññāvibhattilopādi vuttanayameva, samāseneva catthassa
analyzed: na koci virodhaḥ tatas samāsa saññā vibhatti lopa ādi vutta nayam eva samāsena iva catthassa
translated: So there is no contradiction. Then the mode of resolving the compound, the elision of the case-ending, etc., is as already stated.

original: vuttattā “vuttatthānamappayogo”ti casaddassa appayogo.
analyzed: vutta ttā vutta tthānam appayogo ti ca saddassa appayogo
translated: Since the meaning is stated by the compound itself, the word ca is not used in the sense stated.🔽Herein, the first member of a dvanda compound is placed first if it is the more important, and it has the gender of the second member.

original: Idha dvande accitataraṃ pubbaṃ nipatati, parasseva liṅgañca. Itarītarayogassa avayavappadhānattā sabbattha bahuvacanameva.🔽Sāriputtamoggallānā, sāriputtamoggallāne, sāriputtamoggallānehi iccādi, samaṇo ca
analyzed: idha dvande accitataram pubbam nipatati parassa iva liṅgam ca itarītara yogassa avayava ppadhāna ttā sabbattha bahuvacanam eva  sāriputta moggallānā sāriputta moggallāne sāriputta moggallānehi iccādi samaṇaḥ ca
translated: But the plural is used in all instances because the dvanda compound is a class-unit.

original: brāhmaṇo ca samaṇabrāhmaṇā. Evaṃ brāhmaṇagahapatikā, khattiyabrāhmaṇā, devamanussā,🔽candimasūriyā, mātā ca pitā ca mātāpitaro, “tesu vuddhī”tiādinā dvande mātuādipubbapadukārassa
analyzed: brāhmaṇo ca samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ evam brāhmaṇa gahapatikā khattiya brāhmaṇāḥ deva manussā  candima sūriyāḥ mātā ca pitā ca mātā pitaraḥ tesu vuddhi iti ādinā dvande mātu ādi pubba padu kārassa
translated: Sāriputtamoggallānā, sāriputtamoggallāne, sāriputtamoggallānehi, etc.; samaṇo ca brāhmaṇo ca = samaṇabrāhmaṇā. So too, brāhmaṇagahapatikā, khattiyabrāhmaṇā, devamanussā,

original: ākāro. Evaṃ pitāputtā.
analyzed: ākāraḥ evam pitāputtā
translated: candimasūriyā, mātā ca pitā ca = mātāpitaro. The mode of the first member in a dvanda compound is as follows: “tesu vuddhī” (P. 1.1. 70), etc. So too, pitāputtā.

original: “Jāyā ca pati cāti jāyāpati”itīdha –
analyzed: jāyā ca pati ca ati jāyāpati iti idha
translated: “Jāyā ca pati ca = jāyāpati” (P. 1.1. 70). Herein,

original: “Kvacī”ti vattate.
analyzed: kvaci iti vattate
translated: “In some instances” is said.

original: 358. Jāyāya tudaṃ jāni patimhi.
analyzed: jāyāya tudam jāni patimhi
translated: The word “wife” has the feminine form “jāni” in the masculine form “patī.”

original: Jāyāsaddassa tudaṃ jāniiccete ādesā honti patisadde pare kvaci. Tudaṃpati, jānipati, jayampatikā. Ettha niggahītāgamo, “kvacā”dinā rassattañca.🔽Kvaci appasaraṃ pubbaṃ nipatati, yathā – cando ca sūriyo ca candasūriyā, nigamā ca
analyzed: jāyā saddassa tudam jāni iti ca ite ādesāḥ honti pati sadde pare kvaci tudaṃpati jānipati jayampatikā ettha niggahīta āgamaḥ kvaca ādinā  kvaci appasaram pubbam nipatati yathā cando ca sūriyo ca canda sūriyā nigamā ca
translated: These are the replacements for the word “wife” in the masculine form “patī” in some instances. “Jānipatī,” “jayampatī.” Here the suffix -ī is elided by the rule “kvacā,” etc., and the short vowel is lengthened.

original: janapadā ca nigamajanapadā, surā ca asurā ca garuḷā ca manujā ca bhujagā ca gandhabbā🔽ca surāsuragaruḷamanujabhujagagandhabbā.
analyzed: janapadā ca nigama janapadā surā ca asurā ca garuḷā ca manujā ca bhujagā ca gandhabbā  ca sura asura garuḷa manuja bhujaga gandhabbā
translated: In some instances, the first member is contracted, as in “the moon and the sun” (canda-sūriyā), “the towns and the countryside” (nigamā-janapadā), “the gods, the antigods, the garuḍas, the humans, the nāgas, and the gandhabbas” (surā-asurā-garuḷā-manujā-bhujagā-gandhabbā).

original: Kvaci ivaṇṇuvaṇṇantānaṃ pubbanipāto, yathā – aggi ca dhūmo ca aggidhūmā. Evaṃ gatibuddhibhujapaṭhaharakarasayā, dhātavo ca liṅgāni ca dhātuliṅgāni.
analyzed: kvaci i va ṇ u va ṇ antānam pubba nipātaḥ yathā aggi ca dhūmaḥ ca aggi dhūmā evam dhātavaḥ ca liṅgāni ca dhātu liṅgāni
translated: In some instances, the first member is in the feminine form, as in “the fire and the smoke” (aggi-dhūmā). Thus “the elements and the signs” (dhātu-liṅgāni), “the elements and the faculties” (dhātu-buddhi), “the elements and the limbs” (dhātu-bhuja), “the elements and the paths” (dhātu-paṭha), “the elements and the hands” (dhātu-hara), “the elements and the rays” (dhātu-raśmi), “the elements and the rays” (dhātu-sayā).

original: Kvaci sarādiakārantānaṃ pubbanipāto, yathā – attho ca dhammo ca atthadhammā. Evaṃ atthasaddā, saddatthā vā.
analyzed: kvaci sara ādi akāra antānam pubbanipātaḥ yathā attho ca dhammo ca attha dhammāḥ evam attha saddāḥ sadda tthāḥ vā
translated: In some instances, the first member is in the locative case, as in “the meaning and the Dhamma” (attho ca dhammo ca). Thus “the meaning and the words” (attha-saddā), “the words and the meaning” (sadda-atthā).

original: Samāhāre pana – “cakkhu ca sotañcā”ti atthe “nāmānaṃ samuccayo dvando”ti dvandasamāsaṃ katvā vibhattilopādimhi kate –
analyzed: samāhāre pana cakkhu ca sotam ca ati atthe nāmānam samuccayaḥ dvando iti dvanda samāsam katvā vibhatti lopa ādimhi kate
translated: But in a copulative compound, “eye and ear” is the meaning of “cakkhu ca sotañca.” The copulative compound is formed thus: “The copulative compound is a dvanda.” The case-ending is elided, and so on.

original: “Napuṃsakaliṅgaṃ, ekattañcā”ti vattate.
analyzed: napuṃsaka liṅgam ekattam ca ati vattate
translated: “The gender is neuter, and the number is singular.”

original: 359. Tathā dvande pāṇi tūriya yogga senaṅga khuddajantuka vividha viruddha visabhāgatthādīnañca.
analyzed: tathā
translated: So too in a dvanda, in such words as “hand and musical instrument,” “battle and army,” “limb and small animal,” “various and opposed,” “unlike,” and so on.

original: Yathā digusamāse, tathā samāhāradvandasamāsepi pāṇi tūriya yogga senaṅgatthānaṃ, khuddajantukavividha viruddhavisabhāgatthaiccevamādīnañca ekattaṃ hoti, napuṃsakaliṅgattañca.
analyzed: yathā digu samāse tathā samāhāra dvanda samāse pi ekattam hoti napuṃsaka liṅga ttam ca
translated: Just as in a determinative compound, so too in a copulative compound, the number is singular and the gender is neuter in such words as “hand and musical instrument,” “battle and army,” “limb and small animal,” “various and opposed,” “unlike,” and so on.

original: Pāṇino ca tūriyāni ca yoggāni ca senā cāti pāṇitūriya yoggasenā, tāsamaṅgāni pāṇitūriyayoggasenaṅgāni,
analyzed: ca tūriyāni ca yoggāni ca senā ca ati pāṇi tūriya yogga senā tāsamaṅgāni
translated: “Hand and musical instrument and battle and army” are “pāṇitūriya-yogga-sena.” The “limbs” of these are “pāṇitūriyayoggasenaṅgāni.”

original: dvandato parattā aṅgasaddo paccekamabhisambajjhate. Khuddā ca te jantukā ceti khuddajantukā,
analyzed: dvandataḥ parattā aṅga saddo paccekam abhisambajjhate khuddā ca te jantukā ca iti khuddajantukā
translated: The word “limb” is construed separately after the dvanda. “Small and animals” are “khuddajantukā.”

original: vividhenākārena viruddhā vividhaviruddhā, niccavirodhino. Samāno bhāgo yesaṃ te sabhāgā,
analyzed: vividhena ākārena viruddhāḥ vividha viruddhāḥ nicca virodhino samānaḥ bhāgaḥ yesam te sa bhāgā
translated: They are various and opposed, thus they are various and opposed. Those that have a common portion are common.

original: “tesu vuddhī”tiādinā samānassa saādeso, vividhā ca te lakkhaṇato sabhāgā ca kiccatoti
analyzed: tesu vuddhi iti ādinā samānassa sa ādesaḥ vividhā ca te lakkhaṇato sabhāgā ca kiccato ti
translated: “In them increase” is the same as “in them increase, etc.” They are various and they are common in respect of characteristic, thus they are

original: visabhāgā. Pāṇitūriyayoggasenaṅgāni ca khuddajantukā ca vividhaviruddhā ca visabhāgā
analyzed: visabhāgā ca khuddajantukā ca vividhaviruddhā ca visabhāgā
translated: various and common. The limbs of the tusker, etc., and the tiny animals are various and opposed, thus they are various and opposed.

original: cāti dvando, idha bahuttā pubbanipātassa aniyamo, te atthā yesaṃ te pāṇitūriyayoggasenaṅgakhuddajantukavividhaviruddhavisabhāgatthā,
analyzed: ca ati dvandaḥ idha bahu ttā pubba nipātassa aniyamaḥ te atthāḥ yesam te
translated: The compound is a copulative one. Here the rule about the priority of the first member does not apply because of the multiplicity. Those that have that meaning, namely, the meaning of the limbs of the tusker, etc., are those that have that meaning, namely, the meaning of the limbs of the tusker, etc.,

original: te ādayo yesaṃ te tadādayo.
analyzed: te ādayaḥ te tad ādayaḥ
translated: and those that have that as their first member are those that have that as their first member.

original: Ādiggahaṇena aññoññaliṅgavisesita saṅkhyāparimāṇattha pacanacaṇḍālattha disatthādīnañca
analyzed: ādi ggahaṇena saṅkhyā parimāṇa ttha pacana caṇḍāla ttha disa ttha ādīnam ca
translated: By the word “first” is included the number and measure qualified by the different genders, the meaning of cooking and the meaning of the outcast, the meaning of the directions, and so on.

original: dvande ekattaṃ, napuṃsakaliṅgattañca, iti pāṇyaṅgatthabhāvato cakkhusotasaddānaṃ
analyzed: dvande eka ttam napuṃsaka liṅga ttam ca iti pāṇi aṅga attha bhāvataḥ cakkhu sota saddānam
translated: In a copulative compound there is singleness and the neuter gender. Thus the eye, ear, and sound

original: iminā ekattaṃ, napuṃsakaliṅgattañca katvā samāsattā nāmabyapadese kate syādyuppatti amādesādi.
analyzed: eka ttam napuṃsaka liṅga ttam ca katvā samāsa ttā nāma byapadese kate am ādesa ādi
translated: are made one and neuter by this, and when the compound is made, the formation of the feminine is produced by the addition of the syllable ya, and so on.

original: Cakkhusotaṃ, he cakkhusota, cakkhusotaṃ, cakkhusotena. Evaṃ sabbatthekavacanameva.🔽Mukhañca nāsikā ca mukhanāsikaṃ, “saro rasso napuṃsake”ti antassa rassattaṃ, hanu
analyzed: cakkhu sotam he cakkhu sota cakkhu sotam cakkhu sotena evam sabbattha ekavacanam eva  mukham ca nāsikā ca mukha nāsikam saraḥ rassaḥ napuṃsaka iti antassa rassattam hanu
translated: Eye and ear are cakkhusotaṃ, he cakkhusota, cakkhusotaṃ, cakkhusotena. So too in all the other instances.

original: ca gīvā ca hanugīvaṃ. Evaṃ kaṇṇanāsaṃ, pāṇipādaṃ, chavimaṃsalohitaṃ. Hatthapādā maṃsalohitānītiādīnaṃ
analyzed: ca gīvā ca hanu gīvam evam kaṇṇa nāsam pāṇi pādam chavi maṃsa lohitam hattha pādāḥ maṃsa lohitāni iti ādīnam
translated: Mouth and nose are mukhanāsikaṃ. The nasal sound is due to the nasal sound in the final syllable. Chin and neck are hanugīvaṃ. So too in the case of ear and nose, hand and foot, skin, flesh, and blood. But in the case of hand and foot, flesh and blood, etc.,

original: pana itarītarayogena siddhaṃ. Evaṃ pāṇyaṅgatthe.🔽Tūriyaṅgatthe gītañca vāditañca gītavāditaṃ, sammañca tāḷañca sammatāḷaṃ, sammanti🔽kaṃsatāḷaṃ. Tāḷanti hatthatāḷaṃ. Saṅkhe ca paṇavo ca ḍiṇḍimo ca, saṅkhā ca paṇavā
analyzed: panaḥ itarītara yogena siddham evam pāṇi aṅga tthe  tūriyaṅga tthe gītañca vāditañca gīta vāditam sammañca tāḷañca sammatāḷam  kaṃsa tāḷam tāḷanti hattha tāḷam saṅkhe ca paṇavo ca ḍiṇḍimo ca saṅkhā ca paṇavā
translated: the compound is established by the combination of the individual terms. So too in the case of the meaning of “limb of drinking.”🔽In the case of the meaning of “limb of music,” singing and playing are gītavāditaṃ. Clapping and beating are sammatāḷaṃ. Samman means

original: ca ḍaṃṇḍimā cāti vā saṅkhapaṇavaḍiṇḍimaṃ, paṇavādayo dvepi bheriviseso.
analyzed: ca ḍaṃṇḍimā ca ati vā saṅkha paṇava ḍiṇḍimam paṇava ādayaḥ dve api bherī visesaḥ
translated: a metal clapper. Tāḷa means hand-clapping. Conch and drum and tabor are saṅkhā paṇavā ḍiṇḍimaṃ. Paṇavā and ḍiṇḍima are two kinds of drum.

original: Yoggaṅgatthe yathā – phālo ca pācanañca phālapācanaṃ, yugañca naṅgalañca yuganaṅgalaṃ.
analyzed: yoggaṅga tthe yathā phālo ca pācanam ca phālapācanam yugam ca naṅgalam ca yuganaṅgalam
translated: In the case of the meaning of “limb of yoking,” yoke and plough are phālapācanaṃ. Pair and plough are yuganaṅgalaṃ.

original: Senaṅgatthe hatthino ca assā ca hatthiassaṃ, rathā ca pattikā ca rathapattikaṃ, asi
analyzed: senaṅgatthe hatthinaḥ ca assā ca hatthi assam rathā ca pattikā ca ratha pattikam asi
translated: In the sense of army, elephant and horse are elephant-horse, chariot and infantry are chariot-infantry, sword🔽

original: ca cammañca asicammaṃ, cammanti saravāraṇaphalakaṃ. Dhanu ca kalāpo ca dhanukalāpaṃ, kalāpoti tūṇīraṃ.
analyzed: ca cammam ca asi cammam cammanti saravāraṇa phalakam dhanu ca kalāpo ca dhanu kalāpam kalāpo ti tūṇīram
translated: As to the meaning of army: elephants and horses are elephant-horse ; chariots and infantry are chariot- infantry ; swords and shields are sword-shield ; shields are shields of leather from the fence-row. Bows and arrows are bow-arrow ; arrows are reed arrows.

original: Khuddajantukatthe ḍaṃsā ca makasā ca ḍaṃsamakasaṃ. Evaṃ kunthakipillikaṃ, kīṭapaṭaṅgaṃ, kīṭasarīsapaṃ. Tattha kunthā sukhumakipillikā, kīṭā kapālapiṭṭhikapāṇā.
analyzed: khudda jantukatthe ḍaṃsā ca makasā ca ḍaṃsa makasam evam kuntha kipillikam kīṭa paṭaṅgam kīṭa sarīsapam tattha kunthā sukhuma kipillikā kīṭā kapāla piṭṭhika pāṇā
translated: As to the meaning of small creatures: gadflies and flies are gadfly-fly ; … gnats and mosquitoes are gnat-mosquito ; … worms and ants are worm-ant ; … insects and moths are insect-moth ; … caterpillars and locusts are caterpillar-locust. Herein, worms are small creatures that live in the ground; ants are those that live in anthills; insects are those that live in rottenness; moths are those that live in flour.

original: Vividhaviruddhatthe ahi ca nakulo ca, ahī ca nakulā cāti vā ahinakulaṃ. Evaṃ biḷāramūsikaṃ, antassa rassattaṃ, kākolūkaṃ, sappamaṇḍūkaṃ, garuḷasappaṃ.
analyzed: vividha viruddha atthe ahi ca nakulaḥ ca ahī ca nakulā ca ati vā ahi nakulam evam biḷāra mūsikam antassa rassattam kāka ulūkam sappa maṇḍūkam garuḷa sappam
translated: As to the meaning of various and opposed: snakes and mongooses are snake-mongoose ; … cats and mice are cat-mouse ; … the inside and the outside are inside-outside ; … crows and owls are crow-owl ; … snakes and frogs are snake-frog ; … garuḍas and snakes are garuḍa-snake.

original: Visabhāgatthe sīlañca paññāṇañca sīlapaññāṇaṃ, samatho ca vipassanā ca samathavipassanaṃ.
analyzed: visabhāga atthe sīlam ca paññāṇam ca sīla paññāṇam samathaḥ ca vipassanā ca samatha vipassanam
translated: As to the meaning of virtue and understanding are virtue-understanding ; … serenity and insight are serenity-insight.

original: Evaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, hirottappaṃ. Satisampajaññaṃ, lobhamohaṃ, dosamohaṃ, ahirikānottappaṃ,
analyzed: evam nāma rūpam hirā uttappam sati sampajaññam lobha moham dosa moham ahirika anottappam
translated: As to the meaning of name-and-form ; … shame and fear of wrongdoing ; … mindfulness and full awareness ; … greed and delusion ; … hate and delusion ; … lack of shame and lack of fear of wrongdoing ;

original: thinamiddhaṃ, uddhaccakukkuccamiccādi. “Aṃmo niggahītaṃ jhalapehī”ti ettha “aṃmo”ti
analyzed: thinam iddham uddhacca kukkuccam iccādi aṃmaḥ niggahītam jha l apehi iti ettha aṃmaḥ ti
translated: and drowsiness and torpor, agitation and worry, etc. In the passage “The snare is seized, throw it away,” the word “snare”

original: niddesadassanato katthaci napuṃsakaliṅgattaṃ na hotīti daṭṭhabbaṃ, tena ādhipaccaparivāro
analyzed: niddesa dassanato katthaci napuṃsaka liṅga ttam na hoti iti daṭṭhabbam tena ādhipacca parivāro
translated: is a neuter noun. But this does not mean that it is always a neuter noun. Therefore the phrase “the retinue of the overlord”

original: chandapārisuddhi paṭisandhippavattiyantiādi sijjhati.
translated: and the phrase “the purification of virtue, the purification of the mind, the purification of view” are correct.

original: Aññoññaliṅgavisesitānaṃ dvande dāsī ca dāso ca dāsidāsaṃ, “kvacādī”tiādinā majjhe rassattaṃ. Evaṃ itthipumaṃ, pattacīvaraṃ, sākhāpalāsamiccādi.
analyzed: dvande dāsī ca dāso ca dāsi dāsam kvac ādi iti ādinā majjhe rassa ttam evam itthi pumam patta cīvaram sākhā palāsam iccādi
translated: In a dvanda compound consisting of words of different genders, the neuter gender is used in the middle. Thus dāsī ca dāso ca = dāsidāsaṃ, “kvacādī” = kvacana, etc. Thus itthipum = itthipum, pattacīvara = pattacīvara, sākhāpalāsa = sākhāpalāsa, etc.

original: Saṅkhyāparimāṇatthānaṃ dvande ekakañca dukañca ekakadukaṃ, saṅkhyādvande appasaṅkhyā
analyzed: saṅkhyā parimāṇa tthānam dvande ekakam ca dukam ca ekaka dukam saṅkhyā dvande appa saṅkhyā
translated: In a dvanda compound consisting of words denoting number, measure, and place, the first member is used in the neuter. Thus ekakañca dukañca = ekakadukaṃ, saṅkhyādvande appasaṅkhyā = appasaṅkhyā.

original: pubbaṃ nipatati. Evaṃ dukatikaṃ, tikacatukkaṃ, catukkapañcakaṃ, dīgho ca majjhimo ca dīghamajjhimaṃ.
analyzed: pubbam nipatati evam duka tikam tika catukkam catukka pañcakam dīghaḥ ca majjhimaḥ ca dīgha majjhimam
translated: Thus dutikañca tikañca = dutikaṭṭhaṃ, catukkañca pañcakañca = catukkapañcakaṃ, dīgho ca majjhimo ca = dīghamajjhimaṃ, etc.

original: Pacanacaṇḍālatthānaṃ dvande orabbhikā ca sūkarikā ca orabbhikasūkarikaṃ. Evaṃ sākuṇikamāgavikaṃ,
analyzed: pacana caṇḍālatthānam dvande orabbhikā ca sūkarikā ca orabbhika sūkarikam evam sākuṇika māgavikam
translated: In a dvanda compound consisting of words denoting cooking and a slave, the first member is used in the neuter. Thus orabbhikā ca sūkarikā ca = orabbhikasūkarikaṃ. Thus sākuṇikamāgavikaṃ, etc.

original: sapāko ca caṇḍālo ca sapākacaṇḍālaṃ, pukkusachavaḍāhakaṃ, venarathakāraṃ. Tattha
analyzed: sa pākaḥ ca caṇḍālo ca sa pāka caṇḍālam pukkusa chava ḍāhakam vena rathakāram tattha
translated: And the “half-caste” and the “outcaste” are the “half-caste-outcaste” . The “pig-keeper” and the “washerman” are the “pig-keeper-washerman” . The “weaver” and the “chariot-maker” are the “weaver-chariot-maker” . Herein,

original: venā tacchakā, rathakārā cammakārā.
analyzed: venā tad śakā rathakārā cammakārā
translated: the “weaver” is the one who weaves with thread, and the “chariot-maker” is the one who makes chariots.

original: Disatthānaṃ dvande pubbā ca aparā cāti atthe dvandasamāsaṃ, vibhattilopañca katvā
analyzed: disa tthānam dvande pubbā ca aparā ca ati atthe dvanda samāsam vibhatti lopam ca katvā
translated: The “east” and the “west” are the “east-west” in the sense of a dvanda compound. The case-ending and the vowel-sandhi have been made.

original: idhādiggahaṇena ekatte, napuṃsakaliṅgatte ca kate “saro rasso napuṃsake”ti rassattaṃ,
analyzed: idha ādi gahaṇena eka tte napuṃsaka liṅga tte ca kate saraḥ rassaḥ napuṃsaka iti rassattam
translated: Herein, the singleness and the neuter gender have been made by the word “etc.” . The sandhi has been made by the rule “Saro rasso napuṃsake” .

original: pubbāparaṃ, he pubbāpara, pubbāparaṃ, pubbāparena, pubbāparassa iccādi. Evaṃ puratthimapacchimaṃ,
analyzed: pubba aparam he pubba apara pubba aparam pubba aparena pubba aparassa iccādi evam puratthima pacchimam
translated: The “east-west” , the “east-west” , the “east-west” , the “east-west” , the “east-west” , etc. Likewise the “north-south” ,

original: dakkhiṇuttaraṃ, adharuttaraṃ.
analyzed: dakkhiṇa uttaram adhas uttaram
translated: the “south-north” , the “north-south” , etc.

original: “Napuṃsakaliṅgaṃ, ekattaṃ, dvande”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: napuṃsaka liṅgam ekattam dvandeti ca vattate
translated: The singleness and the neuter gender are stated.

original: 360. Vibhāsā rukkha tiṇa pasu dhana dhañña janapadādīnañca.
analyzed: vibhāsā rukkha tiṇa pasu dhana dhañña janapada ādīnam ca
translated: . The singleness and the neuter gender of trees, grass, cattle, wealth, grain, country, etc., are stated by analysis.

original: Rukkha tiṇa pasu dhana dhañña janapadādīnamekattaṃ, napuṃsakaliṅgattañca vibhāsā hoti dvande samāse. Ekattābhāve bahuvacanaṃ, parasseva liṅgañca.
analyzed: rukkha tiṇa pasu dhana dhañña janapada ādīnam ekattam napuṃsaka liṅga ttam ca vibhāsā hoti dvande samāse ekatta abhāve bahuvacanam parassa iva liṅgam ca
translated: The singleness and the neuter gender of trees, grass, cattle, wealth, grain, country, etc., are stated by analysis in a dvanda compound. In the absence of singleness, the plural is used, and the gender is that of the last member only.

original: Tattha rukkhānaṃ dvande assatthā ca kapitthā cāti atthe samāhāre dvandasamāsādimhi🔽kate iminā vikappenekattaṃ, napuṃsakaliṅgattañca. Assatthakapitthaṃ, assatthakapitthā🔽vā. Evaṃ ambapanasaṃ, ambapanasā vā, khadirapalāsaṃ, khadirapalāsā vā, dhavassakaṇṇakaṃ, dhavassakaṇṇakā vā.🔽Tiṇānaṃ dvande usīrāni ca bīraṇāni ca usīrabīraṇaṃ, usīrabīraṇāni vā. Evaṃ muñjapabbajaṃ, muñjapabbajā vā, kāsakusaṃ, kāsakusā vā.
analyzed: tattha rukkhānam dvande assatthā ca kapitthā ca ati atthe samāhāre dvanda samāsa ādimhi  kate iminā vikappena ekattam napuṃsaka liṅga ttam ca assattha kapittham assattha kapitthā  vā evam amba panasam amba panasāḥ vā khadira palāsam khadira palāsāḥ vā dhavassakaṇṇakam dhavassakaṇṇakāḥ vā  tiṇānam dvande usīrāni ca bīraṇāni ca usīra bīraṇam usīra bīraṇāni vā evam muñja pabbajam muñja pabbajāḥ vā kāsakusam kāsakusāḥ vā
translated: Herein, in the case of the pair of trees, assattha and kapittha, the compound is a dvanda,🔽and when that is made, there is the singleness of the two and the neuter gender. Either assatthakapitthaṃ or assatthakapitthā. So too, ambapanasaṃ or ambapanasā, khadirapalāsaṃ or khadirapalāsā, dhavassakaṇṇakaṃ or dhavassakaṇṇakā.

original: Pasūnaṃ dvande ajā ca eḷakā ca ajeḷakaṃ, ajeḷakā vā, hatthī ca gāvo ca assā ca vaḷavā🔽ca hatthigavassavaḷavaṃ, hatthigavassavaḷavā vā, “kvacā”tiādinā rassattaṃ, “osare
analyzed: pasūnam dvande ajā ca eḷakā ca ajeḷakam ajeḷakā vā hatthī ca gāvaḥ ca assā ca vaḷavā  ca hatthi gavassa vaḷavam hatthi gavassa vaḷavā vā kva ca ati ādinā rassa ttam osare
translated: In the case of the pair of grasses, usīra and bīraṇa, the compound is usīrabīraṇaṃ or usīrabīraṇāni. So too, muñjapabbajaṃ or muñjapabbajā, kāsakusaṃ or kāsakusā.

original: cā”ti avādeso ca, gomahiṃsaṃ, gomahiṃsā vā, eṇeyyavarāhaṃ, eṇeyyavarāhā vā, sīhabyagghataracchaṃ,🔽sīhabyagghataracchā vā.
analyzed: ca ati ca go mahiṃsam go mahiṃsāḥ vā eṇeyya varāham eṇeyya varāhāḥ vā sīha byaggha taraccham 🔽sīha byaggha taracchāḥ vā
translated: In the case of the pair of animals, ajā and eḷakā, the compound is ajeḷakaṃ or ajeḷakā. So too, hatthigavassavaḷavaṃ or hatthigavassavaḷavā. In the case of the pair of animals, go and mahiṃsa, the compound is gomahiṃsaṃ or gomahiṃsā. So too, eṇeyyavarāhaṃ or eṇeyyavarāhā, sīhabyagghataracchaṃ or sīhabyagghataracchā.

original: Dhanānaṃ dvande hiraññañca suvaṇṇañca hiraññasuvaṇṇaṃ, hiraññasuvaṇṇāni vā. Evaṃ jātarūparajataṃ, jātarūparajatāni vā, maṇimuttasaṅkhaveḷuriyaṃ, maṇimuttasaṅkhaveḷuriyā vā.
analyzed: dhanānam dvande hiraññam ca suvaṇṇam ca hirañña suvaṇṇam hirañña suvaṇṇāni vā evam jātarūpa rajatam jātarūpa rajatāni vā maṇi mutta saṅkha veḷuriyam maṇi mutta saṅkha veḷuriyāḥ vā
translated: Gold and silver are gold and silver, or gold and silver. So too, gold and silver are gold and silver, or gold and silver. Pearl and crystal and cat’s eye and coral are pearl and crystal and cat’s eye and coral, or pearl and crystal and cat’s eye and coral.

original: Dhaññānaṃ dvande sālī ca yavā ca sāliyavaṃ, sāliyavā vā. Evaṃ tilamuggamāsaṃ, tilamuggamāsā vā.
analyzed: dhaññānam dvande sālī ca yavā ca sāli yavam sāli yavāḥ vā evam tila mugga māsam tila mugga māsāḥ vā
translated: Rice and barley are rice and barley, or rice and barley. So too, sesamum and beans are sesamum and beans, or sesamum and beans.

original: Janapadānaṃ dvande kāsī ca kosalā ca kāsikosalaṃ, kāsikosalā vā, vajjī ca mallā ca vajjimallaṃ, vajjimallā vā, aṅgā ca magadhā ca aṅgamagadhaṃ, aṅgamagadhā vā.
analyzed: janapadānam dvande kāsī ca kosalā ca kāsi kosalam kāsi kosalāḥ vā vajjī ca mallā ca vajji mallam vajji mallāḥ vā aṅgā ca magadhā ca aṅga magadham aṅga magadhāḥ vā
translated: Kāsī and Kosala are Kāsī and Kosala, or Kāsī and Kosala. So too, Vajjī and Malla are Vajjī and Malla, or Vajjī and Malla. Aṅga and Magadha are Aṅga and Magadha, or Aṅga and Magadha.

original: Ādiggahaṇena aññoññappaṭipakkhadhammānaṃ, sakuṇatthānañca dvande vibhāsā ekattaṃ🔽hoti, napuṃsakaliṅgattañca. Kusalañca akusalañca kusalākusalaṃ, kusalākusalā vā,
analyzed: ādi ggahaṇena añña uñña ppaṭipakkha dhammānam sakuṇatthānam ca dvande vibhāsāḥ ekattam  hoti napuṃsaka liṅga ttam ca kusalam ca akusalam ca kusala akusalam kusala akusalāḥ vā
translated: By the word “etc.,” the inclusion of other opposite things in pairs, and of birds, is shown.🔽The state of being singular and the state of being neuter are also included. The profitable and the unprofitable are the profitable and the unprofitable, or the profitable and the unprofitable.

original: evaṃ sāvajjānavajjaṃ, sāvajjānavajjā vā, hīnappaṇītaṃ, hīnappaṇītā vā, kaṇhasukkaṃ,
analyzed: evam sāvajja anavajjam sāvajja anavajjāḥ vā hīna ppaṇītam hīna ppaṇītāḥ vā kaṇha sukkam
translated: So too, the blameworthy and the blameless are the blameworthy and the blameless, or the blameworthy and the blameless. The low and the refined are the low and the refined, or the low and the refined. The dark and the bright are

original: kaṇhasukkā vā, sukhadukkhaṃ, sukhadukkhāni vā, paṭighānunayaṃ, paṭighānunayā vā,🔽chāyātapaṃ, chāyātapā vā, ālokandhakāraṃ, ālokandhakārā vā, ratti ca divā ca rattindivaṃ,🔽rattindivā vā, ahañca ratti ca ahorattaṃ, ahorattā vā, “kvaci samāsanta”iccādinā ākārikārānamattaṃ.
analyzed: kaṇhasukkāḥ vā sukha dukkham sukha dukkhāni vā paṭigha anunayam paṭigha anunayāḥ vā  chāyā ātapam chāyā ātapāḥ vā āloka ndhakāram āloka ndhakārāḥ vā ratti ca divā ca rattindivam  vā ahan ca ratti ca ahorattam ahorattāḥ vā kvaci
translated: Or black and white, or pleasure and pain, or pleasure and pain, or resentment and affection, or resentment and affection,

original: Sakuṇānaṃ dvande haṃsā ca bakā ca haṃsabakaṃ, haṃsabakā vā. Evaṃ kāraṇḍavacakkavākaṃ, kāraṇḍavacakkavākā vā, mayūrakoñcaṃ, mayūrakoñcā vā, sukasālikaṃ, sukasālikā vā.🔽Samāhāradvando.🔽Yebhuyyena cettha –🔽Accitappasaraṃ pubbaṃ, ivaṇṇuvaṇṇakaṃ kvaci;🔽Dvande sarādyakārantaṃ, bahūsvaniyamo bhave.🔽Dvandasamāso niṭṭhito.🔽Pubbuttarubhayaññattha-ppadhānattā catubbidho;🔽Samāsoyaṃ digu kamma-dhārayehi ca chabbidho.
analyzed: sakuṇānam dvande haṃsā ca bakā ca haṃsa bakam haṃsa bakāḥ vā evam kāraṇḍava cakkavākam kāraṇḍava cakkavākāḥ vā mayūra koñcam mayūra koñcāḥ vā sukasālikam sukasālikāḥ vā 🔽samāhāra dvando 🔽yebhuyyena cettha 🔽a c c ita ppasaram pubbam i vaṇṇu vaṇṇakam kvaci 🔽dvande sara ādi akāra antam bahu sva niyamaḥ bhave 🔽dvanda samāsaḥ niṭṭhito 🔽catubbidhaḥ 🔽samāsaḥ iyam kammadhārayehi ca chabbidhaḥ
translated: Or shade and sunshine, or shade and sunshine, or light and darkness, or light and darkness, or night and day, or night and day, or I and night, or I and night, or I and day, or I and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or night and day, or

original: Duvidho abyayībhāvo, navadhā kammadhārayo;🔽Digu dudhā tappuriso, aṭṭhadhā navadhā bhave;
analyzed: duvidhaḥ abyayībhāvaḥ navadhā kammadhārayaḥ  tappurisaḥ aṭṭhadhā navadhā bhave
translated: The indeclinable compound is of two kinds, the copulative compound of nine kinds,🔽The appositional compound is of two kinds, the taddhita compound of nine kinds,

original: Bahubbīhi dvidhā dvando, samāso caturaṭṭhadhāti.🔽Iti padarūpasiddhiyaṃ samāsakaṇḍo🔽Catuttho.
analyzed: bahup bīhi dvidhā dvandaḥ samāsaḥ catur aṭṭhadhā ti  iti  catutthaḥ
translated: The dvanda compound is of two kinds, the tatpurisa compound of eight kinds, the bahubbīhi compound is of two kinds, the karmadhāraya compound is of nine kinds, the tappurisa compound is of two kinds, the dvanda compound is of two kinds, the samāsa is of thirty-two kinds.🔽Thus ends the chapter on compounds in the Pali grammar called “The Great Commentary”.

original: 5. Taddhitakaṇḍa
analyzed: taddhita kaṇḍa
translated: . The chapter on taddhita

original: Apaccataddhita🔽Atha nāmato eva vibhatyantā apaccādiatthavisese taddhituppattīti nāmato paraṃ taddhitavidhānamārabhīyate.
analyzed: a pad ca taddhita  atha nāmataḥ eva vibhati antāḥ a pacca ādi attha visese taddhita uppattī iti nāmataḥ param taddhita vidhānam ārabhīyate
translated: Appositional taddhita🔽Now, from a noun, by means of a case-ending, there is the formation of a taddhita in the sense of appositional and so on. Therefore, the method of forming taddhitās is begun after a noun.

original: Tattha tasmā tividhaliṅgato paraṃ hutvā hitā sahitāti taddhitā, ṇādipaccayānametaṃ
analyzed: tattha tasmā tividha liṅgataḥ param hutvā hitā sahitā ati taddhitā ṇa ādi paccayānam etam
translated: Herein, it is a taddhita because it is formed by being added to a noun of three genders. This is a designation for the suffixes beginning with ṇ.

original: adhivacanaṃ, tesaṃ vā nāmikānaṃ hitā upakārā taddhitāti anvatthabhūtaparasamaññāvasenāpi
analyzed: adhivacanam tesam vā nāmikānam hitāḥ upakārā taddhitā ati anvattha bhūta para samaññā vasena api
translated: Or, because it is a help, a benefit, to the nouns, it is a taddhita. This is a designation for the other, the dependent, in the sense of a subsequent state.

original: ṇādippaccayāva taddhitā nāma.
analyzed: taddhitāḥ nāma
translated: The suffixes beginning with ṇ are called taddhitās.

original: “Vasiṭṭhassa apacca”nti viggahe –
analyzed: vasiṭṭhassa a paccanti viggahe
translated: In the analysis “Vasiṭṭha’s apacca”

original: “Liṅgañca nipaccate”ti ito liṅgaggahaṇamanuvattate.
analyzed: liṅgam ca iti itas liṅga ggahaṇam anuvattate
translated: the taking of the gender is repeated from here “And the gender is contracted”.

original: 361. Vā ṇa’pacce.
analyzed: vā ṇa pacce
translated: . Vā ṇa’pacce.

original: Chaṭṭhiyantato liṅgamhā ṇappaccayo hoti vikappena “tassa apacca”miccetasmiṃ atthe.
analyzed: chaṭṭhiya antataḥ liṅgamhā ṇap paccayaḥ hoti vikappena tassa a paccam iti itasmin atthe
translated: The sixth-case form of a noun has the affix ṇapaccaya optionally in the sense of ‘not that’ .

original: So ca –
analyzed: saḥ ca
translated: And that is

original: 362. Dhātuliṅgehi parā paccayā.
analyzed: dhātu liṅgehi parā paccayā
translated: . The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.

original: Dhātūhi, liṅgehi ca paccayā parāva hontīti paribhāsato apaccatthasambandhiliṅgato
analyzed: dhātūhi liṅgehi ca paccayā honti iti paribhāsataḥ apaccattha sambandhi liṅgato
translated: The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.

original: chaṭṭhiyantāyeva paro hoti. Paṭicca etasmā attho etīti paccayo, patīyanti anena atthāti🔽vā paccayo, “vuttatthānamappayogo”ti apaccasaddassa appayogo, “tesaṃ vibhattiyo lopā
analyzed: chaṭṭhiyantāya iva paraḥ hoti paṭicca etasmai atthaḥ eti iti paccayaḥ patīyanti anena atthā ati  vā paccayaḥ vutta tthānam appayogo ti apacca saddassa appayogo tesam vibhattiyaḥ lopā
translated: The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.

original: ce”ti vibhattilopo ca.🔽363. Tesaṃ ṇo lopaṃ.
analyzed: ca iti vibhatti lopaḥ ca  tesam ṇaḥ lopam
translated: The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.

original: Tesaṃ taddhitappaccayānaṃ ṇānubandhānaṃ ṇakāro lopamāpajjate.🔽364. Vuddhādisarassa vāsaṃyogantassa saṇe ca.
analyzed: tesam taddhita ppaccayānam ṇa anubandhānam ṇakāraḥ lopam āpajjate  vuddha ādi sarassa vā a saṃyoga antassa sa ṇe ca
translated: The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.

original: Ādisarassa vā ādibyañjanassa vā asaṃyogantassa vuddhi hoti saṇakārappaccaye pare.
analyzed: ādi sarassa vā ādi byañjanassa vā a saṃyoga antassa hoti sa ṇa kāra ppaccaye pare
translated: The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.🔽The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.

original: Saṃyogo anto assāti saṃyoganto, tadañño asaṃyoganto. Atha vā vavatthitavibhāsatthoyaṃ
analyzed: saṃyogaḥ antaḥ assa ati saṃyoga antaḥ tad aññaḥ a saṃyoga antaḥ atha vā vavatthita vibhāsa atthaḥ yaṃ
translated: The other is a condition by the bases and the genders.

original: vāsaddo, tadā ca pakatibhūte liṅge sarānamādisarassa asaṃyogantassa vuddhi hoti saṇakāre
analyzed: vā saddaḥ tadā ca pakati bhūte liṅge a saṃyoga antassa hoti sa ṇakāre
translated: The word “vā” is in the natural gender. And then there is the augment “ā” to the root “ra” which is not compounded.

original: taddhitappaccaye pareti attho.
analyzed: taddhita ppaccaye parā iti atthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: “in the case of the verbal noun ending in ‘ā’”.

original: Tena –🔽Vāsiṭṭhādīsu niccāyaṃ, aniccoḷumpikādisu;
analyzed: tena  vāsiṭṭha ādīsu nicca ayam anicca uḷumpika ādisu
translated: Therefore –🔽In Vāsiṭṭha, etc., it is certain; in Anicca, Ūlampikā, etc., it is not certain.

original: Na vuddhi nīlapītādo, vavatthitavibhāsato.
analyzed: na
translated: There is no augment in Nīla, Pīta, etc., because of the delimitation of the vibhattis.

original: Casaddaggahaṇamavadhāraṇatthaṃ.
analyzed: casad dak gahaṇam avadhāraṇa attham
translated: The word “ca” is for the purpose of restriction.

original: Tassā vuddhiyā aniyamappasaṅge niyamatthaṃ paribhāsamāha.
analyzed: tassāḥ vuddhiyāḥ aniyama ppasaṅge niyama attham paribhāsam āha
translated: In the event of the non-restriction of that augment, for the purpose of restriction, the author of the Paribhāṣā says:

original: 365. Ayuvaṇṇānañcāyo vuddhī.
analyzed: ayu vaṇ ṇa an ca ayaḥ vuddhī
translated: And the augment “ā” to “ayu” and “vaṇṇa”.

original: Tesaṃ akāraivaṇṇuvaṇṇānameva yathākkamaṃ ā eoiccete vuddhiyo honti. Casaddaggahaṇamavuddhisampiṇḍanatthaṃ,
analyzed: tesam yathākkamam ā e o it ca ite vuddhiyaḥ honti ca sadda ggahaṇam a vuddhi sampiṇḍana ttham
translated: To those two roots “akāra” and “vaṇṇa”, there are respectively the augmentations “ā”, “e”, and “i”. The word “ca” is for the purpose of including the non-augmentations,

original: avadhāraṇatthaṃ vā. I ca u ca yu, yu eva vaṇṇā yuvaṇṇā, a ca yuvaṇṇā ca ayuvaṇṇā.
analyzed: avadhāraṇa attham vā i ca u ca yu yu eva vaṇṇā yuvaṇṇā a ca yuvaṇṇā ca a yuvaṇṇā
translated: or for the purpose of restriction. “I” and “u” and “yu”, “yu” only is “vaṇṇa”, “yuvaṇṇa”. “A” and “yuvaṇṇa” are “ayuvaṇṇa”.

original: Ā ca e ca o ca āyo. Puna vuddhiggahaṇaṃ “negamajānapadā”tiādīsu uttarapadavuddhibhāvatthaṃ,
analyzed: ā ca e ca o ca āyo puna vuddhi ggahaṇam negama jānapadāti ādīsu uttara pada vuddhi bhāva ttham
translated: “Ā” and “e” and “o” are “āyo”. The repetition of the word “vuddhi” is for the purpose of showing that it is the augmentation of the second member in such words as “negamajānapadā”.

original: ettha ca “ayuvaṇṇāna”nti ṭhānaniyamavacanaṃ āyonaṃ vuddhibhāvappasaṅganivattanatthaṃ.
analyzed: ettha ca ayuvaṇṇānam ti ṭhāna niyama vacanam vuddhi bhāva pasaṅga nivattana attham
translated: And here the words “ayuvaṇṇāna” are for the purpose of restricting the place, for the purpose of preventing the possibility of the augmentations of the “āyas”.

original: Yathā hi katavuddhīnaṃ, puna vuddhi na hotiha;
analyzed: yathā hi kata vuddhīnam punar
translated: Just as those who have attained understanding do not attain it again,

original: Tathā sabhāvavuddhīnaṃ, āyonaṃ puna vuddhi na.🔽Tato akārassa ākāro vuddhi, “saralopomādesappaccayādimhi saralope tu pakatī”ti saralopapakatibhāvā,
analyzed: tathā  tatas akārassa ākāraḥ sara lopa umā desa ppaccaya ādimhi sara lope tu pakatī iti sara lopa pakati bhāvā
translated: So too those who have attained by nature do not attain again.🔽Then the vowel a of the first syllable is lengthened, and because of the omission of the final of the first syllable and the substitution of the vowel i, it becomes Vāsīṭṭha.

original: “naye paraṃ yutte”ti paranayanaṃ katvā taddhitattā “taddhitasamāsa”iccādinā nāmabyapadese
analyzed: naye param yuttā iti para nayanam katvā taddhita ttā taddhita samāsa e c ca ādinā nāma byapadese
translated: Then, because of the addition of the taddhita affix -ya, the compound is called a “taddhita compound” in the rule beginning “taddhita compounds, etc.”

original: kate pure viya syādyuppatti.
analyzed: kate pure
translated: Then the s-prefix is added, as in the original, and the i-vowel is lengthened.

original: Vāsiṭṭho, vasiṭṭhassa putto vā, vāsiṭṭhā iccādi purisasaddasamaṃ. Tassa nattupanattādayopi
analyzed: vāsiṭṭhaḥ vasiṭṭhassa puttaḥ vā vāsiṭṭhāḥ iccādi purisa sadda samam tassa nattu upanatta ādayaḥ api
translated: The word Vāsīṭṭha is the same as the masculine word Vāsīṭṭha, the son of Vāsīṭṭha. Because of the absence of the feminine ending -ī,

original: tadupacārato vāsiṭṭhāyeva. Evaṃ sabbattha gottataddhite paṭhamappakatitoyeva paccayo hoti.🔽Itthiyaṃ ṇappaccayantattā “ṇava ṇika ṇeyya ṇa ntūhī”ti vāsiṭṭhasaddato īpaccayo.
analyzed: tad upacārataḥ vā asiṭṭhāya iva evam sabbattha gotta taddhite paṭhama ppakatito yeva paccayaḥ hoti  itthiyam ṇap paccaya nta ttā ṇava ṇika ṇeyya ṇa vā siṭṭha saddataḥ ī paccayaḥ
translated: it is called Vāsīṭṭhā by extension. Thus in all cases, the first syllable is the basis for the feminine taddhita affix.🔽In the feminine, because of the absence of the taddhita affix -ī, the i-vowel is added to the word Vāsīṭṭha by the rule beginning “ṇava ṇika ṇeyya ṇa ntūhī”.

original: Saralopādiṃ katvā itthippaccayantattā “taddhitasamāsa”iccādisutte caggahaṇena nāmabyapadese
analyzed: sara lopa ādim katvā taddhita samāsa e c ca ādi sutte ca ggahaṇena nāma byapadese
translated: Then, after the omission of the final, etc., the feminine ending is added, and because of the addition of the taddhita affix -ī, the compound is called a “taddhita compound” in the rule beginning “taddhita compounds, etc.” In the feminine noun declension,

original: kate syādyuppatti, vāsiṭṭhī kaññā, vāsiṭṭhī, vāsiṭṭhiyo iccādi itthisaddasamaṃ.
analyzed: kate sī ādi uppatti vāsiṭṭhī kaññā vāsiṭṭhī vāsiṭṭhiyaḥ iccādi itthi sadda samam
translated: In the feminine: Vāsiṭṭhī kaññā, Vāsiṭṭhī, Vāsiṭṭhiyo.🔽In the neuter: Vāsiṭṭhaṃ apaccaṃ, Vāsiṭṭhāni apaccāni.

original: Napuṃsake vāsiṭṭhaṃ apaccaṃ, vāsiṭṭhāni apaccāni iccādi cittasaddasamaṃ. Evaṃ uparipi taddhitantassa tiliṅgatā veditabbā.
analyzed: napuṃsake vāsiṭṭham apaccam vāsiṭṭhāni apaccāni iccādi citta sadda samam evam upari pi taddhita antassa ti liṅga tā veditabbā
translated: In the same way the neuter ending should be understood in the other derivatives.

original: Bhāradvājassa putto bhāradvājo, vesāmittassa putto vesāmitto, gotamassa putto gotamo.
analyzed: bhāradvājassa puttaḥ bhāradvājaḥ vesāmittassa puttaḥ vesāmittaḥ gotamassa puttaḥ gotamaḥ
translated: Bhāradvājo, Vesāmitto, Gotamo.

original: Ettha ca ayuvaṇṇattābhāvā ākārādīnaṃ na vuddhi hoti. Vasudevassa apaccaṃ vāsudevo,
