analyzed: ettha ca ākāra ādīnam na hoti vasudevassa apaccam vāsudevaḥ
translated: And here, because there is no difference of age or sex, there is no augmentation of the vowel and so on. Vāsudevo, Baladevo.

original: baladevo. “Cittako”tiādīsu pana saṃyogantattā vuddhi na bhavati.
analyzed: pana na bhavati
translated: But in the words Cittako, etc., there is no augmentation because of the affix.

original: “Vacchassa apacca”nti viggahe ṇamhi sampatte “vā ṇa’pacce”ti ito vāti taddhitavidhāne
analyzed: vacchassa a paccanti viggahe ṇamhi sampatte vā ṇa pacca iti i taḥ vā ati taddhita vidhāne
translated: But in the analysis of the word Vacchassa apacca, when the ṇam affix is reached, the rule “vā ṇa’pacce” (Pāṇini 1.1.58) is applied,

original: sabbattha vattate, tena sabbattha vākyavuttiyo bhavanti. “Apacce”ti padaṃ yāva saṃsaṭṭhaggahaṇāva vattate.
analyzed: sabbattha vattate tena sabbattha vākya vuttiyaḥ bhavanti padam yāva vattate
translated: and so the derivative is formed with the vati affix in all cases. The word apacca is used as long as the compound is not taken as a dvanda compound.

original: 366. Ṇāyana ṇāna vacchādito.
analyzed: vacchādito
translated: The ṇāyana and ṇāna affixes are added to Vaccha, etc.

original: Vaccha kaccaiccevamādito chaṭṭhiyantato gottagaṇato ṇāyana ṇānaiccate paccayā honti🔽vā “tassāpacca”miccetasmiṃ atthe. Sabbattha ṇakārānubandho vuddhattho, sesaṃ pubbasamaṃ,🔽saṃyogantattā vuddhiabhāvova viseso.🔽Vacchāyano vacchāno vacchassa putto vā. Evaṃ kaccassa putto kaccāyano kaccāno, moggallassa🔽putto moggallāyano moggallāno. Evaṃ aggivessāyano aggivessāno, kaṇhāyano kaṇhāno,
analyzed: vaccha kacca ecca ivamāditaḥ chaṭṭhiyantataḥ gotta gaṇataḥ paccayāḥ honti  vā tassā paccam iti etasmin atthe sabbattha ṇakāra anubandhaḥ vuddha atthaḥ sesam pubba samam  visesaḥ  vacchāyanaḥ vacchānaḥ vacchassa putto vai evam kaccassa putto kaccāyanaḥ kaccānaḥ moggallassa  puttaḥ moggallāyanaḥ moggallānaḥ evam aggivessāyanaḥ aggivessāno kaṇhāyanaḥ kaṇhāno
translated: Vaccha, Kacca, etc., are the names of clans.

original: sākaṭāyano sākaṭāno, muñcāyano muñcāno, kuñjāyano kuñjāno iccādi. Ākatigaṇo’yaṃ.🔽“Kattikāya apacca”nti viggahe –🔽367. Ṇeyyo kattikādīhi.🔽Ādisaddoyaṃ pakāre vattate. Kattikā vinatārohiṇīiccevamādīhi itthiyaṃ vattamānehi liṅgehi ṇeyyappaccayo hoti vā “tassāpacca”miccetasmiṃ atthe.
analyzed: sākaṭāyanaḥ sākaṭānaḥ muñcāyanaḥ muñcānaḥ kuñjāyanaḥ kuñjānaḥ iti ādi 🔽kattikāya a paccanti viggahe 🔽ṇeyyaḥ kattikā ādīhi 🔽ādi saddaḥ iyam pakāre vattate kattikā vinatā rohiṇī iti evamādīhi itthiyam vattamānehi liṅgehi hoti vā atthe
translated: The suffixes -āyana, -āno, -āyano, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -āyāna, -ā

original: Vibhattilope “pakati cassa sarantassā”ti pakatibhāvo. Kattikeyyo, kattikāya putto
analyzed: vibhatti lope pakati cassa sarantassa ati pakati bhāvaḥ kattikeyyaḥ kattikāya putto
translated: The state of being a base is that of the natural base, according to the rule: “The natural base is that of the vowel of the ending.” Kattikeyyo, Kattikāya putto.

original: vā. Evaṃ vinatāya apaccaṃ venateyyo, ikārassekāro vuddhi, rohiṇiyā putto rohiṇeyyo,
analyzed: vai evam vinatāya apaccam venateyyaḥ ikārassa ikāraḥ rohiṇiyāḥ puttaḥ rohiṇeyyaḥ
translated: So too: vinatāya apaccaṃ venateyyo. The i of ikā is elided. The o of rohiṇi is lengthened. Rohiṇeyyo.

original: gaṅgāya apaccaṃ gaṅgeyyo, bhaginiyā putto bhāgineyyo, nadiyāputto nādeyyo. Evaṃ anteyyo,
analyzed: gaṅgāya apaccam gaṅgeyyaḥ bhaginiyā putto bhāgineyyaḥ nadiyā puttaḥ nādeyyaḥ evam anteyyaḥ
translated: Gaṅgāya apaccaṃ gaṅgeyyo. Bhaginiyā putto bhāgineyyo. Nadiyā putto nādeyyo. So too: anteyyo,

original: āheyyo, kāmeyyo. Suciyā apaccaṃ soceyyo, ettha ukārassokāro vuddhi, bālāya apaccaṃ bāleyyo iccādi.
analyzed: āheyyaḥ kāmeyyaḥ suciyā apaccam soceyyaḥ ettha ukārassa ukāraḥ bālāya apaccam bāleyyaḥ iccādi
translated: āheyyo, kāmeyyo. Suciyā apaccaṃ soceyyo. Here the u of ukā is elided. The e of bālā is lengthened. Bāleyyo.

original: “Dakkhassāpacca”nti viggahe ṇamhi sampatte –
analyzed: viggahe ṇamhi sampatte
translated: “Dakkhassāpacca”nti viggahe ṇamhi sampatte—

original: 368. Ato ṇi vā.
analyzed: a taḥ ṇi vā
translated: . Ato ṇi vā.

original: Akārantato liṅgamhā ṇipaccayo hoti vā “tassāpacca”miccetasmiṃ atthe. Dakkhi, dakkhī,
analyzed: akāra antataḥ liṅgamhā ṇi paccayaḥ hoti vā tassā paccam iti itasmin atthe dakkhi dakkhī
translated: The affix ṇipaccayo is added to a feminine noun ending in a vowel, or not, in the sense of “the descendant of that.” Dakkhi, dakkhī,

original: dakkhayo, doṇassa apaccaṃ doṇi. Evaṃ vāsavi, sakyaputti, nāṭaputti, dāsaputti, dāsarathi.
analyzed: dakkhayaḥ doṇassa apaccam doṇi evam vāsavi sakyaputti nāṭaputti dāsaputti dāsarathi
translated: dakkhayo. Doṇassa apaccaṃ doṇi. So too: vāsavi, sakyaputti, nāṭaputti, dāsaputti, dāsarathi.

original: Vāruṇi, kaṇḍi, bāladevi, pāvaki, jinadattassa apaccaṃ jenadatti, suddhodani, anuruddhi iccādi.
analyzed: vāruṇi kaṇḍi bāladevi pāvaki jinadattassa apaccam jenadatti suddhodani anuruddhi iccādi
translated: Vāruṇi, kaṇḍi, bāladevi, pāvaki, jinadattassa apaccaṃ jenadatti, suddhodani, anuruddhi.

original: Puna vāggahaṇena apaccatthe ṇikappaccayo, aditiādito ṇyappaccayo ca. Yathā – sakyaputtassa
analyzed: puna vāc gahaṇena a paccatthe ṇika ppaccayaḥ aditi āditaḥ ṇya ppaccayaḥ ca yathā sakyaputtassa
translated: Or else, by the repetition of the word “after”, the ṇik-suffix is in the sense of “in return”, and the ṇy-suffix is in the sense of “from the beginning”. As in the case of “son of the Sakyans” (sakyaputta).🔽

original: putto sakyaputtiko, “tesu vuddhī”tiādinā kakārassa yakāro, sakyaputtiyo. Evaṃ nāṭaputtiko,
analyzed: putto sakyaputtiko tesu vuddhi iti ādinā kakārassa yakāraḥ sakyaputtiyaḥ evam nāṭaputtiko
translated: Or, by the repetition of the word “etc.”, the ṇik affix is in the sense of apaccayathe, and the ṇy affix is in the sense of adi. As follows: the son of a son of the Sakyans is a Sakyaputtiya . By the rule “In them the long is lengthened” the k becomes y, and so he is a Sakyaputtiyo. So too, a son of a Nāṭan is a Nāṭaputtiya .

original: jenadattiko, vimātuyā putto vemātiko.
analyzed: jenadattikaḥ vimātuyāḥ puttaḥ vemātikaḥ
translated: A son of a Jene is a Jenetiya . A son of a mother who is a Vima is a Vemattika .

original: “Aditiyā putto”ti atthe ṇyappaccayo, vuddhi ca.
analyzed: aditiyā putto ti atthe ṇyap paccayaḥ ca
translated: In the sense of “a son of Aditi” the ṇy affix is, and there is lengthening.

original: 369. Avaṇṇo ye lopañca.
analyzed: a vaṇṇaḥ ye lopam ca
translated: . The feminine is dropped and the vowel is shortened.

original: Avaṇṇo taddhitabhūte yappaccaye pare lopamāpajjate. Casaddena ivaṇṇopīti ikāralopo,
analyzed: a vaṇṇaḥ taddhita bhūte yap paccaye pare lopam āpajjate ca saddena i vaṇṇaḥ pi iti ikāra lopaḥ
translated: The feminine is dropped in the case of the y affix when it is a Taddhita formation. By the rule “The vowel is shortened in ivaṇṇo” the i becomes a.

original: “yavataṃ talanadakārānaṃ byañjanāni ca la ña jakāratta”nti tyakārasaṃyogassa cakāro,
analyzed: byañjanāni ca la ña tyakāra saṃyogassa cakāro
translated: By the rule “The letters talanadakārānaṃ byañjanāni ca la ña jakāratta” the ty becomes c,

original: “paradvebhāvo ṭhāne”ti dvittaṃ, ādicco. Evaṃ ditiyā putto decco.
analyzed: para dve bhāvaḥ ṭhāna iti dvittam ādiccaḥ evam ditiyā puttaḥ deccaḥ
translated: and by the rule “The second syllable is lengthened in paradvebhāvo ṭhāne” the second syllable is lengthened, and so it is Ādicca . So too, a son of a Diti is a Decca .

original: “Kuṇḍaniyā putto”ti atthe ṇyappaccaye kate –
analyzed: kuṇḍaniyā putto ti atthe ṇyap paccaye kate
translated: In the sense of “a son of a Kuṇḍanī” the ṇy affix is made.

original: “Kvacādimajjhuttaresū”ti vattate.
analyzed: kva ca ādi majjha uttaresu iti vattate
translated: Then the rule “Kvacādimajjhuttaresū” applies.

original: 370. Tesu vuddhilopāgamavikāraviparītādesā ca.
analyzed: tesu ca
translated: . There is lengthening, dropping, addition, alteration, and reversal.

original: Tesu ādimajjhuttaresu avihitalakkhaṇesu jinavacanānuparodhena kvaci vuddhi lopa āgama🔽vikāra viparītaādesā hontīti saṃyogantattepi ādivuddhi, ikāralope nyassañādeso, koṇḍañño,
analyzed: tesu ādi majjhuttaresu avihita lakkhaṇesu jina vacana an uparodhena kvaci  vikāra viparīta ādesāḥ honti iti ādi vuddhi ikāra lope koṇḍaññaḥ
translated: In the case of those that have the characteristics of the beginning and middle, the addition, omission, and so on, of the words of the Victor, are sometimes an increase, an omission, an addition,🔽a modification, and a reversal.🔽In the case of the addition of the affix -ya, there is an increase of the initial vowel, as in Koṇḍañño, Kuruno putto Korabyo,

original: kuruno putto korabyo, etthāpi teneva ukārassa avādeso, bhātuno putto bhātabyo.
analyzed: kurunaḥ putto korabyaḥ ettha api tena iva ukārassa a vādesaḥ bhātunaḥ putto bhātabyaḥ
translated: and here too there is the omission of the vowel u, as in Bhātuno putto Bhātabyo.

original: “Upagussa apacca”nti viggahe –🔽371. Ṇavopagvādīhi.
analyzed: upagussa a paccanti viggahe  ṇava upagū ādīhi
translated: In the case of the analysis of the word upagussa apacca,🔽there is the addition of the affix -ya by the rule beginning with ṇavopagvādīhi.

original: Upagu manuiccevamādīhi ukārantehi gottagaṇehi ṇavappaccayo hoti vā “tassāpacca”miccetasmiṃ
analyzed: upagu manu iti evamādīhi ukāra antehi gotta gaṇehi ṇava ppaccayaḥ hoti vā
translated: The affix -ya is added to the clan names ending in u, such as upagusa, manu, and so on, by the rule beginning with ṇavopagvādīhi, or the affix -ya is added to the word apacca,

original: atthe. Ādisaddassa cettha pakāravācakattā ukārantatoyevāyaṃ. Opagavo, opagavī, opagavaṃ,
analyzed: atthe ādi saddassa ca ittha pakāra vācaka ttā ukāra antatas yā iva ayam opagavaḥ opagavī opagavam
translated: in the sense of “the son of so-and-so.” And here, because the word ādi means “the vowel a,” this rule applies only to those ending in u. Opagavo, opagavī, opagavaṃ,

original: manuno apaccaṃ mānavo, “mānuso”ti ṇappaccaye, sāgame ca kate rūpaṃ, bhagguno apaccaṃ
analyzed: manunaḥ apaccam mānavaḥ mānusaḥ iti ṇa ppaccaye sa āgame ca kate rūpam bhaggunaḥ apaccam
translated: the son of Manu apacca is Mānavo, “mānuso” with the affix -ya. And when the vowel i is added, the form is rūpaṃ,

original: bhaggavo, paṇḍuno apaccaṃ paṇḍavo, upavindussa apaccaṃ opavindavo iccādi.
analyzed: bhaggavaḥ paṇḍunaḥ apaccam paṇḍavaḥ upavindussa apaccam opavindavaḥ iccādi
translated: the son of Bhagguna apacca is Bhaggavo, the son of Paṇḍuna apacca is Paṇḍavo, the son of Upavindussa apacca is Opavindavo, and so on.

original: “Vidhavāya apacca”nti atthe –
analyzed: vidhavāya apaccanti atthe
translated: In the case of the meaning “the son of a widow apacca,”

original: 372. Ṇera vidhavādito.
analyzed: ṇeḥ a vidhavā āditaḥ
translated: there is the addition of the affix -ya by the rule beginning with vidhavādito.

original: Vidhavādito ṇerappaccayo hoti vā apaccatthe. Vigato dhavo pati etissāti vidhavā,
analyzed: vidhavā āditaḥ ṇeḥ appaccayaḥ hoti vā a paccatthe vigataḥ dhavaḥ pati etissa ati vidhavā
translated: The suffix ṇer is added to the past participle vidhava, etc., either with the meaning “having gone away” or with the meaning “having gone to.”🔽A widow is one “having gone away from a husband” .

original: vedhavero, bandhukiyā abhisāriṇiyā putto bandhukero, samaṇassa upajjhāyassa putto
analyzed: vedhaveraḥ bandhukiyāḥ abhisāriṇiyāḥ putto bandhukero samaṇassa upajjhāyassa putto
translated: A son of a woman who has gone to a man with a spear is a spear-man .

original: puttaṭṭhāniyattāti sāmaṇero, nāḷikero iccādi.
analyzed: putta ṭṭhāniyattā ati sāmaṇeraḥ nāḷikeraḥ iccādi
translated: A son of a monk’s preceptor is a novice , a sugar-cane man, etc.

original: Apaccataddhitaṃ.🔽Saṃsaṭṭhādianekatthataddhita
analyzed: a pad ca taddhitam  saṃsaṭṭha ādi aneka attha taddhita
translated: This is the appositional indeclinable.🔽The indeclinable with the meaning of “having gone together with,” etc.,

original: “Tilena saṃsaṭṭha”nti viggahe –🔽373. Yena vā saṃsaṭṭhaṃ tarati carati vahati ṇiko.
analyzed: tilena saṃsaṭṭhanti viggahe  yena vā saṃsaṭṭham tarati carati vahati
translated: is analyzed thus: “Having gone together with sesamum” .

original: Yena vā saṃsaṭṭhaṃ, yena vā tarati, yena vā carati, yena vā vahati, tato tatiyantato
analyzed: yena vā saṃsaṭṭham yena vā tarati yena vā carati yena vā vahati
translated: Or he is a sesamum-man by whom one goes, moves, or carries, what one has gone together with, what one has crossed over, what one has moved along, what one has carried.

original: liṅgamhā tesu saṃsaṭṭhādīsvatthesu ṇikappaccayo hoti vā. Telikaṃ bhojanaṃ, tilena
analyzed: tesu saṃsaṭṭha ādīsu atthesu ṇika ppaccayaḥ hoti vā telikam bhojanam tilena
translated: The suffix ṇiko is added to the name of that by which one has gone together with, etc., either with the meaning of that or with the meaning of the possessor,

original: abhisaṅkhatanti attho. Telikī yāgu. Guḷena saṃsaṭṭhaṃ egāḷikaṃ. Evaṃ ghātikaṃ, dādhikaṃ, māricikaṃ, loṇikaṃ.
analyzed: abhisaṅkhatanti telikī yāgu guḷena saṃsaṭṭham egāḷikam evam ghātikam dādhikam māricikam loṇikam
translated: in the sense of “having gone together with,” “having crossed over,” “having moved along,” “having carried.” The meaning is “mixed with sesamum.” Sesamum-rice . Rice mixed with sugar. In the same way, sesamum-gruel , sesamum-drink , sesamum-cake , sesamum-curry , sesamum-sauce , sesamum-milk-rice , sesamum-milk , sesamum-water , sesamum-rice-gruel .

original: Nāvāya taratīti nāviko, uḷumpena taratīti oḷumpiko, vuddhiabhāvapakkhe uḷumpiko.
analyzed: nāvāya tarati iti nāvikaḥ uḷumpena tarati iti oḷumpikaḥ vuddhi abhāva pakkhe uḷumpikaḥ
translated: One who crosses by boat is a boat-man . One who crosses by raft is a raft-man . In the sense of “having the nature of growth” it is a raft-man .

original: Evaṃ kulliko, gopucchiko. Sakaṭena caratīti sākaṭiko. Evaṃ pādiko, daṇḍiko, dhammena🔽carati pavattatīti dhammiko. Sīsena vahatīti sīsiko, vāggahaṇena īkārassa vuddhi
analyzed: evam kullikaḥ gopucchikaḥ sakaṭena carati iti sākaṭikaḥ evam pādikaḥ daṇḍikaḥ dhammena  carati pavattati iti dhammikaḥ sīsena vahati iti sīsikaḥ vāc gahaṇena īkārassa
translated: So too, kulliko, gopucchiko. Sakaṭena caratīti sākaṭiko. So too, pādiko, daṇḍiko. Dhammena

original: na hoti. Evaṃ aṃsiko, khandhiko, hatthiko, aṅguliko.
analyzed: na hoti evam aṃsikaḥ khandhikaḥ hatthikaḥ aṅgulikaḥ
translated: carati pavattatīti dhammiko. Sīsena vahatīti sīsiko. The vowel i is not lengthened by the addition of the word vā. So too, aṃsiko, khandhiko, hatthiko, aṅguliko.

original: Puna vāggahaṇena aññatthesupi ṇikappaccayo, paradāraṃ gacchatīti pāradāriko, pathaṃ gacchatīti pathiko.
analyzed: puna vāc gahaṇena aññatthesu pi ṇika ppaccayaḥ paradāram gacchati iti pāradāriko patham gacchati iti pathiko
translated: Again, by the addition of the word vā, the affix ṇiko is also found in other places: paradāraṃ gacchatīti pāradāriko, pathaṃ gacchatīti pathiko.

original: “Vinayamadhīte, aveccādhīte”ti vā viggahe –
analyzed: vinayam adhīte avecca adhīta iti vā viggahe
translated: “Vinayamadhīte, aveccādhīte”ti vā viggahe—

original: “Ṇiko”ti vattate.
analyzed: ṇikaḥ iti vattate
translated: “ṇiko”ti vattate.

original: 374. Tamadhīte tenakatādisannidhānaniyogasippabhaṇḍajīvikatthesu ca.
analyzed: tam adhīte tenakata ādi sannidhāna niyoga sippa bhaṇḍa jīvika tthesu ca
translated: . Tamadhīte tenakatādisannidhānaniyogasippabhaṇḍajīvikatthesu ca.

original: Catuppadamidaṃ. Tamadhīteti atthe, tena katādīsvatthesu ca tamhi sannidhāno, tattha
analyzed: catuppadam idam tam adhīta iti atthe tena kata ādīsu atthesu ca tamhi
translated: This is a four-part phrase. Tamadhīte means in the sense of “he has learnt that,” and in the sense of “what is done by him,” etc., the word is used in the locative case in the sense of “in his presence,”🔽in the sense of “he is engaged in that,”

original: niyutto, tamassa sippaṃ, tamassa bhaṇḍaṃ, tamassa jīvikā iccetesvatthesu ca dutiyādivibhatyantehi
analyzed: niyuttaḥ tamassa sippam tamassa bhaṇḍam tamassa jīvikā icca itesu atthesu ca dutiya ādi vibhati antehi
translated: in the sense of “his craft,” in the sense of “his goods,” and in the sense of “his livelihood.”

original: liṅgehi ṇikappaccayo hoti vā. Venayiko. Evaṃ suttantiko, ābhidhammiko.🔽“Byākaraṇamadhīte”ti atthe ṇikappaccayādimhi kate –
analyzed: liṅgehi ṇika ppaccayaḥ hoti vā venayikaḥ evam suttantikaḥ ābhidhammikaḥ  byākaraṇam adhīta iti atthe ṇika paccaya ādimhi kate
translated: When the words “he studies grammar” are analyzed,🔽the rule “The vowel of the first syllable of a word of more than one syllable is lengthened when a word is joined to it” applies,🔽and the rule “The augment mā is added to the first syllable of a word of more than one syllable” applies.

original: “Vuddhādisarassa vāsaṃyogantassa saṇe cā”ti vattamāne –
analyzed: vuddha ādi sarassa vā a saṃyoga antassa saṇe ca ati vattamāne
translated: The lengthening of the vowel of the first syllable and the addition of the augment mā are not done to the first syllable of a word of one syllable,🔽but only to the first syllable of a word of more than one syllable.

original: 375. Māyūnamāgamo ṭhāne.
analyzed: mā yūnam āgamaḥ ṭhāne
translated: This is because of the word “in the proper place” in the rule.🔽The lengthening of the vowel of the first syllable and the addition of the augment mā are done to the first syllable of a word of more than one syllable,🔽but not to the first syllable of a word of one syllable.🔽The augment mā is added to the first syllable of a word of more than one syllable,🔽but not to the first syllable of a word of one syllable.🔽The augment mā is added to the first syllable of a word of more than one syllable,🔽but not to the first syllable of a word of one syllable.🔽The augment mā is added to the first syllable of a word of more than one syllable,

original: I uiccebhesaṃ ādisarānaṃ asaṃyogantānaṃ mā vuddhi hoti saṇe, tatreva vuddhi āgamo hoti ca ṭhāneti ekāravuddhāgamo.🔽“Ṭhāne”ti vacanā cettha, yūnamādesabhūtato;
analyzed: ādisarāṇam asaṃyogantānam mā hoti saṇe tatra iva vuddhi āgamaḥ hoti ca ṭhāne iti ekāra vuddha āgamaḥ  ṭhāna iti ca ittha yūnam ādesa bhūtataḥ
translated: but not to the first syllable of a word of one syllable.

original: Yavehi pubbeva eo-vuddhiyo honti āgamā.
analyzed: yavehi pubbā iva eovuddhiyaḥ honti āgamā
translated: The augment mā is added to the first syllable of a word of more than one syllable,🔽but not to the first syllable of a word of one syllable.🔽The augment mā is added to the first syllable of a word of more than one syllable,

original: Yakārassa dvibhāvo.
analyzed: yakārassa dvi bhāvaḥ
translated: but not to the first syllable of a word of one syllable.🔽The augment mā is added to the first syllable of a word of more than one syllable,🔽but not to the first syllable of a word of one syllable.🔽The augment mā is added to the first syllable of a word of more than one syllable,

original: Veyyākaraṇiko, nyāyamadhīteti neyyāyiko. Evaṃ takkiko, vediko, nemittiko, kāyena
analyzed: veyyākaraṇikaḥ nyāyam adhīta iti neyyāyikaḥ evam takkikaḥ vedikaḥ nemittikaḥ kāyena
translated: but not to the first syllable of a word of one syllable.🔽The augment mā is added to the first syllable of a word of more than one syllable,

original: kato payogo kāyiko, kāyena kataṃ kammaṃ kāyikaṃ, vacasā kataṃ kammaṃ vācasikaṃ. Evaṃ
analyzed: kataḥ payogaḥ kāyikaḥ kāyena katam kammam kāyikam vacasā katam kammam vācasikam evam
translated: but not to the first syllable of a word of one syllable.🔽The augment mā is added to the first syllable of a word of more than one syllable,

original: mānasikaṃ, ettha ca “sasare vāgamo”ti sutte vavatthitavāsaddena paccaye parepi sāgamo,
analyzed: mānasikam ettha ca sa sare vāgamaḥ iti sutte vavatthita vā saddena paccaye pare pi sa āgamaḥ
translated: but

original: therehi katā saṅgīti therikā. Evaṃ pañcasatikā, sattasatikā, ettha “ṇavaṇikā”disutte
analyzed: therehi katā therikā evam pañcasatikā sattasatikā ettha ṇavaṇikā ādi sutte
translated: So too with the Pañcasatikā, Satta-satikā, and the Navaṇikā, etc., in the Sutta

original: anuvattitavāggahaṇena īpaccayo na hoti.
analyzed: anuvattita vāc gahaṇena ī paccayaḥ na hoti
translated: The preposition is not used with the word anuvattita in the sense of “following”.

original: Sannidhānatthe sarīre sannidhānā vedanā sārīrikā, sārīrikaṃ dukkhaṃ. Evaṃ mānasikā, mānasikaṃ.
analyzed: sannidhāna atthe sarīre sannidhānā vedanā sārīrikā sārīrikam dukkham evam mānasikā mānasikam
translated: In the sense of “being present” : The feeling that is present in the body is bodily, bodily pain. So too with mental, mental pain.

original: Niyuttatthe dvāre niyutto dovāriko, ettha “māyūnamāgamo ṭhāne”ti vakārato pubbeokārāgamo.
analyzed: niyutta atthe dvāre niyuttaḥ dovārikaḥ ettha māyūnam āgamaḥ ṭhāne ti vakārataḥ pubbe okāra āgamaḥ
translated: In the sense of “being attached to” : The doorkeeper who is attached to the door is a dovāriko. Here the vowel o is substituted for the u of the first member by the rule: “māyūnamāgamo ṭhāne” .

original: Evaṃ bhaṇḍāgāriko, nāgariko, navakammiko, vanakammiko, ādikammiko, odariko, rathiko,
analyzed: evam bhaṇḍāgārikaḥ nāgarikaḥ nava kammikaḥ vana kammikaḥ ādi kammikaḥ odarikaḥ rathikaḥ
translated: So too with bhaṇḍāgāriko, nāgariko, navakammiko, vanakammiko, ādikammiko, odariko, rathiko,

original: pathiko, upāye niyutto opāyiko, cetasi niyuttā cetasikā.🔽Sippatthe vīṇāvādanaṃ vīṇā, vīṇā assa sippaṃ veṇiko. Evaṃ pāṇaviko, modiṅgiko, vaṃsiko.
analyzed: pathikaḥ upāye niyuttaḥ cetasi niyuttā cetasikā  sippatthe vīṇā vādanam vīṇā vīṇā assa sippam veṇikaḥ evam pāṇavikaḥ modiṅgikaḥ vaṃsikaḥ
translated: pathiko, opāyiko, cetasikā.🔽In the sense of “craft” : The playing of the lute is the lute, the craft of the lute is veṇiko. So too with pāṇaviko, modiṅgiko, vaṃsiko.

original: Bhaṇḍatthe gandho assa bhaṇḍanti gandhiko. Evaṃ teliko, goḷiko, pūviko, paṇṇiko, tambūliko, loṇiko.
analyzed: bhaṇḍa tthe gandhaḥ assa bhaṇḍanti gandhikaḥ evam telikaḥ goḷikaḥ pūvikaḥ paṇṇikaḥ tambūlikaḥ loṇikaḥ
translated: In the sense of “commodity” : The commodity of perfume is gandho, gandhiko. So too with teliko, goḷiko, pūviko, paṇṇiko, tambūliko, loṇiko.

original: Jīvikatthe urabbhaṃ hantvā jīvati, urabbhamassa jīvikāti vā orabbhiko. Evaṃ māgaviko, ettha vakārāgamo. Sūkariko, sākuṇiko, macchiko iccādi.
analyzed: jīvika atthe urabbham hantvā jīvati urabbham assa jīvikā ati vā orabbhikaḥ evam māgavikaḥ ettha vakāra āgamaḥ sūkarikaḥ sākuṇikaḥ macchikaḥ iccādi
translated: One who lives by killing goats is a goat-killer, or a goatherd.

original: “Tena katādī”ti ettha ādiggahaṇena tena hataṃ, tena baddhaṃ, tena kītaṃ, tena dibbati,
analyzed: tena kata ādi iti ettha ādi ggahaṇena tena hatam tena baddham tena kītam tena dibbati
translated: In the case of “ten-made” and so on, the word “and so on” includes what is killed by him, what is bound by him, what is stolen by him, what is sold by him,

original: so assa āvudho, so assa ābādho, tattha pasanno, tassa santakaṃ, tamassa parimāṇaṃ,
analyzed: saḥ assa āvudhaḥ saḥ assa ābādhaḥ tattha pasanno tassa santakam tamassa parimāṇam
translated: what is his weapon, what is his disease, what he has faith in, what belongs to him, what is his measure,

original: tassa rāsi, taṃ arahati, tamassa sīlaṃ, tattha jāto, tattha vasati, tatra vidito,
analyzed: tassa rāsi tam arahati tamassa sīlam tattha jātaḥ tattha vasati tatra viditaḥ
translated: what is his heap, what he deserves, what is his virtue, where he is born, where he lives, where he is known,

original: tadatthāya saṃvattati, tato āgato, tato sambhūto, tadassa payojananti evamādiatthe🔽ca ṇikappaccayo hoti. Yathā – jālena hato, hanatīti vā jāliko. Evaṃ bāḷisiko, vākariko,
analyzed: tad atthāya saṃvattati tatas āgataḥ tatas sambhūtaḥ tat assa payojana nti evamādi atthe  ca ṇika ppaccayaḥ hoti yathā jālena hataḥ hanati iti vā jālikaḥ evam bāḷisikaḥ vākarikaḥ
translated: what is conducive to his welfare, where he has come from, where he has originated, what is his purpose.🔽The affix ṇik is used to form nouns in the sense indicated by these words.🔽For example: One who kills with a net is a net-killer, or one who is killed by a net.🔽One who kills with a snare is a snaregatherer.

original: suttena baddho suttiko, varattāya baddho vārattiko nāgo.
analyzed: suttena baddhaḥ suttikaḥ varattāya baddhaḥ vārattikaḥ nāgaḥ
translated: One bound with a rope is a rope-bound elephant.

original: Vatthena kītaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ vatthikaṃ. Evaṃ kumbhikaṃ, phālikaṃ, sovaṇṇikaṃ, sātikaṃ.🔽Akkhena dibbatīti akkhiko. Evaṃ sālākiko, tindukiko, ambaphaliko. Cāpo assa āvudhoti🔽cāpiko. Evaṃ tomariko, muggariko, mosaliko.🔽Vāto assa ābādhoti vātiko. Evaṃ semhiko, pittiko.🔽Buddhe pasanno buddhiko. Evaṃ dhammiko, saṅghiko. Buddhassa santako buddhiko. Evaṃ dhammiko, saṅghiko vihāro, saṅghikā bhūmi, saṅghikaṃ cīvaraṃ, puggalikaṃ.🔽Kumbho assa parimāṇanti kumbhikaṃ. Evaṃ khārikaṃ, doṇikaṃ. Kumbhassa rāsi kumbhiko.🔽Kumbhaṃ arahatīti kumbhiko. Evaṃ doṇiko, aṭṭhamāsiko, kahāpaṇiko, āsītikā gāthā,
analyzed: vatthena kītam bhaṇḍam vatthikam evam kumbhikam phālikam sovaṇṇikam sātikam  akkhena dibbati iti akkhikaḥ evam sālākikaḥ tindukikaḥ ambaphalikaḥ ca apaḥ assa āvudhā ti  cāpikaḥ evam tomarikaḥ muggarikaḥ mosalikaḥ  vātaḥ assa ābādhaḥ ti vātikaḥ evam semhikaḥ pittikaḥ  buddhe pasannaḥ buddhikaḥ evam dhammikaḥ saṅghikaḥ buddhassa santakaḥ buddhikaḥ evam dhammikaḥ saṅghikaḥ vihāraḥ saṅghikā bhūmi saṅghikam cīvaram puggalikam  kumbhaḥ assa kumbhikam evam khārikam doṇikam kumbhassa rāsi kumbhikaḥ  kumbham arahati iti kumbhikaḥ evam doṇikaḥ aṭṭha māsikaḥ kahāpaṇikaḥ āsītikā gāthā
translated: “Cloth” is a thing. “Cloth-wearer” is a cloth-wearer. In the same way, “pot-wearer,” “bowl-wearer,” “gold-wearer,” “silk-wearer.”🔽“Eye” is a god. “Eye-wearer” is an eye-wearer. In the same way, “palm-wearer,” “tamarind-wearer,” “mango-wearer.” “Bow” is a weapon.🔽“Bow-wearer” is a bow-wearer. In the same way, “spear-wearer,” “club-wearer,” “axe-wearer.”🔽“Wind” is a disease. “Wind-wearer” is a wind-wearer. In the same way, “bile-wearer,” “phlegm-wearer.”🔽“Faithful to the Buddha” is a Buddha-worshipper. In the same way, “Dhamma-worshipper,” “Sangha-worshipper.” “Belonging to the Buddha” is a Buddha-worshipper. In the same way, “belonging to the Dhamma,” “belonging to the Sangha.” “Belonging to a person.”🔽“Measure” is a pot. “Pot-wearer” is a pot-wearer. In the same way, “measure-wearer,” “doṇa-wearer.” “Heap of pots” is a pot-heap.🔽“Worthy of a pot” is a pot-wearer. In the same way, “worthy of a doṇa,” “worthy of eight months,” “worthy of a kahāpanṇa,” “worth eighty verses,”🔽

original: nāvutikā, sātikaṃ, sāhassikaṃ. Sandiṭṭhamarahatīti sandiṭṭhiko, “ehi passā”ti imaṃ🔽vidhiṃ arahatīti ehipassiko.
analyzed: nāvutikā sātikam sāhassikam sandiṭṭham arahati iti sandiṭṭhikaḥ ehi passa ati imaṃ 🔽vidhim arahati iti ehipassikaḥ

original: Sīlatthe paṃsukūladhāraṇaṃ paṃsukūlaṃ, taṃ sīlamassāti paṃsukūliko. Evaṃ tecīvariko, ekāsane bhojanasīlo ekāsaniko, rukkhamūle vasanasīlo rukkhamūliko, tathā āraññiko, sosāniko.
analyzed: sīla atthe paṃsu kūla dhāraṇam paṃsu kūlam tam sīlam assa ati paṃsukūlikaḥ evam tecīvarikaḥ eka āsane bhojana sīlaḥ ekāsanikaḥ rukkha mūle vasana sīlaḥ rukkhamūlikaḥ tathā āraññikaḥ sosānikaḥ
translated: The wearing of the rag-robe is the rag-robe as a virtue. He has that, thus he is a “rag-robe-wearer” . Likewise, a “three- robe-wearer” , a “one-seater” , a “tree-root-dweller” , a “forest-dweller” , and a “charnel-ground-dweller” .

original: Jātatthe apāye jāto āpāyiko. Evaṃ nerayiko, sāmuddiko maccho, vassesu jāto vassiko,
analyzed: jātatthe apāye jātaḥ āpāyikaḥ evam nerayikaḥ sāmuddikaḥ macchaḥ vassesu jātaḥ vassikaḥ
translated: As to what is born: he is born in the states of loss, thus he is a “performer of what is born in the states of loss” . Likewise, a “performer of what is born in hell” , a “performer of what is born in the sea” , a “performer of what is born in the rains” ,

original: vassikā, vassikaṃ pupphaṃ, sāradiko, hemantiko, vāsantiko, cātuddasiko, rājagahe
analyzed: vassikā vassikam puppham sāradikaḥ hemantikaḥ vāsantikaḥ cātuddasikaḥ rājagahe
translated: “rains” , “rain-flower” , “performer of what is born in autumn” , “performer of what is born in winter” , “performer of what is born in spring” , “performer of what is born on the fourteenth” , “performer of what is born in Rājagaha” ,

original: jāto, rājagahe vasatīti vā rājagahiko jano, magadhesu jāto, vasatīti vā māgadhiko,
analyzed: jātaḥ rājagahe vasati iti vā rājagahikaḥ janaḥ magadhesu jātaḥ vasati iti vā māgadhikaḥ
translated: “performer of what is born in Rājagaha and lives there” , “performer of what is born in Magadha and lives there” ,

original: māgadhikā, māgadhikaṃ, sāvatthiyaṃ jāto, vasatīti vā sāvatthiko, kāpilavatthiko, vesāliko.
analyzed: māgadhikā māgadhikam sāvatthiyam jātaḥ vasati iti vā sāvatthikaḥ kāpilavatthikaḥ vesālikaḥ
translated: “performer of what is born in Sāvatthī and lives there” , “performer of what is born in Kāpilavatthu” , “performer of what is born in Vesālī” .

original: Loke vidito lokiko, lokāya saṃvattatītipi lokiko. Tathā mātito āgataṃ mātikaṃ, pitito āgataṃ pettikaṃ nāmaṃ.
analyzed: loke viditaḥ lokikaḥ lokāya saṃvattati iti pi lokiko tathā mātitaḥ āgatam mātikam pititaḥ āgatam pettikam nāmam
translated: “What is known in the world” is “what is born in the world” . It is also “what is born in the world” since it occurs in the world. Likewise, “what is born from the mother” is “what is born of the mother” . “What is born from the father” is “what is born of the father” .

original: Sambhūtatthe mātito sambhūtaṃ mattikaṃ. Evaṃ pettikaṃ. Upadhitassa payojanaṃ opadhikaṃ.🔽Sakatthepi asaṅkhāroyeva asaṅkhārikaṃ. Evaṃ sasaṅkhārikaṃ, nāmameva nāmikaṃ. Evaṃ
analyzed: sambhūta atthe mātitaḥ sambhūtam mattikam evam pettikam upadhitassa payojanam opadhikam  asaṅkhāro yā iva asaṅkhārikam evam sa saṅkhārikam nāmam eva nāmikam evam
translated: In the sense of origination: clay originated from the mother is “mattika” . Likewise “pettika” . What is useful to the body is “opadhika” .

original: ākhyātikaṃ, opasaggikaṃ, nepātikaṃ, catumahārāje bhatti etesanti cātumahārājikā.
analyzed: ākhyātikam opasaggikam nepātikam cātumahārājikā
translated: In the sense of vehicle: what is not a vehicle is “asaṅkhārika” . Likewise “sasaṅkhārika” . What is name only is “nāmika” . Likewise “ākhyātika” . What is useful to the body is “opasaggika” . What is useful to the country is “nepātika” . What is useful to the four great kings is “cātumahārājika” .

original: Evaṃ aññatthepi yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: evam aññattha api yojetabbam
translated: Likewise in the sense of other: it should be construed thus.

original: “Kasāvena ratta”nti viggahe –
analyzed: kasāvena rattanti viggahe
translated: In the analysis of “red with kasāva” :

original: 376. Ṇa rāgā tenarattaṃ tassedamaññatthesu ca.
analyzed: rāgā tenarattam tassa idam aññatthesu ca
translated: . Ṇa rāgā tenarattaṃ tassedamaññatthesu ca.

original: Rāgatthavācakā liṅgamhā “tena ratta”miccetasmiṃ atthe, “tasse”ti chaṭṭhiyantato “ida”miccetasmiṃ atthe ca aññatthesu ca ṇappaccayo hoti vā.
analyzed: rāga attha vācakāḥ tena rattam icca etasmin atthe tassa iti idam icca etasmin atthe ca aññatthesu ca ṇa ppaccayaḥ hoti vā
translated: In the sense of “red with that” and in the sense of “this of that” and in the sense of other, the ṇ-suffix is used optionally after a feminine noun in the locative case that expresses the meaning of passion.

original: Kāsāvaṃ vatthaṃ. Evaṃ kāsāyaṃ, kusumbhena rattaṃ kosumbhaṃ, haliddiyā rattaṃ hāliddaṃ, pattaṅgaṃ, mañjiṭṭhaṃ, kuṅkumaṃ, nīlena rattaṃ nīlaṃ. Evaṃ pītaṃ.
analyzed: kāsāvam vattham evam kāsāyam kusumbhena rattam kosumbham haliddiyā rattam hāliddam pattaṅgam mañjiṭṭham kuṅkumam nīlena rattam nīlam evam pītam
translated: Kasāva cloth is “kāsāva” . Likewise “kāsāya” . What is red with saffron is “kosumbha” . What is red with turmeric is “hālidda” . What is red with lac is “pattaṅga” . What is red with madder is “mañjiṭṭha” . What is red with crocus is “kuṅkuma” . What is red with indigo is “nīla” . Likewise “pīta” .

original: Idamatthe mahiṃsassa idaṃ māhiṃsaṃ maṃsaṃ, dadhi sappi cammādikaṃ vā, sūkarassa idaṃ sūkaraṃ, kaccāyanassa idaṃ kaccāyanaṃ byākaraṇaṃ. Evaṃ sogataṃ sāsanaṃ.
analyzed: idamatthe mahiṃsassa idam māhiṃsam maṃsam dadhi sappi camma ādikam vā sūkarassa idam sūkaram kaccāyanassa idam kaccāyanam byākaraṇam evam sogatam sa āsanam
translated: The flesh of the ox is the ox’s flesh, or the curd, ghee, hide, etc., of the ox. The flesh of the pig is the pig’s flesh. The grammar of Kaccāyana is Kaccāyana’s grammar. So the suffix -a is used in this way.

original: “Isissa ida”nti atthe ṇappaccaye kate vuddhimhi sampatte –
analyzed: isissa idanti atthe ṇap paccaye kate vuddhimhi sampatte
translated: When the locative case is made of the word issa, the word vuddhi is added:

original: “Saṇe, yūnamāgamo ṭhāne”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: saṇe yūnam āgamaḥ ṭhāna iti ca vattate
translated: “Saṇe, yūnamāgamo ṭhāne” .

original: 377. Āttañca.
analyzed: ā t tañ ca
translated: And the word atta.

original: I uiccetesaṃ ādisarānaṃ āttañca hoti saṇakārappaccaye pare, casaddena rikārāgamo ca ṭhāneti ikārassa āttaṃ.
analyzed: ā ttam ca hoti sa ṇakāra ppaccaye pare ca saddena rikāra āgamaḥ ca ṭhāne iti ikārassa āttam
translated: The word atta is added to the words beginning with i, etc., when the locative case is made, and the word ṭhāna is added to the word atta, and the vowel i of the word atta becomes a by the rule “casaddena rikārāgamo ṭhāneti” .

original: Ṭhānādhikārato āttaṃ, isūsabhaujādinaṃ;
analyzed: ṭhāna adhikārataḥ ā ttam
translated: The word atta is added by the rule of the locative case to the words issa, usabha, uja, etc.

original: Isissa tu rikārāga-mo cāttānantare bhave.
analyzed: isissa tu ri kāra āgamaḥ ca ātta anantare bhave
translated: But the vowel a of the word atta becomes a by the rule “cāttānantare bhave” .

original: Ārisyaṃ, usabhassa idaṃ āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṃ, āsabhī vācā.🔽Aññatthaggahaṇena pana avidūrabhavo, tatra bhavo, tatra jāto, tato āgato, so assa
analyzed: ārisyam usabhassa idam āsabham ṭhānam āsabhī vācā  aññattha gahaṇena pana avidūra bhavo tatra bhavo tatra jāto tatas āgato so assa
translated: The place of the bull is the bull’s place, or the bull’s voice is the bull’s voice.

original: nivāso, tassa issaro, kattikādīhi niyutto māso, sāssa devatā, tamaveccādhīte, tassa
analyzed: nivāsaḥ tassa issaraḥ kattikā ādīhi niyuttaḥ māso sā assa devatā tam avecca adhīte tassa
translated: But by the word aññattha the meaning “not far away” is included. The word tatra is used in the sense of “existing there,” “born there,” “come from there,” “his dwelling place,” “his lord,” “the month regulated by Kattika, etc.,” “his deity,” “he has studied after considering that,” “his

original: visayo deso, tasmiṃ dese atthi, tena nibbattaṃ, taṃ arahati, tassa vikāro, tamassa
analyzed: visayaḥ deso tasmin dese atthi tena nibbattam tam arahati tassa vikāro tamassa
translated: The 1st is a place, and it is in that place, and it is produced from that, and it is fit for that, and it is a modification of that, and it is the measure of that.

original: parimāṇanti iccevamādīsvatthesu ca ṇappaccayo. Yathā – vidisāya avidūre bhavo vediso
analyzed: parimāṇanti iti ca ivamādīsu atthesu ca ṇa p paccayaḥ yathā vidisāya avidūre bhavaḥ vediso
translated: The 2nd is in the sense of ‘being’ as in these examples: ‘The village is not far from the four directions, therefore it is called the four-cornered village’ .

original: gāmo, udumbarassa avidūre bhavaṃ odumbaraṃ vimānaṃ.
analyzed: gāmaḥ udumbarassa avidūre bhavaṃ odumbaram vimānam
translated: ‘The palace is not far from the udumbara tree, therefore it is called the udumbara palace’ .🔽The 3rd is in the sense of ‘mind’ as in these examples: ‘Pleasure that is in the mind is mental pleasure’ .

original: Bhavatthe manasi bhavaṃ mānasaṃ sukhaṃ, sāgamo. Sare bhavo sāraso sakuṇo, sārasā
analyzed: bhavatthe manasi bhavam mānasam sukham sa āgamaḥ sare bhavaḥ sārasaḥ sakuṇaḥ sārasā
translated: ‘The bird is in the reed, therefore it is called the reed-bird’ .🔽‘The flower is in the reed, therefore it is called the reed-flower’ .🔽The 4th is in the sense of ‘breast’ as in these examples: ‘The son is in the breast, therefore he is called the breast-born son’ .🔽‘The breast-born son is brought up on the breast’ .

original: sakuṇī, sārasaṃ pupphaṃ, urasi bhavo oraso putto, urasi saṃvaḍḍhitattā, mitte bhavā
analyzed: sakuṇī sārasam puppham urasi bhavaḥ orasaḥ putto urasi saṃvaḍḍhita ttā mitte bhavā
translated: ‘The breast-born son is brought up on the breast’ .🔽The 5th is in the sense of ‘former’ as in these examples: ‘The cloud is born in the rainy season, therefore it is called the rainy-season cloud’ .

original: mettā, mettī vā, pure bhavā porī vācā.
analyzed: mettā mettī vā pure bhavā porī vācā
translated: ‘The night is in the rainy season, therefore it is called the rainy-season night’ .🔽‘The rain is in the rainy season, therefore it is called the rainy-season rain’ .🔽‘The month is born in the autumn, therefore it is called the autumn month’ .

original: Jātādīsu pāvuse jāto pāvuso megho, pāvusā ratti, pāvusaṃ abbhaṃ, sarade jāto sārado🔽māso, sāradā ratti, sāradaṃ pupphaṃ. Evaṃ sisiro, hemanto, vasanto, vimho, mathurāyaṃ
analyzed: jāta ādīsu pāvuse jātaḥ pāvusaḥ meghaḥ pāvusā ratti pāvusam abbham sara de jātaḥ sāra daḥ  māsaḥ sāradā ratti sāradam puppham evam sisiraḥ hemantaḥ vasantaḥ
translated: ‘The night is in the autumn, therefore it is called the autumn night’ .🔽‘The flower is in the autumn, therefore it is called the autumn flower’ .🔽‘The people are born in Mathura, therefore they are called the Mathura people’ .🔽‘The harlot is from Mathura, therefore she is called the Mathura harlot’ .

original: jāto māthuro jano, māthurā gaṇikā, māthuraṃ vatthaṃ. Mathurāya āgato māthuro, mathurā
analyzed: jātaḥ māthuraḥ janaḥ māthurāḥ gaṇikāḥ māthuram vattham mathurāya āgataḥ māthuraḥ mathurā
translated: ‘The cloth is from Mathura, therefore it is called the Mathura cloth’ .

original: assa nivāsoti māthuro, mathurāya issaro māthuro rājā. “Sabbato ko”ti ettha puna sabbatoggahaṇena
analyzed: assa nivāsaḥ iti māthuraḥ mathurāya issaraḥ māthuraḥ rājā ettha puna sabbata uggahaṇena
translated: The lord of Mathurā is Māthura. “Sabbato ko” means that by the repetition of the word sabba in the above rule,

original: taddhitatopi kvaci sasarakakārāgamo, māthurako vā, rājagahe jāto, rājagahā āgato,
analyzed: taddhita taḥ pi kvaci sa sara kakāra āgamaḥ māthurakaḥ vā rāja gahe jātaḥ rāja gahe āgataḥ
translated: the suffix -aka is added to the word rājagaha, which is a taddhita formation, to make rājagahako, or rājagaho, meaning “born in Rājagaha,” “come from Rājagaha,”

original: rājagaho assa nivāsoti vā, rājagahassa issaroti vā rājagaho, rājagahako vā. Evaṃ
analyzed: rājagahaḥ assa nivāsaḥ iti vā rājagahassa issaraḥ iti vā rājagahaḥ rājagahakaḥ vā evam
translated: or “Rājagaha is his dwelling place,” or “he is the lord of Rājagaha.” In the same way,

original: sāgalo, sāgalako vā, pāṭaliputto, pāṭaliputtako vā, vesāliyaṃ jātotiādiatthe vesālo,
analyzed: sāgalaḥ sāgalakaḥ vā pāṭaliputto pāṭaliputtakaḥ vā vesāliyam jātaḥ iti ādi atthe vesālaḥ
translated: Sāgala, Sāgalaka, Pāṭaliputta, Pāṭaliputtaka, Vesāliyaṃ jāto means “born in Vesālī,”

original: vesālako vā, kusināre jāto kosināro, kosinārako vā. Evaṃ sāketo, sāketako vā, kosambo,
analyzed: vesālakaḥ vā kusināre jātaḥ kosināraḥ kosinārakaḥ vā evam sāketaḥ sāketakaḥ vā kosambaḥ
translated: Vesāla, Vesālako, Kusināre jāto means “born in Kusinārā,” Kosināro, Kosinārako. In the same way, Sāketa, Sāketako, Kosambī,

original: kosambako vā, indapatto, indapattako vā, kapillo, kapillako vā, bhārukaccho, bhārukacchako
analyzed: kosambakaḥ vā indapattaḥ indapattakaḥ vā kapillaḥ kapillakaḥ vā bhārukacchaḥ bhārukacchakaḥ
translated: Kosambako, Indapatta, Indapattaka, Kapilla, Kapillako, Bhārukaccha, Bhārukacchako,

original: vā, nagare jāto, nagarā āgato, nagare vasatīti vā nāgaro, nāgarako vā. Evaṃ jānapado.
analyzed: vā nagare jātaḥ nagarāḥ āgataḥ nagare vasati iti vā nāgaraḥ nāgarakaḥ vā evam jānapadaḥ
translated: Nagare jāto, nagarā āgato, nagare vasatīti means “born in the town,” “come from the town,” or “he dwells in the town,” Nāgaro, Nāgarako. In the same way, Jānapado.

original: Janapadanāmesu pana sabbattha bahuvacanameva bhavati. Yathā – aṅgesu jāto, aṅgehi
analyzed: janapada nāmesu pana sabbattha bahuvacanam eva bhavati yathā aṅgesu jātaḥ aṅgehi
translated: But in the case of the names of countries, the plural is always used. For example, Aṅgesu jāto, Aṅgehi

original: āgato, aṅgā assa nivāso, aṅgānaṃ issaro vā aṅgo, aṅgako vā, māgadho, māgadhako vā,
analyzed: āgataḥ aṅgāḥ assa nivāsaḥ aṅgānam issaraḥ vā aṅgaḥ aṅgakaḥ vā māgadhaḥ māgadhakaḥ vā
translated: Aṅga is a place where he has come to, or it is his dwelling place, or he is the lord of Aṅga, or he is a man of Aṅga, or he is a man of Aṅga,

original: kosalo, kosalako vā, vedeho, vedehako vā, kambojo, kambojako vā, gandhāro, gandhārako
analyzed: kosalaḥ kosalakaḥ vā vedehaḥ vedehakaḥ vā kambojaḥ kambojakaḥ vā gandhāraḥ gandhārakaḥ
translated: or he is a man of Kosala, or he is a man of Videha, or he is a man of Kamboja, or he is a man of Gandhāra,

original: vā, sovīro, sovīrako vā, sindhavo, sindhavako vā, assako, kāliṅgo, pañcālo, sakko,
analyzed: vā sovīraḥ sovīrakaḥ vā sindhavaḥ sindhavakaḥ vā assakaḥ kāliṅgaḥ pañcālaḥ sakko
translated: or he is a man of Sovira, or he is a man of Sindhu, or he is a man of Assaka, or he is a man of Kaliṅga, or he is a man of Pañcāla, or he is a man of Sakka,

original: tathā suraṭṭhe jāto, suraṭṭhassa issaro vā soraṭṭho, soraṭṭhako vā. Evaṃ mahāraṭṭho,
analyzed: tathā suraṭṭhe jātaḥ suraṭṭhassa issaraḥ vā soraṭṭhaḥ soraṭṭhakaḥ vā evam mahāraṭṭhaḥ
translated: or he is a man of Suraṭṭha, or he is the lord of Suraṭṭha, or he is a man of Suraṭṭha. Thus he is a man of a great country,

original: mahāraṭṭhako vā iccādi.🔽Nakkhattayoge kattikāya puṇṇacandayuttāya yutto māso kattiko, magasirena candayuttena🔽nakkhattena yutto māso māgasiro. Evaṃ phussena yutto māso phusso, maghāya yutto māso🔽māgho, phagguniyā yutto māso phagguno, cittāya yutto māso citto, visākhāya yutto
analyzed: mahāraṭṭhakaḥ vā iccādi  nakkhatta yoge kattikāya puṇṇa canda yuttāya yuttaḥ māsaḥ kattikaḥ magasirena canda yuttena  nakkhattena yuttaḥ māsaḥ māgasiraḥ evam phussena yuttaḥ māsaḥ phussaḥ maghāya yuttaḥ māsaḥ  māghaḥ phagguniyā yuttaḥ māso phaggunaḥ cittāya yuttaḥ māso cittaḥ visākhāya yuttaḥ
translated: or he is a man of a great country.

original: māso vesākho, jeṭṭhāya yutto māso jeṭṭho, uttarāsāḷhāya yutto māso āsāḷho, āsāḷhī
analyzed: māsaḥ vesākhaḥ jeṭṭhāya yuttaḥ māsaḥ jeṭṭhaḥ uttarāsāḷhāya yuttaḥ māsaḥ āsāḷhaḥ āsāḷhī
translated: The month that is associated with the constellation Kattika when the moon is full is the month of Kattika. The month that is associated with the constellation Magha when the moon is full is the month of Magha. Thus the month that is associated with the constellation Phussa is the month of Phussa, the month that is associated with the constellation Magha is the month of Magha, the month that is associated with the constellation Phālguna is the month of Phālguna, the month that is associated with the constellation Citrā is the month of Citta, the month that is associated with the constellation Visākhā is the month of Vesākha, the month that is associated with the constellation Jeṭṭhā is the month of Jeṭṭha, the month that is associated with the constellation Uttarāsāḷhā is the month of Āsāḷhā, Āsāḷhī

original: vā, savaṇena yutto māso sāvaṇo, sāvaṇī. Bhaddena yutto māso bhaddo, assayujena yutto
analyzed: vā savaṇena yuttaḥ māsaḥ sāvaṇaḥ sāvaṇī bhaddena yuttaḥ māsaḥ bhaddaḥ assayujena yuttaḥ
translated: The month connected with the Savana is the Savana month, the Savani. The month connected with the Bhadra is the Bhadra, the month connected with the Assujula.

original: māso assayujo, buddho assa devatāti buddho. Evaṃ sogato, māhindo, yāmo, somo.
analyzed: māsaḥ assayujaḥ buddhaḥ assa devatā ati buddhaḥ evam sogataḥ māhindaḥ yāmaḥ somo
translated: The month associated with the constellation Sāvana is Sāvana, Sāvaṇī. The month associated with the constellation Bhadda is Bhadda, the month associated with the constellation Assayuja is Assayuja, the constellation Buddha is a deity, thus Buddha. So is the case with Sagata, Māhinda, Yāma, Soma.

original: Byākaraṇaṃ aveccādhīte veyyākaraṇo. Evaṃ mohutto, nemitto, aṅgavijjo, vatthuvijjo. Vasātīnaṃ visayo deso vāsāto, udumbarā asmiṃ padese santīti odumbaro deso.
analyzed: byākaraṇam avecca adhīte veyyākaraṇaḥ evam mohuttaḥ nemittaḥ aṅga vijjaḥ vatthu vijjaḥ vasātīnam visayaḥ desaḥ vāsātaḥ udumbarāḥ asmin padese santi iti odumbaraḥ desaḥ
translated: One who has learnt grammar after having investigated the grammar is a grammarian. So is the case with Mohutta, Nemetti, Aṅgavijja, Vatthuvijja. The country which is the domain of the Vasātī people is Vāsāta, Udumbara trees are found in this country, thus Udumbara is a country.

original: Sahassena nibbattā sāhassī parikhā, payasā nibbattaṃ pāyāsaṃ, sahassaṃ arahatīti sāhassī gāthā, ayaso vikāro āyaso. Evaṃ sovaṇṇo, puriso parimāṇamassāti porisaṃ udakaṃ.
analyzed: sahassena nibbattā sāhassī parikhā payasā nibbattam pāyāsam sahassam arahati iti sāhassī gāthā ayasaḥ vikāraḥ āyasaḥ evam sovaṇṇaḥ puriso parimāṇam assa ati porisam udakam
translated: The moat built with a thousand (coins) is Sāhassī, the milk-rice made with milk is pāyāsa, one who deserves a thousand is Sāhassī verse, the transformation of ayasa is āyasa. So is the case with Sovaṇṇa, Porisa, Porisaṃ udakaṃ.

original: Caggahaṇena tattha jāto, tattha vasati, tassa hitaṃ, taṃ arahatītiādīsu ṇeyyappaccayo.
analyzed: ca ggahaṇena tattha jātaḥ tattha vasati tassa hitam tam arahati iti ādīsu ṇa iyya ppaccayaḥ
translated: In such words as ‘one born there’, ‘one who lives there’, ‘what is beneficial to him’, ‘what he deserves’, etc., the ṇeyya affix is used.

original: Bārāṇasiyaṃ jāto, vasatīti vā bārāṇaseyyako, pure viya kakārāgamo. Evaṃ campeyyako,
analyzed: bārāṇasiyam jātaḥ vasati iti vā bārāṇaseyyakaḥ pure evam campeyyakaḥ
translated: One born in Bārāṇasī, or lives there, is a Bārāṇaseyyaka, the letter ka is added as in the word pura. So is the case with Campeyyaka,

original: sāgaleyyako, mithileyyako jano, gaṅgeyyo maccho, silāya jātaṃ seleyyakaṃ, kule jāto🔽koleyyako sunakho, vane jātaṃ vāneyyaṃ pupphaṃ. Evaṃ pabbateyyo mānuso, pabbateyyā🔽nadī, pabbateyyaṃ osadhaṃ, pathassa hitaṃ pātheyyaṃ, sapatissa hitaṃ sāpateyyaṃ dhanaṃ,
analyzed: sāgaleyyakaḥ mithileyyakaḥ janaḥ gaṅgeyyaḥ macchaḥ silāya jātam seleyyakam kule jātaḥ  koleyyakaḥ sunakhaḥ vane jātam vāneyyam puppham evam pabbateyyaḥ mānusaḥ pabbateyyā  nadī pabbateyyam osadham pathassa hitam pātheyyam sapatissa hitam sāpateyyam dhanam
translated: the people of Sāgala, the fish of the Ganges, the Seta fruit growing on a rock, the dog born in the family,🔽the dog of the forest, the flower of the forest. So too: the man of the mountain, the river of the mountain, the herb of the mountain, what is useful for the path, wealth useful for an enemy,🔽wealth.

original: padīpeyyaṃ telaṃ, mātu hitaṃ matteyyaṃ. Evaṃ petteyyaṃ. Dakkhiṇamarahatīti dakkhiṇeyyo iccādi.
analyzed: padīpeyyam telam mātu hitam matteyyam evam petteyyam dakkhiṇam arahati iti iccādi
translated: The people of Sāgala are Sāgaleyyakas, the people of Mithilā are Mithileyyakas. The fish of the Ganges is a Gaṅgeyya. The Sealeyya is that which is produced from the stone. He who is born in the family is a Koleyyaka. The dog is a Sunakhaka. The flower produced in the forest is a Vāneyya. In the same way, the human being of the mountain is a Pabbateyya. The river of the mountain is a Pabbateyyā. The herb of the mountain is a Pabbateyya. That which is beneficial to the path is a Pātheyya. The wealth which is beneficial to the enemy is a Sāpateyya. The oil for the lamp is a Padīpeyya. That which is beneficial to the mother is a Matteyya. In the same way, a Petteyya. He who is worthy of the gift is a Dakkhiṇeyya.

original: 378. Jātādīnamimiyā ca.🔽Jātaiccevamādīnaṃ saddānaṃ atthe ima iyaiccete paccayā honti vā.
analyzed: jāta ādi inamimiyā ca  jāta e c ca evamādīnam saddānam atthe ime iyai c ca ete paccayāḥ honti vā
translated: . And also imi in the sense of born, etc.

original: Pacchā jāto pacchimo, pacchimā janatā, pacchimaṃ cittaṃ, ante jāto antimo, antimā, antimaṃ. Evaṃ majjhimo, purimo, uparimo, heṭṭhimo, paccantimo, gopphimo, ganthimo.
analyzed: pacchā jātaḥ pacchimaḥ pacchimā janatā pacchimam cittam ante jātaḥ antimaḥ antimā antimam evam majjhimaḥ purimaḥ uparimaḥ heṭṭhimaḥ paccantimaḥ gopphimaḥ ganthimaḥ
translated: The words born, etc., have the following synonyms: Pacchā jāto = pacchimo, the last, the youngest. Pacchimā janatā = pacchimaṃ cittaṃ, the last thought. Ante jāto = antimo, the last, the youngest. Antimo = antimā, the last, the youngest. Antimo = antimaṃ, the last, the youngest. In the same way, majjhimo, middle, purimo, first, uparimo, upper, heṭṭhimo, lower, paccantimo, farthest, gopphimo, fleshy, ganthimo, knotty.

original: Tathā iyappaccaye manussajātiyā jāto manussajātiyo, manussajātiyā, manussajātiyaṃ. Evaṃ assajātiyo, hatthijātiyo, bodhisattajātiyo, dabbajātiyo, samānajātiyo, lokiyo iccādi.
analyzed: tathā iyappaccaye manussa jātiyā jātaḥ manussa jātiyaḥ manussa jātiyā manussa jātiyam evam assa jātiyaḥ hatthi jātiyaḥ bodhisatta jātiyaḥ dabba jātiyaḥ samāna jātiyaḥ lokiyaḥ iccādi
translated: Likewise, born in the human race, he is of the human race, in the human race, in the human race. So too, of the horse race, of the elephant race, of the Bodhisatta race, of the Dabba race, of the same race, of the world, and so on.

original: Ādiggahaṇena tattha niyutto, tadassa atthi, tattha bhavotiādīsvapi ima iyappaccayā
analyzed: ādi ggahaṇena tattha niyuttaḥ tat assa atthi tattha bhava iti ādīsu api ime iyappaccayā
translated: By the word “etc.” are included here “bound to that,” “he has that,” “his existence in that,” and so on.🔽And by the word “also” is included the “having that”

original: honti, casaddena ikappaccayo ca. Ante niyutto antimo, antiyo, antiko, putto assa
analyzed: honti ca saddena i ka ppaccayaḥ ca ante niyuttaḥ antimaḥ antiyaḥ antikaḥ puttaḥ assa
translated: “Bound to the end” is the last, the end, the endmost. “Son of him” is his son.

original: atthi, tasmiṃ vā vijjatīti puttimo, puttiyo, vuttiko, kappo assa atthīti kappiyo,
analyzed: atthi tasmin vā vijjati iti puttimaḥ puttiyo vuttiko kappaḥ assa atthi iti kappiyo
translated: “He has it” or “it exists in him” is his son’s son, his son’s son’s son, his son’s daughter, his son’s son’s daughter, his son’s daughter’s son.

original: jaṭā assa atthīti jaṭiyo, hānabhāgo assa atthīti hānabhāgiyo. Evaṃ ṭhitibhāgiyo,
analyzed: jaṭā assa atthi iti jaṭiyaḥ hāna bhāgaḥ assa atthi iti hāna bhāgiyaḥ evam ṭhiti bhāgiyaḥ
translated: “He has a topknot” is a topknotter. “He has a part of loss” is a part of losser. So too, a part of stability,

original: bodhissa pakkhe bhavā bodhipakkhiyā, pañcavagge bhavā pañcavaggiyā. Evaṃ chabbaggiyā,
analyzed: bodhissa pakkhe bhavā bodhi pakkhiyā pañcavagge bhavā pañcavaggiyā evam chabbaggiyā
translated: “The side of the enlightenment” is a side of enlightenment. “The five groups” is a group of five. So too, a group of six,

original: udariyaṃ, attano idanti attaniyaṃ, nakārāgamo.
analyzed: udariyam attanaḥ idanti attaniyam nakāra āgamaḥ
translated: “His own this” is his own. The affix nak is added.

original: Casaddaggahaṇena kiya yaṇyappaccayā ca. Jātiyā niyutto jātikiyo. Evaṃ andhakiyo, jaccandhe niyutto jaccandhakiyo. Sassa ayanti sakiyo. Evaṃ parakiyo.
analyzed: ca sadda gahaṇena ca jātiyā niyuttaḥ jāti kiyaḥ evam andha kiyaḥ jat candhe niyuttaḥ jat candha kiyaḥ sassa sa kiyaḥ evam para kiyaḥ
translated: The affix -ya is added to the words casadha and niyutta to make casadhakiya and niyuttakiya. The affix -ya is added to the words andha and jaccandha to make andhakiya and jaccandhaka. The affix -ya is added to the words sassa and parassa to make sakiya and parakiya.

original: Yappaccayo sādhuhitabhavajātādiatthesu. Yathā – kammani sādhu kammaññaṃ. Sabhāyaṃ🔽sādhu sabbhaṃ, “yavataṃ talanā”dinā ukārādi. Evaṃ medhāya hitaṃ mejjhaṃ ghaṭaṃ. Pādānaṃ
analyzed: yad paccayaḥ sādhu hita bhava jāta ādi atthesu yathā kammani sādhu kammaññam sabhāyam  sādhu sabbham ukāra ādi evam medhāya hitam mejjham ghaṭam pādānam
translated: The affix -ya is added to the words sādhu, hitabhava, jāti, etc., to make sādhuya, hitabhavaya, jātiya, etc.🔽The affix -ya is added to the words kamman, sabhā, etc., to make kammanyaya, sabbhaya, etc.

original: hitaṃ pajjaṃ telaṃ, rathassa hitā racchā, gāme bhavo gammo, gave bhavaṃ gabyaṃ, “osare🔽cā”ti sutte casaddena yappaccaye parepi avādeso. Kavimhi bhavaṃ kabyaṃ, divi bhavā🔽dibyā, thanato jātaṃ thaññaṃ, dhanāya saṃvattatīti dhaññaṃ.
analyzed: hitam pajjam telam rathassa hitā racchā gāme bhavaḥ gammaḥ gave bhavam gabyam osare  ca ati sutte ca saddena ya p paccaye pare pi a v ādesaḥ kavimhi bhavam kabyam divi bhavā  dibyā thanataḥ jātam thaññam dhanāya saṃvattati iti dhaññam
translated: The affix -ya is added to the words medha, pāda, ratha, gāma, gava, osara, kavi, diva, thana, dhana, etc., to make mejjhaya, pajja, racchāya, gammaya, gabbaya, kabbaya, dibbaya, thaññaya, dhaññaya, etc.

original: Ṇyappaccayo parisāyaṃ sādhu pārisajjo, dakārāgamo, samaṇānaṃ hitā sāmaññā janā, brāhmaṇānaṃ hitā brāhmaññā, arūpe bhavā āruppā iccādi.
analyzed: ṇi ap paccayaḥ parisāyam sādhu pārisajjaḥ dakāra āgamaḥ samaṇānam hitā sāmaññāḥ janāḥ brāhmaṇānam hitāḥ brāhmaññāḥ arūpe bhavāḥ āruppāḥ iccādi
translated: The affix -ya is added to the words parisā, samaṇa, brāhmaṇa, arūpa, etc., to make pārisajjhaya, sāmaññhaya, brāhmaññhaya, ārupphaya, etc.

original: “Rājaputtānaṃ samūho”ti viggahe –
analyzed: rāja puttānam samūhaḥ ti viggahe
translated: In the analysis of the word rājaputtānaṃ samūho,

original: 379. Samūhatthe kaṇaṇā.
analyzed: samūha atthe kaṇaṇā
translated: The -ā- is in the place of -aṇ-

original: Chaṭṭhiyantato “tesaṃ samūho”ti atthe kaṇaṇaiccete paccayā honti. Rājaputtako, rājaputtakaṃ🔽vā, rājaputto. Evaṃ mānussako, mānusso, māthurako, māthuro, porisako, poriso, vuddhānaṃ🔽samūho vuddhako, vuddho. Evaṃ māyūrako, māyūro, kāpoto, kokilo, māhiṃsako, māhiṃso,🔽oṭṭhako, orabbhako, aṭṭhannaṃ samūho aṭṭhako, rājānaṃ samūho rājako, bhikkhānaṃ samūho🔽bhikkho, sikkhānaṃ samūho sikkho, dvinnaṃ samūho dvayaṃ, “tesu vuddhī”tiādinā ikārassa
analyzed: tesam samūhaḥ iti atthe kaṇaṇa e c ca ete paccayāḥ honti rāja puttakaḥ rāja puttakam  vā rāja putto evam mānussakaḥ mānussaḥ māthurakaḥ māthuraḥ porisakaḥ porisaḥ vuddhānam  samūhaḥ vuddhakaḥ vuddhaḥ evam māyūrakaḥ māyūraḥ kāpotaḥ kokilaḥ māhiṃsakaḥ māhiṃsaḥ  oṭṭhakaḥ orabbhakaḥ aṭṭhannam samūhaḥ aṭṭhakaḥ rājānam samūhaḥ rājakaḥ bhikkhānam samūhaḥ  bhikkho sikkhānam samūhaḥ sikkho dvinnam samūhaḥ dvayam tesu vuddhi iti ādinā ikārassa
translated: The -ā- is in the place of -aṇ- in the sixth case plural. The words rājaputtakaṃ, rājaputtako, rājaputto are formed.

original: ayādeso. Evaṃ tiṇṇaṃ samūho tayaṃ iccādi.🔽“Samūhatthe”ti vattate.🔽380. Gāmajanabandhusahāyādīhi tā.🔽Gāmajanabandhusahāyaiccevamādīhi tāpaccayo hoti samūhatthe. Gāmānaṃ samūho gāmatā.
analyzed: evam tiṇṇam samūhaḥ iccādi 🔽samūha tthā iti vattate 🔽gāma jana bandhu sahāya ādīhi tā 🔽gāma jana bandhu sahāya e c ca ivamādīhi tāpa ccayaḥ hoti samūha atthe gāmānam samūhaḥ gāma tā
translated: So too: mānussaṃ, mānusakaṃ, mānusako, mānusso; māthuraṃ, māthurāni, māthurā, māthuraṃ, māthurāni, māthurā, māthuro, māthurako; porisaṃ, porisāni, porisā, porisaṃ, porisāni, porisā, poriso, porisako; vuddhaṃ, vuddhāni, vuddhā, vuddhaṃ, vuddhāni, vuddhā, vuddho, vuddhako; māyūraṃ, māyūrāni, māyūrā, māyūraṃ, māyūrāni, māyūrā, māyūro, māyūrako; kākaṃ, kākānī, kākānī, kākaṃ, kākānī, kākānī, kākato, kokilo; māhiṃsaṃ, māhisāni, māhisā, māhiṃsaṃ, māhisāni, māhisā, māhiṃso, māhiṃsako; oṭṭhaṃ, oṭṭhāni, oṭṭhā, oṭṭhaṃ, oṭṭhāni, oṭṭhā, oṭṭhako; orabbhaṃ, orabbhāni, orabbhā, orabbhaṃ, orabbhāni, orabbhā, orabbhako; aṭṭhaṃ, aṭṭhāni, aṭṭhā, aṭṭhaṃ, aṭṭhāni, aṭṭhā, aṭṭhako; rājaṃ, rājāni, rājā, rājaṃ, rājāni, rājā, rājāno, rājako; bhikkhaṃ, bhikkhāni, bhikkhā, bhikkhaṃ, bhikkhāni, bhikkhā, bhikkhu; sikkhā, sikkhāni, sik

original: Evaṃ janatā, bandhutā, sahāyatā, nāgaratā. “Tā”ti yogavibhāgena sakatthepi devoyeva
analyzed: evam jana tā bandhu tā sahāya tā nāgara tā tāti yogavibhāgena devoyā iva
translated: So also janatā, bandhutā, sahāyatā, nāgaratā. Tā means a god or goddess in the sense of a being who has attained a particular state by the power of yoga.

original: devatā, tāpaccayantassa niccamitthiliṅgatā.
analyzed: devatā nicca mitthi liṅga tā
translated: The feminine gender is invariable.

original: 381. Tadassa ṭhānamiyo ca.🔽“Tadassa ṭhāna”miccetasmiṃ atthe chaṭṭhiyantato iyappaccayo hoti. Madanassa ṭhānaṃ
analyzed: tad assa ca  tat assa ṭhānam icca etasmin atthe iyat paccayaḥ hoti madanassa ṭhānam
translated: . And the state of that.

original: madaniyo, madaniyā, madaniyaṃ, bandhanassa ṭhānaṃ bandhaniyaṃ. Evaṃ mucchaniyaṃ.
analyzed: madaniyaḥ madaniyā madaniyam bandhanassa ṭhānam bandhaniyam evam mucchaniyam
translated: The sixth-case form of the word denoting the state of that is the condition for the suffix iya. The state of madness is madaniyaṃ, madaniyā, madaniyaṃ. The state of bondage is bandhaniyaṃ. So also mucchaniyaṃ.

original: Rajaniyaṃ, gamaniyaṃ, dassaniyaṃ, upādāniyaṃ, pasādaniyaṃ. Casaddena hitādiatthepi
analyzed: rajaniyam gamaniyam dassaniyam upādāniyam pasādaniyam ca saddena hita ādi atthe pi
translated: Rajaniyaṃ, gamaniyaṃ, dassaniyaṃ, upādāniyaṃ, pasādaniyaṃ. And by the rule the state of what is beneficial, etc.,

original: upādānānaṃ hitā upādāniyā iccādi.
analyzed: hitāḥ iccādi
translated: is upādāniyā, etc.

original: 382. Upamatthāyitattaṃ.
analyzed: upamatthāyitattam
translated: . The state of being like.

original: Upamatthe upamāvāciliṅgato āyitattappaccayo hoti. Dhūmo viya dissatīti dhūmāyitattaṃ. Evaṃ timirāyitattaṃ.
analyzed: upama atthe upamā vāci liṅgataḥ āyi tatta paccayaḥ hoti dhūmaḥ viya dissati iti dhūma āyi tattam evam timira āyi tattam
translated: The suffix iytatta is added to the word denoting the state of being like, when the word denoting the state is in the feminine gender. It is seen as if it were smoke: dhūmāyitattaṃ. So also timirāyitattaṃ.

original: “Tadassa ṭhāna”nti vattate.
analyzed: tat assa ṭhānan ti vattate
translated: The state of that is said.

original: 383. Tannissitatthe lo.
analyzed: tad nissita tthe laḥ
translated: . Lo is the state of what is dependent on that.

original: “Tannissita”nti atthe, “tadassaṭhāna”nti atthe ca lappaccayo hoti. Duṭṭhu nissitaṃ, duṭṭhu ṭhānaṃ vā duṭṭhullaṃ, duṭṭhullā vācā, lassa dvibhāvo. Evaṃ vedallaṃ.
analyzed: tad nissitam ti atthe tad assa ṭhānam ti atthe ca la paccayaḥ hoti duṭṭhu nissitam duṭṭhu ṭhānam vā duṭṭhullam duṭṭhullā vācā lassa dvi bhāvaḥ evam vedallam
translated: The affix la is used in the sense of “dependent on that” and in the sense of “having that as its place.” The word duṭṭhullā is formed by adding the affix la to the word duṭṭhu in the sense of “dependent on that which is bad” or “having that which is bad as its place.”

original: “Abhijjhā assa pakati, abhijjhā assa bahulā”ti vā viggahe –🔽384. Ālu tabbahule.
analyzed: abhijjhā assa pakati abhijjhā assa bahulā ati vā viggahe  ālu tap bahule
translated: The word abhijjhālu is formed by adding the affix la to the word abhijjhā in the sense of “having abhijjhā as one’s nature” or “having abhijjhā as one’s abundance.”🔽The affix ālu is used in the sense of “abundant in that” when the first case is used.

original: Paṭhamāvibhatyantato āluppaccayo hoti “tadassa bahula”miccetasmiṃ atthe. Abhijjhālu,🔽abhijjhālū, abhijjhālavo. Evaṃ sītālu, dhajālu, dayālu. “Sabbato ko”ti ettha puna
analyzed: paṭhamā vibhati antataḥ ālup paccayaḥ hoti tat assa bahulam icca itasmin atthe abhijjhālu  evam ettha puna
translated: The word abhijjhālu is formed by adding the affix ālu to the word abhijjhā in the sense of “abundant in abhijjhā.”🔽The words sītālu, dhajālu, and dayālu are formed in the same way.

original: sabbatoggahaṇena kakārāgamo, abhijjhāluko, abhijjhālukā, abhijjhālukaṃ. Evaṃ sītāluko,🔽dayāluko, tathā hīnova hīnako. Evaṃ potako, kumārako, māṇavako, muduko, ujuko, appamattakaṃ,
analyzed: sabbatas gahaṇena kakāra āgamaḥ abhijjhālukaḥ abhijjhālukā abhijjhālukam evam sītālukaḥ  dayāluko tathā hīnaḥ uva hīnakaḥ evam potako kumārakaḥ māṇavakaḥ mudukaḥ ujukaḥ appamattakam
translated: The word abhijjhāluko is formed by adding the affix ko to the word abhijjhālu, using the word sabbato in the sense of “from all” to indicate that the affix ka is added.🔽The words sītāluko, dayāluko, and hīnako are formed in the same way.

original: oramattakaṃ, sīlamattakaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: oramattakam sīlamattakam iccādi
translated: The words potako, kumārako, māṇavako, muduko, ujuko, appamattakaṃ, oramattakaṃ, sīlamattakaṃ are formed in the same way.

original: “Yadanupapannā nipātanā sijjhantī”ti iminā paṭibhāgakucchitasaññānukampādiatthesu
analyzed: yat anupapannāḥ nipātanāḥ sijjhanti iti iminā paṭibhāga kucchita saññā anukampā ādi atthesu
translated: The affix la is used in the sense of “that which is not yet arisen” and in the sense of “that which is similar to the original,” “that which is contemptible,” “that which is compassionate,” and so on.

original: kappaccayo. Paṭibhāgatthe hatthino iva hatthikā. Evaṃ assakā. Kucchitatthe kucchito
analyzed: ka ppaccayaḥ paṭibhāga atthe hatthinaḥ iva hatthikāḥ evam assakā kucchita tthe kucchitaḥ
translated: is a compound word in the sense of cause. In the sense of a counterpart, as in elephant-man, horse-man. So too in the sense of a womb, as in womb-born.

original: samaṇo samaṇako. Evaṃ brāhmaṇako, muṇḍako, paṇḍitako, veyyākaraṇako. Saññāyaṃ katako,
analyzed: samaṇo samaṇakaḥ evam brāhmaṇakaḥ muṇḍako paṇḍitako veyyākaraṇako saññāyam katako
translated: A recluse, a recluse’s pupil. So too a brahmin’s pupil, a shaven-head, a wise man’s pupil, a grammarian’s pupil. In the sense of perception, as in a maker of perceptions.

original: bhaṭako. Anukampāyaṃ puttako.
analyzed: bhaṭakaḥ anukampā ayam puttakaḥ
translated: In the sense of compassion, as in a son.🔽So too in the sense of how much, as in how much is there? How much is this?

original: Tathā kiṃyatetato parimāṇatthe ttakavantuppaccayā. Kiṃ parimāṇamassāti kittakaṃ.🔽Evaṃ yattakaṃ, tattakaṃ, ettakaṃ. Vantumhi āttañca, yaṃ parimāṇamassāti yāvā, yāvanto,
analyzed: tathā kiṃyata itataḥ parimāṇa atthe ttaka vantup paccayā kim parimāṇam assa ati kittakam  evam yattakam tattakam ettakam vantumhi yam parimāṇam assa ati yāvāḥ yāvantaḥ
translated: In the sense of how many, as in how many are there? How many are these?🔽In the sense of how good, as in how good is this? So too in the sense of how much, as in how much is this?

original: guṇavantusamaṃ. Evaṃ tāvā, tāvanto. Etāvā, etāvanto iccādi.
analyzed: evam tāvā tāvantaḥ etāvā etāvantaḥ iccādi
translated: In the sense of how many, as in how many are these? In the sense of how good, as in how good is this?

original: “Suvaṇṇena pakata”nti viggahe –
analyzed: suvaṇṇena pakatanti viggahe
translated: In the analysis of the phrase “made of gold” –

original: 385. Tappakativacane mayo.
analyzed: tad pakativacane ma yaḥ
translated: . In the sense of how much, as in “made of” .

original: Tappakativacanatthe mayappaccayo hoti, pakarīyatīti pakati, tena pakati tappakati,
analyzed: tad pakati vacana tthe mayap paccayaḥ hoti pakarīyati iti pakati tena pakati tad pakati
translated: The affix maya is used in the sense of how much. The word pakati is derived from the verb pakarīyati . It is a how-much-ness.

original: tappakatiyā vacanaṃ kathanaṃ tappakativacanaṃ. Suvaṇṇamayo ratho, sovaṇṇamayo vā,
analyzed: tad pakatiyāḥ vacanam kathanam tad pakati vacanam suvaṇṇa mayaḥ rathaḥ sovaṇṇa mayaḥ vā
translated: The word vacana is derived from the verb vacati . It is a speaking. A chariot made of gold, or of gold-leaf.

original: suvaṇṇamayā bhājanavikati, suvaṇṇamayaṃ bhājanaṃ. Evaṃ rūpiyamayaṃ, rajatamayaṃ,🔽jatumayaṃ, dārumayaṃ, mattikāmayaṃ, iddhiyā nibbattaṃ iddhimayaṃ.
analyzed: suvaṇṇa mayāḥ suvaṇṇa mayam bhājanam evam rūpiya mayam rajata mayam  jatu mayam dāru mayam mattikā mayam iddhiyā nibbattam iddhi mayam
translated: a golden vessel is a golden vessel. So too a silver one, a copper one, a bronze one, a clay one, a magical one, a mind-made one, an iron one.

original: Manato nipphannā manomayā, ayasāpakataṃ ayomayaṃ. Ettha ca “manogaṇādīna”nti vattamāne –
analyzed: nipphannāḥ manaḥ mayāḥ ayasā apakatam ayaḥ mayam ettha ca vattamāne
translated: Herein, when it is said “of the man-group, etc.,”

original: 386. Etesamo lope.
analyzed: e te samaḥ lope
translated: . The elision of the final vowel.

original: Etesaṃ manogaṇādīnaṃ anto ottamāpajjate vibhattilope kateti okāro.
analyzed: etesam manaḥ gaṇa ādīnam antaḥ ottamā āpajjate vibhatti lope katā iti okāraḥ
translated: When the elision of the final vowel of the words man-group, etc., has been made, the final vowel of the preceding word becomes the vowel o.

original: Gavena pakataṃ karīsaṃ, goto nibbattanti vā gomayaṃ. “Mayo”tiyogavibhāgena sakatthepi dānameva dānamayaṃ, sīlamayaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: gavena pakatam karīsam gotaḥ nibbattanti vā gomayam dānam eva dāna mayam sīla mayam iccādi
translated: Cow-dung is made by cows; or cow-dung is produced from cows. “Made of” is a compound word in the sense of “having” . Thus: Generosity is of generosity, virtue is of virtue, and so on.🔽The -maya- compound is of many kinds, such as the “mixed” and so on.

original: Saṃsaṭṭhādianekatthataddhitaṃ.🔽Bhāvataddhita
analyzed: saṃsaṭṭha ādi aneka attha taddhitam  bhāva taddhita
translated: The -maya- compound in the sense of “state”

original: “Alasassa bhāvo”ti viggahe –
analyzed: alasassa bhāvaḥ ti viggahe
translated: When it is resolved thus: “The state of being poor,”

original: 387. Ṇyattatā bhāve tu.
analyzed: ṇyat tatā bhāve tu
translated: . The -maya- is in the sense of “state.”

original: Chaṭṭhiyantato ṇyattatāiccete paccayā honti “tassa bhāvo” iccetasmiṃ atthe, tusaddaggahaṇena
analyzed: chaṭṭhi yantataḥ ṇi a t ta tā it ca ete paccayāḥ honti tassa bhāvaḥ i cca itasmin atthe tu sadda gahaṇena
translated: The -maya- is in the sense of “state” when it has a locative case ending. The words “of that” are understood. The words “of that” are understood in the sense of “the state of that.”

original: ttanaṇeyyādippaccayā ca. Bhavanti etasmā buddhisaddā iti bhāvo, saddappavattinimittaṃ
analyzed: ca bhavanti etasmai buddhi saddāḥ iti bhāvaḥ sadda ppavatti nimittam
translated: and the suffixes -eyya, -ā, -ādi, -ppaccayo, etc.🔽The state of being is said to be the cause of the occurrence of the words for it.

original: vuccati, vuttañca – “yassa guṇassa hi bhāvā dabbe saddaniveso tadabhidhāneṇyattatādayo”ti.
analyzed: vuccati vuttam ca yassa guṇassa hi bhāvāḥ dabbe sadda niveso
translated: And it is said: “For the existence of a quality is the cause of the insertion of the word for it in the designation of that.”

original: Ṇyattattanantānaṃ niccaṃ napuṃsakattaṃ, tāpaccayantassa sabhāvato niccamitthiliṅgatā.
analyzed: ṇyat tat tanantānam niccam napuṃsaka ttam tā paccaya ntassa sa bhāvataḥ nicca mitthi liṅga tā
translated: The state of being is always neuter, and the state of being of a cause is always feminine by nature.🔽The suffix -ya is used in the sense of a quality with the words brāhmaṇa, etc.,

original: Ṇyappaccayoyaṃ guṇavacane brāhmaṇādīhi, tattha “avaṇṇo ye lopañcā”ti avaṇṇalopo, ādivuddhi.
analyzed: guṇavacane brāhmaṇa ādīhi tattha avaṇṇaḥ ye avaṇṇa lopaḥ ādi vuddhi
translated: where there is loss of the vowel a, and the augment -i- is added.🔽Laziness.

original: Ālasyaṃ. Evaṃ ārogyaṃ, udaggassa bhāvo odagyaṃ, sakhino bhāvo sakhyaṃ, aṇaṇassa bhāvo āṇaṇyaṃ, vidhavāya bhāvo vedhabyaṃ, dubbalassa bhāvo dubbalyaṃ, capalassa bhāvo cāpalyaṃ.
analyzed: ālasyam evam ārogyam udaggassa bhāvaḥ odagyam sakhinaḥ bhāvaḥ sakhyam aṇaṇassa bhāvaḥ āṇaṇyam vidhavāya bhāvaḥ vedhabyam dubbalassa bhāvaḥ dubbalyam capalassa bhāvaḥ cāpalyam
translated: Thus health, uprightness, friendship, freedom from debt, widowhood, weakness, and fickleness.

original: Viyattassa bhāvo veyyattiyaṃ, maccharassa bhāvo macchariyaṃ. Evaṃ issariyaṃ, ālasiyaṃ, muṇḍiyaṃ, mūḷhiyaṃ. Ettha “veyyattiya”ntiādīsu “tesu vuddhī”tiādinā yamhi ikārāgamo.🔽“Paṇḍitassa bhāvo paṇḍitya”ntiādīsu “yavataṃ talanadakārānaṃ byañjanāni calañajakāratta”nti
analyzed: viyattassa bhāvaḥ veyyattiyam maccharassa bhāvaḥ macchariyam evam issariyam ālasiyam muṇḍiyam mūḷhiyam ettha veyyattiya nti ādīsu tesu vuddhi iti ādinā yamhi ikāra āgamaḥ  paṇḍitassa bhāvaḥ byañjanāni
translated: The state of being clever is cleverness. The state of being stingy is stinginess. So too: the state of being powerful is power, the state of being lazy is laziness, the state of being bald is baldness, the state of being confused is confusion. Herein, in the words veyyattiya, macchariya, etc., the i of the first syllable becomes a by the rule given in the next section “tesu vuddhī” , etc.

original: tyakārasaṃyogādīnaṃ calañajakārādesā, dvittaṃ. Paṇḍiccaṃ, bahussutassa bhāvo bāhussaccaṃ,
analyzed: tyakāra saṃyoga ādīnam calaña jakāra ādesāḥ dvittam paṇḍiccam bahussutassa bhāvaḥ bāhussaccam
translated: In the words paṇḍitya, bāhussacca, etc., the a of the first syllable becomes a by the rule given in the next section “yavataṃ talanadakārānaṃ byañjanāni calañajakāratta” , etc. The second syllable is the same as the first. So too: the state of being wise is wisdom, the state of being learned is learning,

original: “tesu vuddhī”tiādinā ukārassa akāro, evaṃ porohiccaṃ, adhipatissa bhāvo ādhipaccaṃ,
analyzed: tesu vuddhi iti ādinā ukārassa akāraḥ evam porohiccam adhipatissa bhāvaḥ ādhipaccam
translated: by the rule given in the next section “tesu vuddhī” , etc., the u of the first syllable becomes a. So too: the state of being a priest is priesthood, the state of being a lord is lordship,

original: muṭṭhassatissa bhāvo muṭṭhassaccaṃ, ivaṇṇalopo. Kusalassa bhāvo kosallaṃ. Evaṃ vepullaṃ,
analyzed: muṭṭhassatissa bhāvaḥ muṭṭhassaccam i vaṇṇa lopaḥ kusalassa bhāvaḥ kosallam evam vepullam
translated: the state of being forgetful is forgetfulness, the vowel i is elided. The state of being skilful is skill. So too: the state of being extensive is extent,

original: samānānaṃ bhāvo sāmaññaṃ, gilānassa bhāvo gelaññaṃ, “kvacādimajjhuttarā”disuttena
analyzed: samānānam bhāvaḥ sāmaññam gilānassa bhāvaḥ gelaññam kvaca ādi majjhuttara ādi suttena
translated: the state of being the same is sameness, the state of being sick is sickness. By the rule given in the next section “kvacādimajjhuttarā” , etc.,

original: saṃyoge pare rassattaṃ.
analyzed: saṃyoge pare raḥ sattam
translated: the first syllable becomes the same as the second in compounds denoting connection.

original: Suhadassa bhāvosohajjaṃ. Evaṃ vesārajjaṃ, kusīdassabhāvokosajjaṃ, “tesu vuddhī”tiādinā🔽īkārassa akāro. Tathā “purisassa bhāvo porisa”ntiādīsu “yavataṃ talanā”disutte kāraggahaṇena
analyzed: suhadassa bhāvosohajjam evam vesārajjam kusīdassabhāvokosajjam tesu vuddhi iti ādinā  īkārassa akāraḥ tathā purisassa bhāvaḥ talana ādi sutte kāra ggahaṇena
translated: The state of one who is kindly is kindness. analyzed: guṇaḥ yācaka ttam yācaka tā kriyā daṇḍittam daṇḍitā dabbam saccavādi tā pāramitā
translated: The quality is guṇa, the state of the beggar is yācakattaṃ, yācakatā, the action is kriyā, the state of being punished is daṇḍittaṃ, daṇḍitā, the truth-telling is saccavāditā, the perfection is pāramitā,

original: bhassārāmatā, niddārāmatā, lahutā iccādi.
analyzed: bhassārāmatā niddārāmatā lahutā iccādi
translated: bhassārāmatā, niddārāmatā, lahutā, etc.

original: Ttanapaccaye – puthujjanassa bhāvo puthujjanattanaṃ, vedanattanaṃ, jāyattanaṃ.
analyzed: ttana paccaye puthujjanassa bhāvaḥ puthujjanattanam vedanattanam jāyattanam
translated: In the case of the state-of-the-affair-of-that-is-the-basis, the state of the worldling is puthujjanattanaṃ, vedanattanaṃ, jāyattanaṃ.

original: Ṇeyye – sucissa bhāvo soceyyaṃ. Evaṃ ādhipabheyyaṃ, kavissa bhāvokāveyyaṃ, thenassa bhāvo theyyaṃ, mahāvuttinā nakārassa lopo.
analyzed: ṇeyye sucissa bhāvaḥ soceyyam evam ādhipabheyyam kavissa bhāvaḥ kāveyyam thenassa bhāvaḥ theyyam mahāvuttinā nakārassa lopaḥ
translated: In the case of the state-of-the-affair-of-that-is-the-object-of-the-verb, the state of the pure is soceyyaṃ. So too ādhipabheyyaṃ, kavissa bhāvokāveyyaṃ, thenassa bhāvo theyyaṃ, by mahāvutti the nakāra is dropped.

original: “Ṇyattatā”ti yogavibhāgena kammani, sakatthe ca ṇyādayo, vīrānaṃ bhāvo, kammaṃ vā🔽vīriyaṃ, paribhaṭassa kammaṃ pāribhaṭyaṃ, pāribhaṭyassa bhāvo pāribhaṭyatā. Evaṃ
analyzed: yogavibhāgena kammani sa katthe ca ṇi ādayaḥ bhāvaḥ kammam vā  vīriyam paribhaṭassa kammam pāribhaṭyam pāribhaṭyassa bhāvaḥ pāribhaṭya tā evam
translated: “The state of being even” is the state of being even in the sense of workability, and the state of being even in the sense of what is right.🔽“The state of being energetic” is the state of being energetic in the sense of the energy of heroes, and in the sense of work.

original: sovacassatā, bhisaggassa kammaṃ bhesajjaṃ, byāvaṭassa kammaṃ veyyāvaccaṃ, saṭhassa
analyzed: bhisaggassa kammam bhesajjam byāvaṭassa kammam veyyāvaccam saṭhassa
translated: “The state of being a servant” is the state of being a servant in the sense of work for wages, and in the sense of the state of being a servant.

original: bhāvo, kammaṃ vā sāṭheyyaṃ.
analyzed: bhāvaḥ kammam vā sāṭheyyam
translated: “The state of being obedient” is the state of being obedient in the sense of work, and in the sense of the state of being obedient.🔽“The state of being a medicine” is the state of being a medicine in the sense of work, and in the sense of the state of being a medicine.🔽“The state of being a fraud” is the state of being a fraud in the sense of work, and in the sense of the state of being a fraud.

original: Sakatthe pana – yathābhūtameva yathābhuccaṃ, karuṇāyeva kāruññaṃ, pattakālameva pattakallaṃ, ākāsānantameva ākāsānañcaṃ, kāyapāguññameva kāyapāguññatā iccādi.
analyzed: saka atthe pana yathābhūtam eva yathābhuccam karuṇāya iva kāruññam pattakālam eva pattakallam ākāsānantam eva ākāsānañcam kāyapāguññam eva kāyapāguñña tā iccādi
translated: But in the sense of what is right: “The state of being as it really is” is the state of being as it really is; “the state of being compassionate” is the state of being compassionate; “the state of being timely” is the state of being timely; “the state of being the base of infinite space” is the state of being the base of infinite space; “the state of being the excellence of the body” is the state of being the excellence of the body, and so on.

original: “Visamassa bhāvo”ti viggahe –
analyzed: visamassa bhāvaḥ ti viggahe
translated: “The state of being uneven” is the state of being uneven in the sense of work.🔽“The state of being” is said.

original: “Ttatā, bhāve”ti ca vattate.🔽388. Ṇa visamādīhi.
analyzed: bhāva iti ca vattate  ṇa visamādīhi
translated: “The state of being uneven” and so on.

analyzed: visama e t ca evamādīhi chaṭṭhi yantehi ṇa ppaccayaḥ hoti tta tā ca tassa bhāvaḥ i t ca etasmin
translated: The state of being uneven and so on is the state of being uneven, etc., in the sense of work, and in the sense of the state of being uneven, etc.

original: atthe. Ākatigaṇoyaṃ. Vesamaṃ, visamattaṃ, visamatā. Sucissa bhāvo socaṃ, sucittaṃ,

translated: “The state of being good” is the state of being good in the sense of work, and in the sense of the state of being good.

analyzed: sabbassa eva bāḷha saddassa sādha ādesaḥ hoti iyiṭṭhesu visesena bāḷhaḥ iti sādhiyaḥ  appassa kaṇa  sabbassa appa saddassa kaṇa hoti visesena appo ti kaṇiyaḥ kaṇiṭṭhaḥ
translated: . The affix -iyo is added to all words meaning ‘small’ in the sense of ‘inferior’. In particular, appo becomes kaṇiyo, kaṇiṭṭho.

original: “Visesena yuvā”ti atthe “kaṇa”iti vattate.🔽396. Yuvānañca.🔽Sabbassa yuvasaddassa kaṇa hoti iyiṭṭhesu. “Tesu vuddhī”tiādinā ṇakārassa nakāro. Kaniyo, kaniṭṭho.🔽397. Vantu mantu vīnañca lopo.🔽Vantumantuvī iccetesaṃ paccayānaṃ lopo hoti iyiṭṭhesu. Sabbe ime guṇavanto ayamimesaṃ
analyzed: visesena yuvāti atthe kaṇaiti vattate  yuvānañca  sabbassa yuva saddassa ka ṇa hoti iyiṭṭhesu tesu vuddhi iti ādinā ṇakārassa nakāraḥ kaniyaḥ kaniṭṭhaḥ  vantu mantu vīnañca lopo  vantu mantuvī icca etesam paccayānam lopaḥ hoti iyiṭṭhesu sabbe ime guṇavantaḥ ayam imesam
translated: The word kaṇa is used in the sense of ‘in particular, young’.

original: visesena guṇavāti guṇiyo, guṇiṭṭho, visesena satimāti satiyo, satiṭṭho, visesena🔽medhāvīti medhiyo, medhiṭṭho iccādi.🔽Visesataddhitaṃ.🔽Assatthitaddhita🔽“Medhā yassa atthi, tasmiṃ vā vijjatī”ti viggahe –🔽398. Tadassatthīti vī ca.
