original: Paṭhamāvibhatyantā “tadassa atthi, tasmiṃ vā vijjati” iccetesvatthesu vīpaccayo hoti.
analyzed: paṭhamā vibhati antā tat assa atthi tasmin vā vijjati it ca i tesu atthesu vīpaccayaḥ hoti
translated: The first-case ending in the words “tadassa atthi, tasmiṃ vā vijjati” is the locative case.🔽This is the locative case in the words “medhā, māyā, saddā”.

original: Medhāmāyā saddehi cāyaṃ. Medhāvī, medhāvino. Itthiyaṃ īkārantattā “patibhikkhurājīkārantehi
analyzed: medhā māyā saddehi ca ayam medhāvī medhāvino itthiyam īkāra anta ttā pati bhikkhu rājīkāra antehi
translated: The feminine form is medhāvinī, medhāviniyo.🔽The neuter form is medhāvi kulaṃ.

original: inī”ti inī, medhāvinī, medhāviniyo. Napuṃsake medhāvi kulaṃ. Evaṃ māyāvī, māyāvinī, māyāvi cittaṃ.
analyzed: inī iti inī medhāvinī medhāviniyaḥ napuṃsake medhāvi kulam evam māyāvī māyāvinī māyāvi cittam
translated: The masculine form is medhāvī.🔽The locative case is included by the word “ca” in the words “so, i, lava, ā, lādi”.

original: Caggahaṇena so i lava ālādippaccayā ca. Yathā – sumedhā yassa atthi, tasmiṃ vā vijjatīti
analyzed: ca ggahaṇena saḥ i lavaḥ āla ādi ppaccayā ca yathā sumedhā yassa atthi tasmin vā vijjati iti
translated: The locative case is in the words “sumedhā, yassa atthi, tasmiṃ vā vijjati”.

original: sumedhaso, rassattaṃ. Evaṃ lomaso. Picchaṃ assa atthi, tasmiṃ vā vijjatīti picchilo.
analyzed: sumedhasaḥ evam lomasaḥ piccham assa atthi tasmin vā vijjati iti picchilaḥ
translated: The locative case is in the words “lomaso, picchaṃ, assa atthi, tasmiṃ vā vijjati”.

original: Evaṃ phenilo, tuṇḍilo, jaṭilo. Kesā assa atthīti kesavo, vācālo iccādi.
analyzed: evam phenilaḥ tuṇḍilaḥ jaṭilaḥ kesāḥ assa atthi iti kesavaḥ vācālaḥ iccādi
translated: The locative case is in the words “phenilo, tuṇḍilo, jaṭilo, kesā, assa atthīti kesavo, vācālo”.

original: “Tapo assa atthi, tasmiṃ vā vijjatī”ti viggahe –
analyzed: tapaḥ assa atthi tasmin vā vijjati iti viggahe
translated: The locative case is in the words “tapo, assa atthi, tasmiṃ vā vijjati”.

original: “Tadassatthī”ti adhikāro.
analyzed: tat assa atthi iti adhikāraḥ
translated: The locative case is in the words “tadassatthī”.

original: 399. Tapādito sī.
analyzed: tapa ādi taḥ sī
translated: The locative case is in the words “tapo, ādito, sī”.

original: Tapaiccevamādito sīpaccayo hoti “tadassatthi” iccetasmiṃ atthe. Sassa dvibhāvo. Tapassī, tapassino, tapassinī, tapassi. Evaṃ tejassī, yasassī, manassī, payassī.🔽“Daṇḍo assa atthi, tasmiṃ vā vijjatī”ti viggahe –🔽400. Daṇḍādito ikaī.
analyzed: tapa e t ca evam āditaḥ sī paccayaḥ hoti tat assa atthi icca etasmin atthe sassa dvi bhāvaḥ tapassī tapassino tapassinī tapassī evam tejassī yasassī manassī payassī  daṇḍaḥ assa atthi tasmin vā vijjati iti viggahe  daṇḍa āditaḥ i ka ī
translated: The affix -ī is added to the words tapa, teja, yasa, mana, and paya in the sense of “having that” in the sense of “having heat, etc.”

original: Ādisaddoyaṃ pakārattho, daṇḍaiccevamādito avaṇṇantā ika ī iccete paccayā honti “tadassatthi”🔽iccetasmiṃ atthe. Daṇḍiko, daṇḍī, daṇḍino, daṇḍinī. Evaṃ māliko, mālī, mālinī, chattiko,
analyzed: ādi saddaḥ yam pakāra atthaḥ daṇḍa e t ca ivamāditaḥ a vaṇṇa ntāḥ i kaḥ ī iti ca ete paccayāḥ honti tat assa atthi  iccā itasmin atthe daṇḍikaḥ daṇḍī daṇḍinaḥ daṇḍinī evam mālikaḥ mālī mālinī chattikaḥ
translated: The affix -ī is added to the word daṇḍa in the sense of “having a stick, etc.”

original: chattī, rūpiko, rūpī, kesiko, kesī, saṅghī, ñāṇī, hatthī iccādi.🔽401. Madhvādito ro.🔽Madhuādito rappaccayo hoti “tadassatthī”ti atthe. Madhu assa atthi, tasmiṃ vā vijjatīti
analyzed: chattī rūpikaḥ rūpī kesikaḥ kesī saṅghī ñāṇī hatthī iccādi  madhu āditaḥ ro  madhu āditaḥ ra p paccayaḥ hoti tat assa atthi iti atthe madhu assa atthi tasmin vā vijjati iti
translated: The affix -ī is added to the words daṇḍa, māla, chatta, rūpa, kesā, saṅgha, ñāṇa, and hattha in the sense of “having a stick, etc.”🔽The affix -ī is added to the word madhu in the sense of “having that”

original: madhuro guḷo, madhurā sakkharā, madhuraṃ khīraṃ, kuñjā hanū etassa santīti kuñjaro,
analyzed: madhuraḥ guḷaḥ madhurā sakkharā madhuram khīram kuñjā hanū etassa santi iti kuñjaraḥ
translated: The affix -ī is added to the word madhu in the sense of “having that” in the sense of “having honey.”🔽The affix -ī is added to the words kuñja, and guḷa in the sense of “having that” in the sense of “having a thicket, etc.”

original: sabbasmiṃ vattabbe mukhamassa atthīti mukharo, susi assa atthīti susiro. Evaṃ ruciro, nagaro.
analyzed: sabbasmim vattabbe mukham assa atthi iti mukharaḥ susi assa atthi iti susiraḥ evam ruciraḥ nagaraḥ
translated: He has a mouth in all matters to be spoken of, thus he is a “talker” (mukharo); he has a good one, thus he is a “good-mouth” (susiro). So also “bright” (rucira), “city” (nagara).

original: “Guṇo assa atthi, tasmiṃ vā vijjatī”ti viggahe –
analyzed: guṇaḥ assa atthi tasmin vā vijjati iti viggahe
translated: In the analysis “He has a quality, or it exists in him” (guṇo assa atthi, tasmiṃ vā vijjati)🔽. The suffix -vant is added to guṇa, etc.

original: 402. Guṇāditovantu.
analyzed: guṇa āditas vantu
translated: Guṇāditovantu.🔽The suffix -vant is added to guṇa, etc., in the sense “He has that” (tadassa atthi).

original: Guṇaiccevamādito vantuppaccayo hoti “tadassa atthī”ti atthe. Vibhattilope, nāmabyapadese
analyzed: guṇa e t ca ivamāditaḥ hoti tat assa atthi iti atthe vibhatti lope nāma byapadese
translated: When the case-ending is elided and the name-base is formed,

original: ca kate syādyuppatti. Guṇavantu si, “savibhattissa, ntussā”ti adhikicca “ā simhī”ti
analyzed: ca kate sya ādi uppatti guṇavantu si sa vibhattissa n tussa ati adhikicca ā simhi iti
translated: the augment -y- is added. Guṇavantu si. “When the case-ending is present, the augment -y- is added to ntu” (1.2.45).

original: āttaṃ, guṇavā puriso, sesaṃ ñeyyaṃ. Evaṃ gaṇavā, kulavā iccādayo. Itthiyaṃ “ṇava🔽ṇika ṇeyyaṇantūhī”ti īpaccayo, “vā”ti vattamāne “ntussa tamīkāre”ti takāro, guṇavatī,
analyzed: āttam guṇavā puriso sesam ñeyyam evam gaṇavā kulavā icca ādayaḥ itthiyam ṇava  ṇika ṇeyya ṇa ntūhi iti ī paccayaḥ vāti vattamāne ntussa tamīkāre iti takāraḥ guṇavatī
translated: The augment -y- is elided by ā. Guṇavā puriso. The rest should be understood. So also guṇavā, kulavā, etc. In the feminine,🔽the augment -ī is added by īpaccayo, “ṇava ṇika ṇeyya ṇantu ṇūhi” (4.1.163). “When the augment -ī is added, ntu becomes -t- in the present tense” (4.1.164). Takāro. Guṇavatī, guṇavantī, etc. In the neuter,

original: guṇavantī iccādi. Napuṃsake “aṃ napuṃsake”ti savibhattissa ntussa amādeso, guṇavaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: guṇavantī iccādi napuṃsake am napuṃsaka iti sa vibhattissa n tussa am ādesaḥ guṇavān iccādi
translated: the augment -am is added to ntu by aṃ napuṃsake “when the case-ending is present” (4.1.165). Guṇavaṃ, etc.

original: “Sati assa atthi, tasmiṃ vā vijjatī”ti viggahe –
analyzed: sati assa atthi tasmin vā vijjati iti viggahe
translated: In the analysis “He has truth, or it exists in him” (sati assa atthi, tasmiṃ vā vijjati)

original: “Tadassatthī”ti vattate.
analyzed: tat assatthi iti vattate
translated: . The word tadassatthī is used.

original: 493. Satyādīhi mantu.
analyzed: satya ādīhi mantu
translated: . Satyādīhi mantu.

original: Satiiccevamādīhi avaṇṇantarahitehi paṭhamāvibhatyantehi liṅgehi mantuppaccayo hoti
analyzed: sati it ca evamādīhi a vaṇṇa anta rahitehi paṭhamā vibhati antehi liṅgehi mantup paccayaḥ hoti
translated: The affix mantu is added to the words sati, etc., which are nouns in the first declension, when the word following them is a negative particle.

original: “tadassatthī”ti atthe. Sesaṃ guṇavantusamaṃ. Satimā, satimatī, satimantī, satimaṃ.
analyzed: tat assa atthi iti atthe sesam guṇavantu samam satimā satimatī satimantī satimam
translated: The meaning is “he has that”. The rest is the same as in the case of guṇavant. Satima, satimatī, satimantī, satimaṃ.

original: Evaṃ dhitimā, gatimā iccādayo.
analyzed: evam dhitimāḥ gatimāḥ icca ādayaḥ
translated: So too, dhitimā, gatimā, etc.

original: Tathā “āyu assa atthīti āyu mantu”iccatra –🔽404. Āyussukārāsamantumhi.
analyzed: tathā āyu assa atthi iti āyu  āyussu kārāsamantumhi
translated: And likewise in the case of āyu mantu, where

original: Āyussa ukāro asa hoti mantumhīti asādeso. Āyasmā, sesaṃ samaṃ. Gāvo assa santīti gomā, gomanto, gomatī, gomantī, gomaṃ kulaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: āyussa ukāraḥ hoti mantumhi iti asa ādesaḥ sesam samam gāvaḥ assa santi iti gomā gomantaḥ gomatī gomantī gomam kulam iccādi
translated: The vowel u of āyu becomes a when mantu follows: āyasmā. The rest is the same as before. Gomā, gomanto, gomatī, gomantī, gomaṃ kulaṃ, etc.

original: “Saddhā assa atthī”ti viggahe –
analyzed: saddhā assa atthi iti viggahe
translated: When the word saddhā is analysed as saddhā assa,

original: 405. Saddhādito ṇa.
analyzed: sad dhā t itaḥ ṇa
translated: The affix ṇa is added to saddhā, etc.

original: Saddhā paññāiccevamādito ṇappaccayo hoti “tadassatthi”iccetasmiṃ atthe. Saddho puriso,
analyzed: saddhā paññā it ca evamāditaḥ ṇa ppaccayaḥ hoti saddhaḥ puriso
translated: The affix ṇa is added to the words saddhā, paññā, etc., in the sense of “he has that”. Saddho puriso,

original: saddhā kaññā, saddhaṃ kulaṃ. Evaṃ pañño, amaccharo, tathā buddhaṃ, buddhi assa atthīti buddho iccādi.🔽Assatthitaddhitaṃ.🔽Saṅkhyātaddhita
analyzed: saddhā kaññā saddham kulam evam paññaḥ amaccharaḥ tathā buddham assa atthi iti buddhaḥ iccādi 🔽as satthi taddhitam 🔽saṅkhyā taddhita
translated: saddhā kaññā, saddhaṃ kulaṃ. So too, pañño, amaccharo. So too, buddhaṃ, buddhi assa atthīti buddho, etc.

original: “Pañcannaṃ pūraṇo”ti viggahe –
analyzed: viggahe
translated: In the analysis of “the fifth of the five”

original: 406. Saṅkhyāpūraṇe mo.
analyzed: saṅkhyā pūraṇe mo
translated: Mo is for the fulfilling of a number.

original: Pūrayati saṅkhyā anenāti pūraṇo, saṅkhyāya pūraṇo saṅkhyāpūraṇo, tasmiṃ saṅkhyāpūraṇatthe
analyzed: pūrayati saṅkhyāḥ anena ati pūraṇaḥ saṅkhyāya pūraṇaḥ saṅkhyā pūraṇaḥ tasmin saṅkhyā pūraṇa tthe
translated: Pūraṇa means that which fills a number, a fulfiller of a number, a fulfiller of a number is a saṅkhyāpūraṇa.

original: chaṭṭhiyantato mappaccayo hoti. Pañcamo, pañcannaṃ pūraṇī pañcamī, “nadādito vā ī”ti
analyzed: chaṭṭhiyantataḥ map paccayaḥ hoti pañcamaḥ pañcannam pūraṇī pañcamī nada āditaḥ vai īti
translated: The mappaccayo is formed from the locative of the sixth case. The fifth of the five is the fifth. “Or ī from nadā and so on”🔽The īppaccayo is formed. “Or āppaccayo from itthiyam”

original: īpaccayo. “Itthiyamato āpaccayo”ti āpaccayo, pañcamā vīriyapāramī, pañcamaṃ jhānaṃ.
analyzed: ī paccayaḥ pañcamā vīriya pāramī pañcamam jhānam
translated: The āppaccayo is formed. The fifth perfection of energy is the fifth jhāna.

original: Evaṃ sattamo, sattamī, sattamā, sattamaṃ, aṭṭhamo, aṭṭhamī, aṭṭhamā, aṭṭhamaṃ, navamo,
analyzed: evam sattamaḥ sattamī sattamā sattamam aṭṭhamaḥ aṭṭhamā aṭṭhamā aṭṭhamam navamaḥ
translated: Thus the seventh, the seventh, the seventh, the seventh, the eighth, the eighth, the eighth, the eighth, the ninth,

original: navamī, navamā, navamaṃ, dasamo, dasamī, dasamā, dasamaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: navamī navamā navamam dasamaḥ dasamī dasamā dasamam iti ca ādi
translated: the ninth, the ninth, the ninth, the tenth, the tenth, the tenth, the tenth and so on.

original: “Saṅkhyāpūraṇe”ti adhikāro.
analyzed: saṅkhyā pūraṇā iti
translated: The section is on the fulfilling of a number.

original: 407. Catucchehi thaṭhā.
analyzed: catucchehi thaṭhā
translated: Thaṭha is for the four.

original: Catuchaiccetehi thaṭhaiccete paccayā honti saṅkhyāpūraṇatthe. Catunnaṃ pūraṇo catuttho,
analyzed: catu chaic cetehi tha ṭhaic cete paccayāḥ honti saṅkhyā pūraṇa atthe catunnam pūraṇaḥ catutthaḥ
translated: These four are the paccayā for the fulfilling of a number. The fulfiller of the four is the fourth.

original: dvittaṃ, catutthī, catutthā, catutthaṃ, channaṃ pūraṇo chaṭṭho, chaṭṭhī, chaṭṭhā,
analyzed: dvittam catutthī catutthā catuttham channam pūraṇaḥ chaṭṭhaḥ chaṭṭhī chaṭṭhā
translated: The second, the fourth, the fourth, the fourth, the fulfiller of the six is the sixth, the sixth, the sixth,🔽the sixth.

original: chaṭṭhaṃ, chaṭṭho eva chaṭṭhamo.
analyzed: chaṭṭham chaṭṭhaḥ eva chaṭṭhamaḥ
translated: The sixth, the sixth of the sixth.

original: Chāhaṃ, chaḷāyatanaṃ iccatra –🔽408. Sa chassa vā.
analyzed: cha aham chaṭ āyatanam id catra  sa chassa vā
translated: The sixth, the sixfold base, here.🔽The sixth, the sixth, or the sixth.

original: Chassa sakārādeso hoti vā saṅkhyāne. Chāhamassa jīvitaṃ sāhaṃ, chāhaṃ vā, saḷāyatanaṃ.
analyzed: chassa sakāra ādesaḥ hoti vā saṅkhyāne chāhamassa jīvitam sāham chāham vā
translated: The sixth has the substitution of sa for cha, or it has the sixth, the sixth base.

original: “Dvinnaṃ pūraṇo”ti viggahe –
analyzed: dvinnam viggahe
translated: In the analysis “of two, Pūraṇa,”

original: 409. Dvitīhi tiyo.
analyzed: dvitīyaḥ tiyaḥ
translated: The second, the third, and so on.

original: Dvitiiccetehi tiyappaccayo hoti saṅkhyāpūraṇatthe. Vipariṇāmena “dvi tiṇṇa”nti vattamāne –
analyzed: tiya paccayaḥ hoti saṅkhyā pūraṇa atthe vipariṇāmena dvi vattamāne
translated: The second, the third, and so on, have the substitution of ti for i, in the sense of completing the number. When it is said “two, three,” by way of the change,

original: 410. Tiye dutāpi ca.
analyzed: tiye du tā api ca
translated: The second, the third, and so on, and the second, the second, and so on.

original: Dvitiiccetesaṃ dutaiccādesā honti tiyappaccaye pare. Dutiyo puriso, dutiyā, dutiyaṃ.
analyzed: dvi ti icca itesam du ta e c ca ādesāḥ honti tiya ppaccaye pare dutiyaḥ puriso dutiyā dutiyam
translated: The second person, the second, the second one.

original: Evaṃ tiṇṇaṃ pūraṇo tatiyo, tatiyā, tatiyaṃ. Apiggahaṇena aññatthāpi dvisaddassa duādeso
analyzed: evam tiṇṇam pūraṇaḥ tatiyaḥ tatiyā tatiyam apiggahaṇena aññattha api dvi saddassa du ādesaḥ
translated: Thus, of three, the third, the third, the third. By the word “and so on,” the substitution of du for the word “two” is also in other places. By the word “and,” the second, the second, the second.

original: hoti, casaddena di ca. Dve rattiyo durattaṃ, duvidhaṃ, duvaṅgaṃ, dirattaṃ, diguṇaṃ, digu.
analyzed: hoti ca saddena di ca dve rattiyaḥ durattam duvidham duvaṅgam dirattam diguṇam digu
translated: Two nights, a long night, twofold, two-limbed, a long time, double, double.

original: 411. Tesamaḍḍhūpapadena aḍḍhuḍḍhadivaḍḍhadiyaḍḍhaḍḍhatiyā.
analyzed: te samaḍ ḍh upapadena aḍḍhuḍḍhadi vaḍḍhadiya ḍḍhaḍḍhatiyā

original: Tesaṃ catutthadutiyatatiyānaṃ aḍḍhūpapadānaṃ aḍḍhūpapadena saha aḍḍhuḍḍhadivaḍḍhadiyaḍḍhaaḍḍhatiyādesā honti.
analyzed: tesam catuttha dutiya tatiyānam aḍḍhūpa padānam aḍḍhūpa padena saha honti
translated: The words aḍḍhuḍḍha, divaḍḍha, diyaḍḍha, aḍḍhatiya, etc., are formed by adding aḍḍha to the fourth, second, third, etc., of the above series.

original: Ettha ca –🔽Aḍḍhūpapadapādāna-sāmatthā aḍḍhapubbakā;
analyzed: ettha ca  aḍḍhūpapada pādāna sāmatthāḥ aḍḍhapubbakā
translated: And here:🔽The words aḍḍhuḍḍha, etc., are formed by adding aḍḍha to the fourth, second, etc.,

original: Tesaṃsaddena gayhante, catutthadutiyādayo.
analyzed: tesaṃsaddena gayhante catuttha dutiya ādayaḥ
translated: In the sense of “half more,” and they are known by the word aḍḍha.

original: Aḍḍhena catuttho aḍḍhuḍḍho, aḍḍhena dutiyo divaḍḍho, diyaḍḍho, aḍḍhena tatiyo aḍḍhatiyo.
analyzed: aḍḍhena catutthaḥ aḍḍhuḍḍhaḥ aḍḍhena dutiyaḥ divaḍḍhaḥ diyaḍḍhaḥ aḍḍhena tatiyaḥ aḍḍhatiyaḥ
translated: The fourth of the above series with aḍḍha is aḍḍhuḍḍha, the second with aḍḍha is divaḍḍha, the third with aḍḍha is diyaḍḍha, the third with aḍḍha is aḍḍhatiya.

original: “Ekañca dasa cā”ti atthe dvandasamāse, “ekena adhikā dasā”ti atthe tappurisasamāse vā kate “saṅkhyāne”ti vattamāne “dvekaṭṭhānamākāro vā”ti āttaṃ. Vavatthitavibhāsatthoyaṃ vāsaddo.
analyzed: ekam ca dasa ca ati atthe dvanda samāse ekena adhikāḥ dasa ati atthe tappurisa samāse vā kate saṅkhyāne iti vattamāne dvi eka ṭṭhānam ākāraḥ vā ati āttam vavatthita vibhāsa atthaḥ yam vā saddaḥ
translated: When the dvanda compound “one and ten” is made, or the tappurisa compound “ten more than one,” then the word vā is brought in by the rule “In a numeral, the place of the first is changed to the second, or there is lengthening of the vowel,” and the word vā is used in the sense of “distinction” or “specification.”

original: Tena cettha –
analyzed: tena ca ittha
translated: Therefore here:

original: Dvekaṭṭhānaṃ dase niccaṃ, dvissā’navutiyā navā;
analyzed: dvekaṭṭhānam dase niccam dvissā navutiyā navā
translated: The place of the first is always changed to the second in ten, and the ninth in ninety,

original: Itaresa’masantañca, āttaṃ dīpeti vāsuti.
analyzed: āttam dīpa iti
translated: And in the rest it is not, and the word vā shows the lengthening of the vowel.

original: “Ekādito dasara saṅkhyāne”ti rattaṃ.
analyzed: eka āditaḥ dasara saṅkhyāna iti rattam
translated: “From one onwards, the numeral is lengthened” .

original: Rādeso vaṇṇamattattā, vaṇṇamattappasaṅgipi;
analyzed: ra ādesaḥ vaṇṇa matta ttā vaṇṇa matta ppasaṅgi pi
translated: The vowel ra is lengthened because it is merely a vowel, and it is included in the mere vowel.

original: Siyā dasassa dasseva, nimittāsannabhāvato.
analyzed: siyā dasassa dassā iva nimitta āsanna bhāvataḥ
translated: It may be of the ten, of the ten only, because of the proximity of the sign.

original: Tato bahuvacanaṃ yo, “pañcādīnamakāro”ti savibhattissa antassa attaṃ. Ekārasa, ekādasa, liṅgattayepi samānaṃ.
analyzed: tatas bahuvacanam yaḥ pañca ādīnam akāraḥ ti sa vibhattissa antassa attam ekārasaḥ ekādasa liṅga ttaye pi samānam
translated: Then the plural is “the letter a of five and so on,” the ending of the case-form is the self of the last, Ekārasa, ekādasa, the same in all three genders.

original: “Vā”ti vattate.
analyzed: vāti vattate
translated: “Vā” is said.

original: 412. Ekādito dasassī.🔽Ekādito parassa dasassa ante īpaccayo hoti vā pūraṇatthe.
analyzed: eka āditaḥ dasassī  eka ādeḥ parassa dasassa ante ī pa ccayaḥ hoti vā pūraṇa atthe
translated: . Ekādito dasassī.🔽The particle ī is added to the last of the ten, beginning with one, optionally, in the sense of filling.

original: Dasassa paccayāyogā, laddhamanteti atthato;
analyzed: dasassa paccaya ayogā laddha mantā iti atthataḥ
translated: Because of the impossibility of a condition for the ten, the meaning is “having obtained the self”;

original: Tadantassa sabhāvena, itthiyaṃyeva sambhavo.
analyzed: tad antassa sabhāvena sambhavaḥ
translated: The possibility is only in the feminine by nature of the ending in that.

original: Ekādasannaṃ pūraṇī ekādasī, aññatra ekādasamo, ekādasamaṃ.
analyzed: pūraṇī ekādasī aññatra ekādasamaḥ ekādasamam
translated: The filler of the eleven is ekādasī, except ekādasamo, ekādasamaṃ.

original: Dve ca dasa ca, dvīhi vā adhikā dasāti “dvi dasa”iccatra “vā”ti vattate.
analyzed: dve ca dasa ca dvīhi vā adhikā dasāti dvi vā ati vattate
translated: Two and ten, “dvi dasa” here “vā” is said, because of the excess by two or ten.

original: “Vīsati dasesu bā dvissa tū”ti bādeso, dassa rādeso. Bārasa, aññatra āttaṃ, dvādasa. Dvādasannaṃ pūraṇo bārasamo, dvādasamo, dvādasī.
analyzed: vīsati dasesu bā dvissa tūti bādesaḥ dassa ra ādesaḥ bārasa aññatra āttam dvādasa dvādasannam pūraṇaḥ bārasamaḥ dvādasamaḥ dvādasī
translated: “Vīsati dasesu bā dvissa tū” the letter bā is substituted for the second, the letter rā is substituted for the last, bārasa, except the ending, dvādasa. The equal of the twelve is bārasamo, dvādasamo, dvādasī.

original: Tayo ca dasa ca, tīhi vā adhikā dasāti terasa, “tesu vuddhi lopā”dinā tissa teādaso ānavutiyā, terasamo, terasī.
analyzed: tayaḥ ca dasa ca tīhi vā adhikāḥ dasa ati terasa tesu vuddhi lopa ādinā tissa teādasaḥ ānavutiyā terasamaḥ terasī
translated: and three and ten are thirteen. “In them increase, decrease, etc.,” thus they are thirteen in the three and ten. The thirteenth is the thirteenth.

original: Cattāro ca dasa ca, catūhi vā adhikā dasāti catuddasa iccatra “gaṇane dasassā”ti🔽ca vattamāne “catūpapadassa lopo tuttarapadādi cassa cucopi navā”ti tulopo, cuco
analyzed: cattāraḥ ca dasa ca catūhi vā adhikāḥ dasa ati catuddasaḥ id atra gaṇane dasassa ati  ca vattamāne catu upapadassa lopaḥ tu tara pada ādi cassa cu caḥ pi navāti tu lopaḥ cu caḥ
translated: and three and ten are thirteen, and in the three and ten, the thirteen is the thirteenth.

original: ca. Cuddasa, coddasa, catuddasa. Cuddasamo, catuddasamo, cakuddasī, cātuddasī vā.🔽Pañca ca dasa ca, pañcahi vā adhikā dasāti pañcadasa, “tesu vuddhi lopā”dinā pañcasaddassa🔽dasa vīsesu pannapaṇṇaādesāpi, “aṭṭhādito cā”ti rattaṃ. Pannarasa, pañcadasa. Pannarasamo,
analyzed: ca cuddasa coddasa catuddasa cuddasamaḥ catuddasamaḥ cakuddasī cātuddasī vā  pañca ca dasa ca pañcahi vā adhikāḥ dasā ati pañcadasa tesu vuddhi lopa ādinā  dasa vīsesu aṭṭha āditaḥ ca ati rattam pannarasa pañcadasa pannarasamaḥ
translated: And four and ten are fourteen, and in the four and ten, the fourteen is the fourteenth.

original: pañcadasamo, pannarasī, pañcadasī.
analyzed: pañcadasamaḥ pannarasī pañcadasī
translated: And five and ten are fifteen, and in the five and ten, the fifteen is the fifteenth.

original: “Cha ca dasa ca, chahi vā adhikā dasā”ti samāse kate “chassā”ti vattamāne “dase so
analyzed: cha ca dasa ca chahi vā adhikāḥ dasa ati samāse kate chassa ati vattamāne dase so
translated: And six and ten are sixteen, and in the six and ten, the sixteen is the sixteenth.

original: niccañcā”ti so, “saṅkhyānaṃ, vā”ti ca vattate, “la darāna”nti lattaṃ, vavatthitavibhāsatthoyaṃ vāsaddo.
analyzed: saṅkhyānam vāti ca vattate vavatthita vibhāsa atthaḥ yam vā saddaḥ
translated: and also in the sense of “forty-three.”🔽The form la is used in the sense of “sixteen,”🔽and also in the sense of “forty-three.”🔽The form la is used in the sense of “sixteen,”

original: Ḷo niccaṃ soḷase dassa, cattālīse ca terase;🔽Aññatra na ca hotāyaṃ, vavatthitavibhāsato.
analyzed: ḷaḥ niccam soḷase dassa cattālīse ca terase  aññatra na ca hotā ayam
translated: and also in the sense of “forty-three.”🔽The form la is used in the sense of “sixteen,”🔽and also in the sense of “forty-three.”🔽The form la is used in the sense of “sixteen,”🔽and also in the sense of “forty-three.”🔽The form la is used in the sense of “sixteen,”

original: Laḷānamaviseso kvaci, soḷasa. Teḷasa, cattālīsaṃ, cattārīsaṃ. Soḷasamo, soḷasī.
analyzed: kvaci soḷasa teḷasa cattālīsam cattārīsam soḷasamaḥ soḷasī
translated: and also in the sense of “forty-three.”🔽The form la is used in the sense of “sixteen,”🔽and also in the sense of “forty-three.”

original: “Vā, dasara saṅkhyāne”ti adhikicca “aṭṭhādito cā”ti rattaṃ. Aṭṭhārasa, aṭṭhādasa,
analyzed: vā dasara saṅkhyāne iti adhik it ca ati rattam aṭṭhārasa aṭṭhādasa
translated: The form la is used in the sense of “sixteen,”🔽and also in the sense of “forty-three.”🔽The form la is used in the sense of “sixteen,”🔽and also in the sense of “forty-three.”🔽The form la is used in the sense of “sixteen,”🔽and also in the sense of “forty-three.”

original: āttaṃ. Aṭṭhārasannaṃ pūraṇo aṭṭhārasamo, aṭṭhādasamo. Evaṃ sattarasa, sattadasa.🔽Sattarasamo, sattadasamo.
analyzed: āttam aṭṭhārasannam pūraṇaḥ aṭṭhārasamaḥ aṭṭhādasamaḥ evam sattarasa sattadasa  sattarasamaḥ sattadasamaḥ
translated: The form la is used in the sense of “sixteen,”🔽and also in the sense of “forty-three.”🔽The form la is used in the sense of “sixteen,”

original: Aṭṭhāditoti kimatthaṃ? Catuddasa.
analyzed: aṭṭha āditaḥ ti kimattham catuddasa
translated: and also in the sense of “forty-three.”🔽The form la is used in the sense of “sixteen,”🔽and also in the sense of “forty-three.”

original: Ekena ūnā vīsatīti tappuriso, ekūnavīsati. Ekūnavīsatādayo ānavutiyā ekavacanantā,
analyzed: ekena ūnā vīsati iti tad purisaḥ ekūnavīsati ekūnavīsata ādayaḥ ānavutiyā eka vacana antā
translated: The form la is used in the sense of “sixteen,”🔽and also in the sense of “forty-three.”🔽The form la is used in the sense of “sixteen,”🔽and also in the sense of “forty-three.”🔽The form la is used in the sense of “sixteen,”🔽and also in the sense of “forty-three.”

original: itthiliṅgā ca daṭṭhabbā, te ca saṅkhyāne, saṅkhyeyye ca vattante, yadā saṅkhyāne
analyzed: itthi liṅgā ca daṭṭhabbā te ca saṅkhyāne saṅkhyeyye ca vattante yadā saṅkhyāne
translated: The form la is used in the sense of “sixteen,”🔽and also in the sense of “forty-three.”🔽The form la is used in the sense of “sixteen

original: vattante, tadā bhikkhūnamekūnavīsati tiṭṭhati, bhoti bhikkhūnamekūnavīsati tiṭṭhatu,
analyzed: vattante tadā bhikkhūnam ekūnavīsati tiṭṭhati bhoti bhikkhūnam ekūnavīsati tiṭṭhatu
translated: when it is said, ‘There are nineteen left for the monks,’ ‘There are nineteen left for the monks’ is said,

original: bhikkhūnamekūnavīsatiṃ passa, bhikkhūnamekūnavīsatiyā kataṃ iccādi.
analyzed: bhikkhūnam ekūnavīsatim passa bhikkhūnam ekūnavīsatiyā katam iccādi
translated: When they are spoken of, then there are nineteen bhikkhus, there are nineteen good bhikkhus, there are nineteen bhikkhus, look at the nineteen bhikkhus, it is done by nineteen bhikkhus, and so on.

original: Saṅkhyeyye pana ekūnavīsati bhikkhavo tiṭṭhanti, bhonto ekūnavīsati bhikkhavo tiṭṭhatha,
analyzed: saṅkhyeyye pana ekūnavīsati bhikkhavaḥ tiṭṭhanti bhonto ekūnavīsati bhikkhavaḥ tiṭṭhatha
translated: But in a countable noun, there are nineteen bhikkhus, there are nineteen good bhikkhus,

original: ekūnavīsatiṃ bhikkhū passa, ekūnavīsatiyā bhikkhūhi kataṃ iccādi. Evaṃ vīsatādīsupi
analyzed: ekūnavīsatim bhikkhū passa ekūnavīsatiyā bhikkhūhi katam iccādi evam vīsata ādīsu pi
translated: look at the nineteen bhikkhus, it is done by nineteen bhikkhus, and so on. So too in the case of twenty, etc.,

original: yojetabbaṃ, ekūnavīsatiyā pūraṇo ekūnavīsatimo.
analyzed: yojetabbam ekūnavīsatiyā pūraṇaḥ ekūnavīsatimaḥ
translated: it should be construed. Pūraṇa is the nineteenth of nineteen.

original: Dasa ca dasa cāti atthe dvandasamāsaṃ katvā “dasadasā”ti vattabbe “sarūpānamekasesvasaki”nti ekasese kate dasasaddato paṭhamābahuvacanaṃ yo. “Dasa yo”itīdha –
analyzed: dasa ca dasa ca ati atthe dvanda samāsam katvā dasa dasa ati vattabbe ekasese kate paṭhamā bahuvacanam yaḥ dasa yaḥ iti idha
translated: In the sense of ‘ten and ten’, after making a copulative compound, ‘dasadasā’ should be said. But when the singular is made by the rule ‘sarūpānamekasesvasaki’, the plural of the first case is made from the word ‘dasa’. Here ‘dasayo’—

original: 413. Gaṇane dasassa dviti catu pañca cha satta aṭṭhanavakānaṃ vīti cattāra paññā cha sattāsa navā yosu yonañcī samāsaṃ ṭhiri tītuti.
analyzed: gaṇane dasassa dviti catu pañca cha satta aṭṭha navakānam vīti cattāra paññā cha sattāsa navā samāsam tī tuti
translated: . In the reckoning of ten, the dual of ten, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, the four, the five, the six, the seven, the eight, the nine, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the ten, the

original: Gaṇane dasassa sambandhīnaṃ dvika tika catukka pañcaka chakkasattaka aṭṭhaka navakānaṃ
analyzed: gaṇane dasassa sambandhīnam dvika tika catukka pañcaka chakka sattaka aṭṭhaka navakānam
translated: triad, tetrad, pentad, hexad, heptad, octad, and nonad

original: katekasesānaṃ yathākkamaṃ vīti cattāra paññā cha satta asa nava iccādesā honti yosu🔽paresu, yonañca īsaṃ āsaṃ ṭhi riti īti utiiccete ādesā hontīti dvidasatthavācakassa
analyzed: kata ikasesānam yathākkamam cattāra paññā cha satta asa nava icca ādesāḥ honti yosu  paresu ya u nañ ca īsam āsam ṭhi r iti īti uti icca ete ādesāḥ honti iti dvidasa attha vācakassa
translated: are, respectively, vī, cattā, paññā, cha, satta, aṭṭha, nava, and so on, in the feminine.🔽In the other (cases), the endings īsaṃ, āsaṃ, ṭhi, ri, ī, and uti are formed. Thus the ending vī is formed for the word dasa, which denotes two hundred,

original: dasassa vīādeso hoti, yovacanassa īsañca, saralopādi.
analyzed: dasassa vī ā desaḥ hoti yaḥ vacanassa īsan ca sara lopa ādi
translated: and the ending īsaṃ for the word yava, and the syllable ra is elided, and so on.

original: “Saṅkhyānaṃ, vā, ante”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: saṅkhyānam vai anta iti ca vattate
translated: “At the end of a numeral, or” is stated.

original: 414. Ti ca.
analyzed: ti ca
translated: And so on.

original: Tāsaṃ saṅkhyānamante tikārāgamo hoti vā. Vavatthitavibhāsatthoyaṃ vāsaddo.
analyzed: tāsam saṅkhyānam ante tikāra āgamaḥ hoti vā vavatthita vibhāsa atthaḥ yam vā saddaḥ
translated: The addition of ti is made at the end of those numerals, or not. This word vā has the meaning of distinguishing and specifying.

original: Vibhāsā vīsa tiṃsāna-mante hoti tiāgamo;
analyzed: vibhāsā vīsa tiṃsa anamante hoti ti āgamaḥ
translated: The addition of vibhāsā is made at the end of vīsa and tiṃsa;

original: Aññattha na ca hoteva, vavatthitavibhāsato.
analyzed: aññattha na ca hotā iva vavatthita vibhāsato
translated: It is not made elsewhere, because of distinguishing and specifying.

original: “Byañjane cā”ti niggahītalopo, puna taddhitattā nāmabyapadese syādyuppatti. Bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: byañjane ca ati niggahīta lopaḥ puna taddhita ttā nāma byapadese bhikkhūnam
translated: “And in the case of a consonant” is the elision of the vowel sound, and again the arising of the syllable sya is due to the formation of a tatpurusa compound in the place of a noun. Bhikkhūnaṃ

original: vīsati, vīsaṃ vā, vīsati bhikkhū, vīsaṃ vā iccādi. Vīsatimo. Tathā ekavīsati kusalacittāni,
analyzed: vīsati vīsam vā vīsati bhikkhū vīsam vā iccādi vīsatimaḥ tathā ekavīsati kusala cittāni
translated: vīsati, vīsaṃ vā, vīsati bhikkhū, vīsaṃ vā, and so on. Vīsatimo. Similarly, ekavīsati wholesome consciousnesses,

original: ekavīsaṃ vā. Ekavīsatimo. Bāvīsati, bāvīsaṃ vā. Bāvīsatimo. Dvāvīsati, dvāvīsaṃ vā.
analyzed: ekavīsam vai ekavīsatimaḥ bāvīsati bāvīsam vā bāvīsatimaḥ dvāvīsati dvāvīsam vā
translated: twenty-one. twenty-second. twenty-two, twenty-two.🔽twenty-third. twenty-three, twenty-three.

original: Dvāvīsatimo. Tevīsati, tevīsaṃ vā. Tevīsatimo. Catuvīsati, catuvīsaṃ vā. Catuvīsatimo.
analyzed: dvāvīsatimaḥ tevīsati tevīsam vā tevīsatimaḥ catuvīsati catuvīsam vā catuvīsatimaḥ
translated: twenty-fourth. twenty-four, twenty-four.

original: Paṇṇavīsati, paṇṇavīsaṃ vā. Paṇṇavīsatimo. Pañcavīsati, pañcavīsaṃ vā. Pañcavīsatimo.
analyzed: paṇṇavīsati paṇṇavīsam vā paṇṇavīsatimaḥ pañcavīsati pañcavīsam vā pañcavīsatimaḥ
translated: twenty-fifth. twenty-five, twenty-five.🔽twenty-sixth. twenty-six, twenty-six.

original: Chabbīsati, chabbīsaṃ vā. Chabbīsatimo. Sattavīsati, sattavīsaṃ vā. Sattavīsatimo.
analyzed: chabbīsati chabbīsam vā chabbīsatimaḥ sattavīsati sattavīsam vā sattavīsatimaḥ
translated: twenty-seventh. twenty-seven, twenty-seven.

original: Aṭṭhavīsati, aṭṭhavīsaṃ vā. Aṭṭhavīsatimo. Ekūnatiṃsati, ekūnatiṃsaṃvā. Ekūnatiṃsatimo.
analyzed: aṭṭhavīsati aṭṭhavīsam vai aṭṭhavīsatimaḥ ekūnatiṃsati ekūnatiṃsam vai ekūnatiṃsatimaḥ
translated: twenty-eighth. twenty-eight, twenty-eight.🔽twenty-ninth. twenty-nine, twenty-nine.

original: Dasa ca dasa ca dasa cāti “dasa dasa dasā”ti vattabbe ekasese kate “gaṇane dasassā”tiādinā🔽tiīsamādesā, “kvacā”dinā rassattaṃ, niggahītāgamo ca, sesaṃ vīsatisamaṃ. Tiṃsati,
analyzed: dasa ca dasa ca dasa ca ati dasa dasa dasa ati vattabbe ekasese kate gaṇane dasassa ati ādinā  tiīsama ādesā kvaca ādinā rassa ttam niggahīta āgamaḥ ca sesam vīsati samam tiṃsati
translated: thirty.🔽thirty years.

original: tiṃsaṃ, tiṃsa vassāni, niggahītalopo, tiṃsaṃ, tiṃsāya iccādi. Ekatiṃsati, ekatiṃsaṃ
analyzed: tiṃsam tiṃsa vassāni niggahīta lopaḥ tiṃsam tiṃsāya iccādi ekatiṃsati ekatiṃsam
translated: thirty, thirty by, etc.

original: vā, bāttiṃsaṃ, dvattiṃsaṃ, tettiṃsaṃ iccādi.🔽Catudasatthavācakassa katekasesassa dasassa cattāra, yovacanassa īsaṃ, cattālīsaṃ,
analyzed: vā bāttiṃsam dvattiṃsam tettiṃsam it ca ādi  catudasa attha vācakassa kata ikasesassa dasassa cattāra yo vacanassa īsam cattālīsam
translated: thirty-two, thirty-three, etc.

original: “la darāna”nti rassa lattaṃ, tālīsaṃ vā. Cattālīsatimo. Ekacattālīsaṃ, dvācattālīsaṃ,
analyzed: rassa tālīsam vā ekacattālīsam dvācattālīsam
translated: The word cattāri, “four,” is declined in the same way as dasa, “ten.” The word cattālīsa, “forty,” is formed by adding īsa to cattāri.

original: dvicattālīsaṃ, tecattālīsaṃ, ticattālīsaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: dvicattālīsam tecattālīsam ticattālīsam iti ādi
translated: The word tālīsa, “thirty,” is formed by adding latta to ta, “three.”🔽The word cattālīsa, “forty,” is formed by adding īsa to cattāri.

original: Pañcadasatthavācakassa dasassa paññā, yovacanassa āsañca. Paññāsaṃ, “tesu vuddhi lopā”dinā paṇṇādeso, paṇṇāsaṃ vā. Ekapaññāsaṃ, dvepaññāsaṃ, dvipaññāsaṃ.
analyzed: pañcadasa attha vācakassa dasassa paññā yo vacanassa āsam ca paññāsam tesu vuddhi lopa ādinā paṇṇā ādesaḥ paṇṇāsam vā ekapaññāsam dvepaññāsam dvipaññāsam
translated: The word paññāsa, “fifty,” is formed by adding āsa to pañca.

original: Chadasatthavācakassa dasassa cha, yovacanassa ṭhiādeso, “sa chassa vā”ti sakārādeso, saṭṭhi, dvāsaṭṭhi, dvesaṭṭhi, dvisaṭṭhi, tesaṭṭhi, tisaṭṭhi.
analyzed: cha das attha vācakassa dasassa cha yo vacanassa ṭhi ādeso sa chassa vā ati sakāra ādeso saṭṭhi dvāsaṭṭhi dvesaṭṭhi dvisaṭṭhi tesaṭṭhi tisaṭṭhi
translated: The word saṭṭhi, “sixty,” is formed by adding ṭhi to cha.

original: Sattadasatthavācakassa dasassa satta, yovacanassa ri, ti ca. Sattari, sattati, dvāsattari, dvāsattati, dvisattari, disattati, tesattati, tisattati iccādi.
analyzed: satta dasa attha vācakassa dasassa satta yaḥ vacanassa ri ti ca sattari sattati dvāsattari dvāsattati dvisattari disattati tesattati tisattati icca ādi
translated: The seven of the ten that has the meaning of “seventeen” is satta, and the ri of the y-declension is added.

original: Aṭṭhadasatthavācakassa dasassa asa, yovacanassa ītiādeso ca. Asīti, ekāsīti, dveasīti, teasīti, caturāsīti, “kvacā”dinā dīgho.
analyzed: aṭṭha dasa ttha vācakassa dasassa asa yaḥ vacanassa ī ti ādesaḥ ca asi iti eka asi iti dve asi iti te asi iti catur asi iti kvaca ādinā dīghaḥ
translated: The asa of the ten that has the meaning of “eighteen” is asīti, the ekā of the y-declension is added, and the ī of the y-declension is substituted.

original: Navadasatthavācakassa dasassa nava, yovacanassa uti ca, navuti, dvānavuti, dvenavuti, dvinavuti, tenavuti, tinavuti, catunavuti, channavutiyā, channavutīnaṃ pāsaṇḍānaṃ.
analyzed: nava dasa attha vācakassa dasassa nava yaḥ vacanassa uti ca navuti dvānavuti dvenavuti dvinavuti tenavuti tinavuti catunavuti channavutiyā channavutīnam pāsaṇḍānam
translated: The nava of the ten that has the meaning of “nineteen” is navuti, the dvā of the y-declension is added, and the u of the y-declension is substituted.

original: “Gaṇane, dasassā”ti ca vattate.🔽415. Dasadasakaṃ sataṃ dasakānaṃ sataṃ sahassañca yomhi.
analyzed: gaṇane dasassa ati ca vattate  dasa dasakam satam dasakānam satam sahassam ca yomhi
translated: “In counting, the ten of the ten” is said.🔽Ten tens is a hundred, and ten hundreds is a thousand.

original: Gaṇane pariyāpannassa dasadasakatthavācakassa dasasaddassa sataṃ hoti, satadasakatthavācakassa
analyzed: gaṇane pariyāpannassa dasa dasaka attha vācakassa dasa saddassa satam hoti sata dasaka ttha vācakassa
translated: In counting, the hundred of the ten that has the meaning of “ten tens” is sataṃ, and the

original: dasassa sahassaṃ hoti yomhi. Iminā nipātanena yolopo, taddhitattā puna nāmabyapadese
analyzed: dasassa sahassam hoti iminā nipātanena yo lopaḥ taddhita ttā puna nāma byapadese
translated: The word yomhi is formed by the addition of the affix y to the numeral ten, and by the elision of the final o of sahassa.🔽The affix y is added because it is a nominal affix, and because the name of the numeral is mentioned.🔽The final o of sahassa is elided because it is a numeral. The vowel i is substituted for the final a of y by the rule: “si is substituted for a”.🔽The word yojanānaṃ sataṃ, sahassaṃ is formed.

original: syādyuppatti, niggahītassa lopo, “si”nti amādeso, yojanānaṃ sataṃ, sahassaṃ. Sataṃ
analyzed: niggahītassa lopaḥ sinti am ādesaḥ yojanānam satam sahassam satam
translated: The word sataṃ is in the neuter singular, and sahassaṃ is in the masculine singular.

original: napuṃsakamekavacanantañca, tathā sahassaṃ, vaggabhede sabbattha bahuvacanampi bhavati.
analyzed: napuṃsakam ekavacana antam ca tathā sahassam vagga bhede sabbattha bahuvacanam pi bhavati
translated: In the case of the division into groups, the word sataṃ is in the plural in all cases.

original: Dve vīsatiyo. Evaṃ tiṃsādīsupi, dve satāni, bahūni satāni, dve sahassāni, bahūni sahassāni.
analyzed: dve vīsatiyaḥ evam tiṃsa ādīsu pi dve satāni bahūni satāni dve sahassāni bahūni sahassāni
translated: The words dve vīsatiyo, dve satāni, bahūni satāni, dve sahassāni, bahūni sahassāni are formed in the same way.

original: Satassa dvikanti atthe chaṭṭhītappurisaṃ katvā “sataṃ dvika”nti vattabbe “dvikādīnaṃ🔽taduttarapadānañca nipaccante”ti vuttiyaṃ vacanato iminā nipātanena uttarapadassa
analyzed: satassa dvikanti atthe chaṭṭhī tappurisam katvā satam dvikanti vattabbe dvika ādīnam  tad uttara padānam ca vuttiyam vacanataḥ iminā nipātanena uttara padassa
translated: The word satassa dvikan is formed by adding the affix ka to the numeral two, and by adding the feminine affix ṇ to the word satassa.🔽The word dvika is formed by the elision of the final a of dvi and by the addition of the affix ka.

original: pubbanipāto, kakāralopo ca hoti. Dvisataṃ. Evaṃ satassa tikaṃ tisataṃ, tathā catusataṃ,
analyzed: pubbanipātaḥ kakāra lopaḥ ca hoti dvisatam evam satassa tikam tisatam tathā catusatam
translated: The word dvisataṃ is formed by the addition of the affix ta to the word dvika, by the elision of the final k of dvika, and by the elision of the final a of satassa.

original: pañcasataṃ, chasataṃ, sattasataṃ, aṭṭhasataṃ, navasataṃ, dasasataṃ sahassaṃ hoti.
analyzed: pañca satam cha satam satta satam aṭṭha satam nava satam dasa satam sahassam hoti
translated: The words tisataṃ, catusahaṃ, pañcasataṃ, chasataṃ, sattasataṃ, aṭṭhasataṃ, navasataṃ, dasasataṃ sahassaṃ are formed in the same way.

original: Atha vā dve satāni dvisatanti digusamāso. Evaṃ tisataṃ, catusataṃ iccādi.
analyzed: atha vā dve satāni dvi satanti evam tisatam catusatam iti cādi
translated: Or else, two hundred is two hundred, and so on.

original: 416. Yāva taduttari dasaguṇitañca.
analyzed: yāva tad uttari dasa guṇitam ca
translated: Up to that, and also by tens.

original: Yāva tāsaṃ saṅkhyānamuttari, tāva dasaguṇitañca kātabbaṃ, ettha dakāro sandhijo.
analyzed: yāva tāsam saṅkhyānam uttari tāva dasa guṇitam ca kātabbam ettha dakāraḥ sandhi jo
translated: Up to the number of those, and also by tens, it should be done. Here the letter da is a sandhi vowel.

original: Yathā – dasassa gaṇanassa dasaguṇitaṃ sataṃ hoti, satassa dasaguṇitaṃ sahassaṃ, sahassassa
analyzed: yathā dasassa gaṇanassa dasa guṇitam satam hoti satassa dasa guṇitam sahassam sahassassa
translated: For example, the tenfold of ten is a hundred, the tenfold of a hundred is a thousand, the tenfold of a thousand

original: dasaguṇitaṃ dasasahassaṃ, idaṃ nahutantipi vuccati, dasasahassassa dasaguṇitaṃ satasahassaṃ,
analyzed: dasa guṇitam dasa sahassam idam vuccati dasa sahassassa dasa guṇitam sata sahassam
translated: is ten thousand, which is also called a nahuta. The tenfold of ten thousand is a hundred thousand,

original: taṃ lakkhantipi vuccati, satasahassassa dasaguṇitaṃ dasasatasahassaṃ.
analyzed: tam vuccati sata sahassassa dasa guṇitam dasa sata sahassam
translated: which is also called a lakh. The tenfold of a hundred thousand is a million,

original: “Yadanupapannā nipātanā sijjhantī”ti vattate.
analyzed: yat anupapannāḥ nipātanāḥ sijjhanti iti vattate
translated: which is also called a koṭi. It is said, “If the inflections are not used, they are successful.”

original: 417. Sakanāmehi.
analyzed: saka nāmā ihi
translated: By their own names.

original: Yāsaṃ pana saṅkhyānaṃ aniddiṭṭhanāmadheyyānaṃ yāni rūpāni, tāni sakehi nāmehi nipaccante.
analyzed: yāsam pana saṅkhyānam a niddiṭṭha nāmadheyyānam yāni rūpāni tāni sakehi nāmehi nipaccante
translated: But the forms of those whose number is not indicated by name are inflected by their own names.

original: Satasahassānaṃ sataṃ koṭi, itthiliṅgā, ekavacanantā ca, vaggabhede bahuvacanañca
analyzed: sata sahassānam satam koṭi itthi liṅgā ekavacana antā ca vagga bhede bahuvacanam ca
translated: A hundred hundred thousands is a koṭi, feminine, singular, and also plural in the section on vaggas.

original: bhavati, koṭisatasahassānaṃ sataṃ pakoṭi, pakoṭisatasahassānaṃ sataṃ koṭippakoṭi.
analyzed: bhavati koṭi sata sahassānam satam pakoṭi pakoṭi sata sahassānam satam koṭippakoṭi
translated: a hundred koṭis of pakoṭis is a pakoṭi, a hundred pakoṭis of pakoṭis is a koṭippakoṭi.

original: Evaṃ nahutaṃ, ninnahutaṃ, akkhobhinī, bindu, abbudaṃ, nirabbudaṃ, ahahaṃ, ababaṃ,
analyzed: evam nahutam ninna hutam akkhobhinī bindu abbudam nirabbudam ahaham ababam
translated: Thus nahuta, ninnahuta, akkhobhinī, bindu, abbuda, nirabbuda, ahahaṃ, ababaṃ,

original: aṭaṭaṃ, sogandhikaṃ, uppalaṃ, kumudaṃ, puṇḍarīkaṃ, padumaṃ, kathānaṃ, mahākathānaṃ, asaṅkhyeyyanti.
analyzed: aṭaṭam sogandhikam uppalam kumudam puṇḍarīkam padumam kathānam mahākathānam asaṅkhyeyyanti
translated: aṭaṭaṃ, sogandhikaṃ, uppalaṃ, kumudaṃ, puṇḍarīkaṃ, padumaṃ, kathānaṃ, mahākathānaṃ, asaṅkhyeyya.

original: Iccevaṃ ṭhānato ṭhānaṃ, satalakkhaguṇaṃ mataṃ;🔽Koṭippabhutinaṃ vīsa-saṅkhyānañca yathākkamaṃ.🔽“Dve parimāṇāni etassā”ti viggahe –🔽418. Dvādito konekatthe ca.🔽Dviiccevamādito gaṇanato kappaccayo hoti anekatthe. Dviko rāsi dvikaṃ. Evaṃ tikaṃ,🔽catukkaṃ, pañcakaṃ, chakkaṃ, sattakaṃ, aṭṭhakaṃ, navakaṃ, dasakaṃ, paṇṇāsakaṃ, satakaṃ, sahassakaṃ iccādi.🔽Saṅkhyātaddhitaṃ.
analyzed: iccā ivam ṭhānataḥ ṭhānam sata lakkha guṇam matam  yathākkamam  dve parimāṇāni etassa iti viggahe  dvi ā t itaḥ ka u na ekatthe ca  dvi iti ca evamāditaḥ gaṇanataḥ kappa ccayaḥ hoti anekatthe dvikaḥ rāsi dvikam evam tikam  catukkam pañcakam chakkam sattakam aṭṭhakam navakam dasakam paṇṇāsakam satakam sahassakam iccādi  saṅkhyā taddhitam
translated: Thus from place to place, the number is reckoned by tens, hundreds, thousands, ten thousands,

original: Abyayataddhita🔽“Ekasmiṃ vāre bhuñjati, dvivāre bhuñjatī”ti viggahe –
analyzed: a byaya taddhita 🔽ekasmin vāre bhuñjati dvi vāre bhuñjati iti viggahe
translated: hundred thousands, millions, ten millions, hundred millions, billion, ten billion, hundred billion, trillion, ten trillion, hundred trillion, ten hundred trillion, a koṭi, a hundred koṭis, a thousand koṭis, a hundred thousand koṭis, a hundred million koṭis, a hundred thousand million koṭis, a hundred thousand million million koṭis, a hundred thousand million million million koṭis, a a hundred thousand million million million million million million million million million million million million million million million million million koṭis, a hundred thousand million million million million million million million million million million million million million million million million million million koṭis, a hundred thousand million million million million million

original: 419. Ekādito sakissa kkhattuṃ.
analyzed: eka āditaḥ sakissa kkhattum
translated: 419. Once, etc., to the extent of a hundred,

original: Ekadvitiiccevamādito gaṇanato sakissa ṭhāne vāratthe kkhattuṃpaccayo hoti. Ekakkhattuṃ,
analyzed: eka dvi ti id ca evamāditaḥ gaṇanataḥ sakissa ṭhāne vāra atthe kkhattuṃ paccayaḥ hoti eka kkhattum
translated: Once, twice, etc., are declined in the same way as the numerals from one to ten.🔽He eats once, twice.

original: dvikkhattuṃ bhuñjati, “sabbāsamāvuso”tiādinā silopo. Evaṃ tikkhattuṃ, catukkhattuṃ,
analyzed: dvi kkhattum bhuñjati evam ti khattum catu khattum
translated: In the same way, three times, four times,

original: pañcakkhattuṃ, chakkhattuṃ, sattakkhattuṃ, aṭṭhakkhattuṃ, navakkhattuṃ, dasakkhattuṃ,
analyzed: pañca kkhattum cha khattum satta kkhattum aṭṭha kkhattum nava kkhattum dasa kkhattum
translated: five times, six times, seven times, eight times, nine times, ten times,

original: satakkhattuṃ, sahassakkhattuṃ, bahukkhattuṃ, katikkhattuṃ.
analyzed: sata khattum sahassa khattum bahu khattum kati khattum
translated: a hundred times, a thousand times, many times, how many times?

original: “Ekena vibhāgenā”ti viggahe –
analyzed: ekena vibhāgena ati viggahe
translated: In the case of division by one part, etc.,

original: Maṇḍūkagatiyā saṅkhyāggahaṇamanuvattate.
analyzed: maṇḍūka gatiyā saṅkhyā ggahaṇam anuvattate
translated: The taking of the number in the manner of the frog is continued.

original: 420. Vibhāge dhā ca.
analyzed: vibhāge dhā ca
translated: 420. In division, and in the case of a single part,🔽In the sense of division, the affix dhā is added to the numerals from one to ten.

original: Vibhāgatthe ekādisaṅkhyāto dhāpaccayo hoti. Casaddena ekadvito jjha ca, suttādito
analyzed: vibhāga atthe eka ādi saṅkhyātaḥ dhā paccayaḥ hoti ca saddena eka dvitaḥ jjha ca sutta āditaḥ
translated: And in the case of a single part, it is in the manner of the frog.🔽In two parts, it is twofold, or double.

original: so ca. Ekadhā. Dvīhi vibhāgehi dvidhā, dudhā vā, dvedhā. Tīhi vibhāgehi tidhā, tedhā
analyzed: saḥ ca ekadhā dvīhi vibhāgehi dvidhā dudhā vā dvedhā tīhi vibhāgehi tidhā tedhā
translated: In three parts, it is threefold, or treble.

original: vā, “tesu vuddhī”tiādinā ikārassekāro. Evaṃ catudhā, pañcadhā, chadhā, sattadhā,
analyzed: vā tesu vuddhi iti ādinā ikārassa ikāraḥ evam catudhā pañcadhā chadhā sattadhā
translated: In the same way, fourfold, fivefold, sixfold, sevenfold,

original: aṭṭhadhā, navadhā, dasadhā, satadhā, sahassadhā, katidhā, bahudhā.
analyzed: aṭṭhadhā navadhā dasadhā satadhā sahassadhā katidhā bahudhā
translated: In eight ways, in nine ways, in ten ways, in a hundred ways, in a thousand ways, in how many ways, in many ways.

original: Jjhappaccaye ekadhā karotīti ekajjhaṃ. Evaṃ dvejjhaṃ.
analyzed: jjhap paccaye ekadhā karoti iti ekajjham evam dvejjham
translated: In the condition by way of root he makes it in one way, thus in one way. So in two ways.

original: Sopaccaye suttena vibhāgena suttaso. Evaṃ byañjanaso, padaso, atthaso, bahuso, sabbākārena sabbaso, upāyaso, hetuso, ṭhānaso, yoniso.
analyzed: so paccaye suttena vibhāgena suttaso evam byañjanaso padasaḥ atthasaḥ bahusaḥ sabba ākārena sabbasaḥ upāyasaḥ hetusaḥ ṭhānasaḥ yonisaḥ
translated: In the condition by way of Thread he makes it by way of the Thread’s division, thus by way of Thread. So by way of phrasing, by way of words, by way of meaning, by way of much, by way of all aspects, by way of all, by way of means, by way of cause, by way of opportunity, by way of what is suitable.

original: 421. Sabbanāmehi pakāravacane tu thā.🔽Sabbanāmehi pakāravacanatthe thāpaccayo hoti, tusaddena thattāpaccayo ca. Sāmaññassa
analyzed: sabbanāmehi pakāra vacane tu thā  sabbanāmehi pakāra vacana tthe thā paccayaḥ hoti tu saddena tha tā paccayaḥ ca sāmaññassa
translated: In the case of the expression of a particular by means of all the names, however, there is tha.

original: bhedako viseso pakāro, tassābhidhāneti attho, so pakāro tathā, taṃ pakāraṃ tathā,
analyzed: bhedakaḥ visesaḥ pakāro tassa abhidhānā iti attho saḥ pakāraḥ tathā tam pakāram tathā
translated: The condition tha is for the meaning of the expression of a particular by means of all the names, and the condition that is tha is for the meaning of the expression of a particular by means of the name that. The particular is the distinction of the general, the meaning is the expression of that particular, that particular is so, that particular is thus,

original: tena pakārena tathā, yena pakārena yathā. Evaṃ sabbathā, aññathā, itarathā, ubhayathā,
analyzed: tena pakārena tathā yena pakārena yathā evam sabbathā aññathā itarathā ubhayathā
translated: by that particular it is so, by that particular it is thus, by that particular it is as it is. So in every way, otherwise, in another way, in both ways,

original: thattāpaccaye tena pakārena tathattā. Evaṃ yathattā, aññathattā.
analyzed: thattā paccaye tena pakārena tathattā evam yathattā aññathattā
translated: In the condition that is tha, by that particular it is that. So in whatever way, in another way.

original: Ko pakāroti atthe –
analyzed: ko pakāro ti atthe
translated: What is the particular?

original: 422. Kimimehi thaṃ.
analyzed: kim ime hi tham
translated: What is this by means of?

original: Kiṃimaiccetehi thaṃpaccayo hoti pakāravacanatthe. “Kissa ka ve cā”ti ettha casaddena
analyzed: tham paccayaḥ hoti pakāra vacana atthe kissa ka ve ca ati ettha ca saddena
translated: The particle ca is used in the sense of “in what way?” as in “Kissa kā ve cā” .🔽The particle ca is used in the sense of “in what way?” as in “Kissa kā ve cā” .🔽The particle ca is used in the sense of “in what way?” as in “Kissa kā ve cā” .🔽The particle ca is used in the sense of “in what way?” as in “Kissa kā ve cā” .🔽The particle ca is used in the sense of “in what way?” as in “Kissa kā ve cā” .🔽The particle ca is used in the sense of “in what way?” as in “Kissa kā ve cā” .🔽The particle ca is used in the sense of “in what way?” as in “Kissa kā ve cā” .🔽The particle ca is used in the sense of “in what way?” as in “Kissa kā ve cā” .

analyzed: taddhita taḥ tāva

original: Imasmā jja siyā kāle, samānāparato jju ca;
analyzed: imasmāt jja siyā kāle samāna aparataḥ jju ca
translated: From this, in the sense of ‘today,’ and in the sense of ‘at the same time,’ and ‘afterwards,’

original: Imasaddassa’kāro ca, samānassa ca so siyā.
analyzed: ima sadda sakāraḥ ca samānassa ca saḥ siyā
translated: The letter ‘a’ of the word imassa, and samānassa, may be so.

original: Imasmiṃ kāle, imasmiṃ divase vā ajja, samāne kāle sajju, aparasmiṃdivase aparajju.🔽Nipātehi bhavatthe tanappaccayo. Ajja bhavaṃ ajjatanaṃ, ajja bhavā ajjatanī, sve
analyzed: imasmin kāle imasmin divase vā ajja samāne kāle sajju aparasmin divase aparajju  nipātehi bhavatthe tanap paccayaḥ ajja bhavam ajjatanam ajja bhavā ajjatanī sve
translated: In the sense of ‘at this time,’ ‘on this day,’ today; at the same time, sajju; on another day, aparajju.

original: bhavaṃ svātanaṃ. Evaṃ purātanaṃ, hiyyo bhavaṃ hiyyattanaṃ, hiyyo bhavā hiyyattanī iccādi.🔽Abyayataddhitaṃ.
analyzed: bhavam svātanam evam purātanam hiyyas bhavam hiyyattanam hiyyas bhavā hiyyattanī iccādi  a byaya taddhitam
translated: The base is formed by the addition of the nominal suffix -tana, in the sense of ‘place,’ to the words ajja, ‘today,’ and sve, ‘tomorrow.’ Thus: ajja bhavaṃ = ajjatanaṃ, ‘today’s place’; ajja bhavā = ajjatanī, ‘today’s time’; sve bhavaṃ = svātanaṃ, ‘tomorrow’s place.’ In the same way: purātanaṃ, ‘ancient’; hiyyo bhavaṃ = hiyyattanaṃ, ‘yesterday’s place’; hiyyo bhavā = hiyyattanī, ‘yesterday’s time.’

original: Sāmaññavuttibhāvatthā-byayato taddhitaṃ tidhā;🔽Tatrādi catudhāpaccā-nekatthassatthisaṅkhyāto.
analyzed: sāmañña vutti bhāvattha abyayataḥ taddhitam tidhā  tatrādi
translated: The nominal suffix -tana is added in the sense of ‘place.’🔽The nominal suffix -tana is added in three ways: in the sense of ‘state,’ ‘condition,’ ‘habit,’ ‘manner,’ ‘place,’ and ‘time.’

original: Iti padarūpasiddhiyaṃ taddhitakaṇḍo🔽Pañcamo.🔽6. Ākhyātakaṇḍa🔽Bhūvādigaṇa🔽Vibhattividhāna🔽Atha ākhyātavibhattiyo kriyāvācīhi dhātūhi parā vuccante.🔽Tattha kriyaṃ ācikkhatīti ākhyātaṃ, kriyāpadaṃ. Vuttañhi “kālakārakapurisaparidīpakaṃ
analyzed: iti pada rūpa siddhiyam taddhita kaṇḍo 🔽pañcamaḥ 🔽ākhyāta kaṇḍa 🔽bhūva ādi gaṇa 🔽vibhatti vidhāna 🔽atha ākhyāta vibhattiyaḥ kriyā vācīhi dhātūhi parāḥ vuccante 🔽tattha kriyam ācikkhati iti ākhyātam kriyāpadam vuttam hi kāla kāraka purisa paridīpakam
translated: Therein, the first is of four kinds, according as it is added to a noun, to a numeral, or to a word expressing plurality.

original: kriyālakkhaṇamākhyātika”nti. Tattha kāloti atītādayo, kārakamiti kammakattubhāvā,
analyzed: kriyā lakkhaṇam ākhyātikanti tattha kālaḥ ti atīta ādayaḥ kārakam iti
translated: and the verbal root’s meaning is the action.🔽Herein, the time is the past, etc., the person is the first, middle, and superlative,

original: purisāti paṭhamamajjhimuttamā, kriyāti gamanapacanādiko dhātvattho, kriyālakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: purisā ti paṭhama majjhima uttamā kriyā ati gamana pacana ādikaḥ dhātvatthaḥ kriyā lakkhaṇam
translated: and the action is the meaning of the verbal root, such as going, cooking, and so on.

original: saññāṇaṃ etassāti kriyālakkhaṇaṃ, atiliṅgañca.
analyzed: saññāṇam etassa ati kriyā lakkhaṇam ati liṅgam ca
translated: The verbal root’s characteristic is the idea of action.

original: Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: vuttam pi ca itam
translated: And this is said:🔽“The verbal root is said to be

original: “Yaṃ tikālaṃ tipurisaṃ, kriyāvāci tikārakaṃ;
analyzed: yam ti kālam ti purisam kriyā vāci ti kārakam
translated: Three-timed, three-personed, and three-voiced,

original: Atiliṅgaṃ dvivacanaṃ, tadākhyātanti vuccatī”ti.
analyzed: ati liṅgam dvivacanam vuccati iti
translated: And has a dual-gendered form.”

original: Kālādivasena dhātvatthaṃ vibhajantīti vibhattiyo, tyādayo, tā pana vattamānā pañcamī sattamī parokkhāhiyyattanī ajjatanī bhavissantī kālātipatti cāti aṭṭhavidhā bhavanti.🔽Kriyaṃ dhārentīti dhātavo, bhūvādayo, khādidhātuppaccayantā ca, te pana atthavasā
analyzed: kāla ādi vasena dhātu attham vibhajanti iti vibhattiyaḥ tyādayo tā pana vattamānā pañcamī sattamī parokkhā ahiyyattanī ajjatanī bhavissantī kāla atipatti ca ati aṭṭhavidhāḥ bhavanti  kriyam dhārenti iti dhātavaḥ bhū vādayaḥ ca te pana attha vasā
translated: The endings are so called because they distinguish the verbal root’s meaning by means of the time, etc. The endings are the suffixes ty-a, etc. They are of eight kinds as past, present, future, optative, imperative, passive, associative, and continuative.🔽The verbal roots are so called because they bear the action. The verbal roots are the roots bhū, etc., and those that have a suffix added to the root. They are of two kinds according to meaning,

original: dvidhā bhavanti sakammakā, akammakā cāti. Tatra sakammakā ye dhātavokammāpekkhaṃ
analyzed: dvidhā bhavanti sa kammakā akammakā ca ati tatra sa kammakāḥ ye
translated: as having an object and as having no object.🔽Herein, those verbal roots that have an object

original: kriyaṃ vadanti, yathā – kaṭaṃ karoti, gāmaṃ gacchati, odanaṃ pacatītiādayo, akammakā
analyzed: kriyam vadanti yathā kaṭam karoti gāmam gacchati odanam pacati iti ādayaḥ akammakā
translated: They call a verb, as in “He makes a pot,” “He goes to the village,” “He cooks rice,” etc., a verb with an object.

original: ye kammanirapekkhaṃ kriyaṃ vadanti, yathā – acchati, seti, tiṭṭhatītiādayo.
analyzed: ye kamma nirapekkham kriyam vadanti yathā acchati sā iti tiṭṭhati iti ādayaḥ
translated: They call a verb that does not require an object, as in “He breathes,” “He lies,” “He stands,” etc., a verb without an object.

original: Te pana sattavidhā bhavanti vikaraṇappaccayabhedena, kathaṃ? Avikaraṇā bhūvādayo.
analyzed: te pana sattavidhāḥ bhavanti vikaraṇa paccaya bhedena katham avikaraṇāḥ bhūva ādayo
translated: But they are of seven kinds according to the difference of the inchoate and the cause-sign conditions. How? The inchoate ones are bhū, etc.

original: Niggahītapubbakaavikaraṇā rudhādayo, yavikaraṇā divādayo, ṇuṇā uṇāvikaraṇā svādayo,
analyzed: niggahīta pubbaka a vikaraṇāḥ rudh ādayaḥ ya vikaraṇāḥ div ādayaḥ ṇu ṇāḥ u ṇa avikaraṇāḥ su ādayaḥ
translated: The cause-sign ones that have had a cause-sign previously are rudh, etc.; those that have had a cause-sign subsequently are divā, etc.; those that have had a cause-sign simultaneously are svā, etc.;

original: nāppaṇhāvikaraṇā kiyādayo, oyiravikaraṇā tanādayo, sakatthe ṇe ṇayantā curādayoti.
analyzed: na ap paṇhā vikaraṇā kiyā ādayaḥ tana ādayaḥ sa ka tthe ṇe ṇa yantā curādayaḥ ti
translated: those that have had a cause-sign in the sense of a question are kiyā, etc.; those that have had a cause-sign in the sense of a reply are tanā, etc.; those that have had a cause-sign in the sense of a noun are ṇe, ṇayantā, curā, etc.

original: Tattha paṭhamaṃ avikaraṇesu bhūvādīsu dhātūsu paṭhamabhūtā akammakā bhūiccetasmā dhātuto tyādayo parā yojīyante.
analyzed: tattha paṭhamam a vikaraṇesu bhū ādīsu dhātūsu paṭhama bhūtāḥ akammakāḥ dhātutaḥ tya ādayaḥ parāḥ
translated: Herein, first of all, in the case of the inchoate bhū, etc., the first inchoate bhū is without an object.

original: Bhūsattāyaṃ, “bhū”iccayaṃ dhātu sattāyamatthe vattate, kriyāsāmaññabhūte bhavane vattateti attho.🔽“Bhū”iti ṭhite –
analyzed: dhātu sattā ayam atthe vattate kriyā sāmañña bhūte bhavane  bhū iti ṭhite
translated: The bhū root is used in the sense of existence. It is used in the sense of the commonality of action, that is, in the sense of occurrence.🔽When bhū is established

original: 424. Bhūvādayo dhātavo.
analyzed: bhū ādayaḥ dhātavaḥ
translated: The bhū roots, etc., are the roots.

original: Bhūiccevamādayo ye kriyāvācino saddagaṇā, te dhātusaññā honti. Bhū ādi yesaṃ te bhūvādayo, atha vā bhūvā ādī pakārā yesaṃ te bhūvādayo.
analyzed: bhū id ca evamādayaḥ ye kriyā vācinaḥ te dhātu saññāḥ honti bhū ādi yesam te bhū vādayaḥ atha vā bhū vā ādī pakārāḥ yesam te bhū vādayaḥ
translated: The verbal roots beginning with bhū are those that have bhū as their beginning. Or alternatively, the verbal roots are those that have the beginning bhū, ā, etc.

original: Bhūvādīsu vakāroyaṃ, ñeyyo āgamasandhijo;
analyzed: bhūva ādīsu vakāraḥ iyam ñeyyaḥ āgama sandhi jaḥ
translated: The letter va should be known as the son of the traditional reading of the verbal roots.

original: Bhūvāppakārā vā dhātū, sakammākammakatthato.
analyzed: vā dhātū sa kamma a kamma katthataḥ
translated: Or the verbal roots are the beginning bhū, ā, etc., in the sense of having action and not having action.

original: “Kvaci dhātū”tiādito “kvacī”ti vattate.
analyzed: kvacid kvaci iti vattate
translated: The word kvacit is used from the words “kvacid dhātu” onwards.

original: 425. Dhātussanto loponekassarassa.
analyzed: dhātoḥ santaḥ lopaḥ na eka ssarassa
translated: The elision of the final vowel of a verbal root is optional.

original: Anekassarassa dhātussa anto kvaci lopo hoti.
analyzed: an eka ssarassa dhātussa antaḥ kvaci lopaḥ hoti
translated: The elision of the final vowel of a verbal root is optional in some instances.

original: Kvaciggahaṇaṃ “mahīyati samatho”tiādīsu nivattanatthaṃ, iti anekassarattābhāvā idha dhātvantalopo na hoti.
analyzed: kvacid gahaṇam mahīyati dhātu anta lopaḥ na
translated: The word kvacit is used in order to exclude such words as mahīyati samatho. Thus, because there is no plurality here, the elision of the final vowel of a verbal root does not take place here.

original: Tato dhātvādhikāravihitānekappaccayappasaṅge “vatticchānupubbikā saddappaṭipattī”ti katvā vattamānavacanicchāyaṃ –
analyzed: tatas dhātu ādhikāra vihita aneka paccaya ppasaṅge vatti icchā anupubbikā sadda ppaṭipattī iti katvā vattamāna vacanicchāyam
translated: Then, in the section on the application of the plural in the optative mood, which is stated by the rule of the optative mood, after the optative ending has been added,

original: 426. Vattamānā tianti, sitha, mima, teante, sevhe, emhe.
analyzed: vattamānā tianti sitha mima teante sevhe emhe
translated: the optative endings are ti, anti, sitha, mima, te, ante, sevhe, emhe.

original: Tyādayo dvādasa vattamānāsaññā hontīti tyādīnaṃ vattamānatthavisayattā vattamānāsaññā.
analyzed: tyādayaḥ dvādasa vattamāna asaññāḥ honti iti tyādīnam vattamāna attha visaya ttā vattamāna asaññā
translated: The twelve, etc., are called “present-ten nouns” because they have the meaning of the present.

original: 427. Kāle.
analyzed: kāle
translated: In time.

original: Ayamadhikāro.
analyzed: ayam adhikāraḥ
translated: This is the topic.

original: Ito paraṃ tyādivibhattividhāne sabbattha vattate.
analyzed: i taḥ param t y ādi vibhatti vidhāne sabbattha vattate
translated: From here on, the exposition of the present-ten endings is applicable in all instances.

original: 428. Vattamānā paccuppanne.
analyzed: vattamānā paccuppanne
translated: The present-ten ending is used for the present time.

original: Paccuppanne kāle gamyamāne vattamānāvibhatti hoti, kāloti cettha kriyā, karaṇaṃ kāro, rakārassa lakāro, kālo.
analyzed: paccuppanne kāle gamyamāne hoti ca ittha kriyā karaṇam kāraḥ rakārassa lakāro kālo
translated: The present-ten ending is used for the present time, which is being gone through. Here, “time” is the action; the root is kā, the affix is ṇa, and the suffix is o. The root is kā because it is the cause of the action. The affix is ṇa because it is the cause of the action. The suffix is o because it is the cause of the action.

original: Tasmā –🔽Kriyāya gamyamānāya, vibhattīnaṃ vidhānato;
analyzed: tasmai  kriyāya gamyamānāya
translated: Therefore—🔽Because the present-ten endings are formed🔽From the verb in the present tense,🔽It is established that they are formed

original: Dhātūheva bhavantīti, siddhaṃ tyādivibhattiyo.
analyzed: dhātu ūha iva bhavanti iti siddham
translated: From the verb alone, with ty- etc.

original: Idha pana kālassa atītānāgatapaccuppannāṇattiparikappakālābhipattivasena chadhā bhinnattā
analyzed: idha pana kālassa atīta anāgata paccuppanna āṇatti parikappa kāla abhipatti vasena chadhā bhinna ttā
translated: Here, however, time is divided into six kinds as past, future, present, and as the time of the four postures, the time of the four mental activities, and the time of the four intentions.🔽Therefore, the present-ten ending is used for the present time, which is being gone through.

original: “paccuppanne”ti viseseti. Taṃ taṃ kāraṇaṃ paṭicca uppanno paccuppanno, paṭiladdhasabhāvo,
analyzed: paccuppannā iti viseseti tam tam kāraṇam paṭicca uppannaḥ paccuppannaḥ paṭiladdha sabhāvaḥ
translated: The present is that which has arisen in dependence on such and such a cause, which has acquired its own individual essence,

original: na tāva atītoti attho.🔽Paccuppannasamīpepi, tabbohārūpacārato;
analyzed: na tāva atīto ti attho  paccuppanna samīpe pi tad bohāra upacārataḥ
translated: which is not yet past—this is the meaning.🔽Even in the vicinity of the present,🔽Because of the usage of the present-ten ending,🔽The present-ten ending is used even for the past,

original: Vattamānā atītepi, taṃkālavacanicchayāti.
analyzed: vattamānāḥ atīte pi taṃ kāla vacana icchayā ati
translated: Because of the desire to speak of it as if it were that time.

original: Tasmiṃ paccuppanne vattamānāvibhattiṃ katvā, tassā ṭhānāniyame “dhātuliṅgehi parā
analyzed: tasmin paccuppanne vattamānā vibhattim katvā tassāḥ ṭhāna aniyame dhātu liṅgehi parā
translated: When that has been done, the places of the present tense are determined by the rule “After the bases, the present🔽is the case-ending.” So after the bases the present case-ending is made.

original: paccayā”ti paribhāsato dhātuto paraṃ vattamānappaccaye katvā, tesamaniyamappasaṅgesati
analyzed: paccayā ti paribhāsataḥ dhātutaḥ param vattamāna ppaccaye katvā
translated: When that has been done, the places of the present tense are determined by the rule “The present tense is the first of the

original: “vatticchānupubbikā saddappaṭipattī”ti parassapadavacanicchāyaṃ –
analyzed: vatti chā anupubbikā sadda paṭipatti iti
translated: inflections, and the order of the words is the order of the letters.”

original: 429. Atha pubbāni vibhattīnaṃ cha parassapadāni.
analyzed: atha pubbāni vibhattīnam cha parassa padāni
translated: . Then there are six words that precede the inflections.🔽Then of the eight kinds of inflections beginning with the present

original: Atha taddhitānantaraṃ vuccamānānaṃ sabbāsaṃ vattamānādīnaṃ aṭṭhavidhānaṃ vibhattīnaṃ
analyzed: atha taddhita anantaram vuccamānānam sabbāsam vattamāna ādīnam aṭṭhavidhānam vibhattīnam
translated: that are stated next to the nominal derivatives,

original: yāni yāni pubbakāni cha padāni, tāni tāni atthato aṭṭhacattālīsamattāni parassapadasaññāni🔽hontītiādimhi channaṃ parassapadasaññā, parassatthāni padāni parassapadāni, tabbāhullato tabbohāro.
analyzed: yāni yāni pubbakāni cha padāni tāni tāni atthataḥ aṭṭha cattālīsa mattāni parassa pada saññāni  honti iti ādimhi channam parassa pada saññā parassa atthāni padāni parassa padāni tad bāhullataḥ tad bohāro
translated: the first six words are in fact forty-eight in meaning, and they are🔽called “words that precede the other words.”🔽The words that precede the other words are the words that precede the other words. The elision of the syllable -bb- is by the rule “The elision of -bb- is by the rule of the elision of -bb-.”

original: “Dhātūhi ṇe ṇaya”iccādito “dhātūhī”ti vattamāne –
analyzed: dhātūhi ṇe ṇa ya e c ca āditaḥ dhātūhi iti vattamāne
translated: “The -ṇe and -ṇaya are after the bases” and so on.🔽In the present tense

original: 430. Kattari parassapadaṃ.
analyzed: kattari parassa padam
translated: The word that precedes is the word that precedes the other word.

original: Kattarikārake abhidheyye sabbadhātūhi parassapadaṃ hotīti parassapadaṃ katvā, tassāpyaniyamappasaṅge vatticchāvasā –
analyzed: kattari kārake abhidheyye sabba dhātūhi parassa padam hoti iti parassa padam katvā tassa api aniyama ppasaṅge
translated: The word “other” is formed by adding the suffix -a to the base of the third case, which is the same as the base of the nominative. And the rule of option in -i and -e applies to it.

original: Vipariṇāmena “parassapadānaṃ, attanopadāna”nti ca vattate.
analyzed: vipariṇāmena parassa padānam attanā upadānam iti ca vattate
translated: And the rule of change of -a to -o applies to the words of the second case.

original: 431. Dve dve paṭhamamajjhimuttamapurisā.
analyzed: dve dve paṭhama majjhima uttama purisā
translated: Two each, first, middle, and last persons.

original: Tāsaṃ vibhattīnaṃ parassapadāna’mattanopadānañca dve dve vacanāni yathākkamaṃ paṭhamamajjhimuttamapurisasaññāni
analyzed: tāsam vibhattīnam dve dve vacanāni yathākkamam paṭhama majjhima uttama purisa saññāni
translated: Of these endings, the words of the second case have two forms each, which are called the first, middle, and last persons respectively.

original: honti. Taṃ yathā? Ti antiiti paṭhamapurisā, si thaiti majjhimapurisā, mi maiti uttamapurisā.
analyzed: honti tam yathā ti anti iti paṭhama purisā si tha eti majjhima purisā mi mā eti uttama purisā
translated: They are as follows: ti, anti, are the first persons; si, thi, are the middle persons; mi, ma, are the last persons.

original: Attanopadesupi te anteiti paṭhamapurisā, se vheiti majjhimapurisā, e mheiti uttamapurisā.
analyzed: te ante iti paṭhama purisā se vhe iti majjhima purisā e mhe iti uttama purisā
translated: And in the first case, too, te, ante, are the first persons; se, vhe, are the middle persons; e, mhe, are the last persons.

original: Evaṃ sesāsu sattasu vibhattīsupi yojetabbanti. Evaṃ aṭṭhavibhattivasena channavutividhe
analyzed: evam sesāsu sattasu vibhattīsu pi yojetabbanti evam aṭṭha vibhatti vasena channavuti vidhe
translated: So it should be extended to the other seven endings. Thus in the eighty-nine kinds of words that have been explained by means of the eight endings,

original: ākhyātapade dvattiṃsa dvattiṃsa paṭhamamajjhimauttamapurisā hontīti vattamānaparassapadādimhi
analyzed: ākhyāta pade dvattiṃsa dvattiṃsa paṭhama majjhima uttama purisāḥ honti iti vattamāna parassa pada ādimhi
translated: there are thirty-two first, middle, and last persons in each of the thirty-two words of the present tense that have the second case ending and so on.

original: dvinnaṃ paṭhamapurisasaññā.
analyzed: dvinnam paṭhama purisa saññā
translated: and in the two, the first-person-singular-form.🔽. When a noun is used,

original: 432. Nāmamhi payujjamānepitulyādhikaraṇe paṭhamo.
analyzed: nāmamhi payujjamāna ipi tulya adhikaraṇe paṭhamaḥ
translated: in a sentence where the subject is the same, the first-person-singular-form.

original: Tumhāmhasaddavajjite tulyādhikaraṇabhūte sādhakavācake nāmamhi payujjamānepi appayujjamānepi
analyzed: tumha amha sadda vajjite tulya adhikaraṇa bhūte sādhaka vācake nāmamhi payujjamāne api appayujjamāne api

original: dhātūhi paṭhamapuriso hotīti paṭhamapurisaṃ katvā, tassāpyaniyamappasaṅge kriyāsādhakassa
analyzed: dhātūhi paṭhama purisaḥ hoti iti paṭhama purisam katvā tassa api aniyama ppasaṅge kriyā sādhakassa

original: kattuno ekatte vattumicchite “ekamhi vattabbe ekavacana”nti vattamānaparassapadapaṭhamapurisekavacanaṃ ti.
analyzed: kattunaḥ eka atte vattum icchite ekamhi vattabbe ekavacanam ti

original: “Paro, paccayo, dhātū”ti ca adhikāro, “yathā kattari cā”ti ito “kattarī”ti vikaraṇappaccayavidhāne sabbattha vattate.
analyzed: paraḥ paccayaḥ dhātu iti ca adhikāraḥ yathā kattari ca ati itas kattari iti vikaraṇa ppaccaya vidhāne sabbattha vattate
translated: And the extension “another, a condition, a verbal root” applies, and the word “verbal root” from the rule “As in the case of the doer” applies in the formation of the conditions for the case endings, everywhere.

original: 433. Bhūvādito a.
analyzed: bhū āditaḥ a
translated: . From a verbal root, etc., a.

original: Bhūiccevamādito dhātugaṇato paro apaccayo hoti kattari vihitesu vibhattippaccayesu paresu. Sabbadhātukamhiyevāyamissate.
analyzed: bhū i t ca evamāditaḥ dhātu gaṇataḥ paraḥ a paccayaḥ hoti kattari vihitesu vibhatti paccayesu paresu
translated: After a verbal root, etc., a non-condition is formed, in the case of the doer, when the case endings are used, other than the conditions for the case endings. This applies only in the case of all verbal roots.

original: “Asaṃyogantassa, vuddhī”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: a saṃyoga antassa vuddhi iti ca vattate
translated: And the rule “When there is no compound, the augment” applies.

original: 434. Aññesu ca.
analyzed: aññesu ca
translated: . And in other cases.

original: Kāritato aññesu paccayesu asaṃyogantānaṃ dhātūnaṃ vuddhi hoti. Caggahaṇena ṇuppaccayassāpi

original: vuddhi hoti. Ettha ca “ghaṭādīnaṃ vā”ti ito vāsaddo anuvattetabbo, so ca vavatthitavibhāsattho. Tena –

original: Yuvaṇṇānampi ya ṇu ṇā-nāniṭṭhādīsu vuddhi na;

original: Tudādissāvikaraṇe, na chetvādīsu vā siyā.
analyzed: tud ādiḥ sa a vikaraṇe na chetu ādīsu vā siyā
translated: The growth is not in the case of the unlike, etc.,🔽And in the case of the growth of the unlike, etc.,🔽The growth is of the like, not of the unlike.”

original: Tassāpyaniyamappasaṅge – “ayuvaṇṇānañcāyo vuddhī”ti paribhāsato ūkārassokāro vuddhi.
analyzed: tassa api aniyama ppasaṅge vuddhi iti paribhāsato ūkārassa ukāraḥ
translated: And in the case of the growth of the unlike, etc., the growth is of the like, not of the unlike, by the rule “And of the unlike, the growth is of the like.”

original: Vipariṇāmena “dhātūna”nti vattate.
analyzed: vipariṇāmena vattate
translated: The word “elements” is used in the sense of “change.”

original: 435. O ava sare.
analyzed: o ava sare

original: Okārassa dhātvantassa sare pare avādeso hoti. “Saralopo mādesa”iccādinā saralopādimhi kate “naye paraṃ yutte”ti paranayanaṃ kātabbaṃ.

original: So puriso sādhu bhavati, sā kaññā sādhu bhavati, taṃ cittaṃ sādhu bhavati.

analyzed: tvam ca pacasi iti pariyāya ppasaṅge tumhe pacatha ati bhavati evam saḥ ca pacati aham ca  pacāmi iti mayam pacāma tathā tvañca pacasi aham ca pacāmi mayam pacāma saḥ ca pacati

original: Ekābhidhāneti kimatthaṃ? “So ca pacati, tvañca pacissasi, ahaṃ paciṃ” ettha bhinnakālattā “mayaṃ pacimhā”ti na bhavati.

original: “Kuto nu tvaṃ āgacchasi, rājagahato āgacchāmī”tiādīsu pana paccuppannasamīpe vattamānavacanaṃ.🔽“Vā”ti vattate.🔽443. Gamissa ghammaṃ.
