The vowel a is called a vowel. He is a leader of the world, thus he is a leader-of-the-world . The vowel a is called a vowel. He is a leader of beings, thus he is a leader-of-beings . The vowel a is called a vowel. He is a maker, thus he is a maker . The vowel a is called a vowel. He is a verse, thus it is a verse . The vowel a is called a vowel. He is a giver, thus he is a giver . The vowel a is called a vowel. He is a woman giver, thus she is a woman giver . The vowel a is called a vowel. He is a man giver, thus he is a man giver . The vowel a is called a vowel. He is a leader, thus he is a leader . The vowel a is called a vowel. He is a woman leader, thus she is a woman leader . The vowel a is called a vowel. He is a man leader, thus he is a man leader . The vowel a is called a vowel. He has not heard, hears, will hear the Blessed One’s advice and instruction, thus he is a disciple . The vowel a is called a vowel. He is a woman disciple, thus she is a woman disciple . The vowel a is called a vowel. He is a man disciple, thus he is a man

original: Pacatīti pācako. Ayaji, yajati, yajissatīti vā yājako. Ettha hi “kagā cajāna”nti cajānaṃ kagatte sampatte –
analyzed: pacati iti pācakaḥ ayaji yajati yajissati iti vā yājakaḥ ettha hi kagā cajānanti cajānam kagatte sampatte
translated: The maker of a sacrifice is a yājaka, from yaji, yajati, yajissati. Here, in the word cajāna, the reduplication is treated as a single syllable,

original: 571. Na kagattaṃ cajā ṇvumhi.
analyzed: na ka gattam ca jā ṇ vumhi
translated: . The reduplication is not treated as a single syllable in cajāna.

original: Dhātvantabhūtā cakārajakārā kakāra gakārattaṃ nāpajjante ṇvuppaccaye pareti paṭisiddhattā na bhavati.🔽Jana janane, janetīti janako, janikā, “ghaṭādīnaṃ vā”ti ettha vāggahaṇena vuddhi🔽na hoti. Evaṃ khanatīti khanako, sametīti samako, gametīti gamako, dametīti damako,🔽ahani, hanti, hanissatīti vā vadhako, “vadho vā sabbatthā”ti hanassa vadhādeso, hantīti🔽yātako, “hanassa ghāto”ti ṇvumhi ghātādeso, gāvo hanatīti goghātako, rundhatīti rundhako,
analyzed: dhātu anta bhūtā cakāra jakārā kakāra gakāra ttam na āpajjante ṇu uppaccaye parā iti paṭisiddha ttā na bhavati  jana janane janeti iti janakaḥ janikā ghaṭa ādīnam vāti ettha vāc gahaṇena  na hoti evam khanati iti khanakaḥ sameti iti samakaḥ gameti iti gamakaḥ dameti iti damakaḥ  ahani hanti hanissati iti vā vadhakaḥ vadhaḥ vā sabbattha ati hanassa vadha ādesaḥ hanti iti  yātakaḥ hanassa ghāto ti ṇvumhi ghāta ādesaḥ gāvaḥ hanati iti go ghātakaḥ rundhati iti rundhakaḥ
translated: The syllables ca and ja, which are the last syllables of the reduplicated syllable, do not become a single syllable, because the rule “na kagattaṃ cajā ṇvumhi” is a prohibition.

original: niggahītāgamo, saṃyogantattā na vuddhi hoti. Evaṃ bhuñjatīti bhuñjako, kiṇātīti kāyako,
analyzed: niggahīta āgamo saṃyoga anta ttā na hoti evam bhuñjati iti bhuñjako kiṇāti iti kāyako
translated: The maker of a pot is a ghaṭaka, from ghaṭati, ghaṭissati. The maker of a sacrifice is a yājaka, from yaji, yajati, yajissati. The maker of a pot is a ghaṭaka, from ghaṭati, ghaṭissati. original: pāletīti pālako, pūjetīti pūjako.
analyzed: pālā iti iti pālako pūjā iti iti pūjako
translated: Pāle means a guardian, pūje means one who worships.

original: 572. Nudādīhi yuṇvūnamanānanākānanakā sakāritehi ca.
analyzed: nud ādīhi yu ṇ vu ū namana ānanā kānanakā sa kāri tehi ca
translated: With nud and so on, yuṇ, vū, ān, ana, ākā, sakāri.

original: Nudādīhi dhātūhi, sakāritehi ca dhātūhi paresaṃ yuṇvuppaccayānaṃ yathākkamaṃ ana ānana aka ānanakaiccete ādesā honti.
analyzed: nud ādīhi dhātūhi sa kāritehi ca dhātūhi paresam yu ṇ vu p paccayānam yathākkamam anaḥ ānana akaḥ ānana ka e c ca ite ādesāḥ honti
translated: With the roots nud and so on, and with the roots sakāri, the following augmentations are made to the other roots respectively: ana, ān, aka, ākā, and sakāri.

original: Ettha hi –
analyzed: ettha hi
translated: For here:

original: Sakāritehi yuṇvūnaṃ, kāriyassa vidhānato;
analyzed: sa kāritehi yuṇvūnam kāriyassa vidhānataḥ
translated: With sakāri, because the function of the root is enjoined,

original: Kiccakitthambhavo dhātu-ppaccayehipi vediyo.
analyzed: kicca kitthambhavaḥ dhātup paccayehi pi vediyaḥ
translated: The state of being a verb and a noun is known by the augmentations.

original: Nuda khepe papubbo, panudi, panudati, panudissatīti vā atthe ṇvuppaccayo, tassiminā akādeso, “kvaci dhātū”tiādinā nudissa dīgho, panūdako.🔽Sūda paggharaṇe, sūdatīti sūdako. Ñā avabodhane, aññāsi, jānāti, jānissatīti vā atthe ṇvuppaccayo, tassānena ānanakādeso, “ñāssa jājaṃnā”ti jādeso, saralopādi, jānanako.
analyzed: nuda khepe papubbaḥ panudi panudati panudissati iti vā atthe ṇvup paccayaḥ tassiminā aka ādesaḥ kvaci dhātu uti ādinā dīghaḥ panūdakaḥ  paggharaṇe sūdati iti sūdakaḥ ñā avabodhane aññāsi jānāti jānissati iti vā atthe ṇvu ppaccayaḥ tassa anena ānana kādesaḥ ñāssa sara lopa ādi jānanakaḥ
translated: With the meaning “to throw out,” “to throw away,” the augmentation ṇvu is added to nud, and the vowel a is substituted for the final i by the rule “kvaci dhātū” and so on. The long vowel is by the rule “nudissa dīgho,” and the form is panūdaka.

original: Sakāritehi pana āṇa pesane, āṇāpesi, āṇāpeti, āṇāpessatīti vā atthe “sabbato ṇvutvāvī
analyzed: sa kāritehi pana āṇa pesane āṇāpesi āṇāpeti āṇāpessati iti vā atthe sabbatas
translated: With the meaning “to flow out,” the augmentation ṇvu is added to sūda, and the vowel a is substituted for the final i by the rule “ñāssa jājaṃnā” and so on. analyzed: a kattari pi viññeyyaḥ kārake ṇassa sambhavaḥ ti
translated: Is understood as the agent, even though it is not the agent.

original: Ranjanti anenāti rāgo, rañjīyati anenāti vā rāgo, sayaṃ rañjatītipi rāgo. “Ṇamhi🔽ranjassa jo”ti yogavibhāgena jakāro. Pajjate anenāti pādo, patujjate anenāti patodo,🔽jarīyati anenāti jāro. Evaṃ dāro. Tathā kammādīsu, bhujjatīti bhogo. Evaṃ bhāgo,
analyzed: ranjanti anena ati rāgaḥ anena ati vā rāgaḥ sayam rañjati iti pi  ranjassa yogavibhāgena jakāraḥ pajjate anena ati pādaḥ patujjate anena ati patodaḥ  jarīyati anena ati jāraḥ evam tathā kamma ādīsu bhujjati iti bhogaḥ evam bhāgo
translated: Rāga is derived from the root ranj, to delight, in the sense of “he delights by means of this” or “he is delighted by means of this,” or “he delights himself.” The -j- is a ligature by the rule “In the locative of ranj, the -j- becomes -j-.”🔽Pāda is derived from the root paj, to go, in the sense of “he goes by means of this.” Patodo is derived from the root patuj, to go, in the sense of “he goes out by means of this.”

original: bhāro, labbhatīti lābho, voharīyatīti vohāro, dīyatīti dāyo, vihaññati etasmāti vighāto,
analyzed: bhāraḥ labbhati iti lābhaḥ voharīyati iti vohāraḥ dīyati iti dāyaḥ vihaññati etasmā ati vighāto
translated: Jāra is derived from the root jar, to grow old, in the sense of “he grows old by means of this.” Dāra is similar. Bhāga is derived from the root bhuj, to enjoy, in the sense of “he enjoys.” Bhāra is derived from the same root in the sense of “he bears.” Lābho is derived from the root labh, to obtain, in the sense of “he obtains.” Voghāro is derived from the root voh, to speak, in the sense of “he speaks.” Dāyo is derived from the root dā, to give, in the sense of “he gives.” Vighāto is derived from the root vihaññ, to be destroyed, in the sense of “he is destroyed by this.”

original: viharanti etthāti vihāro, āramanti etasminti ārāmo. Evaṃ papāto iccādi.
analyzed: viharanti ettha ati vihāraḥ āramanti etasmin ti ārāmaḥ evam iccādi
translated: A monastery is so called because the bhikkhus dwell there. A park is so called because they resort to it. So too with a pit, etc.

original: “Ṇa”iti vattate.
analyzed: ṇa eti vattate
translated: The syllable ṇa is used.

original: 580. Bhāve ca.
analyzed: bhāve ca
translated: And in the sense of the state.

original: Bhāvatthe bhāvābhidheyye dhātūhi ṇappaccayo hoti. Bhūyate, bhavanaṃ vā bhāvo, paccate, pacanaṃ vā pāko, “kagā cajāna”nti kādeso.
analyzed: bhāva atthe bhāva abhidheyye dhātūhi ṇa p paccayaḥ hoti bhūyate bhavanam vā bhāvaḥ paccate pacanam vā pākaḥ ka gā ca jānanti ka ādesaḥ
translated: The syllable ṇa is used after the verbal-basis in the sense of the state, that is to say, in the sense of what is denoted by the verbal-basis. Bhūyate, bhavanaṃ vā bhāvo, paccate, pacanaṃ vā pāko, “kagā cajāna”nti kādeso.

original: Sica paggharaṇe, secanaṃ seko. Suca soke, socanaṃ soko. Caja hānimhi, acajjittha,
analyzed: sica paggharaṇe secanam sekaḥ suca soke socanam sokaḥ caja hānimhi acajjittha
translated: Sica paggharaṇe, secanaṃ seko. Suca soke, socanaṃ soko. Caja hānimhi, acajjittha,

original: cajjate, cajjissate, cajanaṃ vā cāgo. Yaja devapūjāsaṅgatikaraṇadānesu, ijjittha,
analyzed: cajjate cajjissate cajanam vā cāgaḥ yaja deva pūjā saṅgati karaṇa dānesu ijjittha
translated: cajjate, cajjissate, cajanaṃ vā cāgo. Yaja devapūjāsaṅgatikaraṇadānesu, ijjittha,

original: ijjate, ijjissate, yajanaṃ vā yāgo, yuñjanaṃ yogo. Bhaja sevāyaṃ, abhajjittha, bhajjate,
analyzed: ijjate ijjissate yajanam vā yāgaḥ yuñjanam yogaḥ bhaja sā iva ayam abhajjittha bhajjate
translated: ijjate, ijjissate, yajanaṃ vā yāgo, yuñjanaṃ yogo. Bhaja sevāyaṃ, abhajjittha, bhajjate,

original: bhajjissate, bhajanaṃ vā bhāgo, arajjittha, rajjate, rajjissate, rajanaṃ vā rāgo, jassa gakāro.
analyzed: bhajjissate bhajanam vā bhāgaḥ arajjittha rajjate rajjissate rajanam vā rāgaḥ jassa gakāraḥ
translated: bhajjissate, bhajanaṃ vā bhāgo, arajjittha, rajjate, rajjissate, rajanaṃ vā rāgo, jassa gakāro.

original: Daha bhasmīkaraṇe, pariḍayhittha, pariḍayhati, pariḍayhissati, pariḍayhanaṃ vāti atthe ṇappaccayo.
analyzed: daha bhasmīkaraṇe pariḍayhittha pariḍayhati pariḍayhissati pariḍayhanam vā atthe ṇap paccayaḥ
translated: Daha bhasmīkaraṇe, pariḍayhittha, pariḍayhati, pariḍayhissati, pariḍayhanaṃ vāti atthe ṇappaccayo.

original: “Ṇamhi, vā”ti ca vattate.🔽581. Dahassa do laṃ.🔽Dahaiccetassa dhātussa dakāro lattamāpajjate ṇappaccaye pare vā. Pariḷāho, paridāho. Bhanja avamaddane, bhañjanaṃ bhaṅgo. Sanja saṅge, sañjanaṃ saṅgo, nassa niggahītaṃ.🔽Paccayehi saṅgamma karīyati, saṅkharīyati tena vāti atthe visarujapadādinā, saṅkharaṇanti atthe “bhāve cā”ti vā ṇappaccayo.
analyzed: ṇamhi vāti ca vattate  dahassa daḥ laṃ  daha ai c ca itassa dhātussa dakāraḥ lattam āpajjate ṇap paccaye pare vā pariḷāhaḥ paridāhaḥ bhanja avamaddane bhañjanam bhaṅgo sanja saṅge sañjanam saṅgaḥ nassa niggahītam  paccayehi saṅgamma karīyati saṅkharīyati tena vā ati atthe visa ruja pada ādinā atthe bhāve ca ati vā ṇappaccayaḥ
translated: “I am not” is said.🔽Dahassa do laṃ.🔽If there is dah in this element, the syllable da becomes la in the presence of the syllable na as the case-ending. Parilāho, paridāho. Bhanja avamaddane, bhañjanaṃ bhaṅgo. Sanja saṅge, sañjanaṃ saṅgo, nassa niggahītaṃ.🔽Paccayehi saṅgamma karīyati, saṅkharīyati tena vāti atthe visarujapadādinā, saṅkharaṇanti atthe “bhāve cā”ti vā ṇappaccayo.

original: “Ṇamhī”ti vattate.🔽582. Purasamupaparīhi karotissa khakharā vā tappaccayesu ca.
analyzed: ṇamhi iti vattate  pura sam upa parīhi karotissa kha kha rāḥ vā tad paccayesu ca
translated: and “I am not” is said.🔽The syllable DA becomes LA after the syllable DA, or the syllable DA becomes LA after the syllable DA, when the syllable NA is the following syllable.🔽The syllable DA becomes the syllable LA after the syllable DA, when the syllable NA is the following syllable.🔽The syllable DA becomes the syllable LA after the syllable DA, when the syllable NA is the following syllable.

original: Pura saṃ upa pariiccetehi parassa karotissa dhātussa kha kharaiccete ādesā honti
analyzed: pura sam upa pari icca itehi parassa karotissa dhātussa kha kha ra i cca ite ādesāḥ honti

syllable NA is the following syllable.

original: vā tappaccaye, ṇappaccaye ca pare. “Tappaccayesū”ti bahuvacananiddesena tuṃ tvādīsupi.🔽Dhātvādesassāpi ṭhānopacārena dhātuvohārato “asaṃyogantassa vuddhi kārite”ti vuddhi,
analyzed: vā tad paccaye ṇap paccaye ca pare tad paccayesu iti bahuvacana niddesena tum tva ādīsupi 🔽dhātu ādesassa api ṭhāna upacārena dhātu vohārataḥ a saṃyoga antassa vuddhi kāritā iti
translated: The syllable DA becomes the syllable LA after the syllable DA, when the syllable NA is the following syllable.🔽The syllable DA becomes the syllable LA after the

original: saṅkhāro. Evaṃ parikkhāro, purekkhāro.
analyzed: saṅkhāro evam parikkhāro purekkhāro
translated: is a formation. Thus it is a parikkhāra, a purekkhāra.

original: Vāti kiṃ? Upakāro.
analyzed: vāti kim
translated: What? A benefit.

original: Lubha giddhimhi, lubbhanti tena, sayaṃ vā lubbhati, lubbhanamattameva vā tanti lobho.
analyzed: giddhimhi lubbhanti tena sayam vā lubbhati lubbhana mattam eva vā lobho
translated: Lubha is in the sense of greed; they are greedy by it, or it is greedy itself, or it is just mere greed.

original: Dusa appītimhi, dussanti tena, sayaṃ vā dussati, dussanamattameva vā tanti doso.
analyzed: appītimhi dussanti tena sayam vā dussati dussana mattam eva vā doso
translated: Dusa is in the sense of displeasure; they are displeased by it, or it is displeased itself, or it is just mere displeasure.

original: Muha vecitte, muyhanti tena, sayaṃ vā muyhati, muyhanamattameva vā tanti moho iccādi
analyzed: vecitte muyhanti tena sayam vā muyhati muyhana mattam eva vā iccādi
translated: Muha is in the sense of bewilderment; they are bewildered by it, or it is bewildered itself, or it is just mere bewilderment.🔽Thus it is greed, hate, and delusion, etc.

original: kattukaraṇabhāvesu yathārahaṃ yojetabbaṃ.🔽Gaha upādāne, gayhatīti atthe visarujapadādinā kammani ṇappaccayo.
analyzed: kattu karaṇa bhāvesu yathāraham yojetabbam  gahaḥ upādāne gayhati iti atthe visa ruja pada ādinā kammani ṇap paccayaḥ
translated: It should be construed in the various ways according to the meaning in the case of the various verbal roots.

original: 583. Gahassa ghara ṇe vā.
analyzed: gahassa ghara ṇe vā
translated: Gaha is in the sense of grasping; the ṇap-suffix is added to the root gaha by the rule “gaha, upādāne” , and the ṇ-suffix is added by the rule “gahaṇe vā” .🔽Or it is a house.

original: Gahaiccetassa dhātussa gharādeso hoti vā ṇappaccaye pare, saralopādi, gharaṃ, gharāni.
analyzed: gaha e c ca itassa dhātussa ghara ādesaḥ hoti vā ṇap paccaye pare sara lopa ādi gharam gharāni
translated: The form ghara, etc., is substituted for the verbal root gaha by the rule “gahaiccetassa dhātussa gharādeso hoti vā ṇappaccaye pare” , and the ṇ-suffix is added by the rule “saralopādi” , and so there are the forms gharaṃ, gharāni, etc.

original: Vāti kiṃ? Gaṇhāti, gahaṇaṃ vā gāho.
analyzed: vāti kim gaṇhāti vā gāhaḥ
translated: What? It grasps, or it is a grasping.

original: Sambhavatīti atthe –🔽584. Kvi ca.
analyzed: sambhavati iti atthe  kvi ca
translated: In the sense of “it comes to be”🔽.🔽Kvi is added to all verbal roots.

original: Sabbadhātūhi kvipaccayo hoti, so ca kitasaññattā kattari bhavati.
analyzed: sabba dhātūhi kvi paccayaḥ hoti saḥ ca kita saññattā kattari bhavati
translated: And it is in the nominative case because it is regarded as a noun.🔽.

original: 585. Kvilopo ca.
analyzed: kvi lopaḥ ca
translated: Kvi is elided.

original: Kvino sabbassa lopo hoti. Kitantattā nāmamiva katvā syādyuppatti, silopo, sambhū. Evaṃ vibhavatīti vibhū, abhibhū, sayambhū.
analyzed: kvinaḥ sabbassa lopaḥ hoti ki tanta ttā nāmam iva katvā si lopaḥ sambhū evam vibhavati iti vibhū abhibhū sayambhū
translated: Kvi is added to the root with the meaning “to go” and the vowel is elided. Kitantatthā nāmamiva katvā syādyuppatti, silopo, sambhū. Thus vibhavatīti vibhū, abhibhū, sayambhū.

original: Tathā dhū kampane, sandhunātīti sandhū. Bhā dittimhi, vibhātīti vibhā, pabhātīti pabhā, saha, saṅgamma vā bhanti, bhāsanti vā etthāti sabhā, sahassa sādeso, niggahītalopo ca.
analyzed: tathā kampane sandhunāti iti sandhū bhā dittimhi vibhāti iti vibhā pabhāti iti pabhā saha saṅgamma vā bhanti bhāsanti vā ettha ati sabhā sahassa sa ādesaḥ niggahīta lopo ca
translated: Similarly, dhū means “to shake”; sandhunātīti sandhū. Bhā means “to shine”; vibhātīti vibhā, pabhātīti pabhā. Sabhā means “an assembly”; they shine together, or they shine here, saha, saṅgamma vā bhanti, bhāsanti vā etthāti sabhā. Sahassa sādeso, niggahītalopo ca.

original: Bhujena gacchatīti atthe kvippaccayo.
analyzed: bhujena gacchati iti atthe kvip paccayaḥ
translated: The kvip affix is added to the root with the meaning “to go by means of a limb”.

original: 586. Dhātvantassa lopo kvimhi.🔽Dhātvantassa byañjanassa lopo hoti kvippaccaye pare. Kvilopo, bhujago. Evaṃ urasā
analyzed: dhātu antassa lopaḥ kvimhi  dhātu antassa byañjanassa lopaḥ hoti kvip paccaye pare kvi lopaḥ bhujagaḥ evam urasā
translated: The vowel of the final syllable is elided in kvip.

original: gacchatīti urago, turaṃ sīghaṃ turitaturito gacchatīti turago, khe gacchatīti khago,
analyzed: gacchati iti uragaḥ turam sīgham turita turitaḥ gacchati iti turagaḥ khe gacchati iti khagaḥ
translated: The vowel of the final syllable of the root is elided in kvip. Kvilopo, bhujago. Thus urasā gacchatīti urago, turaṃ sīghaṃ turitaturito gacchatīti turago, khe gacchatīti khago,

original: vihāyase gacchatīti vihago, vihādeso, na gacchatīti ago, nago.
analyzed: vihāyase gacchati iti vihagaḥ na gacchati iti agaḥ
translated: vihāyase gacchatīti vihago, vihādeso, na gacchatīti ago, nago.

original: Khanu avadhāraṇe saṃpubbo, saṅkhani, saṅkhanati, saṅkhanissatīti vā saṅkho. Ramu
analyzed: avadhāraṇe saṃpubbaḥ saṅkhani saṅkhanati saṅkhanissati iti vā saṅkhaḥ ramu
translated: Khanu is added to the root with the meaning “to dig” and the vowel is elided. Saṃpubbo, saṅkhani, saṅkhanati, saṅkhanissatīti vā saṅkho. Ramu

original: kīḷāyaṃ, kuñje ramatīti kuñjaro. Jana janane, kammato jātoti atthe kvippaccayo, dhātvantassa
analyzed: kīḷā ayam kuñje ramati iti kuñjaraḥ jana janane kammataḥ jātaḥ iti atthe kvip paccayaḥ dhātu antassa
translated: He delights in a thicket (of grass) while playing, thus he is a “kuñjara” (elephant). In “janana” (birth), he is born from kamma, thus the kvi affix;

original: lopādi purimasamaṃ, pañcamītappurisova viseso. Kammajo vipāko, kammajā paṭisandhi,
analyzed: lopa ādi purima samam pañcamī tappurisaḥ uva visesaḥ kamma jaḥ vipākaḥ kamma jā paṭisandhi
translated: the elision of the final vowel, etc., is as before. The difference is that the fifth case is used. The result born of kamma is kammaja; the rebirth-linking born of kamma is kammajā paṭisandhi;

original: kammajaṃ rūpaṃ. Evaṃ cittajaṃ, utujaṃ, āhārajaṃ, attajo putto. Vārimhi jāto vārijo.🔽Evaṃ thalajo, paṅkajaṃ, jalajaṃ, aṇḍajaṃ, sirajaṃ, sattamīsamāso. Dvikkhattuṃ jāto
analyzed: kamma jam rūpam evam citta jam utu jam āhāra jam atta jaḥ puttaḥ vārimhi jātaḥ vāri jo  evam thala jaḥ paṅka jam jala jam aṇḍa jam sira jam sattamī samāsaḥ dvi khattum jātaḥ
translated: the materiality born of kamma is kammajaṃ rūpaṃ. So too: cittaja, utuja, āhāraja, attajo putto. He is born in the water, thus he is a “vārijo” (crocodile).

original: dvijo, pacchā jāto anujo iccādi.
analyzed: dvijaḥ pacchā jātaḥ anujaḥ it ca ādi
translated: So too: thalajo, paṅkajaṃ, jalajaṃ, aṇḍajaṃ, sirajaṃ. The compound in the seventh case. He is born twice, thus he is a “dvijo” (twice-born). He is born later, thus he is an “anujo” (younger brother), and so on.

original: Vida ñāṇe, lokaṃ avedīti atthe kvippaccayo.
analyzed: vida ñāṇe lokam avedi iti atthe kvip paccayaḥ
translated: In “vid” (knowing), he has known the world, thus the kvi affix.

original: “Kvimhī”ti vattate.🔽587. Vidante ū.
analyzed: kvimhi iti vattate  vidante ū
translated: “In kvi” is said.🔽The elision of the final vowel is ū.

original: Vidadhātuno ante ūkārāgamo hoti kvimhi, kvilopo. Lokavidū.
analyzed: vidadhātunaḥ ante ūkāra āgamaḥ hoti kvimhi kvi lopaḥ
translated: In kvi, there is addition of the syllable ū at the end of the verbal root vidadhā, and elision of the final vowel. Lokavidū.

original: Disa pekkhaṇe, imamiva naṃ apassi, passati, passissatīti, ayamiva dissatīti vā atthe kvippaccayo.
analyzed: disa pekkhaṇe imam iva nam apassi passati passissati iti ayam iva dissati iti vā atthe kvip paccayaḥ
translated: In “disa” (direction), he sees this as if it were the direction, he sees, he will see, or it appears as if it were this, thus the kvi affix.

original: “Dhātvantassa lopo kvimhī”ti dhātvantalope sampatte –
analyzed: dhātu antassa lopaḥ kvimhi iti dhātu anta lope sampatte
translated: “In kvi, there is elision of the final vowel of the verbal root” . When the elision of the final vowel of the verbal root has taken place,

original: 588. Iyatamakiesānamantassaro dīghaṃ kvaci disassa guṇaṃ do raṃ sakkhī ca.
analyzed: dīgham kvaci disassa guṇam doḥ ram sakkhī ca
translated: 588. The vowel of the final syllable of these words is lengthened before a following disa, and the vowel of the final syllable of the word sakkhi is lengthened before a following ra.🔽The words ima, ya, ta, amha, kiṃ, eta, samāna, icchese, sabba, and nāma are the examples.

original: Ima ya ta amha kiṃ eta samānaiccetesaṃ sabbanāmānaṃ upamānupapadabhāvena disassa🔽dhātussa guṇabhūtānaṃ anto saro dīghamāpajjate, disaiccetassa dhātussa antassa sa
analyzed: ima ya ta amha kim eta sabba nāmānam upamāna upapada bhāvena disassa  dhātussa guṇa bhūtānam antaḥ saraḥ dīgham āpajjate disā i cca itassa dhātussa antassa sa
translated: The vowel of the final syllable of these words is lengthened before a following disa, and the final🔽syllable of the word disa is elided, and the final syllable of the word sakkhi is lengthened before a following ra.🔽The vowel of the final syllable of the word disa is elided, and the vowel of the final syllable of the word sakkhi is lengthened.

original: kkha īiccete ādesā ca honti. Disassa dakāro rakāramāpajjateti kvimhi dhātvantassa🔽sasaddādesaṃ katvā kvilopādimhi ca kate iiti nipātanena imasaddassikāre, tassiminā
analyzed: kkhaḥ ī i t ca ete ādesā ca honti disassa dakāraḥ rakāram āpajjata iti kvimhi dhātu antassa  sa sadda ādesam katvā kvi lopa ādimhi ca kate i iti nipātanena ima sadda si kāre
translated: The vowel of the final syllable of the word disa is elided, and the vowel of the final syllable of the word sakkhi is lengthened.

original: dīghe ca kate syādyuppatti.
analyzed: dīghe ca kate
translated: The vowel of the final syllable of the word disa is elided, and the vowel of the final syllable of the word sakkhi is lengthened.🔽The vowel of the final syllable of the word disa is elided, and the vowel of the final syllable of the word sakkhi is lengthened.🔽The vowel of the final syllable of the word disa is elided, and the vowel of the final syllable of the word sakkhi is lengthened.🔽The vowel of the final syllable of the word disa is elided, and the vowel of the final syllable of the word sakkhi is lengthened.🔽The vowel of the final syllable of the word disa is elided, and the vowel of the final syllable of the word sakkhi is lengthened.

original: Īdiso puriso, īdisā kaññā, īdisī vā, īdisaṃ cittaṃ. Tathā yamiva naṃ passati, yo🔽viya dissatīti vā yādiso, yādisā, yādisī, yādisaṃ. Tamiva naṃ passati, so viya dissatīti
analyzed: īdisaḥ purisaḥ īdisā kaññā īdisī vā īdisam cittam tathā yam iva nam passati yaḥ  viya dissati iti vā yādisaḥ yādisā yādisī yādisam tam iva nam passati saḥ viya dissati iti
translated: The vowel of the final syllable of the word disa is elided, and the vowel of the final syllable of the word sakkhi is lengthened.🔽The vowel of the final syllable of the word disa is elided, and the vowel of the final syllable of the word sakkhi is lengthened.🔽The vowel of the final syllable of the word disa is elided, and the vowel of the final syllable of the word sakkhi is lengthened.🔽The vowel of the final syllable of the word disa is elided, and the vowel of the final syllable of the word sakkhi is lengthened.

original: vā tādiso, tādisā, tādisī, tādisaṃ. Mamiva naṃ passati, ahaṃ viya so dissatīti vā
analyzed: vā tādisaḥ tādisā tādisī tādisam mam iva nam passati aham viya saḥ dissati iti vā
translated: The vowel of the final syllable of the word disa is elided, and the vowel of the final syllable of the word sakkhi is lengthened.🔽The vowel of the final syllable of the word disa is elided,

original: mādiso, mādisā, mādisī, mādisaṃ, maiti nipātanena amhasaddassa masaddādeso. Kimiva
analyzed: mādisaḥ mādisā mādisī mādisam mā eti nipātanena amha saddassa ma sadda ādesaḥ kim iva
translated: Mādiso, mādisā, mādisī, mādisaṃ, maiti: by the addition of the particle ma, the word amha becomes mas.

original: naṃ passati, ko viya dissatīti vā kīdiso, kīdisā, kīdisī, kīdisaṃ. Etamiva naṃ passati,
analyzed: nam passati kaḥ viya dissati iti vā kīdisaḥ kīdisā kīdisī kīdisam etam iva nam passati
translated: Kīdiso, kīdisā, kīdisī, kīdisaṃ: what sort of? how sort of?

original: eso viya dissatīti vā ediso, etādiso vā, edisā, edisī, edisaṃ, eiti nipātanena etasaddassa
analyzed: esaḥ viya dissati iti vā edisaḥ etādisaḥ vā edisā edisī edisam nipātanena eta saddassa
translated: Ediso, etādiso, edisā, edisī, edisaṃ, eiti: by the addition of the particle e, the word etas becomes e.

original: ekāro. Samānaṃ katvā naṃ passati, samāno viya dissatīti sādiso, sadiso, saiti nipātanena
analyzed: ekāraḥ samānam katvā nam passati samānaḥ viya dissati iti sādisaḥ sadisaḥ sa eti nipātanena
translated: Sādiso, sadiso, saiti: by the addition of the particle sa, the word samāna becomes sā.

original: samānassa sādeso, tadantassa vā dīgho, sādisā, sādisī, sadisā, sadisī, sādisaṃ, sadisaṃ.
analyzed: samānassa sa ādesaḥ tad antassa vā dīghaḥ sādisā sādisī sadisā sadisī sādisam sadisam
translated: Sādisā, sādisī, sadisā, sadisī, sādisaṃ, sadisaṃ: the long vowel is due to the final of the preceding word.

original: Dakārassa rakārādese pana īriso, yāriso, tāriso, māriso, kīriso, eriso, sāriso, sariso.🔽Kkhādese īdikkho, yādikkho, tādikkho, mādikkho, kīdikkho, edikkho, sādikkho, sadikkho.
analyzed: dakārassa rakāra ādese pana īrisaḥ yārisaḥ tārisaḥ mārisaḥ kīrisaḥ erisaḥ sārisaḥ sarisaḥ  kkha ādese īdikkhaḥ yādikkhaḥ tādikkhaḥ mādikkhaḥ kīdikkhaḥ edikkhaḥ sādikkhaḥ sadikkhaḥ
translated: Īriso, yāriso, tāriso, māriso, kīriso, eriso, sāriso, sariso: by the change of the dak to rak.🔽Īdikkho, yādikkho, tādikkho, mādikkho, kīdikkho, edikkho, sādikkho, sadikkho: by the change of the dak to kkh.

original: Rakārādese sārikkho, sarikkho, īkārādese īdī, yādī, tādī, mādī, kīdī, edī, sādī.
analyzed: rakāra ādese sārikkhaḥ sarikkhaḥ īkāra ādese īdī yādī tādī mādī kīdī edī sādī
translated: Sārikkho, sarikkho, īdī, yādī, tādī, mādī, kīdī, edī, sādī: by the change of the dak to īk.

original: Casaddena tumhādiupapadepi tumhe viya dissatīti tumhādiso, tumhādisī, khandhā viya dissantīti khandhādisā iccādi.
analyzed: ca saddena tumha ādi upapade pi tumhe viya dissati iti tumhādiso tumhādisī khandhāḥ viya dissanti iti khandhādisāḥ iccādi
translated: Like you, it is seen to be of the same kind as you, thus it is of the same kind as you, of the same kind as you ; like the aggregates, it is seen to be of the same kind as the aggregates, thus it is of the same kind as the aggregates, and so on.

original: Dhara dhāraṇe, apāyesvapatamāne adhigatamaggādike satte dhāreti, dharanti tenāti vā, salakkhaṇaṃ dhāreti vā, paccayehi dharīyati vāti atthe –🔽589. Dharādīhi rammo.
analyzed: dhāraṇe apāyesu apatamāne adhigata magga ādike satte dhāreti dharanti tena ati vā salakkhaṇam dhāreti vā paccayehi dharīyati vā ati atthe  dharā ādīhi rammo
translated: Dhara in the sense of bearing: it bears, it holds, those who have attained the paths, etc., from falling into states of loss, or it is borne, it is held, by conditions, thus it is a bearing, a holding.🔽It is delightful with the bearers, etc.

original: Dharaiccevamādīhi dhātūhi rammappaccayo hoti.
analyzed: dharait ca evamādīhi dhātūhi rammappaccayaḥ hoti
translated: The delightful condition is with the bearers, etc., with the words beginning with dhara.

original: So ca –
analyzed: saḥ ca
translated: And that is🔽To be known here as action,🔽As instrument, as cause,

original: Kammaggahaṇabho bhāva- kammesūtettha vediyo;🔽Akattaripi hotīti, kārake rammappaccayo.
analyzed: bhāva vediyaḥ  a kattari pi hoti iti kārake rammap paccayaḥ
translated: And as the doer too;🔽The delightful condition is the doer,🔽The delightful condition is the instrument,🔽The delightful condition is the cause,🔽The delightful condition is the doer too.🔽The delightful condition is the doer too.🔽Rād is elided, thus it is a bearing, a holding.

original: Rādilopo, dhammo, evaṃ karīyatīti kammaṃ. Vara varaṇe, vammaṃ.
analyzed: ra ādi lopaḥ evam karīyati iti kammam varaṇe vammam
translated: Vara in the sense of choosing: it is a choice.🔽Saṃsa in the sense of praising: it is a praise.

original: Saṃsa pasaṃsane papubbo, piyaiccupapadaṃ, piyaṃ pasaṃsituṃ sīlaṃ yassāti vā piyaṃ pasaṃsanasīlo, piyaṃ pasaṃsanadhammo, piyaṃ pasaṃsane sādhukārīti vā atthe –
analyzed: saṃsa pasaṃsane pa pubbaḥ piya i cc upapadam piyam pasaṃsitum sīlam yassa ati vā piyam pasaṃsana sīlaḥ piyam pasaṃsana dhammaḥ piyam pasaṃsane sādhu kārī iti vā atthe
translated: It is a habit to praise what is dear, thus it is one who has the habit of praising what is dear, or it is a state of praising what is dear, or it is one who does the praising of what is dear, thus it is a praising of what is dear.

original: 590. Tassīlādīsu ṇītvāvī ca.
analyzed: tassīla ādīsu ṇī tva avī ca
translated: It is with the habit, etc.

original: Sīlaṃ pakati, tassīla taddhamma tassādhukārīsvatthesu gamyamānesu sabbadhātūhi ṇī tu āvīiccete paccayā hontīti kattari ṇīpaccayo, saṃyogantattāna vuddhi. Sesaṃ neyyaṃ.🔽Piyapasaṃsī rājā. Atha vā piyaṃ pasaṃsi, pasaṃsati, pasaṃsissati vā sīlena vā dhammena
analyzed: sīlam tu āvi icca ete paccayāḥ honti iti kattari sesam na iyyam  piya pasaṃsī rājā atha vā piyam pasaṃsi pasaṃsati pasaṃsissati vā sīlena vā dhammena
translated: “Virtue” is the nature of the virtuous person. The words “that virtue,” “that state,” “that good practice,” and “that person” are used when the virtuous person is referred to. The words “in all respects,” “by all means,” “in every way,” and “in every respect” are used when the conditions are referred to. The words “increase,” “growth,” and “development” are used when the self is referred to. The rest is to be understood by oneself.

original: vā sādhu vāti piyapasaṃsī, piyapasaṃsinī, piyapasaṃsi kulaṃ. Brahmaṃ carituṃ sīlaṃ🔽yassāti vā brahmaṃ carati sīlena, dhammena, sādhu vāti brahmacārī, brahmacārinī,
analyzed: vā sādhu vāti piya pasaṃsī piya pasaṃsinī piya pasaṃsi kulam brahmam caritum sīlam  yassa ati vā brahmam carati sīlena dhammena sādhu vāti brahmacārī brahmacārinī
translated: “One who praises the dear one” is the king. Or else: he praises the dear one, he is praising, he will praise, by virtue or by Dhamma, “It is good,” thus he is one who praises the dear one. The words “one who praises the dear one,” “one who praises the dear one,” “one who praises the dear one” are used when the person is referred to. “The practice of the divine life” is the virtue.

original: brahmacāri. Evaṃ saccavādī, dhammavādī, sīghayāyī, pāpakārī, mālākārī iccādi.
analyzed: brahmacārī evam sacca vādī dhamma vādī sīgha yāyī pāpa kārī mālā kārī iccādi
translated: “One who lives the divine life” is the one who lives the divine life by virtue, by Dhamma, “It is good,” thus he is one who lives the divine life. The words “one who lives the divine life,” “one who lives the divine life,” “one who lives the divine life” are used when the person is referred to. “One who speaks the truth,” “one who speaks the Dhamma,” “one who is quick,” “one who does evil,” “one who makes garlands,” and so on.

original: Casaddena attamānepi ṇī, paṇḍitaṃ attānaṃ maññatīti paṇḍitamānī bālo, bahussutamānī iccādi.
analyzed: ca saddena attamāne pi ṇī paṇḍitam attānam maññati iti paṇḍita mānī bālaḥ bahu ssuta mānī iccādi
translated: “One who is conceited” is also used when the self is referred to. “One who thinks himself wise” is the wise one. “One who thinks himself learned” and so on.

original: Vatu vattane papubbo, pasayha pavattituṃ sīlaṃ yassāti atthe iminā tuppaccayo, pasayhapavattā.
analyzed: vatu vattane papubbaḥ pasayha pavattitum sīlam yassa ati atthe iminā tup paccayaḥ pasayha pavattā
translated: “One who has entered upon” is used when the meaning is “one who has penetrated and is living.” The word “one who has penetrated and is living” is used when the meaning is “one who has penetrated and is living by force.”

original: Atha vā vaca viyattiyaṃ vācāyaṃ, pasayha pavattituṃ sīlamassāti pasayhapavattā, pasayhapavattāro,
analyzed: atha vā vaca viyattiyam vācāyam pasayha pavattitum sīlam assa ati pasayha pavattā pasayha pavattāraḥ
translated: Or alternatively, it is a state of speech that is inclined to the utterance of speech, thus it is inclined to utterance; those inclined to utterance are inclined to utterance,

original: bhujādittā dhātvantalopadvittāni, sesaṃ kattusamaṃ.
analyzed: bhuja ādi ttāḥ dhātu anta lopa dvittāni sesam kattu samam
translated: The form bhujādittā is the form with the ending lopped off; the rest is the same as the verb.

original: Bhayaṃ passituṃ sīlaṃ yassāti vā bhayaṃ dassanasīlo, bhayaṃ dassanadhammo, bhayaṃ dassane sādhukārīti vā bhayadassāvī, bhayadassāvinī, bhayadassāvi cittaṃ. Evaṃ ādīnavadassāvī.
analyzed: bhayam passitum sīlam yassa ati vā bhayam dassana sīlaḥ bhayam dassana dhammaḥ bhayam dassane sādhu kārī iti vā bhaya dassāvī bhaya dassāvinī bhaya dassāvi cittam evam ādīnava dassāvī
translated: He is of habit to see fear, thus he is a seer of fear; he is of the nature to see fear, he is a doer of seeing fear, thus he is a seer of fear;

original: “Tassīlādīsū”ti adhikāro.🔽591. Sadda ku dha ca la ma ṇḍa ttha rucādīhi yu.
analyzed: adhikāraḥ  sadda ku dha ca la ma ṇ ḍa ttha ruc ādīhi yu
translated: The words “in the sense of habit, etc.” are continued.🔽. The suffixes yu, etc., are used after ku, dha, ca, la, maṇḍa, ttha, ru, etc.

original: Sadda ku dha ca la maṇḍatthehi dhātūhi, rucādīhi ca yuppaccayo hoti tassīlādīsvatthesu.
analyzed: sadda ku dha ca la maṇḍa atthehi dhātūhi ruc ādīhi ca yup paccayaḥ hoti tassi lādi su atthesu
translated: The suffixes yu, etc., are used in the sense of habit, etc., after the verbal nouns in ku, dha, ca, and la, and after the verbal nouns in maṇḍa, and after the verbal nouns in ru, etc.

original: Ghusa sadde, ghosituṃ sīlaṃ assāti vā ghosanasīloti vā aghosayi, ghosayati, ghosayissati
analyzed: sadde ghositum sīlam assa ati vā ghosana sīlaḥ oti vā aghosayi ghosayati ghosayissati
translated: He is of habit to make a sound, thus he is of the nature to make a sound, thus he is a sounder; he makes a sound, he will make a sound.

original: sīlena, dhammena, sādhu vāti atthe iminā yuppaccayo, tassa “anakā yuṇvūna”nti anādeso,
analyzed: sīlena dhammena sādhu vāti atthe iminā yup paccayaḥ tassa an a kā yu ṇ vū nanti an ādesaḥ
translated: The suffix yu is used in the sense of “by means of” , “in accordance with” , “well” . The form is “anakā yuṇvūna” .

original: “aññesu cā”ti vuddhi, so ghosano, sā ghosanā. Bhāsa viyattiyaṃ vācāyaṃ, bhāsituṃ
analyzed: aññesu ca ati so ghosano sā ghosanā bhāsa viyattiyam vācā ayam bhāsitum
translated: “And in others” is growth. He is Ghosaka. That is Ghosanā. Bhāsa is exertion, in speech, to speak.

original: sīlamassāti vā bhāsanasīlo, bhāsanadhammo, bhāsane sādhukārīti vā bhāsano.
analyzed: sīlam assa ati vā bhāsana sīlaḥ bhāsana dhammaḥ bhāsane sādhu kārī iti vā bhāsanaḥ
translated: “And in others” is growth. He is Ghosanā. That is Ghosanā. Bhāsana is in the sense of speaking. He has the habit of speaking, thus he is a speaker. He has the nature of speaking, thus he is a speaker. He is skilled in speaking, thus he is a speaker.

original: Kudha kope, kujjhituṃ sīlamassāti vā kujjhanasīloti vā kodhano, kodhanā, kodhanaṃ.
analyzed: kope kujjhitum sīlam assa ati vā kujjhana sīlaḥ iti vā kodhanaḥ kodhanā kodhanam
translated: Kudha is in the sense of anger. He has the habit of being angry, thus he is an angry man. He has the nature of being angry, thus he is an angry man. He is skilled in being angry, thus he is an angry man.

original: Rusa rose, rosituṃ sīlamassāti vā rosanasīloti vā rosano.🔽Cala kampane, calituṃ sīlaṃ yassāti vā calati sīlenāti vā calano. Kapicalane, kampituṃ
analyzed: rusa rose rositum sīlam assa ati vā rosana sīlaḥ iti vā rosanaḥ  cala kampane calitum sīlam yassa ati vā calati sīlena ati vā kapi calane kampitum
translated: Rusa is in the sense of hatred. He has the habit of hating, thus he is a hater. He has the nature of hating, thus he is a hater. He is skilled in hating, thus he is a hater.🔽Cala is in the sense of trembling. He has the habit of trembling, thus he is a trembler. He trembles by habit, thus he is a trembler. Kapicalana is in the sense of shaking. He has the habit of shaking,

original: sīlaṃ yassāti vā akampi, kampati, kampissati sīlenāti vā kampano, ikārānubandhidhātusarato
analyzed: sīlam yassa ati vā akampi kampati kampissati sīlena ati vā kampanaḥ ikāra anubandhi dhātu sarataḥ
translated: thus he is a shaker. He shakes by habit, thus he is a shaker. He will shake by habit, thus he is a shaker. The root sar is added to the stem ending in i.

original: “kvaci dhātū”tiādinā, “niggahītañcā”ti vā niggahītāgamo. Phadi kiñcicalane, phandituṃ🔽sīlaṃ yassāti vā phandati sīlenāti vā phandano.
analyzed: kvaci dhātu uti ādinā vā kiñci calane phanditum 🔽sīlam yassa ati vā phandati sīlena ati vā phandanaḥ
translated: “In some cases the roots” is stated, etc. “And also the reduplicated aorist” is the reduplication of the aorist. Phadi is in the sense of shaking. He has the habit of shaking, thus he is a shaker. He shakes by habit, thus he is a shaker.

original: Maḍi bhūsāyaṃ, maṇḍayituṃ sīlaṃ yassāti vā maṇḍayati sīlenāti vā maṇḍano. Bhūsa alaṅkāre, bhūsanasīloti vā abhūsayi, bhūsayati, bhūyayissati sīlenāti vā bhūsano, bhūsanā, bhūsanaṃ.
analyzed: bhūsāyam maṇḍayitum sīlam yassa ati vā maṇḍayati sīlena ati vā maṇḍanaḥ alaṅkāre bhūsana sīlaḥ iti vā abhūsayi bhūsayati bhūyayissati sīlena ati vā bhūsanaḥ bhūsanāḥ bhūsanam
translated: The root bhūs means “to adorn,” and maṇḍano is derived from the root maṇḍ, which means “to adorn.” The noun bhūsana is derived from the root bhūs, which means “to adorn,” and bhūsano is derived from the root bhūs, which means “to adorn.”

original: Ruca dittimhi, arucci, ruccati, ruccissati sīlenāti vā rocano. Juta dittimhi, ajoti, jotati, jotissati sīlenāti vā jotano. Vaḍḍha vaḍḍhane, vaḍḍhituṃ sīlamassāti vaḍḍhano iccādi.
analyzed: ruca dittimhi arucci ruccati ruccissati sīlena ati vā rocanaḥ dittimhi ajoti jotati jotissati sīlena ati vā jotanaḥ vaḍḍha vaḍḍhane vaḍḍhitum sīlam assa ati vaḍḍhano iccādi
translated: The root ru means “to delight,” and rocano is derived from the root ru, which means “to delight.” The root ju means “to shine,” and jotano is derived from the root ju, which means “to shine.” The root vaḍḍh means “to increase,” and vaḍḍhano is derived from the root vaḍḍh, which means “to increase.”

original: 592. Pārādigamimhā rū.🔽Pārādiupapadehi parasmā gamiiccetasmā dhātumhā paro rūpaccayo hoti tassīlādīsvatthesu🔽kattariyeva. Pāro ādi yesaṃ te pārādayo, pārādīhi gami pārādigami. Rādilopo, bhavapāraṃ
analyzed: pāra ādi gamimhāḥ rū  pāra ādi upapadehi parasmā dhātumhā paraḥ rūpa ccayaḥ hoti  pāraḥ ādi te pāra ādayaḥ pāra ādīhi gami pāra ādi gami ra ādi lopaḥ bhava pāram
translated: The suffix rū is added to the root.🔽The suffix rū is added to the root when the meaning is “habitual action.”

original: gantuṃ sīlaṃ yassāti vā bhavapāraṃ gamanasīlo, bhavapāraṃ gamanadhammo, bhavapāraṃ
analyzed: gantum sīlam yassa ati vā bhava pāram gamana sīlaḥ bhava pāram gamana dhammaḥ bhava pāram

original: gamane sādhukārīti vā bhavapāragū, bhavapāraguno. Antaṃ gamanasīlo antagū. Evaṃ vedagū, addhagū.🔽“Rū”ti vattate.🔽593. Bhikkhādito ca.🔽Bhikkhaiccevamādīhi dhātūhi rūpaccayo hoti tassīlādīsvatthesu. Ikkha dassanaṅkesu,🔽saṃsāre bhayaṃ ikkhatītipi bhikkhu, vijānituṃ sīlaṃ yassa, vijānanasīloti vā viññū,

original: chaṭṭhī, ṇakāro vuddhattho. Āhananasīlo āghātuko, ghātādeso, saralopādi, karaṇasīlo
analyzed: chaṭṭhī ṇakāraḥ vuddha atthaḥ āhanana sīlaḥ āghātukaḥ ghāta ādeso sara lopa ādi karaṇa sīlo
translated: The sixth is the syllable ṇa, which has the meaning of “increase.” The one who has the habit of striking is a striker . The place of striking is a slaughterhouse . The one who has the habit of making is a maker .🔽The one who has the habit of fearing is a coward . The one who has the habit of protecting is a protector .

original: kāruko sippi. Bhī bhaye, bhāyanasīlo bhīruko, rakārāgamo. Ava rakkhaṇe, āvuko pitā.🔽595. Saṃhanaññāya vā ro gho.
analyzed: kārukaḥ bhī bhaye bhāyana sīlaḥ bhīrukaḥ rakāra āgamaḥ ava rakkhaṇe āvukaḥ pitā  saṃhanaññāya vā raḥ ghaḥ
translated: The one who has the habit of going is a goer .

original: Saṃpubbāya hanaiccetāya dhātuyā, aññāya ca dhātuyā paro rappaccayo hoti, hanassa gho ca. Vāggahaṇaṃ sampiṇḍanatthaṃ, vikappanatthaṃ vā, tena saṅghātotipi siddhaṃ hoti.
analyzed: saṃpubbāya dhātuyā aññāya ca dhātuyā paraḥ rap paccayaḥ hoti hanassa ghaḥ ca vā gahaṇam sampiṇḍana attham vikappana attham vā tena saṅghāta utipi siddham hoti
translated: The suffix -gha is added to the verbal noun in -ana formed from the verbal roots han and ro by the addition of the prefix sam, and to the verbal noun in -ana formed from the verbal root han by the addition of the prefix saṃ, and to the verbal root ñā by the addition of the prefix sam. The word vā is given in order to include the verbal noun in -ana formed from the verbal root han by the addition of the prefix sam, or in order to include the verbal noun in -ana formed from the verbal root han by the addition of the prefix saṃ.

original: Hanassevāyaṃ gho hoti, abhidhānānurūpato;🔽Asaṃpubbā ca ro tena, paṭighotipi sijjhati.
analyzed: abhidhāna anurūpataḥ  a saṃpubbā ca raḥ tena paṭighaḥ tipi sijjhati
translated: The verbal noun in -ana formed from the verbal root han by the addition of the prefix sam is -gha, in accordance with the rule of grammar.🔽The verbal noun in -ana formed from the verbal root ro by the addition of the prefix sam is -gha, in accordance with the rule of grammar.🔽The verbal noun in -ana formed from the verbal root han by the addition of the prefix saṃ is -gha, in accordance with the rule of grammar.🔽The verbal noun in -ana formed from the verbal root han by the addition of the prefix sam is -gha, in accordance with the rule of grammar.🔽The verbal noun in -ana formed from the verbal root han by the addition of the prefix saṃ is -gha, in accordance with the rule of grammar.🔽The verbal noun in -ana formed from the verbal root han by the addition of the prefix sam is -gha, in accordance with the rule of grammar.🔽The verbal noun in -ana formed from the verbal root han by the addition of the prefix saṃ is -gha, in accordance with the rule of grammar.🔽The verbal noun in -ana formed from the verbal root han by the addition of the prefix sam is -gha, in accordance with the rule of grammar.

original: Hana hiṃsāgatīsu saṃ pubbo, saṃhanati samaggaṃ kammaṃ samupagacchati, sammadeva kilesadarathe🔽hanatīti vā saṅgho, rādilopo, samantato nagarassa bāhiye khaññatīti parikhā, itthiyaṃ
analyzed: sam pubbo saṃhanati samaggam kammam samupagacchati sammat eva  hanati iti vā saṅghaḥ ra ādi lopaḥ samantataḥ nagarassa khaññati iti parikhā itthiyam
translated: The verbal noun in -ana formed from the verbal root han by the addition of the prefix sam is -gha, in accordance with the rule of grammar.

original: āpaccayo, antaṃ karotīti antako maccu.🔽“Bhāvakammesū”ti vattate.
analyzed: āpad cayaḥ antam karoti iti antakaḥ maccu 🔽bhāva kammesu iti vattate
translated: The verbal noun in -ana formed from the

original: 596. Nandādīhi yu.🔽Nandaiccevamādīhi dhātūhi paro yuppaccayo hoti bhāvakammesu. “Anakā yuṇvūna”nti yuppaccayassa
analyzed: nanda ādīhi yu  nanda e t ca evamādīhi dhātūhi paraḥ yup paccayaḥ hoti bhāva kammesu anakāḥ yu ṇ vū nanti yup paccayassa
translated: 596. By Nanda and so on.

original: anādeso, nanda samiddhimhi, nanda nandane vā. Bhāve – nandīyate nandanaṃ. Kamme –🔽anandīyittha, nandīyati, nandīyissati, nanditabbanti vā nandanaṃ vanaṃ, gayhati,
analyzed: an ādesaḥ nanda samiddhimhi nanda nandane vā bhāve nandīyate nandanam kamme  anandīyittha nandīyati nandīyissati nanditabbanti vā nandanam vanam gayhati
translated: In the sense of “state” and “action,” the suffix yū is added to the roots beginning with Nanda, thus: “Anakā yuṇvūna” (you should do) is the prohibition of the yū suffix. Nanda in the sense of “state”: in the sense of “action”:

original: gahaṇīyaṃ vā gahaṇaṃ, gaṇhanaṃ vā, caritabbaṃ caraṇaṃ, bhūyate bhavanaṃ, hūyate havanaṃ.
analyzed: gahaṇīyam vā gahaṇam gaṇhanam vā caritabbam caraṇam bhūyate bhavanam hūyate havanam
translated: anandīyittha, nandīyati, nandīyissati, nanditabbanti vā. Nanda means a forest. Gahati, gahaṇīyaṃ vā gahaṇaṃ, gaṇhanaṃ vā. Caritabbaṃ caraṇaṃ. Bhūyate bhavanaṃ. Hūyate havanaṃ.

original: Rundhitabbaṃ rundhanaṃ, rodhanaṃ vā, bhuñjitabbaṃ bhuñjanaṃ, bhojanaṃ vā. Bujjhitabbaṃ
analyzed: rundhitabbam rundhanam rodhanam vā bhuñjitabbam bhuñjanam bhojanam vā bujjhitabbam
translated: Rundhitabbaṃ rundhanaṃ, rodhanaṃ vā. Bhuñjitabbaṃ bhuñjanaṃ, bhojanaṃ vā. Bujjhitabbaṃ

original: bujjhanaṃ, bodhanaṃ vā. Sūyati, suti vā savaṇaṃ, pāpīyatīti pāpuṇanaṃ, pāpanaṃ vā,
analyzed: bujjhanam bodhanam vā sūyati suti vā savaṇam pāpīyatīti pāpuṇanam pāpanam vā
translated: bujjhanaṃ, bodhanaṃ vā. Sūyati, suti vā savaṇaṃ. Pāpīyati pāpuṇanaṃ, pāpanaṃ vā.

original: pālīyatīti pālanaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: pālīyati iti pālanam i c ādi
translated: Pālīyati pālanaṃ.

original: “Yū”ti vattate.
analyzed: yūti vattate
translated: The yū suffix is used.

original: 597. Kattukaraṇapadesesu ca.
analyzed: kattu karaṇa padesesu ca
translated: 597. And in the case of the words kattu and karaṇa.

original: Kattukaraṇapadesaiccetesvatthesu ca sabbadhātūhi yuppaccayo hoti. Ettha ca padesoti
analyzed: kattu karaṇa padesa e c ca itesu atthesu ca sabba dhātūhi yup paccayaḥ hoti ettha ca padesaḥ ti
translated: In the case of the words kattu and karaṇa, the yū suffix is added to all roots in the sense of “state” and “action.” And here the words kattu and karaṇa are called

original: adhikaraṇakārakaṃ vuccati. Kattari tāva – rajaṃ haratīti rajoharaṇaṃ toyaṃ. Āramaṇaṃ
analyzed: adhikaraṇa kārakam vuccati kattari tāva rajam harati iti rajoharaṇam toyam āramaṇam
translated: The doer of a legal issue is called a maker. First, as to the maker: it is water that removes dirt, thus it is a remover of dirt . It is a delight,

original: vijānātīti viññāṇaṃ, vijānanaṃ vā, ānanajādesā. Ghā gandhopādāne, ghāyatīti ghānaṃ,
analyzed: vijānāti iti viññāṇam vijānanam vā ānana ja ādesāḥ ghā gandha upādāne ghāyati iti ghānam
translated: The doer of a legal issue is called a maker. As to the maker: it carries off dust, thus it is a dust-carrier , namely, water. It causes to know, thus it is consciousness , or it is the knowing, namely, the state of the knowing. It smells, thus it is the nose .

original: jhe cintāyaṃ, jhāyatīti jhānaṃ, “kvaci dhātū”tiādinā āttaṃ.🔽Karaṇe – kara karaṇe, karoti tenāti karaṇaṃ, yathāsarūpaṃ saddā byākarīyanti etenāti🔽byākaraṇaṃ. Pūra pūraṇe, pūrayati tenāti pūraṇaṃ. Dīyati anenāti dānaṃ, pamīyati
analyzed: cintā ayam jhāyati iti jhānam kvacid  karaṇe kara karaṇe karoti tena ati karaṇam yathā sarūpam etena ati  byākaraṇam pūra pūraṇe pūrayati tena ati pūraṇam dīyati anena ati dānam pamīyati
translated: It meditates, thus it is meditation , “in some places it is a dhātu, etc.”

original: anenāti pamānaṃ, vuccati anenāti vacanaṃ, panudati, panujjate anenāti vā panūdano.🔽Sūda paggharaṇe, sūdati, sujjate anenāti vā sūdano, suṇāti, sūyati etenāti vā savaṇaṃ.
analyzed: anena ati pamānam vuccati anena ati vacanam panudati panujjate anena ati vā panūdanaḥ  sūda paggharaṇe sūdati sujjate anena ati vā sūdanaḥ suṇāti sūyati etena ati vā savaṇam
translated: As to the instrument: it is an instrument , it is done by it, thus it is an instrument , as is appropriate to the form. It causes to be declared, thus it is a declaration . It fills, thus it is a filling . It is given, thus it is a giving . It is measured, thus it is a measure . It is spoken, thus it is speech . It repels, it is repelled by it, thus it is a repelling .🔽It trickles, it trickles out by it, thus it is a trickling , or it is a trickler . It hears, it trickles by it, thus it is hearing .

original: Lū chedane, lunāti, lūyati anenāti vā lavanaṃ, lavaṇaṃ, loṇaṃ vā. Nayati, nīyati
analyzed: chedane lunāti lūyati anenāti vā lavanam lavaṇam loṇam vā nayati nīyati
translated: It cuts, it is cut by it, thus it is a cutting , or it is a cutter , or it is salt . It leads, it is led

original: etenāti vā nayanaṃ. Pū pavane, punāti, pūyate anenāti vā pavano, sameti, samīyati
analyzed: etena ati vā nayanam pu pavane punāti pūyate anena ati vā sameti samīyati
translated: Or it is the eye because it sees.

original: vā pāpaṃ anenāti samaṇo, samaṇaṃ vā. Tathā bhāveti, bhāvīyati ekāyāti vā bhāvanā.
analyzed: vā pāpam anena ati samaṇaḥ samaṇam vā tathā bhāveti bhāvīyati ekāyāti vā bhāvanā
translated: It purifies, it is purified, by this, thus it is a purifier; it is associated with, it is approached by, evil, thus it is an ascetic; or it is an ascetic because of the ascetic practice. It causes to be, it is caused to be, by one, thus it is a cause.

original: Evaṃ pācanaṃ, pācāpanaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: evam pācanam iccādi
translated: So too, it cooks, it is cooked, thus it is a cooking, a cook, etc.

original: Adhikaraṇe – ṭhā gatinivattimhi, tiṭṭhati tasminti ṭhānaṃ. Evaṃ sayanaṃ, senaṃ vā, āsanaṃ, adhikarīyati etthāti adhikaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: adhikaraṇe gati nivattimhi tiṭṭhati tasmin ti ṭhānam evam sayanam senam vā āsanam adhikarīyati ettha ati adhikaraṇam
translated: In the base: It stands in that, thus it is a place. So too, it lies in that, thus it is a bed; or it is an army. It is sat upon, thus it is a seat. It is governed in that, thus it is a base.

original: Casaddena sampadānāpādānesupi – sammā pakārena dadāti assāti sampadānaṃ, apecca etasmā ādadātīti apādānaṃ.
analyzed: ca saddena sampadāna apādānesu pi sammā pakārena dadāti assa ati sampadānam apecca etasmai ādadāti iti apādānam
translated: In the giving up and the taking up: It gives rightly by means of the way, thus it is the giving up; it is taken up from that, thus it is the taking up.

original: 598. Saññāyaṃ dādhāto i.
analyzed: saññāyam dādhāto i
translated: In the perception:

original: Saññāyaṃ gamyamānāyaṃ dādhāiccetehi dhātūhi ippaccayo hoti, bhāvakammādiadhikārevāyaṃ,
analyzed: saññā iyam gamyamānā iyam dhātūhi ip paccayaḥ hoti bhāva kamma ādi adhikāra iva ayam
translated: When the meaning is “perceived,” the affix i is added to these verbal roots. This is only when the meaning is “state of being”🔽and when there is elision of the saṃ of the verbal root, etc.🔽Dā is the verbal root for “giving”; ā is the prefix; it is taken up, thus it is the taking up. So too, it is the giving up.

original: saralopādi. Dā dāne āpubbo, ādīyatītiādi. Evaṃ upādi. Dhā dhāraṇe, udakaṃ dadhātīti
analyzed: sarala upa ādi dā dāne āpubbaḥ ādīyati iti ādi evam upa ādi dhā dhāraṇe udakam dadhāti iti
translated: Dhā is the verbal root for “holding”; udakaṃ dadhāti, he holds water,

original: udadhi, tesu vuddhilopādinā saññāyaṃ udakassa udādeso. Jalaṃ dhīyate asminti jaladhi,
analyzed: tesu vuddhi lopa ādinā saññā ayam udakassa uda ādesaḥ jalam dhīyate asmin ti jaladhi
translated: In the ocean, etc., the water’s being called “sea” is due to the perception of increase and decrease in it. The ocean is so called because water is collected in it .

original: vālāni dadhāti tasminti vāladhi, sandhīyati, sandadhātīti vā sandhi, nidhīyatīti
analyzed: vālāni dadhāti tasmin ti vāladhi sandhīyati sandadhāti iti vā sandhi nidhīyati iti
translated: The ocean is so called because it contains waves . The ocean is so called because it contains sand . The ocean is so called because it contains treasure .

original: nidhi. Evaṃ vidhīyati, vidadhāti, vidhānaṃ vā vidhi, sammā, samaṃ vā cittaṃ ādadhātīti samādhi.
analyzed: evam vidhīyati vidadhāti vidhānam vā vidhi sammā samam vā cittam ādadhāti iti samādhi
translated: It is so called because it is directed , because it is distributed , because it is the distribution , or because it is the right or even direction of the mind .🔽In the feminine, e.g.🔽In the feminine, in the case of the word for “woman,” the following are the reasons for the feminine ending:

original: 599. Itthiyamatiyavo vā.🔽Itthiyaṃ abhidheyyāyaṃ sabbadhātūhi akāratiyuiccete paccayā honti vā bhāvakammādīsu.
analyzed: itthiyamatiyavaḥ vā  itthiyam abhidheyyāyam sabba dhātūhi akāra ti yu icca ete paccayāḥ honti vā bhāva kamma ādīsu
translated: In the neuter, e.g.

original: Appaccaye tāva jara vayohānimhi, jīrati, jīraṇanti vā jarā, “itthiyamato āpaccayo”ti🔽āpaccayo, paṭisambhijjatīti paṭisambhidā. Paṭipajjati etāyāti paṭipadā. Evaṃ sampadā,
analyzed: appaccaye vayaḥ hānimhi jīrati vā jarā  āpa cayaḥ paṭisambhijjati iti paṭisambhidā paṭipajjati etāya ati paṭipadā evam sampadā
translated: In the neuter, in the case of the words for “age” and “decay,” the following are the reasons for the neuter ending:🔽It is so called because it is divided . The way is so called because it is entered upon . The way is so called because it is distributed .

original: āpadā. Upādīyatīti upādā. Sañjānātīti saññā, pajānātīti paññā. Upekkhatīti upekkhā.
analyzed: āpadā upādīyati iti upādā sañjānāti iti saññā pajānāti iti paññā upekkhati iti upekkhā
translated: It is so called because it is taken up . It is so called because it perceives . It is so called because it understands . It is so called because it is indifferent .

original: Cintanaṃ cintā. Patiṭṭhānaṃ patiṭṭhā. Sikkha vijjopādāne, sikkhanaṃ, sikkhīyatīti
analyzed: cintanam cintā patiṭṭhānam patiṭṭhā sikkha vijjā upādāne sikkhanam sikkhīyati iti
translated: Thinking is thinking. A footing is a footing. Training is training; or it is training since one is trained in it.

original: vā sikkhā. Evaṃ bhikkhā. Jhe cintāyaṃ, parasampattiṃ abhimukhaṃ jhāyatīti abhijjhā,
analyzed: vā sikkhā evam bhikkhā jhe cintā ayam para sampattim abhimukham jhāyati iti abhijjhā
translated: So too, bhikkhu. Covetousness is coveting after the success of others.

original: hitesitaṃ upaṭṭhapetvā jhāyatīti upajjhā, upajjhāyo, sammā jhāyati etthāti sajjhā.
analyzed: hita isitam upaṭṭhapetvā jhāyati iti upajjhā upajjhāyo sammā jhāyati ettha ati sajjhā
translated: A preceptor is one who teaches after attending to welfare. A recitation is a recitation in this .

original: Isu icchāyaṃ, esananti atthe appaccayo, “isu yamūnamanto ccho vā”ti cchādeso, icchā.
analyzed: isu icchā ayam esananti atthe appaccayaḥ isu yamūnam antaḥ cchaḥ vāti ccha ādesaḥ icchā
translated: A wish is a wish in wishing; the suffix -an is a non-derivative ; “isu yamūnamanto ccho vā” is a substitute for cchā ; a wish is a wish.

original: Puccha pucchane, pucchanaṃ pucchā, tikicchanaṃ tikicchā, ghasitumicchā jighacchā,
analyzed: puccha pucchane pucchanam pucchā tikicchanam tikicchā ghasitumicchā jighacchā
translated: An inquiry is an inquiry; the suffix -ā is a non-derivative ; a treatment is a treatment; a wish to eat is hunger;

original: titikkhā, bubhukkhā, pātumicchā pipāsā, maṇḍūkagatiyā vādhikārato vādesābhāvo. Byāpitumicchā vicchā iccādi.
analyzed: titikkhā bubhukkhā pātum icchā pipāsā maṇḍūka gatiyāḥ vā adhikārataḥ vā ādesa abhāvaḥ byāpitum icchā vicchā iccādi
translated: a wish to endure is endurance; a wish to be full is fullness; a wish to drink is thirst; there is no substitute for the word for frog; a wish to spread is a spread, and so on.

original: Tippaccaye sambhavanaṃ sambhūti. Vādhikārato tippaccayamhi na vuddhi, savaṇaṃ suti, nayanaṃ, nīyati etāyāti vā nīti. Mana ñāṇe, maññatīti mati.
analyzed: ti paccaye sambhavanam sambhūti vā adhikārato ti paccayamhi na vuddhi savaṇam suti nayanam nīyati vā nīti manaḥ ñāṇe maññati iti mati
translated: Origination in the three conditions is origination. There is no growth in the three conditions, which is a substitute; hearing is hearing; a leading is a leading; or it is a leading since one is led by it. Mind is knowledge; it is understanding since it understands.

original: “Te, no, timhī”ti ca vattate.
analyzed: te naḥ timhi iti ca vattate
translated: “Te, no, timhī” is used.

original: 600. Gamakhanahanaramādīnamanto.
analyzed: gama khana hana rama ādi inamantaḥ
translated: 600. The end of the roots gama, etc., is not no.

original: Gama khana hana ramaiccevamādīnaṃ makāranakārantānaṃ dhātūnaṃ anto byañjano no hoti🔽tappaccaye, timhi cāti dhātvantalopo. Gamanaṃ, gantabbāti vā gati, upahananaṃ upahati,
analyzed: gama khana hana rama et ca evamādīnam makāra nakāra antānam dhātūnam antaḥ byañjanaḥ na u  tad paccaye timhi ca ati dhātu anta lopaḥ gamanam gantabbā ati vā gati upahananam upahati
translated: The end of the roots gama, khana, hana, rama, etc., is not no in the case of the affix tappaccaya and in the case of timhi.🔽Gati is going, gantabbaṃ, or it is the act of going, gamanaṃ. Upahati is the act of striking, upahananaṃ.

original: ramanti tāya, ramaṇaṃ vā rati. Tanu vitthāre, tananaṃ tati. Yamu uparame, niyamanaṃ
analyzed: ramanti tāya ramaṇam vā rati tanu vitthāre tananam tati uparame niyamanam
translated: Rati is delight, or it is the act of delighting, ramanaṃ. Tati is the act of spreading, tananaṃ.

original: niyati. “Ramato, ramatī”tiādīsu pana akārabyavahitattā na dhātvantalopo, bhuñjanaṃ
analyzed: niyati ramataḥ ramati iti ādīsu pana akāra byavahita ttā na dhātu anta lopaḥ bhuñjanam
translated: Niyati is the act of restraining, niyamanaṃ. But in the case of the words ramato, ramatī, etc., there is no elision of the end of the root because of the intervening a.

original: bhutti, yuñjanaṃ yutti, “bhujādīnamanto no dvi cā”ti dhātvantalopo, dvittañca. Samāpajjanaṃ,
analyzed: yuñjanam bhuja ādīnam antaḥ naḥ dvi ca ati dhātu anta lopaḥ samāpajjanam
translated: Bhutti is the act of eating, bhuñjanaṃ. Yutti is the act of yoking, yuñjanaṃ. The end of the root is elided in the case of the affix tappaccaya and the reduplication is not done by the rule “The end of the roots bhuj, etc., is no, and the reduplication is done” .

original: samāpajjateti vā samāpatti, sampatti, “gupādīnañcā”ti dhātvantalopadvittāni. “Kvaci
analyzed: samāpajjata iti vā samāpatti sampatti dhātu anta lopa dvittāni kvaci
translated: Samāpatti is the act of attaining, samāpajjanaṃ, or it is the state of having attained, samāpajjate. Sampatti is the act of coming together, samāyanaṃ. The end of the root is elided and the reduplication is done by the rule “And also of gup, etc.” .🔽The affix ni is added by the rule “And also of roots beginning with kvac” .

original: dhātū”tiādinā hādito tissa ni hoti. Hāni, jāni iccādi.
analyzed: dhātu uti ādinā ha āditaḥ tissa ni hoti hāni jāni iccādi
translated: Hāni is loss, jāni is knowledge, etc.

original: Yuppaccaye cita sañcetane, cetayatīti atthe yuppaccayo, anādesavuddhī, āpaccayo,
analyzed: yuppaccaye cita sañcetane cetayati iti atthe yuppaccayaḥ an ādesa vuddhī ā paccayaḥ
translated: The affix yuppaccaya is added in the sense of the act of thinking, cetayati, by the rule “Yuppaccaya is added in the sense of the act of thinking.” The vowel a is lengthened by the rule “Lengthening of vowels in the case of āpaccaya.”

original: cetanā. Vida anubhavane, vedayatīti vedanā. Disī uccāraṇe, desīyatīti desanā, bhāvīyatīti bhāvanā iccādi.
analyzed: cetanā vidaḥ anubhavane vedayati iti vedanā disī uccāraṇe desīyati iti desanā bhāvīyati iti bhāvanā iccādi
translated: The root ce means “to will.” The verbal noun is cetanā. The root vid means “to experience.” The verbal noun is vedanā. The root dis means “to utter.” The verbal noun is desanā. The root bhā means “to be.” The verbal noun is bhāvanā.

original: “Itthiyaṃ, vā”ti ca vattate.🔽601. Karato ririya.
analyzed: itthiyam vāti ca vattate  karataḥ ririya
translated: The feminine is also called itthiyaṃ.🔽The feminine is formed by adding the feminine affix ririya to the root.

original: Karadhātuto itthiyamanitthiyaṃ vā abhidheyyāyaṃ ririyappaccayo hoti, rādilopo. Kattabbā kiriyā. Karaṇīyaṃ kiriyaṃ.
analyzed: kara dhātutaḥ itthiyam anitthiyam vā abhidheyyā ayam ririya ppaccayaḥ hoti ra ādi lopaḥ kattabbā kiriyā karaṇīyam kiriyam
translated: The feminine is formed by adding the feminine affix ririya to the root. The feminine of karadhātu is itthiyam. The feminine of anitthiyaṃ is karīyaṃ. The feminine of kiriyā is kiriyaṃ.

original: “Kattarī”ti vattate.🔽602. Jito ina sabbattha.🔽Jiiccetāya dhātuyā paro inappaccayo hoti sabbakāle kattari. Ji jaye, pāpake akusale dhamme ajini, jināti, jinissatīti vā jino.🔽“Inā”ti vattate.🔽603. Supato ca.🔽Supaiccetāya dhātuyā ca paro inappaccayo hoti. original: “Ta”iti vattate.🔽606. Budhagamāditthe kattari.

original: “Tassā”ti vattate.
analyzed: tassa ati vattate
translated: “Tassā” is used.

original: 607. Dhaḍhabhahehi dha ḍhā ca.🔽Dhaḍhanta bhahantehi dhātūhi parassa paccayatakārassa yathākkamaṃ dhakāraḍhakārādesā

translated: . Dhaḍhabhahehi dha ḍhā ca.🔽The letters dha and ḍha are substituted for the letter ta in the affix -t- when the verbs ending in dha and bha have the nominative case.

translated: The suffix -iko is added to the root gam, and the vowel a is changed to i.🔽The suffix -iko is added to the root gam, and the vowel a is changed to i.

original: Tavantuppaccaye – “ā simhī”ti ākāro, aggiṃ hutavā, hutavanto iccādi guṇavantusamaṃ.🔽Tāvīmhi – aggiṃ hutāvī, aggiṃ hutāvino iccādi daṇḍīsamaṃ. Itthiyaṃ inīpaccayo – hutāvinī,🔽napuṃsake – rassattaṃ hutāvi.🔽Vasa nivāse, vassaṃ avasīti atthe tappaccayo, sakārantattā “sādisanta”iccādinā ṭhādese sampatte –🔽“Tassā”ti adhikāro, “sādī”ti ca.🔽613. Vasato uttha.🔽Vasaiccetasmā dhātumhā parassa takārassa sahādibyañjanena utthādeso hoti, saralopādi.

translated: In the syllable before the syllable ending in -u, the form is ā simhī. The syllable ending in -u is like the syllable ending in -a.🔽In the syllable before the syllable ending in -i, the form is aggiṃ hutāvī, aggiṃ hutāvino. The syllable ending in -i is like the syllable ending in -a.🔽In the feminine, the form is hutāvinī.🔽In the neuter, the form is hutāvi.🔽In the syllable before the syllable ending in -a, the form is vassaṃ avasī. The syllable ending in -a is like the syllable ending in -u.🔽The word “tassa” is understood. The syllable ending in -a is like the syllable ending in -u.🔽From the syllable ending in -a, the syllable ending in -u.🔽From the syllable ending in -a, the syllable ending in -u is formed by the substitution of the syllable ending in -u for the syllable ending in -a.

original: hoti. Niṭṭhatakāre evāyaṃ. Atha vā “vū”ti ettha vakāro sandhijo, tantañāyena dutiyañcettha🔽vāggahaṇamicchitabbaṃ, tena akārassapi ukāro siddho bhavati, usito brahmacariyaṃ,
analyzed: hoti niṭṭha takāre eva ayam atha vā ettha vakāro sandhi jo tantañāyena dutiyam ca ittha  vāc gahaṇam icchitabbam tena akārassa api ukāraḥ siddhaḥ bhavati usitaḥ brahmacariyam
translated: should be taken as having the meaning of a long vowel. Thus the vowel a becomes a long vowel. The word usito is formed in this way.

original: vusito, tathā vusitavā, vusitāvī, ikārāgamena byavahitattā utthādeso na bhavati.🔽Bhuja pālanabyavaharaṇesu, odanaṃ abhuñjīti atthe tatavantutāvī, “bhujādīnamanto
analyzed: tathā vusitavā vusitāvī ikāra āgamena byavahita ttā uttha ādesaḥ na bhavati  bhuja pālana byavaharaṇesu odanam abhuñji iti atthe bhuja ādīnam antaḥ
translated: The word vusito is formed in the same way. The words vusitavā and vusitāvī are formed by adding the affix -vā and -ī respectively. The vowel u is not elided because it is separated by the vowel i.

original: no dvi cā”ti dhātvantalopo, takārassa dvittañca, bhutto, bhuttavā, bhuttāvī. Tathā🔽ranja rāge, arañjīti ratto, rattā, rattaṃ. Yuja yoge, ayuñjīti yutto, yuttā, yuttaṃ.
analyzed: naḥ dvi ca ati dhātu anta lopaḥ takārassa bhuttaḥ bhuttavā bhuttāvī tathā  ranja rāge arañji iti rattaḥ rattā rattam yuja yoge ayuñji iti yuttaḥ yuttā yuttam
translated: The words bhutto, bhuttavā, and bhuttāvī are formed in the same way. The word bhutto is formed by adding the affix -tā to the root bhuj, which means to eat, to protect, and to use. The vowel a of the root is elided because it is the final vowel of a verbal root.🔽The word bhuttavā is formed by adding the affix -vā. The word bhuttāvī is formed by adding the affix -ī. The word ratto is formed by adding the affix -tā to the root ranj, which means to delight. The words rattā and rattaṃ are formed in the same way.

original: Vica vivecane vipubbo, viviccīti vivitto, vivittā, vivittaṃ. Muca mocane, amuccīti🔽bandhanā mutto. Tathā tippaccayepi iminā dhātvantalopadvittāni, āsajjanaṃ āsatti,
analyzed: vica vivecane vipubbaḥ vivicci iti vivittaḥ vivittā vivittam muca mocane amucci iti 🔽bandhanā mutto tathā iminā dhātu anta lopa dvittāni āsajjanam āsatti
translated: The words yutto, yuttā, and yuttaṃ are formed by adding the affix -tā to the root yuja, which means to yoke. The words vivitto, vivittā, and vivittaṃ are formed by adding the affix -tā to the root vica, which means to discriminate.🔽The word mutto is formed by adding the affix -tā to the root muca, which means to release. The words muttā and muttaṃ are formed in the same way. The words āsajjanaṃ, āsatti, and āsanna are formed by adding the affix -tā to the root ās, which means to approach.

original: vimuccanaṃ, vimuccati etāyāti vā vimutti.🔽Kudha kope, akujjhīti atthe tappaccayo, tassa “dhaḍhabhahehi dhaḍhā cā”ti dhattaṃ,
analyzed: vimuccanam vimuccati vā  kudha kope a kujjhi iti atthe tad paccayaḥ tassa dhaḍha bhahehi dhaḍhā ca ati dhattam
translated: or it is deliverance because of being delivered by it.🔽Kudha means to be angry; the suffix -iñ is for the meaning of the gerundive; the -d- becomes -dh- by the rule “dhaḍhabhahehi dhaḍhā cā”;

original: “hacatutthānamantānaṃ dodhe”ti dhakārassa dakāro, kuddho. Yudha sampahāre, ayujjhīti
analyzed: ha catutthānam antānam dodheti dhakārassa dakāraḥ kuddhaḥ sampahāre ayujjhi iti
translated: the -k- becomes -k- by the rule “hacatutthānamantānaṃ dodhe”; thus kuddha. Yudha means to fight; the suffix -iñ is for the meaning of the gerundive;

original: yuddho, yuddhaṃ. Sidha saṃsiddhimhi, asijjhīti siddho. Āpubbo rabha rābhasse, ārabhīti🔽āraddho gantuṃ. Naha bandhane saṃpubbo, sannayhīti sannaddho, “dhaḍhabhahehi dhaḍhā
analyzed: yuddhaḥ yuddham sidha saṃsiddhimhi asijjhi iti siddhaḥ āpubbaḥ rabha rābhasse ārabhi iti  āraddhaḥ gantum naha bandhane saṃpubbaḥ sannayhi iti sannaddhaḥ dhaḍha bhahehi dhaḍhā
translated: thus yuddha. Sidha means to succeed; the suffix -iñ is for the meaning of the gerundive; thus siddha. Āpubbo means to be quick; the suffix -iñ is for the meaning of the gerundive;

original: cā”ti nahādito takārassa dhakāro.
analyzed: ca ati na ha āditaḥ takārassa dhakāraḥ
translated: thus āraddho. Naha means to bind; the suffix -iñ is for the meaning of the gerundive; the -n- becomes -n- by the rule “dhaḍhabhahehi dhaḍhā cā”;

original: Vaḍḍha vaḍḍhane, avaḍḍhīti atthe tappaccayo, tassa ḍhattaṃ, “kvaci dhātū”tiādinā dhātvākārassuttaṃ, ḍalopo ca.
analyzed: vaḍḍha vaḍḍhane avaḍḍhi iti atthe tad paccayaḥ tassa ḍhattam kvaci dhātu uti ādinā dhātu ākāraḥ uttam ḍa lopaḥ ca
translated: thus sannaddho. Vaḍḍha means to increase; the suffix -iñ is for the meaning of the gerundive; the -d- becomes -dh- by the rule “kvaci dhātū” and so on;

original: “Hacatutthānamantāna”nti vattate.
analyzed: ha catutthānam antānanti vattate
translated: the -d- is elided by the rule “hacatutthānamantānaṃ dodhe”;

original: 615. Ḍo ḍhakāre.
analyzed: ḍaḥ ḍhakāre
translated: thus vaḍḍha. Ḍo means to be red.

original: Hacatutthānaṃ dhātvantānaṃ ḍakārādeso hoti ḍhakāre pare. Vuḍḍho, vuḍḍhā, “bo vassā”ti
analyzed: ha catutthānam dhātu antānam ḍakāra ādesaḥ hoti ḍhakāre pare vuḍḍhaḥ vuḍḍhā baḥ vassā iti
translated: The fourth vowel of a verbal base is changed to -ḍ- before a following -ḍha. Vuḍḍho, vuḍḍhā.

original: batte buḍḍho. Tippaccaye – bujjhanaṃ, bujjhati vā etāyāti buddhi. Evaṃ siddhi, vaḍḍhi.
analyzed: tippaccaye bujjhanam bujjhati vā etāya ati evam
translated: In the passive, the forms are bujjhati, bujjhanti, etc.

original: Tabbappaccaye – boddhabbamiccādi.🔽“Anto, no”ti ca adhikāro.🔽616. Tarādīhi iṇṇo.🔽Taraiccevamādīhi dhātūhi parassa tappaccayassa iṇṇādeso hoti, dhātvanto ca no hoti,
analyzed: tabba ppaccaye boddhabbam iccādi  antaḥ na u ti ca adhikāraḥ  tara ādīhi iṇ ṇaḥ  tara e t ca evamādīhi dhātūhi parassa tad paccayassa i ṇ na ādesaḥ hoti dhātu antaḥ ca no hoti
translated: In the causative, the forms are bodhesi, bodhenti, etc.🔽In the passive, the forms are boddhati, boddhanti, etc.

original: saralopādi. Tara taraṇe, saṃsāraṇṇavaṃ atarīti tiṇṇo tāreyyaṃ. Evaṃ uttiṇṇo, tiṇṇaṃ
analyzed: tara taraṇe evam
translated: In the passive, the forms are tarati, taranti, etc.

original: vā. Pūra pūraṇe, saṃpūrīti saṃpuṇṇo, “saralopo”tiādisutte tuggahaṇato pubbalopābhāve🔽uvaṇṇato parassa “vā paro asarūpā”ti lopo, saṃyoge rassattaṃ. Tura vege, aturīti
analyzed: vā pūra pūraṇe saṃpūrī iti saṃpuṇṇaḥ sara lopo ti ādi sutte tu gahaṇato pubba lopa abhāve  u va aṇṇataḥ parassa vā paraḥ a sarūpā ati lopaḥ saṃyoge rassa attam vege
translated: In the passive, the forms are pūreti, pūrenti, etc.🔽In the passive, the forms are jarāyati, jarāyanti, etc.

original: tuṇṇaṃ, turitaṃ vā. Jara vayohānimhi, parijīrīti parijiṇṇo. Kira vikiraṇe, ākirīti ākiṇṇo iccādi.🔽617. Susa paca sakato kkhakkā ca.
analyzed: tuṇṇam turitam vā jara vayaḥ hānimhi parijīri iti parijiṇṇaḥ kira vikiraṇe ākiri iti ākiṇṇaḥ iccādi 🔽su sa paca sa ka taḥ kkhakkā ca
translated: In the passive, the forms are kirayati, kirayanti, etc.

original: Susa paca sakaiccetehi dhātūhi parassa tappaccayassa kkhakkādesā honti, anto ca byañjano🔽no hoti. Casaddena mucādito kkādeso. Susa sosane, asussīti sukkho rukkho. Apaccīti🔽pakkaṃ phalaṃ. Saka sāmatthe, asakkhīti sakko assa, omuccīti omukkā upāhanā. “Pacituṃ,🔽pacitabba”ntiādīsu pana na bhavati, ikārena byavahitattā. Evaṃ sabbattha byavadhāne na bhavati.🔽Sīhagatiyā tiggahaṇamanuvattate.🔽618. Pakkamādīhi nto ca.🔽Pakkamaiccevamādīhi makārantehi dhātūhi parassa tappaccayassa ntādeso hoti, dhātvanto🔽ca no hoti. Casaddena tippaccayassa nti ca hoti. Kamu padavikkhepe, pakkamīti pakkanto.
analyzed: su sa paca sa ka e c ca itehi dhātūhi parassa tad paccayassa kkha kka ādesāḥ honti antaḥ ca byañjanaḥ  naḥ hoti ca saddena mu c āditaḥ kka ādesaḥ susa sosane asussi iti sukkhaḥ rukkhaḥ apacci iti  pakkam phalam sāmatthe asakkhi iti sakkaḥ assa omucci iti omukkā upāhanā pacitum  pacitabba nti ādīsu pana na bhavati ikārena byavahita ttā evam sabbattha byavadhāne na bhavati  sīha gatiyā tiggahaṇam anuvattate  pakkama ādīhi ntaḥ ca  pakka ma e c ca evamādīhi makāra antehi dhātūhi parassa tad paccayassa nta ādesaḥ hoti dhātu antaḥ  ca no hoti ca saddena tippaccayassa nti ca hoti pada vikkhepe pakkamīti pakkantaḥ
translated: The vowel of the preceding syllable becomes short in the case of these roots, and the sibilant is changed to kk, and the vowel of the following syllable is not lengthened.🔽The sibilant is changed to kk by the word casadda. Susa, in the sense of “to dry,” asussīti sukkho rukkho, “the tree has dried up.” Apaccīti🔽pakkaṃ phalaṃ, “the fruit is ripe.” Saka, in the sense of “to be able,” asakkhīti sakko assa, “he is able.” Omuccīti omukkā upāhanā, “the sandals are untied.”🔽But in such passages as pacituṃ, pacitabba, it does not occur, because of the intervention of the vowel i. So too in all such cases where there is intervention it does not occur.🔽The mention of tiggahaṇam is a mere reference.🔽618.And nto with pakkamā, etc.🔽The vowel of the preceding syllable becomes short in the case of these roots ending in a vowel, and the sibilant is changed to kk, and the vowel of the following syllable is not lengthened, and the word is not closed.🔽The sibilant is changed to kk by the word casadda. Kamu, in the sense of “to change place,” pakkamīti pakkanto, “he has gone away.”🔽
