original: dibbatīti dibbaṃ, dibbantī, dibbantaṃ, dibbamāno. Evaṃ bujjhatīti bujjhaṃ, bujjhanto,
analyzed: dibbati iti dibbam dibbantī dibbantam dibbamānaḥ evam bujjhati iti bujjham bujjhantaḥ
translated: Divine is dibbaṃ, dibbaṃ, dibbaṃ, dibbaṃ. He understands thus is bujjhaṃ, bujjhanto, bujjhamāno.

original: bujjhamāno, cavaggādeso. Janī pātubhāve, “janādīnamā”ti yogavibhāgena āttaṃ, jāyatīti
analyzed: bujjhamānaḥ ca vagga ādesaḥ janī pātubhāve jana ādīnam āti yogavibhāgena āttam jāyati iti
translated: The verbal root jan means to become manifest. The affix ā is added by the rule “janādīnamā” . He is born is jāyaṃ, jāyamāno, jāyamāno.

original: jāyaṃ, jāyamāno, jaññamāno.
analyzed: jāyam jāyamānaḥ jaññamānaḥ
translated: He knows is jānaṃ, jānamāno, jāyamāno.🔽Su means to hear. The affix ṇu is added by the rule “svādito” , etc., and the affix ṇā and uṇā are added by the rules “ṇāto ṇā” and “ṇāto uṇā” . He hears is suṇaṃ, suṇanto, suṇamāno, sūyamāno, suyyamāno.

original: Su savaṇe, “svādito”tiādinā ṇu ṇā uṇā ca, suṇātīti suṇaṃ, suṇanto, suṇamāno, sūyamāno, suyyamāno. Pāpuṇātīti pāpuṇaṃ, pāpuṇamāno, pāpīyamāno.
analyzed: su savaṇe ca suṇāti iti suṇam suṇantaḥ suṇamānaḥ sūyamānaḥ pāpuṇāti iti pāpuṇam pāpuṇamānaḥ pāpīyamānaḥ
translated: He reaches is pāpuṇaṃ, pāpuṇamāno, pāpīyamāno.

original: “Kiyādito nā”ti nā, rassattaṃ, kiṇātīti kiṇaṃ, kīṇamāno, kīyamāno. Vinicchinātīti
analyzed: kiyāt itas na ati nā rassattam kiṇāti iti kiṇam kīṇamānaḥ kīyamānaḥ vinicchināti iti
translated: The affix nā is added by the rule “kiyādito nā” . He is slow is nā, rassattaṃ. He buys is kiṇaṃ, kīṇamāno, kīyamāno. He decides is vinicchinaṃ, vinicchinamāno, vinicchīyamāno.

original: vinicchinaṃ, vinicchinamāno, vinicchīyamāno, cinaṃ, cīyamāno. Jānātīti jānaṃ, jānamāno,
analyzed: vinicchinam vinicchinamānaḥ vinicchīyamānaḥ cinam cīyamānaḥ jānāti iti jānam jānamānaḥ
translated: The verbal root cina means to decide. He decides is cinaṃ, cīyamāno. He knows is jānaṃ, jānamāno,

original: jādeso, ñāyamāno. Gaṇhātīti gaṇhaṃ, gaṇhamāno, gayhamāno.
analyzed: ñāyamānaḥ gaṇhāti iti gaṇham gaṇhamānaḥ gayhamānaḥ
translated: The verbal root ñā means to know. He knows is ñāyamāno. He grasps is gaṇhaṃ, gaṇhamāno, gayhamāno.

original: Kara karaṇe, karotīti atthe “vattamāne mānantā”ti antappaccayo, “tanādito oyirā”ti
analyzed: kara karaṇe karoti iti atthe vattamāne māna anta ati anta ppaccayaḥ tan āditaḥ oyirāti
translated: Kara means to do. He does is karoti. The affix ant is added by the rule “mānantā” . The affix oyir is added by the rule “tanādito oyirā” .

original: o, “tassa vā”ti adhikicca “uttamokāro”ti uttaṃ, “karassākāro cā”ti akārassukāro.🔽“Yavakārā cā”ti sare ukārassa vattaṃ, dvittaṃ, “bo vassā”ti bakāradvayañca, “kvaci
analyzed: o tassa vā ati adhikicca uttamaḥ okāraḥ iti uttam karassa ākāraḥ ca ati akāraḥ ukāraḥ  ya vakārā ca ati sare ukārassa vattam dvittam baḥ vassa ati bakāra dvayam ca kvaci
translated: O, “tassa vā” means “of that” and “uttamokāro” means “the letter u is lengthened” and “akārassukāro cā” means “and the letter a becomes the letter u”.

original: dhātū”tiādinā ralopo, so kubbaṃ, kubbanto, kubbatī, kubbantī, kubbantaṃ. Uttābhāve
analyzed: dhātu uti ādinā ra lopaḥ saḥ kubbam kubbantaḥ kubbatī kubbantī kubbantam utta abhāve
translated: “Yavakārā cā” means “and the letter ya becomes the letter u” and “dvittaṃ bo vassā” means “the two letters ba become the letter v” and “kvaci dhātū” means “in some roots the r is elided”. So kubbaṃ, kubbanto, kubbatī, kubbantī, kubbantaṃ. In the absence of the lengthening

original: – kammaṃ karonto, karontī, karontaṃ. Māne – uttadvayaṃ, kurumāno, kurumānā, kurumānaṃ,
analyzed: kammam karonto karontī karontam māne
translated: – kammaṃ karonto, karontī, karontaṃ. In the passive – uttadvayaṃ, kurumāno, kurumānā, kurumānaṃ,

original: kubbāno vā. Kammani kayiramāno, karīyamāno vā iccādi.
analyzed: kubbānaḥ vā kammani kayiramānaḥ karīyamānaḥ vā iccādi
translated: kubbāno. In the causative – kayiramāno, karīyamāno.

original: Cura theyye, “curādito”tiādinā ṇe ṇayā, coretīti corento, corentī, corentaṃ, corayaṃ,
analyzed: cura theyye cur ādi taḥ uti ādinā ṇe ṇayā coreti iti corentau corentī corentam corayam
translated: In the root cur “stealing”, by ṇe ṇaya according to “curādito” (Gram. 1.1.65), coretīti corento, corentī, corentaṃ, corayaṃ,

original: corayatī, corayantaṃ, corayamāno, corīyamāno. Pāletīti pālento, pālentī, pālentaṃ,
analyzed: corayatī corayantam corayamāno corīyamāno pāleti iti pālentaḥ pālentī pālentam
translated: corayatī, corayantaṃ, corayamāno, corīyamāno. In the root pāle “to protect”, pāletīti pālento, pālentī, pālentaṃ,

original: pālayaṃ, pālayantī, pālayantaṃ, pālayamāno, pālīyamāno iccādi.
analyzed: pālayam pālayantī pālayantam pālayamānaḥ pālīyamānaḥ iccādi
translated: pālayaṃ, pālayantī, pālayantaṃ, pālayamāno, pālīyamāno.

original: Kārite bhāvetīti bhāvento, bhāventī, bhāventaṃ, bhāvayaṃ, bhāvayantī, bhāvayantaṃ,
analyzed: kārite bhāveti iti bhāventaḥ bhāventī bhāventam bhāvayam bhāvayantī bhāvayantam
translated: He causes to develop is bhāvento, bhāventī, bhāv-entaṃ, bhāvayam, bhāvayantī, bhāvayantaṃ,

original: bhāvayamāno, bhāvīyamāno. Kāretīti kāronto, kārentī, kārentaṃ, kārayaṃ, kārayantī,
analyzed: bhāvayamānaḥ bhāvīyamānaḥ kāreti iti kārontaḥ kārentī kārentam kārayam kārayantī
translated: bhāvayamāno, bhāvīyamāno. He causes to do is kāronto, kārentī, kārentaṃ, kārayaṃ, kārayantī,

original: kārayantaṃ, kārayamāno, kārīyamāno, kārāpento, kārāpentī, kārāpentaṃ, kārāpayaṃ,🔽kārāpayantī, kārāpayantaṃ, kārāpayamāno, kārāpīyamāno iccādi.
analyzed: kārayantam kārayamānaḥ kārīyamānaḥ kārāpentaḥ kārāpentī kārāpentam kārāpayam  kārāpayantī kārāpayantam kārāpayamānaḥ kārāpīyamānaḥ iti ca ādi
translated: kārayantaṃ, kārayamāno, kārīyamāno, kārāpento, kārāpentī, kārāpentaṃ, kārāpayaṃ,🔽kārāpayantī, kārāpayantaṃ, kārāpayamāno, kārāpīyamāno.

original: Vattamānakālikamānantappaccayantanayo.
analyzed: vattamāna kālika māna nta ppaccaya ntanayaḥ
translated: This is the method of the present tense with the causative.

original: Anāgatakālikappaccayantanaya
analyzed: anāgata kālika ppaccaya nta naya
translated: The method of the future tense with the causative

original: “Kāle”ti adhikāro.
analyzed: kāla iti
translated: The context is “at the time.”

original: 647. Bhavissati gamādīhi ṇī ghiṇa.
analyzed: bhavissati gama ādīhi ṇī ghi ṇa
translated: With gam and so on there are ṇī, ghi, ṇā.

analyzed: bhavissati kāle gammamāne gama ādīhi dhātūhi ṇī ghi ṇa e c ca ete paccayāḥ honti ṇakārāḥ  āyati gamanam sīlam assa ati atthe ṇī vuddhi ṇa lopā gāmī gāminaḥ āgāmī kālaḥ ghi iṇa paccaye

The ṇā ending is for the purpose of expressing the future.🔽The meaning is: “It has the nature of going in the future.” The ṇī ending is formed by adding ṇ to the root and then dropping the i. The ṇā ending is formed by adding ṇā to the root and then dropping the i.🔽In the causative with the ghi ending,

translated: the i of the root is dropped by the rule “In some cases the verbal root,” and so on. The meaning is: “It causes to go to the village.” The ṇā ending is formed by adding ṇā to the root and then dropping the i.

original: Bhaja sevāyaṃ, āyati bhajituṃ sīlamassāti bhājī, bhāji, “na kagattaṃ cajā”ti yogavibhāgena nisedhanato “sacajānaṃ kagā ṇānubandhe”ti gattaṃ na bhavati.
analyzed: bhaja āyati bhajitum sīlam assa ati bhājī bhāji na kagattam cajāti yogavibhāgena nisedhanato gattam na bhavati
translated: Bhaja, sevāyaṃ, āyati bhajituṃ sīlamassāti bhājī, bhāji, “na kagattaṃ cajā”ti yogavibhāgena nisedhanato “sacajānaṃ kagā ṇānubandhe”ti gattaṃ na bhavati.

original: Su gatimhi, kārite vuddhiāvādesā ca, āyati passavituṃ sīlamassāti passāvī, passāvi. Āyati paṭṭhānaṃ sīlamassāti paṭṭhāyī, paṭṭhāyi, “ākārantānamāyo”ti āyādeso.
analyzed: su gatimhi kārite ca āyati passavitum sīlam assa ati passāvī passāvi āyati paṭṭhānam sīlam assa ati paṭṭhāyī paṭṭhāyi ākāra antānam āyo ti āya ādesaḥ
translated: Su gatimhi, kārite vuddhiāvādesā ca, āyati passavituṃ sīlamassāti passāvī, passāvi. Āyati paṭṭhānaṃ sīlamassāti paṭṭhāyī, paṭṭhāyi, “ākārantānamāyo”ti āyādeso.

original: “Bhavissatī”ti adhikāro.
analyzed: bhavissati iti adhikāraḥ
translated: “Bhavissatī”ti adhikāro.

original: 648. Kiriyāyaṃ ṇvutavo.
analyzed: kiriyā ayam ṇvu tavaḥ
translated: . Kiriyāyaṃ ṇvutavo.

original: Kiriyāyaṃ kiriyatthāyaṃ gammamānāyaṃ dhātūhi ṇvutuiccete paccayā honti bhavissati kāle. Ṇvumhi – ṇalopavuddhiakādesā, karissaṃ vajatīti kārako vajati.
analyzed: kiriyāyam kiriyatthāyam gammamānāyam dhātūhi ṇvu tu icca ete paccayāḥ honti bhavissati kāle ṇvumhi ṇa lopa vuddhi aka ādesā karissam vajati iti kārakaḥ vajati
translated: Kiriyāyaṃ kiriyatthāyaṃ gammamānāyaṃ dhātūhi ṇvutuiccete paccayā honti bhavissati kāle. Ṇvumhi – ṇalopavuddhiakādesā, karissaṃ vajatīti kārako vajati.

original: Tumhi – “karassa ca tattaṃ tusmi”nti takāro, sesaṃ kattusamaṃ, kattā vajati, kattuṃ
analyzed: tumhi karassa ca tattam tusmin ti takāraḥ sesam kattu samam kattā vajati kattum
translated: Tumhi – “karassa ca tattaṃ tusmi”nti takāro, sesaṃ kattusamaṃ, kattā vajati, kattuṃ

original: vajatīti attho. Evaṃ pacissaṃ vajatīti pācako vajati, pacitā vajati. Bhuñjissaṃ vajatīti
analyzed: vajati iti attho evam pacissam vajati iti pācakaḥ vajati pacitā vajati bhuñjissam vajati iti
translated: vajatīti attho. Evaṃ pacissaṃ vajatīti pācako vajati, pacitā vajati. Bhuñjissaṃ vajatīti

original: bhuñjako vajati, bhottā vajati iccādi.
analyzed: bhuñjakaḥ vajati bhottā vajati iccādi
translated: One who eats goes, one who is fed goes, etc.

original: 649. Kammani ṇo.
analyzed: kammani ṇaḥ
translated: In the word kammani, the affix ṇo is added.

original: Kammasmiṃ upapade dhātūhi ṇappaccayo hoti bhavissati kāle ṇalopavuddhī. Nagaraṃ karissatīti
analyzed: kammasmin upapade dhātūhi ṇa p paccayaḥ hoti bhavissati kāle nagaram karissati iti
translated: In the word kammasmiṃ, the affix ṇap is added to the root, and the affix ṇo is elided and the vowel lengthened. He will make a city,

original: nagarakāro vajati. Lū chedane, sāliṃ lavissatīti sālilāvo vajati. Vapa bījasantāne,
analyzed: nagarakāraḥ vajati chedane sālim lavissati iti sāli lāvaḥ vajati bīja santāne
translated: a city-maker goes. Lū means to cut, he will cut rice, a rice-cutter goes. Vapa means to plant seeds,

original: dhaññaṃ vapissatīti dhaññavāpo vajati. Bhogaṃ dadissatīti bhogadāyo vajati, sindhuṃ
analyzed: dhaññam vapissati iti dhañña vāpaḥ vajati bhogam dadissati iti bhoga dāyaḥ vajati sindhum
translated: he will plant grain, a grain-planter goes. Dā means to give, he will give wealth, a wealth-giver goes. Pi means to drink,

original: pivissatīti sindhupāyo vajati iccādi.
analyzed: pivissati iti sindhu pāyaḥ vajati iccādi
translated: he will drink the river, a river-drinker goes, etc.

original: “Kammanī”ti vattate.
analyzed: kammani iti vattate
translated: The word kammani is said.

original: 650. Sese ssaṃ ntu mānānā.🔽Kammasmiṃ upapade sese aparisamattatthe dhātūhi ssaṃntu māna ānaiccete paccayā honti
analyzed: sese ssam n tu mā anānā  kammasmin upapade sese a parisamatta tthe dhātūhi mānaḥ āna ai c ca ete paccayāḥ honti
translated: In the rest, ssaṃ, ntu, māna, āna.🔽In the word kammasmiṃ, the affixes ssaṃ, ntu, māna, āna are added to the roots,

original: bhavissati kāle gammamāne, te ca kitakattā kattari bhavanti. Kammaṃ karissatīti atthe
analyzed: bhavissati kāle gammamāne te ca kita kattā kattari bhavanti kammam karissati iti atthe
translated: and the affix ṇo is elided and the vowel lengthened. When the future time is expressed, and they are in the instrumental case, they become the agent. In the meaning “he will do the work,”

original: ssaṃpaccayo, ikārāgamo, silopo, kammaṃ karissaṃ vajati, sāpekkhattā na samāso. Ntupaccaye
analyzed: s s paccayaḥ i kāra āgamaḥ si lopaḥ kammam karissam vajati sāpekkhattā na samāsaḥ n tu paccaye
translated: the affix ssaṃ is added, the vowel i is lengthened, and the affix ṇo is elided. He will do the work, he goes. Because of expectation, it is not a compound. In the ntu affix,

original: “tanādito oyirā”ti o, “simhi vā”ti ntva’ntassa attaṃ, kammaṃ karissatīti kammaṃ karonto
analyzed: tanāditaḥ oyirāti o simhi vā attam kammam karissati iti kammam karontaḥ
translated: “Tanādito oyirā” means o. “Simhi vā” means the affix attaṃ. “Kammaṃ karissati” means kammaṃ karonto.

original: vajati iccādi guṇavantusamaṃ.
analyzed: vajati it cādi
translated: Vajati, etc., is similar to guṇavantusamaṃ.

original: Atha vā “bhavissati gamādīhi ṇī ghiṇa”ti ettha “bhavissatī”ti vacanato “ssantu”iti
analyzed: atha vā bhavissati gama ādīhi ṇī ettha bhavissati iti vacanataḥ ssantu iti
translated: Or, in “Bhavissati gamādīhi ṇī ghiṇa,” since the word “bhavissati” is stated, “ssantu”

original: ekova paccayo daṭṭhabbo, tato “simhi vā”ti attaṃ, “ntasaddo a”mitiyogavibhāgena amādeso,
analyzed: ekaḥ iva paccayaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ tatas simhi vā attam nta saddaḥ am iti yogavibhāgena am ādesaḥ
translated: should be seen as the single condition. Then, “simhi vā” means the affix attaṃ. “Ntasaddo a” means the substitution of amādeso by the rule of yogavibhāga.

original: silopo, karissaṃ karissanto, karissantā, karissantaṃ, karissante, karissatā karissantena,
analyzed: si lopaḥ karissam karissantaḥ karissantā karissantam karissante karissatā karissantena
translated: Silopa. Karissam, karissanto, karissantā, karissantaṃ, karissante, karissatā karissantena,

analyzed: karissantehi karissataḥ karissantassa karissatam karissantānam karissatā karissantehi
translated: karissantehi, karissato karissantassa, karissataṃ karissantānaṃ, karissatā, karissantehi,

original: karissato karissantassa, karissataṃ karissantānaṃ, karissati karissante, karissantesūtiādi
analyzed: karissataḥ karissantassa karissatam karissantānam karissati karissante karissantesu utiādi
translated: karissato karissantassa, karissataṃ karissantānaṃ, karissati karissante, karissantesūti, etc.,

original: guṇavantusadisaṃ neyyaṃ.
analyzed: guṇavantu sadisam neyyam
translated: is similar to guṇavantusamaṃ.

original: Mānamhi – okārākārānaṃ uttaṃ, kammaṃ karissatīti kammaṃ kurumāno, kammaṃ karāno vajati. Evaṃ bhojanaṃ bhuñjissaṃ vajati, bhojanaṃ bhuñjanto, bhuñjamāno, bhuñjāno vajati.
analyzed: uttam kammam karissati iti kammam kurumānaḥ kammam karānaḥ vajati evam bhojanam bhuñjissam vajati bhojanam bhuñjantaḥ bhuñjamānaḥ bhuñjānaḥ vajati
translated: In the case of māna, the u and the ṅ of okāra and ākāra are dropped, and the ṅ of kamma is dropped, and the ṅ of vajati is dropped, and the ṅ of kurumāno is dropped, and the ṅ of kuranto is dropped, and the ṅ of karāno is dropped, and the ṅ of bhuñjissaṃ is dropped, and the ṅ of bhuñjanto is dropped, and the ṅ of bhuñjamāno is dropped, and the ṅ of bhuñjāno is dropped, and the ṅ of vajati is dropped.

original: Sabbattha kattari ntumānesu sakasakavikaraṇappaccayo kātabbo.🔽Khādanaṃ khādissatīti khādanaṃ khādissaṃ vajati, khādanaṃ khādanto, khādanaṃ khādamāno,🔽khādanaṃ khādāno vajati. Maggaṃ carissatīti maggaṃ carissaṃ, maggaṃ caranto, maggaṃ🔽caramāno, maggaṃ carāno vajati. Bhikkha āyācane, bhikkhaṃ bhikkhissatīti bhikkhaṃ
analyzed: sabbattha kattari n tu mānesu saka saka vikaraṇa ppaccayaḥ kātabbaḥ  khādanam khādissati iti khādanam khādissam vajati khādanam khādantaḥ khādanam khādamānaḥ  khādanam khādānaḥ vajati maggam carissati iti maggam carissam maggam carantaḥ maggam  caramānaḥ maggam carānaḥ vajati bhikkhe āyācane bhikkham bhikkhissati iti bhikkham
translated: In all these cases the appropriate verbal-noun base must be formed with the passive-voice passive-sign -ana.

original: bhikkhissaṃ carati, bhikkhaṃ bhikkhanto, bhikkhaṃ bhikkhamāno, bhikkhaṃ bhikkhāno carati iccādi.
analyzed: bhikkhissam carati bhikkham bhikkhantaḥ bhikkham bhikkhamānaḥ bhikkham bhikkhāno carati iccādi
translated: In the case of khādana, the ṅ of khādissa is dropped, and the ṅ of khādissaṃ is dropped, and the ṅ of khādanto is dropped, and the ṅ of khādamāno is dropped, and the ṅ of khādāno is dropped, and the ṅ of vajati is dropped. In the case of magga, the ṅ of carissa is dropped, and the ṅ of carissaṃ is dropped, and the ṅ of caranto is dropped, and the ṅ of caramāno is dropped, and the ṅ of carāno is dropped, and the ṅ of vajati is dropped. In the case of bhikkha, the ṅ of āyācane is dropped, and the ṅ of bhikkhissa is dropped, and the ṅ of bhikkhissaṃ is dropped, and the ṅ of carati is dropped, and the ṅ of bhikkhanto is dropped, and the ṅ of bhikkhamāno is dropped, and the ṅ of bhikkhāno is dropped, and the ṅ of carati is dropped.

original: Anāgatakālikappaccayantanayo.
analyzed: anāgata kālika ppaccaya ntanayaḥ
translated: This is the method of explaining the future-tense-sign.

original: Uṇādippaccayantanaya
analyzed: uṇ ādip pac caya nta naya
translated: The method of explaining the uṇādi-signs

original: Atha uṇādayo vuccante.
analyzed: atha uṇ ādayaḥ vuccante
translated: Now the uṇādi-signs are stated.

original: “Dhātuyā”ti adhikāro.
analyzed: dhātuyāti adhikāro
translated: The extension is “in a base” .

original: 651. Kāle vattamānātīte ṇvādayo.
analyzed: kāle vattamāna atīte ṇu ādayaḥ
translated: ṇvādayo in the past and present

original: Atīte kāle, vattamāne ca gammamāne dhātūhi ṇuppaccayo hoti. Ādisaddena yu kta miiccādayo ca honti.
analyzed: atīte kāle vattamāne ca gammamāne dhātūhi ṇup paccayaḥ hoti ādi saddena yu kta mi icca ādayaḥ ca honti
translated: In the past and in the present, the syllable ṇ is formed from the verbal bases by adding the suffix ṇ. The words ādi, yu, kta, mi, ic, etc., are also formed in this way.

original: Kara karaṇe, akāsi, karotīti vā atthe ṇuppaccayo, ṇalopo, vuddhi, kāru sippī, kārū
analyzed: kara karaṇe akāsi karoti iti vā atthe ṇup paccayaḥ ṇa lopaḥ vuddhi kāru sippī kārū
translated: Kara, in the sense of “doing,” becomes akāsi, karotīti vā, in the sense of “he did, he does.” The suffix ṇ is added, the ṇ is elided, and there is augmentation. The words kāru, sippī, kārū, kāravo are formed.

original: kāravo. Vā gatigandhanesu, avāyi, vāyatīti vā vāyu, āyādeso. Sada assādane, assādīyatīti
analyzed: kāravaḥ vā gati gandhanesu avāyi vāyati iti vā sadaḥ assādane assādīyati iti
translated: Vā, in the sense of “going” and “smelling,” becomes avāyi, vāyatīti vā, vāyu. The ā is elided. Sada, in the sense of “tasting,” becomes assādīyati, sādu.

original: sādu. Rādha, sādha saṃsiddhimhi, sādhīyati anena hitanti sādhu. Bandha bandhane,🔽attani paraṃ bandhatīti bandhu. Cakkha viyattiyaṃ vācāyaṃ, cakkhatīti cakkhu. I gatimhi,🔽enti gacchanti pavattanti sattā etenāti āyu. Dara vidāraṇe, darīyatīti dāru kaṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: sādu rādha sādha saṃsiddhimhi sādhīyati anena hitanti sādhu bandha bandhane  attani param bandhati iti bandhu vācā ayam cakkhati iti cakkhu i gatimhi  enti gacchanti pavattanti sattā etena ati āyu dara vidāraṇe darīyati iti dāru kaṭṭham
translated: Rādha, in the sense of “being good,” becomes sādha, saṃsiddhimhi, sādhīyati anena hitanti, sādhu. Bandha, in the sense of “binding,” becomes bandhu, attani paraṃ bandhatīti.🔽Cakkha, in the sense of “opening,” becomes cakkhatīti, cakkhu. I, in the sense of “going,” becomes enti, gacchanti, pavattanti, sattā etenāti, āyu.🔽Dara, in the sense of “tearing,” becomes darīyati, dāru, kaṭṭhaṃ.

original: Sanu dāne. Sanotīti sānu pabbatekadeso. Janīyatīti jānu jaṅghāsandhi. Carīyatīti
analyzed: sanu dāne sanoti iti sānu pabbata eka desaḥ janīyati iti jānu jaṅghā sandhi carīyati iti
translated: Sanu, in the sense of “giving,” becomes sanotīti, sānu, pabbatekadeso. Janīyati, jānu, jaṅghāsandhi. Carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati, carīyati,

original: cāru dassanīyo. Raha cāge, rahīyatīti rāhu asurindo. Tara taraṇe, tālu, lo rassa.
analyzed: cāru dassanīyaḥ raha cāge rahīyatīti rāhu asurindo tara taraṇe tālu laḥ rassa
translated: Rāhu is the lord of the Asuras. He is so called because he hides the moon. Tara means to cross over. Tālu is the palate. Lo is short.

original: Marādīnaṃ panettha ṇumhi “ghaṭādīnaṃ vā”ti ettha vāsaddena na vuddhi, maru, taru, tanu, dhanu, hanu, manu, asu, vasu, vaṭu, garu iccādi.🔽Cadi hilādane, yuppaccayo, “nudādīhi yuṇvūnamanānanākānanakā sakāritehi cā”ti anādeso,
analyzed: mara ādīnam pana ittha ghaṭa ādīnam vā ati ettha vā saddena na maru taru tanu dhanu hanu manu asu vasu vaṭu garu iccādi  ca di hi lādane yup paccayaḥ nud ādīhi yu ṇ vu ū namana ānanā kānanakā sa kāri tehi ca ati an ādesaḥ
translated: But in the case of marā, etc., the ṇumhi is not lengthened by the addition of vās, as in the case of ghaṭā, etc., thus: maru, taru, tanu, dhanu, hanu, manu, asu, vasu, vaṭu, garu, and so on.

original: niggahītāgamo ca, candanaṃ. Bhavati etthāti bhuvanaṃ, “jhalānamiyuvāsare vā”ti uvādeso.
analyzed: ca candanam bhavati ettha ati bhuvanam vā ti u ādesaḥ
translated: Ca means to cut off. The suffix -uppaccayo is added. The anādeso is made by the addition of -nānanākānanakā, thus: candanaṃ. The uvādeso is made by the addition of -vās, thus: bhuvanaṃ.

original: Kira vikkhepe, kiraṇo. Vicakkhaṇo, kampanaṃ karotīti karuṇā, akārassuttaṃ.🔽Ktappaccaye – kalopo, abhavi, bhavatīti vā bhūtaṃ yakkhādi, bhūtāni. Vāyatīti vāto, tāyatīti tāto. Mimhi – bhavanti etthāti bhūmi, netīti nemi iccādi.
analyzed: vikkhepe kiraṇaḥ vicakkhaṇaḥ kampanam karoti iti karuṇā akāraḥ uttam  kta paccaye ka lopaḥ abhavi bhavati iti vā bhūtam yakkha ādi bhūtāni vāyati iti vātaḥ tāyati iti tātaḥ mimhi bhavanti ettha ati bhūmi na iti iti nemi iccādi
translated: Kira means to scatter. Kiraṇo is a scattering. Vicakkhaṇo is one who sees well. Karuṇā is so called because it causes the shaking of the body. The akārassutta is made.

original: 652. Khyādīhi mana ma ca to vā.
analyzed: khyā dīhi mana ma ca taḥ vā
translated: In the case of the khyādippavacanīya khyādīhi mana ma ca to vā, the khyādippavacanīya is made by the addition of -to, thus: kalopo. The khyādippavacanīya is made by the addition of -ma, thus: abhavi. The khyādippavacanīya is made by the addition of -ca, thus: bhūtaṃ. The khyādippavacanīya is made by the addition of -to, thus: vāto. The khyādippavacanīya is made by the addition of -to, thus: tāto. The khyādippavacanīya is made by the addition of -ma, thus: bhūmi. The khyādippavacanīya is made by the addition of -ma, thus: nemi. And so on.

original: Khī bhī su ru hu vā dhū hi lūpī adaiccevamādīhi dhātūhi manapaccayo hoti, massa ca to hoti vā.
analyzed: khī bhī su ru hu vā dhū hi lūpī a dai c ca evamādīhi dhātūhi mana paccayaḥ hoti massa ca to hoti vā
translated: The affix mana is added to the roots khī, bhī, su, ru, hu, vā, dhū, lū, and to the indeclinable ada, and the affix to is added to the last of these, optionally.

original: Adadhātuparasseva, makārassa takāratā;
analyzed: a dadhātu parassa iva makārassa takāra tā
translated: The affix tak is added to the last of the roots

original: Tadaññato na hotāyaṃ, vavatthitavibhāsato.🔽Khī khaye, khīyanti ettha upaddavupasaggādayoti atthe manapaccayo, “kvaci dhātū”tiādinā
analyzed: tat aññatas na hotā ayam  khī khaye khīyanti ettha upaddava upasagga ādayaḥ ti atthe mana paccayaḥ kvaci dhātu uti ādinā
translated: beginning with ad, but not from any other.🔽The affix mana is added to the root khī, to mean “decay,” in the sense of “here the calamities, the adversities, etc., decay,”🔽and the elision of the final n is by the rule kvaci dhātū.🔽The augment v is not added by the rule “after bhī, etc., the augment v is added,” because of the word vādhikārato.

original: nalopo, “aññesu cā”ti vuddhi, khemo. Tathā bhī bhaye, bhāyanti etasmāti bhīmo, vādhikārato
analyzed: na lopaḥ aññesu ca ati tathā bhī bhaye bhāyanti etasmā ati bhīmaḥ vā adhikārato
translated: The affix som is added to the root su, to mean “shining,” in the sense of “it shines,”🔽and the augment v is not added by the rule “after roots ending in a short vowel, the augment v is added,” because of the word vādhikārato.

original: na vuddhi. Su abhisave, savatīti somo. Ru gatimhi, romo. Hu dānādanahabyappadānesu,
analyzed: na su abhisave savati iti somaḥ ru gatimhi romaḥ hu dāna adana habya ppadānesu
translated: The affix omo is added to the root hu, to mean “offering,” in the sense of “it is offered,”🔽and the augment v is not added by the rule “after roots ending in a short vowel, the augment v is added,” because of the word vādhikārato.

original: hūyatīti homo. Vā gatigandhanesu, vāmo. Dhū kampane, dhunātīti dhūmo. Hi gatimhi,
analyzed: hūyati iti homaḥ vā gati gandhanesu vāmaḥ kampane dhunāti iti dhūmaḥ hi gatimhi
translated: The affix amo is added to the root vā, to mean “going” or “smelling,” in the sense of “it goes” or “it smells,”🔽and the augment v is not added by the rule “after roots ending in a short vowel, the augment v is added,” because of the word vādhikārato.🔽The affix omo is added to the root dhū, to mean “shaking,” in the sense of “it shakes,”🔽and the augment v is not added by the rule “after roots ending in a short vowel, the augment v is added,” because of the word vādhikārato.🔽The affix emo is added to the root hi, to mean “going,” in the sense of “it goes,”🔽and the augment v is not added by the rule “after roots ending in a short vowel, the augment v is added,” because of the word vādhikārato.

original: hinotīti hemo. Lū chedane, lūyatīti lomo. Pī tappane, pīṇanaṃ pemo. Ada bhakkhaṇe,
analyzed: hinoti iti hemaḥ tappane pīṇanam pemaḥ bhakkhaṇe
translated: The affix amo is added to the root lū, to mean “cutting,” in the sense of “it cuts,”

original: adatīti atthe mana, massa ca vā takāro, “to dassā”ti takāro, attā, ātumā, “kvaci
analyzed: adati iti atthe mana massa ca vā takāraḥ taḥ dassa ati takāraḥ attā ātumā kvaci
translated: and the augment v is not added by the rule “after roots ending in

original: dhātū”tiādinā adassa dīgho, ukārāgamo ca. Yā pāpaṇe, yāmo.
analyzed: dhātu uti ādinā adassa dīghaḥ ukāra āgamaḥ ca yā pāpaṇe yāmaḥ
translated: and so on. The long vowel is due to the base ending in a vowel. Yā is the night.

original: “Vā”ti vattamāne –
analyzed: vāti vattamāne
translated: When the present tense is expressed,

original: 653. Samādihi thamā.
analyzed: samādihi thamā
translated: the following are the conditions:

original: Samadamadara raha lapa vasa yu du hi si dā sā ṭhā bhasa bahausuiccevamādīhi dhātūhi tha maiccete paccayā honti vā.
analyzed: raha lapa vasa yu du hi si dā sā ṭhā bhasa bahausu it ca ivamādīhi dhātūhi tha ma i t ca ete paccayāḥ honti vā
translated: with the bases sama, dama, dama, ra, lapa, vasa, yu, du, hi, si, dā, sā, ṭhā, bhasa, bahau, and so on.

original: Sama upasame, kvaciggahaṇādhikārā na dhātvantalopo, kilese sametīti samatho samādhi.
analyzed: samaḥ upasame na dhātu anta lopaḥ kilese sameti iti samādhi
translated: Sama means “to be calm.” Because of the rule of inclusion, there is no elision of the final vowel of the base. Samatho means “calmness,” because it is that by which defilements are calmed.

original: Evaṃ damanaṃ damatho. Dara dāhe, daraṇaṃ daratho paridāho. Raha upādāne, rahīyatīti
analyzed: evam damanam damathaḥ dāhe daraṇam daratho paridāhaḥ rahaḥ upādāne rahīyati iti
translated: Similarly, dama means “to control,” and damatho means “control.” Dara means “to burn,” and daratho means “burning,” “fever.” Ra means “to grasp,” and ratho means “a vehicle,” because it is that by which one is carried.

original: ratho, “kvaci dhātū”tiādinā halopo. Sapa akkose, sapanaṃ sapatho. Vasa nivāse, āvasanti🔽etasminti āvasatho. Yu missane, yūtho, dīgho. Du gativuddhimhi, davati vaḍḍhatīti
analyzed: rathaḥ kvacid dhātu uti ādinā ha lopaḥ sapa akkose sapanam sapathaḥ vasa nivāse āvasanti  etasmin ti āvasathaḥ yu missane yūthaḥ dīghaḥ du gati vuddhimhi davati vaḍḍhati iti
translated: Because of the rule “kvaci dhātū,” there is elision of the final vowel of the base. Sapa means “to revile,” and sapatho means “reviling.” Vasa means “to dwell,” and āvasatho means “dwelling,” because it is that in which one dwells.

original: dumo. Hinotīti himo ussāvo. Si bandhane, sīyatīti sīmā, dīgho. Dā avakhaṇḍane, dāmo.
analyzed: dumaḥ hinoti iti himaḥ ussāvaḥ bandhane sīyati iti sīmā dīghaḥ dāḥ avakhaṇḍane
translated: Yu means “to mix,” and yūtho means “a crowd.” Du means “to grow,” and dumo means “a tree.” Hi means “to flow,” and himo means “a flood.” Si means “to bind,” and sīmā means “a boundary.” Dā means “to break,” and dāmo means “a bridle.”

original: Sā sāmatthe, sāmo. Ṭhā gatinivattimhi, thāmo, ṭhassa thattaṃ. Bhasa bhasmīkaraṇe,
analyzed: sā sāmatthe sāmaḥ ṭhā gati nivattimhi thāmaḥ ṭhassa thattam bhasa bhasmīkaraṇe
translated: Sā is in sāmatthe, sāmo. Ṭhā is in gatinivattimhi, thāmo. Ṭhassa is in thattaṃ. Bhasa is in bhasmīkaraṇe,

original: bhasmā, brahmādittā “syā cā”ti āttaṃ. Baha vuddhimhi, brahmā, nipātanato bro bassa.
analyzed: bhasmā brahmā adittā syā ca ati āttam vuddhimhi brahmā nipātanataḥ bro bassa
translated: Sā is the feminine of sāma, sāmo. Ṭhā is the feminine of ṭhāma, ṭhāmo. Bhasa is the feminine of bhasmā, bhasmā. Brahmā is the feminine of brahmā, brahmā. Baha is the feminine of brahma, brahma.

original: Usu dāhe, usmā iccādi.
analyzed: usu dāhe usmai i t ca ādi
translated: Usu is the feminine of usmā, usmā.

original: 654. Masussa sussa ccha ra ccherā.
analyzed: ma sussa sussa ccha ra cche rā
translated: . Masussa sussa ccha ra ccherā.🔽The feminine of masu is sussa, cchara, ccherā.

original: Masuiccetassa dhātussa sussa ccharaccheraiccete ādesā honti. Masu macchere, kvippaccayo, ccharaccherādesā, maccharo, macchero.
analyzed: masu iti etassa dhātussa sussa cchara chera ai cca ite ādesāḥ honti masu macchere kvip paccayaḥ cchara chera ādesāḥ maccharaḥ maccheraḥ
translated: Masu macchere, kvippaccayo, ccharaccherādesā, maccharo, macchero.

original: “Cchara ccherā”ti vattate.
analyzed: vattate
translated: “Cchara ccherā” is said.

original: 655. Āpubbacarassa ca.
analyzed: ā pubba carassa ca
translated: . Āpubbacarassa ca.

original: Āpubbassa caraiccetassa dhātussa ccharaccherādesā honti, casaddena cchariyādeso ca.
analyzed: ā pubbassa carai c cetassa dhātussa cchara chera ādesāḥ honti ca saddena cchari ādesaḥ ca
translated: The feminine of āpubbacara is cchara, ccherā. By the word ca, cchariyā is also included.

original: Bhuso caraṇanti atthe kvippaccayo, cchariyādiādeso, rassattañca. Acchariyaṃ, accharaṃ,
analyzed: bhusaḥ caraṇanti atthe kvip paccayaḥ cchariya ādi ādesaḥ rassa ttam ca acchariyam accharam
translated: Bhuso caraṇanti atthe kvippaccayo, cchariyādiādeso, rassattañca. Acchariyaṃ, accharaṃ,

original: accheraṃ. Accharaṃ paharituṃ yuttantipi acchariyaṃ.
analyzed: accheram accharam paharitum acchariyam
translated: accheraṃ. Accharaṃ paharituṃ yuttantipi acchariyaṃ.

original: 656. Ala kala salehi layā.
analyzed: ala kala salehi layā
translated: . Ala kala salehi layā.

original: Ala kala sala iccetehi dhātūhi la yaiccete paccayā honti. Ala parisamattimhi, allaṃ, alyaṃ. Kala saṅkhyāne, kallaṃ, kalyaṃ. Sala, hula, pada gatimhi, sallaṃ, salyaṃ.
analyzed: ala kala salaḥ it ca etehi dhātūhi la ya e c ca ete paccayāḥ honti ala parisamattimhi allam alyam kala saṅkhyāne kallam kalyam sala hula pada gatimhi sallam salyam
translated: in the sense of ‘to go’ (salla, salya),

original: “Kala salehī”ti vattate.
analyzed: kala salehi iti vattate
translated: the expression ‘kala salehī’ is used.

original: 657. Yāṇa lāṇā.
analyzed: yāṇa lāṇā
translated: Yāṇa, lāṇā.

original: Tehi kala salaiccetehi dhātūhi yāṇa lāṇappaccayā honti. Kalyāṇaṃ, paṭisalyāṇaṃ, kallāṇo,
analyzed: tehi dhātūhi yāṇa lāṇa paccayāḥ honti kalyāṇam paṭisalyāṇam kallāṇo
translated: The syllables kala and sala are the conditions for yāṇa and lāṇā. Kalyāṇa, paṭisalyāṇa, kallāṇo,

original: paṭisallāṇo. Yadā pana lī silesaneti dhātu, tadā “paṭisallayanaṃ, paṭisallāṇa”nti
analyzed: paṭisallāṇaḥ yadā pana silesanā iti dhātu tadā paṭisallayanam paṭisallāṇanti
translated: paṭisallāṇo. But when the root lī is in the sense of ‘to lie down’, then ‘paṭisallayana, paṭisallāṇa’

original: yuppaccayena siddhaṃ, upasaggantassa niggahītassa lattaṃ, rahādiparattā nassa ṇattaṃ,
analyzed: yup paccayena siddham upasagga antassa niggahītassa lattam raha ādi para ttā nassa ṇattam
translated: is formed by the yuppaccaya, the latta of the prefixed niggahīta, the ṇatta of the paratta beginning with ra,

original: ekārassa “kvaci dhātū”tiādinā attañca.
analyzed: eka arassa kvaci dhātu uti ādinā at tañca
translated: and the atta of the e-vowel by ‘kvaci dhātū’ and so on.

original: 658. Mathissa thassa lo ca.
analyzed: mathissa thassa lo ca
translated: . Mathissa thassa lo ca.

original: Mathaiccetassa dhātussa thassa lādeso hoti, casaddena lappaccayo, matha viloḷane, mallo, so eva mallako, yathā hīnako.
analyzed: matha e c ca itassa dhātussa thassa la ādesaḥ hoti ca saddena lap paccayaḥ matha viloḷane mallaḥ saḥ eva mallakaḥ yathā hīnakaḥ
translated: The locative of the root matha is thassa, and the condition is la, by the word ca. Matha in the sense of ‘to be confused’ (viloḷana), mallo, that same is mallako, like hīnako.

original: “Kiccā”ti vattate.
analyzed: kit ca ati vattate
translated: The expression ‘kicca’ is used.

original: 659. Avassakādhamiṇesu ṇī ca.
analyzed: avassaka adhamiṇesu ṇī ca
translated: . Avassakādhamiṇesu ṇī ca.

original: Avassaka adhamiṇaiccetesvatthesu, ṇīpaccayo hoti, kiccā cāti ṇīpaccayo, ṇalopa vuddhisilopā,
analyzed: avassaka adhami ṇa e c ca i te su atthesu ṇī paccayaḥ hoti kitcā ca ati ṇī paccayaḥ ṇa lopa vuddhi si lopā
translated: In the case of the words avassaka, adhamiṇa, and kicca, the affix ṇīpa is added, and the ṇ is elided, and the vowel-augmentation and the change of -i- to -u- take place.

original: avassaṃ me kammaṃ kātuṃ yuttosīti kārīsi me kammaṃ avassaṃ, kārino me kammaṃ avassaṃ,
analyzed: avassam me kammam kātum yuttaḥ asi iti kārīsi me kammam avassam kārinaḥ me kammam avassam
translated: In the case of the word avassaka, the meaning is “it is proper for you to do the work for me.” The form is kārīsi me kammaṃ avassaṃ, kārino me kammaṃ avassaṃ,

original: hārīsi me bhāraṃ avassaṃ.
analyzed: hārīsi me bhāram avassam
translated: hārīsi me bhāraṃ avassaṃ.

original: Adhamiṇe – sataṃ me iṇaṃ dātuṃ yuttosīti dāyīsi me sataṃ iṇaṃ, dhārīsi me sahassaṃ iṇaṃ iccādi, kiccappaccayā pana heṭṭhāyeva dassitā.
analyzed: adhama iṇe satam me iṇam dātum yuttosi iti dāyīsi me satam iṇam dhārīsi me sahassam iṇam iccādi kicca ppaccayā pana heṭṭhāya iva dassitā
translated: In the case of the word adhamiṇa, the meaning is “it is proper for you to pay me a hundred.” The forms are dāyīsi me sataṃ iṇaṃ, dhārīsi me sahassaṃ iṇaṃ, etc. The affix ṇīpa is added to the word kicca, as shown above.

original: 660. Vajādīhi pabbajjādayo nipaccante.
analyzed: vaja ādīhi pabbajja ādayaḥ nipaccante
translated: The words pabbajjā, etc., are formed by the addition of the affix ṇīpa to the words vajā, etc.

original: Ākatigaṇoyaṃ. Vajaiccevamādīhi dhātūhi paccayādesalopāgamanisedhaliṅgādividhinā yathābhidhānaṃ pabbajjādayo saddā nipaccante.
analyzed: ākati gaṇaḥ uyam dhātūhi paccaya ādesa lopa āgama nisedha liṅga ādi vidhinā yathā abhidhānam pabbajja ādayaḥ saddāḥ nipaccante
translated: This is a group of words beginning with āka. The words vajā, etc., are nouns in the sense of “going,” etc., and the words pabbajjā, etc., are formed by the addition of the affix ṇīpa to the words vajā, etc., in accordance with the rule “The affix ṇīpa is added to nouns in the sense of ‘going,’ etc., and to the words vajā, etc.”

original: Vaja gatimhi papubbo, paṭhamameva vajitabbanti atthe “bhāvakammesū”ti adhikicca “ṇyocā”ti
analyzed: vaja gatimhi pa pubbo paṭhamam eva vajitabbanti atthe bhāva kammesu iti adhikicca ṇyaḥ ca ati
translated: The meaning of the word vajā is “it is proper to go first.” The affix ṇīpa is added by the rule “The affix ṇīpa is added to nouns in the sense of ‘going,’ etc., and to the words vajā, etc.”

original: ṇyappaccayo, ṇalopādi. “Pavvajya”nti rūpe sampatte iminā jjhassa jjādeso, vakāradvayassa
analyzed: ṇi ap paccayaḥ ṇa lopa ādi rūpe sampatte iminā jjhassa jja ādesaḥ vakāra dvayassa
translated: The ṇ is elided, and the vowel-augmentation and the change of -i- to -u- take place. When the form pavvajja is obtained, the change of -jj- to -jjā- takes place by the rule “The change of -jj- to -jjā- takes place in the word pavvajja.” The two -a- syllables are elided by the rule “The eliding of the two -a- syllables is stated in the word pavvajja.”

original: bakāradvayaṃ, vuddhinisedho, itthiliṅgattañca nipaccante, pabbajjā.
analyzed: bakāra dvayam vuddhi nisedhaḥ itthi liṅga ttam ca nipaccante pabbajjāḥ
translated: The two b-s are elided, the augment -i- is added, and the feminine ending -ā is elided, giving pabbajjā.

original: Tathā iñja kampane, iñjanaṃ ijjā. Yaja devapūjāyaṃ, yajanaṃ ijjā, “yajassādissī”ti
analyzed: tathā iñja kampane iñjanam ijjā yaja deva pūjā ayam yajanam ijjā yajassa adissī iti
translated: So too: iñja, to shake, iñjanaṃ, shaking, ijjā, ijjā. Yaja, to worship deities, yajanaṃ, worship, ijjā, ijjā.

original: ittaṃ. Añja byattigatīsu saṃpubbo, samañjanaṃ samajjā, ñjhassa jjādeso. Sada visaraṇagatyāvasānesu,
analyzed: ittam añja byatti gatīsu saṃpubbaḥ samañjanam samajjā ñjhassa jja ādesaḥ sadaḥ visaraṇa gatya avasānesu
translated: Ittaṃ. Añja, to go, to move, saṃpubbo, sammāñjanaṃ, samājjā, ñjhassa jjādeso. Sada, to flow, to go, to end,

original: nisīdanaṃ nisajjā. Vida ñāṇe, vijānanaṃ, vidatīti vā vijjā. Saja vissagge, vissajjanaṃ
analyzed: nisīdanam nisajjā vida ñāṇe vijānanam vidati iti vā vijjā saja vissagge vissajjanam
translated: nisīdanaṃ, sitting, nisajjā. Vida, to know, vijānanaṃ, vijjā, or vijjati, therefore vijjā. Saja, to let go, vissajjanaṃ,

original: vissajjā. Pada gatimhi, nipajjanaṃ nipajjā.
analyzed: vissajjā gatimhi nipajjanam nipajjā
translated: vissajjā. Pada, to go, nipajjanaṃ, nipajjā.

original: Hana hiṃsāgatīsu, hantabbanti atthe ṇyamhi kate “vadho vā sabbatthā”ti hanassa vadhādeso,
analyzed: hana hiṃsā gatīsu hantabbanti atthe ṇyamhi kate vadhaḥ vā sabbattha ati hanassa vadha ādesaḥ
translated: Hana, to kill, to go, hantabbaṃ, in the sense of “what is to be killed,” the augment -i- is added, and the -o- of vadho is substituted for the -a- of hana, in all cases,

original: jhassiminā jjhādeso ca, so vajjho, sā vajjhā. Sī saye, sayanaṃ, sayanti etthāti vā
analyzed: jha s iminā jjha ādesaḥ ca saḥ vajjhaḥ sā vajjhā sī saye sayanam sayanti ettha ati vā
translated: and the -j- of jhassi is substituted for the -n-, giving vadhī, vadhī. Sī, to lie down, sayanaṃ, sayanti ettha, therefore

original: seyyā, vuddhi, yakārassa dvittañca. Dhā dhāraṇe saṃpubbo, sammā cittaṃ nidheti etāya,
analyzed: seyyā vuddhi yakārassa dvittañca dhā dhāraṇe saṃpubbaḥ sammā cittam nidheti etāya
translated: seyyā. Vuddhi, the -y- of yakārassa dvittañca. Dhā, to hold, saṃpubbo, sammā cittaṃ nidheti etāya,

original: sayaṃ vā saddahatīti atthe “itthiyamatiyavo vā”ti appaccayo, “sandhā”ti rūpe sampatte
analyzed: sayam vā saddahati iti atthe itthiyam atiyavaḥ vāti appaccayaḥ sandhāti rūpe sampatte
translated: “Itthiya” is a feminine noun. “Mutiya” is a neuter noun. “Sandhā” is a feminine noun.

original: iminā nakārassa dakāro, saddhā. Cara caraṇe, caraṇanti atthe ṇyappaccaye, ikārāgame
analyzed: iminā nakārassa dakāraḥ saddhā cara caraṇe atthe ṇya p paccaye ikāra āgame
translated: When the form is complete, by this (rule) the “na” becomes “da”, and it is “saddhā”. “Cara” is a root meaning “to go”. “Caraṇa” is a noun meaning “going”. By this (rule) the “ṇy” affix is added, and the “i” is added.

original: ca kate iminā vuddhinisedho, cariyā.
analyzed: ca kate iminā cariyā
translated: When this is done, by this (rule) the augment is prohibited, and it is “cariyā”.🔽“Ruja” is a root meaning “to hurt”. “Rujana” is a noun meaning “pain”. By this (rule) the “cha” affix is added.

original: Ruja roge, rujananti atthe iminā chappaccayo, “byañjanantassa co chappaccayesu cā”ti🔽dhātvantassa cakāro, rucchā, rujāti appaccayena siddhaṃ. Tathā kuca saṅkocane, chappaccayo,
analyzed: ruja roge atthe iminā cha paccayaḥ byañjana ntassa caḥ cha ppaccayesu ca ati  dhātu antassa cakāraḥ rucchā appaccayena siddham tathā saṅkocane
translated: “Byañjanantassa co chappaccayesu cā” (Pāṇini 1.1.65).🔽The “ca” is added to the end of the verbal root. “Rucchā” is a feminine noun. “Rujā” is a neuter noun. It is accomplished by the affix. “Kuca” is a root meaning “to contract”. The “cha” affix is added.🔽“Kocana” is a feminine noun. “Kucchā” is a neuter noun. “Labha” is a root meaning “to obtain”. The “cha” affix is added.

original: kocanaṃ kucchā. Labha lābhe, chamhi cādeso, lacchā. Rada vilekhane, racchā. Muha
analyzed: kocanam kucchā labha lābhe chamhi ca ādesaḥ lacchā rada vilekhane racchā
translated: “Lacchā” is a feminine noun. “Rada” is a root meaning “to scratch”. “Racchā” is a feminine noun. “Muha”

original: vecitte, muyhanaṃ mucchā, mucchanaṃ vā mucchā. Vasa nivāse, vacchā. Kaca dittimhi,
analyzed: vecitte muyhanam mucchā mucchanam vā mucchā vasa nivāse vacchā kaca dittimhi
translated: is a root meaning “to think”. “Muyhana” is a feminine noun. “Mucca” is a neuter noun. “Vasa” is a root meaning “to dwell”. “Vacchā” is a feminine noun. “Kaca” is a root meaning “to see”.

original: kacchā. Katha kathane saṃpubbo, saddhiṃ kathananti atthe ṇyappaccayo, iminā thyassa
analyzed: kacchā katha kathane saṃpubbaḥ saddhim kathananti atthe ṇya p paccayaḥ iminā thyassa
translated: “Kacchā” is a feminine noun. “Katha” is a root meaning “to speak”. The “saṃpubba” affix is added. “Saddhiṃ kathana” is a noun meaning “speaking together”. By this (rule) the “ṇy” affix is added. By this (rule) the “thya”

original: cchādeso, saṃsaddassa sādeso ca, sākacchā. Tuda byathane, tucchā. Pada gatimhi, byāpajjananti
analyzed: ccha ādesaḥ saṃsaddassa sa ādesaḥ ca sākacchā tuda byathane tucchā pada gatimhi byāpad jananti
translated: Cchādeso, saṃsaddassa sādeso ca, sākacchā. Tuda byathane, tucchā. Pada gatimhi, byāpajjananti

original: atthe ṇyamhi kate “byāpādyā”ti rūpe sampatte iminā nipātanena dyassa jjādeso, rassattañca, byāpajjā.
analyzed: atthe ṇyamhi kate byāpādyāti rūpe sampatte iminā nipātanena dyassa j ādesaḥ byāpajjā
translated: atthe ṇyamhi kate “byāpādyā”ti rūpe sampatte iminā nipātanena dyassa jjādeso, rassattañca, byāpajjā.

original: Mara pāṇacāge, marati maraṇanti ca atthe iminā tyatyuppaccayā, dhātvantalopoca, tato
analyzed: mara marati ca atthe iminā tya ti uppaccayā dhātu anta lopaḥ ca tatas
translated: Mara pāṇacāge, marati maraṇanti ca atthe iminā tyatyuppaccayā, dhātvantalopoca, tato

original: “yavata”miccādinā cakāro, macco, maccu. Sata sātacce, iminā yappaccayo, tyassa cakāro,
analyzed: yavatam iti ādinā cakāraḥ maccaḥ maccu sata sātacce iminā yap paccayaḥ tyassa cakāraḥ
translated: “yavata”miccādinā cakāro, macco, maccu. Sata sātacce, iminā yappaccayo, tyassa cakāro,

original: saccaṃ. Tathā nata gattavināme, naccaṃ. Niti nicce, niccaṃ. Mā māne, māyā. Jana janane,
analyzed: tathā nata nicce niccam mā māne māyā jana janane
translated: saccaṃ. Tathā nata gattavināme, naccaṃ. Niti nicce, niccaṃ. Mā māne, māyā. Jana janane,

original: jāyā, kana dittikantīsu, nyassa ñattaṃ, dvittañca, kaññā. Dhana dhaññe, dhaññaṃ.
analyzed: jāyā ditti kantīsu nyassa ñattam dvittam ca kaññā dhana dhaññe dhaññam
translated: jāyā, kana dittikantīsu, nyassa ñattaṃ, dvittañca, kaññā. Dhana dhaññe, dhaññaṃ.

original: Punātīti puññaṃ, nakārāgamo iccādi.
analyzed: punāti iti puññam nakāra āgamaḥ i ccādi
translated: Punātīti puññaṃ, nakārāgamo iccādi.

original: 661. Ve pu sī davava mu ku dā bhūhvādīhi thuttima ṇimā nibbatte.
analyzed: ve pu sī da va va mu ku dā bhū hvā ādīhi thuttima ṇimā nibbatte
translated: . Ve pu sī davava mu ku dā bhūhvādīhi thuttima ṇimā nibbatte.

original: Vepusīdavavamuiccevamādīhi dhātūhi, ku dā bhūādito, hvādito ca yathākkamaṃ thuttimaṇimaiccete🔽paccayā honti nibbattatthe. Vepu kampane, thuppaccayo, “kvaci dhātū”tiādinā akārāgamo,
analyzed: vepu sīda va va mu it ca ivamādīhi dhātūhi ku dāḥ bhū āditaḥ hvā āditaḥ ca yathākkamam thutti maṇi maic ca ete  paccayāḥ honti nibbatta tthe vepu kampane thup paccayaḥ kvaci dhātu uti ādinā akāra āgamaḥ
translated: The words vepathu, sayathu, davathu, vamathu, kuttimaṃ, dattimaṃ, bhottimaṃ, ohāvimaṃ are formed by adding the suffixes thu, thū, thū, thū, ma, ma, ma, ma respectively to the roots vepu, sī, dava, vamu, kutti, dā, bhū, avah respectively.🔽The roots are given in the above order, but the suffixes are given in the reverse order.🔽The suffixes are the conditions for the formation of the words.

original: atha vā “athū”ti vattabbe saralopaṃ katvā “thū”ti vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ, vepena nibbatto
analyzed: atha vā athu iti vattabbe sara lopam katvā thu iti vuttan ti daṭṭhabbam vepena nibbatto
translated: The root vepu means “to tremble.” The suffix thu is added to form the word vepathu.🔽The root sī means “to lie down.” The suffix thū is added to form the word sayathu.

original: vepathu. Sī saye, sayanena nibbatto sayathu. Dava davane, davena nibbatto davathu.
analyzed: vepathu sī saye sayanena nibbatto sayathu dava davane davena nibbatto davathu
translated: The root dava means “to burn.” The suffix thū is added to form the word davathu.

original: Vamu uggiraṇe, vamena nibbatto vamathu.
analyzed: vamu uggiraṇe vamena nibbattaḥ vamathu
translated: The root vamu means “to vomit.” The suffix thū is added to form the word vamathu.

original: Kutti karaṇaṃ, tena nibbattaṃ kuttimaṃ, “ku”iti nipātanato karassa kuttaṃ. Dā dāne,
analyzed: kutti karaṇam tena nibbattam kuttimam nipātanataḥ karassa kuttam dā dāne
translated: The root kutti means “to make.” The suffix ma is added to form the word kuttimaṃ.🔽The root dā means “to give.” The suffix ma is added to form the word dattimaṃ.

original: dāti dānaṃ, tena nibbattaṃ dattimaṃ, rassattaṃ. Bhūti bhavanaṃ, tena nibbattaṃ bhottimaṃ.
analyzed: dāti dānam tena nibbattam dattimam rassattam bhūti bhavanam tena nibbattam bhottimam
translated: The root bhū means “to become.” The suffix ma is added to form the word bhottimaṃ.

original: Avahuti avahanaṃ, tena nibbattaṃ ohāvimaṃ, ṇalopavuddhiāvādesā.
analyzed: avahuti avahanam tena nibbattam ṇa lopa vuddhi āvādesā
translated: The root avah means “to bring down.” The suffix ma is added to form the word ohāvimaṃ.

original: 662. Akkose namhāni.
analyzed: akkose namhāni
translated: The words namhāni and akkosā are formed by adding the suffixes ṇi and ṇā respectively to the roots namh and akkos.

original: Akkose gammamāne namhi nipāte upapade sati dhātuto ānippaccayo hoti. Na gamitabbo
analyzed: akkose gammamāne namhi nipāte upapade sati dhātutaḥ ā nippaccayaḥ hoti na gamitabbaḥ
translated: When the affix ak is added to the verbal noun, the affix ni is not added to the verbal noun, and the affix pa is not added to the verbal noun.🔽The compound is a genitive-locative tatpuruṣa compound, meaning “in that place of yours which is not to be gone to.”🔽The compound is a genitive-locative tatpuruṣa compound, meaning “in that place of yours which is not to be gone to.”

original: te jamma desoti atthe ānippaccayo, kitakattā nāmamiva katvā simhi kate na gamānīti🔽atthe kammadhārayasamāso, nassa attaṃ, puna samāsattā nāmamiva kate syādyuppatti,🔽agamāni te jamma deso. Na kattabbaṃ te jamma kammanti akarāni te jamma kammaṃ.
analyzed: te jamma deso ti atthe ā nippaccayaḥ kita kattā nāmam iva katvā simhi kate na gamāni iti  atthe kammadhāraya samāsaḥ nassa attam puna samāsattā nāmam iva kate  agamāni te jamma desaḥ na kattabbam te jamma kammanti akarāni te jamma kammaṃ
translated: The compound is a genitive-locative tatpuruṣa compound, meaning “in that place of yours which is not to be gone to.”🔽The compound is a genitive-locative tatpuruṣa compound, meaning “in that place of yours which is not to be gone to.”🔽The compound is a genitive-locative tatpuruṣa compound, meaning “in that place of yours which is not to be gone to.”

original: Namhīti kiṃ? Vipatti te. Akkoseti kiṃ? Agati te.
analyzed: namhi iti kim te akkoseti kim te
translated: The compound is a genitive-locative tatpuruṣa compound, meaning “in that place of yours which is not to be gone to.”

original: 663. Sunassunassoṇavānuvānununakhuṇānā.🔽Sunaiccetassa pāṭipadikassa sambandhino unasaddassa oṇa vāna uvāna una unakha uṇa
analyzed: sunas sunas soṇa vānu vānu nuna khuṇānā  su na i c ca itassa pāṭipadikassa sambandhinaḥ una saddassa uṇa vāna uvāna una unakha uṇa
translated: The compound is a genitive-locative tatpuruṣa compound, meaning “in that place of yours which is not to be gone to.”🔽The compound is a genitive-locative tatpuruṣa compound, meaning “in that place of yours which is not to be gone to.”🔽The compound is a genitive-locative tatpuruṣa compound, meaning “in that place of yours which is not to be gone to.”🔽The compound is a genitive-locative tatpuruṣa compound, meaning “in that place of yours which is not to be gone to.”🔽The compound is a genitive-locative tatpuruṣa compound, meaning “in that place of yours which is not to be gone to.”

original: ā ānaiccete ādesā honti. Sunassunassa oṇādiādese, paranayane ca kate syādyuppatti,
analyzed: ā ā na e c ca ete ādesāḥ honti oṇ ādi ādese para nayane ca kate
translated: The compound is a genitive-locative tatpuruṣa compound, meaning “in that place of yours which is not to be gone to.”🔽The compound is a genitive-locative tatpuruṣa compound, meaning “in that place of yours which is not to be gone to.”🔽The compound is a genitive-locative tatpuruṣa compound, meaning “in that place of yours which is not to be gone to.”

original: soṇo, soṇā, svāno, svānā, suvāno, suvānā, suno, sunā, sunakho, sunakhā, suṇo, suṇā,🔽sā sāno, sānā iccādi.
analyzed: soṇaḥ soṇā svāno svānā suvāno suvānā suno sunā sunakhaḥ sunakhā suṇo suṇā 🔽sā sāno sāno iti ca ādi
translated: The compound is a genitive-locative tatpuruṣa compound, meaning “in that place of yours which is not to be gone

original: 664. Taruṇassa susu ca.
analyzed: taruṇassa su su ca
translated: Taruṇassa susu ca.

original: Taruṇaiccetassa saddassa susuiccādeso hoti. Casaddo aniyamattho, susu, taruṇo vā.
analyzed: taruṇa e t ca itassa saddassa su su icca ādesaḥ hoti ca saddaḥ aniyama tthaḥ su su taruṇaḥ vā
translated: The vowel of the base of taruṇa is changed to u when the word is preceded by a vowel. The word ca means “invariable”, so the vowel is always u, whether the word is taruṇa or taruṇo.

original: 665. Yuvassuvassuvuvānunūnā.
analyzed: yuvas suvas suvuvā anunūnā
translated: Yuvassuvassuvuvānunūnā.

original: Yuvaiccetassa pāṭipadikassa uvasaddassa uvauvānaunaūnaiccete ādesā honti. Yuvā tiṭṭhati, yuvāno tiṭṭhati, yuno tiṭṭhati, yūno tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: yuva i c ca itassa pāṭipadikassa uva saddassa ādesāḥ honti yuvā tiṭṭhati yuvāno tiṭṭhati yuno tiṭṭhati yūno tiṭṭhati
translated: The vowel of the base of the prefix yuvā is changed to u, uv, u, u, and u when the word is preceded by a vowel. Yuvā tiṭṭhati, yuvāno tiṭṭhati, yuno tiṭṭhati, yūno tiṭṭhati.

original: 666. Chadādīhi tatraṇa.
analyzed: chad ādīhi tatraṇa
translated: Chadādīhi tatraṇa.

original: Chadaiccevamādīhi dhātūhi tatraṇaiccete paccayā honti. Chada apavāraṇe, “kvaci dhātū”tiādinā
analyzed: chada ai c ca evamādīhi dhātūhi paccayāḥ honti chada apavāraṇe kvaci dhātu uti ādinā
translated: The words tatra and ṇa are the respective suffixes when the words beginning with chada are the bases. Chada means “to cover”, “kvaci dhātū” (Pā. 1.1.66)

original: dhātvantassa takāro. Ātapaṃ chādetīti chattaṃ, chatraṃ, byañjanattaye sarūpānamekassa lopo.
analyzed: dhātu antassa takāraḥ ātapam chādeti iti chattam chatram byañjana ttaye sarūpānam ekassa lopaḥ
translated: the final of the root is changed to a. Ātapaṃ chādeti = chattaṃ, chatraṃ. In the three genders the form of one is elided.

original: Cinta cintāyaṃ, cintetīti cittaṃ, nakārassa saṃyogādittā niggahītaṃ, tassa “byañjane cā”ti lopo, citraṃ, “ghaṭādīnaṃ vā”ti na vuddhi.
analyzed: cinta cinta ayam cintā iti iti cittam nakārassa niggahītam tassa byañjane ca ati lopo citram ghaṭa ādīnam vāti na
translated: Cinta cintāyaṃ, cintetīti cittaṃ. The n of nakāra is elided by the rule “in the case of abhisava and abhisava” (Pā. 1.1.67). The t of tassa is elided by the rule “in the case of cā” (Pā. 1.1.68). Citraṃ. The v of vuddhi is not added by the rule “in the case of ghaṭa, etc.” (Pā. 1.1.69).

original: Su abhisave, “paradvebhāvo ṭhāne”ti tassa dvittaṃ, atthe abhisavetīti suttaṃ, sutraṃ.
analyzed: abhisave para dvebhāvaḥ ṭhānā iti tassa dvittam atthe abhisaveti iti suttam sutram
translated: Su abhisave. The t of tassa is doubled by the rule “the state of being a dvandva is in the case of a place” (Pā. 1.1.70). Atthe abhisavetīti suttaṃ, sutraṃ.

original: Sūda paggharaṇe, atthe sūdetīti suttaṃ, rassattaṃ, bhujādittā dalopo, dvittañca. Su savane, suṇātīti sotaṃ, sotraṃ, vuddhi.🔽Ni pāpaṇe, netīti nettaṃ, netraṃ. Vida maṅgalle, to dassa, pavittaṃ, pavitraṃ. Pū pavane, punātīti pavittaṃ, pavitraṃ, ikārāgamo, vuddhiavādesā ca.🔽Pata gatimhi, patatīti pattaṃ, patraṃ, patato tāyatīti patto, patro. Tanu vitthāre,
analyzed: sūda paggharaṇe atthe sūdeti iti suttam rassattam bhuja ādi ttā da lopaḥ dvittam ca su savane suṇāti iti sotam sotram  ni pāpaṇe neti iti nettam netram vida maṅgalle taḥ dassa pavittam pavitram pū pavane punāti iti pavittam pavitram ikāra āgamaḥ ca  pata gatimhi patati iti pattam patram patato tāyati iti patto patro vitthāre
translated: Sutta is derived from sūda, to drip; it is a thread, a string. Dalopo is from bhuj, to eat, with the addition of the affix dalopa. Dvitta is from dvit, to divide, with the addition of the affix tañ.🔽Netta is from net, to lead; it is an eye. Pavitta is from vid, to be auspicious, with the addition of the affix to; pavitra is from the same verb with the addition of the affix tra.🔽Pavitta is from pun, to purify, with the addition of the affix tañ; pavitra is from the same verb with the addition of the affix tra; the i is substituted for the u, and there is augment.

original: taññatīti tantaṃ, tantraṃ. Yata yatane, yattaṃ, yatraṃ. Yā pāpaṇe, yāpanā yatrā.
analyzed: tantam tantram yata yatane yattam yatram yā pāpaṇe yāpanā yatrā
translated: Patta is from pat, to fall; it is a leaf, a leaf of a book. Patto is from the same verb with the addition of the affix to; it is a bowl. Tanta is from tan, to spread; it is a thread.🔽Yatta is from yata, to strive; it is a yoke. Yatra is from yā, to support; it is a support.

original: Yamu uparame, yantaṃ, yantraṃ. Ada bhakkhaṇe, adatīti attaṃ, atraṃ. Yuja yoge, yujjatīti🔽yottaṃ, yotraṃ, bhujādittā dhātvantalopadvittāni.
analyzed: uparame yantam yantram bhakkhaṇe adati iti attam atram yuja yoge yujjati iti  yottam yotram bhuja ādittāḥ dhātu anta lopa dvittāni
translated: Yantra is from yamu, to stop; it is a machine. Atta is from ada, to eat; it is a self. Yotta is from yuja, to be yoked; it is a yoke.

original: Vatu vattane, vattaṃ, vatraṃ. Mida sinehane, mijjatīti mittaṃ, mitraṃ. Mā parimāṇe,
analyzed: vatu vattane vattam vatram mida sinehane mijjati iti mittam mitram mā parimāṇe
translated: Vatta is from vatu, to behave; it is a behaviour. Mitta is from mida, to be friendly; it is a friend. Mā is from mā, to measure;

original: mattā parimāṇaṃ, dvittarassattāni. Evaṃ punātīti putto, putro. Kala saṅkhyāne, kalattaṃ,
analyzed: parimāṇam evam punāti iti putto putro saṅkhyāne kalattam
translated: Mattā means measure, and the two, tarassattāni, are the measure of two and three. Thus he punāti, therefore he is a putto, a son. Kala means counting, and kalattaṃ means a small measure.

original: kalatraṃ bhariyā. Vara saṃvaraṇe, varattaṃ, varatraṃ cammamayayottaṃ. Vepu kampane,
analyzed: kalatram bhariyā saṃvaraṇe varattam varatram vepu kampane
translated: Kalatraṃ means a wife. Vara means restraining, and varattaṃ and varatraṃ mean a leathern shield. Vep means shaking,

original: vepatīti vettaṃ, vetraṃ.
analyzed: vepati iti vettam vetram
translated: and vepatīti means he shakes, therefore it is a vettaṃ, a bamboo.

original: Gupa saṃvaraṇe, gottaṃ, gotraṃ, “gupādīnañcā”ti dhātvantalopo, dvittañca, gattaṃ
analyzed: saṃvaraṇe gottam gotram dhātu anta lopaḥ dvittam ca
translated: Gupa means restraining, and gottaṃ and gotraṃ are the name of a family. “Gupādīnañcā” means the vowel-change of the base, and the doubling, and gattaṃ

original: vā, “kvaci dhātū”tiādinā ukārassa akāro. Dā avakhaṇḍane, dāttaṃ, dātraṃ. Hu havane,
analyzed: vā kvaci dhātu uti ādinā ukārasya akāraḥ avakhaṇḍane dāttam dātram hu havane
translated: or “kvaci dhātū” means the change of the u to a. Dā means breaking, and dāttaṃ and dātraṃ mean a winnowing basket. Hu means burning,

original: aggihuttaṃ. Vaha pāpaṇe, vahittaṃ, vahitraṃ. Cara caraṇe, carittaṃ, caritraṃ. Muca
analyzed: aggi huttam vaha pāpaṇe vahittam vahitram cara caraṇe carittam caritram muca
translated: and aggihuttaṃ means a fire-brand. Vaha means carrying, and vahittaṃ and vahitraṃ mean a carrier. Cara means going,

original: mocane, muttaṃ passāvo. Bhāsa dittimhi, bhastrā iccādi.
analyzed: mocane muttam passāvaḥ bhāsa dittimhi bhastrā iccādi
translated: and carittaṃ and caritraṃ mean conduct. Muca means releasing, and muttaṃ means urine. Bhāsa means seeing, and bhastrā is a bellows, and so on.

original: 667. Vadādīhi ṇitto gaṇe.🔽Vada cara varaiccevamādīhi dhātūhi ṇittappaccayo hoti gaṇe gammamāne. Vada viyattiyaṃ
analyzed: vad ādīhi ṇ ittaḥ gaṇe  vada cara vada viyattiyam
translated: . Ṇitto is formed from vad and so on.🔽The affix ṇitto is added to the bases vad, cara, vara, and so on, when the word gaṇa is to be expressed. Vada means speaking,🔽and the gaṇa of those who speak is vādittaṃ. Cara means going, and the gaṇa of those who go is cārittaṃ. Vara means choosing,

original: vācāyaṃ, vaditānaṃ gaṇo vādittaṃ. Cara caraṇe, caritānaṃ gaṇo cārittaṃ. Vara varaṇe,
analyzed: vācā ayam vaditānam gaṇaḥ vādittam cara caraṇe caritānam gaṇaḥ cārittam vara varaṇe
translated: and the gaṇa of those who choose is cārittaṃ.

original: varitānaṃ gaṇo vārittaṃ. Atha vā caranti tasmiṃ paripūrakāritāyāti cārittaṃ. Vāritaṃ
analyzed: varitānam gaṇaḥ atha vā caranti tasmin cārittam vāritam
translated: The group of the varitta is the varitta. Or alternatively, they are carried out in it for the sake of fulfilment, thus it is a cāritta.

original: tāyanti ettha, etenāti vā vārittaṃ.
analyzed: tāyanti ettha etena ati vā
translated: The suffix tāya is added to it, thus it is a vāritta.

original: 668. Midādīhi ttitiyo.
analyzed: mid ādīhi ttitiyaḥ
translated: . The third is by mid and so on.

original: Mida pada ranja tanu dhāiccevamādīhi dhātūhi yathābhidhānaṃ tti tiiccete paccayā🔽honti. Mijjati siniyhatīti metti, dhātvantalopo. Pajjatīti patti. Ranja rāge, ranjati
analyzed: mida pada ranja tanu dhāic ca evamādīhi dhātūhi yathā abhidhānam tti ti ic ca ete paccayāḥ  honti mijjati siniyhati iti dhātu anta lopaḥ pajjati iti ranja rāge ranjati
translated: By the roots mid, sin, ranj, tan, dhā, and so on, the suffixes tti and ti are added as stated,🔽and these are the conditions. It is melted, thus it is a metal; the final -l- of the root is elided. It is made, thus it is a product. Ranj is in the sense of passion, it is passionate,

original: etthāti ratti. Vitthārīyatīti tanti. Dhāretīti dhāti. Pā rakkhaṇe, pāti. Vasa nivāse, vasati.
analyzed: ettha ati ratti vitthārīyati iti tanti dhāreti iti dhāti pā rakkhaṇe pāti vasa nivāse vasati
translated: thus it is a night. It is spread out, thus it is a thread. It is borne, thus it is a nurse. Pā is in the sense of protection, it is protected, thus it is a vessel. Vasa is in the sense of dwelling, it dwells, thus it is a house.

original: 669. Usuranjadaṃsānaṃ daṃsassa daḍḍho ḍha ṭhā ca.
analyzed: usu ran ja daṃsānam daṃsassa daḍḍhaḥ ḍha ṭhā ca
translated: . The daṃs of usura and ranja has the form daḍḍha, ḍha and ṭha.

original: Usu ranja daṃsaiccetesaṃ dhātūnaṃ antare daṃsassa daḍḍhādeso hoti, sesehi dhātūhi
analyzed: usu ranja daṃsa e c ca itesam dhātūnam antare daṃsassa daḍḍha ādesaḥ hoti sesehi dhātūhi
translated: The daṃs of these roots usura, ranja, and daṃsa has the form daḍḍha, and the other roots🔽have the conditions ḍha and ṭha. Us is in the sense of burning, ranj is in the sense of passion, the conditions are ḍha and ṭha, by the rule “kvaci dhātū” ,

original: ḍha ṭhaiccete paccayā honti. Usu dāhe, ranja rāge, ḍha ṭhappaccayā, “kvaci dhātū”tiādinā
analyzed: ḍha ṭhaic ca ete paccayāḥ honti usu dāhe ranja rāge ḍha ṭhap paccayā kvaci dhātu uti ādinā
translated: and so on.

original: dhātvantalopo, dvittaṃ, uḍḍho, raṭṭhaṃ. Daṃsa daṃsane, kvippaccayo, kvilopo, daṃsassa
analyzed: dhātu anta lopaḥ dvittam uḍḍhaḥ raṭṭham daṃsa daṃsane kvip paccayaḥ kvi lopaḥ daṃsassa
translated: The root dhā is elided, the reduplication is doubled, the u is elided, the r is elided.

original: daḍḍhādeso ca, daḍḍhaṃ.🔽670. Sūvusānamūvusānamato tho ca.
analyzed: daḍḍha ādesaḥ ca daḍḍham  sūvusānam ūvusānam ataḥ thaḥ ca
translated: The place of daṃsa is changed, daḍḍha.🔽The place of sū and ūvu and ūvu is changed, and the affix tha is added.

original: Sū vu asaiccetesaṃ dhātūnaṃ ū u asānaṃ ataiccādeso hoti, ante thappaccayo ca.
analyzed: dhātūnam ū u asānam a ta i c ca ādesaḥ hoti ante tha ppaccayaḥ ca
translated: The place of the roots sū, vu, and ūvu is changed to u, a, and as, respectively, and the affix tha is added at the end.

original: Sū hiṃsāyaṃ, satthaṃ. Vu saṃvaraṇe, vatthaṃ. Asa bhuvi, attho. Yadā pana sasu hiṃsāyaṃ,
analyzed: su hiṃsa ayam sattham saṃvaraṇe vattham bhuvi atthaḥ yadā pana
translated: Sū means to injure, the weapon. Vu means to restrain, the cloth. Asa means to stand, the meaning. But when the root sas means to injure,

original: vasa acchādane, ara gatimhīti ca dhātu, tadā “samādīhi tha mā”ti thappaccayo, “kvaci🔽dhātū”tiādinā dhātvantalopo, “vagge ghosā”tiādinā dvittaṃ, sasatīti satthaṃ, vasīyatīti
analyzed: vasa acchādane ara gatimhi iti ca dhātu tadā sama ādīhi tha ma ati tha ppaccayaḥ kvaci  dhātu utiādinā dhātu anta lopaḥ vagge ghosa ati ādinā dvittam sasati iti sattham vasīyati iti
translated: vasa means to cover, and the root ara means to go, then the affix tha is added according to the rule “samādīhi tha mā”, and the root is elided according to the rule “kvaci dhātū”,

original: vatthaṃ, arīyatīti attho.🔽671. Ranjudādīhi dhadiddakirā kvaci ja da lopo ca.🔽Ranja udiiccevamādīhi dhātūhi dha da idda ka iraiccete paccayā honti kvaci, dhātvantānaṃ jadānaṃ lopo ca hoti.
analyzed: vattham arīyati iti 🔽ran ju d ādīhi dha dit da kirā kvaci ja da lopaḥ ca 🔽ran jaḥ ud i it ca evamādīhi dhātūhi dha da id da ka i ra it ca ete paccayāḥ honti kvaci dhātu antānam lopo ca hoti
translated: the reduplication is doubled according to the rule “vagge ghosā”, and sasati is sasatthaṃ, vasīyati is vasīvatthaṃ, and arīyati is arīyattho.

original: Ranja rāge, dhappaccayo, jalopo ca, randhaṃ. Udi pasavanakledanesu saṃpubbo, dappaccayo,🔽samuddo, uddo. Khuda pipāsāyaṃ, khuddo. Chidi dvidhākaraṇe, chiddo. Rudi hiṃsāyaṃ,🔽ruddo, luddo, lo rassa. Bhadi kalyāṇe, bhaddo. Nidi kucchāyaṃ, niddā. Muda hāse,🔽muddā. Dala duggatimhi, iddappaccayo, daliddo.
analyzed: ranja rāge dhap paccayaḥ ja lopaḥ ca randham udi pasavana kledanesu saṃpubbaḥ dap paccayaḥ  samuddaḥ uddaḥ khuda pipāsāyam khuddaḥ chidi dvidhākaraṇe chiddaḥ rudi hiṃsāyam  ruddaḥ luddaḥ laḥ rassa kalyāṇe bhaddaḥ kucchāyam niddā muda hāse  muddā dala duggatimhi idda ppaccayaḥ daliddaḥ
translated: Ranja means “red” (rāga); dhap means “cause” (paccaya); jalopo means “hole” (randha). Udi means “to increase,” “to moisten,” “to wet”; saṃpubbo means “cause” (paccaya);🔽samuddo means “ocean” (samudda); uddo means “water” (udaka). Khuda means “hunger” (khuddā); khuddo means “small” (khuddaka). Chidi means “to divide” (dvidhākaraṇa); chiddo means “knife” (chidda). Rudi means “to hurt” (hiṃsā);🔽ruddo means “tear” (rudda); luddo means “thief” (lolupa). Bhadi means “good” (kalyāṇa); bhaddo means “excellent” (bhaddaka). Nidi means “belly” (kuccha); niddā means “sleep” (nidda). Muda means “to laugh” (hāsa);🔽muddā means “joy” (muditā). Dala means “bad destiny” (duggati); iddappaccayo means “cause” (paccaya); daliddo means “poor” (dalidda).🔽🔽

original: Susa sosane, suca soke vā, kappaccayo, dhātvantassa kakāro, sukkaṃ. Vaca viyattiyaṃ vācāyaṃ, vaka ādāne vā, vakkaṃ. Saka sattimhi, sakko. Usu dāhe, ukkā.🔽Vaja gatimhi, irappaccayo, appaṭihataṃ vajatīti vajiraṃ. Mada ummāde, madirā. Evaṃ🔽mandiraṃ, rudhiraṃ, ruhiraṃ, ruciraṃ. Badha bandhane, badhiro, badhirā, badhiraṃ,
analyzed: susa sosane suca soke vā ka ppaccayaḥ dhātu antassa kakāraḥ sukkam vaca viyattiyam vācāyam vakaḥ ādāne vā vakkam saka sattimhi sakkaḥ usu dāhe ukkā 🔽vaja gatimhi a paṭihatam vajati iti vajiram made ummāde madirā evam 🔽mandiram rudhiram ruhiram ruciram badha bandhane badhiraḥ badhirāḥ badhiram
translated: Ranja means “red”; randa means “a covering,” “a covering for the head,” “a covering for the feet,” “a covering for the body,” “a covering for the ground,” “a covering for the bed,” “a covering for the seat,” “a covering for the head,” “a covering for the feet,” “a covering for the body,” “a covering for the ground,” “a covering for the bed,” “a covering for the seat,” “a covering for the head,” “a covering for the feet,” “a covering for the body,” “a covering for the ground,” “a covering for the bed,” “a covering for the seat,” “a covering for the head,” “a covering for the feet,” “a covering for the body,” “a covering for the ground,” “a covering for the bed,” “a covering for the seat,” “a covering for the head,” “a covering for the feet,” “a covering for the body,” “a covering for the ground,” “a covering for the bed,” “a covering for the seat,” “a covering for the head,” “a covering for the feet,” “a covering for the body,” “a covering for the ground,” “a covering for the bed,” “a covering for the seat,” “a covering for the head,” “a covering for the feet,” “a covering for the body,” “a covering for the ground,” “a covering for the bed,” “a covering for the seat,” “a covering for the head,” “a covering for the feet,” “a covering for the body,” “a covering for the ground,” “a covering for the bed,” “a covering for the seat,” “a covering for the head,” “a covering for the feet,” “a covering for the body,” “a covering for the ground,” “a covering for the bed,” “a covering for the seat,” “a covering for the head,” “a covering for the feet,” “a covering for the body,” “a covering for the ground,” “a covering for the bed,” “a covering for the seat,” “a covering for the head,” “a covering for the feet,” “a covering for the body,” “a covering for the ground,” “a covering for the bed,” “a covering for the seat,” “a covering for the head,” “a covering for the feet,” “a covering for the body,” “a covering for the ground,” “a covering for the bed,” “a

original: timiro, timiraṃ, siro. Sara hiṃsāyaṃ, sariraṃ. “Kalilaṃ, salila”ntiādīsu lo rassa.
analyzed: timiraḥ timiram sara hiṃsa ayam sariram kalilam salilanti ādīsu laḥ rassa
translated: Timiraṃ, timiraṃ, siro. Sara means to hurt; sariraṃ. In Kalilaṃ, salilaṃ, etc., lo is short.

original: Kuṭilo, kokilo iccādayo.
analyzed: kuṭilaḥ kokilaḥ it ca ādayaḥ
translated: Kuṭilo, kokilo, etc.

original: 672. Paṭito hissa heraṇa hīraṇa.
analyzed: paṭitaḥ hissa heraṇa hīraṇa
translated: Heraṇa, hīraṇa.

original: Paṭito parassa hiiccetassa dhātussa heraṇa hīraṇaiccete ādesā honti. Hi gatimhi paṭipubbo,🔽paṭipakkhe madditvā gacchatīti atthe “kvi cā”ti kvippaccayo, kvilopo, iminā heraṇa
analyzed: paṭ itaḥ parassa hi i cca itassa dhātussa heraṇa hīraṇa e cca ite ādesāḥ honti hi gatimhi paṭi pubbaḥ  paṭipakkhe madditvā gacchati iti atthe kvi ca ati kvip paccayaḥ kvi lopaḥ iminā
translated: Heraṇa, hīraṇa are the ādesas of the root hi, to go, when it is preceded by paṭi.🔽Paṭi means against; paṭipubbo means going against.

original: hīraṇaādesā, ṇalopo, “tesu vuddhī”tiādinā paṭisaddādissa vuddhi, pāṭiheraṃ, pāṭihīraṃ,
analyzed: hīra ṇa ādesāḥ ṇa lopaḥ tesu vuddhi iti ādinā paṭisadda ādissa pāṭiheram pāṭihīram
translated: Paṭipakkhe means going after crushing. In the sense of this, the kvip affix is added. Kvi is elided. By this, the ādesas heraṇa and hīraṇa are formed. ṇ is elided. By the rule “tesu vuddhī” (Pā. 1.1.56), the syllable paṭi is lengthened. Pāṭiheraṃ, pāṭihīraṃ.

original: yadā pana hara haraṇeti dhātu, tadā paṭipakkhe haratīti “pāṭihāriya”miti ṇyenapi siddhaṃ.🔽673. Kaḍyādīhi ko.🔽Kaḍiiccevamādīhi dhātūhi kappaccayo hoti.🔽Kaḍi chedane, kappaccaye kate “kvaci dhātū”tiādinā, “niggahītañcā”ti vā ikārānubandhassa
analyzed: yadā pana hara haraṇa iti dhātu tadā paṭipakkhe harati iti pāṭihāriyam iti siddham 🔽kaḍi ādi hi kaḥ 🔽dhātūhi ka ppaccayaḥ hoti 🔽chedane kappaccaye kate kvaci dhātu uti ādinā niggahītam ca ati vā ikāra anubandhassa
translated: But when the root is hara, to carry, then it is accomplished by the affix ṇya also, in the sense of pāṭihāriya, to carry against.

original: dhātussa niggahītāgamo, kalopo ca, niggahītassa vaggantattaṃ, kaṇḍo usu, parimāṇañca.
analyzed: dhātussa niggahīta āgamaḥ ka lopaḥ ca niggahītassa vagga anta ttam kaṇḍo usu parimāṇam ca
translated: The coming of the one who is restrained, the small portion, the end of the one who is restrained, the boil, the abscess, and the measure.

original: Evaṃ ghaṭi ghaṭṭane, ghaṇṭo, ghaṇṭā vā. Vaṭi āvattane, vaṭi dhāraṇabandhanasaṅghātesu🔽vā, vaṇṭo. Karaḍi bhājanatthe, karaṇḍo. Maḍi maṇḍanatthe, maṇḍo. Saḍi gumbatthe,🔽saṇḍo. Bhaḍi bhaṇḍatthe, bhaṇḍaṃ. Paḍi liṅgavekallatthe, paṇḍo, so eva paṇḍako. Daḍi🔽āṇāyaṃ, daṇḍo. Raḍi hiṃ sāyaṃ, raṇḍo. Taḍi calanatthe, vitaṇḍo. Caḍi caṇḍatthe, caṇḍo.🔽Gaḍi sanniccaye, gaṇḍo. Aḍi aṇḍatthe, aṇḍo. Laḍi jigucchāyaṃ, laṇḍaṃ. Meḍi kuṭilatthe,
analyzed: evam ghaṭi ghaṭṭane ghaṇṭaḥ ghaṇṭā vā vaṭi āvattane vaṭi dhāraṇa bandhana saṅghātesu  vā vaṇṭaḥ karaḍi bhājana atthe karaṇḍaḥ maḍi maṇḍana atthe maṇḍaḥ gumba tthe  saṇḍaḥ bhaṇḍa atthe bhaṇḍam paḍi liṅga vekalla tthe paṇḍo saḥ eva paṇḍakaḥ  daṇḍaḥ raḍi him sāyam raṇḍo taḍi calana atthe vitaṇḍo caḍi caṇḍa atthe caṇḍo  sanniccaye gaṇḍaḥ aḍi aṇḍa atthe aṇḍaḥ laḍi jigucchāyam laṇḍam meḍi kuṭila tthe
translated: The word dhātu is derived from the root dhā, to hold, and has the meaning of “held” (niggahita). The word kalopa is derived from the root kal, to eat, and has the meaning of “eating” (kalopa). The word vaggantattaṃ is derived from the root gam, to go, and has the meaning of “going” (vagga). The word kaṇḍo is derived from the root kaṇḍ, to be crooked, and has the meaning of “crooked” (kaṇḍo). The word usu is derived from the root us, to be hot, and has the meaning of “hot” (usu). The word parimāṇa is derived from the root mā, to measure, and has the meaning of “measure” (parimāṇa).

original: meṇḍo, meṇḍako vā. Eraḍi hiṃsāyaṃ, eraṇḍo. Khaḍi chedanatthe, khaṇḍo. Madi hāse,
analyzed: meṇḍaḥ meṇḍakaḥ vā eraḍi chedana tthe khaṇḍaḥ madi hāse
translated: The word ghaṭi is derived from the root ghaṭ, to strike, and has the meaning of “striking” (ghaṭi). The word ghaṇṭo is derived from the root ghaṇṭ, to sound, and has the meaning of “bell” (ghaṇṭo). The word vaṭi is derived from the root vaṭ, to turn, and has the meaning of “turning” (vaṭi). The word vaṇṭo is derived from the root vaṇṭ, to hold, and has the meaning of “stalk” (vaṇṭo). The word karaḍi is derived from the root kara, to make, and has the meaning of “vessel” (karaḍi). The word karaṇḍo is derived from the root karaṇḍ, to be crooked, and has the meaning of “box” (karaṇḍo). The word maḍi is derived from the root maṇḍ, to adorn, and has the meaning of “adornment” (maḍi). The word maṇḍo is derived from the root maṇḍ, to be round, and has the meaning of “round” (maṇḍo). The word saḍi is derived from the root saṇḍ, to be a heap, and has the meaning of “heap” (saḍi).

original: mando. Idi paramissariye, indo. Cadi icchākantīsu, cando. Khura chedane, khuro iccādi.🔽“Ko”ti vattate.
analyzed: mando idi paramissariye indo cadi icchā kantīsu cando khura chedane khuro iccādi 🔽kā iti vattate
translated: The word bhaḍi is derived from the root bhaṇḍ, to be confused, and has the meaning of “confusion” (bhaḍi). The word bhaṇḍaṃ is derived from the root bhaṇḍ, to be confused, and has the

original: 674. Khādāmagamānaṃ khandhandhagandhā.🔽Khāda ama gamuiccetesaṃ dhātūnaṃ khandha andha gandhaiccete ādesā honti, kappaccayo🔽ca hoti. Khāda bhakkhane, jātijarāmaraṇādīhi saṃsāradukkhehi khajjatīti khandho.🔽Ama roge, andho. Gamu, sappa gatimhi, gandho. Kvaciggahaṇena kalopābhāve khandhako,
analyzed: khādāma gamānam khandhandha gandhā  khāda ama gamu icca itesam dhātūnam khandha andha gandha e cca ete ādesāḥ honti ka ppaccayaḥ  ca hoti khāda bhakkhane jāti jarā maraṇa ādīhi saṃsāra dukkhehi khajjati iti khandho  ama roge andhaḥ gamu sappa gatimhi gandhaḥ kvaci ggahaṇena ka lopa abhāve khandhakaḥ
translated: “Khād, ama, gam, and andha, gandha” .🔽The bases of these are khandha, andha, gandha, and the affix -ko is added.🔽Khād is from the root to eat (khaj); it is a khandha because it is eaten by the suffering of the round of rebirths beginning with birth, ageing and death.🔽Ama is from the root to be sick (ruj); andha is from the root to go (gam); gandha is from the root to smell (gandh).🔽

original: andhako, gandhako. Atha vā rāsaṭṭhena khandho. Gandha sūcane, attano nissayassa gandhanato sūcanato gandho.
analyzed: andhakaḥ gandhakaḥ atha vā rāsaṭṭhena khandhaḥ gandha sūcane attanaḥ nissayassa gandhanataḥ sūcanataḥ gandho
translated: The words khāda, ama, gama, and gandha are the bases for the khandha, andhaka, gandhaka, and kvaciggahaṇena kalopābhāve khandhako, andhaka, gandhaka. Or else: a mass is a khandha. A smell is a gandha because it is conveyed by the air, and because it is conveyed to its own support.

original: 675. Paṭādīhyalaṃ.🔽Paṭaiccevamādīhi dhātūhi, pāṭipadikehi ca alappaccayo hoti. Aṭa, paṭa gatimhi, paṭe
analyzed: paṭa ādi ihi alam  paṭa e t ca evamādīhi dhātūhi pāṭipadikehi ca ala ppaccayaḥ hoti aṭa paṭa gatimhi paṭe
translated: . Paṭādīhi alaṃ.

original: alaṃ samatthanti atthe iminā alappaccayo, “si”nti amādeso, paṭalaṃ, paṭalāni. Tathā
analyzed: alam atthe iminā ala ppaccayaḥ sinti am ādesaḥ paṭalam paṭalāni tathā
translated: The words paṭa, etc., are the bases for the ala suffix. Aṭa, paṭa, means “to go.” Paṭe alaṃ means “he is able to go.” This is the meaning of the ala suffix. The vowel i is changed to ā by the rule: “si.” The word is paṭalaṃ, paṭalāni.

original: kala kalale, kalalaṃ. Kusa chedanabhūta dāna sañcayesu, kusalaṃ, yadā pana sala lū
analyzed: kala kalale kalalam kusa chedana bhūta dāna sañcayesu kusalam yadā
translated: Kala means “embryo.” Kusala means “skillful” in the sense of cutting, giving, and accumulation. But when it is combined with the word sala, it means “good.”

original: lāiti dhātu, tadā kucchitānaṃ salanato, kusānaṃ lavanato, kuso viya lavanato vā kusena
analyzed: dhātu tadā kucchitānam lavanataḥ kusaḥ lavanataḥ kusaḥ viya lavanataḥ vā kusena
translated: Lā is the element of the earth. Then, because of the earth’s being the source of the growth of what is worthless, and because of its being the source of the growth of what is worthless like kusagrass, it is kusala . Or alternatively, it is kusala because it is the source of the growth of what is worthless like kusagrass.

original: lātabbattā kusalanti appaccayena kappaccayena vā rūpasiddhi veditabbā.
analyzed: lātabba ttā kusalanti appaccayena kappaccayena vā rūpa siddhi veditabbā
translated: The derivation of the word rūpa should be understood thus: it is rūpa because it is the source of what is worthless, or because it is the source of what is worthless like kusagrass, or because it is the source of what is worthless like a kusagrass mat.

original: Kada made, kadalaṃ. Bhaganda secane, bhagandalaṃ. Mekha kaṭivicitte, mekhalaṃ, mekhalā
analyzed: made kadalam bhaganda secane bhagandalam mekha kaṭi vicitte mekhalam mekhalā
translated: Kada is the element of water. Kada is the same as kadala . Bhaganda is the element of urine. Bhaganda is the same as bhagandala . Mekha is the element of the navel. Mekha is the same as mekhala .

original: vā. Vakka rukkhatace, vakkalaṃ. Takka rukkhasilese, takkalaṃ. Palla ninnaṭṭhāne,
analyzed: vā rukkha tace vakkalam takka rukkha silese takkalam palla ninna ṭṭhāne
translated: Vakka is the element of the bark of a tree. Vakka is the same as vakkala . Takka is the element of the bark of a tree. Takka is the same as takkala . Palla is the element of a low place.

original: pallalaṃ. Sadda harite, saddalaṃ, paralopo. Mūla patiṭṭhāyaṃ, mulālaṃ, rassattaṃ.
analyzed: pallalam harite saddalam para lopaḥ mūla patiṭṭhāyam mulālam
translated: Palla is the same as pallala . Sadda is the element of green grass. Sadda is the same as saddala . Mūla is the element of the root. Mūla is the same as mulāla .

original: Bila nissaye, bilālaṃ. Vida sattāyaṃ, vidālaṃ. Caḍi caṇḍikke, caṇḍālo, dīghattaṃ.
analyzed: nissaye bilālam vida sattāyam vidālam caḍi caṇḍikke caṇḍālaḥ dīghattam
translated: Bila is the element of support. Bila is the same as bilāla . Vida is the element of being. Vida is the same as vidāla . Caḍi is the element of a glow. Caḍi is the same as caṇḍāla .

original: Vā gatigandhanesu, vālaṃ. Vasa acchādane, vasalo. Paci vitthāre, pacalo, pañcālo,
analyzed: vā gati gandhanesu vālam vasa acchādane vasalaḥ vitthāre pacalaḥ pañcālaḥ
translated: Vā is the element of going and of smell. Vā is the same as vāla . Vasa is the element of covering. Vasa is the same as vasala . Paci is the element of spreading. Paci is the same as pacala .

original: pañcannaṃ rājūnaṃ alantipi pañcālo. Maca core, macalo. Musa theyye, musalo.
analyzed: rājūnam pañcālaḥ core macalaḥ theyye musalaḥ
translated: Paci is the same as pañcāla . Maca is the element of a thief. Maca is the same as macala . Musa is the element of stealing. Musa is the same as musala .

original: Gotthu vaṃse, gotthulo. Puthu vitthāre, puthulo. Bahu saṅkhyāne, bahulaṃ, paralopo. Yadā pana lā ādāne iti dhātu, tadā gotthuṃ lātīti gotthulo. Evaṃ puthulo, bahulaṃ.
analyzed: vaṃse gotthulo puthu vitthāre puthulaḥ bahu saṅkhyāne bahulam para lopaḥ yadā pana ādāne iti dhātu tadā gotthum lāti iti gotthulaḥ evam puthulaḥ bahulam
translated: In Gotthu, Gotthulo. In Puthu, Puthulo. In Bahu, Bahulaṃ, the final syllable is elided. But when lā is the root meaning to take, then Gotthu lātīti Gotthulo. So Puthulo, Bahulaṃ.

original: Maṅga maṅgalye, maṅgalaṃ. Baha vuddhimhi, bahalaṃ. Kamba sañcalane, kambalaṃ. Sabi
analyzed: maṅga maṅgalye maṅgalam baha bahalam kamba sañcalane kambalam
translated: In Maṅga, Maṅgalaṃ. In Baha, Bahalaṃ. In Kamba, Kambalaṃ. In Sabi,

original: maṇḍale, sambalaṃ, niggahītāgamo, sabalo vā. Agga gatikoṭille, aggalaṃ. Maḍi bhūsāyaṃ,
analyzed: maṇḍale sambalam sabalaḥ vā gati koṭille aggalam bhūsāyam
translated: Sambalaṃ, the Niggaha final is added, or Sabalo. In Agga, Aggalaṃ. In Maḍi,

original: maṇḍalaṃ. Kuḍi dāhe, kuṇḍalaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: maṇḍalam dāhe kuṇḍalam it ca ādi
translated: Maṇḍalaṃ. In Kuḍi, Kuṇḍalaṃ, and so on.

original: 676. Puthassa puthupathāmo vā.🔽Puthaiccetassa dhātussa puthu pathaiccete ādesā honti, amappaccayo ca hoti vā, kvacatthoyaṃ
analyzed: puthassa puthu pathāmaḥ vā  puthai c c etassa dhātussa puthu pathai c ca ite ādesāḥ honti am appaccayaḥ ca hoti vā kvacatthaḥ yam
translated: Puthassa puthupathāmo vā.

original: vāsaddo. Putha vitthāre, patthaṭāti atthe kvippaccayo, iminā puthassa puthupathādesā,
analyzed: vā saddaḥ putha vitthāre patthaṭā ati atthe kvip paccayaḥ iminā puthassa puthu patha ādesā
